title: Where Paella Meets Plantains
description: La Parrilla has a Spanish accent that encompasses both the Old World and the New. This Port Jefferson newcomer, which opened in late March, took over the building that housed the Spanish restaurant Costa de Espaa for many years. The owner of La Parrilla, Vin Grillo, a first-time restaurateur, said his menu was a combination of Spanish and Latin American food.

title: The Kids Are Not Happy About Dads New Friend
description: Psychological verisimilitude: If that were all it took to make a powerful movie about family strife and impending mortality, the German filmmaker Sandra Nettelbecks Last Love would join Michael Hanekes Amour on the short list of touching late-life dramas.

title: Outdistancing Suicide, Papas Family Curse
description: The up-close-and-personal promise of cinma vrit in the 1960s could be exploited in a number of ways. Some documentaries explored ordinary life as a subject (Salesman, High School), but just as often they orbited stars (Bob Dylan in Dont Look Back, John F. Kennedy in Primary). The career of the award-winning filmmaker Barbara Kopple has intriguingly spanned this spectrum, as she has both risked her life to chronicle a miners strike in the 1976 stone-cold classic, Harlan County, U.S.A., and watched Woody Allen quip about hotel laundry service in Wild Man Blues (1998).

title: Federal Review Opened in Georgia Death
description: ATLANTA  The United States Department of Justice said Thursday that it had opened a formal review of the death of a 17-year-old boy found in a rolled-up wrestling mat at his Georgia high school in January.

title: A War on the Poor
description: John Kasich, the Republican governor of Ohio, has done some surprising things lately. First, he did an end run around his states Legislature  controlled by his own party  to proceed with the federally funded expansion of Medicaid that is an important piece of Obamacare. Then, defending his action, he let loose on his political allies, declaring, Im concerned about the fact there seems to be a war on the poor. That, if youre poor, somehow youre shiftless and lazy.

title: Judge Invalidates Patent for a Down Syndrome Test
description: A federal judge has invalidated the central patent underlying a noninvasive method of detecting Down syndrome in fetuses without the risk of inducing a miscarriage.

title: Rethinking the Main Course
description: Some animated films, like My Neighbor Totoro, seem nonsensical because they replicate the strange logic of a childs imagination. Others make little sense because the concept is inane, and the execution is manic and unoriginal. Free Birds, the new cartoon about time-traveling turkeys, is the second kind.

title: The Ode Heard Round the World
description: With the release last spring of a phenomenally popular iPad app, an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum of the original manuscript, and now the documentary Following the Ninth: In the Footsteps of Beethovens Final Symphony, the Ninth seems to be having a cultural moment. Of course, thats not quite right: Since its premiere in 1824, it has never truly left the spotlight.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Being Partly Jewish
description: IN the course of a year, my family celebrates Yom Kippur, Rosh Hashana, Sukkot, Simhat Torah, Hanukkah, Passover and many Shabbats. We also celebrate All Saints Day and All Souls, Advent, Christmas, Lent and Easter. We are part of a growing movement to raise interfaith children with both family religions.

title: Serious Danger of Blood Clots Halts Sale of Leukemia Drug
description: Sales of a promising leukemia drug, Iclusig, are being suspended because of the risk of life-threatening blood clots and severe narrowing of blood vessels, the Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: In Alabama Race, a Test of Business Efforts to Derail Tea Party
description: MOBILE, Ala.  With only days to go before a special Republican primary runoff for Congress here in South Alabama, the national business lobby is going all in.

title: No Lights or Cameras, but Draft Has Action
description: When the N.B.A.s Development League stages its annual draft Friday night, the event might be most notable for everything that it is not.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Welcomed With Kisses, Stanford Freshmen Risk the Kissing Disease
description: STANFORD, Calif.  It is minutes to midnight. A sultry full moon hangs over Stanfords Memorial Church, bathing the campuss red roofs and adobe-toned walls.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Singularity & Co.
description: The vintage science fiction bookstore Singularity & Co. operates from a small storefront in Brooklyn.

title: Kenya: Somali Militants Attacked
description: The Kenyan military led an African Union operation against Islamist militants in southern Somalia on Thursday in an effort to vanquish the group that claimed responsibility for a terrorist attack last month in a Kenyan mall that killed more than 60 people. In a statement on Thursday, Kenya said it had conducted a major aerial offensive on a militant training camp run by the group, the Shabab, in the Dinsoor region of Somalia, possibly killing as many as 300 militants and destroying the site. The casualty estimate could not be independently confirmed. Kenya said that the training camp had been used by Shabab operatives who had infiltrated Kenya, and that it was where those who carried out the mall attack had received their training. A spokesman for the African Union peacekeeping mission said the attack was part of the forces broader campaign against the Shabab. A Shabab spokesman denied that any of its camps had been attacked, Reuters reported.

title: The Invisible Team: Barcelonas Little Brother, Espanyol
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Every day, Javier Aguirre sits in his office and reads four all-sports newspapers. And every day, he finds himself furious as he turns page after page (after page after page).

title: Mexico: Junk Food Tax Is Approved
description: Aiming to curb unhealthy consumption habits, Mexicos Congress on Thursday approved new taxes on sugary drinks and junk food. Lawmakers approved a tax of one peso per liter, or about 8 cents, on soft drinks and an 8 percent sales tax on high-calorie foods, including potato chips, sweets and cereal. President Enrique Pea Nieto is expected to sign the taxes into law in January. The soft drink and food industries lobbied heavily to defeat the plan, but lawmakers said it was necessary to reduce rising rates of obesity and diabetes, as well as to raise revenue. Almost 70 percent of Mexicans are overweight, and about a third are obese, according to the World Health Organization. The foundation of New York Citys mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, financed an ad campaign to support the so-called soda tax. The taxes were among several revenue-raising measures approved by lawmakers, including higher taxes on the wealthy and the elimination of some breaks for industrial plants on the border with the United States, known as maquiladoras.

title: Preserving the Future From the Past
description: Sometime during Singularity & Co.s first year in business, a 10-year-old boy walked with his father into this science fiction, fantasy and vintage pulp bookstore. The boy stopped at the entrance, inhaled audibly and announced, I love the smell of old books!

title: With Gritty Slugger Brian McCann, Its Buyer Beware
description: When it comes to Brian McCann, the free-agent catcher who has spent his entire career with the Atlanta Braves, the phrase most often used is old school. A big, burly, bearded catcher with a picture-perfect left-handed swing, McCann is easy to imagine playing in baseballs early days.

title: South Sudan: One-Sided Vote in Disputed District
description: Residents of the disputed district of Abyei voted overwhelmingly in favor of joining South Sudan, according to results announced by the referendums organizers on Thursday. Zachariah Deng Majok of the Abyei Referendum High Committee said that 99.9 percent of those who had voted wanted to be part of South Sudan. But the nonbinding referendum was not recognized by the governments of Sudan and South Sudan or by the African Union. Both Sudan and South Sudan claim ownership of oil-rich Abyei, and the region is shared uneasily by two ethnic groups: the more-settled Ngok Dinka and the nomadic Misseriya. The Ngok Dinka, allied with South Sudan, took part in the referendum, but the Misseriya, who are close to Sudans government, did not. President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan has said he will work with his South Sudanese counterpart, Salva Kiir, to resolve the Abyei dispute.

title: Tunnel for Smuggling Found Under U.S.-Mexico Border; Tons of Drugs Seized
description: SAN DIEGO  A deep tunnel snaking nearly 600 yards from Mexico under the border and into a San Diego warehouse is one of the most sophisticated underground drug smuggling passageways ever discovered, complete with electricity, ventilation and an electronic rail system, federal authorities said Thursday.

title: International Court Postpones Kenyattas Trial
description: The International Criminal Court on Thursday postponed the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya on crimes against humanity charges until February.

title: The Politics of Petulance
description: Senate Republicans on Thursday again refused to allow the nomination of a highly qualified judicial nominee to come up for a full vote. Their use of the filibuster is by now all too familiar, and the latest casualty is Patricia Ann Millett, whom President Obama nominated in June, along with two other people, to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: In Reversal, Court Allows Texas Law on Abortion
description: Only three days after a federal judge blocked a new Texas law that threatened to shut down many of the states abortion clinics, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, reversed the decision, saying the rule should take effect while the case is argued in the months to come.

title: Virginia Tech Held Not Negligent in 07 Killings
description: Virginia Techs warnings to students as a mass shooting began in 2007 were not negligent, the states Supreme Court ruled Thursday, thwarting a wrongful-death lawsuit brought on behalf of two students who were killed.

title: Fisher Price Commercial
description: A Spanish-language advertisement for Fisher Price toys.

title: Manna Dey, 94, the Voice of Many a Bollywood Star, Dies
description: Manna Dey, an acclaimed Indian singer whose voice was heard in scores of Bollywood movies, died on Oct. 24 in Bangalore. He was 94.

title: Spanish Message With One Word That Needs No Translation
description: TO get ready for the holiday season, Mattel is adding some informal Spanish language to a marketing campaign meant to reach Latina mothers. The campaign, called Toy Feliz, or Toy Happy in English, is a play on the Spanish phrase Estoy feliz, or Im happy.

title: Chiefs Owners Plan Yields Quick Fix (but Not a Hasty One)
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Clark Hunt is used to hearing from fans of the Kansas City Chiefs. After all, he grew up around the team, which his father, Lamar, founded as the Dallas Texans more than half a century ago, and he has been its chairman and chief executive since Lamar died in 2006.

title: As Cuts to Food Stamps Take Effect, More Trims to Benefits Are Expected
description: Starting Friday, millions of Americans receiving food stamps will be required to get by with less government assistance every month, a move that not only will cost them money they use to feed their families but is expected to slightly dampen economic growth as well.

title: Secular Turkish Government Permits Religious Symbol
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Before Thursday, the last time a female lawmaker entered Turkeys Parliament wearing an Islamic head scarf was in 1999. She was taunted, expelled from the building and later stripped of her Turkish citizenship after it was revealed that she also carried an American passport.

title: Banksy-Altered Painting Brings $615,000 at Auction
description: A thrift-store painting is now worth well over half a million dollars, thanks to the imprimatur of Banksy. The Banality of the Banality of Evil, a landscape that he doctored by adding a Nazi military figure, his own signature and a certificate of authenticity, sold for $615,000 in a charity auction that ended on Thursday evening. The money was to benefit Housing Works, which anonymously received the painting in its Gramercy shop and put it up for sale online on Tuesday. The auction attracted 138 bids, from a minimum starting offer of $74,000, with the price jumping by several hundred thousand dollars in the final moments.

title: Germanys Blind Spot
description: The Treasury Departments semiannual report on the international economy and exchange rates usually makes for boring reading. But the latest edition, released this week, broke from that tradition by offering some blunt and much-needed perspective about the German economy: Its heavy reliance on exports is hurting weaker European countries that share the euro.

title: New Yorks Constitutional Amendments
description: New York State voters will decide on Tuesday on six amendments to the highly detailed State Constitution. In earlier editorials, we argued that the amendment to expand casino gambling in the state should be rejected. An amendment that would allow state judges to stay on the bench to age 80 deserves a yes vote.

title: A Bad Ruling on Stop-and-Frisk
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was unwise to put a stay on the necessary remedies Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan ordered in August in response to the civil rights violations of New York Citys stop-and-frisk policy. And it overreached in taking the extraordinary step of removing Judge Scheindlin from the long-running litigation.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 1, 2013
description: Hes free, but hes not completely free.

title: Bill Limiting Pesticide Use on Hawaii Island Is Vetoed
description: The mayor of Kauai County, Hawaii, has vetoed a hotly contested bill that would have restricted the use of pesticides by companies developing genetically modified crops on the island.

title: Palestinians in Peace Talks With Israel Offer Resignations
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian negotiators engaged in peace talks with Israel offered their resignations on Thursday in protest over the continuing construction of Israeli settlements and what Palestinians say is a lack of strong American action on this issue, according to an official involved in the process.

title: A Colorful Food Lovers Feast for the Eyes, Starring Flavors of the Bronx
description: The man in the purple suit knocked insistently until the metal door finally swung open on a recent afternoon. He bounded down the steps to a basement pool hall in the Bronx, where a worn lunch counter served some of the tastiest pork-and-okra stews and braised goat outside of the Dominican Republic.

title: The Baron and the Bronx
description: Baron Ambrosia, the fictional food enthusiast created by the filmmaker Justin Fornal, explores hidden culinary treasures in the Bronx ahead of the premier of his new movie.

title: Chinatowns Renew Push for Traditional Gateways
description: In those moments of imaginative flight, when he suspends reason and allows himself to dream, Wellington Z. Chen pictures glory on the streets of Lower Manhattan.

title: Breeders Cup: Trainers Arent Helping as Drugs Damage Sport
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  The Breeders Cup World Championships are milestone days for a sport that cant get out of the way of itself for 363 days a year. There are two days of full fields of the finest American racehorses and a European or South American invader or two.

title: De Blasio Attracts Silicon Valley Donors
description: Nathan Blecharczyk, Brian Chesky and Joe Gebbia live in California, but they have a lot riding on the policies of the next mayor of New York.

title: Mller, an Architect of the Holocaust, Is Said to Be Buried in a Jewish Cemetery in Berlin
description: BERLIN  For all the efforts Germany has made in coming to terms with its Nazi past, the fate of one of the prime architects of the Holocaust has long eluded the authorities and historians.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 31, 2013
Angry Over U.S. Surveillance, Tech Giants Bolster Defenses
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has spent months and millions of dollars encrypting email, search queries and other information flowing among its data centers worldwide. Facebooks chief executive said at a conference this fall that the government blew it. And though it has not been announced publicly, Twitter plans to set up new types of encryption to protect messages from snoops.

title: A New Account in a Murder Case Closed 21 Years Ago
description: Jennifer Negron died on New Years Day, 1992, a week after she turned 16, her beaten, stabbed body found near dawn on a corner in East New York, Brooklyn.

title: Corrections: November 1, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Tab Carrier in a Bar
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  O.K., Brad Wilber. You finally got the best of me. This was a DNF (Did Not Finish, for those just joining us) for me. Laugh your maniacal laugh and enjoy your victory. I will vanquish you next time. I hope.

title: Homeownership Has Crucial Role in Westchester Race
description: In Westchester, a county of both horse farms and homeless shelters, property taxes, not surprisingly, are at the heart of the race for county executive.

title: Garnett Has a Precise System Before Hes a Go
description: It is moments before tipoff, and Kevin Garnett is a space shuttle, advancing methodically through a complex launch sequence, preparing himself for thunderous flight.

title: When Insurers Drop Policies: Three Stories
description: Charles Nance, Dean Wright and Julie Tyrrell are getting dropped  forced out of their existing health insurance plans  and landing smack in the middle of the uproar over President Obamas health care law.

title: On Fox, a Sterile End to a Series
description: The days of ecstatic fans tearing up a field after home teams have won a World Series and announcers conducting clubhouse interviews with their eyes stinging from Champagne doused on them are in the past. Now, security prevents fans from exuberant marauding, and a gigantic stage is erected on the field to accommodate interviews with players, owners and commissioners.

title: De Blasio as Manager: Delegating, Yet Keeping a Tight Leash
description: They have staked out positions on taxes and charter schools, pedestrian plazas and a ban on large sugary drinks. But the Democratic and Republican candidates to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have rarely expounded on the biggest day-to-day challenge that awaits them in City Hall: managing a bureaucracy of 300,000 workers.

title: U.S. Plans to Sweeten Its Sales Pitch to Foreign Investors
description: WASHINGTON  Declaring we are open for business, President Obama on Thursday announced an expansion of federal efforts to lure foreign companies to invest in the United States, including making sales pitches a formal part of every American ambassadors portfolio.

title: Troubled Start for Health Law Has Democrats Feeling Anxious
description: WASHINGTON  Already under fierce attack from Republicans over the new health care law, President Obama now faces broad and mounting Democratic concerns that the troubled start of the insurance program will cut into the political benefit the party received from the government shutdown and cost Democratic candidates in next years midterm elections.

title: A Way of Life, and Its Slow Death
description: The Tuareg are good people, Robyn Symons billowy but deadly serious documentary Behind the Blue Veil tells us early on. Theirs is a matriarchal society (unusual for Muslims), monogamous and family-oriented. They cherish the desert, because they feel fully alive there. It is their culture. And they are being forced into extinction.

title: Stephen Drew Is Just Like His Brother, Right Down to the Ring
description: BOSTON  During the mayhem in the Red Sox clubhouse after their third World Series championship in 10 seasons, Stephen Drew claimed that he does not follow in his older brother J. D.s footsteps. But the evidence suggests otherwise; in the very next sentence he described how he wears the No. 7 jersey to honor J. D.

title: America, That Very Tough Neighborhood
description: The immigrant couple in Barry Shurchins new film leave the Soviet Union in the late 1970s in hopes of finding religious freedom in the United States, so their son can be a Jew. What they experience is more like an American horror story, one filled with knives and guns, suicide, abuse and nefarious figures. Its an unseemly pileup of misfortune resting on a rather weak foundation.

title: German Politician Meets With Snowden
description: BERLIN  Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, met for almost three hours in Moscow on Thursday with Hans-Christian Strbele, the longest serving member of the parliamentary committee that oversees German intelligence.

title: The Hidden Meaning of Films, Take 2
description: The Perverts Guide to Ideology, Sophie Fienness second collaboration with the public intellectual Slavoj Zizek, sets out a daunting task. Titling a film that way, even tongue in cheek, recalls the Monty Python sketch about summarizing Proust, only with an even broader remit.

title: 50 Years Ago, Thats the Way It Was
description: The overstatement starts early and never lets up in One PM Central Standard Time, a documentary about coverage of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy that strives mightily to reinforce the perception that Walter Cronkite was the only journalist working that day.

title: Saoirse Ronan, Hollywoods Leading Lady in Waiting
description: Poised on the edge of adulthood, the Irish actress Saoirse Ronan still lives at home with her parents, but is coming into her own with an Oscar nomination, films with Wes Anderson and Ryan Gosling, and a budding friendship with Patti Smith.

title: In Tbilisi, Georgia, Bold New Buildings Rise From the Ruins of Dead Empires
description: In Tbilisi, Georgia, a shiny new architectural skyline has become a political issue as much as an aesthetic one  is it slapdash commercialism ruining the cultures authentic history or a step toward a more progressive society?

title: Word of the Day | evenhanded
description: evenhanded \e-vn-han-dd\ adjective

title: With Late Floater, Rose Sinks Knicks
description: CHICAGO  It was an impossible shot, or at least it looked that way to Carmelo Anthony.

title: White House Will Focus on Climate Shifts While Trying to Cut Greenhouse Gases
description: The White House is expected to take new steps on Friday to help society adapt to global warming, an acknowledgment that worldwide efforts to control emissions will be inadequate to head off big climatic shifts.

title: A Rapid Revival for the Chiefs
description: Clark Hunt, the Chiefs chairman and chief executive, reshaped his team after a 2-14 finish, and the moves quickly paid dividends.

title: Gearing Up for an Ultramarathon in Southwest China
description: We were near the end of our morning run when Zhang Mei looked up at the imposing escarpment rising to the west of the ancient town of Dali. Ms. Zhang, the founder of WildChina, a boutique travel agency, was visiting her hometown, in a remote and mountainous corner of southwestern China. I knew her from Beijing and happened to be in Dali this week, too, so I somehow allowed myself to be talked into doing a run with her. She was training for her fifth marathon, which she planned to run in Guangdong Province in late November. Our morning run had taken us past farm fields and white-washed village homes and the blue expanse of Erhai Lake, one of Chinas largest bodies of fresh water.

title: From Todays Paper: A Homecoming After Troops Rout Congo Rebels
Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) MOBY-DICK FROM SAN FRANCISCO OPERA Jay Hunter Morris, below, tackles the role of the obsessive Captain Ahab in Jake Heggie and Gene Scheers adaptation of the Melville classic, presented by the San Francisco Opera last fall. Stephen Costello (as Greenhorn), Jonathan Lemalu (Queequeg), Morgan Smith (Starbuck), Talise Trevigne (Pip), Matthew ONeill (Flask) and Robert Orth (Stubb) round out the cast. Patrick Summers, the companys principal guest conductor, led this production (above), directed by Leonard Foglia and presented here as part of the PBS Fall Arts Festival.

title: News Quiz | November 1, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: China Says Terror Group Was Behind Tiananmen Attack
description: Chinas domestic security chief said a terrorist organization was behind this weeks attack at Beijings Tiananmen gate that left five people dead and 40 injured.

title: Asian Economies Strengthen as Demand for Exports Grows
description: HONG KONG  The gradual recovery in the United States, Europe and China filtered through to much of the rest of Asia in October, data released Friday showed, lifting manufacturing activity and easing concerns about the regions flagging growth.

title: One Casualty of Eavesdropping on Merkel: A Warm Rapport
description: WASHINGTON  At one level, the National Security Agencys surveillance of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is a highly technical story of digital-age espionage, in which the spying is done by entering codes into a distant mainframe instead of by hiding bugs in a politicians boudoir.

title: Chinese Doctors Becoming the Targets of Patients Anger
description: Chinas hospitals are a battleground  not just for the war on illness but also for the one between physicians and their patients.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Nov. 1, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: R.B.S. to Create Bad Bank for Troubled Loan Portfolio
description: LONDON  Little over five years after the worlds biggest bank rescue, Britains Royal Bank of Scotland on Friday announced a new plan aimed at speeding up its overhaul, returning money to taxpayers and returning the company to profit.

title: Hong Kong Finds Switch to Cleaner Fuels Has Flaws
description: Municipal governments all over the world, particularly in developing countries with rapidly growing fleets of cars and choking air pollution, have been rushing over the last few years to force taxis and buses to switch to burning liquefied petroleum gas and compressed natural gas, frequently offering subsidies for them to do so.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Environmental Activists Arrested After Protesting Arctic Oil Exploration
description: In the article Activists Feel Powerful Wrath as Russia Guards Its Arctic Claims, Steven Lee Myers reports on Greenpeace activists arrested by Russia.

title: Should the U.S. Be Spying on Its Friends?
description: Germany is angry at the United States for spying on Chancellor Angela Merkel. Brazil and Mexico were upset to learn that the National Security Agency was eavesdropping on their leaders, too. The French and Spanish both summoned the American ambassador to address spying allegations in their countries as well.

title: Broccolis Extreme Makeover
description: The ad agency Victors & Spoils has created campaigns for some of the biggest brands in the food industry  Coca-Cola, Quiznos and General Mills among them. Until now, what theyd never done was try to figure out how to sell broccoli. Or any vegetables or fruits of any kind. This of course is not unique to Victors & Spoils. Major American advertising agencies tend not to get hired by produce growers to help them market fresh fruits and vegetables. They are hired by large companies making huge profits from processed foods to reach into whatever crannies of the American (or global) public they have not yet connected with. Victors & Spoils is exceedingly good at doing just that. The agencys Smile Back campaign for Coca-Cola, which was released this summer, has been hailed as an ingenious use of a kind of guerrilla advertising, albeit with very slick production, composed of footage of grinning, attractive ambassadors for Coca-Cola pedaling through cities and rural areas around the globe, handing out free Cokes to anyone who smiled back.

title: Forever 15
description: Ilana Panich-Linsman still recalls being an awkward 15-year-old in western Massachusetts, leading a fairly innocent life with a few brainy friends.

title: Can You Make Cabbage Cool?
description: It should surprise no one that vegetables have an image problem. Even if you dont have a kid who scrunches his nose at anything leafy, you may have done so yourself when you were small.

title: The Life of an Undocumented South Asian Immigrant
description: I met Nirmal several years ago in New York. I had become increasingly interested in the lives of undocumented laborers in the city, and therefore had started talking with taxi drivers, kebab sellers, and restaurant workers. I was looking for answers to two questions, the first of which was what might happen if illegal immigrants from South Asia should ever want to retire in the United States?

title: New York Today: Marathon Revival
description: Updated 12:12 p.m. | Chances are you remember last years New York City Marathon.

title: Indonesia Confronts Australian Ambassador on Reports of Spying
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias Ministry of Foreign Affairs summoned Australias ambassador on Friday to respond to news media reports that Australias embassy in Jakarta was used as part of a United States-led spying effort, saying such actions were not acceptable and had harmed its diplomatic relations with both countries.

title: At N.S.A. Headquarters
description: Inbox management at the National Security Agency.

title: Daily Report: Tech Giants Bolster Defenses in Response to U.S. Surveillance
description: Google has spent months and millions of dollars encrypting email, search queries and other information flowing among its data centers worldwide. Facebooks chief executive said at a conference this fall that the government blew it. And though it has not been announced publicly, Twitter plans to set up new types of encryption to protect messages from snoops. It is all reaction to reports of how far the government has gone in spying on Internet users, sneaking around tech companies to tap into their systems without their knowledge or cooperation, Claire Cain Miller reports.

title: Week 9 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Chiefs (8-0) at Bills (3-5)

title: ING to Unwind Mortgage Securities
description: LONDON  In another sign of improving outlook for European banks, the Dutch financial services firm ING said on Friday that it would unwind a portfolio of securities tied to mortgages in the United States that was shifted off its books by the Dutch government during the financial crisis.

title: Restoring Trans-Atlantic Trust
description: BERLIN  IN the wake of revelations that the American government tapped the cellphone of Germanys chancellor, Angela Merkel, trans-Atlantic relations have reached a low point not seen since the Iraq war.

title: Baseline Epics Spur a Debate About Court Speed
description: With another ATP Tour season set to finish Monday at the World Tour Finals in London, there would seem little cause for concern for mens tennis.

title: Rehab for Doctoral Defectors
description: Want to transition out of academia? Heres help.

title: The Repurposed Ph.D.
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, a monthly meeting convened around a long table in a Whole Foods cafeteria on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. As people settled in, the organizer plopped down a bag of potato chips and tackled housekeeping matters, like soliciting contributions. But she did not insist. I know that some of you are in fragile situations, she said.

title: Federer and Nadal Have Equal Claims on Greatness, for Now
description: Lets agree, for the moment, to swear off the greatest-of-all-time-debate even if Rod Lavers two true Grand Slams still seem quite a pair of trump cards.

title: Today in Small Business: Thank You for Sharing
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Teenagers in The Times | October 2013
description: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson Teaching With Teenagers in The Times.

title: Israeli Strikes in Gaza Kill 4 Hamas Militants
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli military strikes killed four Palestinian militants from the military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, late Thursday and early Friday after five Israeli soldiers were wounded in an explosion near the Israel-Gaza border.

title: Chinese I.P.O.s Try to Make a Comeback in U.S.
description: HONG KONG  Chinese companies are trying to leap back into the United States stock markets.

title: Optimism, and Caution, as Spain Attracts Investment
description: MADRID  Like other Spanish builders, Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, or F.C.C., had struggled to convince investors that it could extract itself from Spains housing market quagmire.

title: An Early Split, but Their Commitment Grew Stronger
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Q. & A. | Brian Eno on the Best Use of a Television, Why Art Students Make Good Pop Stars and the Meaning of Visual Music
description: Most know Brian Eno as the multifarious musician who was a founding member of the glam band Roxy Music; produced seminal albums by U2 and Talking Heads; and is widely considered to be one of the pioneers of ambient music. But Eno was an art student before he became a musician, and he never lost his yen for visual innovation. The recently released book Brian Eno: Visual Music (Chronicle, $50) chronicles more than four decades of his experiments with video, light and new media. Here, Eno looks back on the intersection between his visual art and his music making.

title: Fright Night on the Subway
description: New Yorkers and tourists appeared on the subway in their best costumes for Halloween night.

title: Pentagon News Service, Read at First Light and Debated All Day, Fades Away
description: WASHINGTON  The Defense Departments Early Bird news service  which drove debates at the Pentagon, and its senior leaders to frustration, with its compilation of articles on military operations, budget politics and weapons programs  was declared dead on Friday.

title: Babies Can Learn Music in the Womb
description: A new study suggests that babies can learn a melody they hear while still in the womb, and recognize it after they are born.

title: India a Hub for Patients From Afghanistan
description: NEW DELHI  Three years ago, the family of Rohullah Afzali, 23, a medical student at a university in Herat in western Afghanistan, noticed changes in his behavior. He was often brooding, anxious and sometimes angry. He would stay awake for three, even four nights on end.

title: Amanda Peet on Her New Play
description: Amanda Peet, Sarah Jessica Parker and Blythe Danner talk about collaborating on Ms. Peets new play, The Commons of Pensacola.

title: New York Leads Country in Foreign-Born Voters, Analysis Says
description: Even without legislation to let noncitizens vote in local elections, fully three in 10 New Yorkers who go to the polls on Tuesday are likely to have been born abroad.

title: Changing Her Game: Actress to Author
description: Amanda Peet turned 40 last year deeply disillusioned about her acting career. After early success with off-kilter film performances as a would-be assassin in The Whole Nine Yards and a drug-addled mistress in Igby Goes Down, she was mostly getting offers to play peripheral roles  girlfriends, wives, ex-wives. (Her furrowed brow was no match for the end of the world in 2012.) And she couldnt help resenting bigger stars who were nabbing plum cable series that used to be for those of us who were waiting to do TV, as Ms. Peet put it.

title: The (Not So) Secret Life of Walter Mitty
description: The Timess David Carr chats with Ben Stiller about his upcoming movie, The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.

title: Letting a Milquetoast Live Large
description: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty is a piece so deeply knit into the culture that even many people who have not read the short story could tell you that it is about a very average Joe who flees his banal existence through a trapdoor of the imagination. James Thurbers 1939 tale is a model of economy, a portrait of a hapless man who cycles through heroic fantasies as he goes about the quotidian business of his day.

title: Lou Reed and the Neighbors
description: Dear Diary:

title: Roth Unbound and Enemies Within
description: Roth Unbound

title: Checking In on a Diner That Understands Social Media
description: Last fall, I blogged here about a small business in Reno, Nev. that takes social media very seriously. The Squeeze In restaurants,open only seven hours a day, just for breakfast and lunch, have been serving guests since 1974. It has four locations, with plans to open a fifth in San Diego next year, and it also happens to be one of the savviest users of social media that Ive come across.

title: Ring of Power
description: Mae Holland, a woman in her 20s, arrives for her first day of work at a company called the Circle. She marvels at the beautiful campus, the fountain, the tennis and volleyball courts, the squeals of children from the day care center weaving like water. The first line in the book is:  My God, Mae thought. Its heaven.

title: Is Tech Lit an Oxymoron?
description: Aldous Huxley once maintained that the most profoundly important sociological factor of modern times was the growth of technology and what may be called the technicization of every aspect of human life. And Huxley, of course, didnt live long enough to book a hotel room with his iPhone.

title: Comics, One Frame at a Time
description: Reading a comic book or a graphic novel used to be a relatively straightforward affair. After you bought one, youd follow the narrative fusion of words and art, turning the pages manually, admiring ads for sugar water and Sea-Monkeys along the way. But digital conversion has brought new possibilities. Now that comics creators can present stories on tablets and smartphones, theyre reinventing the reader experience.

title: Subjective Lives
description: MRS. POEBy Lynn Cullen  Gallery Books, $26.

title: Attention Must Be Paid
description: Ineluctable modality of the visible. So begin the musings of Stephen Dedalus as he walks along Sandymount Strand in the third chapter of James Joyces Ulysses. Signatures of all things I am here to read. The chapter isnt just a tour de force of prose writing. Its an exquisitely sensitive depiction of a mind at play. Conscious of his own consciousness, Dedalus monitors his thoughts without reining them in. Hes at once focused and unfocused. Seemingly scattered ideas, sensations and memories coalesce into patterns, into art.

title: Dont Be a Jerk
description: We expect startling ideas from those Silicon Valley technocrats whose brightness so often leaves the young dazzled and the old dazed.

title: Engineered Performances
description: The strange anthropological lesson of social media is that human beings, if given a choice, often prefer to socialize alone. Since the founding of Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other mainstays of what technology writers have come to call the social Web or Web 2.0, a sizable portion of humanity has learned to be together while apart, sacrificing intimacy for control and spontaneity for predictability. On the Web, we can be whoever we wish to be, editing the face we show to others in ways that arent possible in physical space. We can also fine-tune the complexity and depth of our interactions and relationships. The result is a sense of freedom whose appeal is evident in the exponential growth of the largest social media services, but it may be a misleading sense of freedom since the tools that make it possible are, for the most part, commercial enterprises, subtly shaping our behavior in ways designed to earn profits for their proprietors.

title: Brain Gain
description: When the world chess champion Garry Kasparov was beaten in 1997 by Deep Blue, an I.B.M. supercomputer, it was considered to be a major milestone in the march toward artificial intelligence. It probably shouldnt have been. As complex as chess is, its easy to see that its rules can be translated into algorithms so that computers, when they eventually got enough processing power, could crunch through billions of possible moves and past games. Deep Blues calculations were a fundamentally different process, most people would say, from the real thinking and intuition a human player would use.

title: Spyware vs. Spyware
description: When we hear about peoples identities being stolen  e-mail appropriated, accounts infiltrated, lives invaded and subverted  a sense of helplessness envelops us. Sure, the victims of such crimes can rebuild their virtual lives, with new account numbers, passwords, Internet providers and computers. But none of this changes the fact that the culprits are unlikely to be caught. We feel something similar when we learn of a new governmental encroachment into our privacy, as we did with the revelations Edward Snowden furnished last spring about the National Security Agencys ability to monitor our lives online. In both instances, its as if everything that was once promised by the computer age  certainty, precision, safety, power  has been little more than a lie.

title: Pushing Their Buttons
description: Why do many people think that Facebook, Google, Microsoft and Apple are rivals? They hardly compete directly. Sure, Facebook and Google both sell targeted Web-based advertisements. But they offer such different services that they dont share a core mission. Apple makes its money selling devices and mobile apps. Microsoft sells computer software and video game consoles. Google makes a free suite of applications that could challenge Microsoft Office. But it has not. Google also runs a social network that no one uses. And it gives away a mobile smartphone operating system. All four seem to be safely in control of distinct missions and markets. They intersect only slightly.

title: One-Click Wonder
description: About a quarter of the way into The Everything Store, Brad Stones engrossing chronicle of the rise of Jeff Bezos and Amazon, he reveals that in the late 1990s, Bezos seriously contemplated trying to collect two copies of every book ever printed and store them in a warehouse in Lexington, Ky. Called the Alexandria Project, a k a Noahs Ark, the initiative never got out of dry dock. And Lexington had no idea about its near miss with biblical importance.

title: Inside the List
description: Nothing Fancy: Wally Lambs fifth novel, We Are Water  about a dysfunctional family coming together for a same-sex wedding  enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. Lamb was one of the early winners of the Oprah Winfrey sweepstakes; he vaulted onto the list in 1997 when his debut, Shes Come Undone, was chosen for her book club, and all of his novels since have also been best sellers.

title: Four Characters
description: A hundred and forty characters doesnt sound like much, but as Twitter has shown over the course of its short, intense life, theyre enough to aid a revolution, ruin a reputation or direct help after a disaster. Critics tend to focus on the irresponsibility or narcissism of the form, or to say it breeds snark or false praise, or that it enables people to feel politically involved when theyre just ranting from their couches.

title: Put That Down!
description: Recently, I found myself on the subway next to a young girl watching cartoons on an iDevice. She stroked its screen softly  lovingly, even  while her face relaxed in happiness. I was charmed. And terrified. We dont yet know what, if any, the implications will be for a generation coming of age in a digital era, and the question fills even the most tech-savvy among us with a mixture of wonder and trepidation. But that is exactly what two youth-minded researchers, Howard Gardner and Katie Davis, set out to answer in an ambitious and admirable project. Their efforts, spanning several years, have culminated in the meticulously researched and thoughtful book The App Generation: How Todays Youth Navigate Identity, Intimacy and Imagination in a Digital World, which explores how young people view themselves and their relationships when smart devices are nearly ubiquitous, social rites happen via text message and the currency of popularity is traded in likes and comments on social-sharing apps.

title: Linked In
description: Social psychologists love the Prisoners Dilemma. They use it to demonstrate the nature of calculated self-interest, with a setup like this: Theres a reward ($10, say) to be split between two players, and what one gets depends on whether the other decides to split things fairly. If both players choose to cooperate, each gets $5. If one cooperates but the other chooses to defect, the cooperative player gets nothing and the defector gets all $10. If both defect, they each get a dollar. The challenge is to decide without knowing what your partner has chosen. Defecting is the safer bet: youll get at least $1 and possibly $10. If you cooperate, you run the risk that your partner will defect, grabbing the whole pot and leaving you looking like a chump.

title: Word Travels Fast
description: For nearly 20 years, weve thought of new media as the brash young upstart and old media as the stalwart if increasingly embattled establishment. But what if new media arent as new as we assume  and old media not really old at all? So argues Tom Standage in Writing on the Wall, a provocative book that asks us to look at media less in terms of technology  digital or analog?  than in terms of the role they invite us to play. Are we passive receptors for whatever facts, opinions and ad messages come our way? Or are we participants, sharing what we like with others, amending or commenting in the process? The second is characteristic of the Internet in general and social media in particular. But theres nothing revolutionary about this, Standage says. Instead, its the role of consumer, so typical of 20th-century mass media, thats unnatural  and to Standage, a historical blip.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE KEATS BROTHERS: The Life of John and George,  by Denise Gigante. (Belknap/Harvard University, $22.95.) The Cockney Pioneer deserves a place next to the Cockney Poet in the visionary company of Romanticism, Gigante writes in this savvy pairing of the lives of John Keats (1795-1821) and George Keats, whose emigration to America and fluctuating fortunes on the Western frontier inspired his brothers most sublime poetry.

title: Whole Wheat Almond Biscotti
description: These are based on the classic biscotti de Prato, but they are much less sweet and made with whole wheat flour and almond flour. Cut them in thin slices on the diagonal and dip them in tea, coffee or wine.

title: 36 Hours in Dsseldorf, Germany
description: Dont pity Dsseldorf. Yes, it probably has a much lower profile than it should, far lower than bigger cities like Berlin and Munich  even arguably lower than that of its nearby archrival, Cologne. Yes, its soccer team, Fortuna Dsseldorf, was recently relegated from the top division to the second Bundesliga. And no, the capital of the North-Rhine Westphalia state is not regularly considered one of Europes top tourist destinations. But let this be your advantage. The artsy, cultivated hometown of both the great Romantic poet Heinrich Heine and the German punk-rock legend Die Toten Hosen, Dsseldorf has more than enough attractions for a rich cultural weekend  or even longer. Although the city is celebrating the 725th anniversary of its founding this year, Dsseldorfs real draws are to be found in its dozens of new developments: stylish contemporary architecture, impressive modern art, cool new restaurants and even new takes on altbier, the local brew that ranks among Germanys best beer styles.

title: Editors Choice
description: AT NIGHT WE WALK IN CIRCLES,  by Daniel Alarcn. (Riverhead, $27.95.) A guerrilla theater troupes tour in an unnamed South American country occasions a provocative look at war culture and public roles in Alarcns vibrant second novel.

title: Talks on Antarctic Marine Reserve Fail to Reach Agreement
description: PARIS  International negotiations aimed at creating one of the worlds largest marine reserves in the waters off Antarctica ended in failure this week in the face of resistance from Russia, China and Ukraine, delegates to the talks said Friday.

title: T LUXURY
description: In Tbilisi, Georgia, a shiny new architectural skyline has become a political issue as much as an aesthetic one  is it slapdash commercialism ruining the cultures authentic history or a step toward a more progressive society?

title: Creating the Broccoli Craze
description: What happens if an advertising agency markets fresh fruits and vegetables the way they do processed foods?

title: Iggy Pops Smoking Web
description: Barack Obamas most-liked Instagram images; Sylvia Plath, illustrator.

title: The 10.20.13 Issue
The Tell-Tale Green Heart
description: Wow! Would you look at this! Dr. Stephen Lahey, the chief of cardiac surgery at the University of Connecticut, broke the soothing rhythm of the Beatles song playing in the background of the operating room. He looked up at the anesthesiologist and his surgical assistant. This guys heart  its green.

title: My Own Unprivate Little Italy
description: The smell of warm chicken blood in the stairwell of my friend Zoes apartment building on Mulberry Street is one thing I will never forget from the summer of 1980. Zoe and I held our breath against the thick air as we came and went. Was the family downstairs really slaughtering chickens in their apartment? Or were we just little girls with active imaginations?

title: Fahrenheit 45-Fun
description: I help run a college TV network that recently held a promotional event where we destroyed a large number of VHS tapes to celebrate an upgrade. The tapes were all either ours (and already digitized) or donated explicitly for the purpose of destroying them. Some people were upset, even publicly comparing it to a book burning. Does it make sense to see a book burning as wrong but a tape smashing as acceptable? Is there a moral component to destroying ones own property? ETHAN GOLDSTEIN, WORCESTER, MASS.

title: Who Made That Referee Shirt?
description: In the early days of football, the officials wore white dress shirts, often with a bow tie and usually a beret-type hat, says Paul Lukas, editor of the Uni Watch blog, which chronicles sartorial trends in sports. The notion was that a formally dressed gentleman has an air of authority, and thats what you want in an official.

title: Randi Zuckerberg: I Really Put Myself Out There
description: You were among the first 20 people hired at Facebook, and the sister of the C.E.O. Why did you leave?  I had been working seven days a week for six straight years. Having a son was the first time I got to pull my head up and see that there was a whole big world out there besides just working for Facebook.

title: As Long as Youre Watching People Have Sex, You Could Be Learning Something
description: Once, 15 years ago, I spent three strange days hanging around the Sheraton hotel in Universal City  which is not so much a city as a mostly unincorporated area in Los Angeles County that houses Universal Studios and its attendant theme park  reporting on an event that billed itself as an academic conference on the First Amendment and pornography. I was there on assignment for a magazine that was introducing a section on education, and the hook was that the conference was being sponsored by the Center for Sex Research at California State, Northridge, and something called the Free Speech Coalition, which I later learned was the lobbying arm of the adult-entertainment industry.

title: The Tell-Tale Green Heart
description: A very odd finding during routine surgery helps explain everything.

title: Jumper Cables for the Mind
description: This couldnt possibly be a good idea. On Friday the 13th of September, in an old brick building on 13th Street in Bostons Charlestown neighborhood, a pair of electrodes was attached to my forehead, one over my brains left prefrontal cortex, the other just above my right eye socket. I was about to undergo transcranial direct-current stimulation, or tDCS, an experimental technique for delivering extremely low dose electrical stimulation to the brain. Using less than 1 percent of the electrical energy necessary for electroconvulsive therapy, powered by an ordinary nine-volt battery, tDCS has been shown in hundreds of studies to enhance an astonishing, seemingly implausible variety of intellectual, emotional and movement-related brain functions. And its side effects appear limited to a mild tingling at the site of the electrode, sometimes a slight reddening of the skin, very rarely a headache and certainly no seizures or memory loss. Still, I felt more than a bit apprehensive as I prepared to find out if a little bit of juice could amp up my cognitive reserves and make me, in a word, smarter.

title: Far Out on a Limb
description: Why shouldnt prosthetics be works of art?

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Taking the Subway With Zombies and Superheroes
description: If the subway is New York Citys great equalizer, its town square for the antisocial, then what can be made of its Halloween?

title: Extra Care Curbs MRSA in Hospitals
description: The life-threatening bacterial infections known as MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, dont respond well to antibiotics, but a new study in Veterans Affairs hospitals suggests they do respond to infection control techniques. Efforts like screening every patient for MRSA, using gowns and gloves when caring for infected patients, washing hands often, and creating a conviction among hospital staff that everyone is personally responsible for infection control were found to help reduce the rate of infections.

title: Turkey and Iran Signal a Softening of Differences Over Syria
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Turkey and Iran, on opposing sides of the civil war in Syria, signaled a thaw in relations on Friday, asserting that they shared concerns about the rise in sectarianism there and could collaborate to bring peace to their neighbor.

title: Exclusive | 383 West Broadway
description: After a three-year renovation, a glamorous 7,200-square-foot penthouse loft is entering the market for $32 million.

title: A Stylized Sanctuary in SoHo
description: After a spare-no-expense renovation that juxtaposes late-19th-century architectural elements against Venetian plaster walls and a futuristic six-foot-tall marble fireplace, a sprawling artists studio in a former textiles warehouse in SoHo has metamorphosed from a bare-bones loft with great light to a self-illuminating, Savant-powered 7,200-square-foot pleasure palace ripe for the ultraluxury market.

title: Slashing the Food Stamps Program
description: Even as negotiations proceed in Congress over a new farm bill likely to contain a large cut in food stamps, needy Americans who rely on the program are confronting an immediate drop in benefits.

title: The Harm Germany Does
description: The Germans are outraged, outraged at the U.S. Treasury department, whose Semiannual Report On International Economic And Exchange Rate Policies says some negative things about how German macroeconomic policy is affecting the world economy. German officials say that the reports conclusions are incomprehensible  which is just bizarre, because theyre absolutely straightforward.

title: Comic Finds New Life, and Punch Lines, in Australia
description: PERTH, Australia  ITS Friday night, and Lazy Susans Comedy Den in this West Australian city is packed. Among the lineup of performers is Sami Shah, late of Karachi, Pakistan.

title: Speech Recognition, Still Imperfect
description: My transcribed voice mail reads, in part:

title: Why Would Reading Is Fundamental Partner With McDonalds?
description: Starting on Friday, McDonalds plans to give away 20 million books in its Happy Meals over a two-week period, while giving another 100,000 books to children nationwide through a partnership with the nonprofit organization Reading Is Fundamental, commonly known as RIF. McDonalds would prefer that we focus on the positives of its campaign: RIFs website notes that two-thirds of children living in poverty have no books at home, and 80 percent of preschool and after-school programs serving low-income populations have no age-appropriate books for their children.

title: Dental Coverage on the Insurance Exchanges
description: Older adults and their caregivers have complained for years that Medicare, which now covers 52 million Americans, does not provide dental benefits.

title: Video Reviews of Enders Game, Dallas Buyers Club and About Time
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the science fiction film Enders Game, the drama Dallas Buyers Club and the comedy About Time. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Tales of Danger for You to Survive
description: Not always, but every now and then, the movies tell us whats on our minds almost before we know ourselves. After a summer of postapocalyptic films in which the earth became a labor camp or else was overrun by zombies, we now have, just in time for the holiday season, four exceptionally good movies that are concerned just with surviving. Theyre not about victory but about merely enduring, getting through some bad days and then some even worse ones, with a little help at the very end, perhaps, but mostly on your own.

title: When Should Parents Intervene to Help a Bullied Child?
description: From Michael Winerip at Booming:

title: Tale of the Seed and the Song
description: Up here, you know the Douglas fir rules the woods. Its the tree among trees, reaching heights over 400 feet and these Oregon hills and mountains are full of their kind. As a kid I recall wandering up through the western coast range by truck, a rickety old Ford Bronco my buddys uncle let us use since it had a winch on account of nine times out of ten wed get stuck up to the knee in some sloppy earth up there from the rains.

title: Folk Art Collection From Imprisoned Former Museum Chairman Going to Auction
description: More than 200 watercolors, pieces of furniture, carvings, weather vanes and other valuable items that were once destined for the American Folk Art Museumare being auctioned at Sothebys on Jan. 25. The collection, estimated to be worth between $6.4 million and $9.5 million, belonged to the museums former chairmanRalph O. Esmerian, who once owned the jewelry retailer Fred Leighton and who is currently serving a six-year sentence for a series of financial frauds totaling $210 million.

title: Skills Practice | Writing Effective Openings
description: Lets cut to the chase for the peyote-eating optimists out there: as long as LeBron James, Derrick Rose, Kevin Durant, James Harden and any team coached by Gregg Popovich walk the wood planks of the N.B.A., a championship banner will not swing at Madison Square Garden or Barclays Center.

title: Ford Issues Recall for Focus E.V. and Ambulances
description: Following an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Ford says it will recall about 2,500 of its 2012-14 Focus Electric because of a power-loss problem.

title: Brentano Quartet Moves From Princeton to Yale
description: When the Tokyo String Quartet retired earlier this year, Yale Universitys music school found itself without a faculty string quartet for the first time in 37 years. But it has not taken the school long to remedy that. Yale announced on Friday that the Brentano Quartet  an ensemble known for its inventive programming, its passion for new music, and its polished but driven performances  would become the schools quartet in residence starting in the fall of 2014.

title: The Gun Report: November 1, 2013
description: Gun ownership in America has racial overtones, British and Australian researchers say.

title: Critics Perspective: A. O. Scott
description: A. O. Scott offers a few insights on being a film critic at The New York Times.

title: Giving Stilettos the Business
Ending Vietnams Suicide Season
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  Almost every summer, the Vietnamese read about the latest group of students who have committed suicide after failing the university entrance exam. This surprises no one. Suicides are so common that one news website headline posed the question: Is this exam season or suicide season?

title: In Our Pages: November 2
description: 1938 Robot Could Land Airplane

title: Kate Winslet on Screen
description: A look back at the career of the actress.

title: Prepared, Professional and Oh So Human
description: On the first day of filming Labor Day, her new movie, Kate Winslet had a chat with Gattlin Griffith, the 14-year-old actor playing her son.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Tech Issue
description: This week, Clive Thompson discusses Smarter Than You Think; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Tom Standage talks about Writing on the Wall: Social Media  The First 2,000 Years; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Reinventing Broccoli as a Cover Girl
Drone Strikes Are Said to Kill Taliban Chief
description: LONDON  American drones on Friday killed the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, dealing a major blow to a militant group that has terrorized Pakistan and that tried to set off a car bomb in New York City in 2010, according to Pakistani intelligence officials and militant commanders in the tribal belt.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in London; Washington; and Thailand
description: Georgians Revealed: Life, Style and the Making of Modern Britain, LondonThe Victorian and Elizabethan periods may be well known, but many quintessentially polite things thought of as British  taking tea, theatergoing and a fascination with gardening  originated in Georgian England. Georgians Revealed, from Nov. 8 to March 11 at the British Library, explores the roots of popular culture and the revolution in everyday life that took place between 1714 and 1830, through artwork, rare books and everyday objects, like the first fashion magazines. (Above, a circa 1714 portrait of George I.) Talks about culinary history, poetry and the emerging middle class; guided walking tours; and a night of Vice and Virtue with live music and performances, and food and drink, are highlights.

title: How the Richest Have Fared
description: For the 400 richest Americans, the year 2002 was similar to 2009: 2002 was one year after the technology bubble burst, while 2009 was a year after the financial crisis. Income reached a peak in 2007 (2009 is the most recent year for which data is available).

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Tech Issue
description: This week, Clive Thompson and Tom Standage.

title: High Income, Low Taxes and Never a Bad Year
description: For the superrich, 2009 was supposed to be the annus horribilis.

title: Dodd-Frank Is Indeed Taking Root
description: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Sky Ferreiras Time, Finally
description: After plenty of false starts and gossip-column notoriety, Ms. Ferreira has made a substantial debut album, Night Time, My Time. Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss.

title: Chicago Philanthropists Gift to Aid Studies of Southeast Asia
description: LONDON  An American philanthropist and major donor to President Obamas campaign and Democratic causes has given 20 million (about $32 million) to Londons School of Oriental and African Studies to support research into Buddhist and Hindu art in Southeast Asia.

title: Russia to Transfer Detained Greenpeace Activists
description: MOSCOW  Russia, unexpectedly and without explanation, is preparing to transfer 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship from a detention center in the far northern city of Murmansk to a jail in St. Petersburg, the organization said Friday night.

title: Currency Traders Put on Leave Amid Investigation
description: LONDON  Nearly a dozen traders have been placed on leave at five large banks in recent days amid a wide-ranging investigation into potential manipulation of the foreign-exchange market.

title: Kerry Plans Brief Stop in Egypt, His First Since Military Takeover, State Media Report
description: CAIRO  Secretary of State John Kerry will travel to Egypt on Sunday in his first visit since the military deposed President Mohamed Morsi four months ago, state news media reported. The trip, which is supposed to last a few hours, was an unpublicized addition to Mr. Kerrys official itinerary as he begins a nine-day trip that includes a fence-mending visit to Saudi Arabia.

title: Security Agent Is Killed at Los Angeles Airport
description: LOS ANGELES  A 23-year-old man wielding an assault rifle and carrying 100 rounds of ammunition shot and killed a Transportation Security Administration officer at Los Angeles International Airport on Friday morning, sending travelers fleeing in panic and paralyzing one of the worlds busiest airports for hours.

title: Shares of Container Store Double in Trading Debut
description: Shares of the Container Store, which sells home organization products like storage bins and filing cabinets, doubled in their debut Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock climbed as high as $36.74 during the trading day, 104 percent above the initial public offering price.

title: Popcast: Sky Ferreiras Time, Finally
description: The singer and model Sky Ferreira was signed by Parlophone records as a teenager. Now, at 21, after a series of false starts and a trail of gossip-column notoriety, shes made a substantial debut album, literate in pop history, full of big melodies, frustration, distortion and a glamorous kind of antiglamour.

title: T WINTER LUXURY
description: Poised on the edge of adulthood, the Irish actress Saoirse Ronan still lives at home with her parents, but is coming into her own with an Oscar nomination, films with Wes Anderson and Ryan Gosling, and a budding friendship with Patti Smith.

title: Image of the Day: November 1
On the Clock, on Personal Business
description: I am a hospital physician. The consultant colleague with whom I share an office spends a large amount of paid work time doing Internet banking and arranging his family affairs. This includes phone calls to his wife and children. Hes supposed to spend his generously allocated nonclinical time preparing the resident education program, and the residents have complained about his apparent lack of interest in their training.

title: Is This Turning Into the Red Sox Century?
description: Bostons World Series triumph gives them eight championships as a franchise, which of course pales next to the 27 won by the Yankees.

title: Jets Defense Preparing for Another Tall Order
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  If there is any consolation from last Sundays debacle against Cincinnati, Calvin Pace said, it is that the Jets get to play again before their bye week.

title: Troubleshooter Reports Progress and Barriers in Bid to Repair Health Portal
description: WASHINGTON  Federal officials said Friday that they had spent $630 million on information technology for the federal health insurance website, and they expressed growing frustration with hardware and software problems that continued to thwart millions of people trying to buy insurance in the online market.

title: Breakthrough Performances
description: Logan Hill looks at some of the noteworthy performances of the holiday movie season.

title: Irish Karaoke: Livin on a Prayer
description: Performing in order: Cam McDaniel, T.J. Jones, Zack Martin, Austin Collinsworth, Mathias Farley, Amir Carlisle, Corey Robinson, Sheldon Day and Louis Nix III.

title: A Risk Communicator Says Industry Should Embrace Labeling of Genetically Modified Foods
description: David Ropeik, a consultant in risk communication who has worked for industry in the past (along with other clients), has posted a provocative call for big food and agriculture companies to end their aggressive fight against labeling requirements for foods containing genetically modified ingredients.

title: Activists Accuse Walmart of Condoning Torture of Pigs by Pork Suppliers
description: As part of a campaign to put pressure on Walmart, Mercy for Animals, an animal rights organization, released harrowing video this week documenting what activists call the torture of pigs by workers at a Minnesota pork farm that supplies the retail chain.

title: At Notre Dame, a Parents Day Game Might Require a Red Carpet
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  At some point in the fourth quarter of home games, the Notre Dame marching band plays Livin on a Prayer, an 80s rock anthem by Bon Jovi. The 10,000-plus green-shirted faithful in the student section sing along with the chorus: Whoa, were halfway there. ...

title: Republican Campaign Committee Pushes Back Against Conservative Group
description: In a warning shot to outside conservative groups, the National Republican Senatorial Committee this week informed a prominent Republican advertising firm that it would not receive any contracts with the campaign committee because of its work with a group that targets incumbent Senate Republicans.

title: Book Review Podcast: Brain Gain
description: In The New York Times Book Reviews Tech Issue, Walter Isaacson reviews Smarter Than You Think: How Technology Is Changing Our Minds for the Better, by Clive Thompson. Mr. Isaacson writes:

title: Star Turns Amid a Winter Flurry
description: Jared Leto, Dallas Buyers Club

title: In the East at Dawn, an Eclipse on Sunday
description: On Sunday in the eastern United States, the sun will rise with a large bite taken out of it by the moon  a partial eclipse at dawn.

title: Manage Fatigue in a Nonstop World With a Nap
description: I didnt get enough sleep one night recently. I realize thats scarcely a big confession, but its a rare event for me. Because Im acutely aware of how critical sleep is to my mood, focus, creativity and even my motivation, Im usually vigilant about getting the sleep I require to wake up fully rested.

title: Call It Amphibious Cooking
description: SELDOM DOES A RECIPE say it doesnt matter whether you use meat or fish. But sometimes, its true. Grilled swordfish, for instance, tastes good with a savory wild mushroom sauce of the sort you might make for a pork roast.

title: A Prankster and His Films Mature
description: When I was 20 years old, I had no plans to ever be a filmmaker, said the director Spike Jonze, cozy in a cotton button-down oxford shirt and a crew-neck sweatshirt, even on a stiff couch in a bland, beige Hells Kitchen video-editing suite. Me and my friends had BMX magazines and skate magazines, and I was a photographer who made skate videos. There was just no way that would have ever even crossed my mind.

title: Both Parties Are Abusing the Filibuster
description: On Thursday, the same day that Republicans filibustered two of President Obamas nominees, a Democratic senator announced that she too would block a vote on someone the president wants to hire. That means both parties are now abusing their power to advise and consent.

title: F.C.C. Plans Sweeping Changes to Bolster AM Radio
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission, seeking to revive the sagging fortunes of AM radio, has proposed removing or updating regulations that station owners believe have left many AM channels on the precipice of death.

title: Yankees Re-Sign Jeter for One Year at $12 Million
description: Derek Jeter endured the most agonizing season of his career in 2013, getting into only 17 games as a series of leg injuries and four trips to the disabled list prevented him from doing anything close to what he normally does on a baseball field.

title: In-Flight Devices, Yes. But What About the Power?
description: Updated, 5:44 p.m. | With the Federal Aviation Administrations decision to allow passengers to use portable electronic devices throughout flights, the next question from fliers will most likely be, So, wheres the power outlet?

title: Norman Rockwells New England
description: I had driven for three and a half hours from New York so that I could go for a walk. And here I was at last, strolling along River Road in Arlington, Vt. The quiet, unpaved street winds along the banks of the Batten Kill, which is said to be the best trout stream in Vermont. In the distance, the green hills were ablaze with red and orange and offered what seemed like a quintessential New England view.

title: A Father Tries to End the Fat Talk
description: Recently, I was changing my 2-year-old sons diaper and I happened to be shirtless.

title: Knit One, Purl Two and Run 26.2
description: The long-distance friendship between Susie Hewer and David Babcock is held together by colored yarn and a world record few people knew existed.

title: Dickenss Unknown Character: Himself
description: He still preoccupies me, Dickens, as a person, Ralph Fiennes said recently, between bites of grilled salmon in the back room of a quiet restaurant on a bright, breezy October day in New York. His film The Invisible Woman, which he directed and in which he stars as Charles Dickens, had just been screened for the news media at the Walter Reade Theater a few blocks away, and hed spent half an hour afterward fielding questions about the strange, painful love story the movie tells. So you would think he might, at this point, be rather Dickensed out. He was not. The psychology of him fascinates me, still, he said, softly, sounding a little surprised himself. Who was he, really?

title: Where Mental Asylums Live On
description: GUATEMALA CITY  DONALD RODAS, a baby-faced man in his late 20s with paranoid schizophrenia, arrived at Guatemalas only public psychiatric hospital last year after being charged with murdering his parents. He says he often wanders freely through the sprawling facility of dilapidated one-story buildings and wooded courtyards, where detainees charged with crimes mingle with ordinary patients and the developmentally disabled.

title: Changes in Labor Force Mask Gains in the Jobs Situation
description: THE unemployment rate has fallen by nearly three percentage points since the Great Recession was at its worst four years ago. But another indicator of the labor market has shown no improvement at all.

title: New York City Marathon, by the Numbers
description: The worlds largest marathon took place on Sunday. A look at the number of paper cups, the oldest runner and other unexpected facts about the race.

title: Brooklyn Motor Works: From Underwater to on the Water
description: When you think of waterfront property, beach houses and restaurants probably supersede motorcycle shops among the things that come to mind. But Brooklyn Motor Works, the Harley-Davidson repair shop that occupies the garage perched on a small pad of concrete and gravel in Red Hook, on the banks of New York Harbor, wasnt always a waterfront property. It took Hurricane Sandy for it to end up there.

title: Off the Charts: Job Picture May Be Better Than It Appears
description: Much of the decline in the labor force participation rate is actually a result of an aging population.

title: Same New York Rivers, but All Else Was New
description: They came to New York from near and far  Connecticut and Australia, Pennsylvania and Norway  to paint the wonders of the new century. But even though the 50-odd artists whose works are on view in the magnificent new show at the Hudson River Museum were all looking at the same railyards and bridges and waterways, they were seeing very different things.

title: Youre Going to Need a Bigger Bowl
description: These hearty vegetarian meals in a bowl (or on a plate) are inspired by the Korean dish bibimbap. I call them Big Bowls because they are also inspired by a popular food truck Ive eaten at, in Portland, Ore., whose only offering is called Whole Bowl, and is a comforting bowl of brown rice, with black beans, salsa, avocado and queso blanco. The long line of people I observed at this truck confirmed for me the fact that a simple, satisfying meal with grain, protein and terrific vegetables can be worth standing in line for.

title: Snowdens Letter of Appeal to Washington
description: Edward J. Snowden appealed to Washington in a letter he gave to Hans-Christian Strbele, a veteran member of the Green Party in the German Parliament.

title: Snowden Asks U.S. to Stop Treating Him Like a Traitor
description: BERLIN  Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American security contractor granted temporary asylum by Russia, has appealed to Washington to stop treating him like a traitor for revealing that the United States has been eavesdropping on its allies, a German politician who met with Mr. Snowden said on Friday.

title: Descriptions of Chaos and Fear at Los Angeles Airport Shooting
description: Updated, 4:03 p.m. | As my colleagues Jennifer Medina and Timothy Williams reported, a Transportation Security Administration officer was killed, at least one terminal was evacuated, flights were grounded, and several other people were sent to the hospital with injuries after a shooting at Los Angeles International Airport on Friday, the authorities said.

title: In Whitmans Backyard, a Salute to Poetry
description: Faith Lieberman is a poet and former teacher, among other things, who in the late 1990s discovered that she also had a talent for organization. Starting in 1997, she put together three poetry festivals in Huntington, the last of which was shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and resonated with the trauma of that event, she said. I felt I needed a rest, said Ms. Lieberman, who lives in Lloyd Harbor.

title: For Vettel, No Pressure in Abu Dhabi Race
