description: Sundays Grand Prix of Abu Dhabi  17th of the 19 races counting for the Formula One World Drivers and Constructors championships  finds itself in a peculiar situation. Aside from providing some entertainment for the local citizenry, the race wont count for anything of note.

title: Bloomers on the Loose Side. Then the Aftermath.
description: The audience does not actually see the mortifying incident in The Underpants.

title: Nas Gives a Benediction for a Harvard Hip-Hop Fellowship
description: The rapper Nas made his first appearance at Harvard University on Thursday, not to perform but to give his blessing to a new fellowship in his name  formally, the Nasir Jones Hip-Hop Fellowship.

title: Lhotas Strengths and Weaknesses, Exposed on 9/11
description: Nobody ever asked Joseph J. Lhota about the thick three-ring binder on his desk at City Hall, a dusty tome that bore a cryptic label: E.O.W.

title: Aiming for Truly Sustainable Buildings
description: Over the last decade, the most widely recognized seal of approval for green buildings among New York City buyers has been LEED, a label that stands for Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design.

title: A Toast to Dearest Distant Friends
description: It is a sorry fact of life that sometimes and somehow we lose touch with our oldest and closest friends. Such is the case of Janet and Lily, the middle-age characters of The High Water Mark, a new play by Ben Clawson that Luna Stage is presenting in West Orange.

title: Market Failure and Government Failure
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Pricewaterhouse Takeover of Booz Risks Culture Clash
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers proposed takeover of the strategy firm Booz & Company would be the most prominent example yet of a Big Four auditor bulking up on consulting. But restrictions enacted after the Enron scandal of 2001 mean advisory services employees could end up battling with accountants over clients. While the midsize Booz & Company may feel pressure to compete with rivals like Boston Consulting Group and McKinsey & Company, the proposed deal with PricewaterhouseCoopers risks a huge culture clash.

title: Above Ground and Below
description: The delight is definitely in the details in William B. Helmreichs The New York Nobody Knows: Walking 6,000 Miles in the City (Princeton University Press). Professor Helmreich, a sociologist at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, invites readers on a romp through largely unexplored neighborhoods that is as entertaining as it is enlightening.

title: Q. & A. | Nick Waplington on the Last Days of Alexander McQueen
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: More Than Shadows: Stars of Strauss
description: Its late in the afternoon near the end of a long rehearsal day at the Metropolitan Opera House, and in a spacious room deep in the storied buildings recesses, two illustrious sopranos, Anne Schwanewilms and Christine Goerke, look as though they might start a Rockettes kick line. Arms around each others waists as they run through a triumphant final ensemble number in Die Frau Ohne Schatten (The Woman Without a Shadow), the Richard Strauss opera that returns to the Met stage this Thursday night, the vocalists briefly cavort in lock step, beaming as they sing.

title: The Steps of City Hall
description: New York's City Hall has long been a theatrical setting where aspiring politicians make and break their careers, and where mayors have courted stage, screen, sporting and other celebrities.

title: A Romance With a Long Interruption
description: The love story between Anne Koch and Robert Sibson began like a European version of a teenage romance dreamed up by the director John Hughes.

title: Attraction Unmasked
description: Children relish Halloween for the candy, but as patrons of a Rickys store know, adults prefer a salacious Sailor Moon costume to a Mars bar. These poems about the holidays erotic underpinnings were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: First Big Role, Right Out of School
description: Its been the craziest year of my life, Ben Schnetzer said, laughing.

title: What Governor Cuomos Dad Said About Gambling
description: Gambling interests have tons of cash and are spending it freely to support Gov. Andrew Cuomos constitutional amendment to add seven new casinos in New York State.But opponents of the amendment have the words of one especially persuasive advocate:former Gov. Mario Cuomo, the present governors father.

title: A Nod to Siberia and the Balkans
description: Its rare to hear a new work that surprises with both its beauty and originality, as does Caroline Shaws a cappella Partita for Eight Voices, for which she was awarded the Pulitzer Prize in music earlier this year. Ms. Shaw, who is also a violinist, wrote the work for the ensemble Roomful of Teeth, of which she is a member. The Partita, released on New Amsterdam Records last year, incorporates nontraditional vocal techniques like Tuvan throat singing, yodeling, speech, murmurs and other vocal effects. On Monday at Le Poisson Rouge, Roomful offers the premiere performance of the Partita, as well as works by Caleb Burhans, Brad Wells and William Brittelle. (8 p.m., 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village, 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com; $25.)

title: He Knew Men, He Knew Women
description: Bob Guccione liked to brag that he knew women. But he also knew men.

title: Hoping for Morning Lows in the 30s
description: Rain or shine, the meteorologist Irv Gikofsky, known as Mr. G, reserves Sundays for long runs, short naps and time with his family. On weekdays, Mr. G, 68, delivers the weather at 6 a.m. on WCBS-FM radio, and again at 5 and 10 p.m. on WPIX-TV newscasts; on Fridays, he also has a WPIX segment, Its a G Thing, about noteworthy New Yorkers. With no broadcast on Sunday, he relaxes in the Upper West Side apartment he shares with his wife, Sang Mota Gikofsky, 45, a social worker, and stepdaughter, Jaida Kyi, 23, a fashion student. Lately he has been training for this years New York City Marathon, taking place Sunday; this will be his 30th year participating in the event. The marathon reveals the human spirit at its best, he said. This year, Jaida will join him for the first time.

title: Creepy, Silent Ode to Death
description: Images redolent of World War I and German Expressionism converge in F. W. Murnaus silent Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror (1922), coming to Film Forum on Monday. An unauthorized adaptation of Dracula, the film employs a range of visual flourishes (coffins overflowing with vermin, a carriage pulled by masked horses) and treatments (accelerated film speeds, reverse negative images) to convey its singular ambience of plague, dread and menace. The films principal special effect is its antagonist, Max Schrecks Count Orlok, a hairless predator with large clawlike hands, pointy ears and a rodentlike countenance.

title: Windows to Past, Wide and Tall
description: Over the years, Reinhard Mucha has been something of an elusive artist. He avoided New York in the 1980s to escape a scene that catered to celebrity artists. But Mr. Mucha, who is German, has even so remained a New York presence, turning up in museum shows (hes also in the Museum of Modern Arts permanent collection) and as an influence on others work. Now Mr. Mucha himself has come to town with his first solo New York show in 13 years, which opened on Saturday at the Luhring Augustine Gallery.

title: Movement Extremes
description: Too much strength can just about ruin a dance, but this week affords a rare opportunity to experience its power in both formidable and subtle ways when two choreographers, Maria Hassabi and Elizabeth Streb, reveal its nerve and beauty. In Premiere, a work for five at the Kitchen, Ms. Hassabi displays her captivation with bodies that move at an unimaginably slow pace. The shakes, the tremors and the sweat  results of such pared-down motion  tell the real story. (Wednesday to Saturday, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, 212-255-5793, thekitchen.org.)

title: A Not-Quite New Guy on New Girl
description: Elizabeth Meriwether found herself in a pickle familiar to veteran renters: She had lined up the perfect apartment  a sun-filled loft  and rounded up four roommates who got along perfectly. Plans were made. Contracts were signed. Then, at the last minute, somebody backed out.

title: Weekend Reading: Calm Before the Storm
description: [Editors note: Please do not read this if you are a junior banker at Goldman Sachs.]

title: Irreverent, Sure, but Relevant, Too
description: Kenny Kramer stood at a podium, his hair tied in a ponytail. He shuffled a stack of readings, adjusted his glasses and scanned the wedding guests, looking very much the officiant.

title: 2013 Nissan Sentra
description: Nissans redesigned compact claims a place at the table, but it wont be the life of the party.

title: Missing Hand in Mets Commissions
description: If the Metropolitan Opera is going to become a house that truly fosters new works, it has a lot of catching up to do, and the general manager, Peter Gelb, seems to know it. Since taking over the company in 2006, he has asked opera fans to have patience as the Met grapples with this essential responsibility.

title: The Secret to Their Staying Power
description: Dancing past the age of 40 is hard enough. But what about 50? Or 60? At Garth Fagan Dance, the burning question, from one season to the next, is simple: How do they do it?

title: New Yorkers: Mentoria Hutchinson
description: For decades, Ms. Hutchinson, 61, has been energetically directing traffic with a shoulder shake and a hip shimmy.

title: Women Edging Their Way Into the D.J. Booth
description: When the D.J. duo Nervo, the Australian twins Olivia and Miriam Nervo, first began spinning three years ago, they used to shock people just by showing up.

title: Just Like the Films We Used to Know
description: White Christmas (1954), Directed by Michael Curtiz

title: Indie Grace, African Funk, Whispery Muscle
description: Minor Alps GET THERE

title: Why Attractive Candidates Win
description: JOHN F. KENNEDY, Sarah Palin, Mitt Romney, Kirsten Gillibrand: Americans have a long history of electing good-looking leaders. Of course, not every successful candidate could be a stand-in for George Clooney or Angelina Jolie. Indeed, sometimes a less attractive candidate triumphs over a better-looking rival. So when and why do voters prefer more attractive politicians?

title: 90s Comebacks: Of Toad and Live
description: The mid-1990s had room for all sorts of unlikely rock stars. Indie rock and grunge had  how to put it politely?  wiped the glamour off the guys with guitars. Once those modes had been mainstreamed, the genres stars could be just, you know, dudes. Resilient dudes at that. Two of the most dudely are in the midst of whodathunkit comebacks.

title: Tinsel Time! Peek-a-Boo, Twirling and Retreat, in a 10th-Anniversary Celebration
description: This week at the Joyce Theater, the choreographer Larry Keigwin celebrates his companys 10th anniversary, an achievement that shouldnt be taken lightly. In modern dance, thats an eon.

title: Dancing With the Cars
description: A busy Manhattan intersection during the morning rush might seem an unlikely place to make your dance floor, but thats where Mentoria Hutchinson mixes it up with thousands of impatient drivers every day.

title: Canada Tests Animal Detectors
description: MONKLAND, ONTARIO  Signs warning motorists about deer and moose, some approaching mooselike dimensions themselves, are a fixture on many Ontario highways. But the signs ubiquity is also their shortcoming.

title: Aware at the Wheel
description: Here are recommendations from the Insurance Information Institute to reduce the chance of a collision with an animal:

title: Heading Over to Queens
description: Queens neighborhoods are giving Manhattan and Brooklyn a run for the money.

title: The Tilt Toward Queens
description: Queens, the citys most sprawling borough, has long been a landing pad for new arrivals and those looking for a cheaper alternative to Manhattan. Over the decades, newcomers from practically every corner of the world have moved in, making it the most diverse borough in New York City.

title: Scene City: Who Said Halloween Was for Kids?
description: Heidi Klum goes geriatric at Marquee, V Magazine dazzles at the Standard.

title: In Communion With Bach, Head, Heart and Fingers
description: In 1985, the 300th anniversary of Bachs birth, the Hungarian-born pianist Andras Schiff, then 31, gave three concerts at the Metropolitan Museum, prompting many to declare him the Bach pianist of his generation. The first two programs offered the six keyboard partitas and another work or two, and the third consisted of the Goldberg Variations.

title: Review: Nissan Sentra
description: Compact sedan buyers have never had so many excellent choices. Deciding on one means doing your homework. Tom Voelk checks out the Nissan Sentra to see if it makes the grade.

title: Even in Bright Hues, Color It Beige
description: If the redesigned 2013 Sentra has hit its target, what was Nissan aiming at?

title: Rules for Sending Packages to Inmates in New York
description: A New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision list of who can send what, and how, and what is permitted and what is not.

title: CHART
description: A tale of two royal princesses  and the besties who stepped into their heels to play Diana of Wales and Grace of Monaco.

title: Transforming Movements
description: What does queer performance mean? In the second edition of the Queer New York International Arts Festival, the notion of queer relates not only to gender and identity, but also falls under the bigger umbrella of otherness. Programmed by Andr von Ah (who died in September) and Zvonimir Dobrovic, the event offers a look at artists working in anomalous, eccentric and even otherworldly forms.

title: Rye Spaetzle Gratin
description: Mixing up a batch of spaetzle is as easy making pancake batter. But youll need a hand to make the dumplings without a spaetzle maker.

title: Innovation Imperative: Change Everything
description: WHEN the first commercially successful steamship traveled the Hudson River in 1807, it didnt appear to be much of a competitive threat to transoceanic sailing ships. It was more expensive, less reliable and couldnt travel very far. Sailors dismissed the idea that steam technology could ever measure up  the vast reach of the Atlantic Ocean surely demanded sails. And so steam power gained its foothold as a disruptive innovation in inland waterways, where the ability to move against the wind, or when there was no wind at all, was important.

title: For Interfaith Gay Couples, Just One Obstacle Is Cleared
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  One morning last summer, Connie Knapp got a phone call from her minister. Several days earlier, the Supreme Court had handed down a ruling fortifying the movement for same-sex marriage. Her pastor, the Rev. Chip Low, had a feeling that Ms. Knapp and her partner, Anne Corey, might want to have a wedding.

title: Machines for Building That Serve a Higher Purpose
description: The dump truck is bent and full of holes, but the daily abuse of a construction site is not to blame. This mass of perforated steel is a work of art.

title: Construction, Elevated
description: A look at some of the pieces in Wim Delvoyes Gothic works series.

title: DVDs Screening by an Open Fire
description: Nashville (1975), Directed by Robert Altman

title: Deer Mating Season: Drivers Beware
description: Its the deadliest time of the year for deer, which also pose a particular danger to motorists in autumn with the arrival of the mating and hunting seasons.

title: Hawks Mystical Marathon
description: For those in tune with the annual cadence of the seasons, migration is nothing less than mystical. What superficially seems random can shimmer with the kaleidoscopic diversity of evolution when more thoroughly examined.

title: Bill Cunningham | Costumery
description: The fall foliage brings an abundance of lumberjack plaids and checks.

title: Spaetzle at Home: Crank Up the Fluegelhorn and Fill the Steins
description: Unless you have an Eastern European heritage or a penchant for replicating the hearty cuisine of German beer halls, it may never have occurred to you to make spaetzle at home. I have both, and the small, squiggly egg dumplings are one of the first carb-heavy, comfort-food dishes I crave when the weather turns cold.

title: The Cellblocks Amazon.com
description: A couple of weeks ago, a street team from Sendapackage.com was standing on a sidewalk near Columbus Circle in Manhattan talking with a dozen women about to board a charter bus that would take them upstate to visit their relatives in prison. It was 10 p.m. and many of the women huddled in the darkness were toting sleepy children; most were also burdened with plastic bags of Pop Tarts, pretzels, cookies and potato chips  junk food unavailable to men behind bars.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 1
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include: the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy, a century-old land dispute and a Halloween parade.

title: Big Gains for Auto Sales Despite a Government Pothole
description: DETROIT  The tempo for new-car sales in the United States accelerated after the 16-day partial government shutdown, as pent-up demand for refreshed vehicle models are keeping the industry on track for its best sales in six years.

title: Catching Up on the Bennett Hypothesis
description: ON HIS nationally syndicated radio show, Bill Bennetts Morning in America, William J. Bennett often advises students about college. Stories from callers burdened by student loans inspired his latest book, Is College Worth It?, written with David Wilezol. Dr. Bennett, 70, is not surprised that the cost of a four-year college has increased so much. In a 1987 opinion piece in The New York Times, which he wrote when he was President Reagans education secretary, he predicted it.

title: Bill Cunningham | Costumery
description: A tiptop autumn week of color in New York, what with the foliage, Halloween and the art of carving pumpkins, the arrival of marathon runners and the abundance of lumberjack plaids and checks. In Paris, the rage is patchwork jeans from Junya Watanabe, but people could just as well make their own patchwork. In Central Park, a headless horseman rides again.

title: Big Ticket | Treetop Park Views for $16 Million
description: Another of the floor-through luxury residences at 18 Gramercy Park with direct treetop views, along with dibs on a special key permitting access to that private and historic park, sold for $16 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The 4,207-square-foot residence, No. 7, has four bedrooms, five and a half baths, and a corner living room that commands 40 feet of park frontage; the monthly carrying charges are $11,225.31.

title: La Scala Musicians Endorse Successor to Barenboim
description: The musicians of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan have agreed to endorse Riccardo Chailly as artistic director to succeed Daniel Barenboim, who announced that he would step down two years ahead of schedule, in 2014, a spokesman for La Scala, Carlo Maria Cella, said.

title: After Boston Bombings, New York Police Plan Tight Security at Marathon
description: As part of an enhanced security plan developed after the Boston Marathon bombings in April, the New York Police Department plans to deploy helicopters, police boats, scuba divers, bomb-sniffing dogs and hundreds of cameras, as well as hundreds of officers, at Sundays New York City Marathon.

title: More Notes On Germany
description: A few more things to say about Germanys trade surplus and the US report saying, correctly, that its harmful to the world economy.

title: What the Well-Dressed Warrior Wears
description: Katniss Everdeen as fashions It Girl? Thats how the costume designer Trish Summerville imagined the teenage warrior portrayed by Jennifer Lawrence in The Hunger Games: Catching Fire: As a previous victor, she must be camera-ready as Panem prepares for the 75th games.

title: Application Upload: Your Voice via Video
description: IN 2009, Tufts and George Mason University opened the multimedia floodgates by inviting applicants to submit videos. While few admissions offices have followed suit and added a video solicitation, a sweep through YouTube shows videos, from existential mulling to absurdist displays of multitasking, being made for a wide swath of institutions. The incentive is clear for students who express themselves best via multimedia, and who isnt looking for an edge?

title: The New Faces of College Admissions
description: MY DAUGHTER was in college. I had let go, just as the school had suggested. Then the email arrived, asking me to pitch in and join its admission network. Id thought I was finished with school volunteer work!

title: Words of Admissions Wisdom
description: The misty bogs of Scotland may perennially top the Bowker list of favorite fictional settings, but what can beat the twisted, ivy-trimmed road to First Choice U for melodrama and suspense? The latest in the increasingly popular admissions genre is a novel called Early Decision: Based on a True Frenzy.

title: The Sophomore Slump
description: Pity the sophomore. You are feted as a freshman, but no one seems to care that youre back on campus. Quirky first-year seminars have been replaced by large foundation classes, making you doubt that major in econ or bio. Youre not high enough up the totem pole to do fun stuff like join a research team or lead student organizations. With the newness of college gone, malaise sets in.

title: Tax on Textbooks? Yes and No
description: ATTENTION out-of-state students: dont take that rental copy of The Art of Public Speaking home with you. Textbooks rented through Amazons Warehouse Deals are not to be carried over state lines. Renters will be charged the purchase price of any textbook that goes interstate, according to Amazons Textbook Rental Terms and Conditions.

title: Looking for Intimacy in the Age of Facebook
description: IT WAS the only time I have ever allowed college students to have their cellphones out during class, in their hands no less.

title: Bulletproof Whiteboards
description: THE University of Maryland Eastern Shore will introduce a security upgrade later this year: 200 bulletproof whiteboards for professors to hang in their classrooms and, if need be, hide behind. We just wanted to add one more tool to help us ensure the safety of the campus community, said Ernest Leatherbury, chief of campus police. The whiteboards are user-friendly and noninvasive.

title: For Profit and People
description: Imagine we could actually build a system of schools that  set up every single student who enrolled in it for success, unlike the schools we have today in higher education, where most students who enter it get no credential at all, most students that enter it are left with a mountain of student debt. GENE WADE at TEDx San Francisco

title: The Value in a Free Degree
description: WHEN it opened in 2009 to some media fuss, University of the People was a free-culture concept in a competitive, proprietary universe. It charged no tuition and was open to anyone who could do the work. Professors volunteered their time. Now, four years later, the first students are reaching graduation, raising a question no R.O.I. calculator has yet sought to answer: What is a free online degree worth?

title: Rewards for Showing Up
description: HOW to get overscheduled students to show up at events? Frequent-shopper rewards.

title: Move Over G.E.D.
description: THERES something that New York State wants to clarify for those facing the diploma or G.E.D. box on job applications: General Educational Development is a brand name (like Kleenex and Xerox). Thats important because come Jan. 2 adults in New York and Indiana cannot take the G.E.D. Theyll sit for the Test Assessing Secondary Completion (TASC), from CTB/McGraw, while adults in nine states can take HiSET, the new E.T.S. High School Equivalency Test. After the G.E.D.s 72-year reign, the splintering comes as a result of an ambitious agenda: the G.E.D. being unveiled in January will align with Common Core State Standards and be offered only on computer (in sync with federal digital literacy standards for adults). Rankled that the adult demographic had not yet been exposed to these new standards  and that their costs will double, to $120 a test taker  states asked other test makers to develop something. As for the new G.E.D., it is being positioned as more than just a high school endpoint. It will now indicate test takers levels of performance, with an honors category for those deemed at college or career readiness. Are you ready? Here are sample questions from the new tests, all of which assess math, science, social studies and language arts abilities.

title: LinkedIn for Students
description: LINKEDIN has been skewing younger. It lowered its minimum user age from 18 to 14, and introduced University Pages in August. So far, more than 1,000 pages are being curated by universities. The centerpiece of each page is a school-specific data crunch of LinkedIn users who are students and alumni, including where they live and work. The school itself nearly always tops the where they work lists, apparently because of teaching assistants and work-study. The largest employer of Ivy Leaguers on LinkedIn, after the school, is Google. And McKinsey & Company apparently likes graduates of highly ranked business schools. A look at the University Pages of Businessweeks top 10 schools shows the following companies employing the most alumni, or at least those who list the school and company on their LinkedIn profiles. (Numbers on LinkedIn frequently fluctuate.)

title: Harvard-Size Ambitions
description: THE ambition of the Minerva Schools at K.G.I., which calls itself the first elite American university to open in 100 years, is certainly not modest. The founder, Ben Nelson, a businessman with a longstanding armchair interest in education, aims to mount a stripped-down, low-cost challenge to Harvard.

title: How to Get an A- in Organic Chemistry
description: THE molecule looked like a giant jellyfish. Or maybe a spider. Halfway through my organic chemistry final, the monster lay there on the page, mocking me. My task: explain how the ungainly molecule folds into a tidy package. The problem: I had no clue. Maybe if I looked at it sideways? No, that didnt help. This was getting ugly.

title: Disability Studies: A New Normal

title: A Surprise Ally for the Rich

The report combines various listings  for $9 million duplexes in Chelsea, for a $44.9 million loft mansion in TriBeCa  with Mr. Steinbergs insights on the high-end property market and the city more generally. Titled Mayoral Issues: A Tale of Two Cities? the October editors note recommended that the citys presumptive next leader, Bill de Blasio, devise a worst tenants list, and cautioned those who criticize Michael R. Bloomberg that a mayors role is to be effective C.E.O. of the city, not best friend.

title: The Parallel Lives of Princess Di, Princess Grace and the B.F.F. Actresses Playing Them in the Movies

Both were universally adored before dying in mysterious auto accidents. Their biopics appear to be star vehicles for the B.F.F. actresses  and the chattering class is abuzz, because both movies are so tiara-twistingly bad as to inspire outrage and bewilderment. Are they propaganda campaigns to bring down parasitic Western monarchies as we know them? You be the judge.

title: Ts Luxury Issue
description: In our latest issue, we explore the many definitions of luxury. Our cover story features Saoirse Ronan, the Irish actress on the brink of adulthood who has upcoming films with Wes Anderson and Ryan Gosling and an Oscar nomination already under her belt. Countess Marina Cicogna  the 79-year-old Italian who is also an award-winning movie producer, photographer of the jet set and hostess of truly legendary parties  shows us that glamour has no age limit. We head to Tbilisi, Georgia, where a shiny new skyline is rising from centuries of architectural history. In China we meet Melvin Chua, the man who is connecting the worlds luxury brands with the worlds fastest-growing consumer market. In Milan, we visit one of the last truly Old World interiors firms, Studio Peregalli, and in Belgium designer Michael Verheyden shares the objects he creates, which are imbued with remarkable beauty and spiritual power. Finally, we check in with one of the greatest icons of luxury, Giorgio Armani, cataloging the reach of his multibillion-dollar empire and the pleasures of his sweet, sweet life.See all stories from the issue >>

title: Texas Clinics Stop Abortions After Court Ruling

The day after a federal appeals court cleared the way for Texas restrictive abortion law to take effect while it faces legal challenge, many clinics across the state said they had stopped providing abortions and were preparing to shut down, leaving women seeking their services distraught.

title: Plutocrats vs. Populists
description: TORONTO  HERES the puzzle of America today: the plutocrats have never been richer, and their economic power continues to grow, but the populists, the wilder the better, are taking over. The rise of the political extremes is most evident, of course, in the domination of the Republican Party by the Tea Party and in the astonishing ability of this small group to shut down the American government. But the centrists are losing out in more genteel political battles on the left, too  that is the story of Bill de Blasios dark-horse surge to the mayoralty in New York, and of the Democratic presidents inability to push through his choice to run the Federal Reserve, Lawrence H. Summers.

title: Egyptian Network Abruptly Suspends TV Satirist

That came one week after he mocked the ultranationalism and pro-military fervor gripping Egypt during the season premiere of his weekly program.

title: So Great

But when I finally finished (making up for my abysmal showing yesterday), I was surprised at how many things I learned from this puzzle by Tom Heilman and how great most of the entries were.

title: Budget Grief for the Poor and Jobless
description: More than four years into an economic recovery, poverty and unemployment remain elevated, while the income gains from economic growth have flowed almost exclusively to the top 1 percent of earners. Those are not the hallmarks of a healthy economy, let alone a just society or a stable democracy.

title: A Bad Reversal on the Texas Abortion Law
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has dealt a grievous blow to the reproductive health and rights of Texas women. On Thursday, the court allowed Texas, pending the courts final resolution of the case, to enforce a provision in the states new abortion law that requires doctors who perform the procedure to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital. As a result, a third of the states 36 licensed abortion clinics have stopped providing abortions.

title: For County Executive in Westchester

The Democratic challenger, Noam Bramson, the mayor of New Rochelle, says he will protect the social safety net while promoting smart growth development and greater cooperation among the countys local governments.

title: Can Iraq Be Saved?
description: With Iraq wracked by the worst violence in three years, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki was in Washington this week looking for military aid and other help. This was quite a turnabout, since he had essentially forced American troops to leave in 2011. Since then, the pressures in Iraq have grown, and Mr. Maliki bears much responsibility for the current turmoil.

title: Planning for a Needed Break From Work
description: JOSEPH BUBMAN took six months off his job as a management consultant two years ago to work with a charity in Kenya and Guatemala. It was something he had dreamed of doing and he spent almost a year planning it.

title: Robert Rheault, Green Beret Ensnared in Vietnam Murder Case, Dies at 87

description: If things go according to plan, the peripatetic Tim Cahill will have only a few more soccer sojourns on his itinerary this year.

title: How Trains Saved the Union
description: On Sept. 20, 1863, Union Gen. William S. Rosecrans was defeated at the crucial battle of Chickamauga that left 16,000 men killed, wounded and captured, after which he retreated into Chattanooga, situated on the south bank of the Tennessee River. Confederate Gen. Braxton Bragg pursued him, taking possession of the heights of Missionary Ridge and Lookout Mountain, east and south of town. Rosecrans was trapped  the only main road out of town, along the river toward a railhead that linked Chattanooga with Nashville, was in range of Confederate artillery in the mountains. Rosecranss only good supply route was lost.

title: After Long Careers, Hill and Kidd Are on Different Paths This Season
description: Grant Hill celebrated his 41st birthday last month, and on that day he was on the Duke campus, appearing at an event to mark the 50th anniversary of black students attending the university.

title: Nets Prevail, Showing Heat That Rivalry Has Two Sides
description: It is too early, perhaps, to assess how the Nets will fare against the Miami Heat as this N.B.A. season progresses. But within a so-called rivalry that has been so one-sided, so punishing, in recent years, it is probably never too early to start the emotional buildup.

title: One-Month Checkup
description: Success signing up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act has been elusive for some and a dream come true for others. It often depends on geography.

title: Health Exchange: A One-Month Checkup
description: The Affordable Care Acts goal of providing health insurance for all Americans grew more complicated when governors of more than 30 statesopted not to create their own health care exchanges. That left the federal government responsible for enrolling a much larger portion of the population than it had expected, which is at least part of the reason for the troubled rollout of HealthCare.gov.

description: After 18 years in prison, Sundhe Moses was paroled. His case is part of a broad investigation into Louis Scarcella, a retired detective suspected of using questionable tactics and evidence.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) PROMISED LAND (2012) Matt Damon, above, plays a corporate predator and staunch defender of his companys cause  fracking, the contentious drilling technique for natural gas  who arrives in a small farming town with the belief that he is offering local landowners a lifeline. Some, hearing the amounts being offered for drilling rights, are eager to sign up. But troubles arise when an old-timer (Hal Holbrook) starts asking questions about what fracking will do to the water supply, the livestock and the land itself. Then an environmental activist (John Krasinski) appears on the scene. The movie has a point to make, and it does so in a way that is both honorable and disappointing, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, directed by Gus Van Sant and written by Mr. Damon and Mr. Krasinski. It admirably tries to represent both sides of the fracking debate, even though its allegiance is clearly to the antifracking position. There is nothing wrong with such advocacy, except that in this case it means that the movie veers away from its strengths, ending in a welter of convenient (and dubious) plot twists and puffed-up speeches.

And he gave a shout-out to new competency-based programs at public universities, private institutions and profit-making colleges alike. The programs dispense with the credit hour and classrooom time with a professor in favor of self-paced online learning and assessments that measure what people can actually do.

description: Honda is recalling 344,000 of its 2007-8 Odyssey minivans because a malfunctioning computer could cause heavy and unexpected braking without the driver pressing on the brake pedal and without illumination of the brake lamps, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: In Baseballs Time Machine, 21st Century Belongs to the Red Sox
description: If it were not bad enough that the Yankees missed the playoffs for only the second time since 1993, and if there were not enough agony with all the injuries and the losses and the Alex Rodriguez story leaving a sour taste for everyone, surely the final indignity came the night before Halloween when their archrivals became champions  again.

title: The N.S.A.s Evolution
description: The National Security Agency was founded in 1952, and its surveillance capabilities were limited by legislation in 1978. But with the attacks of September 2001 came a new sense of urgency.

title: Documents Show N.S.A. Efforts to Spy on Both Enemies and Allies
description: Classified documents showing how the N.S.A. routinely spies on friends as well as foes.

title: Variety: An Acrostic to Set Your Clock By
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  A very timely puzzle this is, because we get to set our clocks back this Sunday and enjoy either an extra hours sleep or additional mayhem, depending on your lifestyle.

title: Paces Influence Grows as His Playing Time on Jets Defense Declines
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The wall outside the Jets locker room at their headquarters here is lined with the teams historical numerical roster, and that was where Calvin Pace was pointing, discussing his football mortality, on a recent afternoon.

title: No Morsel Too Minuscule for All-Consuming N.S.A.
description: When Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, sat down with President Obama at the White House in April to discuss Syrian chemical weapons, Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and climate change, it was a cordial, routine exchange.

title: With Saints, Affable Ryan Is Locked in a Big Easy Bear Hug
description: NEW ORLEANS  On a recent night at Ms. Maes, a smoky, always-open bar in the Uptown section here at the corner of Magazine and Napoleon Streets, a woman with rollers in her hair feverishly danced alone to Robin Thickes Blurred Lines under a flag that read, Youre in Saints country. In the back of the bar, the air hockey, Foosball and pool tables went unattended, and the video poker machines, sandwiched by an ATM on one side and a Ms. Pac-Man game on the other, managed to lure only one patron.

title: How Anna Chakvetadze, Rising Star at 20, Became a Retiree at 26
description: As Russia faces Italy in the Fed Cup final without its top 11 players, Anna Chakvetadze will be watching and reminiscing. She represented her country eight times at the Fed Cup and helped Russia defeat Italy in the final six years ago.

title: Pakistani Taliban Gather to Select Successor to Leader Killed in U.S. Drone Strike
description: LONDON  Pakistani Taliban commanders met Saturday to choose a successor to Hakimullah Mehsud, their leader who was killed Friday in an American drone strike, as mainstream political leaders stepped up their criticism of the United States and vowed to press ahead with peace talks.

title: At Los Angeles International Airport, Two Lives Collide in a Fatal Instant
description: LOS ANGELES  One was a troubled 23-year-old, with an assault rifle and an apparent grudge against the government, who witnesses said seemed to be hunting for airport security officials. The other was a 39-year-old father of two who for three years had been a screener of the torrent of passengers who move through the security lines at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Womens Flexibility Is a Liability (in Yoga)
description: FROM my own practice and research, I know that yoga is generally a good thing. The bending, stretching and deep breathing can renew, calm, heal, strengthen, lift moods, lower the risk of heart disease, increase flexibility and balance, counter aging and improve sex. In short, the benefits are many and commonplace while the serious dangers tend to be few and comparatively rare.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 3
description: Im not going anywhere. Theres plenty of work left to do.

title: Robots or Aliens as Parents? Colleges Gauge Applicants Creativity
description: As legions of high school seniors polish their college applications, plowing through predictable essay topics about their lives and goals, they might also run across something like this: Tell us your favorite joke and try to explain the joke without ruining it.

title: Seeking Laughs in a New Place
description: The journalist Sami Shah satirized Pakistani politics. Then, facing security threats, he and his family moved to Australia, where he now uses stand-up comedy to help adapt to his new life.

title: Honeywells David Cote, on Decisiveness as a 2-Edged Sword
description: This interview with  David Cote, chairman and chief executive of Honeywell, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Hopefuls in New York and New Jersey Pack Their Final Weekend
description: On a bright autumn day, the candidates for governor of New Jersey and mayor of New York City embraced the final days of their campaigns with rallies, bus tours and visits to diners, butcher shops  and the site of a planned garbage transfer station.

title: Business Best Sellers
description: 1. Lean In by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell (Knopf). The chief operating officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.

title: When Backstage Was No Big Deal
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  THE Lou I knew liked speed and cheap Scotch. Had short hair and wore weird shoes. Just as he could write something as harrowing as Rock Minuet or as tender as Perfect Day, he could also be frightening, the surliest of misanthropes, or the most gentle person imaginable.

title: At Sears, Those Big Losses Get in the Way
description: Id like to go faster. Id like to go bigger. Were just not making money, which makes it much, much harder to fund the transformation.

title: Red Bulls Prepare for a Seasoned Rival
description: HANOVER, N.J.  On their last trip to Texas, only two weeks ago, the Red Bulls game against the Houston Dynamo was over moments after it started.

title: In New York Casino Vote, a Dance With Temptation
description: In the 48 states that permit at least some form of commercial gambling, lively debate continues over the industrys relentless efforts to expand. On Tuesday, New Yorkers will vote on a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit up to seven new full-scale gambling casinos in the state. (The states five existing casinos are confined to Indian reservations.)

title: Oden Has a Fragile Body but a Strengthened Spirit
description: MIAMI  Never a man of many words, Greg Oden still has a few quick moves. On the eve of another season he was not physically ready for, he posted up his slender 7-foot frame for an interview in a corner of the Heats practice gym, took a few questions and spun his way through the door leading into the locker room.

title: Keep the Gates of Paradise Open
description: I RECENTLY made what can best be described as a personal pilgrimage to Florence, Italy, where I wanted to gaze once again on Lorenzo Ghibertis recently restored golden Baptistery doors, known as the Gates of Paradise, and remember how they changed my life.

title: Japanese Civil Servant Runs Marathon for Fun, Not Profit
description: Over the years, Japan has produced some of the worlds best marathon runners, yet few of them have made their mark in New York, largely because many of them run for corporate teams that have restrictive schedules.

title: Virginia Governors Race
description: I.O.U.s Give the Democrat a Significant Edge

title: The Dangers of a Stock Market Melt-Up
description: Investors arent worrying much about the stock market, and that worries Edward Yardeni.

title: Earning Less, but at Home
A Goalkeepers Revenge: Stoke Citys Begovic Scores Goal
description: It is one thing to score a goal only 14 seconds into a game. But it is quite another when that goal scorer turns out to be a goalkeeper.

title: I Want to Be Friends With Republicans
description: The trouble started the night Jeff, one of the guys I drink and talk about God with, announced that hed been summoned to court for the Zimmerman trial jury pool. Wed kept politics out of our Wednesday night meetings, which are held on my back porch, the six of us seated at an old dining room table propped next to my broken hot tub (Florida short-sale homes come standard with broken hot tubs). Instead of Bible Study, we call it our Tavern Ministry, and while we were often drunk halfway through, a churchlike decorum had always held sway. Once the case came up, though, decorum collapsed.

title: In Praise of Art Forgeries
description: IN Queens, a guy working in his garage churned out Pollocks and Rothkos that fooled the experts, sold for millions of dollars and helped destroy the Knoedler & Company gallery, as we learned in recent months. In China, thousands of artisans have forged the countrys artistic treasures, both ancient and modern, according to a report in The New York Times.

title: Calling America: Hello? Hello? Hello? Hello?
description: SINGAPORE  HAVING lived and worked abroad for many years, Im sensitive to the changing ways that foreigners look at America. Over the years, Ive seen an America that was respected, hated, feared and loved. But traveling around China and Singapore last week, I was confronted repeatedly with an attitude toward America that Ive never heard before: Whats up with you guys?

title: A Bad Day to Die
description: You probably know the scene in Stanley Kubricks Dr. Strangelove: Slim Pickens, playing the pilot of the B-52 that has been ordered to attack Russia by his bonkers commander, General Ripper, is reviewing the contents of the crews survival kit. It contains among other essential items $100 in gold, nylon stockings and one issue of prophylactics. At the end of the list he remarks, Shoot, a fella could have a pretty good weekend in Vegas with all that stuff.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Obamas Use of His Power
description: Readers discuss the presidents style and accomplishments.

title: Pot and Jackpots
description: BASED on what stirs passions and wins headlines, it would be easy to imagine that the only cultural debates that matter in America are the ones that have to do with sex.

title: The Tumbling Boundaries of Gay Rights
description: ELLIOTT MANAGEMENTS lofty offices in Midtown Manhattan look north, south, east and west across the boroughs thicket of skyscrapers. But the most intriguing view I got during a visit there last week was of something else: the changed gay-rights landscape and its implications for the Republican Party.

title: This Is Why We Need Obamacare
description: THE biggest health care crisis in America right now is not the inexcusably messy rollout of Obamacare.

title: Mark Rampolla
description: As a Peace Corps volunteer in Latin America, Mark Rampolla developed a taste for coconut water and turned it into a food trend by founding Zico, a leading brand of coconut water.

title: From Love Nests to Desire Surveillance
description: I ASKED Mike Nichols, the director of Harold Pinters Betrayal on Broadway, why love triangles have such a mythic hold on the imagination.

title: Poverty in America Is Mainstream
description: Few topics in American society have more myths and stereotypes surrounding them than poverty, misconceptions that distort both our politics and our domestic policy making.

title: In the N.B.A., ZIP Code Matters
description: AS the N.B.A. season gets under way, there is no doubt that the leagues best player is 6-foot-8 LeBron James, of the Miami Heat. Mr. James was born poor to a 16-year-old single mother in Akron, Ohio. The conventional wisdom is that his background is typical for an N.B.A. player. A majority of Americans, Google consumer survey data show, think that the N.B.A. is composed mostly of men like Mr. James. But it isnt.

title: The Frackers and the Birth of an Energy Boom
description: One could argue that, except for the Internet, the most important technological advance of the last two decades has been hydraulic fracturing, widely known as fracking. Practically overnight, it seems, this drilling technique has produced so much oil and gas beneath American soil that we are at the brink of something once thought unattainable: true energy independence. And its repercussions, for geopolitics, the environment and other areas, are only now being grasped.

title: That Dreadful Day in December
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  Every day in this first year is a very difficult journey, said Mark Barden, whose 7-year-old son Daniel was one of the 20 schoolchildren slain last December here in the Sandy Hook shooting massacre. And with the anniversary of the tragedy coming up, it seems to be getting more difficult.

title: Insurance Policies Not Worth Keeping
description: Congressional Republicans have stoked consumer fears and confusion with charges that the health care reform law is causing insurers to cancel existing policies and will force many people to pay substantially higher premiums next year for coverage they dont want. That, they say, violates President Obamas pledge that if you like the insurance you have, you can keep it.

title: The Aloha Spirit, for Everyone
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  Hawaii is on the brink of becoming the 15th state to allow same-sex couples to marry. The victory, once it comes, will have a special resonance. This is the state whose Supreme Court in 1993 first opened the door to marriage equality by declaring marriage a basic civil right, setting off a reactionary scramble that led to the federal Defense of Marriage Act, a legal bulwark against gay couples that the United States Supreme Court has partly demolished.

title: A Victory Against Dark Money
description: A group of wealthy donors wanted to give millions to two right-wing California political campaigns last year, but didnt want anyone to know their identities. They came up with a scheme that any money-launderer would be proud of, funneling the cash through a convoluted series of independent spending groups that were allowed to collect unlimited dollars. By the time the donations had been used to buy advertising, the original money trail had been erased.

title: States Take on Privacy
description: Tired of waiting for Congress to pass comprehensive privacy legislation, state lawmakers are taking matters into their own hands, and not a moment too soon. Legislatures across the country have enacted laws to regulate the kinds of information that companies and law enforcement agencies can collect about individuals and how it can be done.

title: A Teenagers Course, Altered by Motherhood
description: In the third trimester of her pregnancy, Daniel Harris, then 16, struggled to comfortably sleep through the night. So she was awake just after 4 a.m., when the sound of screaming became audible. She thought a next-door neighbor was responsible for the commotion, until her frightened younger sister went to her bedroom and a sick realization hit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: So You Want to Play Pro Basketball
description: A look at the traits of basketball players.

title: Week 9: Saints (6-1) at Jets (4-4)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Eloquent Empty Spaces
description: A photographer captures glimpses of cityscapes in their rare moments of emptiness.

title: Eloquent Empty Spaces
description: WHEN I began photographing cities at twilight, I was attracted to outlying regions, places that seemed unloved and overlooked. More recently, I have been lured back to the central areas of cities, where economic turmoil has produced its own gaps in the urban facade.

title: The Human Face of Our Health Care Mess
description: Republicans have been focusing on the messiness of the Obamacare rollout, and thats perfectly legitimate. It has been very messy. Some liberals think they shouldnt acknowledge the problems, because that just gives the critics more talking points. I disagree: The rollout has been a disaster, and President Obama was misleading when he said everyone could keep their existing insurance. Lets not disguise the truth.

title: In Touch With Nature, and With Rock n Roll
description: WOODEN WONDERS My business partner, Joel Babbit, picked out the furniture, including the desk in my office. I was really pleased with his choice. Wood gives us so much, including beautiful furniture. And lets not forget that wood is a renewable resource. The instrument that has given me so much joy and a great career, the piano, is also made of wood, as are so many other musical instruments.

title: Boy, 9, Is Killed by S.U.V. in Brooklyn
description: A 9-year-old boy was killed and three other people were hurt when a sport utility vehicle jumped the curb at an intersection in Fort Greene, Brooklyn,on Saturday, the authorities said.

title: Filly Sustains Fatal Injury at Breeders Cup
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  The second day of the Breeders Cup off to a tragic start when Secret Compass fell during the Juvenile Fillies race, dismounting her rider, John Velazquez. The filly sustained a lateral condylar fracture with dislocation and was euthanized.

title: Sin and Unsinn
description: Continuing on my German theme: Matt OBrien catches something that Id missed  and its really, really bad. Ive mentioned before that the European Commissions estimates of the structural rate of unemployment in troubled economies are disastrously misleading. Its model (pdf) just isnt designed to cope with sustained slumps that put some countries into near- or actual deflation, where the downward stickiness of nominal wages becomes a crucial issue. What the model does in such cases is interpret the failure of these countries to experience accelerating deflation as a rise in the structural rate of unemployment.

title: If a Young Child Wanders, Technology Can Follow
description: Most parents have experienced that feeling of fear when a young child wanders off at the playground or disappears during a trip to the supermarket. New technology, in the form of voice watches and miniature sensing devices, is aimed at thwarting such distress by keeping track of children who are too young to carry a smartphone.

title: Fantasy Football: 2013 Matchup Analysis, Wide Receiver
description: This chart looks ahead to the rest of the season and indicates what kind of fantasy matchup a player will have.

title: Riding the Hashtag in Social Media Marketing
description: About once a week, Gary Vaynerchuk posts a Twitter message that reads, Is there anything I can do for you? He means it literally. He is inviting his roughly one million followers to send requests for any kind of help or favor. And if you respond, he will try to punch you in the face.

title: Social Media Animal for Hire
description: A day in the life of Gary Vaynerchuk, an entrepreneur whose energy seems endless.

title: Oarfish Offer Chance to Study an Elusive Animal Long Thought a Monster
description: It was a big day for marine biologists: On Oct. 13, the body of an 18-foot oarfish was dragged from the water onto Santa Catalina Island off the California coast, presenting a rare opportunity for local scientists to study one of the worlds most elusive and awe-inspiring big fish.

title: Two French Journalists Are Kidnapped and Killed by Gunmen in Mali
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Two French journalists were kidnapped and killed in northern Mali on Saturday, the French Foreign Ministry said, underscoring the continuing instability of a region retaken from fighters linked to Al Qaeda only eight months ago.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 3
description: Technical problems that continue to complicate President Obamas signature health care law and reports of high-level espionage on both enemies and allies have made for a tumultuous week in the White House. Also, some Republicans are threatening to block the administrations nominees for federal posts until the survivors of the 2012 attack on the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, appear before Congress. Supporters on both sides of each issue will hash it out on the Sunday news shows.

title: France 1930, Germany 2013
description: Did France cause the Great Depression? It sounds a bit like a joke (Billy Crystal in Moscow, 1989: I was raised thinking you were the enemy; you were raised thinking I was the enemy. We were both wrong: its the French) But its the actual title of a very good paper by Doug Irwin, who points out that France, with its undervalued currency, soaked up a huge proportion of the worlds gold reserves in 1930-31, and suggests that France was responsible for about half the global deflation that took place over that period.

title: Stolen Produce
description: Greetings all! Im filling in for Deb for the day, which is just long enough to rave about this Sunday puzzle from Andy Kravis and Victor Barocas. Fair warning first: there are spoilers below.

title: Little-Noticed Czech Team Snares a European Title
description: A Czech team with few top-ranked players on its roster was the surprise winner of the European Club Cup open division title last week in Rhodes, Greece.

title: In Detroit, Mayors Race Is One Piece of a Puzzle
description: DETROIT  If people along the streets of this city seem less than consumed by the prospect of choosing a new mayor on Tuesday, perhaps it is the barrage of distractions: the governor who has been testifying in a courthouse here about Detroits descent into bankruptcy; the appointed emergency manager who has brought in his own team to run City Hall; the long list of questions about the fate of this citys artwork, its streetlights, its tens of thousands of empty buildings.

title: I.O.U.s Give the Democrat an Edge in Virginia
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Their cheeks brushed as they whispered into each others ears, Bill Clinton and Terry McAuliffe, together again.

title: As Bush Settles Into Dallas, Golf Tees and Family Time Now Trump Politics
description: DALLAS  When the executive director of former President George W. Bushs public policy institute decided to move on recently, he stopped by for an exit interview. Mr. Bush asked if he had anything in particular he wanted to talk about.

title: Japanese Pitchers Winning Streak Ends at 30
description: Masahiro Tanaka finally lost. In what may have been his last start in Japan, the ace of the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles, who had not lost in more than a calendar year, dropped a game with his team on the verge of a championship.

title: G.O.P. Pursues Hispanic Votes With Abortion Stance
description: Following this summers divisive abortion debate in the State Legislature, Texas Republicans see an opening for the 2014 election as they work to reach out to Hispanic voters who could be spurred to the polls by the partys anti-abortion stance.

title: Twerking? Oh, Please. That Was Back in 10.
description: Three years ago, on a small side stage of Austins Fun Fun Fun Fest, the rapper Big Freedia introduced Austin to New Orleans bounce music, the hip-hop subgenre that prominently features what  thanks to Miley Cyruss performance at this years Video Music Awards ceremony  has since become known far and wide as twerking.

title: Names Invoked on the Stump May Shift Votes
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: With or Without $2 Billion, Water Woes Unlikely to Go Away
description: Ahead of Tuesdays election, hundreds of thousands of Texans have already cast ballots on Proposition 6, which would amend the State Constitution so that $2 billion could be taken from the states savings account to help finance water infrastructure projects.

title: Allan Block, Whose Sandal Shop Was Folk Music Hub, Dies at 90
description: Allan Block, a leather craftsman and fiddler who made sandals and music in his Greenwich Village shop  which became a bubbling hub of folk music during the 1950s and 60s; a showcase for talented pickers and singers like Ramblin Jack Elliott, Doc Watson and Maria Muldaur; and a destination for aspiring musicians like John Sebastian and Bob Dylan  died on Oct. 23 at his home in Francestown, N.H. He was 90.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: ANTHONY LACOSTE The Air Force back, right, ran for 263 yards, the second most in program history, and scored three touchdowns for the host Falcons, who ended a seven-game skid with a 42-28 win over Army, which had three scores from Angel Santiago.

title: Bernard Goetz, Man in 84 Subway Shooting, Faces Marijuana Charges
description: Nearly three decades after becoming notorious as the subway rider who shot four teenagers on a Manhattan train, Bernard H. Goetz found himself back in the news on Saturday, after being charged with trying to sell marijuana to an undercover police officer.

title: Brothers Share Stage, but Rangers Stepan Steals It
description: Neither Jordan nor Eric Staal could recall a time when they and their brother Marc played an organized game together.

title: A Mansion Without an Occupant
description: After 12 years as a backdrop for V.I.P. receptions and high-powered meetings, Gracie Mansion, home of New Yorks mayors, is expecting a full-time resident.

title: New York Mayors Mansion Seeks a Missing Item (the Mayor)
description: John Quincy Adams slept there before he was president, and Louis-Philippe of France slept there before he was king  as did, at one time or another, Charlie Chaplin and Menachem Begin; also, Fiorello H. La Guardia and eight other mayors.

title: Fillys Death Overshadows a Triumph at the Breeders Cup
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  A span of less than three hours at the Breeders Cup World Championships at Santa Anita Park on Saturday starkly illustrated the excruciating swings of emotion intrinsic to thoroughbred racing.

title: Srdja Popovic, 76, Serbian Champion of Rights, Dies
description: Srdja Popovic, a Serbian lawyer and celebrated human rights advocate who pressed for reform and free speech for five decades, first under Communist rule in the former Yugoslavia and later under the strongman Slobodan Milosevic and his successors, died on Tuesday in Belgrade. He was 76.

title: Grard de Villiers, 83, French Spy Writer, Dies
description: Grard de Villiers, a French popular novelist whose raffish, long-running spy-thriller series, S.A.S., sold more than 100 million copies and became a kind of drop box for real-world secrets from intelligence agencies around the world, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 83.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 2, 2013
Schumer Endorses Clinton for President in Iowa Speech
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, used a speech to Iowa Democrats on Saturday night to endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton for president, another indication of how quickly the party is coalescing behind the former secretary of state.

title: Corrections: November 3, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Mutai and Jeptoo Storm to Victories in New York Marathon
description: It was a day for the Kenyans at the New York City Marathon on Sunday: Geoffrey Mutai and Priscah Jeptoo won the mens and womens races. This is their countrys third sweep of the individual titles in this race.

title: Stick Figures and Stunted Growth as Warring Syria Goes Hungry
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rana Obaid began her life less than two years ago in a comfortable house draped with roses, the daughter of a grocer locally famous for his rich homemade yogurt. But war and siege brought hunger so quickly to their town near Damascus that when she died in September, at 19 months, her arms and legs were as thin as broomsticks.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Nov. 1, 2013
description: When Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius apologized about the rollout of the Obamacare website this week, she joined a growing number of leaders in business and government who have decided that saying sorry was the smart choice in the face of some crisis or gaffe.

title: Hard-Luck Horse Wins Breeders Cup Classic by a Nostril
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  This is how championship races should be run  with fury and beauty and with the horses carrying not only jockeys on their backs, but hopes and dreams and stories. As Mucho Macho Man, Declaration of War and Will Take Charge pounded down the stretch of North Americas richest race, the people who had taken them here gritted teeth, pounded their programs and willed their horses to the finish line.

title: Reeling From War, Afghan Society Ill-Equipped to Face Addiction
description: Afghanistans western border towns with Iran have become veritable zombie villages in recent years  encampments where entire families are shambling addicts.

title: That Other Big Afghan Crisis, the Growing Army of Addicts
description: ISLAM QALA, Afghanistan  The addicts stalk the streets of this border post like hollowed-out skeletons, hair matted by filth and eyes glassy. The villages that hug the roads are veritable zombie towns, where families of men, women and children hide their addiction within barren mud compounds.

title: Marina Gruber, Clayton Nall
description: Marina Cristine Gruber and Clayton Matthew Nall were married Saturday in Stanford, Calif. Joyce Allegro, a retired judge of the Santa Clara County Superior Court, officiated at the Faculty Club of Stanford University.

title: Denise Signorelli and Colin Benn
description: Denise Maria Signorelli and Colin Michael Benn were married Saturday in Naples, Fla. The Rev. Angelia Winn of the nondenominational Springs of Bonita Church in Florida officiated in Eighth Avenue South Park.

title: J. D. McClatchy and Chip Kidd
description: Joseph Donald McClatchy (left) and Charles Iacone Kidd were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, a staff member of the City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Johanna Sourbeer, James Lasser
description: Johanna Nicole Sourbeer and James Lawrence Lasser are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Kaaterskill farm in Catskill, N.Y. Rabbi Harold Kudan is to officiate.

title: Megan Piper, Joseph Incantalupo
description: Megan Katherine Piper and Joseph Charles Incantalupo were married Friday at St. Marys Roman Catholic Church in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Ralph Barile, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Posner, Mark Cognetti
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Posner, a daughter of Holly Jane Posner and Dr. Martin Allan Posner of Larchmont, N.Y., was married Saturday to Mark Anthony Cognetti, a son of Susan Cognetti and Sal Cognetti Jr. of Clarks Green, Pa. The Rev. Leo J. ODonovan, a Roman Catholic priest and former president of Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Church in New York.

title: Paul Hertz, James Rauchman
description: Paul Eric Hertz and James Howard Rauchman were married Saturday in the James Room at Barnard College in New York. Dana Patton,aUniversal Lifeminister, officiated.

title: Rebecca Chesler and Michael Baum
description: Rebecca Faye Chesler, the daughter of Barbara G. Chesler and Evan R. Chesler of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Michael Peter Baum, the son of Barbara Baum and Steven P. Baum of White Plains. Judge Loretta A. Preska of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Kimberly Eisler, Gareth Glaser Jr.
description: Kimberly Fanya Eisler and Gareth Evan Glaser Jr. were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Janet Roberts in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Alexandra Chopivsky and Martn Corredera Silvn
description: Alexandra Natalya Chopivsky and Martn Corredera Silvn were married Friday in the Bishops Garden of the Washington National Cathedral. The Rev. Daniel P. Kane, a priest with the Catholic Dioceses of One Spirit, led a nondenominational ceremony. On Aug. 31, Archbishop Zoria Yevstratiy led a religious ceremony at St. Volodymyrs Ukrainian Orthodox Cathedral, Kiev Patriarchate in Kiev, Ukraine.

title: Katherine Ludlow, Ricardo Palmerola
description: Dr. Katherine Dodge Ludlow was married Saturday in Philadelphia to Dr. Ricardo Ismael Palmerola. The Rev. James F. McAndrews, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Josephs Church.

title: An Age Difference Proves Beneficial
description: Minsuh Son and Joshua Ari Savitch were married Friday by Robert P. Duckworth, the clerk of the Anne Arundel County Circuit Court, who officiated at the courthouse in Annapolis, Md.,

title: Bevin Hill, Daniel Gilmour
description: Bevin Grace Hill and Daniel Peterson Gilmour were married Saturday in Cleveland, Ga. The Rev. Ophelia G. Laughlin, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Neverland Farms, a wedding venue.

title: Christopher Kelly, Neritan Xhaferi
description: Christopher Michael Kelly and Neritan Xhaferi were married Saturday by Mary C. Pugh, a Connecticut justice of the peace, at St. Clements Castle and Marina in Portland, Conn.

title: Timothy Bralczyk, Martin Torre
description: Timothy Stephen Bralczyk and Martin Borromeo Torre were married Saturday at the Alger House, an event space in New York. Leslie C. Petrick, Mr. Bralczyks sister, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: William Reynolds, Daryl Muller
description: William Joseph Reynolds and Daryl Andrew Muller were married Friday in Washington. Barbara Barton Greenberg, an aunt of Mr. Muller who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the District of Columbia War Memorial.

title: Sara Tedeschi, James Psota
description: Dr. Sara Katharine Tedeschi and James Ryan Psota are to be married Sunday at Castle Hill on the Crane Estate in Ipswich, Mass. Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, a friend of the couple, has received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Dinah Denmark, Alice Greene
description: Dinah Marie Denmark and Alice Greene were married Friday in New York. Eileen Koretz, who retired as the supervising judge of New York County Criminal Court, officiated at Judge Koretzs apartment.

title: Caitlin McNamara, Christopher Chalke
description: Caitlin Daly McNamara and Christopher Thomas Chalke were married Saturday evening at St. Aloysius Gonzaga Church in Washington. Bishop Kevin J. Farrell, of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Dallas, performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. John J. Enzler.

title: Did He Make the Doritos? Who Cares
description: Rebecca Sagner Buurma, a daughter of Deborah Sagner of New York and Matthew W. Buurma of Summit, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Lawrence Howard Rappoport, the son of Bernice Rappoport and Kenneth Rappoport of Egg Harbor Township, N.J. Rabbi Julie Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

title: Jessica Sibelman, Erez Davy
description: Jessica Lynn Sibelman and Erez Joseph Davy are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Richard S. Fagan at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Joy Freeman and Drew Freilich
description: Joy Esther Freeman and Dr. Drew Alexander Freilich were married Saturday evening in Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Dan Levin officiated at the Polo Club.

title: Jeffrey Trammell, Stuart Serkin
description: Jeffrey Bevis Trammell and Stuart David Serkin were married Tuesday in Washington. Sandra Day OConnor, the retired associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, officiated at the court.

title: Lucille Sawyer and Jonathan Keller
description: Lucille Kille Sawyer and Jonathan McNeil Keller were married Friday evening at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in Manhattan. Matt Green, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Bitten by the Same Bug
description: Chloe-Valentine Roeder and Adam Carter Roberts were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton in Sarasota, Fla., where Rachel Roberts, a sister of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Gillian Brody, Noah Zachary
description: Gillian Sloane Brody and Noah Joshua Zachary were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, an event space in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Tracy Dugo, John Porges Jr.
description: Tracy Palac Dugo and John Randolph Porges Jr. were married Saturday at Belle Mer, a wedding reception hall in Newport, R.I. Carlo D. Guzman, a cousin of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Alyse Shorland, Kyle Bruno
description: Alyse Renee Shorland and Kyle Christopher Bruno were married Saturday at the Trump Winery in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Truman Bishop Smith, a Baptist minister and a great-uncle of the bride, officiated.

title: Kyong Pak, Andrew Spraggs
description: Kyong Joo Pak and Andrew Laurence Spraggs were married Saturday at Elysian, an event space in Los Angeles. Claire Doyle, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

title: With Rivalry Rejuvenated, Florida State Routs Miami
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  The Florida State crowd, a Doak Campbell Stadium record of 84,409, decided it was going to be impatient, brush off the final month of the season, ignore unbeatens Oregon and Ohio State, and just declare what was on its mind.

title: From Samurai and Cherry Tree
description: The small town of Kakunodate is the only place in the world where cherry bark ware, or kabazaiku, is still made.

title: Samsung Ready to Slowly Lift Veil to Investors
description: TOKYO  Secrecy has served Samsung Electronics well. Keeping its rivals guessing has helped Samsung, the South Korean technology giant, build a formidable lead in the smartphone industry, where it now sells more than one in three handsets worldwide.

title: Londons National Theater Celebrates 50 Years on Stage
description: LONDON  Londons National Theater threw itself a 50th birthday party on Saturday, paying tribute to the storied past of what is arguably the most important address in the English-speaking stage.

title: Egyptians Following Right Path, Kerry Says
description: CAIRO  In the highest-level American visit here since the Egyptian military removed the countrys first democratically elected president from power, Secretary of State John Kerry pressed Egyptian leaders on Sunday to stick to their road map for restoring democracy.

title: Bangladesh Sentences 2 Expatriates to Death for War Crimes
description: NEW DELHI  A war crimes tribunal in Bangladesh on Sunday sentenced two expatriates  one now living in the United States and the other in Britain  to death by hanging for the murder of 18 people described as prominent intellectuals, during the countrys 1971 war of independence from Pakistan.

title: German Surpluses: This Time Is Different
description: Theres a tendency, in discussing Germanys position in world trade, to assume that massive surpluses have always been the German norm  that the countrys high-quality products have always fueled an export engine that inevitably sold much more abroad than Germans bought. But its not true. Heres Germanys current account balance as a percentage of GDP since 1980:

title: Behind Autism and a Tantrum, a Break in a Childs Routine
description: The game plan was simple. My mother Brenda and I were on a shopping trip to buy clothes for Michael, my 4-year-old autistic son, and his 5-year-old sister, B.J., at the PX in West Point, N.Y. I figured 15 minutes, tops, from front door to checkout. Anything longer was courting trouble. I never took both children out unless I had a one-to-one adult-to-child ratio. Yet my mother had limited mobility. She had recently moved in with us after a serious illness. Two months later, my son was given his diagnosis, and since then I had felt torn between taking care of the children and giving my mother the time she needed.

title: In Our Pages: November 4
description: 1913 German Scientist Lauds Americas Aigrette LawBERLINIn prohibiting the importation and wearing of the plumage of live birds, the American Government has enacted an epoch-making legislative measure!

title: To Those Influencing Environmental Policy But Opposed to Nuclear Power
description: Four climate scientists, three of whom have published in peer-reviewed literature on energy issues (a sampler fromWigley, HansenandCaldeira), are pressing the case for environmental groups to embrace the need for a new generation of nuclear power plants in a letter they distributed overnight to a variety of organizations and journalists.

title: Disruptions: Under a New Chief, Yahoo Still Seeks Its Voice
description: In Googles early days, when employees were preparing to release a new project, they had to make a pilgrimage to see Marissa Mayer, employee No. 20, and the head of design and user interface. This was not fun.

title: Bringing Golf to East Harlems Girls
description: It was on the first tee at the Mosholu Golf Course in the Bronx that Teddy Griffith introduced a group of teenage girls to golf.

title: Driver Charged With Negligent Homicide in Death of Boy, 9
description: The red Ford Expedition mounted the sidewalk along DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on Saturday afternoon not once, but twice.

title: First Winner Named in Madonnas Art for Freedom Project
description: Madonna announced on Sunday the first winner in the Art for Freedom online competition that she and Vice, the multimedia company, have established to encourage visual and video artists, photographers and poets to create works that focus on social justice. Madonna has also expanded her partnerships in the project to include the social website Tumblr.

title: Jeptoo Wins in a Sprint From Behind
description: Priscah Jeptoo of Kenya sprinted on the last leg to win the New York City Marathon womens race on Sunday and take the World Marathon Majors series title.

title: Mutai Bides His Time for a Repeat Victory
description: Before the New York City Marathon started Sunday, Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya was the man to watch. He set the course record of 2 hours 5 minutes 6 seconds in 2011 and owned the unofficial world record, set in Boston the same year.

title: Clemency for Snowden? U.S. Officials Say No
description: If Edward J. Snowden believes he deserves clemency for his disclosures of classified government documents because they provoked an important public debate about the reach of American spying, he has failed to sway the White House and at least two key members of Congress.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 7 P.M. (BET) BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Black Girls Rock!, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the emotional development of young black women, joins forces with BET to pay tribute to role models in professional and public service.
