Tracee Ellis Ross and Regina King host this special, taped at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, honoring women in business, politics, entertainment, sports and community service, including Queen Latifah, Patti LaBelle, Venus Williams, Misty Copeland, Marian Wright Edelman and Ameena Matthews. Performers include Ledisi, foreground above, and Jennifer Hudson, Kelly Rowland, Janelle Mone, Sevyn Streeter and Amber Riley.

title: When the Sky Is No Limit
description: There was no way that Julie Taymor was ever going to dream a little Dream. The director who redefined spectacle on Broadway for better (The Lion King) and for worse (Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark) has now given New York a Midsummer Nights Dream that doesnt so much reach for the heavens as roll around in them, with joyous but calculated abandon.

title: Enders Game Is No. 1, With a Caveat
description: Summit Entertainment marketed Enders Game as the motion picture event of the year, but moviegoers  fresh off Gravity and looking ahead to The Hunger Games: Catching Fire  apparently saw through that: Enders Game took in a so-so $28 million at North American theaters over the weekend, winning the box-office race but probably ending studio hopes of introducing a new film franchise. A Summit spokesman called the total solid and in line with the studios preweekend expectations.

title: Are We Too Dependent on Apps?
description: How many times a day do you play a game on your phone, send messages through WhatsApp or Snapchat, post updates on Twitter and Facebook or upload a selfie to Instagram? A dozen? Two dozen?

title: A Midsummer Nights Dream
description: Photos from Julie Taymors production for Theater for a New Audience.

title: Djokovic Rallies Twice Against Ferrer to Win Paris Masters
description: PARIS  The resilient autumn of Novak Djokovic was showcased in microcosmic form Sunday as he twice rallied to defeat David Ferrer, 7-5, 7-5, in the final of the BNP Paribas Masters.

title: 4 Wheelchair Titles in 4 Top Marathons
description: Nothing could stop Tatyana McFaddens race toward a milestone  not the headwind, not the concern about another searing rib injury, not the threat of another crippling flat tire and certainly not the other female wheelchair competitors Sunday in the New York City Marathon. McFadden sped past them all.

title: Rand Paul Muses About Dueling With His Accusers
description: In the 1800s, so many Kentuckians were killing one another in duels that the Legislature saw fit to require that incoming state officeholders swear an oath that they had not fought in a duel, issued a challenge for a duel or assisted at a duel, so help me God.

title: China Strips Army Official of Position After Attack
description: BEIJING  A senior military commander in Chinas restive far west has been stripped of his position on a powerful Communist Party governing body after an attack in the nations capital last week that claimed five lives and deeply unnerved the Chinese leadership.

title: The Changing Geography of Beggar-thy-Neighbor
Power Plants Try Burning Wood With Coal to Cut Carbon Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the Environmental Protection Agency considers requiring existing coal-fired power plants to cut their carbon dioxide output, some utilities have started to use a decidedly low-tech additive that accomplishes that goal: wood.

title: Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Seem
description: Americans spend an estimated $5 billion a year on unproven herbal supplements that promise everything from fighting off colds to curbing hot flashes and boosting memory. But now there is a new reason for supplement buyers to beware: DNA tests show that many pills labeled as healing herbs are little more than powdered rice and weeds.

title: When Socrates Met Phaedrus: Eros in Philosophy
description: Crazy Hot

title: Senate Vote on Workplace Bias Against Gays Poses a Test for the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  A major test of how carefully Republicans can navigate the intraparty politics of sexuality will come on Monday, when the Senate holds a crucial vote on a bill to outlaw workplace discrimination against gay men, lesbians and transgender people.

title: The Difference Four Days Can Make
description: Television networks would prefer ratings that include those who view a recorded show up to seven days after it airs as opposed to the current standard of three days. On these shows, the extra days would result in a measure that boosted the audience by a million viewers, on average.

title: Colorado Is Asking Taxpayers for $1 Billion to Help Schools
description: DENVER  In one poor school district in Colorados San Luis Valley, students take classes in a bus garage, using plastic sheeting to keep the diesel fumes at bay. In another, there is no more money to tutor young immigrants struggling to read. And just south of Denver, a district where one in four kindergartners is homeless has cut 10 staff positions and is bracing for another cull.

title: Error-Free Jets Outrun Saints
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It has been like this for the Jets every week for the last two months, whether on the banks of the Ohio River or in a dome in Atlanta or in a Boston suburb, so on Sunday, it had to be that way again: They walked into a stadium and, for three hours, transformed it into one of the most interesting places in town.

title: Sharing a Heritage, a Home and a Way With Words
description: The Celtic oral tradition merges with snapshots of old Manhattan  and old Dublin  in Eamon Morrisseys engrossing one-man show Maeves House, at the Irish Arts Center. The woman of the title is Maeve Brennan, the Irish writer whose short stories and Talk of the Town items, often written under the nom de plume the Long-Winded Lady, filled pages at The New Yorker for about 30 years, beginning in 1949. Mr. Morrisseys play recites passages from some of her work and recalls his familys links with Brennan as well.

title: Epic TV Series Aims to Celebrate China-Myanmar Ties
description: The first-ever television series jointly produced by China and Myanmar  a 40-episode epic depicting the adventures of a ninth-century Burmese prince who travels to the Tang dynasty imperial court with his famed dancing troupe  has wrapped up filming and is scheduled for broadcast next year.

title: Elections Today
description: Tuesday is Election Day, and voters across the region will elect local and state officials and will decide the fate of proposed constitutional amendments.

title: Short Peeks Backstage at New York City Ballet
description: What does it really take to be a dancer in New York City Ballet? In city.ballet., a new web series to be released on Monday by AOL On Originals, key ingredients are strength, grit, talent and perseverance. Having a life outside ballet is not a bad idea. And when all else fails, reach for the wine. After a recent performance of Swan Lake, the principal dancer Teresa Reichlen confesses, she kind of had two dinners, half a bottle of wine and  she adds with a sheepish smile  a margarita, and thats it. Thats it!

title: Camp Classic
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  The Monday through Thursday puzzles this week appeared last Saturday at the Arlington Puzzle Festival in Arlington, Va. A report on the 2012 festival is posted here and the 2013 results should be posted soon.

title: Recovery on the Roads
description: Since losing a leg while serving in Afghanistan, Alfredo De Los Santos has become a national champion in the handcycle marathon.

title: A Night of Revivals With Fokine, Tharp and Morris
description: All three works shown on Friday by American Ballet Theater at the David H. Koch Theater were making welcome returns to the companys repertory after too-long absences. All three were pure dance; they made marvelously diverse fare. The opener was Michel Fokines Les Sylphides (1909), which used to be a signature work for Ballet Theater through most of its first five decades; when Fokine staged it for this company in 1940, it was his final version of what was already a classic. This revival was followed on Friday by two ballets created for this troupe: Twyla Tharps Bach Partita (1983) and Mark Morriss Gong (2001).

title: A Veterans Path to Recovery by Marathon Racing
description: A light mist covered the hilly roads by Alfredo De Los Santoss neighborhood in Hopewell Junction, N.Y., last week. The streets of his tidy development were quiet and deserted, except for Freddie, as he likes to be called, whizzing along the rain-slicked road, intensely pumping his handcycle.

title: Solemn Panorama of Battle
description: Graphic novelists tend to be a little neurotic and obsessive, but in that fraternity, Joe Sacco has long been regarded as an exception. For one thing, Mr. Sacco, whose new book, The Great War, comes out on Monday, is completely well adjusted. Of all of us, hes far and away the most normal, his colleague Art Spiegelman said recently. Mr. Sacco laughed when told of this and said, Im not sure thats a good thing or not.

title: Voices Raised for Peace, With Noh and Manga
description: Looking for new frontiers in opera has become a full-time preoccupation for some observers, critics and fans alike. Its disappointing, then, that War Sum Up, presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Howard Gilman Opera House as part of the Next Wave Festival on Friday night, had just two engagements. A stimulating multidisciplinary, pan-cultural creation mounted by the Danish arts laboratory Hotel Pro Forma, the show was just the kind of thing that could get adventuresome opera lovers thinking and talking.

title: Tug of War Stretches Architects Legacy
description: When Luis Barragn, considered by many to be Mexicos greatest architect, died in 1988, he left a scattering of gemlike private houses and public works around Mexico City and Guadalajara, his hometown. But an important part of his legacy  his professional archive and the copyright to designs and images of much of his work  ended up thousands of miles from his native land.

title: Rebelling With Global Beats and WikiLeaks
description: Not every dance party starts  as did M.I.A.s show on Friday night at Terminal 5  with a live video transmission from Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, urging a sold-out crowd to fight the military occupation of cyberspace. Mr. Assange called M.I.A. the most courageous woman working in Western music and prescient. He cited lyrics from The Message, a song M.I.A. released in 2010 with the lines iPhone connected to the Internet/Connected to the Google/Connected to the government, and added, It turns out she was right.

title: A Spider-Man Caper Full of Broadway Characters, All of Them Real
description: Its unseemly to take pleasure in any creative failure. Artists strive and struggle all the time, and those who refuse to court the possibility of humiliation probably arent trying hard enough. If the sound of somebodys well-intentioned work going splat makes you happy, perhaps you should seek worthier targets for your schadenfreude.

title: Ex-Bassist for the Grateful Dead Strikes a Deal
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y.  Phil Lesh has logged countless miles on the road as the bassist of the Grateful Dead and, since the late 1990s, in various post-Dead ensembles. But at 73, he is looking for a change.

title: New Details Emerge About Tainted Gallery
description: The art forger Ken Perenyi remembers Anthony Masaccio as a practiced partner in the sale of fake paintings, a man with movie-star looks and the nickname Tony Cha Cha who mingled with models and artists in the back room of Andy Warhols hangout Maxs Kansas City during the 1970s.

title: Art Found in Germany Linked to Nazi Looting
description: Works by Matisse, Picasso and Chagall are said to be among a collection of 1,500 pieces of art found in Munich, according to BBC News and the German magazine Focus. The works were reportedly confiscated by the Nazis during the 1930s and 40s and, if confirmed as genuine, would be among the largest recoveries of looted art with a possible value over $1.3 billion. The stockpile was discovered by chance in 2011, when tax investigators obtained a warrant to search the home of Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of the art dealer Hildebrand Gurlitt. There are international warrants out for at least 200 pieces in the collection, which is being stored in a secured warehouse in Munich. It is unclear why the discovery was not publicly reported until now. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum estimates that the Nazis seized about 16,000 works of art in all, according to BBC News.

title: Distance Swimmer Has a Book Deal
description: Diana Nyad, the 64-year-old whose quest to swim from Cuba to Florida captivated the world, has struck a deal to write a memoir. Knopf, the publisher of Sheryl Sandberg, Alice Munro and Nathan Englander, acquired the memoir, calling it a book about her life in and out of the water. Jordan Pavlin, executive editor at Knopf, will edit the book.

title: ABC Extends the Lives of Some New Sitcoms
description: ABC has announced the short-term fates of its remaining freshman comedies, with The Goldbergs and Trophy Wife both receiving full-season orders. Super Fun Night, which stars Rebel Wilson, received an additional order of only four episodes, setting the show up to be replaced at some point later in the season. Another new comedy, Back in the Game starring James Caan, did not receive an additional episode order, leaving its future in doubt after its initial 13-episode order is completed. The vote of confidence for Trophy Wife was something of a surprise, considering its ratings have been the lowest out of the four shows through the early part of the season. The other three have been on fairly equal ground in terms of viewership, but none could be qualified as hits. The Goldbergs has averaged 6.1 million total viewers; Super Fun Night 6.4 million; Back in the Game 6.7 million; Trophy Wife has averaged 4.7 million.

title: The Tallest, Richest Additions to the Skyline
description: Three residential buildings under construction in Manhattan are so tall that they will be instant landmarks. And apartments inside are selling for record amounts.

title: Amnesty Bill That Would Clear Ousted Premier Stirs Thai Anger
description: BANGKOK  The Thai government is facing growing anger among its own supporters as well as protests by an emboldened opposition over a far-reaching amnesty bill that could allow former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to return home by wiping clean corruption cases against him.

title: Gift Books for Your Favorite Bridge Player
description: As we continue our look at bridge gift books published this year, we come to those for intermediate players looking to better their game.

title: From Baby Einstein to Baby Austen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Crossing the Border, and Into Federal Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking More Pay for Delayed Play
description: In 2007, faced with the growing popularity of digital video recorders, advertisers agreed to pay television networks for commercials viewed within three days of a shows first broadcast.

title: Gang Rape in India
description: To the Editor:

title: Kansas School Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating in Cemeteries
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankee Fans, This Is for You
description: To the Editor:

title: The Value of Head Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk to Iran, It Works
description: There were high expectations after President Obama and Irans president, Hassan Rouhani, talked on the phone in late September. Those hoping for a diplomatic resolution to the nuclear standoff were excited that a breakthrough was imminent; meanwhile, some American allies, like Israel and Saudi Arabia, expressed deep skepticism over a potential American rapprochement with Iran.

title: Start-Up to Offer Didion E-Books
description: The start-up Zola Books is trying to persuade book buyers to flock to its website, a hybrid that is designed to be a bookseller, curator and social-networking site all in one.

title: New Leaders for Bucks County Playhouse
description: Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., has announced that Robyn Goodman will be the theaters new executive producer and that Alexander Fraser will be the new producing director. They will assume their roles in January, after the departure of Jed Bernstein, who is set to become the next president of Lincoln Center. Ms. Goodman is the lead producer of Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella on Broadway. She was also the producer of the Broadway runs of Avenue Q and In the Heights. Mr. Frasers recent credits include serving as an associate producer on the Chicago staging of Kinky Boots and the Broadway production of The Normal Heart.

title: Doctor, First Tell Me What It Costs
description: DURHAM, N.C.  IF an antibiotic would cure your infection, your doctor would probably still warn you about the chance of sun sensitivity before prescribing the pill.

title: Frank Wess, 91, Saxophonist and Flutist With the Basie Band, Dies
description: Frank Wess, who helped popularize the flute as a jazz instrument in the 1950s and 60s with the Count Basie Orchestra, where he was also a standout saxophone soloist, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Mexico's Soda Pop Ploy
description: My first job out of college, in 1983, was working for Coca-Cola. The training, which lasted a month, was the same for everyone: all day in a truck, making deliveries, mostly to rural areas. We would leave before dawn and return as the sun was setting. We delivered soft drinks to churches and whorehouses. We went to places that didnt appear on any map, where there were no roads beyond the tracks left by trucks like ours. We went where the government didnt go, where there were no hospitals, no schools and sometimes even no running water.

title: A New Publisher for Playbill
description: It seems as if Bruce Hallett will work only for magazines with instantly identifiable covers.

title: Brands Align With the Mustachioed Month of Movember
description: IN November 2011, executives at Just for Men, the hair color brand, noticed an inexplicable surge in Canada for sales of its facial-hair line, Mustache & Beard. The brand had done no special advertising or promotion, and yet Canadian sales were up 30 percent over the month before, and up slightly in the United States as well.

title: Sub-Elite Runners Chase Improvement
description: Greg Cass crossed the finish line in 2 hours 36 minutes 33 seconds, his lifetime earnings from distance running holding steady at $75.

title: Reflecting on a Dream, and Preparing to Move On
description: Lets first get a few things out of the way, like any there she is clichs you may be entertaining, or smirking asides about how world peace must be her idea of deep thought.

title: Ads Scant When Twitter Crosses Borders
description: BERLIN  From Manila to Madrid, international consumers now represent more than three-quarters of the 232 million people who regularly use Twitter.

title: Walt Bellamy, Hall of Famer Traded by the Knicks, Dies at 74
description: Walt Bellamy, the Hall of Fame center who was among the leading N.B.A. scorers and rebounders of his time but who was remembered as well for being traded away by the Knicks for Dave DeBusschere in a final step toward their first championship season, died on Saturday. He was 74.

title: In Rodriguez Arbitration, Two Sides Play Hardball
description: A trainer for Alex Rodriguez was shopping in Times Square with his wife and three young children one recent Saturday when he was followed into Toys R Us. A man working on behalf of Major League Baseball approached and handed him some paperwork. It was a subpoena to testify against Mr. Rodriguez.

title: Neighborhood Numbers: Sheepshead Bay
description: VOTING AGE CITIZENS 46,767

title: An Event for the Elite and the Average Alike
description: Welcome back. The New York City Marathon had to be canceled in 2012 after the killer storm Sandy invaded the region, and Sundays marathon was shadowed by the memory of shrapnel murderously exploding across Boylston Street in Boston last April. But back they came, the elite whippets near the front, the more standard human body types massed in the back  two races in one.

title: The Appearance of Impartiality
Day After Throwing 160 Pitches, Tanaka Closes Japan Series Clincher
description: One day after he threw 160 pitches in a complete-game loss in Game 6 of the Japan Series on Saturday, Masahiro Tanaka went back to the mound and threw 15 more pitches to get the save in Game 7.

title: Lonely Advocate for Restraint in Egypt Tiptoes Around Talk of Compromise
description: CAIRO  The news agency headline last week seemed harmless enough, perhaps even flattering. It paraphrased an Egyptian cabinet minister saying that his government and its opponent, the Muslim Brotherhood, should pursue reconciliation.

title: Stratospheric Views, and Prices
description: Walking slowly to the windows facing the meadow of green that is Central Park, Gary Barnett slips into salesman mode as he spreads his arms wide, embracing the sweeping birds-eye view he has from the 87th floor of his shimmering skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Buildings for Billionaires
description: A new crop of ultra-luxurious New York high rises are vying to be the next hot it building and are attracting billionaires from nearby as well as abroad.

title: Diverse Neighborhood Has Mixed Enthusiasm About New York City Mayors Race
description: The last presidential candidate Steve Waldman voted for was Hubert H. Humphrey. The last mayor he cast a ballot for was Edward I. Koch. And hell be darned if he is going to break his nonvoting streak by partaking in the mayoral election on Tuesday.

title: Security Noticeable at First and Then a Blur
description: As the elite runners came down the final 150 yards of the New York City Marathon, and the finish line came into focus, the crowd on either side of them erupted in cheers, blowing horns, ringing bells and clapping inflatable sticks. They passed several police officers and four bomb-sniffing dogs sitting in the middle of the street and an officer wearing an N.Y.P.D. hat and wielding a video camera. Just beyond the finish line, to the side, were more officers and more dogs.

title: Disney and Dish Wrangle Not Over Broadcast Fees, but the Future of TV
description: A sweeping distribution deal between television giants, the Walt Disney Company and Dish Network, expired more than a month ago, and there is still no new deal in sight.

title: Obama Campaigns for Terry McAuliffe
description: Ahead of Tuesday's election, President Obama campaigned in Arlington alongside Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia.

title: Breakneck Pace a Certainty in Duel Between Sixers and Warriors
description: Each week during the N.B.A. season, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue.

title: In Pakistan, Drone Strike Turns a Villain Into a Victim
description: LONDON  In life, Hakimullah Mehsud, the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, was Public Enemy No. 1: a ruthless figure who devoted his career to bloodshed and mayhem, whom Pakistani pundits occasionally accused of being a pawn of Indian, or even American, intelligence.

title: Moving Moments Send Shivers, Both Good and Bad
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  There were awe-inspiring moments aplenty, like Magician moving like a John Deere tractor as he mowed down rivals in the lane of the Breeders Cup Turf to give European horses their fifth victory of these world championships. Or Wise Dan, the reigning horse of the year, showing why he should retain that title with a last-to-first rush in the Turf Mile that was as breathtaking as it was powerful.

title: Both Sides Invoke Obama in Climax of Virginia Governors Race
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  To motivate voters, Virginias bitter rivals for governor reached out to the same figure on the weekend before Election Day: President Obama.

title: Its the Golden Age of News
description: OVER the past 20 years, to loud laments from media veterans, American news organizations have retreated from the costly business of foreign coverage  closing bureaus, slashing space and airtime. Yet for the curious reader with a sense of direction, this is a time of unprecedented bounty.

title: Romney Sees Christie as Potential G.O.P. Savior in 16
description: Mitt Romney said on Sunday that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey could be the Republican nominee for president in 2016 and could save our party, comments that appeared to contradict reports that Mr. Romneys presidential campaign had been concerned about Mr. Christies health.

title: Those Depressing Germans
description: German officials are furious at America, and not just because of the business about Angela Merkels cellphone. What has them enraged now is one (long) paragraph in a U.S. Treasury report on foreign economic and currency policies. In that paragraph Treasury argues that Germanys huge surplus on current account  a broad measure of the trade balance  is harmful, creating a deflationary bias for the euro area, as well as for the world economy.

title: Under Health Care Act, Millions Eligible for Free Policies
description: Millions of people could qualify for federal subsidies that will pay the entire monthly cost of some health care plans being offered in the online marketplaces set up under President Obamas health care law, a surprising figure that has not garnered much attention, in part because the zero-premium plans come with serious trade-offs.

title: A Prayer in the Town Hall
description: The wall between church and state is one of the most powerful and enduring images in American law, but as a metaphor it fails to capture the complicated and porous relationship most Americans have to the expression of religion in public life.

title: Arrest of the Avalanches Goalie Casts a Shadow on a Promising Season
description: DENVER  During their drive to Pepsi Center, there was much shimmering ground for two Colorado Avalanche fans to cover: the poise and production of the teams 18-year-old rookie forward, Nathan MacKinnon; the inspired play of the defense; the mad genius of the first-year coach, Patrick Roy. And yet, as Keith Martin and his son-in-law drove to the Avalanches game here Saturday night against the Montreal Canadiens, they spoke mostly of the dark cloud shadowing the teams resurgence.

title: Congress Can Help on Iran
description: It is crucial that Congress work constructively with President Obama as he tries to lead the way in negotiating a nuclear agreement with Iran. But some lawmakers are so suspicious of Iran and so blindly committed to more sanctions that they could sabotage the best opportunity in years for a peaceful resolution of an issue that has long blocked any fundamental improvement in relations between the two countries while complicating the prospects for stability in the Middle East.

title: Marijuana and Alcohol
description: Americans are growing more comfortable with marijuana, with 58 percent favoring legalization, according to the latest Gallup poll. At the same time, some researchers believe they have identified a side benefit to increasing availability of the drug: It could lead to decreased consumption of alcohol among young people.

title: Add a Dollar an Hour in New Jersey
description: Ideally, Congress would raise the federal minimum wage above the paltry $7.25 an hour. But since there is little chance of that happening soon, it is up to the states to provide relief for low-wage workers. Nineteen states and the District of Columbia have so far increased the minimum wage above the federal level. Tuesday will be New Jerseys chance to do the same.

title: Outside Money at Issue in Boston Mayors Race as Labor Unions Weigh In
description: BOSTON  With Bostons first competitive mayors race in three decades going down to the wire, John R. Connolly has seized on the issue of outside labor support for his opponent, Martin J. Walsh.

title: To Shape Young Palestinians, Hamas Creates Its Own Textbooks
description: GAZA CITY  When a class of Palestinian ninth graders in Gaza recently discussed the deadly 1929 riots over access to the Western Wall in Jerusalem, it was guided by a new textbook, introduced this fall by the Islamist Hamas movement.

title: SAC Nears an Insider Trading Guilty Plea, but Legal Cases Arent Shut
description: The criminal case against the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors has reached a conclusion, people briefed on the matter said, with the government expected to announce Monday that SAC will plead guilty to insider trading charges and pay a fine of roughly $1.2 billion.

title: End of Casino Partnership Leaves Fate of East Boston Racetrack in Doubt
description: BOSTON  Suffolk Downs, a famed but fading thoroughbred racetrack in the neighborhood of East Boston, had dreams of a major revitalization, and when the state approved casinos in 2011, it partnered with the Caesars Entertainment Corporation to apply for the sole casino license that would be awarded in the greater Boston area.

title: Irans Top Leader and U.S. Counter Criticism of Talks
description: TEHRAN  With talks over Irans nuclear program set to resume in Geneva this week, both sides engaged in a bit of public diplomacy Sunday: Irans supreme leader moved to quiet hard-liners in his country by expressing support for his negotiating team, while the chief American negotiator reiterated in an Israeli television interview that no deal is better than a bad deal.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 3, 2013
At Marathon, Security Wins
description: When Krista Powell boarded a ferry at the southern tip of Manhattan early Sunday to head to the starting line of her first New York City Marathon, she expected to spend some quiet moments taking in the citys skyline. Then she looked to her left.

title: Time Travel and Time Steps: Tapping Into Harlem History
description: The band takes the last bow in After Midnight, the sparkling new jazz revue that opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Sunday night. This may be unusual for Broadway, where the players are normally in the pit  and the music often sounds as if it could have been piped in from Hong Kong  but its entirely as it should be.

title: News From the Advertising Industry for the Week of Nov. 4
description: Accounts

title: Nets Hit Depths 2 Days After Conquering the Heights
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Victor Oladipo stripped the ball from Deron Williams at midcourt, and as nine other players watched from the other end, he frolicked the length of the floor, elevated to the rim and finished a 360-degree, two-handed dunk.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 4
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Koch Group Has Ambitions in Small Races
description: CORALVILLE, Iowa  Election seasons in this small eastern Iowa town are usually cordial affairs. But this year, a group backed by the billionaire Koch brothers has changed that.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 4
description: BLACKBERRY Shareholders of BlackBerry will learn on Monday if Fairfax Financial Holdings, which owns about 10 percent of the beleaguered smartphone maker, will transform a tentative offer for the company into a formal bid. Fairfax is conditionally offering $9 a share, valuing BlackBerry at about $4.7 billion, but it is unclear if it has raised enough money to make a firm offer. A group made up of BlackBerrys co-founders, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, as well as Qualcomm, which makes the chips inside BlackBerry phones, and the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management may also make a bid as soon as Monday.

title: A Few Paces From the Race, a Starting Line for Girls in Basketball
description: On marathon Sunday, crowds lining Lafayette Avenue in Brooklyn cheered enthusiastically as wave after wave of runners passed by.

title: European Borders Tested as Money Is Moved to Shield Wealth
description: PARIS  There was nothing extraordinary about the casually dressed businessman waiting on a Paris train platform except, it turned out, for the envelopes he carried  stuffed with 350,000 euros in cash, and seized by French customs agents as he prepared to depart for Belgium.

title: Saints High-Octane Offense Sputters
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Quarterback Drew Brees understands that the cadence of the New Orleans Saints offense is precious, not just for each individual play, but for the course of an entire game. When the offense is in rhythm, the team scores a plethora of points, and opponents are left helpless.

title: Fire Began in Living Room, and I Couldnt Help Him
description: It was not love at first sight.

title: Top 2 Candidates Vow to Make City Hall More Faith-Friendly
description: Muslims want to add holidays to the school calendar. Christians are pressing to use school gyms and auditoriums for worship. Ultra-Orthodox Jews are demanding that the city stop regulating an ancient circumcision rite.

title: Popular Demand
description: In an age when every baseball game is on television and some are streamed to mobile devices, radio audiences are dwindling, but the audience jumped at the end of the season.

title: East German Model City Rusts, Quarter-Century After Berlin Walls Fall
description: EISENHTTENSTADT, Germany  For a little while, at least, Tom Hanks put Eisenhttenstadt back on the map.

title: A B.C.S. Logjam, Possibly, to End Them All
description: For those who wish the college football playoff would start this year instead of next season, welcome to Week 11. This is when three games laden with Bowl Championship Series implications will help clear a logjam of undefeated teams atop the rankings or bolster the likelihood that at least three will finish the season without a loss.

title: Referendum on Casinos Stirs Hopes in Tiny Town
description: NICHOLS, N.Y.  Sitting on a temperamental bend of the Susquehanna River, this upstate New York town is not exactly Las Vegas, with little to offer visitors other than some baseball diamonds, a couple of bars and a Main Street that dead-ends at an excavation company.

title: The Sloth Effect
description: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Tapping Medical Marijuanas Potential
description: Marijuana has been used medically, recreationally and spiritually for about 5,000 years. Known botanically as cannabis, it has been called a crude drug: marijuana contains more than 400 chemicals from 18 chemical families. More than 2,000 compounds are released when it is smoked, and as with tobacco, there are dangers in smoking it.

title: Loves Improbable Shot for Timberwolves Spoils Knicks Rally
description: The Knicks avoided Kevin Love last season. He missed the Minnesota Timberwolves first game against the Knicks because of an eye injury, and he missed the second after having surgery on his right hand. His team lost both contests without him.

title: Red Bulls Blow Lead and Settle for Draw
description: After a workout on Friday at the teams training complex, Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke, with a smile, sidestepped the inevitable question: Would a tie at Houston in the first-game of a home-and-home playoff series suffice?

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 4, 2013
description: To see a huge gun on the boat next to us, that wasnt expected. It was kind of drastic, but, unfortunately, its just what has to be done after people destroy an event for other people.

title: The China Dream
description: Trouble on the way to paradise.

title: A Race Through the City
description: Tens of thousands of New York City Marathon participants crossed through all five boroughs, filling streets and bridges, and drawing crowds of supporters.

title: Supporters Caustic Remark Spices Up Mayoral Campaigns Final Days
description: Joseph J. Lhota spent the final Sunday of his flailing mayoral candidacy seemingly liberated from the burdens of a competitive campaign.

title: Going Back to Basics
description: The Jets were not flashy, but they churned out 198 rushing yards and protected the ball to beat the Saints.

title: Jets Close-Up
description: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE Trailing by 26-17 midway through the fourth quarter, New Orleans went for it on a fourth-and-inches at the Jets 36. The Saints, with all their offensive talent, handed the ball off to tight end Josh Hill on a misdirection play. Jets linebacker Quinton Coples thundered in and stopped Hill for an 8-yard loss. Coples said that he had not seen the play on film but that you cant be surprised by anything.

title: A Student at N.Y.U. Is Rescued From a Shaft
description: A 19-year-old New York University student whose friends said he had been missing since early Saturday was rescued Sunday evening from a narrow shaft sandwiched between two buildings in TriBeCa.

title: With Alpha House, Amazon Makes Bid for Living Room Screens and Beyond
description: Not long ago, I was on the set of a show about politics, Washington and a senator gone rogue. The set had all the trappings of a big-time television production, but it will be delivered not by broadcast or cable, but over the Internet by a technology company that has not historically been in the business of original productions.

title: Word of the Day | junta
description: junta \hun-t, jn-, hn-\ noun

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (13) LOU REED: ROCK AND ROLL HEART (1998) The director Timothy Greenfield-Sanders tours Mr. Reeds career, from his days with the Velvet Underground and denizen of Warhols Factory to his solo work and collaboration with Robert Wilson. The film also touches on dark side of Mr. Reed, above, but is careful to note that he has gone past all that, Caryn James wrote in The New York Times about this American Masters presentation. And though the documentary takes too much at face value, Mr. Reed himself sounds more sophisticated about how public image and reality bleed together. Im not remotely really like the Lou Reed character that I managed to make on record, although after a while I thought he was so cool that I thought it might be fun to be him, so I did, he says. He later points out that in the 80s he married and started going to A.A. Having cleaned up his act no doubt certifies him as PBS ready. Mr. Reed died at 71 on Oct. 27.

title: Giving Awards, Raggedly
description: If you believe in awards, you believe in importance, in hierarchies, in arcs of triumph that take you from the bottom to the top. An award says you matter. An awards show is not only a celebration of excellence, but also of people who believe in the system.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 28-Nov. 3
description: Eye-hand coordination is a critical element of sports. Then again, sometime the hands seem to act on their own.

title: Corrections: November 4, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: News Quiz | November 4, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: In Remote Village, Chinas Leader Faces Awkward Question: Who Are You?
description: It must have been a slightly uncomfortable moment for the village official.

title: Let My Bicycle Go
description: Dear Diary:

title: One Place Where the U.S. Can Rest Easy About Chinas Influence?
description: The bond between China and Pakistan is often called as high as the highest peaks, as deep as the deepest ocean. When things are going well, the proximity phrase  as close as lips and teeth  is thrown in, with winces on both sides.

title: Egypts Ex-President Is Defiant at Murder Trial
description: CAIRO  Held incommunicado for the four months since his overthrow as president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood walked into a makeshift courtroom on Monday for his new role as a defendant in a murder trial.

title: Take Me to the River
description: In Erica McDonalds imagination, normal folks doing their laundry become hardy trekkers hauling their cumbersome loads across a concrete plain looking for somewhere to clean their clothes. She sees them as victims of industrial prosperity, where a built-over landscape obliterates rivers and forces the sherpas on a search for man-made oases for washing. To carry out her vision, Ms. McDonald, a New York-based art and documentary photographer and founder of Develop Photo, an online photo educational resource, followed real-life strangers to and from the Laundromat  some quite a ways away.

title: HSBC Profit Rises; Bank Is Cooperating With Foreign Exchange Inquiry
description: LONDON  HSBC, Britains biggest bank, said on Monday that third-quarter earnings rose 10 percent from the period a year earlier, helped by its cost-reduction program.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Nov. 4, 2013
description: Before Taking the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Not Monsters, But Really Big Fish, Found in California
description: In the article Oarfish Offer Chance to Study an Elusive Animal Long Thought a Monster, Douglas Quenqua reports on two big fish that washed up on California shores in recent weeks.

title: Whod Import Pigs to Israel? Ancient Europeans, Researchers Say
description: JERUSALEM  Israel may not be the most obvious place to study pigs, given that religious strictures in both Judaism and Islam forbid their consumption.

title: What Personal Essay Topic Would You Assign to College Applicants?
description: Influential figures, obstacles overcome, dreams for the futurethese are common topics for college application essays.

title: Week 9 N.F.L. Quick Hits: Gronkowski at His Best
description: Patriots 55, Steelers 31

title: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Moss on Getting People to Eat Their Vegetables
description: Michael Moss, a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative reporter for The Times, wrote an article for this weeks health issue about creating an effective marketing campaign for broccoli. His last article for the magazine, about the processed-food industry, was adapted from his book, Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us.

title: New York Today: A Losing Tradition
description: Updated 12:05 p.m. | Candidates trailing in the polls usually tell you not to trust the numbers.

title: Changing Style in Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  Sting had Hollywoods finest up on their feet and dancing when he performed at the Art and Film Gala in Los Angeles on Saturday. But there was no pushy paparazzi or frenetic public cheering and flourishing cellphone cameras, as music, film and art stars from Mary J. Blige, through Jane Fonda and Jake Gyllenhaal, to the art dealers Larry Gagosian and Dasha Zhukova gathered at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art for its third annual fund-raising gala.

title: Ryanair Cuts Its Annual Outlook for the Second Time in Two Months
description: PARIS  Ryanair, the European budget airline, slashed its annual profit forecast for the second time in two months on Monday, reflecting the intensifying scramble for passengers among airlines, particularly in Western Europe, at a time of high unemployment and stalled economic growth.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 4, 2013
description: Update: Nov. 5, 2013

title: Daily Report: Twitter Looks to Increase Ad Revenue Beyond U.S.
description: From Manila to Madrid, international consumers now represent more than three-quarters of the 232 million people who regularly use Twitter. The problem is, Twitter is still figuring out how to make money from those users abroad. The company received 26 percent of its total revenue from markets outside the United States in the third quarter, compared with around 17 percent at the end of last year, according to regulatory filings, Mark Scott reports.

title: The War on Cancer: From Nixon Until Now
description: When President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act many expected quick results, comparing the effort to the one that put man on the moon. After 42 years, what progress have we made?

title: Hopeful Glimmers in Long War on Cancer
description: This weeks Retro Report video examines the war on cancer  a federal research initiative authorized by President Richard M. Nixon in 1971. Many anticipated quick results, in part because of the public relations campaign, complete with ads suggesting we could cure cancer by the bicentennial, that successfully pushed Mr. Nixon into making the commitment.

title: Hedge Funds Plan Proxy Battle for ValueVision Media
description: Two activist hedge funds, the Clinton Group and Cannell Capital, have joined forces to mount a proxy battle for control of the Internet and television shopping network ValueVision Media.

title: New Options for Small Businesses Looking to Go Paperless
description: Academics predicted the rise of a paperless society decades ago. Were not there yet, but at least on the small-business front, were getting closer. In fact, a host of new tools have arrived recently, including Shake, an app platform that allows users tocreate, sign and send legally binding agreements from theirsmartphones; Zipmark, a digital checkbook; and SimpleScan, a mobile scanner and document management system that integrates with cloud apps used by small businesses.

title: Home Builders to Merge in $2.7 Billion Deal
description: Tri Pointe Homes, the West Coast builder controlled by Barry S. Sternlichts Starwood Capital, is merging with the home-building subsidiary of Weyerhaeuser, a large owner of timberlands, in a deal valued at $2.7 billion.

title: What Will a New Army Chief Mean for Pakistan and the Neighborhood?
description: Since it was announced last month that Pakistans army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, would be retiring, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has kept the country dangling on his choice, creating a new parlor game for the chattering classes in the process. General Kayani has been characteristically mum, except for an unusual press release that said he was leaving the office on Nov. 29, without closing out other options, even as he accepted the concurrent role of chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: In Providence, a Hipster Hotel in a Former Brothel
description: It was only a matter of time before Providence, R.I., long a petri dish for eggheads, design wunderkinds and culinary aspirants, would get its very own vintage-y, self-consciously cool hotel. The Dean, 52 rooms housed in a historic building from 1911 that was once a brothel, reflects the states bookish and somewhat gritty impulses toward homegrown authenticity. The lodgings original mosaic tile flooring is intact, as is the old-timey brick facade, and rooms are furnished mostly with flea market finds. While the hotels name is an ode to the areas academic community  its close to R.I.S.D. and Brown University  its arrival signals Providences continued cultural renaissance outside campus gates.

title: In Poll, Many Chinese Angry at Perceived U.S. Media Bias
description: Lawyers might call it a leading question, one that would possibly be ruled out of order in a court of law: How do you feel about the American media repeatedly putting out malicious views of China?

title: Report of Nazi-Looted Trove Puts Art World in an Uproar
description: BERLIN  There was no hint that the older man who called a couple of years back about selling a picture could be sitting on an unimaginable trove of art confiscated or banned by the Nazis. When the proffered work, Lion Tamer by the German artist Max Beckmann, was collected, the seller seemed to be a proper gentleman in Munich dispensing with a lone, dusty art gem at the end of his life.

title: Militant Attack Kills Seven in Assam
description: NEW DELHI  At least seven members of the Rabha tribe were gunned down during Diwali celebrations in the northeastern state of Assam, killed by militants from a rival tribe, the state police said Monday.

title: In Our Pages: November 5
description: 1938 Hitler Plays Godfather

title: A Takeover Bid for BlackBerry Collapses, and Its Chief Executive Vacates His Post
description: Updated, 9:06 p.m. | OTTAWA  A tentative takeover bid for BlackBerry from its largest shareholder collapsed on Monday, clouding the immediate future of the company.

title: Pakistan Court Grants Bail to Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A court in Islamabad granted bail to the former military leader Pervez Musharraf, his lawyer said Monday, in a case related to his role in the 2007 siege of a mosque where the army fought militants holed up inside the compound.

title: Epic Fail: The Business Edition
description: BlackBerry is just the latest example where a promising company falls in love with its own product while missing the signs that consumers are destined to move on.

title: Twitter Raises Price Range for Its I.P.O.
description: Twitter is feeling more optimistic about investor appetite for its imminent initial public offering.

title: Issue of Prayer Returns to the Court
description: WASHINGTON  Thirty years ago, a state senator and a Presbyterian minister faced off in the Supreme Court over whether the Nebraska Legislature could open its sessions with a prayer. The court said yes, siding with the minister, and for three decades that settled matters. Such prayers are commonplace.

title: Violence Mars Election in Kosovo
description: PARIS  The future of a landmark power-sharing agreement between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in Kosovo was called into doubt on Monday after local elections in Kosovo over the weekend were blighted by violence and intimidation by people suspected of being Serbian hard-liners.

title: A Tale of Two Fed Presidents
description: Props to Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Richmond Fed, for admitting that he has been wrong so far about inflation. Indeed he has: Lacker has been warning about inflationary dangers for more than five years. Still, given the behavior of so many interest rate and inflation hawks in this Lesser Depression  the norm seems to be never even acknowledging the wrong predictions, or trying to rewrite what they said in the past  Lackers frank confession of error is refreshing.

title: Reaction on the Streets and Online as Morsi Appears in Court
description: Last Updated, 5:38 p.m. | As my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Mayy el-Sheikh report, Egypts deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, appeared in court on Monday to face charges of inciting the murder of protesters, his first public appearance since his removal from office in July.

title: In Part-Time Jobs, Women Outearn Men
description: The oft-lamented gender wage gap disappears and actually reverses when only part-time workers are considered, according to a new data release from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Mens Wearhouse Rejects Jos. A. Bank Again
description: Mens Wearhouse again rebuffed a $2.3 billion takeover bid by Jos. A. Bank on Monday, refusing to allow the rival retailer confidential access to its books. The move may be the last salvo in the battle to combine two of the countrys biggest retailers of mens suits.

title: Europes Inflation Problem
description: Its too low.

title: The Airbnb Economy in New York: Lucrative but Often Illegal
description: Tama Robertson is an artist who sells paintings and makes jewelry, but this being New York City, she also works in real estate. She has worked as an associate broker and invested in some properties of her own, but in recent years, she has supplemented her income with something a bit more contentious: She rents out a room in her own apartment to travelers she finds on the website Airbnb.

title: Ghesquire Named Vuitton Womens Design Director
description: Nicolas Ghesquire was appointed on Monday as the womens design director for Louis Vuitton, taking over from Marc Jacobs, who left the fashion house last month.

title: Ousted Egyptian President in Court
description: Egyptian state television showed video of Mohamed Morsi arriving for his trial on charges of inciting murder  the deposed presidents first public appearance since being removed from office July 3.

title: Bill Advances to Outlaw Discrimination Against Gays
description: WASHINGTON  A measure that would outlaw workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity overcame a significant obstacle in the Senate on Monday as seven Republicans crossed party lines and voted to begin debate on the bill.

title: Tiling Torment
description: Our puzzle this week was proposed by regular Numberplay contributor Joshua Zucker. The puzzle begins with a classic.

title: Today in Small Business: Unwinding a Failed Start-Up
description: What is affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: What a Big Investment Says About BlackBerrys Endgame
description: BlackBerrys announcement that the company was ending its sale process and receiving a $1 billion investment is all about the companys endgame.

title: $1.2 Billion Fine for Hedge Fund SAC Capital in Insider Case
description: The hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen sat at the center of his vast trading floor on Monday, buying and selling stocks. In a sign of his enduring influence on Wall Street, he did business with major banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase.

title: Reports of a Positive Test in 2006 Call Rodriguezs Words Into Question
description: Alex Rodriguez tested positive for a banned stimulant in 2006, the first year Major League Baseball tested for the substance, according to two people with knowledge of the drug testing results. The positive test raises questions about public statements Rodriguez has made in connection with the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: ScienceTake: The Contagious Yawn
description: People are not the only animals who yawn, or who catch yawns from each other; dogs and chimps even catch human yawns. It may have to do with empathy, which seems to have deep roots in evolution.

title: Kerry Reassures Saudis U.S. Shares Their Goals
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  In his first meeting with Saudi Arabias ruling monarch since becoming secretary of state, John Kerry sought to reassure the king on Monday that the Obama administration and the Saudis shared common objectives on Syria, Iran and Egypt.

title: Where Is Nadya of Pussy Riot?
description: MOSCOW  Soon after she arrived in a penal colony in Mordovia in late 2012, Nadezhda (Nadya) Tolokonnikova, the leader of the protest punk group Pussy Riot, asked for a copy of Anatoly Marchenkos My Testimony, an exhaustive accounting of the life of Soviet political prisoners. Marchenko spent 15 of his 48 years in Soviet prisons, including a number in Mordovlag (an acronym for Mordovian camps), the part of the gulag where Tolokonnikova was serving her two-year sentence.

title: Feeling For | Boys in the Hood
description: The seasons best mens parkas are vibrant, sleek and meant to be worn on the slopes and off.

title: Brazil Says It Spied on U.S. and Others Inside Its Borders
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils government acknowledged on Monday that its top intelligence agency had spied on diplomatic targets from countries including the United States, Iran and Russia, putting the Brazilian authorities in the uncomfortable position of defending their own surveillance practices after repeatedly criticizing American spying operations.

title: The New Vintage Life
description: A look inside three Brooklyn apartments decorated with the taxidermy, antique skeletons and other Victoriana that are making their way back into home decor.

title: Rentals That Are Local, and Luxurious
description: HomeAway, the private home rental company, has started a new website aimed at its ritziest customers, who want not only accommodations owned by locals, but the very best of such.

title: Justices Decline an Appeal on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court decided on Monday not to hear an appeal from a decision striking down an Oklahoma abortion law after all, dismissing as improvidently granted a case it had agreed to consider in June.

title: Sting and Paul Simon Will Tour Together
description: In the continuing sitcom that is popular music  and also in real life  Sting and Paul Simon once lived in the same building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, they recalled in a recent telephone conversation.

title: Teenagers Postpone Learning to Drive, and Thats Not Good
description: More and more teenagers are putting the brakes on driving.

title: Gluten-Free Chocolate Buckwheat Biscotti
description: These biscotti have a crumbly texture when they emerge from the first baking, so allow the logs to cool and cut them carefully, about 1/2 inch thick (if you cut them too thin they can fall apart). Buckwheat flour is a great backdrop for the chocolate; it doesnt dominate but seems rather to show off the chocolate.

title: Gluten-Free Raisin Pistachio Biscotti
description: I use a mix of almond flour and either millet flour or cornmeal for these. They are irresistible. If you soak the raisins in amaretto before you make the biscotti there will be a slightly bitter edge to the flavor. As in other whole grain biscotti I use some butter here, which makes for a more delicate cookie, requiring a slightly thicker slice than a wheat flour cookie.

title: Hazelnut, Orange and Honey Biscotti
description: Orange, hazelnut and honey make a wonderful combination in this whole wheat biscotti. The hard cookies should be sliced thin, which will yield a lot of cookies! They are wonderful dipped in tea.

title: Cornmeal Coconut Biscotti
description: When I use a grainy flour like cornmeal I always include some fat in the biscotti, and this time I went with coconut oil, which contributes great flavor and a sweet perfume. Use fine or medium-grind cornmeal and make sure to use fine coconut flakes. I used organic sugar (not brown) for these; the sugar is off-white rather than white, and coarser than regular granulated sugar.

title: Image of the Day: November 4
More Turmoil in Russian Ballet World
description: Nikolai Tsiskaridze, the flamboyant former Bolshoi Ballet star who hit the headlines when his disputes with company management were linked to the January acid attack on the companys artistic director, Sergei Filin, is once again in the spotlight.

title: J.&J. to Pay $2.2 Billion in Risperdal Settlement
description: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay more than $2.2 billion in criminal and civil fines to settle accusations that it improperly promoted the antipsychotic drug Risperdal to older adults, children and people with developmental disabilities, the Justice Department said on Monday.

title: High-Level Executive Switches to Carlyle From Warburg Pincus
description: The Carlyle Group has hired Kewsong Lee away from his post as managing director at Warburg Pincus, an unusually high-level transition within private equitys executive ranks.

title: Weigh In on Twitters I.P.O. Value
description: Twitter is increasing the price for its upcoming initial public offering by as much as a third. The social network is now looking to raise $23 to $25 a share, according to a filing on Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Lithuanian Opera Rounds Out Prototype Festival Lineup
description: The Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now festival of avant-garde chamber opera and musical theater has added one stage production  the American premiere of Have a Good Day! by the Lithuanian composer Lina Lapelyte  as well as two concerts to the schedule it announced in July. It has also set the dates for the individual productions.

title: Casinos, Pot and the Quest For Consistency
description: My Sunday column on pot and jackpots  that is, the march toward marijuana legalization and the spread of casino gambling  tried to widen the usual culture-war frame to encompass not just bedroom-and-altar hot buttons, but the way the broader logic of consenting adults is working itself out in other areas of American life. One point I didnt get to, though, is the extent to which both of these issues, pot and gambling, illustrate what one might call the rationalizing impulse in modern American politics, which seeks perfect fairness and consistency at the expense of compromises rooted in the accidents of history, and which makes it hard for conservatives to defend older, inherently-arbitrary arrangements even when they make practical sense.

title: Rosie Huntington-Whiteleys Jet-Set Chic
description: The Girl: The actress was travel-ready in a star-print cardigan, oversize shades and fedora at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday.

title: Appealing Observation Status to Medicare
description: A question for readers: Have you filed an appeal with Medicare after it would not cover nursing home care or prescription drugs following hospitalization  because you were on observation status? Wed like to know about it. Please leave a comment.

title: Ask Well: CoQ10-Drug Interactions?
description: Question:

title: Two-Faced Allies: Pakistan and the U.S.
description: Less than a week after Pakistans prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, returned home from a trip to Washington, an American drone killed Hakimullah Mehsud, a man who had terrorized all Pakistan as the leader of the countrys most dangerous militant group, the Pakistani Taliban.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

title: New Chief Curator for the Frick
description: The Frick Collection has appointed Xavier F. Salomon to be its chief curator, filling a spot left vacant by Colin B. Bailey who left in June to become director of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: AARP promoted three members of the AARP Media Sales management team, based in New York, to new posts. Mark Bradbury, director of insights and integrated marketing, becomes senior director of insights and integrated marketing. Shelagh Daly Miller, vice president for advertising, becomes vice president and group publisher. And Peter Zeuschner, Northeast sales manager, was promoted to digital sales manager.

title: Iranians Rally Against U.S., 34 Years After Embassy Takeover
description: TEHRAN  Thousands of Iranian demonstrators surrounded the former United States Embassy building in Tehran on Monday, in the largest anti-American rally in years, bolstering hard-liners who oppose attempts by the Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, to establish relations with the Islamic republics archenemy.

title: So, Travis Bickle Walked Into a Bar
description: Over the past decade or so, mixologists have seemed to resurrect almost every significant drinking era in American history. Pre-Prohibition cocktails have been meticulously recreated. The aesthetic of the Prohibition-era speakeasy has been thoroughly explored. And Mad Men has inspired bars to plumb the hard-drinking days that followed World War II.

title: On Gay Rights, Congress Lags
description: Heres a study in contrast:

title: LACMA Red Carpet
description: Looks from the Art and Film Gala in Los Angeles red carpet, including Kate Hudsons dress, with its barely-there breast pieces.

title: Ads Celebrate Mozart in the City
description: Each year, November becomes Movember as men raise money to fight cancer by growing mustaches. This year, November is Movember for another reason, as a radio station and website known for classical music celebrate what they are declaring to be a month of Mozart.

title: An Operatic Monster Mash
description: A mild-mannered bachelor tried to kiss a zombie on Saturday evening on the Lower East Side. He succumbed to her bite soon after. A group of medical students made earnest attempts to reanimate a corpse. Religious objects were desecrated. There was blood.

title: Marathon Style
description: Runners in the New York City Marathon showed their style during the race.

title: Excerpt: 'Domesticated'
description: Laurie Metcalf and Jeff Goldblum in a scene from Bruce Norris's new play at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.

title: Monday Motorsports: Johnson Overwhelms Texas Nascar Field
description: Jimmie Johnson proved to be unbeatable Sunday in the 500-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Texas Motor Speedway. In the process, he moved into the points lead in the chase for the season championship.

title: A Memorial for Marcella Hazan
description: Marcella Hazan, the cooking teacher and author whose works redefined Italian food for a generation of American cooks, was remembered Sunday by her friends and colleagues at a memorial dinner in New York, where she lived and taught for four decades. Mrs. Hazan died at 89 in Florida on Sept. 29. Friends and colleagues said at the dinner, which was at SD26 in Chelsea, Mrs. Hazan was remembered as a rigorous teacher, a fond mother, a brilliant and straightforward cook and a curmudgeon on culinary matters.

title: Dismiss Diversification at Your Own Risk
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His sketches are archived on Your Money.

title: A Key to Quantum Computing, Close to Home
description: A blue dye found in many household items, including the British five-pound note, could fill an important need in the quest to develop a quantum computer, researchers say.

title: No Heroism in Playing After a Head Injury
description: Manchester City once had a goalkeeper named Bert Trautmann. Trautmann, a German, spent his professional career in England and was known for his uncanny ability to save penalty kicks. His most famous moment, though, came when he helped City win the F.A. Cup at Wembley Stadium despite playing the final part of the game with a broken neck.

title: Ali, Tyson and Captain Kirk: Coil Festival Announces Lineup
description: An imagined boxing match between Muhammad Ali and Mike Tyson and a video remix built of Capt. James T. Kirks observations from the original Star Trek television series are among the offerings in the 2014 edition of Performance Space 122s ninth Coil Festival.

title: Central Connecticut State University Ends Lockdown After Suspects Arrest
description: The report on Monday afternoon was alarming: A man in a ski mask carrying a gun and a samurai sword had been seen walking on campus at Central Connecticut State University. That 911 call led officials to declare a campus emergency, direct everyone on campus to stay indoors for several hours and cancel classes.

title: The Impact of the Settlement on SAC Capital and Cohen
description: The plea agreement between the Justice Department and SAC Capital Advisors that calls for the firm to pay almost $1.2 billion to resolve insider trading charges is carefully drafted to permit the government to continue its pursuit of Steven A. Cohen, the hedge fund firms founder and owner. SAC has finally put the governments criminal case behind it, but Mr. Cohen remains the focus of a continuing criminal investigation and an administrative complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Editorial Is Under Fire for Saying President Clearly Misspoke on Health Care
description: ATimes editorial on Sunday on the new health care law let President Obama off the hook with its too-soft choice of words, according to some readers who complained to me on Monday.

title: Hepatitis C, a Silent Killer, Meets Its Match
description: Determined to get rid of the hepatitis C infection that was slowly destroying his liver, Arthur Rubens tried one experimental treatment after another. None worked, and most brought side effects, like fever, insomnia, depression, anemia and a rash that felt like your skin was on fire.

title: Elizabeth Gilbert Finds Inspiration Behind the Garden Gate
description: LOS ANGELES  After the runaway success of Eat, Pray, Love, her 2006 memoir of divorce, spirituality and self-improvement, the writer Elizabeth Gilbert set off on an entirely different path. The Signature of All Things, her acclaimed new novel, is about  of all things  a fictional 19th-century botanist.

title: New Hope on Hepatitis, Herbal Supplements Under Scrutiny, Eat, Pray, Botany
description: New drugs could change the way Hepatitis C is treated; think thats St. Johns Wort youre buying?; Elizabeth Gilbert talks about her new novel, The Signature of All Things.

title: Extra Cash and New Chief Buy BlackBerry Just a Bit More Time
description: BlackBerrys liquid infusion wont douse its cash burn. The troubled company is selling $1 billion of convertible debt after attempts to find a buyer flopped. Even its big supporter, Fairfax Financial, has backed away from taking full control. The extra money and a new boss buy BlackBerry a bit more time. But its prospects are bleak.

title: Far-Off Planets Like the Earth Dot the Galaxy
description: The known odds of something  or someone  living far, far away from Earth improved beyond astronomers boldest dreams on Monday.

title: Pakistani Party Votes to Block NATO Supply Lines if Drones Persist
description: LONDON  The ruling party in a northwestern province of Pakistan voted Monday to block NATO supply lines by Nov. 20 unless the United States stops its drone strikes in the nearby tribal belt.

title: Vaccine Approved for Brain Fever
description: The World Health Organization has approved a new vaccine for a strain of encephalitis that kills thousands of children and leaves many survivors with permanent brain damage.

title: Poisonous to Pets
description: Q. I know chocolate is harmful to dogs. What else hurts pets but not people?

title: Why a Pension Case Will Not Change Private Equity Tax Law
description: Steve Judge is president and chief executive of the Private Equity Growth Capital Council.

title: Wall Streets Marathoners Go the Extra Mile
description: Updated, 5:14 p.m. |

title: S.E.C. Clarifies That Crowdfunding Portals Will Be Able to Take Commissions
description: Last week, in our post about the Securities and Exchange Commissions proposed regulation for crowdfunding, we reported that the rules might make it harder for specialized crowdfunding portals to earn much of a living facilitating such deals.

title: Medical Ethics Have Been Violated at Detention Sites, a New Report Says
description: A group of experts in medicine, law and ethics has issued a blistering report that accuses the United States government of directing doctors, nurses and psychologists, among others, to ignore their professional codes of ethics and participate in the abuse of detainees in Afghanistan, Iraq and Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Walkabout: A Flight Safety Video Set to Song; a Museum Dedicated to Show Biz
description: Jazz HandsVirgin Americas new foot-stomping, musical flight-safety videois attracting lots of attention on the Internet (our In Transit post is here), but some remain unconvinced that all of the pizzazz will actually get passengers attention. (The Economist)

title: Concerns About Jerky Pet Treats
description: Seven years ago, Jordan Smith offered her two dogs a Christmas treat: pieces of chicken jerky. Within hours, Eugene, a 14-year-old wire-haired pointing griffon, and Choppy White, a poodle of uncertain age, had diarrhea and were vomiting. A week later, Choppy White died of liver failure.

title: Humpback Dolphin Clan Branches Out
description: A group of humpback dolphins off the northern coast of Australia has been designated a separate species, previously unknown, following a genetic investigation by scientists with the Wildlife Conservation Society. Looking to prove that there were more than two species of humpback dolphin, researchers collected physical and genetic evidence from the animals around the world, eventually proving there were four distinct species. The Australian group has not yet been given a name.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 29  Nov. 4, 2013
description: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

title: Rethinking Medical Programs (2 Letters)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: How to Shorten Commutes (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Survival of the Extraordinary  A Fly With Tricky* Wings
description: [Update, Nov.8, 8:00 p.m. | The wings on this fly are tricky, indeed. Read this great post by Morgan D. Jackson, an entomology grad student and photographer, to get a very nuanced and appropriately skeptical examination of such wing patterns: Ants, Spiders, or Wishful Thinking?]

title: Maine Governor Candidate Says He Is Gay
description: BOSTON  Michael H. Michaud, a Democrat who represents conservative, northern Maine in Congress and is a leading candidate for governor next year, announced in a newspaper column Monday that he is gay.

title: Not-So-Herbal Supplements
description: A study using DNA testing offers perhaps the most credible evidence to date of adulteration, contamination and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.

title: Bangladesh Takes Step to Increase Lowest Pay
description: Criticized over unsafe conditions and low pay in its garment industry, Bangladesh took a first step to raise wages on Monday with a special government-appointed board voting to nearly double the minimum wage. Factory owners complained that the increase was too high, labor leaders that it was too low.

title: Science on His Own Terms
description: There is Big Science, defined as science that gets the big bucks. There is tried and true science, which, from an adventurous dissidents point of view, is boldly going where others have gone before but extending the prevailing knowledge by a couple of decimal places (a safe approach for dissertation writers and grant seekers).

title: More Like Her
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Netflix Acquires Streaming Rights to a Highly Praised Documentary
description: Netflix said on Monday that starting early next year it will be the exclusive streaming distributor for The Square, an Arabic documentary about the Egyptian protest centered in Tahrir Square, which is considered a leading contender for an Oscar nomination.

title: The Read Around: Nicholas Sparks
description: Nicholas Sparks, author of The Longest Ride, says elements like betrayal, loss and honesty are all needed to make a novel work.

title: Finding the Higgs Leads to More Puzzles
description: Near the end of The Tempest, in what has been taken as Shakespeares farewell speech, the sorcerer Prospero breaks his staff and declares, Our revels now are ended. And he goes on:

title: When Fuzzy Slippers Arent Enough
description: I eat soup all year long. But when the wind blows cold enough for me to unearth my fuzzy slippers, thats when I really crave a bowl of thick, pured vegetable soup.

title: Yankees Offer One-Year Deals to Three Players
description: The Yankees extended one-year qualifying contract offers of $14.1 million to Curtis Granderson, Robinson Cano and Hiroki Kuroda on Monday, setting the stage for intrigue in the days ahead.

title: The Texas Abortion Emergency
description: Outside the chambers of federal appellate judges Priscilla Owen, Jennifer Elrod, and Catharina Haynes, virtually everyone understands that H.B. 2, the new Texas law that places various restrictions on a womans ability to obtain an abortion, is not about protecting womens health  its about stopping abortion.

title: Weekend Gun Report: November 1-3, 2013
description: On Friday morning, Paul Ciancia, 23, walked into Los Angeles International Airport with a legally purchased .223-caliber assault rifle and five 30-round magazines andopened fire on a T.S.A. security checkpoint, killing 39-year-old Gerardo Hernandez, a father of two who had screened passengers there for three years, and wounding four otherstwo additional T.S.A. agents and two passengers. The rampage was halted when he was shot in the mouth and the leg by authorities. The next day, federal prosecutors charged him with murder.

title: A Talent Whose Light Was Bright but Brief
description: For some in the dismayingly large club of rock stars who died too young, its easy to imagine an alternate future in which fate or bad judgment does not intervene and they live to a ripe old age. John Lennon becomes a patron of the arts and fends off repeated requests that he run for office. Cass Elliot does a stint on The View.

title: Testing Supplements
description: Genetic testing of 44 herbal supplements from a dozen companies found that only two companies used completely authentic ingredients.

title: Raft of New Works Scheduled for Ecstatic Music Festival
description: The Ecstatic Music Festival, which has quickly become the alt-classical worlds main showcase, will offer 11 concerts during its fourth season, which opens Jan. 31 and runs through March 29. As in past years, the concerts, which are assembled by the composer Judd Greenstein, are double or triple bills in which ensembles (many led by composers) perform separate sets and also join forces, either on new collaborative works or improvisations.

title: The Read Around: Nicholas Sparks
description: In The Read Around, a new weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Nicholas Sparks talks about his novel The Longest Ride and how he approaches building a story that will work for both page and screen.

title: Being a Working Mother Means Always Having to Say Youre Sorry
description: Sorry!

title: Editor Did Not Agree to Phone Hacking, Lawyer Says
description: LONDON  Andy Coulson, former editor of the tabloid The News of the World, now defunct, never agreed to any illegal phone hacking at the newspaper, his lawyer told the jury on Monday at the Old Bailey in the trial of Mr. Coulson; his former boss and onetime lover, Rebekah Brooks; and six others.

title: Book About Amazon Is Reviewed on Amazon, by Founders Wife
description: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, has yet to make a public peep about The Everything Store, a major biography of Mr. Bezos and his company that was published last month.

title: Disabled Chinese Struggle for a Good Education, and Acceptance
description: Ni Zhen didnt want to become a masseur, even though neighbors, educators and seemingly everyone else in his native Shandong Province urged him in that direction  because he is blind.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: With cuts to SNAP, 76 million meals will be off the table for the poorest families in New York City alone. Related: A sobering piece by Ian Frazier in the New Yorker about homelessness in New York, which is higher than its been in decades.

title: Supreme Court Takes Up Steelworkers Bid for Time to Put on Work Gear
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court, which ordinarily confronts complicated questions, heard arguments on Monday about what might seem like a simple one: What does it mean to change clothes?

title: Brahms to Ives to Knotty Swedish Consonants, a Mezzo Goes the Full Range
description: The superb mezzo-soprano Jamie Barton, quickly becoming known for the flood of sound she can unleash, began her recital on Sunday afternoon singing against type.

title: A Science Project With Legs
description: The average teenage boy is likely to have an interest in chicken only when it hits his dinner plate.

title: A Traitor to His Class? Such Good Fun
