description: David Letterman is not only an author of This Land Was Made for You and Me (but Mostly Me), a new humor book he created with Bruce McCall. He is also a target of its pointed populist satire, and he knows it.

title: Taking a Toll
description: The number of new infections and acute cases of hepatitis C has fallen sharply, but because many of those currently infected are baby boomers now middle-aged and older, long-term medical problems caused by the virus are expected to rise.

title: Defectors Land on Their Feet
description: PHOENIX  Cuba takes special measures to hold on to one of its most precious cultural resources: ballet dancers. To discourage defections, authorities sometimes keep talented performers from touring or warn younger artists that finding a ballet job will be tough in an unappreciative capitalist world.

title: Dont Start Up Your Tablet on the Runway Just Yet
description: THE confusion light is on.

title: Holidays Holding Hands
description: The expectations for our familys holiday meals are usually as rigid as the compartments of a plastic prison plate. Any deviation, any scrambling of tradition (Who put raisins in the cranberry sauce? You call this a latke? It looks more like matzo brei!), is treated as heresy. The offending cook can expect hours of protest, and maybe a loss of skillet privileges.

title: In Performance: Patrick Page
description: Patrick Page plays Rufus Buckley, the district attorney in the stage adaptation of John Grishams novel A Time to Kill. The show is on Broadway at the Golden Theater.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Fergus Hendersons The Complete Nose to Tail Cookbook
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: The Sounds of a Torn Region United in Many Languages
description: At the end of The Cycles of Life: A Musical Exploration of the Balkans, conceived and presented by the Catalan early-music explorer Jordi Savall at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, five soloists sang five different songs at once. In five different languages.

title: Using a Familiar Device to Dance Out of the Past, Page by Page
description: The device of using old dance photographs as material for new choreography goes back decades. Nineteenth-century photographs of people in motion by Eadweard Muybridge  pointing the way to flip-book continuity  have inspired several choreographers. Images of Isadora Duncan and Vaslav Nijinsky have entered into many dances.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Russia and Indonesia.

title: Poetry Profiles: Graywolf Press
description: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Jeffrey Shotts, Graywolfs executive editor, with Fiona McCrae, the presss director and publisher.

title: CDs From Celine Dion and Midlake
description: CELINE DION

title: A Roman Sculpture, a Study on Lying and a Disturbing F.D.A. Report
description: There are only about 4,000 black rhinoceroses left in the world  at least until next year, when a high bidder gets a chance to shoot one. This week brought news of a controversial auction, plus an account of what the Food and Drug Administration found in imported spices.

title: Playing the Game Again, With an Insiders Look at the Players
description: Barack Obamas performance in Denver in Debate No. 1 against Mitt Romney was widely perceived as something between a flop and a disaster: even supporters complained that the president seemed listless, passive, peevish, disdainful and distracted. The president and his aides promised a comeback in Debate No. 2  suddenly a must-win showdown, needed to stop the bleeding, reassure the base and stem a migration of independents to Mr. Romney.

title: A Force for Face-to-Face Communication
description: Clifford I. Nass, a professor of communication at Stanford who died on Saturday, regaled me several times over the years about his method for torturing students in the undergraduate dorm hall where he was an adviser. He would make them communicate face to face.

title: CNN Ratings Fall as Health Care Coverage Rises
description: CNN provided heavy coverage last week of the troubled introduction of the website tied to the Affordable Care Act. The result was the lowest weekly ratings for CNN in more than a year.

title: Bartoks Quartets Mixed With a Dose of Indie Rock
description: Bartok primarily wrote instrumental music, with a large catalog that features relatively few vocal selections. But his instrumental pieces owe a substantial debt to the voice, with inflections of his native Hungarian woven throughout works like his fourth string quartet.

title: The Continued Taming of the N.F.L.
description: The N.F.L. has made several rule changes to try to limit injuries. William C. Rhoden wonders if the often violent onside kick could be the next play to be outlawed.

title: Video Sports of The Times: The Continued Taming of the N.F.L.
Todays Scuttlebot: The Unicorn Club, and Explaining N.S.A. Access to Tech Company Data
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: DNA Bar Coding
description: DNA Bar Coding  is a technique for quickly analyzing short sequences of genes to identify plant or animal species.

title: Singleton to Retire as Chairman of MediaNews Group
description: William Dean Singleton, the co-founder and chairman of MediaNews Group, who over the years earned a reputation for extensive cost-cutting, will retire in December, the company announced on Monday.

title: Role of Humanities, in School and Life
Getting International Aid Relief to War-Torn Syrians
A Surreal Spying Industry
Parking Rules
description: Because of Election Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Health Effects of Radiation
Immigration Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary in 2016? Not So Fast
description: Hillary Clinton of all people knows how political fortunes turn on a dime. But she must be puzzled nonetheless, and spooked, that over a six-month period when she made no big news whatsoever, her popularity took a double-digit tumble.

title: Glamour Travel With Four Boys
description: MY father was a pilot, and when I was a child we never had family vacation road trips. We got to fly, and I thought that was so cool. My parents insisted that I had to wear a suit jacket. That rule stuck, and I still wear a jacket when I travel.

title: The Animated Life of A. R. Wallace
description: This paper-puppet animation celebrates the life of Alfred Russel Wallace, who is co-credited with Charles Darwin for the theory of natural selection.

title: Secrets of a Game Show Writer
description: The word only, an adverb that portends disappointment for the hopeful theatergoer (standing room only) and an adjective that mocks the sibling-deprived (only child), is a trivia writers best friend. Shortly before he died, Dr. Seuss confessed that Green Eggs and Ham was the only book I ever wrote that still makes me laugh. The actor Bruce Dern, after appearing alongside the Duke in the 1972 western The Cowboys, correctly boasted that he was the only actor who ever killed John Wayne.

title: Crist, Former Florida Governor, Tosses Hat in Ring Again
description: ST. PETERSBURG  Hopscotching from one Democratic touchstone to the next  education, voting rights, the environment and bipartisanship  former Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida announced Monday that he would run for the job once again, this time as a Democrat.

title: The Animated Life of A.R. Wallace
description: Although Alfred Russel Wallace made one of the most important scientific discoveries in history, hes been all but forgotten. A contemporary of Charles Darwin, Wallace was the other guy to discover natural selection  the evolutionary process whereby better adapted organisms are more likely to survive and pass on their traits than less adapted ones. Although two people discovered this theory, evolution by natural selection is virtually synonymous with Darwin. This is partly due to the lasting fame of Darwins opus, On the Origin of Species, but some argue it is also due to Wallaces extraordinary modesty  he lauded Darwins work and humbly downplayed his own contributions. In 1889 he even wrote a book in support of evolution titled Darwinism.

title: No Riders Killed in First 5 Months of New York City Bike-Share Program
description: To many, the ingredients for New York Citys bike-share program suggested a sort of sadistic alchemy.

title: With Cows in Mind, Swiss Farmers Wage Litter Battle
description: SOLOTHURN, Switzerland  Before he mows the hay he feeds his dairy cows, Hansueli Wyss performs a new ritual: He scours the fields of his 65-acre farm amid the rolling hills of this farming region, dotted with steep-roofed homes like his 150-year-old farmhouse, for junk  empty bottles and soda or beer cans, hamburger cartons, and much else.

title: Turning On iTunes Menus
description: Turning On

title: De Blasio Seeks Mandate as Lhota Hopes for Upset
description: Concerned that his overwhelming lead in the race to be New York mayor could depress voter turnout, Bill de Blasio on Monday warned supporters against complacency as he sought to win with a decisive mandate that could propel his liberal agenda.

title: Ukraine: Workers Removing Parts of Chernobyl Plant
description: Workers at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine have begun dismantling a ventilation stack that has filtered radioactive gases from the reactor that was destroyed in an accident in 1986. The first section, weighing 33 tons, was lifted off the stack Thursday for storage in the plants turbine hall, according to a report on the plants website. The work is expected to take about five weeks. The distinctive red-and-white tower is being removed to allow a new arch-shaped enclosure to be placed over the concrete sarcophagus that was built after the disaster to entomb the wrecked reactor. The arch, scheduled to be completed in 2015, will allow workers to eventually dismantle the old sarcophagus and dispose of the radioactive fuel. As part of the preparation for the work, a new, smaller ventilation stack for removing radioactive aerosols that remain in Reactor 4 was built nearby.

title: The Mets Delicate Dance With a Billionaire
description: When the Mets needed money after their owners were fleeced by Bernard L. Madoff, they turned to Steven A. Cohen, a hedge-fund billionaire. Their first request to him to invest came in 2010. A year later, Cohen emerged again as a possible financial lifeline before the Mets agreed to sell 33 percent of the team for $200 million to David Einhorn, another hedge-fund wizard. But that deal eventually collapsed.

title: For Athletes, a Home for Away Games
description: When the Minnesota Vikings checked into the J. W. Marriott Chicago last season, the hotels staff scrambled to fix a mistake: They had stocked the wrong flavor of Pedialyte, a favorite rehydration drink for players.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Here are our recommendations for some races and state constitutional amendments in New York and New Jersey. Poll hours are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. in New York and 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. in New Jersey.

title: Arming the T.S.A. Is Not a Solution
description: Police are still piecing together the details of Fridays fatal shooting at Los Angeles International Airport, but it appears as if the gunman, Paul Ciancia, targeted Transportation Security Administration agents. In response to the attack, the union representing T.S.A. screeners said the agency should arm certain employees and assign them to checkpoints. The administrator of the T.S.A., John Pistole, said he would discuss changes to security protocols with Congress.

title: F.C.C.s Chief Hires a Critic of the Agency
description: WASHINGTON  Tom Wheeler was sworn in on Monday as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and promptly named to his senior staff Gigi B. Sohn, one of the agencys most outspoken critics but a supporter of the new leader.

title: Mr. Kerry Fumbles in Egypt
description: Secretary of State John Kerrys trip to Egypt, included in his Middle East itinerary at the last minute, served only to add to the confusion over the Obama administrations policy toward this critically important Arab nation. Mr. Kerry was the highest-ranking American official to visit Cairo since Mohamed Morsi, the countrys first democratically elected president, was deposed in July. Mr. Kerry seemed to go further than necessary or prudent to make common cause with the authoritarian generals who led the coup and are now running the country.

title: The Fate of the Humanities
Brooklyn Diocese Sues One of Its High Schools in Queens
description: For more than 30 years, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and the nonprofit group running Christ the King High School in Queens have acted as one, managing the twin hurdles of declining enrollments and shrinking revenues with a joint aim of fostering parochial education.

title: Toward Ending Workplace Discrimination
description: An overdue measure to outlaw employment discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity cleared a procedural hurdle on Monday night in the Senate. The move is one step toward putting into federal law a basic principle most Americans support: Job applicants and employees should be judged on their professional credentials and the caliber of their work, and not be held back because of who they are.

title: SAC: A Textbook Case of Corporate Prosecution
description: SAC Capitals guilty plea to insider trading and $1.2 billion fine may represent a sweeping victory for Preet Bharara, the United States attorney, and his team of prosecutors, and vindication for their multiyear investigation of one of the countrys most successful hedge funds. But the decision to indict a company, and to spare, at least for now, its founder and billionaire manager, Steven A. Cohen, has already ignited criticism.

title: Buy One, Give One Spirit Imbues an Online Store
description: TOMS started in 2006 with what was then a novel idea: for every pair of shoes it sold, it would donate a pair to a child living in poverty. Along with donating more than 10 million pairs to date, the company spurred a trend of buy one, give one companies, with the eyeglass maker Warby Parker among the best known.

title: Few Eager to Talk Peace in Syria, but a Mediator Wont Stop
description: UNITED NATIONS  Lakhdar Brahimi says he prefers to navigate by sight. By this, he means that to find ways out of war, he looks for a course while talking. It distinguishes his mediating style, those who have worked with him say, and it has worked in his favor in the many conflicts he has mediated on behalf of the United Nations: holding elections in Haiti, forming a government in Iraq, ending a civil war in Lebanon.

title: Hockey History, as Documented by Prime Minister
description: The historian Jacques Barzun once wrote, Whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn baseball. That notion probably goes double for Canada and hockey.

title: Uighur Scholar in Ugly Confrontation With Security Agents
description: Ilham Tohti, a well-known scholar who is arguably Chinas most vocal advocate for the rights of its Uighur minority, said he got into an ugly confrontation with security agents in Beijing on Saturday after the men rammed his car and threatened to kill his wife and children.

title: After a Decade, SAC Capital Blinks
description: SAC Capital Advisors first sought to fend off a federal indictment. Then the hedge fund, run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, offered to pay about $700 million to settle. Finally, SAC suggested it plead guilty to only some of the criminal charges in the five-count indictment.

title: After Los Angeles Airport Shooting, No Easy Answers on Security Strategies
description: WASHINGTON  When Stephen L. Holl, the chief of police at the Washington Metropolitan Airports Authority, gathered his staff for the regular morning meeting on Monday, he opened with a sobering assessment.

title: Americans Jailed for Months in Qatar After Daughters Death
description: Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple with three adopted children from Africa, lived as a family in the affluent Persian Gulf kingdom of Qatar starting in July 2012. For most of the time since then, the parents have been imprisoned there, accused of starving their 8-year-old daughter to death with the intent of selling her organs.

title: For 36 Hours, N.Y.U. Student Was Trapped Between 2 Buildings
description: In a crowded city, Asher Vongtau was completely alone, trapped in a space barely wider than a shoe box after plummeting perhaps 100 feet into the tiny crevice between two buildings in TriBeCa.

title: A Finding of Guilty in the Killing of Sean Taylor
description: MIAMI  After an 11-day trial, a 23-year-old man charged in the killing of the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor in 2007 was found guilty Monday of second-degree murder and armed burglary.

title: U.S. in Talks to Settle Suit Over American-US Airways Merger
description: The Justice Department has started talks with American Airlines and US Airways, seeking concessions on airport takeoff and landing slots in exchange for dropping an antitrust lawsuit aimed at blocking their merger, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said on Monday

title: Shooting Suspects Steps Are Traced in Search for Clues to L.A. Airport Attack
description: LOS ANGELES  The morning that a gunman opened fire at the Los Angeles International Airport, killing a security official and wounding two others, Paul Ciancia walked unannounced into a roommates room and asked for a ride the airport, according to a federal search warrant released by federal prosecutors Monday.

title: Fixing the System
description: Its Election Day. Virginians are electing a new governor, New Yorkers are choosing a new mayor, and all over the country, dozens of local races are being decided. Because this is an off-year election, in which there are no federal races, voter turnout is going to be abysmal. We all know that.

title: Strategic Move Exempts Health Law From Broader U.S. Statute
description: WASHINGTON  The Affordable Care Act is the biggest new health care program in decades, but the Obama administration has ruled that neither the federal insurance exchange nor the federal subsidies paid to insurance companies on behalf of low-income people are federal health care programs.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 5, 2013
description: It seems that the universe produces plentiful real estate for life that somehow resembles life on Earth.

title: Big Money Flows in New Jersey Races to Thwart Christie Agenda
description: Democrats and unions, fearful that a landslide victory by Gov. Chris Christie will reshape New Jerseys political landscape, have poured tens of millions of dollars into a record-breaking outside spending campaign that has transformed the states election season.

title: In Bullying Case, Questions on N.F.L. Culture
description: Jonathan Martin and Richie Incognito spent most of the season side by side, a pair of 300-pound men made rich from football, crouched inches apart on the offensive line of the Miami Dolphins. When the defense took the field, they sat on the bench in order of their position  Martin, the left tackle, next to Incognito, the left guard. They were as connected as teammates could be  though they could hardly be more different.

title: Christie Hopes to Show G.O.P. He Has Diverse Support
description: The question in the governors race in New Jersey on Tuesday is not who will win, but by how much, and where?

title: A Plea for Catholic Schools to Ignore New Guidelines
description: A group of Roman Catholic scholars has called on Catholic schools to ignore the new educational standards known as the Common Core, a set of guidelines on what students should know and be able to do from kindergarten through 12th grade, opening a front with parallels to the fight over using the guidelines in public schools.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 4, 2013
Corrections: November 5, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: After Extramarital Activities, Politician Looks for the Words
description: All hes trying to do, says Bill, a proverbial man in a bar, struggling to find the words, is to begin the conversation, the honest conversation.

title: The Revolution Is Not an Apple
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  The southeast was the last sector to fall in for me today, which may just be the way Paula Gamache wanted it. Whether or not that is true, it worked out well because it saved the reveal for last and, indeed, cracked me up.

title: As U.S. Weighs Spying Changes, Officials Say Data Sweeps Must Continue
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has told allies and lawmakers it is considering reining in a variety of National Security Agency practices overseas, including holding White House reviews of the world leaders the agency is monitoring, forging a new accord with Germany for a closer intelligence relationship and minimizing collection on some foreigners.

title: In Housing Court, Different View of New York Citys Mayoral Race
description: A chill wind pinching his face, Compton Bremner takes his place among hundreds of men and women who clutch dispossess notices and rent receipts.

title: Hearing Voices, and Listening to the Right One
description: Two distinct voices have fought for authority over RaeJanese Chambers since the onset of her schizophrenia at age 29. While both speak with equal clarity, Ms. Chambers, 41, ascribes only one of them to her illness.

title: A Yiddishe Momme of Music, Chana Mlotek, Dies at 91
description: Chana Mlotek, an impassioned sleuth and archivist of Yiddish music whose song collections allowed thousands to imbibe the mirthful and mournful melodies of the shtetl, ghetto and Yiddish theater, died on Monday at her home in the Bronx. She was 91.

title: Knicks Dissect Ugly First Quarter With the Hope to Clean It Up
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It was not enough for Raymond Felton to live through one of the franchises worst first quarters in recent memory.

title: Nalini Ambady, Psychologist of Intuition, Is Dead at 54
description: Nalini Ambady, a social psychologist whose research on the surprising accuracy of first impressions was popularized by Malcolm Gladwell in Blink, his best-selling nonfiction book of 2005, died on Oct. 28 in Boston. She was 54.

title: For Uninsured, Clearing a Way to Enrollment
description: LA GRANGE, Ky.  Kelli Cauleys fingers raced over her keyboard as she asked the anxious woman at her side a series of questions. What was her income? How many people lived in her household? Did she smoke? (Thats the only health question it asks, Ms. Cauley said of the application they were completing.)

title: North Korean Sailors Reported Killed in October Sinking; South Says There Was No Clash
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A North Korean naval vessel sank last month, killing an unspecified number of sailors, according to North and South Korean news media.

title: Eligible to Enroll
description: David Elson is among thousands of Kentuckians who are considering their options for health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

title: Nets Full of Stars and Questions About Roles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The most parroted word lately among Nets players and coaches has been process. It is a euphemism, really, that connotes the distinct growing pains the team is going through at the moment, trying to array its vast talent into winning combinations.

title: Kentucky Is Ahead in Health Insurance Enrollment
description: The work of enrollment navigators in states like Kentucky shows how the federal exchange could work once its many technical problems are solved.

title: Suspect Is Dead in New Jersey Mall Shooting
description: A man wearing black and carrying a rifle opened fire at a large northern New Jersey mall on Monday night, prompting hundreds of customers to seek cover and an extensive search for the suspect, officials and witnesses said.

title: Pesticides Linked to Endometriosis Risk
description: Why some women and not others get endometriosis  the growth of uterine tissue outside the uterus that can cause pain and infertility  is not known, but researchers have come up with one possible contributing factor: pesticide poisoning.

title: Q. and A. With Ron Duguay
description: Ron Duguay was selected 13th in the 1977 N.H.L. amateur draft by the Rangers. He became a fan favorite, not just for his hockey skills but for his cascading brown hair, active night life and commercial appearances.

title: Manning Set to Face Motivated Raiders
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning was on a plane home to New Jersey on Sunday evening when Philadelphias Nick Foles was heaving touchdown pass after touchdown pass against the Oakland Raiders.

title: Seattles Mayor Faces Challenge, Despite Signs of Success
description: SEATTLE  Mayor Mike McGinn seems like the kind of candidate this city would love. A former Sierra Club chapter leader and an avid cyclist, he bikes to work from his home in north Seattle. He has focused his campaign for a second term on issues voters care about here: climate change, transportation and reducing police brutality. And the economy is doing pretty well, with construction cranes whirring on the horizon and job numbers growing.

title: Idzik Pleased With Performance of Ryan and Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  John Idzik committed a bit of a Freudian slip Monday while mentioning how many challenges Geno Smith has confronted during the last nine months  er, nine games.

title: Senator Rand Paul Faces New Charges of Plagiarism
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, who in recent weeks has had to explain how Wikipedia entries came to be incorporated into his speeches with no attribution, faced charges of direct plagiarism on Monday night.

title: Mets Games Move to WOR-AM
description: The Mets formally announced that their radio games are moving to WOR-AM (710) in a five-year deal with the news and talk stations owner, Clear Channel Media and Entertainment. The announcement did not say if Howie Rose, who has called Mets games since 1996, and Josh Lewin, who joined the Mets broadcast team in 2012, will be moving to WOR from WFAN, AM and FM, which had carried the games since 1987. In a statement, the Mets said: "Now that our agreement is official, WOR is in discussions regarding announcers.

title: Obama to Campaign to Ensure Health Laws Success
description: WASHINGTON  On the fifth anniversary of his election, President Obama told a rally of grass-roots supporters on Monday evening that Ive got one more campaign in me  to make sure his signature health care law works.

title: The Bidding Is Sluggish at a Special Estate Sale
description: The highly anticipated fall auction season got off to a surprisingly gloomy start on Monday night at Christies, which held a special sale of paintings, drawings and sculptures from the estate of Jan Krugier, the Geneva-based dealer who died in 2008.

title: The Decline of the Tea Party
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Helpouts From Google Connects People With Experts Over Live Video
description: A new product from Google, Helpouts, connects people with experts over video chat to give free or paid advice for tasks as varied as how to apply lipstick, how to treat a burn or how to speak Mandarin.

title: Word of the Day | congeal
description: congeal \kn-jel\ verb

title: Ducks Defeat Rangers Behind a Rookies 32 Saves
description: The Anaheim Ducks were concluding an eight-game trip, but the Rangers were the more lethargic squad Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) IN THE SPOTLIGHT WITH ROBIN ROBERTS: COUNTDOWN TO THE CMA AWARDS Ms. Roberts visits some of country musics biggest stars at home in this lead-in to the Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday. The lineup features Jason Aldean (above with Ms. Roberts), who discusses fame, fortune and the tabloid headlines that he says contributed to the end of his marriage; Luke Bryan, who talks about two family tragedies that nearly broke him; Shania Twain, who ponders her battle with stage fright; and Dolly Parton and Kenny Rogers, who reminisce about their hit Islands in the Stream.

title: I Want to Be a Millennial When I Retire
description: My son Max is a 25-year-old singer and songwriter who goes by the moniker Dolfish. When my friends ask how his career is going, I say, Theres a girl in Indiana with Dolfish tattooed on her arm, although that doesnt exactly answer their question.

title: Chinas Dynasties, in Song
description: The order of Chinas dynasties can be a complicated puzzle for students of Chinese history. The Harvard professors William Kirby and Peter Bol offer this trick: a song that names the major dynasties, the Republic of China and the Peoples Republic of China (or as the lyrics have it, Mao Zedong) to the tune of Frre Jacques.

title: News Quiz | November 5, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Tweets From Inside N.J. Mall During Gunfire
description: Updated 9:05 a.m.Hundreds of police officers descended on the sprawling Garden State Plaza Mall in Paramus, N.J., Monday night after multiple shoppers reported a gunman with a long rifle fired shots inside the mall around 9:15 p.m. No one was reported injured, officials said.

title: Home Buyers Feel Let Down by Indias Top Builders
description: Nitin Grover, a 33-year-old lawyer, has been dreaming of moving from his rented home to an apartment of his own. In 2008, Mr. Grover and his wife, who were paying monthly rent of 30,000 rupees, or nearly $500 at the current exchange rate, surveyed the real estate landscape around New Delhi, Indias capital. They decided to buy a place in Gurgaon, on the outskirts of the city.

title: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 5, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Claim to Be
description: In the article Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Seem, Fares Akram and Jodi Rudoren report on a recent study that found widespread adulteration and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.

title: Renault and Nissan Seek a Tie-Up With Mitsubishi
description: PARIS  Renault, the French automaker, and its Japanese alliance partner Nissan Motor, are exploring a possible tie-up with Mitsubishi Motors in a deal to include cooperation on electric vehicles, the companies said Tuesday.

title: South Korean Government Seeks  Ban on Small Leftist Party
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The government of President Park Geun-hye asked the Constitutional Court of South Korea Tuesday to disband a small leftist party accused of supporting North Korea at the cost of the Souths national security.

title: Outsource Your Way to Success
description: Jon Steinsson and Emi Nakamura do not have enough time to do everything they need to do. Theyre recently tenured, highly productive rising stars at Columbia University, as well as parents to an infant. But they have a secret weapon helping them prioritize: Econ 101.

title: At West Point: Duty, Honor, Gay Marriage
description: Daniel Lennox and Larry Choate III were wandering the aisles of a Walmart in Fort Benning, an Army post near Columbus, Ga.

title: Does TV Capture the Diversity of America Yet?
description: Saturday Night Live does not have a black woman as a cast member, a fact that has become a hotly discussed issue. The debate raises a larger issue that seems to come up again and again: Is television too white?

title: E.U. Predicts Anemic Growth and High Unemployment in 2014
description: BRUSSELS  A fragile recovery across the European Union is not expected to bear fruit until next year. And unemployment is likely to remain high in countries like Greece and Spain, and even rise in France, the Unions head of economic policy warned Tuesday.

title: Diplomats Fail to Agree on Details for Syria Peace Talks
description: GENEVA  Senior diplomats from the United States, Russia and the United Nations failed on Tuesday to agree on a date for convening a long-awaited peace conference aimed at settling the Syria conflict, acknowledging it would not take place this month and possibly not this year.

title: German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art
description: It is almost certainly the biggest trove of missing 20th-century European art discovered since the end of World War II, and the first glimpse of it on Tuesday brought astonishment but also anger and the early stirrings of what will likely be a prolonged battle over who owns the works.

title: New York Today: To the Polls
description: Updated 12:10 p.m. | Its finally here  Election Day.

title: Its Election Day
description: Today is Election Day across the nation, as voters in many states go to the polls to choose local and state officials.

title: Broccoli Gone Wild
description: Two weeks ago, while researching Michael Mosss cover story about broccolis image problem, I learned about the Kitchen Community, a Colorado-basednonprofit that has put up, in low-income neighborhoods, billboards with simple recipes to encourage people to cook. Cool idea, except that the broccoli recipe struck me as wrong: Olive oil & salt, 350 oven, 1 hour. Broccoli is a favorite in my house. During the week, I boil the florets in two inches of water, drain and add butter and salt. Sometimes, if Ive had enough sleep, I go wild and saut it after parboiling  this adds char and brings out sweetness. My husband can steam it with scientific precision. None of these methods take an hour; maybe 15 minutes.

title: Daily Report: In New York, Airbnb Offers Extra Income but Questionable Legality
description: Airbnb is a service adored by some, despised by others, and most commonly known as a place to rent out your apartment while you are out of town for a few days, Elizabeth A. Harris reports. But doing so is often illegal in New York City, one reason the company has locked horns with the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

title: United Nations Group Warns on Emissions
description: PARIS  Major polluters must immediately begin to reduce greenhouse gas emissions if the rise in global temperatures is to be held in check, or else a higher price will have to be paid later, according to a report released Tuesday by the United Nations Environment Program.

title: U.S.-Saudi Relations
description: A tense meeting between Secretary of State John Kerry and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia.

title: After Outside Pressure, Rebels in Congo Lay Down Their Arms
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  Col. Mamadou Moustafa stood at the front lines of the battle for eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, surveying his soldiers fighting to dislodge rebels from the surrounding hills.

title: New Warnings for Old Problems
description: The latest revisions to The Timess stylebook gave us an opportunity to take aim at some perennial usage problems, nagging missteps that are staples of After Deadline. Weve added a handful of new warnings in hopes of cutting down on these repeat offenses.

title: Where to Vote in the New York Region
description: The polls are now open throughout the New York region.

title: On the Chinese Internet, Big Interest in Smogs Threat to Fertility
description: How do you get online readers to click on a story about a long, official report about climate change? One answer, grabbed by editors of Chinese news sites Tuesday, was to play up a single line about a link between air pollution and fertility rates.

title: Intersection: Fall Style in Boston
description: In Bostons Back Bay neighborhood, residents are inspired by the change of seasons, old relationships and the Beastie Boys.

title: Chiara de Blasio Style
description: Looking at how the daughter of New York Citys Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio and others have made the floral headband a part of their fashion.

title: Pink Floyds Comfortably Numb and Other Takes
description: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: An 8-Year-Old Girls Lung Cancer Is Blamed on Air Pollution
description: An 8-year-old girl in Jiangsu Province is the youngest person in China to have received a diagnosis of lung cancer, which a doctor treating her has attributed to air pollution, according to an official news report.

title: Endo Health to Buy Specialty Drug Maker for $1.6 Billion
description: Endo Health Solutions, a health care company known for its pain medication, has reached a deal to acquire a Canadian specialty drug company, Paladin Labs, for $1.6 billion in stock and cash.

title: In Performance: Patrick Page of A Time to Kill
description: In the courtroom drama A Time to Kill, a stage adaptation of the John Grisham novel, Patrick Page plays a Mississippi district attorney, prosecuting the case against black man who kills his daughters two white attackers. In this scene, he addresses the jury. The show, adapted by Rupert Holmes and directed by Ethan McSweeny, is on Broadway at the Golden Theater.

title: An Alternative to the Family Business: The Family Bank
description: Lately, Ive noticed that children of business owners seem less interested than previous generations in joining a family business. Of course, just because they do not want to work in a business with their parents does not mean they are not interested in business at all. And that has led some families who have the means to try a concept known as the family bank.

title: AOL Revenue Rises 6% as Profit Plunges
description: AOL, the giant online portal turned media company, on Tuesday reported third-quarter revenue of $561 million, up 6 percent from a year earlier.

title: The Changing Rules of Outing
description: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: In Kentucky, a Glimpse of Health Insurance Help
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Jennifer Albrecht lost her job after being given a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis last year  a turn of events that her husband, Hugh, described as feeling like a building fell on us. She stretches out her medicine because she cannot afford the refills, suffering worse flare-ups as a result. But last month, after seeking the help of a kynector  one of Kentuckys counselors certified to help people sign up for insurance under the federal health care law  Ms. Albrecht found she qualified for Medicaid. Her coverage will take effect at the beginning of 2014.

title: Spies R Us
description: WASHINGTON  A solid majority of Americans say it is unacceptable for the United States to monitor the phones of allied leaders, according to a recent poll by the Pew Research Center. But Israelis arent so fussed.

title: Suicide Ends Long Night of Chaos Inside New Jersey Mall
description: A young man. A powerful weapon. And a crowded public space.

title: European Telecom Giants in More Deals
description: Consolidation continued on Tuesday in Europes telecommunications industry, as the big players dispose of assets to refocus their strategies.

title: The Making Of | Waldorf Astorias Eccentric New Ad Campaign, Starring Olga Kurylenko
description: Dont laugh at her! The French photographer Bruno Dayan was shushing two young crew members who were snickering while his subject, the actress Olga Kurylenko, flapped her arms in an effort to stay upright. It wasnt her maroon stilettos that were giving her trouble, it was her pose. For the main image in a new campaign for Waldorf Astoria Hotels & Resorts, Dayan had positioned Kurylenko, a Ukrainian-born beauty, in midstride in the lobby of the luxury hotel chains Chicago location. A bellhop, who had been yanked into the shot by Dayan from the curb outside, stood 20 feet behind her holding a luggage cart. To Kurylenkos left stood a male model in a velvet dinner jacket whom she was supposed to notice as she breezed by. Kurylenko took two deep breaths and made eye contact with the model as Dayans flash started again. Beautiful, he barked. No, no, no, relax your mouth. Not too sultry.

title: A Childs Take on the Mayoral Election
description: Dear Diary:

title: Detroit: A Race Overshadowed by Bankruptcy
description: As a trial scrutinizing Americas largest municipal bankruptcy enters its seventh day here, the fight over Detroits top elected office will be decided Tuesday when voters select the next mayor of this battered city in desperate need of a comeback.

title: My Suicide Attempt and My Struggles to Get Help
description: To the woman I love with my whole heart and soul: You are finally free of the terror I have caused in your life, I wrote. I am sorry for everything I have done to you. I deserve every bit of sorrow I feel.

title: During I.V.F., Keeping a Marriage Strong
description: My friend Rachel is undergoing treatment at the same in vitro fertilization clinic, so I often check in with her: to commiserate, compare notes, even meet up  either at our clinic uptown or downtown at the acupuncturist, where we both got pricked a few times a week to warm our wombs. And yet for all our similarities in treatment, theres one difference between us: shes single.

title: A Slum Spends Sleepless Nights in Fear of Eviction
description: NEW DELHI  On the morning of March 24, 2011, several hundred police officers, accompanied by giant bulldozers, surrounded the slum of Gayatri Colony in west Delhi as part of an eviction drive by the Delhi Development Authority, which claims ownership of the colonys land.

title: Militants Kill 5 Police Officers in India
description: NEW DELHI  Militants killed five Indian police officers in a shootout in the forest near Indias border with Bangladesh on Tuesday, marking the second deadly episode in a week linked to the same armed group, known as the Garo National Liberation Army.

title: New York: The Other Races on Your Ballot
description: The race for mayor of New York City has dominated headlines for months, but dozens of other contests will also take place during the general election on Tuesday. Click here to learn more about statewide ballot proposals and candidates for other New York City races, including borough president, district attorney and your local City Council seat.

title: Greece Resumes Talks With Lenders Over Budget Gap
description: ATHENS  Government officials resumed talks with representatives of Greeces foreign creditors on Tuesday amid a dispute over the size of a budget gap for next year and whether more austerity measures would be needed to cover it.

title: The Gun Report: November 5, 2013
description: Guns are now allowed in public libraries in Seattle, thanks toa state supreme court ruling holding thatcities have no right to ban guns in public places such as parks and libraries. The board of the library system said it did not have a choice but to remove its longstanding ban on firearms.

title: 1963: First Woman in Space
description: Hello Hawk, hello Hawk, this is Seagull

title: National Races Were Watching Today
description: In Virginia, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, the Republican candidate, and Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, are running for governor of a state that had once been a Republican stronghold. Mr. McAuliffe, who has been slightly ahead in the polls, was joined by President Obama at a rally on Sunday. And Mr. Cuccinelli has been winding down his campaign with a whirlwind of events, campaigning alongside a roster of Republican governors and presidential hopefuls.

title: Lady Gaga Said to Fire Her Manager
description: Lady Gaga has fired her manager, Troy Carter, just days before the release of her new album, according to three people with direct knowledge of the news who were not authorized to speak about it.

title: New York: Lhota Has Little to Say as He Casts Ballot
description: If voting for himself for mayor felt climactic for Joseph J. Lhota, he did not revel in the moment on Tuesday morning.

title: Acers Chief Resigns Amid Slump in PC Sales
description: SEOUL Acer, the Taiwanese computer maker, said Tuesday that its chief executive, J.T. Wang, had resigned, citing an inability to come to grips with a downturn in the PC business.

title: Ford Pays a High Price for Plant Closing in Belgium
description: GENK, Belgium  Rumors of job cuts at the big Ford plant in this scruffy former coal mining town had been circulating for months. But on a clear morning a year ago, almost nobody in Genk expected what came next.

title: Nominees Named for Clive Barnes Awards
description: The nominees for the fourth annual Clive Barnes Awards for young actors and dancers were announced Tuesday by the Clive Barnes Foundation, which was established in 2009 to administer the prize.

title: 152 Bangladeshi Border Guards Get Death Penalty Over Revolt
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  In an apparently unprecedented ruling, 152 former members of the Bangladesh Rifles, a paramilitary border security force, were sentenced to death on Tuesday in connection with a bloody 2009 mutiny in which several thousand troops took control of their headquarters, demanding better working conditions, and killed scores of people.

title: Today in Small Business: The Making of a Food Truck King
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: New York: For Bloomberg, a Last Vote as Mr. Mayor
description: When a man named Bloomberg, dressed in a crimson tie and a crisp winter coat, showed up to vote on Tuesday at Public School 6 on the Upper East Side, Jeris Coles, the poll worker assisting him, had a question. What was the mayors first name, again?

title: Belgian Town Braces for Ford Exit
description: After battling unions and politicians, Ford has reached a settlement allowing it to close its factory in Genk, Belgium. The move comes at a high price for the company, its workers and the community.

title: Feeling For | Furry Accessories for Winter
description: Take the chill off by layering on sumptuously shaggy gear that will keep you warm without sacrificing even a bit of cool.

title: Paintings Discovered in Germany
description: Hundreds of forgotten art works were found hidden in a Munich apartment.

title: In the N.F.L., Even the Strong Have Weaknesses
description: Who could have predicted that winless Tampa Bay would nearly upset Seattle? After nine weeks in the N.F.L., 25 teams have lost at least three games. The other seven teams, including the Seahawks, have significant strengths, but also weaknesses that they hope to hide.

title: Free-Floating Inflation Hysteria
description: Brad DeLong has some fun with Senator Pat Roberts, who has gone from praising Janet Yellen in August to denouncing her as a dangerous inflationist now. So the senator is willing to say whatever the Tea Party wants him to say; big surprise.

title: What Would Aldous Huxley Make of the Way We Consume Media and Popular Culture?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Jennifer Szalai on the prescience  or lack thereof  of the Brave New World author, who died 50 years ago this month.

title: Worst. Conspirators. Ever.
description: From the FT, about the Murdoch phone-tapping affair:

title: Image of the Day: November 5
Invitation to a Dialogue: Democracy Gone Awry
In JetBlue Loyalty Program, Families Can Share Points
description: JetBlue Airways recently announced the latest addition to its TrueBlue loyalty program  family pooling. Families can now elect to earn and share points as a group, free of charge.

title: Dont Tell Coach': Playing Through Concussions
description: Nausea, sensitivity to bright lights, headache: Chris Coyne knew right away that the helmet-to-helmet hit during football practice had given him a concussion. His fifth, in fact.

title: For a Rich Fish, Red Wine Flatters
description: If you are going to treat a rich fish like tuna as if it were a steak, complete with a red-wine sauce, youll want to drink red wine, too. But not a red thats heavy, oaky or tannic. I would look for a wine that will flatter the peppery spicing. This immediately suggests a Loire Valley red made with cabernet franc, like a Chinon, Bourgueil or Saumur-Champigny, either on the lighter, fresher side or well aged. Burgundy would be delicious, especially a lighter wine like a Marsannay or Santenay, or maybe an older Volnay.

title: Bill De Blasio Votes With His Family
description: After voting in Park Slope, Bill De Blasio shared a story about how his daughter made a surprise visit on Election Day.

title: New York: An Election Day Surprise for de Blasio
description: Bill de Blasio arrived almost an hour behind schedule at his polling place at a library in Park Slope, Brooklyn. But Mr. de Blasio, who recently admitted that he was not a morning person, said that he had not overslept. Instead, his daughter, Chiara, who had told him that she couldnt make it back from college in California for Election Day because of tests, had surprised him by showing up at their house this morning, causing the delay.

title: A New Design for Wireless Sound
description: Pity the poor audio speaker. So boxy and square.

title: The Gin Goes Back Into the Barrel
description: John Little, the founder and master distiller of Smooth Ambler, a West Virginia microdistillery, fell into the aged-gin business by accident. Early in 2012 he had just distilled a batch of his standard gin when he realized he was out of bottles to put it in.

title: End of the Assembly Line
description: Automotive plants in Europe that closed or ceased production this year, or whose closure has been announced.

title: Musical America Names Audra McDonald Musician of the Year
description: The soprano and actress Audra McDonald, though better known for her theater and jazz performances than for her classical work these days, has been named musician of the year by Musical America, a classical music journal that was founded as a weekly newspaper in 1898 and now publishes an online magazine and an annual directory (in print and online) that lists performers, ensembles, music schools and management companies.

title: New Jersey: Hometown Voting
Though Defiant, Senator Accused of Plagiarism Admits Errors
description: WASHINGTON  SenatorRand Paulof Kentucky acknowledged Tuesday that mistakes in his office had caused unattributed writing by others to appear in his own work and announced that he was instituting safeguards to prevent such breaches from happening again.

title: Boston: A New Mayor for the First Time in 20 Years
description: Election Day in Boston began briskly as voters went to the polls under sunny blue skies to elect a new mayor for the first time in two decades.

title: New York: Crossover Votes Unlikely This Year
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani and Michael R. Bloomberg both ran for mayor as Republicans (Mr. Bloomberg later became an independent) and were elected mayor in large part thanks to the support of Democratic voters. Scholars at the City University of New Yorks Center for Urban Research have analyzed the crossover Democratic vote, and suggest that this years pattern is likely to be very different. Their analysis is available here.

title: Brazil's North Zones
description: The Frugal Traveler heads to the north sides of So Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, where urban explorers can find affordable adventures.

title: In Rio and So Paulo, Go North
description: It is a startlingly pleasant anomaly in the normally intimidating 11-million-person megacity of So Paulo. On a quaint square across from a tiny 112-year-old church, a bar called Frang (frangobar.com.br) offers worn wooden tables in cozy nooks, an astonishing 500-label beer list and a celebrated version of the popular Brazilian chicken croquettes called coxinhas.

title: Virginia: A Street Fight for Turnout
description: Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor, just shrugged when one commuter declined to shake his hand at a Metro station. Cant get em all, he said, more amused than disappointed.

title: Palestinian Inmate With Cancer Dies in Israeli Hospital
description: GAZA  A Palestinian prisoner with cancer died in an Israeli hospital on Tuesday, prompting accusations of medical malpractice by Palestinian leaders.

title: Mighty, Muslim and Leaping Off the Page
description: With most superheroes, when you take away the colorful costume, mask and cape, what you find underneath is a white man. But not always. In February, as part of a continuing effort to diversify its offerings, Marvel Comics will begin a series whose lead character, Kamala Khan, is a teenage Muslim girl living in Jersey City.

title: Should Our Daughters Come to Our (Gay) Wedding?
description: One morning when I was making breakfast before school, my second-grade daughter, fresh off her schools diversity unit on homosexuality, decided it was time I had a lesson in gay rights. First, she said, you should never use the word gay in a negative way, as in Thats so gay! Very interesting, I said, plotting to push a little deeper into this intriguing topic. So what is gay, I asked? Gay is when two boys like each other, and lesbian is when two girls like each other, she explained. Did she know anyone who was gay or lesbian, I asked? Im pretty sure Im a lesbian because all my friends are girls, she declared. Did she know anyone else? Well, Larry only plays with boys, so he must be gay. Anyone else? Nope.

title: In Our Pages: November 6
description: 1938 Plot to Kill King of Siam Found

title: Diane Pauluss Cirque du Soleil Show Headed to New York
description: Cirque du Soleil has discovered that one way to wow New Yorkers  that is, beyond the companys usual blend of daring acrobatics and high-gloss artistry  is to come to town with productions staged by major directors. Last year, Cirque brought Totem, staged at Citi Field by Robert Lepage, the Canadian director whose production of Wagners Ring at the Metropolitan Opera has been the subject of debate among opera aficionados in recent years, and who also directed Ka, the Cirque spectacular in which an acrobat fell to her death in June.

title: New Rule, and Vacancy, for a Wall St. Regulator
description: Updated, 8:10 p.m. | Bart Chilton, the outspoken regulator whose colorful commentary on financial risk taking positioned him as a fierce critic of the industry he helped oversee, announced on Tuesday that he was leaving his post at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The move is the latest sign that Wall Streets scrappiest regulatory agency is poised for a makeover.

title: Its Election Day. Why Is No One Panicking?
description: Election Day! A day for fresh starts and new directions, though probably not in New Jersey, which looks set to re-elect its Republican governor, Chris Christie, by an overwhelming margin over the Democrat, Barbara Buono. Just how overwhelming is the big question, and the answer may well affect how much Mr. Christie will intrude into the lives of non-Jersey Americans in the next presidential race.

title: New York: Stop-and-Frisk Crosses into the Ballot Box
description: Just after 7 a.m. on Tuesday, Darrian Smith, 48, a custodian at Public School 150 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, was sweeping the grounds outside the school, which also serves as a polling place.

title: On the Verge | In Portland, a New Shopping Center Thats So Portland It Hurts
description: An unexpected location in Portland, Ore., has evolved into a gleaming retail destination.

title: Listen to the Mockingbird
description: The tune, so recognizable, was composed by an African-American street musician named Richard Milburn in 1855, about whom too little is known. The words were written by Alice Hawthorne, the nom de plume of a lyricist whose real name was Septimus Winner. (Why would anyone refuse to use such a name?)

title: New York: As Expected, Not Very Many Voters at the Polls
description: By early Tuesday afternoon, election officials and both mayoral campaigns said turnout at the citys 1,200 polling places was low to moderate, at most.

title: Allen Edmonds Changes Private Equity Hands
description: The private equity firm Brentwood Associates has won the bidding war for the Allen Edmonds Corporation, the high-end mens shoemaker, ending a sale process that included suitors like Mens Wearhouse.

title: Notes Reveal Chaotic White House Talks on Health Care Site
description: WASHINGTON  More than 100 pages of war room notes released by congressional investigators on Tuesday offer a window into the chaos that overwhelmed the Obama administration as the federal health insurance marketplace started up last month and officials realized that its problems could not be fixed quickly.

title: Chris Chase, Actress Who Turned to Writing, Dies
description: Chris Chase, an actress, journalist, memoirist and co-author of autobiographical books about Rosalind Russell, Josephine Baker and Betty Ford, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Behind Those Fast Growth Rates, Rising Inequality
description: DAKAR, Senegal  It was his first post-election news conference, at a luxurious villa high above the Congo River, and the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo was in a combative mood. How dare the reporters question his countrys progress, he argued: just look at our sizzling growth rate  double, even triple, the rates of those pitiful laggards in the West.

title: DirecTV Reports Gain in U.S. Subscribers
description: DirecTV surprised Wall Street on Tuesday by reporting a gain of 139,000 television subscribers in the United States in the third quarter of the year, a sharply higher rise than analysts had expected.

title: Proposed Rule Limits Size of Commodities Traders Positions
description: In 1979, Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Hunt famously bought up as much silver as they could in the commodities market. By the time they were done, the brothers had acquired more than a third of the worlds supply of silver, sending the price of the precious metal soaring.

title: Idaho Town Struggles After Pinning Hopes on a Failed Factory
description: POCATELLO, Idaho  With great fanfare, a Chinese polysilicon factory broke ground on 67 acres here in 2007. Then, as the rest of the nation tumbled into recession, the plant rose up in shimmering promise, leaving this tough-edged railroad town  blue collar and union in a sea of southeast Idaho potato farms  feeling pretty good about the future.

title: Detroit: Challenges Loom for Next Mayor
description: A federal bankruptcy judge will have final say over this citys financial overhaul. A state-appointed emergency manager has run this City Hall for months and may not leave anytime soon. The current mayor, Dave Bing, would not seek another term, criticizing a supposed partnership with state officials that has left him powerless and perturbed.

title: Election Day in New York City
description: New Yorkers cast their vote for a new mayor.

title: In Mideast, Kerry Tries to Nudge Peace Talks Along
description: JERUSALEM  With Middle East peace negotiations showing signs of lapsing into an all-too-familiar paralysis, Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here Tuesday night for a flurry of meetings aimed at jolting the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to reinvigorate the three-month-old round of talks.

title: A Website Concludes Its Users Need More Hand-Holding
description: In my most recent post, we were challenged to simplify a fairly complex online value proposition. Bid4Spots allows advertising clients to reverse bid for radio airtime. When the site was introduced, the company believed that customers would fully commit to the auction online without human interaction. Over time, however, it realized that it was going to be necessary to have Bid4Spots representatives walk clients through the process.

title: Buttercream Frosting
description: Melissa Clark gets help from her daughter Dahlia to make a delicious and fluffy cake topping.

title: New Italian Sculptures Will Have a Park View
description: A pair of 13-foot-high statues  one in marble and the other in polished stainless steel  by the architect and designer Antonio Pio Saracino are coming to a public plaza in Manhattan.

title: Boston: Deciding on a New Mayor and a Casino
description: At lunch time on Election Day, there were more volunteers than voters clustered at a high school in East Boston, where voters had gone to pick the citys first new mayor in 20 years and to decide whether to approve a referendum that could reshape this faded neighborhood by allowing a new casino there.

title: A Party Is Icing on the Cake
description: Heres a peek behind the scenes: we shot this video on my actual birthday. And this is the cake I have been making over the last several years to celebrate. Its a rich almond birthday cake frosted with buttercream.

title: Wheelies: The Pickup Slowdown Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

title: Even Elected Officials Have Trouble Voting in Texas
description: When Republican lawmakers began making it harder to vote by passing voter ID laws, their target was not white politicians.

title: With TiVo, More Features for TV Lovers
description: TiVo knows what television lovers want.

title: Lael Brainard to Step Down From Treasury Post
description: WASHINGTON  Lael Brainard, the countrys top financial diplomat, is leaving her post at the end of the week, a Treasury official said. Some have speculated that the White House might choose her for a position on the Federal Reserves board of governors.

title: She Snoozes, but Wins
description: Whats the most memorable moment in Sleeping Beauty? When Princess Aurora encounters the fateful spindle, or when the prince awakens her with a kiss?

title: I Have Smoked Crack Cocaine, Torontos Mayor Admits on Camera
description: Last Updated, 5:34 p.m. | After dodging questions for months about video evidence said to show him using drugs, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto stunned constituents and his own staff on Tuesday by telling a scrum of reporters, Yes, I have smoked crack cocaine.

title: A Congolese Rebellion Routed, a Photographers Work Continues
description: The column of soldiers marched uphill single file, slowly but deliberately making its way to the town of Bunagana, on the border between the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda. Pete Muller trekked alongside them to photograph the moment when Congolese soldiers liberated the town from the control of the M23 rebel group, part of a rapid advance by government forces that pushed the group out of areas it held in its year-and-a-half long insurrection.

title: Taking a Better Selfie With an Audiovox App
description: It appears that selfies  those self-portraits of you and your arm  are here to stay, even gaining mention in the Oxford Dictionaries.

title: New York: In the Running
description: A major element of The Timess reporting on the mayoral race was the long-form, biographical series called In the Running, which examined the lives and careers of the leading candidates, with detail and perspective. The series was intended to offer a picture of the candidates behind the scenes, how they thought and how they acted in high-pressure situations. Here is a catalog of these articles. Check them out  they offer a unique look back at the campaign and some insight into the next administration.

title: New York: Sunshine at the Polls
Road to Morocco Stops in Yonkers
description: YONKERS  It is sometimes said that if you go to the makeshift Jewish museum in the medina of Fez, Morocco, and quietly ask the custodian there if he has any mahia, you might get lucky. Then again, you could simply turn to a married couple in downtown Yonkers.

title: On Staten Island, Wilderness With Creature Comforts
description: Its not surprising that the 19th-century transcendentalists were attracted to Emerson Hill on Staten Island: The neighborhood still has a measure of the natural beauty of the wilderness that first attracted those poets and philosophers.

title: Iranian Minister Says Nuclear Deal Is Possible This Week
description: PARIS  Two days before negotiations resume in Geneva between Iran and the United States and other Western powers aimed at ending a fight over the disputed Iranian nuclear program, the countrys foreign minister sounded an optimistic note on Tuesday, saying a deal was possible as soon as this week.

title: Toronto Mayor Admits Crack Use, as Wild Ride in Office Continues
description: TORONTO  He has been thrown out of a Toronto Maple Leafs hockey game for being drunk and belligerent. He groped a female politician at a fund-raiser for a Jewish community group, and was asked to stop coaching a high school football team after having a violent confrontation with one of the players. He has admitted to drinking too much.

title: New York Sees Light Turnout After Lopsided Mayoral Polls
description: New York City voters headed to the polls on Tuesday to decide whether they would put a Democrat back in control of the nations largest city for the first time in two decades.

title: Mayor of Toronto Admits to Drug Use
description: Mayor Rob Ford said he smoked crack cocaine when he was in a "drunken stupor" last year.

title: Going
description: By Sam Phillips

title: Pretty Time Bomb
description: By Sam Phillips

title: Tavis Smiley to Write Book on Martin Luther King Jr.s Final Days
description: The television and radio host Tavis Smiley will write a book about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Smileys publisher said, exploring the attacks on Dr. Kings character, ideology, and political tactics and how they shaped both the year leading up to his death in 1968 and his lasting legacy.

title: The Art of the Prosthesis
description: The people who ask Sophie de Oliveira Barata to make their prosthetic limbs  Nadav Kander photographed several of them for this past weekends health issue  want hands and legs that are not only functional but also personally expressive in some way. She produces her bespoke creations, like the snake-arm seen above, out of her London-based Alternative Limb Project. The pictures made us curious to know more about de Oliveira Baratas enterprise, so she sent us some interesting facts about her work making prostheses:

title: The Tax Motive in Endo Healths Deal
description: Greed is seeping into the art of mergers and acquisitions. Endo Health Solutions is the latest buyer to receive a warm welcome for a sensible acquisition with notable savings. Its market value jumped almost as much as the $1.6 billion price of its purchase, Paladin Labs. But the deal also involves a huge tax dodge, and investors arent factoring in enough risk.

title: Look-Alikes Top the B.C.S. Standings
description: Alabama and Florida State, which both remain undefeated and are Nos. 1 and 2 in this weeks Bowl Championship Series standings, are look-alikes, right down to the shades of red in their jerseys, one crimson, the other garnet.

title: At the Polls
description: Voters cast their ballots in races across the country.

title: Colorado: Drive-Through Voting in Denver
Fantasy Football Week 10: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
description: Socrates said: The more you learn, the more you realize how little you know. That saying held true this past week more so than usual, leading to another abnormal scoring leader list that included the likes of Nick Foles, Jerricho Cotchery, Jason Campbell and the previously thought to be missing Tom Brady.

title: Chevron and Ukraine Set Shale Gas Deal
description: LONDON  Western oil companies trying to find shale gas in Europe are discovering that Ukraine, eager to reduce its dependence on Russian energy imports, is one of their most willing partners.

title: Farm-Raised Salmon, Maple Cotton Candy and More
description: To Cook: Fillets That Come From the Farm

title: Pink Tea Cup Lands in Brooklyn
description: Headliner

title: Rachel Roys Beauty Regimen for Two Coasts
description: Unlike many clothing designers, Rachel Roy, 39, lives in New York and Los Angeles, whose different climates pose skin-care challenges. But her beauty routine is fairly consistent. BEE SHAPIRO

title: Rand Pauls Plagiarism
description: The story so far, told (almost) entirely in other peoples words. Brackets indicate original thinking. Click the links for attribution.

title: Tasting Tokyo With a Chefs Notes
description: As much as David Kinch, the chef and owner of the restaurant Manresa in Los Gatos, Calif., uses local ingredients like abalone and nasturtium petals in his kitchen and features them in his new cookbook, Manresa: An Edible Reflection, it would be misleading to say the Bay Area is his only muse.

title: Restaurant Report: Crate in Asheville, N.C.
description: On paper, the recipe for Crate, a traditional Spanish tapas restaurant that opened in 2011 in downtown Asheville, seems to lack some requisite ingredients. First, the chef and co-owner Katie Button isnt Spanish. Then theres the fact that just six years ago she was a budding scientist, not a restaurateur. Finally, real Spanish food is an anomaly in this part of the country, where farm-to-table Americana is firmly rooted.

title: New York: Awaiting a Democrats Return
description: On the Upper East Side, some voters were jubilant at the prospect of sending a Democrat to City Hall after two decades  even if they had mixed feelings about the candidate.

title: Prince Charles May Have Unfair Tax Edge, Report Says
description: LONDON  Royal households have historically been better at collecting tax than paying it. Prince Charles is about to find that out.

title: Karley Sciortino: In Her Own Voice
description: AGE 28

title: A Taste of the Wild
description: Stripping cooking to its raw elements in South Carolina: foraging, hunting, fishing and farming.

title: Swamp to Table
description: HARDEEVILLE, S.C.  I am sitting in the most amazing puddle of mire, Matt Jennings, the chef at Farmstead in Providence, R.I., announced into the dark from his perch atop a 12-foot-high hunting blind.

title: Federal Charges in Port Chester Police Dept. Feud
description: A caustic feud in Westchester County between a villages longtime police chief on medical leave and the acting chief reached a climax recently with some physical and verbal threats and resulted in a federal witness-tampering complaint against the longtime chief that carries the possibility of a 20-year sentence.

title: J Mays, Noted Ford Designer, to Retire
description: Ford Motor announced Tuesday that J Mays, who has directed the automakers designs for 16 years and is group vice president and chief creative officer, would retire in January. Succeeding Mr. Mays, 59, will be Moray Callum, 54, who has been responsible for the design of Fords cars in the Americas since 2006 and will assume the title of vice president of design.

title: Virginia: Marking a Broken Voting Machine
Syrian Children Draw What Used to be Home
description: After enduring two and a half years of the grueling brutality that defines Syria, the fall of Assads regime is no longer the most pressing concern of most Syrians. Rather, When will we return home? is the question that haunts the over seven million displaced Syrians. Of course, the fact that the first concern is the reason the second one exists adds to the countrys mass despair.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Brooks Brothers Cashmere Scarf
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Quality Italian
description: Inside the Midtown restaurant that seems to have figured out that some people would rather eat in a theater than a church.

title: Domestic Dispute Leads to Test of Federal Power
description: WASHINGTON  A lurid domestic dispute provided the unlikely backdrop for a major test of federal power on Tuesday at the Supreme Court, one a government lawyer said could affect the eradication of chemical weapons in Syria.

title: The Hardy Folks Who Found Gold in Shale
description: The history of oil and natural gas extraction has largely been the story of men with long straws, as Daniel Day-Lewis memorably demonstrated in There Will Be Blood, trying to drink one anothers milkshakes.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, Yemen and the West Bank.

title: New York: Hugs and Handshakes in Crown Heights
description: Outside a subway station in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, this afternoon, Bill de Blasio hugged and kissed women, shook mens hands, and bent from his 6-foot-5-inch height to greet small children and ask their ages.

title: Where the Trolleys Still Run in New York
description: The steak will be here in a minute. First, the show.

title: The Pulitzer Prize Was Nice and All, but a Work Is Finally Fully Heard
description: You might assume that any music piece that wins the Pulitzer Prize would already have had its premiere. Not necessarily, as indicated by the inspiring story of Caroline Shaws Partita for Eight Voices, an exhilarating, sensual and playful work.

title: Parts of a Pretzel Empire Are for Sale in Amish Country
description: GAP, Pa.  Since 1988, philanthropy and a highly successful brand of soft pretzel have combined to provide marriage counseling and other family services to this community in Lancaster County, some 55 miles west of Philadelphia.

title: Swan Song Too Hawkish for Some
description: LOS ANGELES  The Wind Rises is the type of art film that typically speeds into the Oscar race. Critics at film festivals have swooned over its nuance. It delivers messages about turbulent modern times by examining traumatic events of the past. The films 72-year-old director and writer, Hayao Miyazaki, a cinematic giant, has said the ambitious animated picture will be his last, a final bow.

title: Profits at 21st Century Fox Hampered by TV Investments
description: Investments in new cable channels were a drag on 21st Century Foxs third-quarter profits, but total revenues still surpassed analysts expectations.

title: Putting Up With Evil, Then Getting a Princely Hand
description: PHOENIX  Few careers in ballet have shown a more remarkable trajectory than that of Ib Andersen. I remember him in 1979 in Copenhagen as a young star of the Royal Danish Ballet (he had been the youngest principal in its history), shining in several of the mid-19th-century classics by the Danish master August Bournonville. A year later Mr. Andersen was a principal of New York City Ballet, where he created roles in new ballets by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins.

title: Blooming, Languishing, Reviving
description: Most of the guys are in their 50s now, and 50 isnt old for rock stars anymore. But most rock stars have not messed things up as thoroughly as the Stone Roses did roughly 20 years ago. One minute their debut album was being acclaimed as among the greatest ever; the next they were embroiled in a legal battle that delayed their follow-up album for five years. It flopped, and the group broke up.

title: Philip Smith, Philharmonics Principal Trumpet, to Retire
description: Philip Smith, the New York Philharmonics principal trumpet, announced on Tuesday that he would retire from the orchestra at the end of the 2013-14 season. He will have been a member of the orchestra for 36 years: he joined as co-principal trumpet in 1978, when Zubin Mehta, then the orchestras music director, hired him away from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. He became the orchestras principal trumpet in 1988.

title: The Making of an Immortal Movie
description: In 1967, George Romero, a Bronx-born 27-year-old transplanted to Pittsburgh, shot a cheap independent movie in rural Pennsylvania. The film, Night of the Living Dead, became a horror classic, spawning sequels and helping to inspire the vogue for zombies raging on television and in multiplexes. Rob Kuhnss informative documentary Birth of the Living Dead recounts the risks, improvisation and innovation that went into the movies production.

title: Alabama: Small Race Reflects G.O.P. Divide
description: The city of Atmore in southwestern Alabama typically takes a turn in the national spotlight when an inmate is executed at the state prison there.

title: N.J. Exit Poll: Economy Weighs Heavily on Voters
description: According to early results from exit polls conducted by Edison Research, the issue that mattered most to voters in the New Jersey race for governor was the economy, with half of all voters selecting it as the key issue for them. The economy was followed by taxes, which was selected by one out of every four voters.

title: Romantic Comedy: Imbibe in Moderation
description: In Kat Coiros new film, A Case of You, the mildly neurotic Sam (Justin Long) is a struggling writer in Brooklyn making a living from movie novelizations, but he has a Serious Book inside him. Shamed for his bachelor status by his happily married and pregnant former classmate (Sienna Miller), Sam woos the mildly daffy coffeehouse clerk Birdie (Evan Rachel Wood, in a departure from her darker portraits), who is also a caricature artist in Prospect Park. To impress her, he studies her Facebook page and awkwardly pretends to share her interests, including cooking, Joan Baez, the guitar, Carlos Castaneda and ballroom dancing.

title: Va. Exit Poll: Mixed on Candidates, Sour on Economy
description: In the tight Virginia governors race, exit polls found voters giving the candidates equal marks on ethics.

title: Meadham Kirchhoffs Rule-Breaking Topshop Collection
description: Fresh off a triumphant ready-to-wear presentation this spring  a typically demented, dazzling mash-up of Charles Addams and Leigh Bowery  the London-based fashion label Meadham Kirchhoff has put together a witty new collection for Topshop, which includes everything from a pair of glittery ruby platforms with marshmallow heels to frilly baby-doll dresses and mohair jumpers. Its another spirited line from a design team that is determined to break the rules. The industry has become dictatorial, Edward Meadham says. All we ask is that we can show our clothes exactly how we want to, exactly how it comes out of us. What people make of it after that is up to them. Available Nov. 21.

title: Eminem Grows Older, but Not Up
description: We have watched Eminem age, all of us, difficult as it has been. Weve seen him lash out at his mother, his then-wife, and his fans. Weve seen him soften ever so slightly under the weight of fatherhood. Weve seen him court protest, then express befuddlement over the hubbub. Weve seen him retreat into drugs, and then climb out of the morass.

title: A Fantastical Shootout, Moving Across Space and Time
