description: With a story ripped not from the headlines but seemingly from a strategy guide for the Parker Brothers board game Risk  control of a unified South America is the best possible starting point for global military domination  Call of Duty: Ghosts is the silliest entry in an increasingly silly series, even as it remains quite possibly the most lucrative one in video games.

title: N.Y. Exit Poll: Ready for Change
description: New York City residents went to the polls today with contrary views of the current administration. While they approve of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs performance, they are also looking for a change from his policies.

title: Main Street Advocacy Advertisement
description: Main Street Advocacy, a moderate Republican group, is planning to defend candidates it views as more electable in Republican primaries against more conservative organizations.

title: Illinois Sends Bill Allowing Gay Marriage to Governor
description: The Illinois House of Representatives voted Tuesday to allow same-sex couples to wed, ending months of delay over the issue in the Capitol and clearing the way for Illinois to become the 15th state, along with the District of Columbia, to permit gay couples to marry.

title: LG Shows Off the Bend in Its Flex
description: SEOUL, South Korea LG Electronics of South Korea took the wraps off its new curved smartphone, the G Flex, on Tuesday, showing off the device at a gathering of mostly Korean journalists at its headquarters here.

title: Holy Fictional Mayors, Batman
description: Fiction and reality have often played off each other during onscreen depictions of New York politics.

title: N.Y. Exit Poll: Worried but Optimistic
description: Despite worries over the New York City economy, voters feel the city is headed in the right direction.

title: New F.C.C. Chairman Outlines His Vision
description: Few people who have engaged the maw of regulation that has historically characterized the Federal Communications Commission would be likely to call it the Optimism Agency.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,274 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: N.J. Exit Poll: Problems for G.O.P., Support for Gay Marriage
description: Compared to the last time they voted for governor, New Jersey voters are less approving of Barack Obamas performance as president, an exit poll conducted on Tuesday by Edison Research showed. In 2009, 57 percent approved of how Mr. Obama was handling his job; this year a bare majority approve.

title: Apple Releases Report on Government Requests
description: Apple on Tuesday released a report showing the number of requests about its customers that it has received from government agencies around the globe.

title: New York: Holy Fictional Mayors, Batman
description: Fiction and reality have often played off each other during onscreen depictions of New York politics.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: A Land Where I.E. Still Dominates, and Responding to Bezoss Wife
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Ethnic Variations in Fertility Treatment
description: Race or ethnicity may be a factor in the success of fertility treatment, a new study suggests.

title: Va. Exit Polls: Complete Results
Police Confiscate Banksy Balloons and Say Theyre Not Art
description: Banksy! is still in police custody  that is, the balloons that spell the British street artists name, as well as an exclamation point, are. And they may never get out.

title: Unequal Funding
description: Because school districts are mostly funded locally, through property taxes, there are enormous disparities between states in the amount of resources available to public schools.

title: In Public Education, Edge Still Goes to Rich
description: There arent many things that are more important to that idea of economic mobility  the idea that you can make it if you try  than a good education, President Obama told students at the State University of New York in Buffalo in August.

title: Deceased Wifes Foresight Helps Man Make Progress
description: The year: 1990. The place: Canvanas, Puerto Rico. Anita Villalongo was a Puerto Rican, with dramatic cheekbones and skin the color of caramel. Eugenio German was a Dominican, the irises of his eyes chocolate brown rimmed by a deep ocean blue. Eugenio sold ice cream from a pushcart. Anita left her building each day to buy a cone.

title: Live Nation Reports Lower Profits on Higher Revenue
description: Live Nation Entertainment, the concert industry giant that includes Ticketmaster, reported lower profits for its third quarter, but higher revenue as attendance to its concerts and festivals grew around the world.

title: Va. Exit Poll: More Voters Say They Are Democrats
description: Compared with voters who went to the polls four years ago in Virginia, the demographics of the electorate in 2013 have shifted in small but meaningful ways.

title: Chris Christie Coasts to 2nd Term as Governor of New Jersey

title: Nicholas S. G. Stern

title: Bloomberg, Champion of the Poor
description: DURING New York Citys mayoral race, criticism of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for neglecting the poor ignored his bold and unprecedented antipoverty measures. He may not have eliminated inequality or reversed the impact of the Great Recession  over the last two years, the poverty rate has crept up to 21.2 percent from 20.1 percent  but failure to acknowledge what he did in fact accomplish is not only unfair but also shortsighted. Usually depicted as a champion of the rich, Mr. Bloomberg mounted an antipoverty program at a moment when poverty as an issue was off the national radar and even politically toxic.

title: Torontos Hot Mess
description: TORONTO  JUST the other day, a definitive Toronto image was making the rounds on Twitter. One of the turnstiles in the subway system had broken and no guards were around, so passengers had left their tickets and change in a small pile on the side. I live in an absurdly law-abiding, rule-following city. Theres one major exception: the mayor. He smokes crack. He said so on Tuesday. Twice.

title: In a Message to Poachers, U.S. Will Destroy Its Ivory

title: Too Big to Breathe?
description: SHANGHAI  I arrived here on Oct. 19th and was greeted with this news: A combination of cold weather, lack of wind, coal-powered heating and farmers burning off post-harvest debris had created a perfect storm of pollution in the northeastern industrial city of Harbin, home to 10 million people. It was so bad that bus drivers were getting lost because the smog-enveloped roads would only permit them to see a few yards ahead. Harbins official website reportedly warned that cars with headlights turned on were moving no faster than pedestrians and honking frequently as drivers struggled to see traffic lights meters away.

title: Obama Presses Case for Immigration Changes

The leaders included Joe Echevarria, chief executive of Deloitte LLP; Marillyn A. Hewson, chief executive of Lockheed Martin; Stephen A. Schwarzman, chairman of Blackstone, and several others who had not previously played such prominent roles in supporting an immigration overhaul.

description: The Food and Drug Administration made the appropriate call last week when it suspended sales of a promising leukemia drug for desperately ill patients that turned out to be unexpectedly dangerous. (ABC) THE 47TH ANNUAL CMA AWARDS Carrie Underwood and Brad Paisley (below) return as hosts of this ceremony, billed as country musics biggest night and broadcast live from the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Kenny Rogers, a five-time Country Music Association Award winner and recent Country Music Hall of Fame inductee, will be honored with the Willie Nelson Lifetime Achievement Award and a tribute by Jennifer Nettles, Rascal Flatts and Darius Rucker. Taylor Swift will receive the Pinnacle Award, which recognizes an artist who has made a positive impact on the appreciation of country music. Ms. Swift will take the stage with Vince Gill and Alison Krauss, the Zac Brown Band will perform with Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters, and Hunter Hayes will team up with Jason Mraz. And Jason Aldean, Luke Bryan, Blake Shelton, Ms. Swift and George Strait will compete for the evenings top honor, entertainer of the year. description: Two Chinese banks that sold nearly $2 billion worth of shares in Hong Kong stock market listings received lukewarm receptions on Wednesday from investors concerned about how Chinas financial system would cope with a potential deluge of bad debt that could swamp the countrys economy.

title: A Small Business Starts to Navigate the Affordable Care Act
description: Last week, I took a phone call from Maggie, my health insurance broker. Im calling my clients who are getting big increases this year, she said. I didnt want to just send an email.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The New Mayor of New York City
description: In the article Heading to City Hall, Bill de Blasio Is Used to Exceeding Expectations, Javier C. Hernndez writes about this man in the news.

title: A Train Too Far
description: ISTANBUL  Last Tuesday the city celebrated the 90th anniversary of Turkeys founding with unusual pomp. Senior politicians cut the ribbon on a spectacular new metro system that runs some 200 feet below the Sea of Marmara and can carry 1.5 million people every day between the European and Asian sides of the city.

title: Cisco Counters Its Young Competitors in Data Networking
description: Cisco Systems has announced its big play for the future of data networking, a multibillion-dollar business that holds the Internet together. Its comprehensive, probably compelling for people who already own lots of Cisco equipment (which is most large companies that operate networks), and for Cisco at least, expensive.

title: Blurring Art, Artifice and Pop Culture
description: Lady Gaga the relentless is back in full force on Artpop (Streamline/Interscope), her third full-length studio album of new songs. It took hip surgery, for injuries that she had aggravated onstage, to knock her off her tour and sideline her from media exposure for a few months earlier this year. But in summer the next push began with a single, Applause, that simultaneously reaffirmed her need for the love of her audience and announced her new pivot to align herself with the (visual) art world, singing, Pop culture was in art, now arts in pop culture, in me.

title: Daily Report: Samsung Promises to Double Its Dividend
description: At a meeting with investors in Seoul on Wednesday, executives from Samsung Electronics laid out their vision for the companys future, saying they would fine-tune a strategy that has helped the company become the worlds biggest smartphone maker, Eric Pfanner reports. Samsungs one-third share of the global smartphone business is more than double the volume of its nearest competitor, Apple.

title: An Unofficial Barista at Starbucks
description: Dear Diary:

title: The European Central Banks Inflation Conundrum
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank will meet on Thursday under renewed pressure to do more to stimulate the Continents sluggish economies, as evidence grows that the recovery is failing to pick up speed and that inflation has fallen so low as to become worrisome.

title: Battle Over ValueVision Set to Heat Up
description: The move by the activist hedge fund Clinton Group to try to oust senior executives at the Internet and shopping network ValueVision Media is poised to become a bitter battle.

title: New York: De Blasio to Meet With Bloomberg
description: Fresh off his overwhelming victory in Tuesdays mayoral election, Bill de Blasio planned to meet on Wednesday morning with the man who has run the city for the last 12 years, Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Helen Caldicott, Chernobyl and the New York Academy of Sciences
description: Helen Caldicott, a physician who for decades has fought nuclear power, wrote a letter to The Times criticizing David Ropeiks recent Op-Ed article on outsize fears of radiation. Caldicotts letter contained a mischaracterization of a much-criticized Russian study that attributed a million deaths to the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, calling it a New York Academy of Sciences report. I contacted academy staff to get the organizations view. Heres the result:

title: Carlyle Reports Lower Earnings for Third Quarter
description: Updated, 11:02 a.m. | The private equity giant Carlyle Group reported lower third-quarter earnings on Wednesday, amid a slow period in selling its investments.

title: On Beauty | Bare Is Beautiful
description: A face without makeup looks wholesome and shows confidence  but doesnt come without effort.

title: Shrinking Numbers and Growing Persecution Threaten Sikhs and Hindus in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  J.K. Sharma, a large Sikh man in a black turban, works out of a small room lined with jars and herbs in the ruined and dusty Shor Bazaar in Kabul. In a war-ravaged country where miracles are in short supply, Mr. Sharma makes a living as a magician, providing advice and talismans to Muslim Afghans for a fee.

title: If Only Grazed Grasslands Could Sop Up All Industrial CO2
description: Theres a very helpful post on the RealClimate blog critiquing the appealing, virally shared, and largely wishful climate change strategy that Allan Savory laid out in a popular TED talk not long ago. Savory  a biologist, farmer and environmentalist and more  claimed that certain approaches to managing grazed grasslands could more than absorb all of the carbon dioxide were adding to the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels.

title: Despite Fumbles, Obama Defends Health Care Law
description: DALLAS  President Obama strongly defended his signature health care law on Wednesday in the largest state that has refused to participate, as rattled Senate Democrats called for changing or delaying key parts of the new health coverage.

title: The Vespa 946: A Scooter for the Wealthy
description: Have you ever come across a $10,000 scooter? Well, meet the 946, Vespas newest and most expensive model. With swooping lines and a big red leather-textured seat, it neatly epitomizes the Italian brands gradual transformation from maker of inexpensive transportation for the masses to purveyor of two-wheeled fashion accessories.

title: A Meaningful Minute
description: At 9:59 in the morning, in a seaside city somewhere, a little girl named Jodie is about to draw the final silver button on her picture of an elegantly dressed duck. She pauses for a minute to consider her work. That short span of time is all it takes for Jonathan, her baby brother, to take his first steps. And throughout the multiracial, multiethnic town, other important things happen in that same time frame. An ambulance speeds past, a soldier says goodbye to his mother, a grandfather plays a funny game of leaf houses with his granddaughter. A homeless woman pushes her belongings down the street in a grocery cart. A baby is born, and two friends, Belle and Vashti, pop seaweed on the beach.

title: Lawyers Challenge Detention of Greenwalds Partner in London
description: LONDON  In Londons High Court on Wednesday, lawyers challenged the legality of the temporary detention of David Michael Miranda, the partner of Glenn Greenwald, a journalist who has been writing about the secret documents taken by a former analyst for the National Security Agency, Edward J. Snowden.

title: Sebelius Rejects Delays to Get Time to Repair Problems at Health Site
description: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, said Wednesday that the government needed to fix hundreds of problems with the website for the federal health insurance marketplace, but she categorically rejected bipartisan calls to delay parts of the new health care law.

title: New York: Voter Turnout Appears to Be Record Low
description: Turnout in Tuesdays election for New York City mayor appeared to have set a record low of 24 percent of registered voters.

title: India Gives Foreign Banks New Door Into Local Market
description: MUMBAI  Indias central bank unveiled late Wednesday a far-reaching set of regulations to allow foreign banks into the countrys long-protected domestic market. But it demanded that they do so through subsidiaries incorporated in India and said that eligibility would be limited to banks from countries that reciprocate by letting in Indian banks.

title: Neal Boenzi, Photographer
description: The art of the street photograph as told by Neal Boenzi, who has been recently celebrated as one of the most inventive masters of the form.

title: Performing on the Paris Metro
description: Each year, thousands of musicians from around the world audition to earn a license to play on the Paris Metro.

title: Pointless Political Punditry
description: Ive never been a fan of the entrail reading that follows off-year elections, in which observers try to read great significance into details of the voting patterns. Partly thats because nobody really knows how to do this; partly its because stuff happens, and the political environment a year or three years from now is going to be very different.

title: In Our Pages: November 7
description: 1913 Olympia Auto Show

title: North Atlantic Fiscal Policy
description: The economic crisis of 2008 was, as I like to say, a North Atlantic affair. There were monstrous housing bubbles in both America and Europe, rising household debt on both sides, and then more or less comparable busts in both places. Ours was more exotic, involving fancy instruments nobody understood, where theirs involved more plain-vanilla banking excess. But overall things werent that different.

title: Reader Idea | Researching Political History to Understand How a Community Problem Was Solved
description: With New York City electing Bill de Blasio as its new mayor, we thought it was a fitting time to publish this Reader Idea, from the coordinator for educational programs at the LaGuardia and Wagner Archives, part of LaGuardia Community College in Queens.

title: Released From Prison, and Starting a Company
description: Like most entrepreneurs, Frederick Hutson cannot resist trying to solve a thorny problem. His company, Pigeonly, based in Las Vegas, taps an underserved and captive market by offering prison inmates an easy and efficient way to receive photos from loved ones and to make phone calls to them inexpensively. Isolation is the worst thing for an inmate, Mr. Hutson said. It makes it hard for him to rebuild his life when he gets out.

title: Remembering Editta Sherman, Duchess of Carnegie Hall
description: Someone had gotten a large black hat made of flowers and displayed it with a jaunty tilt  just the way Editta Sherman wore hers  next to the coffin, as if to set a Lets Party! tone for the wake and funeral of Ms. Sherman, the 101-year-old portrait photographer who was known as the Duchess of Carnegie Hall.

title: Backstage Nerves Through the Ages
description: The theater is like an old Jewish mother in a Woody Allen film: always melodramatically, nonsensically on the verge of death. The cause of the affliction, however, varies. Some say ticket prices. Others blame those miserable critics. Television and the Internet are occasionally villains in this drama. But for a historically minded set, a crucial data point in this tragedy is the decline of the repertory, a resident company of actors of the sort that, say, Shakespeare used at the Globe.

title: Qatari Court Orders Temporary Release of American Couple
description: DOHA, Qatar  A court in the wealthy Persian Gulf emirate of Qatar on Wednesday ordered the temporary release of Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple accused of starving their 8-year-old daughter to death, a family member said after the hearing.

title: SAC Capital Cuts a Deal
description: Steven A. Cohens hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, was the target of a decade-long insider trading investigation. Six former SAC traders pleaded guilty and two others, whohavedenied the charges, have been indicted. Now the investigation has led to a deal that calls for SAC to plead guilty tocriminal insider trading charges, and to pay a fine of $1.2 billion.

title: Podesta Starting a Think Tank on Inequality
description: John Podesta, a longtime adviser to Bill and Hillary Clinton and President Obama, is starting a research center in Washington to investigate the causes and effects of growing economic inequality.

title: Knicks Trying to Find Themselves, or Anybody at All, on Defense
description: Missed assignments, blown rotations, wild closeouts and a general lack of communication and purpose  the Knicks made just about every defensive error a team could make in their 102-97 loss Tuesday to the Charlotte Bobcats.

title: After de Blasios Big Victory, Even Bigger Challenges
description: He pledged to remake New Yorks social fabric, stoked the hopes of discouraged liberals and vowed that a city defined by its luxuries would once again be a comfortable home for those with money struggles and the poor.

title: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 1
description: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members.

title: Health Care Deal Is Latest to Seek Corporate Tax Shelter Abroad
description: Corporate inversions keep coming as American companies seek ways to avoid paying high taxes.

title: The Revenge of Donorism
description: There were plenty of reasons for Ken Cuccinellis defeat last night in Virginia at the well-greased hands of Terry McAuliffe, but because the race turned out to be so surprisingly close were going to hear a lot about the money: McAuliffe (of course) had it, Cuccinelli did not, the national Republican Party did not exactly go all-in on his behalf, and so the campaign ended up being defined, and possibly won, by a Democratic advertising blitz that the G.O.P. barely countered.

title: Today in Small Business: Working Weekends
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Nikki Finke Leaves Deadline Hollywood
description: After nearly a year of squabbling, the Hollywood blogger Nikki Finke has parted ways with Jay Penske, the media entrepreneur who in 2009 bought her high-octane industry website Deadline.com.

title: Image of the Day: November 6
Treating the Village to Cure the Disease
description: In communities across Africa, health workers are going house to house with medicine to combat lymphatic filariasis, or L.F., which is the worlds second-largest cause of chronic disability. They make sure the children are old enough, the women arent pregnant and no one is seriously ill. Then people take two pills while the health worker watches. She writes down their names in her ledger.

title: Its a Captive Market. But Is It Big Enough?
description: Like most entrepreneurs, Frederick Hutson cannot resist trying to solve a thorny problem. As Donna Fenn explains in an article we have just published, his company, Pigeonly, which is based in Las Vegas, taps an under-served and captive market by offering prison inmates an easy way to receive photos from loved ones and to make phone calls to them inexpensively. Isolation is the worst thing for an inmate, Mr. Hutson said. It makes it hard for him to rebuild his life when he gets out.

title: Classical Playlist: Jan Lisiecki, Mitsuko Uchida, Stile Antico and More
description: Times critics share what theyve been listening to lately.

title: An Argument for Federal Involvement in Housing
description: Obamacares early problems could recast the debate about a mortgage market overhaul.

title: Marcella Cooks
description: Mark Bittman cooking with Marcella and Victor Hazan at their home in Florida.

title: Remembering Marcella
description: Marcella Hazan, who died Sept. 29 at the age of 89, never intended to bring real Italian cooking to America. But no matter how accidental her impact, it can hardly be overstated. What Alice Waters did for restaurants, Hazan did for home cooks, demonstrating that the simple treatment of decent ingredients leads to wonderful dishes.

title: Amid Capitol Turmoil, Postal Crisis Drags On
description: WASHINGTON  In early 2009, John E. Potter, then the postmaster general, delivered a dire warning to Congress: The United States Postal Service would run out of money unless lawmakers stepped in and passed legislation to help the agency stabilize its finances.

title: Chandlers Leg Fracture Leaves Knicks Thin in the Post
description: Even after 12 seasons in the N.B.A., Tyson Chandler wanted to improve his game over the summer. So he went to work on a short jump shot that he felt could stretch defenses and bolster the Knicks offense. The team considered it a bonus  a way for the 7-foot-1 Chandler to supplement his considerable responsibilities anchoring the post. But that was Chandler, searching for solutions where no problems existed.

title: U.S. Investors Brush Aside Fears About Chinese Internet Companies
description: For American investors, love of technology has conquered a fear of China.

title: A Better Nights Sleep for a Slimmer Christie
description: SOUTH AMBOY, N.J.  While Gov. Chris Christie celebrated a big public victory in New Jersey on Tuesday, he has also been privately enjoying another success: better sleep, as a result of his weight loss.

title: Homes for $750,000
description: Homes in Chicago, Georgia and Newport, R.I.

title: What You Get for $750,000
description: CHICAGO

title: The Passion of Solomon Northup
description: Critics are already hailing the film adaption of Solomon Northups slave narrative, 12 Years a Slave, as a shoo-in for the Academy Award nominations. But many viewers will likely wonder, given that this is a big-budget film with big-budget actors, how faithful it is to the book. The stakes may seem particularly high for a slave narrative, since many likely believe these books offer an unfiltered view of slavery.

title: Just When You Thought It Was Safe to Relive the 70s
description: Those gloriously cheesy 1970s movies in which fistfuls of C-list celebrities face wholesale slaughter at the hands of unnatural acts of nature are lampooned in the new musical Disaster! at the St. Lukes Theater.

title: Time Warners Profit Rises, Lifted by TV
description: Time Warner reported mostly upbeat earnings on Wednesday, and television was the biggest reason.

title: A Larger Place in Park Slope, This Time Ours
description: The small duplex on West 69th Street had been handed down to Andrea Wolinetz and Alexis Placzek by friends. During their three years there, the $2,050-a-month rent had risen to $2,300  still a steal, but not the same sort of steal, Ms. Placzek said.

title: Library Exhibition to Celebrate the Beatles Time in New York
description: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Beatles first visit to New York, and the Ed Sullivan Show appearances that lit the fuse on Beatlemania in America, the New York Public Library and the Grammy Museum are collaborating on a multimedia exhibition, Ladies and Gentlemen  The Beatles!

title: Justices Weigh Constitutionality of New York Towns Prayers
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court, which begins its sessions with an invocation to God, considered on Wednesday whether a town in upstate New York had crossed a constitutional line in opening its Town Board meetings with mostly Christian prayers. The justices seemed to find the issue unusually difficult, with several of them suggesting there was no satisfactory principled answer.

title: Children Eat More After Sleeping Less
description: Children who do not sleep enough may be increasing their risk for obesity, according to a new study.

title: Beneath Martiniques Beauty, Guided by a Poet
description: As the stories poured out, eyes sparkled, smiles widened, hands danced. Everyone I met on Martinique harbored at least one intimate memory of Aim Csaire  a quiet encounter or speech etched forever in their consciousness  but they all agreed: this poet, playwright and politician, who achieved an almost monumental status on the Caribbean island, was the most humble man they had ever known.

title: Exploring Aim Csaires Martinique
description: Scenes from the Caribbean island on the 100th anniversary of the poet and politicians birth.

title: Beyond Orlandos Theme Parks, a Beer Culture Grows
description: Craft beer is usually not what comes to mind when thinking about Orlando. Walt Disney World, Universal Studios or another splashy theme park, yes, but not beer. Today, however, this landlocked central Florida city is getting a reputation for its growing craft beer scene. In the past few years, locals in the Orlando area have opened bars offering a wide selection of beers from small producers, and some are even opening spots that serve ales brewed in house.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Monaco in Philadelphia
description: Rates

title: Nietzsche and Wagners Greatest Hits, and Naughty Bits
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  When Nietzsche and Wagner first met in 1868, the philosopher, more than 30 years Wagners junior, found a father figure. Wagner got an acolyte and mouthpiece.

title: Russians Meet With an Uncle of Assad in an Effort to Jump-Start Peace Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As American diplomacy on the war in Syria flounders, unable to deliver the main exile opposition group to proposed peace talks, Russian officials on Wednesday stepped up their efforts to promote alternate opposition figures, meeting in Geneva with Rifaat al-Assad, an uncle of President Bashar al-Assad who was forced out of the country in 1984 after attempting to lead a coup.

title: Why Twitter May Have to Pay Income Taxes One Day
description: Potential investors in Twitterss planned initial public offering may be struggling to estimate how much the company will have to pay in taxes in the future. An article in Politico on Friday highlighted some of the techniques Twitter might use to legally avoid taxes.

title: Babys Gaze May Signal Autism, a Study Finds
description: Updated, 1:11 a.m. | When and how long a baby looks at other peoples eyes offers the earliest behavioral sign to date of whether a child is likely to develop autism, scientists are reporting.

title: Internet Kills the Video Store
description: Blockbuster, which had more than 9,000 retail stores across America just nine years ago, is closing the few hundred video-rental stores that it still has, the companys owner, Dish Network, said on Wednesday in a bittersweet but long-expected announcement.

title: House Hunting in Central Barcelona
description: Despite Spains punishing market, luxury properties like this one near Gauds Park Gell are showing some resilience.

title: House Hunting in Barcelona, Spain
description: A 19TH-CENTURY VILLA IN CENTRAL BARCELONA

title: Do Moderates Have the Guts to Take Back the G.O.P.?
description: Establishment Republicans feel pretty good about their wins yesterday in New Jersey and Alabama. (Many are also quietly saying I told you so about Ken Cuccinellis loss in the Virginia governors race.) For those in the traditional Chamber of Commerce wing of the party, the next year will be about regaining control from the Tea Partiers who have been driving the partys policies since 2010.

title: De Blasio, Preparing to Become Mayor, Signals Sea Change in New York
description: In his first morning as New York Citys mayor-elect, Bill de Blasio spent a cordial, if somewhat awkward hour with the man he will soon replace, Michael R. Bloomberg, making small talk about the intricacies of garbage pickup.

title: Bill de Blasios Path to Mayoral Success
description: With his mantra "A Tale of Two Cities," Bill de Blasio captured voters' concerns about inequality in New York City. But he had to overcome far more famous rivals to get to City Hall.

title: SACs $1.2 Billion Settlement Clears One Judicial Hurdle and Awaits Another
description: Federal prosecutors and SAC Capital Advisors cleared a legal hurdle on Wednesday after Judge Richard J. Sullivan said he would sign off on the civil portion of the hedge funds insider trading guilty plea and roughly $1.2 billion penalty.

title: Fall Fashion That Is Anything but Stiff
description: Youll always feel put together in a collared shirt, so why not wear one that brings a little pizazz to the party? The shirts here, with contrast collars, embellishments and playful tweaks, do for the classic what vodka does for tonic. Wear as you normally would, with tailored pants or jeans and a blazer; just have more fun.

title: The Gun Report: November 6, 2013
description: Dick Metcalf, the technical editor of Guns & Ammo magazine, announced in his December editorial that he supports gun control regulations, a position that is earning him derision within the gun-rights crowd.

title: Dont Yell at Your Children. But If You Do, Dont Yell at Yourself.
description: Personally, I wouldnt yell at my children if they would just do what Ive asked the first time, or maybe do the thing Ive asked them to do 463 times in the past. Or if they didnt chase one another through the kitchen at dinnertime, brandishing light sabers. Or if they got up when the alarm clock went off in the morning, or put their shoes on so we could leave the house, or moved that glass of milk, the one thats right by your elbow and  too late.

title: First Draft Pick Finally Gets First Basket
description: Anthony Bennett, the N.B.A.s No. 1 draft pick this year, has already had many firsts in these early weeks of the season: his first home game with the Cleveland Cavaliers, his first blocked shot, his first victory.

title: Who Beats Christie?
description: And now for the requisite Chris Christie and 2016 post, occasioned by all the otherChris Christie and 2016 posts that his landslide re-election have spawned. Mine is inspired by the skeptics  from the right, Henry Olsen; from the left, Jonathan Chait; from the media version of the center, Ron Fournier  who all offer reasons to doubt Christies presidential mojo, and spin out entirely plausible scenarios in which his liabilities cost him the G.O.P. nomination. Well, entirely plausible except for one thing, which I think Chaits conclusion underplays:

title: Mayor-Elect Bill de Blasio
description: When he began his mayoral campaign on a freezing cold January day outside his home in Brooklyn, Bill de Blasio was just one of several Democratic candidates all claiming to be the progressive voice of change for a post-Bloomberg New York. His Democratic and Republican opponents belittled his policy proposals, his record and his supposed lack of experience.

title: De Blasio Enters to 'Royals'
description: Bill de Blasio entered his election night party to the song "Royals," by Lorde.

title: Voters Reject* Labels for Genetically Engineered Food in Washington State
description: Washington State voters, with only four* mainly-urban counties around Seattle bucking the tide, appeared to reject* a ballot initiative that would have required labeling for foods with genetically modified ingredients (with a variety of exceptions), according to the states election Web site. The map above is from the state Office of the Secretary of State. Theres more from CNN and USA Today. Industry heavily outspent backers of the labeling initiative, but the measure was also opposed by many newspapers, including the Seattle Times and Olympian.

title: 'Ain't No Mountain High Enough'
description: Bill de Blasio exited his victory night speech to "Ain't No Mountain High Enough."

title: Royals, a Dickensian Anthem, Becomes de Blasios Victory Song
description: Bill de Blasio strode onstage in Brooklyn on Tuesday night to give his victory speech as New York Citys mayor-elect to a song by a teenager from New Zealand, Royals, by Lorde. Royals is currently the No. 1 song in the United States on Billboard magazines Hot 100. It also gives catchy form to what had been a major theme of the de Blasio campaign: his tale of two cities, addressing the income inequality between the wealthy few and a struggling majority.

title: Google Is Ordered to Block Images in Privacy Case
description: LONDON  A French court ruled Wednesday that Google must remove from its Internet search results all images of a former Formula One car racing chief at an orgy. The ruling in the privacy case could have ramifications for the tech giants operations across Europe.

title: Kerrys Path Steepens in Israeli-Palestinian Talks
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  Secretary of State John Kerrys uphill path to a peace accord between Israel and the Palestinians seemed ever steeper on Wednesday, as the two sides clashed bitterly over Jewish settlements in the West Bank, while the exoneration of a right-wing Israeli politician threatened to inject a volatile element into the talks.

title: Satellite Falls to Earth
description: A European satellite that mapped Earths gravitational field in exquisite detail will be pulled down by gravity to its fiery destruction sometime in the next few days.

title: Rocky on Broadway Finds Its Apollo Creed
description: The new Broadway musical Rocky has its Master of Disaster.

title: Sel Rrose on the Lower East Side
description: A few months ago, in a gray, nondescript box on Delancey Street, a bar opened. No one was hired to hype it. It didnt bait the blogs with a top-secret tequila cave or bacon-infused cocktails. And the stratagem worked, insofar as Sel Rrose, as the bar is called, has been ignored by the right people.

title: Fantagraphics Seeks Support With a Kickstarter Campaign
description: Fantagraphics Books, the graphic novel imprint that, since the mid-1970s, has published a large and varied line, with new works and classic reprints, and has fought to establish comic books as a form of high art, has fallen on hard times since its co-founder, Kim Thompson, was diagnosed with lung cancer in February.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Sesame Letterpress Bespoke Stationery
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Travel Diary
description: Sam Buffa, the entrepreneur behind the Fellow Barber shops and several Brooklyn restaurants, heads to the Italian island to ride for Team USA in the International Six Days of Enduro.

title: Call Collins? Knicks Have Little to Lose
description: One week into an already stressful season, the Knicks do not have a center, a defensive beacon in the N.B.A. storm. There is no short or complete answer to the loss of Tyson Chandler, who has a nondisplaced fracture of the right fibula. But there will be suggestions on how to cobble together a plan to survive for the next four to six weeks. And here is one:

title: Gergiev Defends Himself Against Criticism Over Russias Anti-Gay Law
description: Valery Gergiev, the Russian conductor whose performances have drawn protests in New York and London this fall from gay-rights advocates opposing Russias new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality, issued a statement on his Facebook page Wednesday saying, It is wrong to suggest that I have ever supported anti-gay legislation and in all my work I have upheld equal rights for all people.

title: Closing In: A Campaigns Final Hours
description: Damon Winter went behind the scenes with Bill de Blasio in the days leading up to the mayoral election.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: The Book Thief
description: Brian Percival, the director of The Book Thief, narrates a scene from his film.

title: Vote of Confidence in Mexicos Version of Amazon.com
description: The Mexican venture capital firm Latin Idea Ventures said this week that it had made its first investment in an e-commerce company, Linio, a Mexico City start-up that, like Amazon.com in the United States, sells a wide array of products.

title: A Time to Kill Sets Broadway Closing Date
description: John Grisham may lure readers to his novels in droves, but not to Broadway: The stage adaptation of his best-selling book A Time To Kill will close there on Nov. 17, the producers announced on Wednesday.

title: Killing of French Journalists Reverberates in France and Mali
description: PARIS  Diplomats, journalists and humanitarian workers gathered in Paris on Wednesday to mourn the brutal killing of two seasoned French journalists by insurgents in Mali, an episode that has raised questions about Frances plans to withdraw some of its troops from the country over the next two months.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of The Book Thief
description: In this video, the director Brian Percival narrates a sequence from his film adaptation of the Markus Zusak novel featuring Sophie Nlisse as Liesel and Geoffrey Rush as her foster father Han. In this scene, Liesel has stolen a book from a Nazi book-burning rally. Mr. Percival discusses his ideas behind the scene and offers insight into how it was shot. The movie opens Nov. 8.

title: Giving Old Loews Theater in Brooklyn a Second Chance
description: The Kings Theater is big. Its the borough that got small.

title: In The Counselor, Fashions and Furnishings Play a Pivotal Role
description: CLOTHING, CARS, STRETCHES OF ASPHALT, a plush leather chair: no object is too insignificant to escape the director Ridley Scott, who injects such totems in his films with spirited lives of their own.

title: Hey, Players, Make Yourselves at Home
description: Youd have to assume that the life of classical musics star soloists and recitalists might be isolating and lonely, with long stretches of travel and short bursts of communal activity. But on Sunday, the violinist Hilary Hahn was at the center of a social whirl, which could be variously described as a marathon concert, a school day and a carnival.

title: Nepal Tours Get Local
description: For those who want to meet local people as well as appreciate the grandeur of the landscape, the India-based tour operator Village Ways will introduce community-based trips to Nepal in 2014.

title: Scene City: All Eyes on Tilda Swinton
description: Anna Wintour, David Bowie, Karl Lagerfeld and others at MoMAs annual Film Benefit.

title: Beethoven and One of Frances Musical Mystics Strive for Glimpses of the Divine
description: Since white light results not from an absence of color but from the presence of all colors, it is altogether appropriate that Lincoln Centers White Light Festival should find a place for that supreme musical colorist Olivier Messiaen. And on Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the Cleveland Orchestra, led by its music director, Franz Welser-Mst, performed Messiaens Trois Petites Liturgies de la Prsence Divine of 1944, a piece for a chorus of sopranos, piano and an orchestra fitted out with exotic instruments, alongside works by Beethoven.

title: Dancing to Bach, With Head Wobbling and Chest Thumping
description: Along with new casts, the mixed bills by American Ballet Theater at the David H. Koch Theater on Saturday introduced the least distinguished offering of the companys fall season. Made by Stanton Welch in 2001, it is a showpiece for seven men without shirts. The lead dancer slaps his chest, not like Tarzan but like a man applying a defibrillator to himself, an action that seems to call for a shouting of the works title: Clear.

title: Enriching Your TV Picture, From the Couch
description: IF you are close to spending thousands of dollars on a TV because you want a better picture, you may want to save your money. You can almost certainly make your TVs picture look better than it did when the set was brand-new, and doing so is relatively easy.

title: A Wall Street Island for Lhota
description: Joseph J. Lhota will not be moving into Gracie Mansion. New Yorkers made sure of that in the mayoral election on Tuesday.

title: Missing Nash but Not the Net, the Rangers Win Their 4th in 5 Games
description: Rick Nash followed through on a huge slap shot at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, but it was only in a photograph on the cover of the game program. The actual Nash was nowhere to be seen, still out with a concussion he sustained a month ago, leaving Rangers fans wondering when, if ever, he will be healthy enough to come back.

title: Arcade Fires Album Is No. 1
description: Arcade Fires new album, Reflektor (Merge/Universal), debuted at No. 1 on this weeks Billboard album chart, with sales of 140,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The bands previous album, The Suburbs (Merge/Universal), from 2010, also topped Billboards chart in its first week.

title: Sympathy for the Devil Worshipers
description: Its easy enough to be in favor of a nonsectarian prayer before a legislative session  some invocation of a higher power that theoretically doesnt exclude anyone (besides atheists, that is)  but what exactly does such a prayer sound like?

title: Twitter, a Risky Investment
description: Twitter will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday. Here are three reasons the company may be a risky investment.

title: BAE to Stop Building Ships at Historic British Site
description: LONDON  As an island nation that once built an empire by sea, Britain has a proud history and longstanding expertise in shipbuilding.

title: Ombr: A Ubiquitous Word for That Faded Look
description: Some clients point to the photos they are clutching of Khlo Kardashian and Alexa Chung as they enter the hair salon. Others describe the desired effect: hair that transitions from dark roots to light ends. Then, there are those who are fluent in the language of trend. They ask for ombr.

title: Google Gives a Hint About Its Mystery Barges
description: Google has finally commented on its mysterious barges floating near San Francisco and Portland, Me. But its comments do not shed much light on the mystery.

title: The CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, a Support Network Comes of Age
description: After 9/11, a fashion competition was born, with the first award of $200,000 going to the Proenza Schouler designers in 2004. Heres what some designers are doing now.

title: Television Sales Look Grim Again This Year
description: The TV industry looks more bleak every year. After sales of television sets fell last year, they are poised to shrink once again this year.

title: W.H.O., Fighting Polio in Syria, Says More Children Need Vaccinations
description: Escalating its emergency battle to stop the spread of a polio revival in Syria, the World Health Organization has doubled the number of children it says should be urgently vaccinated to more than 20 million throughout the Middle East, the organizations top official in charge of eradicating the highly contagious and crippling disease said Wednesday.

title: An African Past, Embodied and Onstage Today
description: A man in a shiny suit faces away from those who watch him. His fingers tickle the air, as if feeling for something. The signals he senses must be intensifying, since his weather-vane body starts shunting into angles, bouncing like a car with loose suspension. As a beat fades in, his shoulders and knees pick it up, until he is stepping high in a dance you might identify as African.

title: More Asteroid Strikes Are Likely, Scientists Say
description: When an asteroid exploded over the Russian city of Chelyabinsk in February, shattering windows for miles and injuring well over 1,000 people, experts said it was a rare event  of a magnitude that might occur only once every 100 to 200 years, on average.

title: Tilda Swinton Saluted by MoMA and a Starry Guest List
description: In her two-decade-plus film career, Tilda Swinton has been a muse to many fashion designers. No wonder a tribute to her on Tuesday night, at the Museum of Modern Arts annual Film Benefit, had a starry guest list that rivaled the Mets Costume Institute Gala.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, England, Greece and Syria.

title: Why I Lost It on Election Night
description: THE New York City mayoral election was hardly a nail-biter. But Bill de Blasios landslide win might have been nominally less historic had I not torn up my ballot and flung it at a bewildered election volunteer near my home on the Upper West Side.

title: Thors Nemesis Makes Some Thunder
description: LONDON  In a scene close to the end of the 2011 superhero film Thor, the two central characters confront each other. They are brothers, although Loki, played by the British actor Tom Hiddleston, has just denied this. Loki, this is madness, says Thor (Chris Hemsworth). Is it madness? Mr. Hiddleston responds, his face quivering with intensity, his breath ragged, his eyes filming with tears. Is it? Is it?

title: A Showman Whose Dazzle Hid Darkness
description: After Bob Fosse won an Oscar (for directing Cabaret), two Tonys (for choreographing and directing Pippin) and an Emmy (for directing Liza With a Z) in 1973, a rare triple coup, he reacted the way any world-class show business depressive would: He decided he had nowhere to go but down.

title: U.S. Will Ease Sanctions if Iran Halts Nuclear Program, Official Says
description: GENEVA  On the eve of a new round of talks between world powers and Iran, a senior Obama administration official said Wednesday that the United States was prepared to offer Iran limited relief from economic sanctions if Tehran agreed to halt its nuclear program temporarily and reversed part of it.

title: Roiling the Waters at River House
description: On a recent afternoon, the River Club was far from bustling. The main dining room was closed, so a handful of elderly couples headed to the pool area, where a bar menu was being served. A man using a walker spoke with his lunch companions of a recent trip to an antiques show. An Elsie de Wolfe aesthetic prevailed in several nearby sitting rooms, where the tufted red leather furniture was unoccupied.

title: Cooking the Turkey Dinner, With a Little Help From My Phone
description: Thanksgiving is a time to spend wholesome moments with family and enjoy great food and drink.

title: App Smart: Help With Thanksgiving
description: Android and iOS apps to help in the kitchen and keep the kids amused during the holiday, as reviewed by The Timess Kit Eaton.

title: Conquering Androids World of Themes
description: A few weeks ago, I ditched my iPhone 4S for an HTC One, and now I think the difference between the worlds most popular smartphone operating systems  Apples iOS and Googles Android  can be explained with a metaphor about home decorating.

title: Hudson Valley Town Is a Playwrights Home and Template
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  Whenever Richard Nelson hit a bump writing about the Apples, the fractious, fictitious family in his critically acclaimed cycle of four plays at the Public Theater this fall, inspiration lay just around the corner.

title: Error Creates Deals Too Good to Be True on Walmarts Site
description: First, there was Black Friday. Then came Cyber Monday.

title: With the Raven, Henry Stimler Expands His Nightlife Presence
description: In his own words, Henry Stimler was always a wandering spirit and dreamer. He grew up the second child of five in an ultra-Orthodox home in the predominantly Jewish area of Golders Green, North London.

title: A Band Likes to Morph and Blend as It Reaches
description: How far can R&B be pushed toward jazz? Hiatus Kaiyote, an Australian band that performed on Tuesday night at Le Poisson Rouge, seems determined to find out. It calls its music future soul; its album Tawk Tomahawk (Flying Buddha) was released in Australia last year and in the United States this year. On it, the band sails through one ambitious song after another.

title: An Epic, Century-Old Motorcycle Race Comes to Sardinia
description: As the co-owner of the Brooklyn restaurants Vinegar Hill House and Hillside and the impresario behind the Fellow Barber mini-empire of elegant, old-timey mens grooming salons, Sam Buffa is already the subject of major male lifestyle envy. The 35-year-old seems even more the embodiment of a certain type of guys fantasy life when you learn that he also races motorcycles, something he started doing with his dad as a kid growing up in Half Moon Bay, Calif.

title: Vogue Fashion Fund: Where No Designer Is Left Behind
description: Whoever said, If you want to try a risky career, open a restaurant, surely never considered becoming a clothing designer.

title: Sweating the Details Is Part of the Test for Designers
description: The challenge, as Steven Kolb, the chief executive of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, explained to the group in the backyard of Anna Wintours townhouse, was to create a ready-to-wear design incorporating elements from performance wear. In other words, something that could be worn from the gym to the office, he said.

title: Shopping Events Starting Nov. 7
description: Openings

title: Documents Reveal How Looted Nazi Art Was Restored to Dealer
description: Throughout the waning years of World War II, a band of Allied soldiers, art historians, curators and scholars labored to safeguard Europes cultural heritage and recover the millions of artworks and other treasures plundered by the Nazis and their collaborators. Nicknamed the Monuments Men, this group set up a string of temporary collection points for the valuables.

title: Blue, Through Lesbian Eyes
description: Of the many things to note about the seven-minute lesbian sex scene in Blue Is the Warmest Color, a French drama about a teenage girl who becomes passionately involved with a slightly older woman, is how very long it seems to go on.

title: Despite Blackout, CBS Profit and Revenue Rise
description: Despite its protracted dispute over the summer with Time Warner Cable, CBS posted another solid earnings report on Wednesday with steady increases in revenue and profit for the third quarter.

title: Cuts Have Hagel Weighing Realigned Military Budget
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon has traditionally managed rivalries among services by giving each more or less equal shares of the base military budget.

title: Late Night Ends Early for Some New York Clubbers
description: At Greenhouse, the smallish two-level dance club on Varick Street in Manhattan, Sunday nights are filled with a frisky mix of gay guys, club kids, homeys and an occasional tourist with a guidebook.

title: Going Beyond the Baseboard
description: If you find yourself warming to a European-produced designer radiator, youll be happy to know that some models are distributed in the United States. Contact the company for the names of retailers. Or you can buy directly from overseas.

title: Textiles with Roots in the Rain Forest
description: In 2010, Cristina Grajales Gallery in New York presented a solo exhibition of the work of Hechizoo, a textile studio founded in 2000 in Bogot by Jorge Lizarazo, an architect-turned-weaver. Hechizoo combines native plant fibers like fique and cumare palm with nylon filament and metals to create iridescent carpets and screens.

title: A Double Take Under Your Feet
description: The British artist Richard Woods creates stylized renderings of construction materials (such as brick and wood) and applies them to household dcor. His colorful, comic book-like graphics have appeared on chairs, tables and wallpaper, as well as on the sides of buildings. The floor has certainly not escaped his attention. His latest project, a collection of 11 parquet- and floorboard-patterned wool rugs for Memphis-Milano, are produced in Nepal, where they are woven on traditional looms. I like the idea of making a rug out of something thats usually underneath the rug, Mr. Woods said, adding that he isnt conscious of any influence his surname may have had on his work. The rugs are produced in a signed limited edition of 36 and range in size from about 3 by 5 feet ($2,466) to about 8 by 11 feet ($14,466). Shown is RW Rug #5 ($6,692). Information: 011-39-02-655-4731 or store.memphis-milano.com.

title: Dressing the Turkey? Dress the Menorah, Too.
description: When precocious children come up with ideas for salable inventions on long car rides, preoccupied parents typically just keep driving. But about 10 months ago, when Asher Weintraub, 9, suggested combining Thanksgiving table decorations and Hanukkah menorahs this year, since the holidays are making a rare simultaneous appearance, his parents, Anthony Weintraub and Caroline Baron, actually listened. The Manhattan family commissioned a prototype for Ashers computer sketch of a menurkey, a menorah shaped like a turkey holding candles in its plumes. A Kickstarter campaign, also Ashers idea, brought in $48,345 and Internet fame, and now plaster menurkeys are being sold for $50 at the Jewish Museum in New York. When I saw it made, Asher said, it looked way better than I expected. As for his next invention, he added, Maybe an app. Information: 212-423-3333 or shop.thejewishmuseum.org.

title: Trust Me: You Should Be Impressed
description: A new superyacht by Zaha Hadid presents the billionaire playboy with a problem. There is undeniable prestige of trolling Mediterranean harbors in a yacht designed by a Pritzker-prize-winning architect. But the boats outer shell is made of an interwoven network of support bands, which gives it a futuristic webbed look and obscures the primary decks. Who on shore will see the bikinied frolicking?

title: Turning Up the Heat
description: Europeans are endlessly inventive when it comes to radiator design. Why are Americans lagging behind?

title: A Radiance All Their Own
description: Several winters ago, Guus van Leeuwen, who was then an industrial design student, was riding with his girlfriend in a horse-drawn sleigh in Sweden. Wrapped in reindeer pelts, the couple watched steam rise from the bodies of the sweating animals in front of them. Thats when it all came together, Mr. van Leeuwen said.

title: A Fisherman in New Yorks Sea of Faces
description: Heres how Brandon Stanton spends several hours each day: He walks up to total strangers in New York City, requests permission to take their pictures and then asks questions so personal they might make Oprah Winfrey blush.

title: 36 Hours in Aruba
description: Averaging 82 sunny degrees year round, fringed with blond beaches and lapped by turquoise shallows, Aruba lets the climate do the talking when it comes to appealing to tourists. Beach lovers flock here, happy to claim a chaise with a paperback in one hand and a cold Balashi beer in the other. But the Dutch islands manageable 20-by-6-mile dimensions and its desert landscape  calm and sandy on one coast, rough and rocky on the other  make it an explorers island, too. Notably multicultural, with Dutch, the Creole-like Papiamento, Spanish and English commonly spoken, the island is also increasingly sophisticated, with an aloe-focused spa, a new avant-garde restaurant and a Ritz-Carlton resort, the islands most luxurious property, set to open Nov. 22.

title: From Architecture to Art in Aruba
description: Take a spin around this sunny island off the coast of South America.

title: A Garden of Creature Comforts
description: Gardeners brought up on the mishaps of Peter Rabbit can now curl up with Beatrix Potters Gardening Life: The Plants and Places That Inspired the Classic Childrens Tales, by Marta McDowell, out this month from Timber Press ($24.95).

title: Deals on Linens, Carpets and Chairs
description: During Mia & Finns basement sale, Friday and Saturday, bed and table linens are up to 70 percent off (an Izia quilt, usually $420, will be $135); 73 Saint James Place (Lafayette Avenue), Brooklyn, 646-943-0796.

title: Should I Replace Worn Light Switches?
description: Q. My home has old, worn light switches and outlets. Should I replace them before I put it on the market?

title: Case of Insect Interruptus Yields a Rare Fossil Find
description: About 165 million years ago, in what is now northeastern China, two insects were doing what comes naturally. Suddenly, in the middle of copulating, they were struck dead, felled by poisonous gas from a volcanic eruption.

title: Judge Who Overturned Skakel Murder Conviction Declines Bail Request
description: ROCKVILLE, Conn.  Michael C. Skakel, a Kennedy relative who has been serving a 20-year-sentence for killing his Greenwich neighbor Martha Moxley when they were both 15, returned to prison on Wednesday after a hearing in which the judge who  set aside Mr. Skakels 2002 conviction declined to grant bail.

title: Forgive Me, Virginia Woolf
description: When I was 5, my parents decided I was old enough to decorate my own bedroom.

title: Bolshoi Director Testifies at Acid-Attack Trial
description: MOSCOW  It had all the intrigue and sensation of the Bolshoi Ballets most spectacular productions, but the drama that unfolded on Wednesday in the Meschchansky District Court here was one that storied dance company will forever dread.

title: A Sprint or a Marathon? Bach and Beethoven Variations in a Single Evening
description: Andras Schiffs latest traversal of Bachs keyboard works, a two-year project, ended on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall with the Goldberg Variations.

title: Teenagers Lawyer Blames Pothole for Crash
description: There has been plenty of finger-pointing in the case of a teenage driver who struck a 4-year-old girl, killing her and injuring her grandmother in June while speeding away from the police on the Upper West Side. Now the boys lawyer is blaming a pothole for the accident.

title: A Grand Slam From a Posthumous Victor Mollo Book
description: For the past few columns, we have been looking at noteworthy bridge books published this year that might make good gifts.

title: The Making Of
description: The Brooklyn design duo created to-scale installations of quintessentially British things for the windows of J. Crews new international flagship on Regent Street in London.

title: Saving Buffalo, Wreck by Wreck
description: In Upstate New York, buyers with activist inclinations are preserving a city, one foreclosed house at a time.

title: Small-Scale Developers, Big Dreams
description: BUFFALO  It was the proverbial melting pot, festive, aromatic and polyphonic. There were young hipsters (identifiable by their wool caps and archaic facial hair) and local homesteaders, along with settlers from Myanmar, Bhutan, Pakistan and Africa, to name just a few of the cultures represented at this once-blighted citys annual auction of foreclosed properties. Would-be homeowners and property moguls huddled over the listings for more than 4,300 parcels of vacant lots and houses, their hoped-for choices highlighted and starred.

title: Tinkering With the Ghosts of Tailors
description: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns redo a Lower East Side loft, preserving the marks of former occupants (and their sewing machines).

title: Staying in Character
description: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns had long fantasized about buying a place in New York, but it took an old clothing factory on Orchard Street to convince them.

title: Defending Forgeries? Art Lovers Strike Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Twitter Prices Its Initial Offering at $26 Per Share
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitter, long protected in its Silicon Valley nest, is about to venture into the more unforgiving world of Wall Street.

title: For Detroits New Mayor, Power, With Conditions
description: DETROIT  Congratulatory phone calls dominated Mike Duggans first 24 hours as the next mayor of this downtrodden city, but the coming days may be the most crucial to laying the groundwork for his administration, as conversations begin with state officials about his role at City Hall.

title: Colombia and Rebels Reach Deal on Political Participation
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Negotiators for the Colombian government and the countrys largest guerrilla group announced Wednesday that they had agreed on a framework for the rebels to take part in the political process, a crucial step forward in peace talks aimed at ending nearly 50 years of fighting between the government and the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: On Everpix, and Silk Road 2.0 Launches
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Works From the Collection of Hildebrand Gurlitt
description: Some of the works that may be found among the 1,400 artworks seized by German authorities from the home of Cornelius Gurlitt.

title: Reflections on Christie and de Blasio
description: To the Editor:

title: First Date Announces Last Performance
description: No need to pick out invitations or hire a caterer: the musical comedy First Date will finish its Broadway run on Jan. 5 after 34 previews and 174 regular performances, the producers announced late Wednesday.

title: Using Textbooks to Push the Palestinian Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Sexual Abuse in the Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Dumping Sewage in the Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Iowa Towns Vote Delivers Rebuke to Kochs Group
description: The mayoral and City Council candidates in an Iowa town who were most closely aligned with the message promoted by Americans for Prosperity, the deep-pocketed conservative political group, were roundly defeated on Tuesday in a sharp rebuke of outside influence in local politics.

title: Peacekeepers in Congo to Focus on Another Rebel Group
description: UNITED NATIONS  Having helped rout one powerful rebel group in the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo, United Nations peacekeepers are expected to turn their attention to subduing another, diplomats said Wednesday, as the Security Council prepared to draft a statement on the next steps in that vast, mineral-rich country.

title: History Channel Is Eying Remake of Roots
description: The History Channel may remake Roots, the ABC mini-series that made history when it was broadcast in 1977. The cable channel confirmed that it had bought the rights to the mini-series (and the Alex Haley book that it was based upon) and had started developing an eight-hour version of it. The original Roots, about a multigenerational African-American familys experiences from the time of slavery onward, was 12 hours and a national phenomenon, as evidenced by the fact that more than half of all American households tuned in for the finale. The development was first reported by Deadline.com on Tuesday, which quoted a senior vice president at the channel, Dirk Hoogstra, as saying We would like to revive that cultural icon for a new audience.

title: Taking Aim at the Wrong Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  ASK most people in this city what the most important step is to increasing economic growth and job creation, and theyll reply, Reduce the budget deficit!

title: On Holding Hands and Fake Marriage: Stories of Being Gay in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Yegor grew up in a Siberian town called Lyubov, which means love in Russian, but he has never told his parents that when he falls in love, it is with other men.

title: Thursdays Games to Watch
description: 2 OREGON at 6 STANFORD

title: Presidential! Season! Soonish!
description: Chris Christie! He won! Lets talk about his presidential prospects incessantly for the rest of the month!

title: Wall St. Bonuses Over All Are Predicted to Rise 5 to 10% (Bond Traders Excluded)
description: When it comes to compensation, it looks as if 2013 is going to be remembered as a pretty good year to have worked on Wall Street, unless you are a fixed-income trader.

title: Obama Defends the Affordable Care Act
description: The president spoke in Dallas about the issues surrounding the health care legislation.

title: New Bow for CARE Packages
description: THE CARE package, once a familiar symbol of providing relief overseas, is being taken down from the shelf, dusted off and reimagined for a new generation of potential donors.

title: Slavery Isnt a Thing of the Past
description: The movie 12 Years a Slave is receiving rapturous reviews for depicting the antebellum South less as a gauzy land of elegant plantations than as the raw backdrop of monstrous brutality.

title: N.F.L. Picks Lawyer to Lead Inquiry Into Dolphins
description: The N.F.L. has appointed Ted Wells, one of the countrys top defense lawyers, to investigate the allegations of workplace misconduct swirling around the Miami Dolphins, a sign the league wants to reassure the public that it is taking the matter seriously.

title: Swiss Report Supports Theory Arafat Was Poisoned
description: JERUSALEM  Nine years of mystery and intrigue surrounding the death of Yasir Arafat, the symbol of the Palestinian national struggle, took a contentious turn on Wednesday with the publication of a forensics report by Swiss scientists that lends support to the theory that Mr. Arafat died of poisoning with radioactive polonium-210.

title: Defeat of School Tax Stings Colorado Democrats
description: DENVER  They had $10 million in contributions, a barrage of advertising and support from the usually warring factions of the educational establishment. But Democratic leaders in this swing state were dealt a stinging defeat on Tuesday as voters resoundingly rejected an effort to raise taxes by $1 billion a year to pay for a sweeping school overhaul.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Redskins (3-5) at Vikings (1-7)
description: 8:30 p.m., NFL Network

title: The Passion of Parenting
description: Ive been a single dad for 13 years. As with most single parents  and indeed with most parents  it hasnt always been easy.

title: Measures to Legalize Marijuana Are Passed
description: DENVER  Marijuana proponents scored significant victories on Tuesday as voters around the country passed ballot measures decriminalizing marijuana possession and approved regulatory taxes on the drug.

title: Ruble Hopes to Join Ranks of the $ and
description: MOSCOW  The ruble, once the legal tender of the bread line and little else, is now almost a normal currency for international commerce, but it lacks a graphic symbol like the dollar sign. On Wednesday, in an effort the leadership hopes will further raise the currencys profile and make it as acceptable as the dollar or the euro, the Central Bank posted five possible symbols for Russians to vote on. The winner will be announced on Dec. 5.

title: In Slide of Swedish Tennis, There Is No End in Sight
description: STOCKHOLM  When the second-highest-ranked Swedish player took the court for his first match at the recent Stockholm Open, the fans who were scattered around the warm, wooden benches at the Kungliga Tennishallen stomped approval that echoed off the arched ceiling.

title: Twitters Market Valuation Suggests Wall St. Sees Huge Growth Potential
description: Twitter is a young company generating large losses as it competes in a highly uncertain sector of the economy.

title: Next Door to War, Theres Money to Be Made
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  Wars, as businessmen have recognized for centuries, can be very profitable. Evidence of that is on display here, where a half-dozen military supply stores in the center of this town near the Syrian border are busy catering to a clientele flooding in from all over the Middle East.

title: Details Emerge of Potential Google Monitor in Europe
description: Wanted: A Google watchdog in Europe.

title: Pirate Nights
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Years ago, aboard my first ship as a young cadet, I noticed a man pacing along the bridge deck. I asked the third mate who he was.

title: Texas Stringent Voter ID Law Makes a Dent at Polls
description: HOUSTON  First, Judge Sandra Watts was stopped while trying to vote because the name on her photo ID, the same one she had used for voter registration and identification for 52 years, did not exactly match her name on the official voter rolls.

title: Nepals Tentative Democracy Prepares to Vote
description: After decades of political upheaval and paralysis, Nepal is scheduled to hold national elections on Nov. 19.

title: Baylors Briles Is a Down-Home Innovator
description: STEPHENVILLE, Tex.  Jake and Dorothys Cafe opened in 1948, four decades before Art Briles came to town and helped change football with an offense that would, appropriately, spread from central Texas to the N.F.L.

title: In Fractured Nepal, Plans for National Elections Provide a Series of Subplots
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nepals former first lady insisted that she was not a crook.

title: Mr. de Blasios Moment
description: Bill de Blasio won the New York mayors race on Tuesday night, and, on Wednesday, he started accepting job applications and citizens ideas for his administration at a website for the transition. It is a nice gesture, striking the notes of diversity and openness that he hit throughout the campaign.

title: In New York Citys Sharp Left Turn, Questions of Just How Far
description: New York City voters stepped decisively to the political left on Tuesday, turning their collective back on two decades of Republican-backed mayoral rule.

title: Chinese Leaders Economic Plan Tests Goal to Fortify Party Power
description: HONG KONG  Chinas president, Xi Jinping, is about to plunge the country and himself into a risky experiment: an attempt to carry out market-driven economic overhauls while reinforcing the Communist Partys pillars of political and ideological control. This mixed agenda has magnified doubts about whether he can deliver on his promises of transformation.

title: China Wants Its Movies to Be Big in the U.S., Too
description: LOS ANGELES  Investment capital? Theyre loaded.

title: Getting Government Technology Right
description: The problems with the federal health insurance website have highlighted the need for broad reform in how the government uses technology to deliver public services.

title: Second Thoughts on Neighborhood Watches
description: Far too late to save the life of Trayvon Martin, the community of Sanford, Fla., where Mr. Martin was shot to death last year by a roaming neighborhood watch volunteer, is wisely changing course and banning civilians from packing firearms on future citizen patrols.

title: Subject to Further Review
description: The National Football League once again finds itself searching beyond the Xs and Os of the playing field to protect the games image as a rough-and-tumble entertainment rooted in innocent sport. The league has opened an investigation into accusations of locker room hazing on the Miami Dolphins that reportedly descended to racist and homophobic slurs and macho threats against a player and his mother.

title: Lessons on Immigration in Two Governors Races
description: Republicans in Congress studying the results from the governors elections in New Jersey and Virginia on Tuesday see two starkly different test cases for how the party should move on immigration.

title: Protest Over Kelly Is Focus of Inquiry, Brown University Says
description: Brown University will investigate a protest last month that forced the cancellation of a speech by the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, and decide whether anyone should be disciplined, the university said on Wednesday.

title: Mexico: Court Orders Full Sentence in Drug Agents Death, but Killer Is Free
description: The Mexico Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned a lower court ruling that allowed a drug kingpin accused of murdering an American drug enforcement agent in the 1980s to walk free. The effect of the high court ruling is unclear; the drug lord, Rafael Caro Quintero, left prison Aug. 9 and may not be easy to find. The American government, which filed an extradition request for him after his release, this week offered a $5 million reward for information leading to his capture. According to the high court ruling, lower court judges made a mistake when they decided there had been a jurisdiction problem in trying Mr. Caro Quintero in federal court and ordered his release. The new ruling allows the Mexican authorities to order him back to prison to complete the remaining 12 years of his 40-year sentence for the killing of the agent, Enrique Camarena, although Mexico could choose to extradite Mr. Caro Quintero if he is found.

title: The Netherlands Appeals Detentions of Greenpeace Activists in Russia
description: The Netherlands appealed to an international tribunal to order Russia to release a ship and 30 crew members of Greenpeace International who were detained in September while protesting offshore oil exploration in the Arctic. Russia, which has since charged the crew members with hooliganism, refused to recognize the courts jurisdiction in what it considers an internal legal matter. The tribunal of the Law of the Sea Treaty, based in Hamburg, scheduled a ruling for Nov. 22, which could increase diplomatic pressure on Russias government to resolve the case.

title: Who Should Get Financial Aid?
Virginia G.O.P. Assesses Loss to Rival It Saw as Weak
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans in Virginia awoke Wednesday with the knowledge that a bad streak had been extended: With the election of a Democratic governor, Terry McAuliffe, Republicans have lost seven of the past eight statewide, top-of-the-ballot races, including those for governor, senator and president  a run of misery dating to 2005.

title: A College Degree Within Reach, Then Came the Medical Bills
description: The worst stomach ache of Manpriya Samras life sent her to Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn in March 2012, when doctors told her that her appendix was about to burst. An emergency surgery successfully removed the inflamed organ, but Ms. Samra soon learned that her ordeal was only just beginning.

title: New Help for Poor Immigrants Who Are in Custody and Facing Deportation
description: At about 1:15 p.m. on Wednesday, Maximino Leyva Ortiz, wearing an orange jumpsuit, his wrists shackled, stood before a judge in an immigration courtroom in Lower Manhattan, a lawyer at his side. The federal government was seeking to deport him.

title: An Offer From Amazon to Its Most Bitter Rivals
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazon is going to the people who dislike and fear it the most  independent bookstore owners  and offering to work together to fulfill the needs and desires of their customers.

title: Sharp Circle
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I know what youre thinking. Youre probably thinking, Its a rebus. Lets see how badly Deb messed up on this one. And, if history is any way to predict these things, youd be right. But not today.

title: Playing With a Full Deck, and Your Head
description: As I write these words, I sit staring at a playing card. The five of hearts, actually. Theres nothing special about it: Its from a classic pack, with the familiar oil-defying coating and the ornate design on the back featuring two odd winged creatures on what appear to be bicycles. (Never noticed that before.)

title: A Cop Will Get a Killer to Sing (Thats Not a Spoiler)
description: Murder for Two, which opened at the McGinn/Cazale Theater in July, reopened Wednesday at the New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton; 212-239-6200, telecharge.com. Following are excerpts from the review that appeared in The New York Times on July 26; the full text is here.

title: G.O.P. Weighs Limiting Clout of Right Wing
