description: Leaders of the Republican establishment, alarmed by the emergence of far-right and often unpredictable Tea Party candidates, are pushing their party to rethink how it chooses nominees and advocating changes they say would result in the selection of less extreme contenders.

title: An Exaggerated Vision of the Female Form in Venezuela
description: A national embrace of plastic surgery is reflected in increasing sales of mannequins with bulging bosoms and cantilevered buttocks, wasp waists and long legs.

title: Growing Endowments Change Colleges Investment Strategy
description: In a year of strong gains, college endowments reversed a long-term trend toward alternative investments like private equity and venture capital funds, according to a study releasedWednesday. Overall, endowments earned an 11.7 percent investment return in 2012-13, said the study, by the National Association of College and University Business Officers, and Commonfund. After years of increasing, alternative investments fell from 54 percent of assets to 47 percent. Endowment returns were sharply negative during the recession, then very strong for two years, and near zero in 2011-12.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 6, 2013
Venezuelas Inflated Vision of Beauty
description: In Venezuela, women are confronted with a culture of increasingly enhanced physiques fueled by beauty pageants and plastic surgery.

title: Mannequins Give Shape to a Venezuelan Fantasy
description: VALENCIA, Venezuela  Frustrated with the modest sales at his small mannequin factory, Eliezer lvarez made a simple observation: Venezuelan women were increasingly using plastic surgery to transform their bodies, yet the mannequins in clothing stores did not reflect these new, often extreme proportions.

title: Judge in Terrorism Case Orders Look at Secret Records
description: A judge presiding over the military commissions prosecution of five people accused in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has ordered the government to show him confidential correspondence with the International Committee of the Red Cross about prison conditions at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, a defense lawyer said Wednesday. The judge, Col. James Pohl, also issued an order taking control of the team that reviews correspondence between defense lawyers and the defendants, including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. The order also relaxes some limits on what defense lawyers can discuss with their clients, said James G. Connell III, a defense lawyer for Ali Abd al Aziz Ali. The case has been bogged down in pretrial hearings, with no actual trial in sight. The judge decided that he would review the Red Cross records before deciding whether to allow the lawyers to see them.

title: A Third Navy Official Is Arrested in Bribery Case
description: Federal prosecutors said Wednesday that a third Navy official had been arrested on charges of accepting prostitutes and luxury travel from an Asian ship-servicing company that overbilled the Navy by millions of dollars. Navy Cmdr. Jose Luis Sanchez, 41, was arrested in Tampa and was also charged with accepting $100,000 from Glenn Defense Marine Asia, whose chief executive, Leonard Glenn Francis, was arrested in September. Federal authorities in San Diego have also charged a Navy commander, Michael V.K. Misiewicz, 46, and John B. Beliveau II, a naval investigator, in the case.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,274 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: A Familiar Result in Seattle, as Voters Oust Mayor for the Third Time in 12 Years
description: SEATTLE  Seattle voters performed what has become a fall ritual: dumping the mayor.

title: Legal Brief Filed in Support of Judge in Stop-and-Frisk Case
description: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio has promised that on Day 1 of his administration, he would withdraw New York Citys appeal of sweeping reforms ordered by a federal judge in the Police Departments stop-and-frisk practices.

title: Arkansas: Man Charged in Power Grid Attacks
description: A 37-year-old man was indicted Wednesday in connection with a series of attacks on the power grid in Central Arkansas earlier this year. A federal grand jury charged Jason Woodring with eight counts, including a terrorist attack against a railroad carrier. Mr. Woodring was arrested last month after the authorities said he repeatedly sabotaged electrical equipment and caused at least $2.1 million in damage. In one instance, Mr. Woodring is alleged to have sought to use a moving train to down a support tower. No one was injured in the attacks, which began in August and led to brief power failures.

title: Food Companies Claim Victory Against Labeling Initiative in Washington State
description: Some of the nations major food companies declared victory on Wednesday over an initiative in Washington State that would have required labeling of some foods that contain biotech ingredients, although supporters of labeling held out hope that hundreds of thousands of uncounted votes might yet turn the tide.

title: Ace Parker, Pro Football Hall of Famer From Leather-Helmet Days, Dies at 101
description: Ace Parker, a star running back in the National Football League who could do just about everything on a football field in the days of leather helmets and 60-minute men, died on Wednesday in Portsmouth, Va. He was 101 and the oldest living member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Germany Considers Having Snowden Testify to Inquiry
description: BERLIN  The German government will examine how the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden could testify to a parliamentary inquiry into American intelligence activities in Germany, the interior minister said Wednesday, amid rising demands not only to thank Mr. Snowden for his disclosures but also to grant him full political asylum.

title: Life on a Leaf
description: The title of a Finnish artists doctoral thesis is also the name of the home that it inspired.

title: Corrections: November 7, 2013
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: N.F.L. Week 10 Game Probabilities: Balance of the Bengals
description: The A.F.C. North appears to have had a changing of the guard.

title: Clifford Nass, Who Warned of a Data Deluge, Dies at 55
description: Clifford Nass, a Stanford professor whose pioneering research into how humans interact with technology found that the increasingly screen-saturated, multitasking modern world was not nurturing the ability to concentrate, analyze or feel empathy, died on Nov. 2 near Lake Tahoe. He was 55.

title: Strong Mix of Art Propels a Fine Night at Sothebys
description: So the market is alive, right? asked the relieved auctioneer, Tobias Meyer, as a buoyant, two-hour sale of Impressionist and modern art at Sothebys concluded on Wednesday night. After two dreary evening sales at Christies this week, fears that the art market was diving into the doldrums were dashed, at least for one night.

title: Coalition Seeks Publics Advice on New York Citys Goals
description: New York Citys mayoral transition will not be limited to the confines of City Hall.

title: The Bankruptcy Exemption
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 7, 2013
description: I say that inner beauty doesnt exist. Thats something that unpretty women invented to justify themselves.

title: Red Bulls Extend Playoff Frustration
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Through 18 seasons in Major League Soccer, nothing has ever been easy for the Red Bulls. And so it was again Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena.

title: Word of the Day | mollify
description: mollify \m-l-fi\ verb

title: Reports of Military Sexual Assault Rise Sharply
description: WASHINGTON  Reports of sexual assault in the military increased sharply during the last fiscal year, new Pentagon figures showed Wednesday, just weeks before a defense bill with provisions to tackle the problem is expected to reach the Senate floor.

title: Billionaires Received U.S. Farm Subsidies, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government paid $11.3 million in taxpayer-funded farm subsidies from 1995 to 2012 to 50 billionaires or businesses in which they have some form of ownership, according to a report released Thursday by the Environmental Working Group, a Washington-based research organization.

title: Cyprus in Plan to Develop a Natural Gas Industry
description: LONDON  Cyprus, seeking to rebuild its economy after the collapse of its banking industry, will announce on Thursday an agreement with Total, the French oil giant, to develop a plant to liquefy natural gas, the Cypriot energy minister said.

title: Yankees Have Many Holes to Fill, and Many Phone Calls to Make
description: Facing an abundance of roster questions, the Yankees are willing to talk to virtually every free agent in the coming weeks, General Manager Brian Cashman said.

title: Contractor Who Ran Special Education Pre-K Programs Is Charged With Fraud
description: A man who ran preschool programs for children in New York with developmental disabilities was arrested on Wednesday on charges that he diverted hundreds of thousands of dollars in government money meant to help the children to himself.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO James Lipton, who has a recurring guest role on Netflixs Arrested Development as the prison warden Stefan Gentles, interviews his cast mates Will Arnett, Jason Bateman, Portia de Rossi, Alia Shawkat, Jeffrey Tambor and Jessica Walter (above with Mr. Lipton), as well as Mitchell Hurwitz, the shows creator.

title: Country Awards Hold Swift Close
description: How many Nashville stalwarts does it take to keep Taylor Swift in country music? Thats the question that was asked again and again at the 47th annual Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday night.

title: C.I.A. Is Said to Pay AT&T for Call Data
description: WASHINGTON  The C.I.A. is paying AT&T more than $10 million a year to assist with overseas counterterrorism investigations by exploiting the companys vast database of phone records, which includes Americans international calls, according to government officials.

title: 2 French Banks Post Higher Profits and Plan Swap on Derivatives Venture
description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale and Crdit Agricole, two of Frances biggest banks, said on Thursday that they were in talks about an asset swap that would give Socit Gnrale full control of their Newedge Group derivatives venture.

title: Signs of a Turnaround at Steel Giant ArcelorMittal
description: LONDON  ArcelorMittal, the worlds largest steel maker, on Thursday reported a narrower loss than a year earlier, as an improving world economy helped offset persistent problems in Europe.

title: News Quiz | Nov. 7, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 7, 2013
description: Use context clues and your knowledge of word roots to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

title: Guangzhou Gives Hope to Chinas Long-Suffering Soccer Fans
description: There have been numerous new dawns in Chinese soccer over the years, but this Saturday may witness the birth of a genuinely exciting period as Guangzhou Evergrande looks to become the first club from the worlds most populous country to become the champion of Asia since 1990.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Hundreds of Forgotten Art Works Found Hidden in Germany
description: The article German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art describes a recent discovery in Germany that astonished the art world.

title: Indian Lawmaker Charged With Information Law Activists Murder
description: NEW DELHI  A member of the Indian parliament has been arrested on the charges of conspiring to kill a Right to Information activist in the western state of Gujarat. The arrest on Wednesday took place more than three years after the murder.

title: Lee Harvey Oswald Was My Friend
description: It was 7 a.m. on Sunday when the single phone at the bottom of the stairs echoed through my parents red-brick house, right off Monticello Park in Fort Worth. Mr. Gregory, a woman said as my father picked up, I need your help. Who are you? he asked in his Texas-Russian accent, still half-asleep.

title: Stars of the Silver Screen in Black Sweaters
description: In one of Victor Skrebneskis earliest memories from the 1930s, he is 4 years old and sitting in the fifth row at Chicagos Standard movie theater for a matinee double bill. His neck strains as he looks almost straight up at the towering image of Frankenstein.

title: What Can Older People Learn From Your Generation?
description: In an article currently on the most emailed list, a baby boomer describes how his 25-year-old son does what he loves, even if it doesnt earn him much money. His sons life, he writes, is making him rethink how success might be measured.

title: Greek Police Raid Occupied Broadcasting Building
description: ATHENS  Greek riot police officers raided the headquarters of the countrys former state broadcaster, ERT, on Thursday, forcibly removing dozens of staff members who had been occupying the building since June, when the authorities abruptly shut down the organization, citing wasteful spending.

title: Earnings at Siemens Dip
description: FRANKFURT  The German engineering and electronics giant Siemens said on Thursday that its profit fell 10 percent in the quarter ended Sept. 30 as sales dipped and the company booked restructuring costs.

title: Beijing Seeking a Break in the Impasse over North Korea
description: For a diplomat who reportedly does not like to fly  no-smoking cabins cut into his nicotine habit  Wu Dawei, Chinas special representative for Korean Peninsula affairs, has been a busy man.

title: Nestl to Sell Its Jenny Craig Brand to Private Equity Firm
description: LONDON  Nestl, the Swiss food giant, said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its Jenny Craig brand in North America and Australia, New Zealand and other parts of the Pacific region to North Castle Partners, a Connecticut private equity firm focused on health and wellness businesses.

title: SEMA Show: A Candy Factory for the Auto Enthusiast
description: LAS VEGAS  The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show here can sound rather boring when just the facts are recited: about 2,500 vendors showing some 2,000 new products in one million square feet of exhibit space.

title: New York Today: Stealth Drought
description: Updated 11:53 a.m. | Theres news in the weather forecast today: It may rain a tenth of an inch or so.

title: Why Zimbabwe Sanctions Boomerang
description: Few Robert Mugabe speeches over the past 10 years have failed to include some blazing rhetorical flourish against the West. Shame, shame, shame to the United States of America. Shame, shame, shame to Britain and its allies, he declared at the United Nations General Assembly in September. Zimbabwe is for Zimbabweans, so are its resources. Please remove your illegal and filthy sanctions from my peaceful country.

title: U.S. Signals Flexibility as Iran Nuclear Talks Resume
description: GENEVA  Negotiators from Iran and six world powers convened in Geneva on Thursday as American officials signaled that the United States was prepared to offer Iran limited relief from economic sanctions if it agreed to halt its nuclear development program and reverse part of it.

title: Inspectors in Syria Have Only One Site Left to Check
description: LONDON  International chemical weapons inspectors reported further progress on Thursday in eliminating Syrias stockpile, saying they had verified the destruction of 22 of the 23 sites that the Syrian government declared had been used for the production and mixing of the banned munitions.

title: The Kombi Madeleine
description: SO BERNARDO DO CAMPO, Brazil  Over more than a half-century of production here, the Volkswagen Kombi, or minivan, has been many things to Brazil: ambulance, fire truck, hearse, food vendor, impromptu furniture store, school bus and sugar-cane juice dispenser  to name just a few. For most people in this nation of immigrants it is a Brazilian car with distant German roots.

title: Bank of England Holds Rate Steady
description: LONDON  Britains central bank on Thursday decided to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low amid signs that the countrys economic recovery was gaining speed and consumer confidence improved.

title: Ex-Leader Of Pakistan Is Released On Bail
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans former military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, was freed on bail Thursday after six months under house arrest.

title: Tiananmen Attack Linked to Police Raid on a Mosque in Xinjiang
description: Could the attackers responsible for a deadly assault on the heart of the Chinese capital on Oct. 28 have been motivated by revenge? That is the theory offered up by a former local official from the hometown of Usmen Hasan, the man identified by the Chinese police as the driver of a car that struck and killed two tourists before going up in flames at Tiananmen Square.

title: Daily Report: Twitters I.P.O. Takes Flight, Despite Slowing Growth
description: With 70 million shares sold in its initial public offering, Twitter has raised $1.8 billion. But as Twitter it makes the transition to a publicly traded company, attracting and retaining users has become one of its biggest challenges, Vindu Goel reports.

title: European Central Bank Makes a Surprise Rate Cut
description: FRANKFURT  In an unexpectedly swift reaction to economic warning signals, the European Central Bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low on Thursday, moving to head off what some economists fear could be a long period of stagnation like the one that has afflicted Japan.

title: Opening With a Pop, Key Moments From Twitters First Day of Trading
description: Updated, 4:22 p.m. | Twitter began life as a public company on Thursday, and DealBook followed the first day of trading as it happened.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Gut Feeling
description: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a previously healthy 47-year-old woman who for the past two years has had episodes of abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting so severe she has needed to be hospitalized?

title: Warburg Pincus Names General Counsel
description: The private equity firm Warburg Pincus has appointed Robert B. Knauss, a corporate partner at the law firm Munger, Tolles & Olson in Los Angeles, as general counsel and managing director.

title: Twitters Big Day
description: Twitter is ready for its Wall Street debut. The social media company set the price of its initial public offering at $26 a share on Wednesday evening, raising $1.8 billion and achieving a valuation of $18.1 billion, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times. Its stock is set to begin trading on Thursday under the ticker symbol TWTR on the New York Stock Exchange. The I.P.O. price, a subject of debate between the board and its underwriters until late on Wednesday afternoon, came in above an already heightened price range, reflecting strong demand for the stock, Mr. Goel reports.

title: Struggling to Manage a Multigenerational Staff
description: At the last She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about some of their most pressing concerns, including hiring high-level employees and managing a multigenerational staff.

title: Growth Gain Blurs Signs of Weakness in Economy
description: Five years after the global economy was falling at its fastest rate, Western economies are still failing to gain much-needed momentum, despite the efforts of central bankers on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Social Securitys Job
description: Does Social Security need to be fixed?

title: Nests Tony Fadell on Smart Objects, and the Singularity of Innovation
description: Tony Fadell is the founder and chief executive of Nest, a company that is trying to bring a high-end technology experience to some of the most prosaic areas of the home. Nests first product was a thermostat, which it followed with a smoke alarm.

title: A Day That Will Live In IMFamy Forever
description: Or, actually, maybe not, since as far as I know its only being live-streamed. But anyway, Im at the Jacques Polak research conference at the IMF, and the livestream is here. My own talk is at 4.

description: On Nov. 15, the presidents and the prime ministers of an array of countries once ruled by the British Empire will assemble in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital, for the annual meeting of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

description: Dear Diary:

title: F.D.A. Ruling Would All but Eliminate Trans Fats
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed measures on Thursday that would all but eliminate artery-clogging, artificial trans fats from the food supply, the culmination of three decades of effort by public health advocates to get the government to take action against them.

title: Identifying With the Bulldogs
description: The bulldog is no longer just the sports mascot at Fresno State. It has been appropriated by a violent street gang called the Bulldogs, vexing university officials.

title: Fresno State Loves Its Bulldogs, but So Does a Gang
description: FRESNO, Calif.  Bulldogs can be seen snarling from flagpoles, from baseball caps, from T-shirts and from tattoos  one man has the dogs face inked across his torso, its behind across his back. Young men on street corners bark at passing patrol officers. They call their children little dogs or bull puppies. Police raids find their targets asleep beneath red blankets emblazoned with the dog.

title: In Oslo, an Art Rock Hotel
description: Guests staying in a newly renovated suite at The Thief, a boutique hotel in Oslo, Norway, are being offered the latest in luxury amenities: the chance to share a room with some rock stars.

title: Sherman Alexie: By the Book
description: The author of The Lone Ranger and Tonto Fistfight in Heaven and The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian would love to go on a date with Dorothy Parker and get verbally eviscerated.

description: The actor Patrick Stewart and Vivienne Harr, a 9-year-old who has been protesting slavery, rang the opening bell before Twitter began trading shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pakistani Taliban Pick Hard-Liner as Leader, Imperiling Proposed Peace Talks
description: LONDON  In a surprise choice that bodes poorly for proposed peace talks, the Pakistani Taliban on Thursday appointed as their new leader the hard-line commander responsible for last years attack on Malala Yousafzai, the teenage Pakistani education activist.

title: In Our Pages: November 8
description: 1938 Reich Embassy Secretary Shot

title: Theme Parks and Movies Propel Profit at Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  Disney ended its fiscal year in blockbuster style on Thursday, reporting solid growth in fourth-quarter profit, unveiling a substantial Netflix deal and savoring a stock price that has climbed 35 percent over the last 12 months.

title: Fast-Paced Evolution in the Andes
description: In 1799 the great naturalist Alexander von Humboldt and his companions set out from Caracas, Venezuela, to climb the Andes. They struggled up a mountainside enveloped in mist so thick they had to clamber over rocks by hand. When the fog cleared, von Humboldt was left astonished by the view. Vast grasslands stretched all around him, home to an astonishing number of different trees, shrubs and flowers.

title: Fantasy Baseball: The Mets and Cano
description: The Mets are in desperate need of a left-handed power hitter who can bat cleanup in their lineup behind David Wright and give the batting order an identity.

title: U.S. Reading and Math Scores Show Slight Gains
description: American fourth and eighth graders showed incremental gains in reading and math this year, but achievement gaps between whites and blacks, whites and Hispanics, and low-income and more affluent students stubbornly persist, data released by the Education Department on Thursday showed.

title: When Advanced Math Placement Is a Struggle
description: This weeks question is an amalgam of two questions, but because I have received quite a few inquiries about ability grouping, I thought Id do a mash-up in order to cover all the issues surrounding the challenge of academic placement.

description: Marco Zanini, the newly appointed creative director for the house of Schiaparelli, pens a love note to Cartiers custom stationery.

description: This Poetry Pairing commemorates Veterans Day, which will be celebrated in the United States on Monday. It pairs the poem Gone, Gone Again by Edward Thomas, which was published in 1917, with the ArtsBeat blog post Kerry James Evans: From Combat Engineer to Poet by Dana Jennings.

title: Unequal Progress on Standardized Tests
description: Average scores on the National Assessment of Educational Progress have been rising but large disparities among races and economic classes remain.

title: A Mysterious Realm of Exquisite Objects
description: Heres a good question for Jeopardy!: One of the worlds longest-running dynasties, it emerged around 57 B.C. and grew to dominate the Korean Peninsula in the seventh and eighth centuries before meeting its demise in A.D. 935.

title: If Congress Were Swayed by Facts
description: If Congress were swayed by facts and evidence, lawmakers would not be considering cuts to food stamps and unemployment benefits. And the White House would rethink the cuts to Social Security that it included in its most recent budget.

title: Counting the Costs of the Civil War
description: While the desire to document military exploits and wars is as old as writing itself, the recording of military medical data is a relatively modern phenomenon. Although some initial attempts to chronicle the health of troops occurred in the first half of the 19th century, the first large-scale, wartime medical and behavioral health surveillance effort was conducted during the American Civil War.

title: Possible Meteor Over California Has Social Media Abuzz
description: A fireball lit up the sky over Southern California around 8 p.m. Wednesday, and scientists are saying that it may have been part of a South Taurid meteor shower.

title: Image of the Day: November 7
Fantasy Football: Week 10 Matchup Breakdown
description: After the Indianapolis Colts Reggie Wayne was lost for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament, it was assumed that the teams talented second-year wide receiver, T.Y. Hilton, would become the top receiving option for Andrew Luck. It took Hilton a couple of quarters to warm up Sunday night against the Houston Texans before racking up 114 yards and 3 touchdowns in the second half.

description: What happens to the characters in Mozarts popular Cos Fan Tutte when the curtain goes down? The love stories in the opera end so inconclusively that questions remain even for the cast.

description: Most opera fans are intensely involved with the characters of great operas. We are protective of them, even the evil ones.

description: It should be hard to say goodbye to a car that youve owned for almost 40 years, but that was not the case with my classic. My recently departed car was a 1974 Jensen-Healey. Im sure you understand.

title: V.A. Is Faulted Over Landmarks Condition
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of landmark buildings where wounded soldiers have received treatment, some dating back to the Civil War, are at risk of being abandoned or demolished because of poor management by officials at the Department of Veterans Affairs, preservationists said in a report released on Thursday.

title: Wendy Davis, Texas Legislator, to Write Memoir
description: Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator whose 11-hour legislative filibuster of an abortion bill gave her instant fame in the Democratic Party, is about to take the next logical step in her political ascent: writing a memoir.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Carnegie Hall Benefit to Turn Nathan Lane Into Nathan Detroit Once Again
description: For one night Nathan Lane will again roll the dice as the gambler Nathan Detroit in Carnegie Halls concert staging of Guys and Dolls, the music hall announced on Thursday.

title: Colon Cancer Screening Lags
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all adults aged 50 to 75 be screened for colorectal cancer, but the agency announced this week that one third of them  23 million people  have never been properly tested.

title: The Long-Term Cost of Feckless Policy
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: White House Tours Resume
description: The White House has resumed public tours of the executive residence and East Wing this week, after severe cuts to the governments budget in March, known as sequestration, ended the visits, The Associated Press reported.

title: Senate Approves Ban on Antigay Bias in Workplace
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday approved a ban on discrimination in the workplace based on sexual orientation and gender identity, voting 64 to 32 in a bipartisan show of support that is rare for any social issue. It was the first time in the institutions history that it had voted to include gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people in the countrys nondiscrimination law.

title: Ruling From the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
description: Jesse M. Furman of Federal District Court in Manhattan, found that the city, through benign neglect, was in violation of the of the Americans of Disabilities Act.

title: What Our Patients Can Teach Us
description: When the man who was about to become my patient couldnt tolerate the fatigue any longer, he asked his son, one of 10 children, to take him in their buggy from his woodworking shop to the local doctor who tended to this Amish community, located 90 miles south of Cleveland. Labs showed a white blood cell count that was 12 times normal and profound anemia, and he was driven by ambulance to our hospital.

title: Kerry Takes Personal Approach to Mideast Peace
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Traveling around the Middle East with Secretary of State John Kerry, particularly for a reporter whose last State Department tour was with Hillary Rodham Clinton, is a seat-of-the-pants experience. Itineraries are notional. Improvisation is the rule.

title: Goldman Discloses Foreign Exchange Inquiry
description: LONDONGoldman Sachs on Thursday became the latest big bank to acknowledge that it was the subject of a series of wide-ranging investigations into the potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland to Pay $153.7 Million to Settle Mortgage Case
description: Updated, 8:14 p.m. |

title: Michael Palmer, Doctor Who Became Top Author, Dies at 71
description: Dr. Michael Palmer, a physician who began writing tightly plotted thrillers at his kitchen table in 1978 to escape the inner chaos of alcohol and drug addiction, in the process finding a worldwide audience (and sobriety) as the author of top sellers like Extreme Measures and Natural Causes, died on Oct. 30 in Queens. He was 71.

title: The Gun Report: November 7, 2013
description: The father of Jose Reyes, the 12-year-old boy who killed a math teacher and wounded two classmates before committing suicide at a Sparks, Nev., middle school on Oct. 21, said the handgun his son used was procured from their home and wasnt locked up. Jose Reyes and his wife, Liliana, said they never told him where the 9mm semi-automatic pistol was stored, but he somehow managed to find it.

title: Katia Beauchamp of Birchbox, on the Strength of Optimism
description: This interview with Katia Beauchamp, co-founder and co-chief executive of Birchbox, a beauty products website, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Court Says New York Neglected Disabled in Emergencies
description: New York City has violated the rights of about 900,000 of its residents with disabilities by failing to accommodate for their needs during emergencies, a federal judge ruled on Thursday.

title: Scene City: At AREA Nightclubbing as an Art Form
description: AREA, the legendary nightclub from 30 years ago, reopens for one night only.

title: The CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund: Where No Designer Is Left Behind
description: Many have landed high-profile positions or new backers. But has it all been a bed of roses?

title: Card Act Cleared Up Credit Cards Hidden Costs
description: Four years ago, Congress decided to force down the hidden fees that credit card companies collect from their customers. It passed a law called the 2009 Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act  a name chosen so the law would be known as the Card Act.

title: Imported From Turkey, a Taste of Home
description: For proof of how far hard work and a good attitude can take you in life, one could do worse than drop in at Lisas Mediterranean Cuisine in downtown Ridgewood.

title: Reaction Is Cautiously Positive to Indias Bank Rules
description: MUMBAI  New regulations issued by Indias central bank would make it easier and more attractive for global banks to enter the Indian market, a senior banker and several analysts said on Thursday, though they cautioned that restrictions in the rules might slow the pace of expansion.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Player Tiers
description: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: My Caribbean: 5 Vignettes
description: How do you define the Caribbean? Writers intimately acquainted with the islands answer with postcards from their ancestral homes.

title: Festivals Where the Beat Makes You Move
description: Am I the only one who returns from the Caribbean acutely in need of rest? Blame the music. The region is drenched in genres I crave  reggae, calypso, zouk, and the list goes on  which means that night after night has me feeling like Odysseus battling the Sirens: cursed be that delicious din at the dancehall or the rum shop, destined to foil my fantasy of an early nights sleep.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Looking to Norwegian, 22, to Revive Image of Chess
description: On Saturday, Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, and Viswanathan Anand, a 43-year-old Indian, will stride to the center of a stage in a hotel in Chennai, India, shake hands and sit down at a chess board to begin a match for the world championship title.

title: Rev. Eugene Callender, Who Saw Potential of School Dropouts, Dies at 87
description: The Rev. Dr. Eugene S. Callender, a civil rights advocate best known for starting an innovative series of street academies for disadvantaged New York City youths that became a model for nontraditional educational programs nationwide, died on Nov. 2 in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: British Intelligence Chiefs Say Leaks by Snowden Hurt Security
description: LONDON  Britains intelligence chiefs, in unprecedented public testimony before Parliament, said on Thursday that the published leaks of secret documents stolen by Edward J. Snowden, the former American intelligence analyst, had damaged their ability to keep Britain safe.

title: Congo Rebels, After Giving Up Struggle, Are Disarmed
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Ugandan military has begun the process of disarming large numbers of rebels from the neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo, a military spokesman said Thursday.

title: Living With Cancer: Tumbling Blocks
description: On a night several months ago, the digital clock blinked 11:53. My husband was asleep so I crept down the hall, only turning on a light when I got into my study. On a sheet on the floor were fabrics laid out for a new quilt in the tumbling block pattern. Pictures of my friends kept me company, but there was no photo of the woman over whom I was grieving.

title: Hedge Fund Is Said to Push for Mens Wearhouse Merger
description: Over the last two months, Mens Wearhouse has steadfastly rebuffed a $2.3 billion takeover bid by a smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank.

title: The Intrepids Re-enlisted Artifacts
description: Veterans of World War II and Vietnam War service on the Intrepid aircraft carrier, despite miserable living conditions aboard, developed sentimental attachments to souvenirs. Hundreds of artifacts have been donated in the last few months to the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in New York, in honor of the carriers 70th anniversary.

title: So Far, So Good for Twitter
description: Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange called out orders for shares of Twitter for the first time Thursday morning as one of Wall Streets traditional rituals thrust the young company into the public markets.

title: Ethiopian Lunch Box
description: The pop-up vegan restaurant operates inside Mama Joys during daytime hours in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: The Ceremony Outshines the Stage
description: Is something burning? someone at my table whispered.

title: The Implications of Ownership
description: Its so 70s was the consensus of a group leaving a recent performance of the Yale Repertory Theater, where Caryl Churchills Owners is giving theatergoers much to discuss on the way home.

title: Rape in the Ranks
description: At a press conference on Capitol Hill yesterday, two Marine veterans explained their support for Senator Kirsten Gillibrands bill to reform the way the military handles sexual assault cases. Instead of letting the accusers commander oversee the investigation and decide whether to bring charges, Ms. Gillibrand argues  sensibly  that such authority should rest outside the chain of command, with impartial military prosecutors.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Ashley Williamss Raccoon Bag
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Twitter as the Yin to Facebooks Yang
description: Twitters public debut is turning out to be the yin to Facebooks yang.

title: Marinated Snark Is a Dish Best Served Cold
description: Dana Goodyears new book, about being a wallflower at the American food orgy, won me over on its second page. Thats where she admits that, as a kid in the back of the family station wagon, she used to nibble on Milk-Bone dog biscuits. Im not sure why this image lit up my pleasure sensors. These Scooby snacks were, she writes, tastier than you might expect.

title: More to Remember Than Just the Madeleine
description: Most people spend the week before a marathon resting up and carbo loading.

title: Your Advice for Seeing Chicago With Kids
description: After starting in New York, then heading to Paris, our series on traveling to big cities with children returns to the United States next week with a stop in Chicago.

title: Trends from HTML5 Dev Conf
description: I recently attended the HTML5 Developer Conference (their second event of 2013, I also went to the April conference) in San Francisco and enjoyed the sessions and feel. Here are a few trends I noticed this time:

title: Touches of Tokyo, but California Rolls, Too
description: Norimaki maintains a low profile between a furniture store and a dry cleaner in a small shopping plaza at the center of Washington Depot. Only two small signs hang outside; one is in Japanese characters, and the other says simply sushi. The restaurants spacious, 1,000-square-foot dining area contains just 22 seats (including six at the sushi bar), with the center of the room occupied by a tree sculpture that appears to be growing through the dropped ceiling.

title: Text to Text | The Book Thief and Auschwitz Shifts From Memorializing to Teaching
description: Over the years we have written extensively about the Holocaust, and linked in our lessons to just a tiny fraction of the thousands of articles on the topic that can be found in The Timess archives.

title: Bruce Dern in Pictures
description: Images from the actors career.

title: Qualified Loans, Redefined
description: The mortgage industry is bracing for the coming of Q.M., the new federal rules defining a qualified mortgage  or one underwritten to standards deemed safe for consumers. The implementation of Q.M. poses a compliance headache for lenders, though the average borrower is unlikely to notice any difference when the rules take effect in January. The most immediate differences will be felt by borrowers at the higher and lower ends of the income scale.

title: Gift Guide
description: Each day until Christmas, check in for a new holiday gift idea.

title: For Vinyl Collectors, a $482,000 Bargain on eBay
description: Pssst. Wanna buy a record shop?

title: Different Kinds of Health Care Disruption
description: After yesterdays detour into electoral politics, lets turn back to the health care debate. Last week, amid the ongoing coverage of rising premiums and cancelled plans,the health care laws defenderstook a new tack, arguing that the most plausible conservative alternatives to Obamacare would involve even more disruption of existing arrangements with the implication being, then, that Republican outrage over rate shock is either straightforwardly cynical or else a sign that the G.O.P. would never, ever be willing to embrace a reform that disrupts the status quo at all.

title: When Nest Emptied, Discontent Entered
description: When their last child left for college, Arlene Petty, now 64, felt resentment about her decades-long marriage to Ed Petty, also now 64. Facing an empty nest, she asked for a trial separation. In hindsight, both would have done things very differently.

title: Photos From the Underground
description: The underground persists, but now it likes a little exposure.

title: A Portrait of Eternally Beguiling Americana
description: During the two intermissions of a recent performance of Our Town at the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey, I overheard a number of older patrons remark that they had never before seen it. That was a bit surprising, because this great, enduring play by Thornton Wilder has been staged countless times since its 1938 premiere in Princeton.

title: What Obama Could Do for L.G.B.T. Workplace Protections
description: The United States Senate, which has had us all switching to the Paint Drying Network in search of relative excitement, did its job today and passed, 64-32, an important, far-too-delayed bill to ban discrimination in the workplace based on sexual orientation or identity.

title: A Tax Subsidy for Richer Schools
description: Updated, 11/8/13 | to add chart and to include mention of 2004 study on deductibility.

title: Letters: Searching for Kennedy
description: Searching for Kennedy

title: Applying Plumbers Common Sense to Fix Europes Banks
description: Charlie Mullins made his fortune fixing other peoples plumbing. More recently, Mr. Mullins, the outspoken founder and owner of Pimlico Plumbers in London, is seeking to fix the European banking sector.

title: A Simple Way to Perk Up an Old-Fashioned
description: The recipe for Josey Packards Autumnal Old Fashioned  which appears in my Drink column this weekend  includes smallish quantities of two syrups: One with cinnamon, the other with Demerara sugar. These are easy to prepare, so dont let the prospect of a little extra work deter you from making the cocktail.

title: The Great Old-Fashioned Debate
description: Theres a terrific mini-monologue in the 1942 film You Were Never Lovelier in which Fred Astaires fast-talking would-be rou tells Rita Hayworths ingnue: As theyd say in Brooklyn, I cant bat in your league. Im a plain, ordinary guy from Omaha, Nebraska. Just an old-fashioned, everyday Middle Westerner.. . . But youre streamlined. Youre today. Sister, I was raised amongst the grasshoppers, I am strictly from corn. And then the duo breaks into song and dance, which is where Jerome Kern and Johnny Mercers sublime ballad, Im Old Fashioned, debuted.

title: War of Umbrage
description: Chasmal. Is that a word? Here, Ill use it in a sentence for you: Santorum had been turfed out of office in 2006, losing his re-election bid by a chasmal 18-point margin. According to Merriam Webster, it is indeed a word, meaning resembling a chasm. In other words, Santorum got beaten badly. But why use other words, when chasmal is available?

title: Da Vinci and the Biblioteca Reale
description: A look at works in an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum.

title: Where a Little Dose of Leonardo Is Still a Lot
description: In 2003, the Metropolitan Museum mounted an exhibition of just under 100 drawings by Leonardo da Vinci and pulled in close to half a million visitors in just over two months. This fall, the Morgan Library & Museum is presenting a miniature  very miniature  version of that show called Leonardo da Vinci: Treasures From the Biblioteca Reale, Turin, and it, too, should generate serious traffic, particularly as it includes two outstanding items  a book and a drawing  that the Met didnt have.

title: No Fairy Tale: Robert Hilburn Talks About Johnny Cash: The Life
description: Robert Hilburns new biography of Johnny Cash starts with Cash as a young boy in rural Arkansas, walking along a gravel road at night and singing to himself. The more than 600 pages that follow cover everything  from the famed concert in Folsom Prison (Mr. Hilburn was there that day) to the unlikely, celebrated records Cash made with the hip-hop producer Rick Rubin starting in 1994. As Stephen Holden wrote in his obituary of Cash when the singer died at 71 in 2003, he was one of the few performers who outlasted trends to become a mythical figure rediscovered by each new generation. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Hilburn, a former longtime music critic for The Los Angeles Times, discussed the biopic Walk the Line, Cashs tumultuous marriage to June Carter, Cashs influence today and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: After a Break, Turkeys Prime Minister Again Courts Controversy
description: ISTANBUL  In his time in power, more than a decade now, Turkeys prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has alienated large portions of the population for his seeming intrusions into private lives. He has told women how many children they should have, has sought to outlaw abortion and adultery and to limit alcohol consumption and once, oddly, went on a public tirade against white bread.

title: An Ibsen Who Rages Over Ritalin and Economic Austerity Plans
description: Get on with the play!

title: The Subjects Arent the Same
description: Stepping into the Park Avenue Armory, you can time-travel backward through the history of prints, if you care to. Contemporary ones are clustered near the entrance to the International Fine Print Dealers Associations annual Print Fair, now in its 23rd year, but a fine selection of modern and old master prints lies just beyond.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Monet Seaside Gardens, Blooming Side by Side
description: Garden at Sainte-Adresse, Monets 1867 painting of a sun-dappled seaside that features the artists father, Adolphe, wearing a panama hat and watching boats, has belonged to the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1967. For the next six months, anyway, it has a new companion. Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive and co-founder of the Oracle Corporation, has lent the museum Monets Adolphe Monet Reading in a Garden, painted the same year, in which the artists father  wearing the same clothes  is relaxing with a newspaper in the shade.

title: Steve Mumford: The Snow Leopard
description: Postmasters

title: Konrad Lueg
description: Greene Naftali

title: Martina Bacigalupo: Gulu Real Art Studio
description: The Walther Collection Project Space

title: Arlene Shechet: Slip
description: Sikkema Jenkins & Company

title: Fixing the System: Your Turn
description: In my last column I asked readers for their best ideas about how to fix the political and electoral system. Heres a sampling of the responses. Thanks to everyone who participated.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, Japan, Bangladesh and Spain.

title: Housing Treasures and Trivia of Two Worlds Fairs
description: ON April 22, 1963, John F. Kennedy, sitting in the Oval Office, pressed the numbers 1964 on an early touch-tone telephone. It was an exciting, if stage-managed, moment.

title: The Corporate Chief of Sex as Big Business
description: Good Bob has Filthy Gorgeous: The Bob Guccione Story almost entirely to himself. Bad Bob never shows up, though Incompetent Bob does have a cameo.

title: At Your Disposal
description: Well, I loved this book. I dont know if it helps you or anyone to delay that assessment, so I wont. Jonathan Miles can write, and here hes written a wonderful book, and theres no one I would not urge to read it.

title: Another Dickens Orphan, Still Seeking More
description: Mike Newells screen adaptation of Charles Dickenss Great Expectations is never more alive than when it pauses from its breakneck storytelling to gawk at the chaos of 19th-century London. There is Pip, a former blacksmiths assistant, now outfitted as a gentleman, being shoved this way and that while stumbling through the mud and the carnage of a London meat market. The bacchanals of the Finches of the Grove, the rich boys club he joins, are deafening animal-house melees of flying furniture and dishes.

title: Safety Board Faults Truck and Bus Oversight
description: WASHINGTON  Federal safety officials missed or ignored warning signs before four deadly crashes involving heavy trucks or intercity buses in the last year, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Thursday. The government shut down some of the companies, but only after a total of 25 people were killed and 83 injured in the four accidents.

title: Art at Industry City, and Concerts for Brooklyn Conservatory
description: A little over a year since Hurricane Sandy ransacked the city, certain communities are still recovering. Artists whose studios and galleries are clustered in hard-hit neighborhoods, like Chelsea in Manhattan and Red Hook in Brooklyn, were particularly affected, and to celebrate their perseverance, the artist and Brooklyn Rail publisher Phong Bui, whose own studio was ruined in the storm, has organized Come Together: Surviving Sandy, a new exhibition at the vast Industry City complex in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

title: Next Cast of Yankees? To Be Continued
description: Derek Jeter recently began working out in Tampa, Fla., in his effort to return to the Yankees as their everyday shortstop, and that is the teams plan. But Manager Joe Girardi acknowledged Thursday that the Yankees could not be certain that Jeter, their 39-year-old captain, who is coming off the worst injury of his career, would be able to do so until they saw him in games. For now, it is merely a hope.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Love Is Its Own Reward
description: For the last nine years, I have been raising an exs son as my own. I am about to become his legal guardian. I never married or had biological children, so this is probably the only official family event I will have in my life. I have gone to countless weddings, showers, brises, christenings  you name it  and have given generously and happily to my friends. If my family hosts a celebration for the guardianship, would it be wrong to strongly hint that equivalent, big occasion gifts are welcome?

title: Song and Dance, With Groove
description: What a trouper Justin Timberlake is. He started his solo tour  after sharing a summer tour with Jay Z  at Barclays Center on Wednesday night with a lavish marathon of a concert: two full-length sets separated by an intermission and ending just after midnight. He mustered large forces: dancers, a big band with horns, extensive videos and lasers, and an overhead catwalk-like stage that traversed the whole arena. (He brings his show to the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on Saturday.)

title: This Guys No Puppy Hugger
description: The comedian Bill Burr has a name that perfectly matches his delivery: informal, punchy, with a quick staccato snap.

title: Disney Reports 13% Increase in Profit
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company reported a 13 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, as strength in three major divisions  theme parks, consumer products and movies  offset television-related declines.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: medical marijuana, hepatitis C and contaminated chicken. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Tackling Obstacles, the Good Kind
description: AT the Epic Hybrid Training Center in Manhattan, there are monkey bars, ropes, sandbags, resistance bands and some mysterious contraptions in place of the usual exercise machines and weights.

title: A Refuge Found in Pages
description: Speaking in the honeyed, insinuating tone of the Wolf cajoling Little Red Riding Hood to do his bidding, the narrator of The Book Thief is none other than Death himself (Roger Allam), although he coyly refuses to disclose his identity. This irritating know-it-all regularly interrupts the story of Liesel (Sophie Nlisse), a bright-eyed girl living with foster parents in a fictional German town during World War II, to comment obliquely on human nature and mortality.

title: Originator of the Man-Skirt and Corset Revivals
description: Jean Paul Gaultiers contribution to late-20th-century fashion might be summed up in two garments: the corset and the mens skirt. Stepping back a bit, however, Mr. Gaultier accomplished much more than that. He was one of the first openly gay designers, and in an era ruled by street fashion, he made being a high-fashion designer seem cool. The army of pop stars who followed in his wake, becoming designers themselves, is evidence of this, as well as the popularity of television shows like Project Runway and the smaller contingent of artists who have used fashion collections and runway shows as models for performance-based art works. (Just this week, Rainer Ganahls Comme des Marxists, an obvious play on Comme des Garons, appeared at White Columns as part of Performa 13.)

title: After a Parents Death, a Rush of Change
description: When my father died six months shy of his 83rd birthday and my 42nd, I was shocked to find that in the midst of grief, one clear desire emerged, uncontestable: I wanted a child. This was not a decision, or even really a thought; it was more like a reflex.

title: In Paris, a Ragtag, Resplendent District Prepares for Its Close-Up
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Major University and How It Works
description: At Berkeley, the documentarian Frederick Wisemans magisterial examination of the University of California, Berkeley, is conspicuous for not identifying the scores of people shown teaching, studying and exchanging ideas in and out of the classroom. Some may recognize the universitys chipper, ever-smiling former chancellor Robert J. Birgeneau, who retired this year. An even more prominent figure is Robert Reich, the former secretary of labor, now a professor at Berkeleys Goldman School of Public Policy, who delivers an insightful lecture on leadership and the need for self-evaluation.

title: Guide Dog Schools
description: Training animals at guide dog schools takes two years and can cost $60,000.

title: Here, Home for a Baton
description: Good news: With the fifth season of Contact!, the contemporary-music series the New York Philharmonic inaugurated in 2009, comes a performance space that finally suits the informal tone the orchestra desired but never previously delivered.

title: Precious Eyes
description: JENNIFER MURRAY woke after a night out with friends and thought her husband was playing a trick on her. She could not see anything and did not believe him when he said it was daytime.

title: How to Choose a Charity Wisely
description: DONATING to charities this time of year used to be relatively efficient and painless. After watching the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade, you plunked some money into a Salvation Army bucket, wrote some checks, contributed some household items and were done.

title: The Produce Isnt Pretty, but Its Edible
description: SEATTLE  BENJAMIN RASMUS cycled 850 miles over 10 days around Washington State last year to promote gleaning, or gathering edible produce left behind in fields after harvest.

title: A Donation With Name Recognition
description: AT the Childrens Center, a nonprofit organization that provides mental health services to families in Salt Lake City, some children might be drawing in the Dr. Paula Swaner and Dr. William McCreary art therapy room. Their parents could be meeting with staff members in the Katherine W. Dumke and Ezekiel R. Dumke Jr. speech and language therapy office.

title: Her Name Is Famous, but Shes Not About Nothing
description: YOU expect to see Jessica Seinfeld at fancy galas, turned out in designer gowns and stiletto pumps, smiling for the camera on the arm of her famous husband.

title: Charities Get Into Fast Food
description: FACED with declining donations, some nonprofit organizations are getting into the fast-food business.

title: In Crowdfunding, New Source of Aid After Catastrophe
description: WYL COLLINS and his wife, Jessie, managed to salvage only a few belongings after Colorados devastating floods in September destroyed their home and their T-shirt printing equipment in Lyons, a small town about 15 miles north of Boulder.

title: The Hammer Resurgent
description: As if underscoring their films essential witlessness, the folks at Marvel Entertainment have inexplicably missed the opportunity to make a splash by opening Thor: The Dark World on a Thursday. But repackaging a Norse god as an alien superhero takes chutzpah, not humor (unless you count the Viking ship that serves as his spacecraft), and movie studios have yet to lose money by assuming that their audiences have the intellectual discernment of newborns. So if the multiple idiocies on view strike you as neither here nor there, its probably because your eyeballs are too busy recoiling from the onslaught of disorienting 3-D effects, or else too distracted by the title characters Popeye arms and really big mallet.

title: Gadfly Urges a Corporate Model for Charity
description: TO illustrate the Charity Defense Councils mission  protect the protectors  the nonprofits website displays a shield pierced by several arrows. Apparently, the organizations founder and president, Dan Pallotta, got tired of taking barbs unarmed.

title: Rethinking the Dinner Gala
description: The three-course dinners. The auctions and raffles. The speeches from sponsors. The requests for donations. These are the ingredients of many a charity event, and they have stood the test of time.

title: Charities Try Provocative Ads to Attract Attention
description: TO introduce a wider audience to Water Is Life, an upstart aid organization that provides potable water to villages in developing countries, DDB New York startled even unflappable New Yorkers.

title: Government Giving Nonprofits Angst
description: WASHINGTON  FOR some nonprofits, the good times are back. Corporate profits and the stock market are up, and wealthy families have regained nearly all the income they lost during the recession. In turn, charitable giving has increased for each of the last three years, and many nonprofits have intensified fund-raising or seen huge donations roll in: a $100 million gift to the Central Park Conservancy, say, or Harvards new $6.5 billion capital campaign.

title: A Few Good Causes, but Plenty of Time to Spend on Them
description: WHEN Sanford I. Weill wanted to test the sound of the new concert hall named for him and his wife, Joan, in Sonoma, Calif., he called his friend, the pianist Lang Lang, to stop by on his way to a concert with the San Francisco Symphony and approve the acoustics.

title: After the Tuition Bill, the Fund-Raising Pitch
description: ON the University of Virginias website, next to a photo of parents of current students, there is a plea to join them in supporting school traditions by signing up for the Parents Committee; a separate link prompts parents to contribute $2,500 to $25,000 annually.

title: Giving Circles: More Impact to Go Around
description: INSIDE the red-brick St. Michaels Lutheran Church in North Philadelphia, more than a century old, the walls, lined with stained glass windows, reverberate with the haunting strains of a chorus of middle schoolers singing Leonard Cohens Hallelujah.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: North Korea Says It Arrested a South Korean Spy
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Thursday that it had arrested a spy sent by the intelligence agency of its rival, South Korea.

title: $10 Minimum Wage Proposal Has Growing Support From White House
description: The White House has thrown its weight behind a proposal to raise the federal minimum wage to at least $10 an hour.

title: Long Island Bakeries Prepare for Holiday Pie Demand
description: When George Zulkofske stepped into the kitchen at the Jericho Cider Mill on a recent afternoon, a cook was folding several pounds of peeled, sliced apples into a big bowl that contained a drift of cinnamon and light brown sugar. Twenty apple pies were browning in a large oven.

title: He Lost His Titles, but Never His Cool
description: In The Armstrong Lie, Alex Gibneys absorbing but overlong documentary portrait of Lance Armstrong, begun after he won the Tour de France seven consecutive times (1999-2005), Mr. Armstrong exhibits an unwavering poise and an almost robotic self-possession and air of superiority, with barely discernible blips of defiance and irritation. In the face he presents to the camera, he is still a winner, despite having been stripped of his titles for doping.

title: Clare Rojas Gets in Touch With Her Abstract Side
description: Clare Rojas, the Bay Area-based multidisciplinary artist, refuses to confine her expansive practice to a single medium. Instead, she glides from paintbrush to pen, from camera to guitar (or banjo  she produces bluegrass-infused music under the moniker Peggy Honeywell), and in recent years has become known for creating powerful folk-art-inspired tableaus that tackle traditional gender roles.

title: West 57ths Hodgepodge Block
description: The developer Extell now has the go-ahead from the Landmarks Preservation Commission to cantilever a 1,400-foot tower over the Art Students League at 215 West 57th Street, which will create, certainly, a beanstalk presence on what was already a thoroughly jumbled block.

title: Old Friends Make a Deal and Try to Avoid the Devil
description: Bernice (LisaGay Hamilton) and Fontayne (Yolonda Ross), the title characters of John Sayless noirish thriller Go for Sisters, are not biological siblings but former high school friends who once looked so much alike that people said they could go for sisters. In their tense reunion 20 years later, in a seedy Los Angeles outlier, they are on opposite sides of the law.

title: Across Generations, Gathering Insights
description: Vera Josephs life could be a lot worse, but it could also be a lot more purposeful.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: As Twitter Trades, Honoring the Hashtag Godfather
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: In Soulful Devotion, Glimmers of Doom
description: The Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki has long had an aerial fixation, setting one movie after another in the realms of fanciful flight, from Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind to Kikis Delivery Service to the underrated Porco Rosso (about a World War I flying ace who turns into a pig man). Mr. Miyazaki remains enchanted with the idea of being airborne, which animation freely lends itself to, having sent little girls, castles and even swine into flight.  The Wind Rises , his newest film, tells the fictionalized story of Jiro Horikoshi, a gifted aeronautic engineer who is historically notable  or infamous  for designing deadly warplanes used by Japan in World War II. Mr. Miyazakis lyrical chronicle of the inventors creative process and his poignant romance reminds us that staying aloft is a fraught endeavor. Yet even in this film about an absorbed artist of the floating world, premonitions of the calamitous events to come cannot be entirely absent.

title: A Sort Of Vacation (Personal)
description: Its been a really nice, civilized day: talking about economic research and policy issues with smart, knowledgeable people, plus sharing some good memories of graduate school.

title: The Jackpots Smaller, and the Winners More Relatable
description: COMMERCIALS from the New York Lottery tend to take a humorous approach to how much life changes after winning millions. In a recent spot for the Powerball drawing, for example, a man makes everyone he talks to laugh heartily, with the commercial revealing that he is wearing an undetectable earpiece and repeating jokes from a room of seven comedy writers he is employing, led by the comedian Andy Richter.

title: For the Beer, for the Food, for the Feeling
description: The couple had just taken a big step: getting engaged. And of all the places they could have gone to celebrate on a recent fall evening, they chose the Tapp, a one-year-old bar in Tarrytown. Cuddling in a corner and showing her ring to the waitress and other patrons as they gathered around, the two had a grand time.

title: The New Queens Museum
description: A look at renovations at the museum.

title: A Local Place for a Global Neighborhood
description: The United Nations of voices we encounter on Manhattans streets is global but transient: Visitors from abroad come to town and they look, they shop, they leave.

title: In Iowa, but Dreaming of D.C.
description: A little sneeze, dont worry, Mitt Romney says to an Iowan while shaking hands during his 2012 campaign for president. A little hay fever. Im in hay country. With off-the-cuff moments like that, A. J. Schnacks new documentary, Caucus, which follows the candidates vying for the Republican nomination in Iowa, sometimes feels more like a Christopher Guest film than like a political documentary.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: White House Names Senior Bank of America Executive to Commerce Post
description: Updated, 8:10 p.m. |

title: Peter Max Art That Wasnt on the Dorm Wall
description: Some visitors to Peter Max, an exhibition that opened at the Nassau County Museum of Art last month, may find themselves saying, I had that poster in my dorm room!

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Eider Ducks Carry a Chilly Warning
description: The ice is harder to understand now, the Inuit hunter and sculptor Simeonie Kavik tells us midway through People of a Feather, Joel Heaths lyrical examination of the link between hydroelectric power and an endangered Arctic ecosystem.

title: Twitters I.P.O. Draws Protesters to Companys San Francisco Offices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Some 150 protesters (more characters than a tweet!) gathered outside Twitters headquarters on Thursday, the first day of the companys stock trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Most in the crowd wore stickers that read Dont Twit on Me.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 8-14
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Device Rules May Vary by Flight
description: Dont turn on those smartphones during takeoff just yet.

title: Everythings Broken? Then Let the Show Begin
description: By the time Alaina Herman was finished with the Broken? Fix It! exhibition at the Long Island Childrens Museum, she had learned how to rebuild a brick wall, change the oil in a car and glue a cracked china plate back together. But what really caught her attention was a demonstration on repairing window screens.

title: Seeking a Gateway to a Passport in Seattle
description: The very legitimate rom-com formula has been abused by budgets big and small; sugar is sweet, but sweet alone overwhelms all other tastes. The modest Hong Kong entry Finding Mr. Right has the standard odd-couple pairing youve seen on the menu before, but there are moments of substance in this macaroon of a movie.

title: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 8-14
description: Red Grooms New York City

title: Obamacare: Consider the Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: BlackBerrys Latest Investors Include Canadian and Qatari Groups
description: OTTAWA  A combination of Canadian, American and Qatari investors are helping to finance Fairfax Financial Holdings planned $1 billion investment in the struggling smartphone maker BlackBerry.

title: A Camera Aimed at the Conscience
description: Theres a logic at work in the motivated, morality-jarring animal-rights documentary The Ghosts in Our Machine: If animals have emotions, and if we see that human actions cause them sadness, anger and fear, then we will become moved to help.

title: 21st-Century Slavery
Spare Times for Nov. 8-14
description: Veterans Day Weekend (Friday through Monday) In keeping with a tradition largely in place since 1919, Veterans Day honors peace and those in the armed forces on the 11th day of the 11th month at the 11th hour. On Monday there will be a procession along Fifth Avenue, from 26th to 52nd Streets, starting at 11:10 a.m., with Ann E. Dunwoody, the first woman to become a four-star general and who is now retired, as the grand marshal. Sponsored by the United War Veterans Council, the parade also commemorates the 60th anniversary of the end of the Korean War. A ceremony at 10 a.m. in Madison Square Park, at Broadway and 23rd Street, will start things off. More details: vetsday.org.

title: Battle Scars
description: Leonard Gold, 94, spent a year in Europe during World War Two as a photo reconnaissance pilot taking photos of bomb damage over Germany.

title: Plagiarism and Rand Paul
description: To the Editor:

title: Even One Win Can Mean Everything
description: A mournful Midwestern ballad devoid of grace notes, Medora views the crumbling of small-town America through the eyes of the Hornets, a high school basketball team that can barely remember what its like to win a game.

title: Time to License Bicyclists
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family Grocery, With a Long Pedigree
description: At Zingone Brothers, operating as a grocery on Manhattans Upper West Side for 78 years, the regulars are treated like they are part of the family.

title: Youth and Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. and A. With Bayern Munichs Arjen Robben
description: Arjen Robben has won nearly every title while playing for club teams in the Netherlands, England, Spain and Germany. One year after missing a crucial penalty kick for Bayern Munich in the Champions League final against Chelsea in Munichs home stadium, the Allianz Arena, Robben silenced (some) doubters by scoring the winning goal as Munich defeated its Bundesliga rival, Borussia Dortmund, to win the Champions League title at Wembley Stadium last May. Robben, 29, who plays wing for Munich, spoke with Jack Bell of The Times before sustaining an injury against Hertha Berlin in late October.

title: Army Suspends R.O.T.C. Closings at 13 Universities
description: ATLANTA  The Army told 13 universities this week that it would step back from a plan to shutter their Reserve Officers Training Corps programs, disrupting a strategy that had been promoted as an effort to refocus the militarys recruiting amid demographic shifts.

title: A Report on Chernobyl
description: To the Editor:

title: Filling the Gaps of a Checkered Childhood
description: Its common for animated movies to tell stories about feeling like a fish (or a mermaid) out of water, but the hand-drawn hybrid Approved for Adoption is an actual memoir steeped in that sensation.

title: Still Chasing That Elusive Tiara
description: Having a modest amount of name recognition through television appears to have made Casey Wilson (Happy Endings) and June Diane Raphael (NTSF:SD:SUV) think they could write themselves a movie to star in. But theyre not big enough celebrities to make you want to sit through the tepid result just for the pleasure of their company.

title: Apologizing, Obama Yields to Criticism of Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama bowed Thursday night to mounting criticism that he had misled the American people about the health care law, apologizing to people who were forced off their health insurance plans by the Affordable Care Act despite assurances from me.

title: A Zingone in Every Aisle
description: Me? Im from Columbus Avenue, said Dominick Zingone, 53, a tall and suave member of the clan behind Zingone Brothers, an old-fashioned grocery store on the Upper West Side. And thats exactly how the rest of the Zingones feel. No one has forgotten that Grandpa Domenico left the lemon groves of Praiano on the Amalfi Coast at 15, crossed to the New World on the Giuseppe Verdi and landed at Ellis Island on Sept. 3, 1920, but since 1927 a Zingone has been selling produce on the avenue.

title: Like an Outlaw-Country Song
description: All their lives, Frank (Emile Hirsch) and his brother, Jerry Lee (Stephen Dorff), have been dealt only bad hands. Abandoned by their father, their mother lost to illness, they jumped trains as teenagers, costing Jerry Lee part of his leg. Now the hard-drinking Frank works at a factory in Reno, Nev., when he isnt tending to the fragile, disheveled Jerry Lee, whose sole gift is for drawing: pictures of Willie Nelson and, mostly, voluptuous women. Frank tells him fantastical stories, flights of fancy (beautifully animated by Mike Smith) in which Jerry Lee is often the hero.

title: For Prisoners and Families, Burials With Dignity
description: HUNTSVILLE  During a recent vigil at the Captain Joe Byrd Cemetery in this East Texas city, about 40 members and friends of the Texas Interfaith Center for Public Policy laid flowers at tombstones and remembered the more than 3,000 prisoners buried there.

title: Balancing Act for Indias Top Banker
description: MUMBAI  Raghuram Rajan, the head of Indias central bank, began his career as an economic theoretician. But a willingness to delve into the mechanics of an economic system may prove to be a bigger asset as he tries to straighten out Indias economy.

title: Facing Limits on Financing Road Repairs
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Young Love, Interrupted by a Nuclear Bomb
description: You know what its like when you fall in love for the first time, and then World War III breaks out? Well, Daisy (Saoirse Ronan), the spiky 16-year-old American heroine of How I Live Now, is about to find out. Shipped off for the summer to relatives in the English countryside, Daisy hides her vulnerability behind bleached-out bangs and coal-black eyeliner, compulsively washing her hands after contact with her free-spirited cousins and their chaotic farmhouse.

title: Accounts Differ to F.B.I. and CBS on Benghazi
description: Dylan Davies, a security officer hired to help protect the United States Special Mission in Benghazi, Libya, gave the F.B.I. an account of the night that terrorists attacked the mission on Sept. 11, 2012 that contradicts a version of events he provided in a recently published book and in an interview with the CBS News program 60 Minutes.

title: Guns, Chases and Disreputable Pleasures in the City of Light
description: Edgar Maries Paris Countdown is a buddy movie with a downbeat heart. Its two not quite heroes, Milan (Olivier Marchal) and Victor (Jacques Gamblin), have bad history with each other and worse history with the Terminator-like villain Serki (Carlo Brandt), whom they betrayed in an ochre-tinted Mexico. Six years later, Serki is out of jail and wants revenge in a purple-tinted nighttime Paris.

title: Debating New Charter Schools, Their Policies and Their Effects
description: On an evening in late October, several hundred parents crowded into a Temple Beth-El auditorium near downtown San Antonio to learn about a new school opening next fall.

title: What Shell Do for a Passport
