description: The much-hyped Internet of Things may someday arrive as promised. While we wait, maybe we should grab a pint of good beer?

title: Grasping at Life, Petals, Pain and All
description: ROXBURY, Vt.  Look up at those leaves and then frame them with your fingers, Ed Pincus said, facing an enormous maple tree covered in orange and red. He arranged his unsteady hands  he had Parkinsons since 2009  so that he could view the leaves Technicolor contrast against blue sky. Now, when you remove the frame, dont they look different from before?

title: A White House in Crisis Mode, but Some Allies Prod for More Action
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama was seething. Two weeks after the disastrous launch of HealthCare.gov, Mr. Obama gathered his senior staff members in the Oval Office for what one aide recalled as an unsparing dressing-down.

title: With Alabama and L.S.U., a More Earthbound Game
description: In college football, the field has become the party deck for the quarterback. Many games are a loose, festive three hours of lickety-split football, a full buffet.

title: Holiday
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Child-Proofing Harry Potter
description: The second Professor McGonagall pulls Oliver Wood from his charms class, I realize Im in Pinkalicious territory again. In a flash, the entire sequence from Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone comes back to me: Madam Hooch orders the class not to fly; Harry hops on his broomstick; McGonagall catches him and introduces him to Wood, the captain of the Gryffindor quidditch team, as its new seeker.

title: On Nicolas Ghesquire, and Sweatpants
description: MY OBSESSION THESE DAYS is to find a decent pair of sweatpants. And by decent, I mean particular: not too skinny, perhaps something in a fine knit (ribbing is O.K.), and definitely not anything pooling at my ankles. Im willing to pay a lot of money for my dream sweats, not a fortune but certainly I can do better than Modells.

title: Wholesome Biscotti (Some Even Gluten-Free)
description: Some pastries lend themselves to interpretation and adaptation to whole grain variations; others are best left alone in their white flour and sugar splendor. Biscotti, the dry Italian cookies that are twice baked (which is what the name means), are a kind of pastry that does. They are supposed to be hard, and dont have to be too sweet, though most of the biscotti you find in coffee shops are  too sweet, that is.

title: Late to the Race, but Early to the Finish Line
description: GEOJE, South Korea  SIM JAE-DUK, a South Korean shipyard worker, checked into his motel in Front Royal, Va., on a May evening in 2006, sleepy after his first-ever trip to the United States  on a budget flight that first stopped in Tokyo and San Francisco. Two days later, he set off on the Massanutten Mountain Trails 100-Mile Run and won it, setting a record of 17 hours, 40 minutes, 45 seconds, which has yet to be broken.

title: Tailgating Gets Online Playbooks
description: The coleslaw was the culprit. After receiving several dozen emails discussing who would bring the coleslaw to a football tailgate party at Washington & Lee University in Lexington, Va., Caroline Hundley was losing her patience.

title: Against Disclosure
description: IN the policy world, corporate disclosure is widely seen as an unalloyed good. Publicly traded corporations are under growing pressure to reveal more information about C.E.O. compensation, political spending and even the dangers that climate change poses for the company.

title: Chrysler Recalls 1.2 Million Ram Trucks
description: Chrysler is recalling about 1.2 million Ram trucks to correct problems that could result in a loss of steering, as well as almost 94,000 of its 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokees because of electronic problems that could disable two safety systems, the automaker said on Friday.

title: Movie Review: 'The Wind Rises'
description: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews the movie "The Wind Rises."

title: Market Report | Take a Hike
description: Rugged designer boots that are the height of style and can scale any mountain.

title: Satire Show Raises Questions in Egypt
description: Bassem Youssef, a popular satirist, was taken off the air after making jokes about Egypts military leadership. The shutdown set off a debate, calling into question the armys commitment to democracy.

title: Bonus Work Space, Right in the Lobby
description: Pity the poor cubicle: modern-day workers seem to prefer any other place to these narrow, partitioned-off desks.

title: A Horse of a Different Color
description: Those who know Alexandra Solimine cannot quite get over the fact that a woman who has said she so hated horses and everything about them while growing up in the equestrian-minded community Far Hills, N.J., ended up marrying Kris Kampsen, a dedicated polo player from Florida.

title: That Rangers Rush
description: Hours before the puck drops at 7:30 in Madison Square Garden, waves of energy begin to reach Buddys Sports Corner, a memorabilia store in the Paramus Park Mall in New Jersey.

title: Protesting Twitter
description: This week, while executives from Twitter were celebrating a successful initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange, San Franciscans wearing Dont Twit on Me stickers were picketing the companys headquarters because its presence in their neighborhood has made it unaffordable.

title: T WINTER TRAVEL
description: Rugged designer boots that are the height of style and can scale any mountain.

title: Background: Irans Nuclear Program and Possible Steps to a Broad Agreement
description: While Iran enters the nuclear talks with hopes that the West will ease the economic sanctions, its nuclear program cannot be easily turned back.

title: Lara Logans On-Air Apology for Flawed Benghazi Report
description: As my colleagues Bill Carter and Michael Schmidt report, the CBS News correspondent Lara Logan apologized on Friday for her flawed 60 Minutes report on the deadly assault on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, last year.

title: Gluten-Free Dessert Pastry
description: I worked with many different combinations of flours before settling on this one. I love the flavor of the oat flour, but it is so fine that when I tried using all oat flour the pastry crumbled much too easily. So I combined it with corn flour, which is finely ground cornmeal; Bobs Red Mill produces the version I used. Millet flour will also work, but it has a chalkier flavor. The almond flour absorbs moisture and helps hold the dough together. The dough will crack if you roll it out cold, so I roll it between pieces of plastic before I chill it. Then I remove it from the refrigerator and let it soften just enough so that I can line the tart pans without it cracking.

title: Boeing Warns Washington State Could Lose 777X if Labor Deal Is Rejected
description: Boeing threatened on Friday to consider locations besides Washington State to assemble its new 777X jets after a union leader sharply criticized the terms of a tentative labor deal to keep the work in Washington.

title: Bring Out the Good Stuff for the Guests
description: Gifts that will come in handy for entertaining.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks listings include a duplex on the Upper West Side; a pet-friendly apartment in Murray Hill; and a Cobble Hill unit in a 2011 building.

title: An App for Job Seekers
description: Applying for jobs is unpleasant.It combines the tedium of filling out endless paperwork with the existential question of what you really want to do or, in more dire situations, whether theres anything out there for you.And even in a recovering economy, employers still seem unwilling to take chances, leaving many applicants feeling doomed to repeat the process ad infinitum.

title: Waking Area Nightclub From the Dead
description: The sidewalk was crammed with kooky artists and well-dressed celebutantes, craning their necks to get a glimpse of Invisible Sculpture, a piece by Andy Warhol that consists of a pedestal and a wall label.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A townhouse in Dobbs Ferry with three bedrooms and a four-bedroom ranch in Sands Point.

title: A New Type of Cat, Ready to Rumble
description: Firesand Orange is what Jaguar calls the paint that flashed from the F-Type sports car that I recently drove. The crowd-pleasing shade recalled such things as a pumpkin, a traffic cone and a hunters vest.

title: Bill de Blasios Circle of Power
description: Key advisors in the orbit of New York Citys mayor-elect: the people he met as a city official, a political operative and a Brooklyn parent.

title: An Early Import Fighter That Only Embarrassed
description: General Motors first front-wheel-drive compact models  the Buick Skylark, Chevrolet Citation, Oldsmobile Omega and Pontiac Phoenix  arrived for 1980 with great promise. Known by G.M.s internal code as the X-body models, or X-cars, the four models replaced larger rear-drive sedans that included the popular Chevy Nova.

title: An Artifact From a Grim Era in Detroits Showrooms
description: This was the car that started the decline, Alan Spiegel said, turning his beige Chevrolet Citation into the parking lot of the Bridge View Tavern, a restaurant that, he promised, served the best burgers in Westchester County.

title: Shady Paths on Which a Butterfly Flutters
description: Space and time are precious commodities in the dance world. As the inaugural artist in residence at BAM Fisher, the newest and most versatile theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the choreographer Kate Weare had the relative luxury of two weeks to rehearse in the Fishers Fishman Space. Her new piece, Dark Lark, had its New York premiere there on Wednesday.

title: More Muscle, Same Magic
description: TESTED 2014 Mazda CX-5 Grand Touring AWD

title: Cuomo Orders Investigations Into Claims of Anti-Semitic Acts in a School District
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday that he had directed the New York State Police and the State Division of Human Rights to investigate allegations of anti-Semitic harassment of children in the Pine Bush Central School District.

title: Roar, Britannia
description: Jaguars F-Type roadster is a snarling, clawing animal. It may have its flaws, but the supercharged 495-horsepower V8 engine isnt one of them.

title: Review: 2014 Jaguar F-Type S
description: A high-end audio system that's fun to drive? Jaguar's 2014 F-Type snarls like the Rolling Stones and tracks as precisely as a needle in a groove. Tom Voelk recommends a good set of headphones.

title: Chamber Music of a Very Different Kind
description: The tones emanating from a cars exhaust pipes  a V8s deep bellow, say, or the piercing wail of a high-revving V12  have long been inspirations to an enthusiasts ear. What others may deem mere noise can, appropriately tuned, become a symphony of internal combustion.

title: Movie Trailer: 'Higher'
description: "Higher Unplugged" looks at the making of "Higher," which follows snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the Teton Gravity Research crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal.

title: Mapping a Life, and Finishing a Long Trip
description: Great storytellers can be terrible interview subjects. Patrick Leigh Fermor, the British travel writer, was one of them. Artemis Cooper, the author of Patrick Leigh Fermor: An Adventure, recently published by New York Review Books, found out the hard way.

title: Pictures of the Day: Louisiana and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Louisiana, Syria, India and Thailand.

title: Coming: New Snowboarding and Skiing Video Series
description: Jeremy Jones has long flirted with danger in executing daring feats atop his snowboard in far-flung locations. Teton Gravity Research has documented Joness efforts through a trilogy of films, Deeper, Further and, now, Higher, the trailer for which can be viewed here. This trailer sets the tone for TGRs new web series, Higher Unplugged, which The Times will feature, starting on Nov. 20. Another series from TGR, Behind the Line, can be viewed at nytimes.com/sports, starting on Nov. 13.

title: Through Group Dating, Getting to Know You (and You and You)
description: On a balmy Tuesday evening, half a dozen young people gathered for drinks, as young people will, at the HiFi Bar in the East Village.

title: Neighbors, Yet Worlds Apart
description: If you lived in Apartment 17A at 1280 Fifth Avenue, a Robert A. M. Stern-designed building, which goes by the baptismal name One Museum Mile, you would have acquired 1,863 square feet for $2.8 million. After a while, perhaps following the birth of a second child or during a bout of the kind of enervating status anxiety that afflicts so many in Manhattan, you would find yourself coveting the combined unit upstairs  the five-bedroom place priced at $8.7 million. You dont have the money, but maybe if you changed careers, or husbands, or gained a windfall from a dubious lawsuit, you would. You indulge these fantasies, even as you look out your window toward the gloomy, austere towers of Schomburg Plaza, a former Mitchell-Lama complex, or walk four blocks east and south to the sprawl of projects on Madison Avenue.

title: 40 Years On, No Foul Play Found in Chilean Poets Death
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Chilean and international forensics experts have ruled out poisoning or other foul play in the death of the Nobel Prize-winning poet Pablo Neruda in 1973, according to a report released Friday.

title: Adam Driver, Unconventional Looks and a Brooding Manner
description: Mr. Driver offers a respite from cookie-cutter beauty.

title: Your Vegetable Ad Here
description: Last week, we challenged readers to follow the lead set by the ad agency Victors & Spoils in rebranding broccoli and write their own slogans for untrendy vegetables. We received nearly 400 submissions, demonstrating a full range of our readers imaginations (Cauliflower is the Charlemagne of crucifers, suggested Chuck Spohr, from Skokie, Ill.) and observations (Beets turn your pee a beautiful shade of pink, wrote Sally Macrae from Toronto.) Ukrainian girls know. You? was a suggestion for a slogan for cabbage, referring to, as Ksenia from New York put it, the belief in Eastern Europe that consuming lots of cabbage makes breasts more appealing. And Mike Williams from Melbourne, Australia, suggested this: They say if you wrap your feet in cabbage it will cure your arthritis. Why not just eat it? Why not, indeed.

title: For Gore Vidal, a Final Plot Twist
description: Gore Vidal always kept a fire burning in the grate, his nephew Burr Steers said as we stood in the authors living room in Los Angeles, even when it was 110 degrees outside. Mr. Vidal had suffered hypothermia while serving in the Army during World War II, Mr. Steers added, and his left knee was made of titanium.

title: The Syllable Everyone Recognizes
description: Are there words that are universally understood, across all countries and cultures? A team of linguists has proposed one: huh.

title: At New York Hotel, Marilyn and Joe Get a Room
description: The Lexington New York City recently completed a $46 million renovation of its public spaces, guest rooms and suites, part of which pays homage to two of the propertys famous former residents, Joe DiMaggio and Marilyn Monroe.

title: Different Side of a Continent
description: Through her excellent new record, Beautiful Africa (Nonesuch), Rokia Traor, the middle-class daughter of a Malian diplomat, remains honest, curious, feminist, defiant toward anyone who considers her work beneath her station  Afro-progressive, as she puts it in the title track.

title: People as Puzzles of Infinite Variety
description: What was that about eight million stories in the naked city?

title: Italian Light on Monteverdi
description: Though she is beloved of connoisseurs and critics, the Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci remains little known among a broader New York public. Its not for lack of talent, since she is an artist of singular gifts and refined temperament. But her local performances have been limited to just two concerts: one in February 1999, the other in April 2012. Unconventional and intense, Ms. Antonacci has become a specialist in the intimate affair, comfortable and potent in the early-music repertory.

title: The Future Is African
description: Afrofuturism, a genre that mixes science fiction with the culture, history and politics of the African diaspora, is as old as Sun Ras 1974 film Space Is the Place and as new as Janelle Mones latest album. If youve been following artists like Wangechi Mutu, Sanford Biggers or Robert Pruitt, you probably already know that its driving a lot of contemporary art. The Shadows Took Shape, opening Thursday at the Studio Museum in Harlem, cements the trend with work by 29 artists, including the three mentioned above.

title: Exploding in Unison
description: Sun, by the Hofesh Shechter Company, will let bright light pour down upon chaos. Yet the chaos may still smoke. Mr. Shechter  born in Israel, based in Britain  is known for explosive movements, and they abound in Sun, much of which is performed in unison. The choreography is also influenced by cinematic techniques of montage.

title: How Dare You Take Your Own Life?
description: The rising incidence of suicide among service members and veterans has received considerable attention. A crisis call center for veterans based in Canandaigua, N.Y., is at the forefront of trying to address the problem, and the harrowing work done by operators there is chronicled in Crisis Hotline: Veterans Press 1, a documentary on HBO at 9 p.m. on Monday, Veterans Day.

title: What to Eat With Hard Cider
description: When the air turns brisk, cider is a stunning choice to accompany a weekend lunch. Here, in place of the classic soup and sandwich, you have what amounts to a sandwich floating atop a soup laced with cider. All you need is a salad and dessert.

title: Bill Cunningham | Marathon Colors
description: An overview of the 2013 New York City Marathon, where the idea of a white T-shirt turned into the colors that children would wear.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 8
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Images include New Yorks next mayor, an all-girls golf team and a racetrack upstate.

title: Adam Driver, an Unlikely Face on TV or in Fashion
description: Im like a sight gag, said Adam Driver, who plays the ugly-handsome, so-awful-to-Hannah-hes-catnip bad boyfriend from HBOs Girls.

title: Bill Cunningham | On the Run
description: On the Run A candy shop of color was seen at last weekends New York City Marathon, and at Saturdays international run, top left. Some of Sundays 50,000 runners are seen in 50 photographs in vibrant fall colors.

title: How Hipsters Ruined Paris
description: PARIS  THE northern edge of Pariss Ninth Arrondissement, near the Place Pigalle, was once known as la Nouvelle-Athnes, both for the neo-Classical flourishes of its most graceful blocks and for the creative geniuses who swept in to inhabit them.

title: So, This Is How a Book Moves: Page by Page
description: For her companys return to the Joyce Theater, the Montreal choreographer Marie Chouinard takes inspiration from a book, not bodies. In Henri Michaux: Mouvements, based on a volume by that Belgian poet and artist, Ms. Chouinard sets up a challenging task: to choreograph 64 pages of ink drawings, as well as a 15-page poem and an afterword.

title: All Beethoven, All the Time, in a String Quartet Survey
description: New York has not lacked for complete surveys of Beethovens string quartets in recent years. The Metropolitan Museum of Art alone presented one in each of the last two seasons, by the Pacifica Quartet in 2011-12 and the Endellion String Quartet in 2012-13.

title: President Speaks in New Orleans
description: President Obama talked about the economy and his desire for more spending on major infrastructure projects.

title: Seven Days of Style | Nicolas Ghesquires New Role, Dueling YSL Biopics and the Return of the Pixie Cut
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTURENov. 2  8

title: The Pop-Up Activist of the Lower East Side
description: Eric Ho watches the boom on the Lower East Side, the torrent of new restaurants and boutiques opening, and sees something different. He sees Detroit. Specifically, walking the neighborhood last spring, he saw vacant storefronts  more than 200 of them in the area east of the Bowery and south of 14th Street.

title: Dry Cider, an American Favorite, Rebounds
description: In Paris earlier this year, I stopped for lunch at Breizh Caf in the Marais, a Breton spot that is just about my favorite place to eat crepes. Not only is the food great, but Breizh offers an extraordinary list of dry artisanal ciders, most unavailable in the United States. Its a joy for any cider lover.

title: In Precision Pointwork, Rage and Sadness
description: When its artistic machinery clicks into gear, American Ballet Theater exemplifies three ideals in dance: classicism, dramatic brio and anything by Alexei Ratmansky. The companys program on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater was a stellar tripleheader.

title: How the Internet Has Changed the R.S.V.P.
description: With ease come presumption and murk. Take, for instance, the modern R.S.V.P. The Internet has allowed a host or event producer to painlessly publicize his or her event to sultans and skateboarders in minutes, the digital invitation beaming on their computer screens and cellphones like an onion puff dangling from a stick.

title: CBS Apologizes for Benghazi Report
description: Accounts differ from a man interviewed by 60 Minutes who said he was at the U.S. mission the night of the attack that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

title: Deadly Blast Hits Hotel in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A car loaded with explosives blew up outside one of Mogadishus most expensive hotels Friday evening, leaving what witnesses and officials described as a scene of devastation, burning vehicles and mangled victims. News services said that four to 11 people were killed and scores wounded in the blast, which appeared to be carried out by the Shabab, the militant Islamist insurgent group battling Somalias government.

title: Feels Like Old Brooklyn
description: Newburgh, N.Y., with its grand but neglected architecture, is reminiscent of 1980s Brooklyn, before gentrification. The community is working to revitalize the troubled city.

title: Striking a Rich Vein, of Sorts
description: When youve been rescued from inside a giant shark by a guy with a chain saw, anything is likely to seem anticlimactic. But for the actress who had that honor in Sharknado, Cassie Scerbo, the latest Syfy creature feature, Beast of the Bering Sea, must have seemed especially disappointing.

title: LAllegro at 25
description: Mark Morriss masterwork, which celebrates its 25th anniversary this month, returns to New York as part of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: Still Tingling Spines, After 25 Years
description: Some artistic creations cause immediate sensations, and some create a sense of wonder. With only a very few, however, does that sense of wonder address the entire culture that has produced the work of art. One such piece is Mark Morriss Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato, a full-evening dance work that has almost invariably had a sensational effect on audiences and celebrates its 25th anniversary this month. When it was young, its virtues of innocence, exuberance and abundance amazed many viewers. (Our era can produce this?) In the last two years, I have met other people who have felt the same way after seeing it for the first time.

title: Robert Rhinehart: Dreaming of the Skies and Traveling Light
description: Progress can be slippery to define. After all, one persons progress is another ones transgress. Case in point: Soylent, the food-replacement drink that Robert Rhinehart concocted and has been living on for more than 10 months. The project has sparked enough controversy and raised enough money onCrowdhoster for him to start manufacturing it. (The first shipments are expected to go out next month.)

title: A Soft Spot for G.M.s Bad Old Days
description: Alan Spiegel of Scarsdale, N.Y., knows the reputation of G.M.s woeful front-wheel-drive compacts of the early 1980s. But he cant help but love his Chevy Citation X-11.

title: Revivals Victorian, Gothic and Civic
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.  As Hannah Brooks drove down Liberty Street, she felt the magnetic pull of this city 60 miles north of Manhattan, with its Hudson River views, its architectural masterpieces and its shocking decay. You drive through these damaged areas and you find pockets of these amazing buildings, saidMs. Brooks, who was at the time a resident of Fort Greene, Brooklyn. You can see that theyre crying out to be saved.

title: Chilling Out: Life in a Slow, Cute Lane
description: Its a Saturday morning in autumn, and while other people are outside enjoying the last of the fall foliage or cheering on their kids sports teams, youre sunk down on your couch, watching an Animal Planet program about sloths. Could this picture get any sadder?

title: Merging and Splitting iPhoto Events
description: Merging and Splitting iPhoto Events

title: Poetic Tribute to a Composer
description: Ned Rorem, the composer of poetic art songs and author of sharp-witted essays and diaries, turned 90 last month. He didnt look a day over 70 on Tuesday as he acknowledged, with a wry smile, a standing ovation from the audience at Merkin Concert Hall after an evening-long birthday tribute by the New York Festival of Song. It contained all the key ingredients of his work: a deep poetic sensibility laced with sardonic wit and a romantics receptivity to the sublime in nature parceled into forms that have all the economy of New York apartment living.

title: A Drummer, a Pianist and a Bassist, by Any Name, Find Their Niche
description: The acoustic piano trio continues to be a stable currency in jazz, holding firm against so many other fluctuations. Theres always some attention-grabbing innovation in the field, but its also worth noting when a new trio simply seems to arrive at its own style, having sifted through a preponderance of options. The Colin Stranahan Trio is quietly becoming one of these, as it indicated on Thursday, in the second of two nights at Smalls.

title: Eyewitness Reports After Typhoon in Philippines
description: Updated 3:30 p.m., Nov. 9 Dramatic images and video from local journalists and eyewitnesses show the extent of the damage in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, which  tore through the center of the Philippines on Friday.

title: Art Matters | A Different Kind of Light Show at the Guggenheim
description: James Turrell isnt the only artist who can make the Guggenheim glow. Last Wednesday, for the first night of the 2013 Guggenheim International Gala made possible by Dior, the techno wizard Richie Hawtin brought back his Plastikman persona for one night with a light show that emanated from a cubic tower that rose from the floor of the museums famous rotunda. The event, which this year honored Turrell (whose Aten Reign illuminated the museum all summer) and Christopher Wool (whose career-spanning exhibition is on view now), centered around Hawtins pulsing installation, which gave a nod both to the history of rave culture and to the kinds of cross-genre artworks the museum supports (including the Performa piece by Florian Hecker coming to the museum this very weekend).As Hawtin slid up and down the scales, with pops, zips and plastic sounds, the tower produced synchronized light projections. Luminaries such as Zachary Quinto, Elizabeth Olsen and Zosia Mamet, all dressed in Dior for the event, looked on, transfixed.

title: Bridge Books for Declarers and Duplicate Players
description: Among the popular bridge books reprinted this year are two updated classics: The Secrets of Winning Bridge, by Jeff Rubens (Bridge World Books), and Treasury of Bidding Tips, by Eddie Kantar (Master Point Press).

title: Trotters Legacy: A Legion of Chefs
description: There are two eras in Chicago dining: B.C. and A.C.

title: The Olympics of the Future
description: TOKYO  From the moment in September when Tokyo won the tight race to host the 2020 Summer Olympics, locals have been unleashing ideas  some far-fetched, others tantalizingly imaginable  of what the city will offer the more than 10 million spectators expected to attend the Games.

title: In a Shadow, a Well of Human Pain and Joy
description: There are some seemingly batty elements in Strausss fairy tale opera Die Frau Ohne Schatten (The Woman Without a Shadow), first performed in Vienna in 1919. Even Strauss was somewhat baffled by Hugo von Hofmannsthals libretto. The work has confused many opera lovers as well. There was a noticeable number of empty seats at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night when Herbert Wernickes 2001 production returned for the first time in 10 years.

title: Swooning at Pops Altar
description: The grandiloquent, soupy musical world of the multinational quartet Il Divo conjures a chaste romance-novel fantasy of dashing suitors tearing their hearts off their sleeves to make the ladies at court faint with ecstasy. Pass the smelling salts, please.

title: Where a Camel Can Squeeze Through a Needles Eye
description: When Cyrene, the youngest daughter of Ben and Jewel Tankard, returns from prom on the premiere of Thicker Than Water, she nods at the promise ring on her finger and assures her parents, Im still a virgin.

title: Syrians on Both Sides of the War Increasingly See Assad as Likely to Stay
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A growing number of Syrians on both sides of their countrys conflict, along with regional analysts and would-be mediators, are demanding new strategies to end the civil war, based on what they see as an inescapable new reality: President Bashar al-Assad is staying in office, at least for now.

title: Speaking of the Devil, With Song
description: There was no memorial service for New York City Opera when it recently dissolved after a 70-year run.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: Its a Wrap
description: Among his many haiku-like observations, the skillful genius and soccer philosopher Johan Cruyff once said, They cant beat you, but you can lose to them.

title: Label Updates May Be Allowed for Generics
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed a rule on Friday that would permit generic drug makers to update their labels if they received information about potential safety problems. The move puts the companies on equal footing with brand-name manufacturers, but it also opens the door to lawsuits against them for the first time since the Supreme Court barred such cases two years ago.

title: Three Questions on the Jobs Picture
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Home Depot Apologizes for a Tweet That Offends
description: Home Depot spent much of Thursday and Friday scrambling to apologize after a message sent from the companys primary Twitter account, @HomeDepot, was criticized as racially insensitive.

title: Now, Batistas Shipbuilding Firm to File for Bankruptcy
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The empire of the Brazilian businessman Eike Batista took another hit on Friday, as his shipbuilding firm OSX said it would file for bankruptcy.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 8
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New Yorks next mayor, an all-girls golf team and a racetrack upstate.

title: In a New Role, Ewing Falls to His Old Team
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  From the suspension of J. R. Smith, to the loss of Tyson Chandler with a broken right leg, to a disappointing 1-3 start, the Knicks dramas have started early this season. So it was fitting that an otherwise nondescript November game would offer yet another odd twist to the year.

title: Discussing Costs in the Doctors Office
description: To the Editor:

title: As Universities Evolve
description: To the Editor:

title: Pragmatism on Iran
In College and Foster Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu Pre-Deplores Bad Deal on Irans Nuclear Program
description: As my colleagues Michael Gordon and Mark Landler report, before Secretary of State John Kerry flew to Geneva from Tel Aviv on Friday to try to close an interim nuclear deal with Iran, he met with Israels prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, who made his disapproval of the potential agreement clear to reporters at the airport.

title: Prayers for All Faiths
description: To the Editor:

title: Video: The Fate of Egypts Jon Stewart
description: When Egyptians tuned in last week to watch the satire show Al Bernameg, often called Egypts answer to The Daily Show, they found instead an anchor announcing that the program had been suspended. A statement issued by the channels board said the program had violated its editorial policy.

title: Rhino Horns: a) Increase Potency; b) Cure Cancer; or c) Bring a Prison Term
description: The sport utility vehicle pulled up outside an RV park in Alvarado, Tex., where a homeless man was hanging around, waiting for work doing odd jobs.

title: Spotting Autism in an Infants Gaze
description: A new study suggests that tracking a babys eye movement may lead to earlier autism detection.

title: Why Surveillance Doesnt Faze Britain
description: LONDON  Think of it as the Skyfall session. In a committee room of the House of Commons, the heads of the British secret services appeared on Thursday before a panel of M.P.s in what might have been a re-enactment of that scene from the latest Bond movie  minus the shootout.

title: John Hawk, Hero of Normandy Battle, Dies at 89
description: John Hawk, an Army sergeant in World War II who was awarded the Medal of Honor for a single-handed exploit that led to the capture of more than 500 German troops in northern France in 1944, died on Monday in Bremerton, Wash. He was 89.

title: Central African Republic: Violence Increases Hunger Risk, U.N. Warns
description: United Nations officials on Friday reported new deprivations in the Central African Republic, one of Africas most unstable countries. The World Food Program of the United Nations, which has been feeding 250,000 people in the Central African Republic since January, said in a statement that 1.1 million were at risk of hunger and that their plight could worsen because of poor harvests and economic collapse from political violence. Navi Pillay, the top United Nations human rights official, said fighting between members of the Seleka insurgent organization and self-defense groups had worsened sectarian and communal splits in the country. This escalation of violence and hatred must be halted before it spins completely out of control, she said. The warnings came as Jeffrey D. Feltman, the United Nations under secretary general for political affairs, attended an African Union emergency committee meeting in Bangui, the capital, and urged more cooperation to halt what he called the countrys downward spiral.

title: Venezuela: U.S. Reporter Detained
description: Venezuelan authorities have detained an American journalist working for The Miami Herald, the newspaper said Friday. The journalist, Jim Wyss, was picked up Thursday near the countrys western border with Colombia while reporting on Venezuelas economic problems and coming municipal elections, according to an article on the newspapers website. The article, posted Friday, said Mr. Wyss was being held by military intelligence authorities. Dave Wilson, a senior editor at the newspaper, said it was not clear why Mr. Wyss had been detained. Mr. Wyss is the newspapers Andes region bureau chief and lives in Colombia. An official with the Information Ministry in Caracas said he could not confirm Mr. Wysss detention.

title: California: Co-Founder of Pinkberry Convicted
description: Young Lee, a co-founder of Pinkberry, the frozen yogurt chain, was found guilty Friday of assault with a deadly weapon in the beating of a homeless man. Mr. Lee accused the man, who was panhandling near a freeway ramp in Hollywood in 2011, of disrespecting him by flashing a sexually explicit tattoo, prosecutors said. Mr. Lee beat him with a tire iron, breaking his arm, they said. Mr. Lee, 49, is no longer connected to the chain. He faces up to seven years in prison.

title: With Survey, Vatican Seeks Laity Comment on Family Issues
description: ROME  Often, when the Vatican speaks, it can be a fairly one-sided conversation, issuing encyclicals and other formal documents stating the Roman Catholic Churchs official position on doctrine or other matters.

title: Chrysler and Toyota Announce Recalls
description: Chrysler said it was recalling about 1.2 million Ram trucks in North America to correct problems that could result in a loss of steering, after saying earlier Friday that it will recall 94,000 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokees because of electronic problems that could disable two safety systems. Chrysler said it was aware of seven accidents involving the Rams, resulting in two injuries. The automaker estimated that 453,000 of the trucks would need repairs because the steering systems tie rods were not aligned properly, though it said it would need to recall all 1.2 million trucks to find the flawed vehicles. Meanwhile, Toyota also said it was recalling about 3,800 of its Tacoma pickups from the 2013-14 model years because their 4-cylinder engines could be damaged and possibly stop running.

title: As City Hall Changes Hands, Construction Will Go On
description: A new tenant will move into the mayors office in January for the first time in 12 years and will have plenty of headaches to deal with  a looming budget deficit, being one. He may also want to pack a hard hat.

title: Friday Night Music: San Fermin
description: Many thanks to the commenter who pointed me to this band  also featured on an NPR Tiny Desk Concert.

title: The Russians Are Coming!
description: The eponymous heroine of Gaetano Donizettis opera Lucrezia Borgia had just died, and the final notes of music had barely faded into the November night when hundreds of workers began to transform New York Citys Academy of Music. Less than 24 hours later, the 4,000-seat entertainment emporium  an opera house, theater, and meeting and exposition hall, all under one roof  was to host the social event of the 1863 season. The citys elite had quickly snapped up 2,000 tickets for the Soire Russe: a grand ball for the officers of the Russian fleet at anchor in New York.

title: Walter H. Stern, Who Coined the Term Fiscal Cliff, Dies at 88
description: Fiscal Cliff, n.

title: Right Wings Surge in Europe Has the Establishment Rattled
description: HVIDOVRE, Denmark  As right-wing populists surge across Europe, rattling established political parties with their hostility toward immigration, austerity and the European Union, Mikkel Dencker of the Danish Peoples Party has found yet another cause to stir public anger: pork meatballs missing from kindergartens.

title: SAC Pleads Guilty, Then Judge Calls a Timeout
description: After spending the better part of a decade fighting a federal insider trading investigation, SAC Capital Advisors must wait a few extra months for closure.

title: In a Helping Profession, She Needed Help, Too
description: The Georgia heat that Bernice Porterfield had endured for more than 30 years did not compare to the furnace-like temperatures of a New York City apartment without air-conditioning in the summer.

title: As Tensions Fall in Iran, So Do Costs of Gasoline
description: HOUSTON  Gasoline prices are tumbling just in time for the holiday shopping season to begin.

title: Mormons Offer Cautionary Lesson on Sunny Outlook vs. Literary Greatness
description: In 1888, speaking about the possibility of Mormon literature, the church leader Orson F. Whitney made an audacious promise to his fellow Mormons: We will yet have Miltons and Shakespeares of our own. Yet 125 years later, there is no Mormon Milton. There is no Mormon Milosz, no Mormon Munro.

title: Politically Adrift, Algeria Clings to Its Old Ways
description: ALGIERS  Algeria seems stuck in a state of limbo.

title: Bidders Cry Foul Over Auction of Banksy Painting
description: The elusive street artist known as Banksy grabbed headlines on Halloween when a painting he donated to a New York charity sold online for $615,000.

title: Prayers in Little Manila as a Typhoon Hits Home
description: At Krystals Cafe and Pastry Shop, a Filipino restaurant in Woodside, Queens, customers tucked into heaping platters of fish called sinigang na bangus, or pulled strips of pork off a Flintstones-size bone known as crispy pata. The very ordinariness of the Friday afternoon in the area known as Little Manila, where many of New York Citys more than 13,000 Filipinos live, underscored for some just how far they were from their homeland.

title: Dan Lurie, 90, Star and Promoter of Bodybuilding, Dies
description: Dan Lurie, whose chiseled physique and feats of strength earned him the title of Americas most muscular man and made him a cover model for fitness magazines and a walking promoter for both the sport and the business of bodybuilding, died on Wednesday in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 90.

title: Lottery Numbers
Saturdays College Football Games to Watch
description: 10 L.S.U. at 1 ALABAMA

title: Era Fades for Helping Hand at the Washroom Sink
description: However you look at it, its a rather static life. All night long cooped up in the bathroom. Turn on the tap, squirt some soap, pass over a hand towel, offer a mint or a stick of gum, maybe suggest a dash of cologne  or would you like some dental floss? Then tidy up the sink, scoop up any trash or worse from the floor.

title: Immigration Vote Unlikely This Year, Lawmaker Says
description: A top Republican lawmaker told protesters he met with in his home district in California this week that the House of Representatives would not have time this year to vote on any immigration measure.

title: Candid Criticism for Fed That Wasnt on the Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  It started off as yet another staid International Monetary Fund conference on financial crises, filled with ample praise for one of its high-wattage speakers, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, and carefully calibrated comments on optimal monetary policy.

title: On Iran, Netanyahu Can Only Fume
description: JERUSALEM  Incensed by the prospect of an interim deal that would ease some sanctions against Iran during negotiations over its nuclear program, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is doing what he is best known for, and perhaps best at: He is speaking out, in strident tones, despite the inevitable discomfort for a high-profile guest from Washington.

title: Detective Admits Spying on Colleagues
description: A New York City police detective pleaded guilty on Friday to arranging to hack into dozens of email accounts and gaining access to a federal law enforcement database to gather information on his colleagues, said Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.

title: A Prosecutor Is Punished
description: For what may be the first time on record, a former prosecutor in Texas is going to jail for failing to turn over exculpatory evidence in a murder trial. The 10-day jail sentence for the prosecutor, Ken Anderson, is insultingly short  the victim of his misconduct, Michael Morton, spent nearly 25 years in prison. But because prosecutors are so rarely held accountable for their misconduct, the sentence is remarkable nonetheless.

title: What Greece Cannot Afford
description: Greek society and the economy cannot afford any more measures, Prime Minister Antonis Samaras said on Monday. There is no room or need for any more across-the-board wage and pension cuts, he declared.

title: The Wrong Way to Save a Forest
description: In July 1995, President Bill Clinton, in a moment of weakness he later regretted, signed a budget bill containing a rider allowing timber companies to conduct so-called salvage logging in areas burned by forest fires. The measure, advertised as necessary to forest health, would in fact have allowed indiscriminate logging and caused widespread environmental damage. It took a year of protests, court battles and legislative wrangling to undo it.

title: Equal Coverage for the Mentally Ill
description: A struggle over decades to force insurers to cover mental health and addiction services on the same basis as medical and surgical costs is headed for success under new rules issued on Friday by the Obama administration. The rules will cover most Americans with health insurance, including those in many employer-sponsored plans, in other group plans, in some but not all Medicaid plans, and in policies bought on the individual markets.

title: Prized for His Aggression, Incognito Struggled to Stay in Bounds
description: He was a timid Little Leaguer teased by opponents and belittled by teammates. He was mocked for being pudgy and gentler than the other boys, even though he was bigger than most of them.

title: When a Gun Advocate Dissents
description: Its not as if Dick Metcalf was some kind of gun control fanatic.

title: Detroit Bankruptcy Case Turns on Issue of Good Faith
description: DETROIT  The Detroit bankruptcy trial ended on Friday, after nine days of emotional and often heated testimony that raised questions about whether the city is insolvent and whether city and state officials gave creditors a fair chance to negotiate their debts before Detroit filed for Chapter 9 protection in July.

title: Before Global Games, Rio Is Fighting to Dim Red Light
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In the frenzy to prepare this city for its big moment as host of next years World Cup and the 2016 Summer Olympics, the authorities are razing slums, upgrading stadiums and shuttering some of the citys red-light emporiums, hoping to present a cleaned-up image of Brazils sexiest metropolis.

title: Consumer Watchdog Takes Up Debt Collection
description: IF you have had a bad experience with a debt collector, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to hear from you. The bureau said this week it was getting ready to update rules governing how debt collectors may communicate with borrowers.

title: Missing the Bad Old Days
description: Its been a tough week. Lets take a break and discuss the catfish inspection program.

title: For Rent: Fixer-Uppers in a National Park
description: SANDY HOOK, N.J.  The National Park Service put out an unusual for-rent sign last month: 35 historic buildings, including the genteel quarters of lieutenants and captains, at a wind-swept former Army base overlooking Sandy Hook Bay. The only catch: the structures are serious fixer-uppers.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 9, 2013
description: They really are a throwback to another era. Like a hatcheck girl. Who wears a hat anymore? What are you going to do  check your Yankees baseball cap?

title: Editors Note: November 9, 2013
description: ARTS & LEISURE

title: One Way to Stand
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  This was a nice, tight puzzle that solved in a very businesslike way for me. Until 1 Across fell, of course. Then I laughed out loud. BUTT-DIALED is a new one for the New York Times puzzle archives, as you might have guessed. And that was quite a punny clue. Well find out more about how that came about in Michael Ashleys notes.

title: Bloomberg News Is Said to Curb Articles That Might Anger China
description: BEIJING  The decision came in an early evening call to four journalists huddled in a Hong Kong conference room. On the line 12 time zones away in New York was their boss, Matthew Winkler, the longtime editor in chief of Bloomberg News. And they were frustrated by what he was telling them.

title: Gay Marriage Battle Nears End in Hawaii, the First Front Line
description: HONOLULU  When, as most everyone expects, Gov. Neil Abercrombie signs into law same-sex marriage here in the coming days, it may almost seem like a routine event. Hawaii is poised to be among 16 states to approve gay marriage, along with Illinois and shortly after Minnesota, New Jersey and Rhode Island.

title: Animated Take on Bloombergs Coverage of China
description: On Friday evening, Next Media Animation posted to the Internet its unique take on the emerging conflict at Bloomberg News over two ill-fated investigative stories about China. Both examine Chinese leaders and businesspeople and were written by veteran reporters in Hong Kong. Some Bloomberg employees say that senior editors in New York, led by Matthew Winkler, the longtime editor-in-chief, have barred the stories from publication to ensure that Bloomberg has access in China. Bloomberg has come under fire from Communist Party officials since it published a prize-winning investigative series last year on the family wealth of Chinese leaders, including that of Xi Jinping, the new party chief.

title: Executions Stall as States Seek Different Drugs
description: HOUSTON  Florida ran out of its primary lethal-injection drug last month and relied on a new drug that no state had ever used for an execution. At Ohios next scheduled execution, the state is planning to use a two-drug combination for the first time. Last month in Texas, Michael Yowell became that states first inmate executed using a drug made by a lightly regulated pharmacy that usually produces customized medications for individual patients.

title: 11 Motorcyclists Are Indicted in Assault on an S.U.V. Driver
description: Eleven motorcyclists, including an undercover New York police detective, have been indicted in connection with the assault on a man who was driving a Range Rover with his wife and infant son on the Henry Hudson Parkway, the Manhattan district attorneys office announced on Friday.

title: Contracting Case Implicates 2 Admirals
description: WASHINGTON  Two United States admirals, including the Navys chief intelligence officer, were stripped of their access to classified information on Friday after being implicated in a contracting scandal that federal prosecutors are investigating in San Diego.

title: In Puerto Rico, but Unable to Leave New York Behind
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  It would have been easy to be fooled by the sun and sand, the tropical drinks and the men in bathing suits playing cards on the beach, and think that New Yorks politicos were simply unwinding after a marathon election season.

title: Nets, Sloppy Again, Fall to the Wizards
description: WASHINGTON  The Nets victory over the Utah Jazz on Tuesday night was cast as a learning experience, a redemptive triumph that would erase the bad taste left from a blowout loss on Sunday against the Orlando Magic. It would represent a turning point, they said, a move away from avoidable mistakes.

title: In Sandy Hook Bay, an Unusual Opportunity
description: The National Park Service is looking for tenants for 35 historic buildings at Fort Hancock that can invest in the structures in order to save them.

title: Cuts in Hospital Subsidies Threaten Safety-Net Care
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  The uninsured pour into Memorial Health hospital here: the waitress with cancer in her voice box who for two years assumed she just had a sore throat. The unemployed diabetic with a wound stretching the length of her shin. The construction worker who could no longer breathe on his own after weeks of untreated asthma attacks and had to be put on a respirator.

title: UConn Survives Maryland and Renews Title Pursuit
description: Shabazz Napier was one of the last Connecticut players to leave the floor at Barclays Center on Friday night, and a fan wearing a fuzzy-eared Huskies hat stopped him before he did.

title: Yankees Bring Back Coaches
description: When the Yankees failed to make the playoffs this year for the first time since 2008, the finger of blame did not fall on the front office, because ownership felt the staggering list of injuries was the problem, not the decision makers.

title: Down but Not Out, a Polarizing Mayor Concedes Nothing
description: LAWRENCE, Mass.  To some in this worn former mill town, Mayor William Lantigua is an ebullient man of the people, an old-style ward politician who can fix your streets and clear them of trash. To others, he is the incubator of political scandal, shaming a city already struggling with crises over schools and finances. Half the city loves him, half the city cant stand him.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Macys renovates its flagship store in Manhattan, a shipbuilder cuts 1,800 shipbuilding jobs in Britain and Twitters stock starts trading in New York.

title: Bobby Thomason, Pro Bowl Quarterback, Dies at 85
description: Bobby Thomason, a three-time Pro Bowler who in 1953 became the first Philadelphia Eagles quarterback to pass for more than 400 yards in a game, died on Tuesday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 85.

title: Philippine Typhoon Death Toll Feared in Thousands
description: MANILA  The powerful typhoon that swept across the Philippines on Friday, one of the strongest storms ever to make landfall, cut a path of destruction through several central islands, leaving the seaside city of Tacloban in ruins and leading to early, unconfirmed estimates of as many as 10,000 dead.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (CUNY) THE SCENT OF GREEN PAPAYA (1993) In this first installment of Contemporary French Film, a five-movie series, the director Tran Anh Hung follows Mui (played by Lu Man San as a child; by Tran Nu Yen-Khe, left, as a woman), a 10-year-old servant for an affluent family in 1950s Vietnam, across a decade as she falls in love with a handsome pianist she has admired since childhood. The Scent of the Green Papaya marks a luxuriant, visually seductive debut for Mr. Hung, whose film is often so wordlessly evocative that it barely needs dialogue, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Reaching into the past for its precisely drawn memories, it casts a rich, delicate spell. Afterward, Jerry Carlson, the host of City Cinematheque, interviews La Frances Hui, the film curator for Asia Society New York.

title: Portrait of Deng as Reformer in 1978 Plenum Ignores History
description: Chinas Communist Party leader, Xi Jinping, wants the late Deng Xiaopings magic. Mr. Xi will lay out proposals for economic rejuvenation at a leadership conference that started Saturday, and state-run media have likened the event to a historic meeting in 1978 when, they say, Mr. Deng began an era of market reform and opening up.

title: The Sex Toys in the Attic
description: Ive been thinking about an extremely beautiful sex toy an old boyfriend got me  I think it is on my mind because he is having heart surgery this week. This is how it is at a certain age; when you hear about an old boyfriend its not because he got married or got a great job, it is because theyre threading tubes into his chest and doing an ablation on his heart.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Gents Cashmere Cap
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Talks With Iran Fail to Produce a Nuclear Agreement
description: GENEVA  Marathon talks between major powers and Iran failed on Sunday to produce a deal to freeze its nuclear program, puncturing days of feverish anticipation and underscoring how hard it will be to forge a lasting solution to Irans nuclear ambitions.

title: Non-Crisis France
description: A few people have asked a pretty good question, albeit in fairly belligerent tones: How can I say that France isnt doing too badly, when I also say that the euro has been such a problem?

title: My Head Talks Actual Economics
description: Aha. The IMF has now posted video of the entire Jacques Polak research conference. If you scroll down on the right to the Mundell-Fleming lecture, you can see me in action. But Id recommend some of the other material too, especially the tribute to Stan Fischer.

title: A Founder of Twitter Goes Long
description: Between downtown San Francisco and the new Twitter offices six city blocks to the west, things get sketchy. There is a strip club, a budget motel with weekly rates and, on the gentrified edge of this no-mans land, the offices of Medium, the new venture of Evan Williams, one of Twitters co-founders.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mario and the Austerians
description: Just an obvious point that Im not sure enough people have been making: Mario Draghis surprise rate cut is, in effect, a repudiation of the nascent triumphalism of Europes austerians.

title: Reporter for Reuters Wont Receive China Visa
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government has rejected the visa application of a veteran American journalist who had been waiting eight months to begin a new reporting job in China for Thomson Reuters, the company said.

title: Giants Defensive Revival Coincides With Their Opponents Woes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A defense stung by lapses and backbreaking plays when the Giants dropped their first six games has not allowed a touchdown in the last 10 quarters, a turnaround that defies easy explanation entering Sundays home game against the Oakland Raiders.

title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  One of the things I love about Split Decisions is that they are both easy and maddeningly hard at the same time.

title: Mets Alderson Can Finally Spend, Assuming He Wants To
description: For three years, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson has tried building a roster on a limited budget. At a clear disadvantage, he faced small expectations, as if batting with one hand tied behind his back and staring at Matt Harvey on the mound. He had to take a few weak swings and hope for the best, until more money came off the books.

title: Transition Begins in Boston, for First Time in a Generation
description: BOSTON  With the election last week of Martin J. Walsh as mayor, Boston is poised to break out of the mold cast by Mayor Thomas M. Menino, who has thoroughly dominated the city and its government during his 20-year tenure, the longest in the citys history.

title: Bernard Tyson of Kaiser Permanente, on Speaking Your Mind
description: This interview with  Bernard J. Tyson, chief executive of Kaiser Permanente, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Maldives Court Orders Another Delay After Presidential Vote Sets Up Runoff
description: NEW DELHI  A third attempt to hold a presidential election in the tiny Indian Ocean nation of Maldives was thrown off course early Sunday, after an order from the Supreme Court delayed a runoff scheduled for that day.

title: More Notes On France-Bashing
description: First things first: France has problems. Unemployment is high, especially among young people, many small businesses are struggling, the population is aging (although not nearly as much as in many other countries, Germany very much included.)

title: N.F.L. Coaches: In Charge and at Risk
description: The day before he had emergency quadruple-bypass surgery in 1998, Dan Reeves relayed his symptoms  accelerated, burning sensations in his chest and throat  and asked his doctor if a checkup could wait until after the N.F.L. season.

title: They Loved Your G.P.A. Then They Saw Your Tweets.
description: At Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., admissions officers are still talking about the high school senior who attended a campus information session last year for prospective students. Throughout the presentation, she apparently posted disparaging comments on Twitter about her fellow attendees, repeatedly using a common expletive.

title: What Sets Spurs Apart Is Lost on Knicks
description: Once every season, the San Antonio Spurs visit Madison Square Garden  as they are scheduled to do Sunday afternoon  to remind the Knicks, in a larger contextual sense, of everything they are not. And that is not good.

title: Good Deals on Pills? Its Anyones Guess
description: THIS month, a dysfunctional website stymied hundreds of thousands of Americans trying to check out new health insurance options under the Affordable Care Act. But that embarrassing technical glitch may have masked a more fundamental question: Can Americans shop effectively for health care?

title: Powerful Typhoon Causes Devastation in Philippines
description: A deadly storm left the seaside city of Tacloban in ruins.

title: For Grieving Mother, Many More Challenges
description: Please dont tell Ena Griffin that heaven needed another angel.

title: Earnings, but Without the Bad Stuff
description: Twitters red-hot stock offering last week makes clear that, as in the first Internet bubble, investors will pay up for a company even if it hasnt turned a profit.

title: The Co-Villains Behind Obesitys Rise
description: Why is obesity soaring? The answer seems pretty clear. In 1955, a standard soda at McDonalds was only seven ounces. Today, a medium is three times as large, and even a childs-size version is 12 ounces. Its a widely held view that obesity is a consequence of our behaviors, and that behavioral economics thus plays a central role in understanding it  with markets, preferences and choices taking center stage. As a behavioral economist, I subscribed to that view  until recently, when I began to question my thinking.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 10
description: We take responsibility for the handful of men who pleaded guilty and whose conduct gave rise to SACs liability.

title: Casinos and the Economy
Dolphins, a Franchise Under Fire, Now Under a Microscope
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Some days, the Miami Dolphins owner, Stephen Ross, must wonder why he bought the team.

title: Work Up a Sweat, and Bargain Better
description: If better health isnt enough incentive to take a brisk walk, perhaps there is another one: it may get you a better deal.

title: Mug-Shot Websites, Retreating or Adapting
description: In this episode, a pair of updates.

title: Embracing the Millennials Mind-Set at Work
description: Are millennials  those born from roughly 1980 to 2000  about to fundamentally change companies for the better? Yes, if companies dare to listen.

title: Sunday Dialogue: How the Justices Shape Our Democracy
description: Readers discuss how court rulings have changed U.S. politics.

title: My Kingdom for an English Course!
description: His university had 394 English majors last year, down from 501 when he arrived in 1984, but Professor Edmundson said he does not fret about the future. In the end, we cant lose, he said. We have William Shakespeare.

title: Flyers Riverton Rifle Content to Give His Coach the Glory
description: Reggie Leach was setting out from his home on an island in Lake Huron to meet his teammates from the Stanley Cup-winning 1974 and 75 Philadelphia Flyers this weekend in Toronto, where their coach, Fred Shero, will be inducted posthumously into the Hockey Hall of Fame.

title: Week 10 Matchup: Raiders (3-5) at Giants (2-6)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Goodbyes With Respect
Spurs and Knicks: Proud Era vs. Loud Errors
description: Since Tim Duncan joined San Antonio as a rookie for the 1997-98 season, the team has been a model of success and stability. During that period, the Knicks have often been a dysfunctional mess. The teams did meet in the 1999 N.B.A. finals, with the Spurs winning in five games, but for the most part the two clubs have gone distinctly separate ways.

title: The Death of Letter-Writing
description: In recent years, a number of journalists and critics have lamented the death of the literary letter. The publication of Saul Bellows letters in 2010 and William Styrons last year were accompanied by waves of speculation about how many more such collections we can expect. There was also no small amount of hand-wringing about how The Collected Emails of Dave Eggers (or whomever) will never cast quite the same spell.

title: The 21st Century Silver Spoon
description: In 1899, the sociologist Thorstein Veblen scathingly critiqued what he called the conspicuous consumption of Americas upper class. The rich were so obsessed with their social status, he wrote, that they would go to gratuitous lengths to signal it. His famous example was silver flatware: handcrafted silver spoons, though no more serviceable than and hardly distinguishable from aluminum ones, conferred high social rank and signaled membership in what he called the leisure class.

title: The Mets Frank Francisco Fiasco
description: Until now, Sandy Alderson has spent little money on free agents as general manager of the Mets, for the most part because he did not have the money to spend. The biggest free-agent contract he has approved to date with the Mets was the two-year, $12 million deal he gave to Frank Francisco in December 2011. Francisco did not pitch particularly well  he had his highest earned run average in the majors in his first year as a Met  and then he got hurt.

title: Alfre Woodard
description: Alfre Woodard has been a familiar face on stage, film and television since the 1980s. She plays Mistress Harriet Shaw in 12 Years a Slave, which opened in theaters nationwide this weekend.

title: Why I (Still) Support Obamacare
description: AT the recent New York Times forum in Singapore, Eleonora Sharef, a co-founder of HireArt, was explaining what new skills employers were seeking from job applicants, but she really got the audiences attention when she mentioned that her search firm was recently told by one employer that it wouldnt look at any applicant for a marketing job who didnt have at least 2,000 Twitter followers  and the more the better. She didnt disclose the name of the firm, but she told me that it wasnt Twitter.

title: Lessons in a Surveillance Drama Redux
description: IT was almost eight years ago that The Times published a blockbuster story by James Risen and Eric Lichtblau about a secret Bush administration program to eavesdrop on Americans without warrants. But for many Times readers, it still resonates deeply.

title: Funny Girl
description: HOLLYWOOD  AS Hollywood bowed down to Hillary Clinton, who swept through on a state visit with Chelsea on Friday, there seemed to be only one person here with any reservations.

title: A Cure for the Allergy Epidemic?
description: WILL the cure for allergies come from the cowshed?

title: After Mental Illness, an Up and Down Life
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  IN 2005, a distraught mother rushed her 13-year-old son to the emergency room for a psychiatric evaluation. The boy was overwrought, consumed by anxiety. The physicians asked the standard questions: Did he want to kill or hurt himself or others? No, was his answer.

title: Is It O.K. to Kill Cyclists?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  EVERYBODY who knows me knows that I love cycling and that Im also completely freaked out by it. I got into the sport for middle-aged reasons: fat; creaky knees; the delusional vanity of tight shorts. Registering for a triathlon, I took my first ride in decades. Wind in my hair, smile on my face, I decided instantly that I would bike everywhere like all those beautiful hipster kids on fixies. Within minutes, however, I watched an S.U.V. hit another cyclist, and then I got my own front wheel stuck in a streetcar track, sending me to the pavement.

title: Violence, Greed and the Gridiron
description: WHILE Tony Dorsett described the collision, CNN played the footage, from 1984.

title: Oklahoma! Where the Kids Learn Early
description: TULSA, Okla.  LIBERALS dont expect Oklahoma to serve as a model of social policy. But, astonishingly, we can see in this reddest of red states a terrific example of what the United States can achieve in early education.

title: Fear of the Dark
description: TWO years ago, the first time the government and the utility industry held an emergency drill to simulate a cyberattack on the nations power grid, 75 agencies and utilities showed up. For a second drill next week, organizers are expecting more than 200.

title: Treasure Hunters of the Financial Crisis
description: Five years ago, the global financial system was falling apart. Lehman Brothers had imploded. Banks had stopped lending. Foreclosure signs were as common as weeds on the front lawns of suburban homes.

title: Kenya and the International Criminal Court
description: Two Kenyan leaders charged with crimes against humanity have retaliated with an all-out attack on the International Criminal Court. Although Kenya is a court member, and President Uhuru Kenyatta and Deputy President William Ruto have agreed to cooperate, they are doing everything they can to discredit the institution by accusing it of racial bias and of being a Western tool.

title: Reality Sets In
description: For about a decade, American military commanders leading the fight against Al Qaeda, the Taliban and Saddam Hussein had a blank check from Congress to buy whatever weapons and other supplies they needed. Now, the Pentagon is being forced to live with less in a new era of fiscal austerity.

title: Still Dangerous
description: Five years ago, when the economy imploded, the world learned that the global financial system was, in part, a casino built on derivatives, complex instruments that are supposed to reduce risk but are instead widely used by banks and other big investors for speculation. Since then, new rules have been created to rein in derivatives through transparency, oversight and competition. Issued by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the agency empowered by the Dodd-Frank reform law to regulate most derivatives, the rules could indeed make the system safer, if they are aggressively enforced.

title: The Other Paris, Beyond the Boulevards
description: PANTIN, France  I live just outside Paris, beyond the Priphrique, the eternally clogged ring road that separates the City of Light from its suburban areas of darkness. My neighborhood is in Pantin, where the infamous northeastern suburbs  the banlieues  begin. When I told one Parisian where I lived during casual chatter at a dinner party in the chic Marais quarter, he actually stepped away from me and blurted: Quelle horreur! But it isnt a horrible place. And its where, for better or worse, a new France is being forged.

title: Dear Governor Christie
description: I KNOW, governor, I know: Its still too early for presidential speculation, youre just focused on the job at hand and any talk of 2016, while flattering, is purely hypothetical.

title: How I Helped Teachers Cheat
description: FROM 2001 to 2010, I worked as an academic ghostwriter, helping students cheat in college and grad school. Inevitably, over a decade there were a few unsatisfied customers.

title: Manfred Rommel, Son of German Field Marshal, Dies at 84
description: Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was a hero of Hitlers Germany, the legendary Desert Fox who seized the worlds attention with his daring tactics in North Africa from 1941 to 1943.

title: Civility Need Not Be Excluded From the Culture of the N.F.L.
description: As the situation with the Miami Dolphins was escalating, Calvin Hill recalled the rigors of his N.F.L. rookie-hood, and not with particular fondness.

title: New York City Asks Court to Vacate Rulings on Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
description: The Bloomberg administration, in its most aggressive push yet to erase the stain of a judges rulings on police stop-and-frisk practices, asked a federal appeals court on Saturday to vacate her decisions, which had ordered sweeping changes including the appointment of a monitor.

title: The Oklahoma Model for American Pre-K
description: As readers know, one of my hobby horses is the need for early childhood education as the most cost-effective way to break the cycles of poverty in America. But the issue never gets much traction, and one reason is the perception that its politically hopeless: Republicans would never go for such a program. My Sunday column tries to push back at the assumption that its hopeless and notes that one of the leaders in providing pre-K in America isnot Massachusetts, not New York, not some other blue state, but reliably red Oklahoma. Its all the more surprising because Oklahoma spends less per pupil on education than almost any other state, and pays its teachers near the bottom. This is not a state that believes in lavish spending on schooling. Yet, quite remarkably, it provides universal high-quality pre-K, with a ratio of no more than 10 students per staff member, and all teachers have a college degree.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 10
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey handily won re-election on Tuesday, and will continue his victory lap with an appearance on four of this weeks Sunday shows. Some Republicans are looking to the governor as the future of their party, especially after such a strong win in a Democratic state.

title: Bye-Lines
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Sometimes what you need on a Sunday is a nice, mellow solve, and this puzzle by Alan Olschwang fits the bill. No big surprises, not too hard, and a theme that falls fairly easily if you know the speakers of these exit lines. Even if you dont, the crossings are kind, and the Bye-Lines are easy to solve.

title: New China Cities: Shoddy Homes, Broken Hope
description: HUAMING, China  Three years ago, the Shanghai World Expo featured this newly built town as a model for how China would move from being a land of farms to a land of cities. In a dazzling pavilion visited by more than a million people, visitors learned how farmers were being given a new life through a fair-and-square deal that did not cost them anything.

title: Dissatisfaction and Dysfunction in a Model for Chinas Urbanization
description: As China pushes ahead with government-led urbanization, Huaming might be an example of another transformation: the ghettoization of Chinas new towns.

title: Hawaii Nears Approval of Gay Marriage
description: HONOLULU  The State House of Representatives passed a bill late Friday to legalize same-sex marriage, all but ensuring that Hawaii will soon join 15 other states and the District of Columbia in allowing gay couples to wed.

title: Texas Youth Is Named M.V.P. of American League
description: When the United States Chess League began playing in 2005, there were eight teams  and some basic questions. Would the league be able to keep itself afloat financially? And would enough elite players participate to make it a success?

title: Richard Witkin, 95, Witness to the History of Aviation, Dies
description: Richard Witkin, a longtime aviation reporter for The New York Times who shared a Pulitzer Prize in 1987 for coverage of the Challenger space shuttle disaster, died on Thursday in Marlborough, Mass. He was 95.

title: Obamas Portable Zone of Secrecy (Some Assembly Required)
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama travels abroad, his staff packs briefing books, gifts for foreign leaders and something more closely associated with camping than diplomacy: a tent.

title: Priceless Moment for Pirates, but $632,500 for the Uniform
description: For more than a half-century, Bill Mazeroski kept the Pittsburgh Pirates uniform he wore when he hit the home run to win the 1960 World Series in a cedar chest in his Pennsylvania home. He opened it once to make sure moths had not eaten through it. This year, Mazeroski decided to sell it and other memorabilia.

title: Aided by Army of Vapers, E-Cigarette Industry Woos and Wins Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Facing a decision on whether to impose tight restrictions on a booming market for electronic cigarettes, members of the European Parliament received a pleading letter in September that was signed by thousands of former smokers worried that the positive story of e-cigarettes may be about to come to an abrupt halt.

title: Elderly Womans Killing Lays Bare Myanmars Religious Divisions
description: THABYU CHAING, Myanmar  Paralyzed from the waist down, Daw Aye Kyi was too heavy for her daughter and granddaughter to carry into the surrounding jungle when a Buddhist mob stormed through this rice-farming village hunting for Muslims.

title: Tours Open at the Penitentiary of New Mexico
description: In 36 hours, 33 inmates were killed and more than 200 were injured in February 1980.

title: For Riot Site in New Mexico, a Gift Shop but No Ghost Stories
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  When it came time to organize the celebrations for New Mexicos centennial last year, Gov. Susana Martinez turned to the members of her cabinet for suggestions. The Corrections Department secretary, Gregg Marcantel, a burly former Marine just months into the job, was stumped. What could the states troubled prison system, faced with a high rate of recidivism and drastic budget cuts, possibly have to offer?

title: Debating a New Pope, Faith and Doctrine
description: Some American Catholics in the churchs conservative wing say Pope Francis has left them feeling abandoned and deeply unsettled.

title: Conservative U.S. Catholics Feel Left Out of the Popes Embrace
description: SMYRNA, Ga.  When Pope Francis was elected in March, Bridget Kurt received a small prayer card with his picture at her church and put it up on her refrigerator at home, next to pictures of her friends and her favorite saints.

title: Storied Party of Mandela Faces South Africa Unrest
description: MARIKANA, South Africa  When Alton Dalasile got his first job as a miner in the late 1980s, he immediately joined the National Union of Mineworkers, a powerful organization that not only fought for workers rights but also battled the brutal system of racial segregation known as apartheid. When his unions political ally, the African National Congress, was on the ballot in 1994 in South Africas first fully democratic election, Mr. Dalasile enthusiastically cast his ballot for Nelson Mandela, the countrys first black president.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 9, 2013
Venezuela Releases U.S. Journalist After 2 Days
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The Venezuelan authorities on Saturday released an American journalist who had been detained and questioned by military intelligence officials.

title: Corrections: November 10, 2013
description: SPORTS

title: Con Men Prey on Confusion Over Health Care Act
description: To the list of problems plaguing President Obamas health care law, add one more  fraud.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: AARON MURRAY The Georgia quarterback threw for two touchdowns in a 45-6 home win over Appalachian State. He became the Southeastern Conference career leader in touchdown passes, with 115. Danny Wuerffel had 114.

title: A Portfolio of Celebrated Characters
description: Jack Mitchells photographs captured a history of the arts in the late 20th century.

title: As Washington Keeps Sinking, Governors Rise
description: LOS ANGELES  Washington these days is the symbol of governmental failure, rocked by a shutdown, legislative paralysis and the disastrous debut of President Obamas health care program. Public opinion of Mr. Obama and members of Congress is on a steady decline.

title: Jack Mitchell, Photographer of the Arts, Dies at 88
