title: A Clash Over Bill Clinton?
After Clashes With Saudis, Laborers Opt to Go Home
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of foreign laborers turned themselves over to the authorities in Saudi Arabia on Sunday to be sent to their home countries after a night of protests and clashes in which one foreigner and one Saudi were killed.

title: Bystanders Shot by the Police Face an Uphill Fight to Win Lawsuits
description: Outside the Empire State Building in Midtown one mild morning in the summer of 2012, the crowd consisted of tourists and office workers  and a solitary gunman who was fleeing the site of a murder. As the police closed in, the gunman drew his .45-caliber handgun, and two officers opened fire, discharging 16 shots in all.

title: The Greatest President
description: Representations in textbooks, news reports and other media, along with the passing of generations, have influenced views of United States presidents over time.

title: Heartache To a Beat, Or Several
description: Inexorable beats and looming heartache fill the songs of Polica, a band from Minneapolis that performed at Webster Hall on Friday night. Its music opens up wide spaces to expose tidings of desire, separation, longing, bitterness and resolve: breakup songs that absolve no one.

title: No Quick Fixes for Chinas Overwhelmed Organ Transplant System
description: Suffering from bile duct cancer and with no family to support him and little money for treatment, Xu Bao, 35, vowed that if he suffered an early death he would give something back to society. He decided that he would donate his corneas to fellow Chinese waiting for transplants.

title: A Brazilian Boom Town of Eternal Beauty Faces Its Troubled Side
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  Baroque architectural gems grace this city. Musicians enthrall audiences with high-octane performances reflecting Salvadors status as a bastion of Brazils popular culture. Luxury residential towers overlook a stunning harbor. The industrial park on the citys outskirts contains cutting-edge plants opened by Ford and other multinational corporations.

title: Nitro Circus, Extreme Athletics Brand, to Merge With Touring Company
description: One of the highlights of any Nitro Circus show comes when Aaron Fotheringham, an extreme wheelchair athlete, careers down the megaramp and does a double back flip in midair, landing 50 feet away.

title: Removing Fuel Rods Poses New Risks at Crippled Nuclear Plant in Japan
description: TOKYO  It was the part of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant that spooked American officials the most, as the complex spiraled out of control two and a half years ago: the spent fuel pool at Reactor No. 4, with more than 1,500 radioactive fuel assemblies left exposed when a hydrogen explosion blew the roof off the building.

title: Using Humor to Talk About Birth Control
description: FEW things may be less comfortable to talk about with ones parents than sex and birth control, and with that in mind, a new public service campaign hopes to offer guidance through a series of ads and online videos.

title: News From the Advertising Industry for the Week of Nov. 11
description: Accounts

title: Chinas President Steps Boldly Backward
description: When it comes to acting on pledges for economic and political reform, President Xi Jinping displays a confusing agility.

title: Big Datas Little Brother
description: SAN FRANCISCO  David Soloff is recruiting an army of hyperdata collectors.

title: Storm Track Veers Away From Vietnam
description: After plowing through the Philippines, Typhoon Haiyan took a right turn over the South China Sea on Sunday, avoiding the central coast of Vietnam, where hundreds of thousands of people had been evacuated to emergency shelters. Instead, it made landfall early Monday much farther north, near the Chinese border.

title: South Florida Faces Ominous Prospects From Rising Waters
description: MIAMI BEACH  In the most dire predictions, South Floridas delicate barrier islands, coastal communities and captivating subtropical beaches will be lost to the rising waters in as few as 100 years.

title: BlackBerrys Woes Draw Canadas Contrarian Mogul Into Spotlight
description: Throughout the first weekend of November, V. Prem Watsa, the Canadian immigrant success story and chairman of Fairfax Financial Holdings, was huddled in the offices of his Toronto law firm, Torys, trying to salvage the biggest bet of his career.

title: Daring to Complain About Obamacare
description: LOS ANGELES  THE Anthem Blue Cross representative who answered my call told me that there was a silver lining in the cancellation of my individual P.P.O. policy and the $5,400 annual increase that I would have to pay for the Affordable Care Act-compliant option: now if I have Stage 4 cancer or need a sex-change operation, Id be covered regardless of pre-existing conditions. Never mind that the new provider network would eliminate coverage for my and my sons long-term doctors and hospitals.

title: Smith Returns, but His Game Does Not
description: The loudest roar at Madison Square Garden on Sunday was not produced by a Carmelo Anthony jumper or a strong defensive effort by the Knicks. There were few such moments in their embarrassing 120-89 loss to the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Danger Persists for Reporters in Pakistan, Despite Vow to Protect Them
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The killers were waiting for Ayub Khattak, a small-town reporter in northwestern Pakistan, as he returned to his house one evening in October. They gunned him down just outside his door.

title: N.C.A.A. Dodges a Bullet, but Change Is on the Way
description: On Friday, after United States District Judge Claudia Wilken made her latest ruling in OBannon v. the N.C.A.A., two men involved in the matter spoke with each other by telephone. One was Ed OBannon, a former U.C.L.A. basketball star; the other, Sonny Vaccaro, the sneaker marketing executive turned perpetual N.C.A.A. antagonist.

title: The Vets We Reject and Ignore
description: TODAY, we honor the nations 22 million veterans, including more than 2.5 million who served in Iraq, Afghanistan and other fronts in the war against Al Qaeda. But we are turning our backs on hundreds of thousands of veterans who were discharged under conditions other than honorable and so do not qualify as veterans under federal law.

title: New Hope for Homeless Vets
description: Each Veterans Day we lament the number of men and women who have ably served in uniform but find themselves lost, broken and homeless once out of it. Their stories are tragic and seemingly endless. For all the well-intentioned talk about meeting the needs of homeless veterans, it remains a slow and difficult process that sometimes fails.

title: Venezuelan Soldiers Deployed to Stores
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The Christmas shopping season has started with a jolt here, with the socialist Venezuelan government dispatching soldiers to occupy a major chain of electronic goods stores, ordering prices slashed there and in other shops that it has accused of price gouging.

title: Marrying Companies and Content
description: On Thursday, Contently, a hot little company, held a buzzy conference at the Bowery Hotel on a very of-the-moment topic.

title: Many Black New Yorkers Are Seeing de Blasios Victory as Their Own
description: A black janitor in Brooklyn almost shouted out the name when asked about his vote in the mayoral race. Bill de Blasio, he said, knows my struggle.

title: The Plot Against France
description: On Friday Standard & Poors, the bond-rating agency, downgraded France. The move made headlines, with many reports suggesting that France is in crisis. But markets yawned: French borrowing costs, which are near historic lows, barely budged.

title: Conservative Republicans Recoil at the Notion That Christie Is the Partys Savior
description: Time magazine splashed Chris Christies profile on its latest cover. High-profile Republicans, including the only female Hispanic governor in the nation, are urging him to run for president. MSNBCs Morning Joe program seems to be anointing him the savior of the Republican Party.

title: High and Low Premiums in Health Care
description: The debate over the effect the Affordable Care Act will have on individuals and families who buy their own policies has mostly been waged in anecdotes. Supporters of the law point to grateful individuals who were previously unable to get insurance or paid exorbitant premiums but found affordable coverage on the new health insurance exchanges. Critics counter with frustrated people who liked their old policies but will now be forced to buy a more comprehensive policy and pay a higher premium for it.

title: Same Time, Same Channel? TV Woos Kids Who Cant Wait
description: When Eric Nelsons 6-year-old daughter, Charlotte, and 10-year-old son, Asa, discover that they cannot rewind or fast-forward a TV show, they are perplexed  and their father is, too. It is hard to explain the limitations of live television to children who have grown up in an on-demand world.

title: New Faces for a Hobbled Commission
description: The Senates confirmation of two new members to the Federal Election Commission, one of the most dysfunctional and politically riven agencies in Washington, offers a ray of hope. The work of the commission has been stymied for months thanks to a standoff engineered by obstinate Republicans.

title: 60 Minutes Airs Apology on Benghazi
description: Lara Logan was scheduled to deliver a report on Sundays 60 Minutes about disabled veterans who climb mountains. Instead, she appeared in front of the newsmagazines trademark black backdrop and issued an apology.

title: Broncos Win, but Not Without Raising Doubts for Playoffs
description: SAN DIEGO  If doctors took away his cellphone in the days immediately after Broncos Coach John Fox had heart surgery, they surely must have demanded that he give up control of the television remote Sunday as he sat at home watching the Broncos 28-20 victory over the San Diego Chargers.

title: Low-Stress Voting
description: Voting should be easy, convenient and efficient  no lines, and no panic about choosing between voting or being late to work.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 10, 2013
A Time to Pause
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who leaves office at midnight on Dec. 31, has been urgently pushing a plan to build new commercial towers in Manhattan around Grand Central Terminal. The idea is to demolish outdated buildings and erect modern office buildings to compete with London or Singapore. New York could use more top-flight office space, but the proposal to rezone 73 blocks in East Midtown needs work.

title: Border War Brewing for the Olympics
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Kacey Bellamy and Courtney Birchard were hockey teammates and close friends at the University of New Hampshire. The friendship endures, Bellamy said, but we definitely know our boundaries. Were not afraid to mix it up with each other on the ice, absolutely.

title: A Word That Turned Her Life Around: Mom
description: After she started high school, Analeida Serrano began to experience an anxiety disorder triggered by situations like crowded classrooms.

title: Vox Media Buying Curbed.com Network of Sites
description: Vox Media, a company with three strong digital brands, including the technology site The Verge, is adding to its portfolio. The company plans to announce on Monday that it is buying Curbed.com L.L.C., which runs three web publications that deliver in-depth neighborhood coverage, with attitude, of real estate, dining and retailing.

title: Latino Comedian Returns to Where It All Began
description: The bodega cat knew trouble was brewing in the Torres Family Deli-Grocery as it slunk past the bags of plantain chips and boxes of Goya crackers. Sure enough, two men lunged at each other, grunting and grabbing as they fell to the scuffed tile floor near the glassed-in counter.

title: Salvaging Obama
description: President Obama is under water. His approval in the polls is low and sinking, his signature initiative is staggering from a combination of incompetence and sabotage, his foreign policy is a jumble. Congress is a Bermuda Triangle where the most elementary White House business disappears. The public is numbed and disgusted. Allies are theatrically furious about eavesdropping. Put it this way:

title: For the Want of Real Leaders, N.F.L. Culture Will Stay Lost
description: By now we know what Richie Incognito is accused of doing to his Miami Dolphins teammate Jonathan Martin. Name-calling. Bullying. Threats. What we dont know is the truth of what happened between them, or who is going to fix the cruel locker room culture that the situation has exposed.

title: Talk of Penalty Is Missing in Ads for Health Care
description: New Yorks health exchange slogan is Todays the Day. Minnesota has enlisted Paul Bunyan. Oregon held a music contest, and California stresses the peace of mind that will come with insurance.

title: Reining In Manning to Role of Game Manager
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was a moment frozen in poses of stunning failure, coach and quarterback wearing now-familiar expressions of utter exasperation. Hands on hips, Tom Coughlin stared at a hangdog-looking Eli Manning like a disbelieving father whose son has just backed the car out of the driveway and into a tree.

title: Twelfth Night and Richard III
description: Scenes from the two productions now running in repertory on Broadway.

title: Boys Will Be Boys (and Sometimes Girls)
description: The man dressed as a woman dressed as a man declares, with understandable agitation, that disguise is truly a wickedness. But dont ask anyone lucky enough to be at the Belasco Theater, home to a peerless production of Shakespeares Twelfth Night, to agree with him. I mean her. I mean him.

title: Film on Love and Gang War in Puerto Rico Is Coming to New York
description: On the sixth day of filming, the housing projects managers decided to paint.

title: Prosecuting Executives for Wall Street Crime
Health Website Tests a Tycoon and Tinkerer
description: WASHINGTON  Jeffrey D. Zients, a multimillionaire entrepreneur and management consultant, joined the Obama White House in 2009 with a mandate to streamline the federal bureaucracy. A year later, he issued a prescient warning.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Nov. 8, 2013
description: This week, voters elected Bill de Blasio as New York Citys new mayor by a decisive margin. Can he deliver on his promises? He campaigned on raising the taxes of the wealthy to pay for pre-kindergarten classes, providing more affordable housing and rejecting how Mayor Bloomberg has run the city for the past 12 years. This week on Money Talking, Joe and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine consider how successful the new mayor might be in enacting his agenda.

title: Leonard Herzenberg, 81, Immunologist Who Revolutionized Research, Dies
description: Leonard Herzenberg was in his lab at Stanford University one day in the early 1960s, laboriously counting cells under a microscope. His eyes hurt. Theres got to be some kind of machine that can do this, he remembered muttering.

title: The Streets of Salvador
description: In what may serve as a cautionary tale for other cities in the developing world, the Brazilian boom towns rising prosperity exists alongside a darker reality.

title: Mystery of a 257-Year-Old Cannon Lingers
description: STILLWATER, N.Y.  It sits now in its rightful home, after a strange journey along the East Coast, its whereabouts a mystery even as it passed through an amusement park, various collectors hands and an art museum in Alabama.

title: For 2014, G.O.P.s Challenges Stem From Within
description: BEDFORD, Pa.  Art Halvorson makes for an unlikely Republican primary challenger to a six-term incumbent like Representative Bill Shuster. He is a newcomer to this quiet corner of south-central Pennsylvania who retired here after a long Coast Guard career.

title: Anya Hindmarch: Building a Bag Brand
description: Suzy Menkes sits down with the accessories designer to discuss the evolution of her brand and her design inspiration.

title: Popular Demand
description: Five of the top albums sold in Canada the week ending Nov. 3 were also on the United States top 10 list.

title: Building a Brand, One Bag at a Time
description: LONDON  The shop window has a flock of baby chicks apparently skittering by bold handbags. Inside, there are purses shaped like crumpled potato chip bags and beach totes with smiley suns and the words Have a Nice Day.

title: On Field and on Sideline, Changes Bring Same Result for Texans
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The understudy Wade Phillips played an N.F.L. head coach on Sunday, and in some respects, it was as if nothing had changed since the last time he inhabited the role. Phillips, relieved of his lead position with a one-win Dallas Cowboys team three Novembers ago, was again at the helm of an underachieving Texas team, a Super Bowl contender gone bad.

title: Textbooks Reassess Kennedy, Putting Camelot Under Siege
description: WASHINGTON  The President John F. Kennedy students learn about today is not their grandparents J.F.K.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Giants Stretch Streak
description: The Giants defeated the Raiders, 24-20, at MetLife Stadium, continuing a modest comeback from an 0-6 start with their third win in a row.

title: In Detroit, Protests of Shooting of Woman Who Sought Help
description: Civil rights groups protested in Detroit this weekend after a young black woman was shot on the porch of a suburban home earlier this month, as she apparently sought help after she had car trouble.

title: Behind E-Commerce Spree, a Day for Bare Branches
description: Chinas burgeoning, one-day e-commerce festival goes by several names  Bare Branch Day, Singles Day (in English), the Double Eleventh. Observed every year on Nov. 11, its roughly the equivalent of Black Friday and Cyber Monday combined, with a Not Valentines Day thrown in for good measure. A festival aimed at the unmarried, this year its expected to clock up sales  on mostly discounted online goods  of about 30 billion renminbi, or $5 billion, the state media estimated.

title: Encouraging Paid Employment
description: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Rethinking Term Pregnancy
description: Anyone who has roasted a turkey knows that if you take it from the oven too soon, it will not have cooked through, and if you leave it in too long, it will be dry and tough.

title: Warnings on Childrens Drugs Found to Help Curb Misuse
description: In 2007, amid mounting concern that infant cough and cold medicines were unsafe and misused, manufacturers voluntarily withdrew products intended for children younger than 2. The makers revised the labels on the rest of the medicines, which now warn parents that they should not be given to children younger than 4.

title: Evolving Portraits of J.F.K.
description: While textbook writers have been consistent in describing President John F. Kennedys charisma and ability to inspire the country, they have become more critical of his handling of issues from civil rights to the Cuban missile crisis and the Vietnam War.

title: Postal Service to Make Sunday Deliveries for Amazon
description: WASHINGTON  The cash-short United States Postal Service, which has failed to win congressional approval to stop delivering mail on Saturdays to save money, has struck a deal with the online retailer Amazon.com to deliver the companys packages on Sundays  a first for both, with obvious advantages for each.

title: Word of the Day | repute
description: repute \ri-pyt\ noun and verb

title: Gun Violence in American Movies Is Rising, Study Finds
description: LOS ANGELES  A study set for publication in the December issue of Pediatrics confirms what some of Hollywoods sharpest critics have suspected: The level of gun violence in the top-selling PG-13 movies has been rising, and it now exceeds that in the most popular R-rated films.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 3-9
description: Sometimes, to surpass the competition, an athlete must strive for elevation, literally.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) CRISIS HOTLINE: VETERANS PRESS 1 (2013) Since 2001, more veterans have committed suicide than have died in combat in Iraq and Afghanistan, according to the United States Department of Veterans Affairs. The Veterans Crisis Line in Canandaigua, N.Y., receives more than 22,000 calls each month from former soldiers who are contemplating ending their lives because of the psychological wounds of war and the challenges of returning to civilian life. In this documentary in honor of Veterans Day, Ellen Goosenberg Kent examines the traumas endured by veterans, and the hotlines trained responders, above, who provide support in the hope of saving lives.

title: Chinas One-Day Shopping Spree Sets Record in Online Sales
description: HANGZHOU, China  Unmarried men across China used to spend Nov. 11 lamenting their single status with a drink. Now that unofficial holiday has become the worlds largest online shopping event.

title: Game to Watch: Pacers Streak Toward Chicago
description: Each week during the N.B.A. season, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue.

title: Woman Shot Near Campus in New Jersey
description: A gunman shot a 27-year-old woman in the arm near Kean Universitys campus in Union Township, N.J. on Sunday night, before fleeing into the surrounding streets.

title: Corrections: November 11, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Scale of Destruction Slows Relief Efforts in Philippines
description: CEBU, Philippines  The scale of the devastation and the desperation wrought by one of the most powerful storms ever to buffet the Philippines came into much clearer view on Monday, three days after it hopscotched across the countrys midsection whipping up monstrous walls of seawater.

title: Novartis to Sell Diagnostics Unit to Grifols for $1.7 Billion
description: Novartis, the Swiss pharmaceuticals group, is selling its diagnostics business to Spanish health care company Grifols S.A. for $1.7 billion in an all-cash deal.

title: News Quiz | November 11, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Stiff Job Opening in Queens
description: Dear Diary:

title: Europes Macro Muddle (Wonkish)
description: So, laying over in a lounge with wifi, so time for a post.

title: Battling Dengue Fever
description: Officials in Delhi are dealing with a rise in reports of Dengue Fever.

title: Delhi Battles Dengue Fever
description: NEW DELHI  Shakuntala, a 35-year-old domestic worker who uses only one name, watched, puzzled, as a city official poured water from a can placed outside her house into an empty paint bucket. Located in one of the many unauthorized slums of the capital, the house stands on the edge of a pond of muddy brown water. A herd of pigs frolicked about in the garbage that was collecting on the periphery of the water.

title: Week 10 N.F.L. Quick Hits: A Broncos Offense That Builds
description: Broncos 28, Chargers 20

title: Greek Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
description: ATHENS  The Greek government survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament early on Monday after its main political rival, the leftist Syriza, failed to gain adequate support for its censure motion. The coalition, however, saw its slim majority reduced further after one of its legislators broke ranks.

title: Shire of Ireland to Pay $4.2 Billion for U.S. Drug Maker
description: LONDON  The Irish pharmaceutical company Shire has agreed to pay $4.2 billion in cash to acquire ViroPharma, a Pennsylvania biopharmaceutical firm, in a move intended to bolster its roster of treatments for rare diseases, the companies said on Monday.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Typhoon Haiyan Devastates the Central Philippines
description: In Devastation Feared Across Central Philippines in Typhoons Wake, Keith Bradsher and Gerry Mullany write about Fridays storm and its aftermath.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Nov. 11, 2013
description: Before You Take the Quiz

title: Battle Scars, Still Stinging 70 Years Later
description: If you have trouble viewing the video, please click here.

title: What Are the Best Ways to Learn About History?
description: There are many ways to learn about history, including visiting historical sites, memorials and museums. People can also learn about the past from those who lived it, such as those who serve or are serving in the military and whom we formally honor on Veterans Day.

title: Protests Escalate in Bangkok, Rattling Government and Raising Fears of Clashes
description: BANGKOK  With thousands of antigovernment protesters in the streets of Bangkok on Monday, Thailands opposition announced a campaign of civil disobedience, including a three-day general strike later this week and a call for businesses to delay paying their taxes.

title: Kerry Tries to Reassure Mideast Allies on Iran
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  Secretary of State John Kerry sought to reassure this Persian Gulf ally on Monday that negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program would not put its security at risk, and he pleaded with critics of a deal, notably Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, not to try to scuttle an accord before the details were hammered out.

title: New York Today: A Parades Long Comeback
description: Updated 12:05 p.m. | New York CitysVeterans Day parade, which steps off this morning, has marched a long way.

title: The Day the Lights Went Out
description: In 2003, a blackout crippled areas of the U.S. and Canada, leaving some 50 million people in the dark. Ten years later, we are still grappling with concerns over the vulnerability of the power grid.

title: China Offers Relatively Modest Aid for Typhoon Victims
description: As international aid pours into the Philippines for victims of Typhoon Haiyan, China has offered $100,000 in cash, a figure that seems modest compared with its other recent contributions for humanitarian relief abroad.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Jonathan Mahler on Mike Rice, Rehabilitation and Aggression in College Sports
description: Jonathan Mahler, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about Mike Rice, the Rutgers basketball coach who was fired for mistreating his players. Mahler last wrote for the magazine about Oaklands Occupy movement.

title: The Blackout That Exposed the Flaws in the Grid
description: On a late Thursday afternoon in the summer of 2003, everything turned off. As this weeks Retro Report video illustrates, in the span of a few minutes, the biggest power outage in United States history brought swaths of the Northeast, the Midwest and Canada to a standstill. Around 50 million people were left without power. In the days and weeks that followed, reporters and investigators raced to pinpoint the source of the outage, while larger questions swirled about the stability of the power grid in the 21st century. Here, a Times reporter who covers energy technology reflects on that day and the changes that resulted.

title: Daily Report: Hoping to See Big Pictures in a Blizzard of Tiny Data Points
description: David Soloff is recruiting an army of hyperdata collectors, Quentin Hardy reports.

title: A Business Owners First Brush With HealthCare.gov
description: A couple of years ago I wrote the following: I would like to be able to go to my insurers Web site, and go to a page that generates an instant rate adjustment based on a brief description of a possible new hire. Lets say I get to enter the age and sex (and maybe whether they smoke) of the prospective employee and any others in their family. Then I get a number right then and there that tells me what this will do to my insurance rates.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 11, 2013
description: Updated: Nov. 12, 2013

title: Markets Evolve, as Does Financial Fraud
description: It is usually the case that there are not new frauds, just new avenues for deception. As the financial world has evolved into a high-speed race to trade assets while investment strategies are kept secret, both regulators and investors face the challenge of finding the fine line between permissible trading and manipulation aimed at generating unfair profits.

title: Struggle for Survival in Philippine City Shattered by Typhoon
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Decomposing bodies still lie along the roads, like a corpse in a pink, short-sleeve shirt and blue shorts facedown in a black, muddy puddle 100 yards from the airport. Just down the road is a church that was supposed to be an evacuation center but is littered with the bodies of those who drowned inside.

title: Snapshots From the Fall Art Season in London
description: LONDON  The tiny figures are painted in brushstrokes thinner than a hair  a bride dressed in festive red, merchants with their wares, would-be bureaucrats studying for a state exam in a state pavilion  set against a bay, a stand of trees. They are part of Prosperous Suzhou, a vast panorama of urban life painted in 1759 by Xu Yang, one of the many works on view in Masterpieces of Chinese Painting 700-1900 at the Victoria & Albert Museum here through Jan. 19.

title: Separating the Market-Moving Tweets From the Chaff
description: Carl C. Icahn wields it as a megaphone. Traders and analysts use it to chat publicly about stocks. Eyewitnesses employ it to post messages about news events before they make headlines.

title: Indias Politicians Ignore Women Voters in Election Campaigns
description: On the eve of Diwali, I was walking around the inner circle of Connaught Place, a well-known shopping center in Delhi, with a journalist friend. The business arcade teemed with people. Suddenly loud, belligerent voices tore through the festive air. We stopped.

title: Protests Over Delay of Election in Maldives
description: NEW DELHI  Political turmoil deepened in the Maldives on Monday as the police clashed with protesters after a third attempt to hold a presidential election was thrown off course by a court order.

title: Iran Says It Has Agreed to Road Map With U.N. Agency on Nuclear Inspections
description: PARIS  The International Atomic Energy Agency said on Monday that Iran had agreed to resolve all outstanding issues with the agency and would allow international inspectors managed access to two important nuclear facilities that have not been regularly viewed.

title: Fresh Ideas on Wall Street
description: New rules and new technology are changing the way Wall Street does business. That has led to innovation, but it has also meant that old tricks appear in new guises, as DealBook shows in its fall special section on ideas and innovation.

title: Amy Robach of ABC Says On-Air Mammogram Found Breast Cancer
description: Amy Robach, an anchor on ABCs Good Morning America, had avoided her doctors recommendation for a mammogram screening for a year, when a producer for the show called at the end of September and asked her to consider undergoing a televised mammogram.

title: On Losing a Veteran Son to a Broken System
description: As a parent, you spend your entire life trying to protect your children. You provide them with the very best you can; you hope they learn from your mistakes. Its so easy when they are young and a simple because I said so is reason enough.

title: Bloody End for Iranian Rockers Seeking Musical Freedom in U.S.
description: For their music they had risked the wrath of Irans government, practicing American-style rock in makeshift soundproof studios and performing it in underground clubs and parking lots, despite the threat of fines, detention or arrest. Growing up together in Tehran, they had found a sound: part punk, part garage rock, part their own invention.

title: Leading Syrian Opposition Group, Yielding to Pressure, Votes to Join Peace Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  During the fractious weekend debates that ended with the main Syrian exile opposition coalition yielding to international pressure by dropping its refusal to hold peace talks with President Bashar al-Assads government, tensions ran so high that one prominent coalition member slapped another in the face, participants in the gathering said.

title: Suit Charges 3 Credit Ratings Agencies With Fraud in Bear Stearns Case
description: The collapse of two Bear Stearns hedge funds in 2007 was among the earliest signs of the impending financial crisis. More than six years later, lawyers continue to fight over the cause of their demise.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Star Wars Darth Vader and Yoda Cuff Links
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Militant Leader Is Killed in Pakistan
description: LONDON  A senior leader of the feared Haqqani militant network was shot dead on the outskirts of the Pakistani capital, officials said Monday, in a new blow to the close-knit cluster of militant groups that shelter in northwestern Pakistan.

title: In Our Pages: November 12
description: 1963: Sir Alec Chides Khrushchev

title: Credit Ratings Lawsuit
description: The collapse of two Bear Stearns hedge funds was among the earliest signs of the impending financial crisis. More than six years later, lawyers continue to fight over the cause of their demise.

title: A Massage With the Greatest of Ease
description: Spagoers looking for a massage with a little extra intensity, and pizzazz, may be interested in the new aerial silk massage being offered by the Ritz-Carlton Spa in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Private Equitys Online Courtship
description: FOR decades, private equity firms relied on highly paid middlemen to raise money. But soon, the process may be as simple as logging on to a website.

title: The Case Against Too Much Independence on the Board
description: Regulators and institutional investors keep pushing the independent directors as the cure-all for what ails Americas corporations. Yet that independence, like innovation itself, can be too much of a good thing.

title: K.K.R. to Buy Landscaping Company Brickman for $1.6 Billion
description: Updated, 12:35 p.m. |

title: Transocean Makes Peace With Icahn
description: Transocean ended its feud with Carl C. Icahn on Monday, agreeing to pay a $3-a-share dividend, make $800 million in cost cuts and undertake shifts in strategy.

title: Honesty That Benefits All
description: It seems that headlines too often highlight the bad deeds of players in financial markets. There are insider trading scandals. Traders collude on interest rate manipulation. Executives backdate options. We often hear the excuse, Everyone else was doing it, so I didnt think it was wrong.

title: Today in Small Business: Now Accepting Bitcoin
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: The Francis Era: Synthesis or Civil War?
description: My colleague Laurie Goodstein had a good piece yesterday about conservative Catholics who feel unsettled byPope Franciss approach to the papal office, which seems like a good hook for returning, a month later, to my own take on the Francis experiment. In that piece, I talked a bit about the idea of a religious center meaning a way of being religious thats simultaneously modern and devout, engaged with contemporary realities but still rooted in a recognizably Biblical worldview  and argued that since the 1960s its become harder for believers of any traditional faith to claim that kind of ground. The tendency, instead, has been toward either toward a kind of separatism and retrenchment on the one hand, or accommodation and then often dissolution on the other  and this has been true for Jews and Protestants as it has been for Catholics.

title: Image of the Day: November 11
One Answer to the Index Fund: Build a Better Index
description: PAUL A. SAMUELSON made a startling and significant case for index funds in 1974. In a deliberately provocative essay, Mr. Samuelson, who had already won the Nobel in economic science and written the most influential economics textbook in history, said most professional investment managers should drop dead.

title: Rooney Maras Otherworldly Outfit
description: The Girl: The actress accented an all-white, ethereal confection with a thick cherry lip at the premiere of her new film Her at the Rome Film Festival last night.

title: Self-Mutilation on Red Square
description: MOSCOW  On Sunday the protest artist Petr Pavlensky sat naked on Red Square and drove a nail through his scrotum and into the pavement.

title: A Different Kind of Hearing Aid
description: Jim Cooke blames his hearing loss on the constant roar of C-119 aircraft engines he experienced in the Air Force. He didnt wear protective gear because, like most 20-year-olds, you think youre indestructible, he said. By the time he was 45, he needed hearing aids for both ears.

title: U.S. Sets Roster for Scotland and Austria Games
description: Twenty-three American players began assembling in Glasgow on Monday after being selected by the United States national team coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, for the last two friendly international matches before the draw for the 2014 World Cup draw.

title: U.N. Court Rules for Cambodia in Temple Dispute With Thailand
description: BANGKOK  The International Court of Justice on Monday handed Cambodia a partial victory in its territorial dispute with Thailand over the land surrounding an ancient temple along the countrys border.

title: Ask Well: Buying Cheaper Drugs Online
description: Question:

title: Gordon Hamiltons Unfair Thrones
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Gordon Hamilton of MathPickle.com.

title: The Read Around: Jesmyn Ward
description: Jesmyn Ward discusses her memoir, Men We Reaped, and the challenge of writing about people she has known and loved.

title: A Co-President Quits Disneys Video Game and Web Unit
description: LOS ANGELES  John Pleasants, the hard-charging co-president of Disneys video game and web division, announced his resignation on Monday, effective immediately, although he will continue as a consultant for a while.

title: Mapping the Destruction of Typhoon Haiyan
description: Maps of the storm surge and damage in Tacloban.

title: Banks May Curb Traders Use of Chat Rooms
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse, JPMorgan Chase and other investment banks are considering limiting the ability of their traders to chat electronically with other banks amid a series of investigations of potential manipulation of the foreign exchange market, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Rebalancing Act
description: Chinas G.D.P. and employment by sector reveal that services and manufacturing are increasing while agriculture and mining are decreasing.

title: Introducing: Capitalizing on China
description: When I started Auction Systems Auctioneers and Appraisers almost 18 years ago, my vision wasnt to own a multinational company. And I certainly did not imagine that I would one day be dividing my time between China and the United States, routinely spending three weeks abroad and then five weeks back home.

title: Pumpkin Pie
description: One of my all-time favorite pies, this one is sweet with spices but not very sugary. Because of the small amount of molasses, this is darker than classic pumpkin pie. Make it with fresh roasted pumpkin, or use canned pumpkin. I am finding small pie pumpkins in supermarkets, and theyre perfect for the job.

title: Apple Tart With Almond Topping in a Gluten-Free Shell
description: This tart is inspired by a recipe by Jacquy Pfeiffer, from his upcoming cookbook The Art of French Pastry. The apples are caramelized first with sugar and spices, then spread in the pastry, topped with an almond, egg white and sugar topping, and baked.

title: Roasted Sweet Potato Pie or Flan
description: I like this as much without a crust as with one. Its not a flan in the traditional sense, with a caramel component. Its an irresistibly creamy one. If you use 2 eggs instead of 3 (see variation) the texture will be smoother but it wont slice as neatly.

title: Veterans Stats, on Veterans Day
description: From around the Internet, disheartening news about the difficulties confronting veterans.

title: Janneke Straub Named Executive Director of Ojai Music Festival
description: The Ojai Music Festival, a classical music festival long known for its championship of adventurous contemporary works, announced on Sunday that it has appointed Janneke Straub as its executive director, starting in January. Ms. Straub comes to the festival from the American Youth Symphony, where she has been executive director since 2008. Before that, she spent 13 years at the Los Angeles Philharmonic, where she raised money for projects that included several new-music commissioning programs.

title: Why I Let My Son (Finally) Join the Boy Scouts
description: My son started asking back in first grade: Mom, can I join Boy Scouts?

title: Saying a Chapter of War Is Ending, Obama Vows Aid for Veterans
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama pledged Monday that Americans will never forget the sacrifices made by the countrys military veterans, and promised that his administration would continue pushing for money to support the men and women home from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Scene City | Starlets and Artists Toast Guggenheim
description: Dior drew a fashionable crowd at the Guggenheim International Gala.

title: Stepping Up With a Plan to Save American Cities
description: FOR decades, cities and states that needed more cash for their workers pensions have turned to local taxpayers, the municipal bond market or even the workers themselves. Now those options appear to be drying up.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 5-11, 2013
description: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

title: For $99, Eliminating the Mystery of Pandoras Genetic Box
description: IF DNA is destiny, then Anne Wojcicki is in the right business.

title: On the Ground in Tacloban
description: The Timess Keith Bradsher reported on the devastation in Tacloban, the Philippines, days after Typhoon Haiyan ripped through the city.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: American Advertising Federation, Washington, renamed its annual Addy Awards competition as the American Advertising Awards. James Edmund Datri, president and chief executive of the organization, said he hoped that local chapters would still call the awards that are presented to winners Addy awards.

title: Fans and Friends React to the Shooting Deaths of Iranian Band Members
description: Early Monday, a rock musician in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, killed three other musicians before taking his own life, the police and neighbors said. Two of the victims were members of a rock band of Iranian expatriates called the Yellow Dogs. The gunman was another Iranian-American musician, the police said.

title: Slowing the Revolving Door Between Public and Private Jobs
description: It has been called corrupt, corrosive and hazardous to our health. Yet, Washingtons revolving door spins on.

title: Chanel, Self-Appointed Guardian of Pariss Artisan Workshops
description: When fashions Old World specialty ateliers were on the verge of extinction, Chanel came to the rescue. Now its ushering them into the future.

title: A Jolt to Complacency on Food Supply
description: For a look at what climate change could do to the worlds food supply, consider what the weather did to the American Corn Belt last year.

title: For Better Performance, Hedge Funds Seek the Inner Trader
description: In the hedge fund industry, as in sports, performance is everything.

title: Giving People a Glimpse of What Their Pets See
description: FORGET about a birds-eye view. A leader in pet foods is introducing a digital campaign for a principal brand that promises to provide views from the dogs- and cats-eye perspective.

title: Braves Plan to Leave Turner Field for Suburbs
description: The Atlanta Braves said Monday that they will leave Turner Field in four years for a ballpark they plan to build in the wealthy northern suburbs where most of their fans live. The move follows one already planned by the N.F.L.s Atlanta Falcons, who have said that they will stay downtown but will trade their current home in the Georgia Dome for a retractable-roof stadium to be built nearby at a cost of $1.2 billion.

title: Aaron Glick Awarded T Fellowship for Theater Producers
description: Aaron Glick, a theater producer whose productions have included the PigPen Theater Companys Off Broadway staging of The Old Man and the Old Moon, has been awarded a T Fellowship, a one-year program meant to support the development of emerging producers.

title: Cruise Lines Are Ready for Some Football
description: Over the last few years, it seems as if major cruise lines have been harnessing the star power of every kind of celebrity to sell more voyages. Some feature food from Top Chefs, entertainment from American Idols or even a chance to sail the Caribbean with the members of the band Kiss.

title: 20 Million in Mideast to Get Polio Vaccine
description: Health officials will try to get polio vaccines to more than 20 million children across the Middle East to contain a major outbreak there, the World Health Organization and Unicef announced last week.

title: Fighting Across the Rappahannock
description: Charlie Clark basked in the warmth of a budding romance on a cold autumn day in 1863. His friend and fellow lieutenant in the Union Army, Solomon Russell, had fallen for a Southern belle in war-torn Virginia. On the morning of Nov. 7, 1863, the officers left their camp in Warrenton to call upon her. They made their way to the home of the widow Rosina Dixon and found the focus of Russells desire: the 15-year-old Anna. Whatever words passed between the Yankee officer and rebel maiden went unrecorded, though Clark referenced the encounter years later in his reminiscences, noting that Russell was deeply in love with Anna.

title: Injuries to Players Raise Questions on Athlete I.P.O. Plan
description: Sunday was a bad day for Fantex, the fledgling company promoting initial public offerings of National Football League stars.

title: Determining the Victims of Insider Trading
description: The guilty plea hearing last week in the Justice Departments prosecution of SAC Capital Advisors raised an interesting question about the law of insider trading: Just who are the victims of a violation? A provision of the federal securities laws gives those who traded at the same time as the insider a right to sue for a violation, but the Justice Department said they are not victims of the crime.

title: Giving Foreign Clients a Piece of New Yorks Luxury Real Estate
description: It takes a certain kind of person to regard luxury real estate in New York as cheap, maybe even embarrassingly cheap when compared with other global capitals. If such people hail from the former Soviet Union, and want to add a Manhattan address to a portfolio that might already include homes in London or Dubai or St. Tropez, they might seek out a real estate agent who appreciates their unusual perspective. They might seek out Gennady Perepada.

title: Notes From a Storm-Wrecked Land
description: QUEZON CITY, Philippines  ON Wednesday, two days before Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines, I assigned the short story Fredo Avila, by Gina Apostol, to my introduction to literature class at Ateneo de Manila University. Its set in the writers hometown, Barugo, in the eastern province of Leyte.

title: Adding Pounds, Then New Knees
description: In his mid-forties, Charles Carroll, a letter carrier in Shrewsbury, Mass., started taking anti-inflammatory medicine for his achy knees. Despite his young age, osteoarthritis had begun to settle in.

title: Obama Speaks on Veterans Day
description: The president delivers remarks at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.

title: Choosing to Chew Gum
description: Q. Is chewing gum bad for you?

title: Gliders in the Ocean Deep, Autism in an Infants Gaze, Martin Cruz Smiths Life With Parkinsons
description: Autonomous robots take to the seas to investigate currents, fish and climate change; a new study uses eye-tracking techniques on infants to look for early signs of autism; the author of Gorky Park talks about living with a diagnosis of Parkinsons disease for the last 18 years.

title: Getting Less Touchy on Windows 8, and Adjusting the iOS Mail App
description: Less Touchy

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Gay Talese and Juliette Lewis
description: The legendary journalist and the Oscar-nominated actress take on Saint Laurent roller skates, Sylvester Stallone as an artist and more.

title: Martin Cruz Smith Reveals a Twist in His Tale
description: It is probably no accident that the pivotal object in Martin Cruz Smiths newest detective thriller, Tatiana, is a notebook nobody can read.

title: How to Help Philippines Typhoon Victims
description: Updated, Tuesday, 5:44 p.m. | As the full scale of the devastation wrought across the islands of the Philippines over the weekend by Typhoon Haiyan came into fuller view on Monday, governments around the world have pledged aid to the victims. The Pentagon has dispatched an advance team of 90 marines and sailors, and U.S.A.I.D. has pledged emergency shelter and hygiene materials and 55 tons of food. The American Embassy in Manila has donated $100,000 for water and sanitation assistance.

title: BlackBerrys Turnaround Starts All Thumbs
description: BlackBerrys turnaround is starting out all thumbs. The $85 million worth of stock handed to the companys new boss, John Chen, over five years at least provides the right incentives. But the struggling Canadian company surely needs more attention than one man doing both top jobs, especially if hes commuting from California.

title: Single Tooth Tells of Long-Extinct Platypus
description: Based on the discovery of a single tooth, researchers say they have identified an ancient species of giant platypus. The finding provides new clues about the lineage of the modern platypus. The fossil record is very, very patchy for the platypus, and these are a unique group of mammals, said the lead researcher, Rebecca Pian, a vertebrate paleontologist at Columbia University and the American Museum of Natural History. Unlike most mammals, they lay eggs instead of giving birth to live offspring; their snouts are covered with electroreceptors that can detect underwater prey; and the male has a venomous spur on its hind feet.

title: When One Kitchen Isnt Enough
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  When Tony Maws designed the open kitchen at Craigie on Main, the celebrated restaurant he opened here five years ago, he positioned his workstation to serve as a kind of welcome mat.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Gay Talese and Juliette Lewis
description: The legendary journalist, known for his expertise in crafting the celebrity profile, and the Oscar-nominated actress, who will star alongside Meryl Streep and Julia Roberts in the forthcoming film adaptation of Tracy Lettss Pulitzer-winning play, August: Osage County, take on Iggy Azalea, a feather-tipped ballpoint pen, high-top roller skates and more.

title: A Winter Innovation: The Airport Coat Check
description: ITS getting cold in the Northern Hemisphere, and that means we are about to enter the Winter Campaign in the overhead bin wars.

title: In Hookups, Inequality Still Reigns
description: Natasha Gadinsky, 23, says she doesnt have any regrets from her years in college. But the time she hooked up with a guy at Brown University does come close.

title: Tracking the Worlds Biggest E-Commerce Event
description: Chinese consumers were expected to spend more than $5 billion Monday for Singles Day, which is considered the worlds biggest e-commerce event.

title: The Old-Fashioned, in Song and Dance
description: Updated, 12:15 p.m. | My Drink column this month was partially inspired by the song Im Old Fashioned, by Jerome Kern and Johnny Mercer. It debuted in the 1942 romantic comedy You Were Never Lovelier, in a total charmer of a song-and-dance routine.

title: After Near Miss on Iran, Kerry Says Diplomacy Is Still the Right Path
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  Secretary of State John Kerry came up a few disputed words short of closing a landmark nuclear deal with Iran on Sunday in Geneva. Now he is defending the diplomacy that led to that near miss against a rising chorus of critics at home and abroad.

title: Tidying Up Your Financial Life
description: From buying a home to paying for college, our financial decisions seem more complex, and it often seems as if things are far beyond our control. It leads to a feeling of anxiety. Plus, were so busy making money, trying to make ends meet, that it seems all but impossible to manage it in any meaningful way. Who has the time to track a monthly budget?

title: A Bully Defying the Bullies of His Era
description: The interplay between personality and politics, temperament and leadership is one of the key themes animating Doris Kearns Goodwins telling books about Abraham Lincoln (Team of Rivals), Franklin D. Roosevelt (No Ordinary Time) and Lyndon B. Johnson (Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream). The same is true of her sprawling new book, The Bully Pulpit, which gives us revealing portraits of Theodore Roosevelt and his close friend, handpicked successor and eventual bitter rival, William Howard Taft.

title: The Read Around: Jesmyn Ward
description: In The Read Around, a new weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Jesmyn Ward talks about her memoir, Men We Reaped, and the challenge of writing about people she has known and loved.

title: No Need to Fumble for Reading Glasses
description: Snakes can optimize their vision by controlling the blood flow in their eyes when they perceive threats, a new study from the University of Waterloo shows. Kevin van Doorn and Jacob Sivak of the universitys science faculty discovered that the visual blood flow patterns of the coachwhip snake changed depending on its surroundings. And instead of eyelids, snakes have clear scales called spectacles, which work like windows, covering and protecting their eyes. The findings were published in the latest issue of The Journal of Experimental Biology.

title: Acquitted Israeli Politician Returns to Job as Foreign Minister
description: JERUSALEM  Avigdor Lieberman, the powerful Israeli nationalist politician whose blunt talk has often stirred outrage at home and abroad, was reinstated on Monday as the countrys foreign minister. Mr. Lieberman, who was acquitted last week of corruption charges that had dogged him for more than a decade, was back at the diplomatic helm on Monday night after a stormy debate in Parliament and a vote confirming his reappointment.

title: Exploring the Ocean
description: Underwater drones are changing the way scientists study the sea.

title: Ocean Drones Plumb New Depths
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Five miles offshore from the Golden Nugget casino, Michael F. Crowley, a marine scientist at Rutgers University, heaves three lifeboat-yellow drones off the back of his research vessel.

title: The Rush to Coin Virtual Money With Real Value
description: Updated, 5:46 p.m. | If cash is king, virtual cash may be the crown prince in waiting.

title: Long-Term Benefits of Music Lessons
description: Childhood music lessons can sometimes leave painful memories, but they seem to carry benefits into adulthood. A new study reports that older adults who took lessons at a young age can process the sounds of speech faster than those who did not.

title: Science Bookshelf
description: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of The Tipping Point and Outliers.

title: Not Quite Laverne and Shirley
description: Celeste Delacroix Griffin is having a lousy day. True, shes been sprung from the slammer just in time for Christmas Eve, after that little shoplifting incident. But its been a quick roll downhill from there for this seedy vagabond from The Mutilated, a rarely seen Tennessee Williams comedy being boisterously revived at the New Ohio Theater in a production starring the quirky team of Penny Arcade and Mink Stole.

title: Fifth Avenue, 11:38 A.M.
In College Admissions, Social Media Can Be a Double-Edged Sword
description: When I wrote my Technophoria column this weekend about how some college admissions officers have occasionally identified social media posts that negatively affected applicants chances of acceptance, I assumed the phenomenon would not come as news to the parents of high school students.

title: No Health Insurance? Just Drink.
description: This is the strangest P.R. campaign yet against the Affordable Care Act. Generation Opportunity, the Koch-funded group behind the Creepy Uncle Sam ads, is throwing tailgate parties to educate young people about the exchanges. Read: To convince young people to forgo health insurance.

title: Walkabout: Garbage Piling Up in Madrid; Easing Travel for Passengers with Disabilities
description: A Mess in Madrid Travelers to Madrid may want to pack a pair of thigh-high boots: a strike by city sanitation workers has entered its seventh day, leading to some nasty trash pileups. (Bloomberg)

title: When Healers Get Too Friendly
description: It takes only a moment to step over the line, especially when no one knows exactly where the line is. In my case, it started with a visit from my old friend the activist.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, Virginia, France and Serbia.

title: A Marathoners Many Hurdles
description: Idrissa Kargbo, a coffee deliverer from Sierra Leone, dreams of becoming one of the best runners in the world. It is an audacious goal.

title: An Accidental Cattle Ranch Points the Way in Sustainable Farming
description: PESCADERO, Calif.  When Tom Steyer first learned that his wife, Kat Taylor, wanted to sell beef from the cattle herd on their ranch here, he rolled his eyes.

title: Quinoa Hush Puppies: A Healthful Twist on a Southern Staple
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

title: A New Political Party Aims to Save Socialism, and the Constitution, in China
description: A lot of people have been applying to join. I cant keep up with the applications, said Wang Zheng, a scholar who on Nov. 6 did something unusual. She announced the establishment of a new political party in China, where the Communist Party holds all power and tolerates no opposition outside of it.

title: East and West, Mingling in One Mans Body
description: As a child in London, enthralled by Michael Jackson, Akram Khan wasnt as interested in his Bangladeshi heritage as his parents might have liked. But he was serious about one thing: dance. After mastering the classical Indian form Kathak, he went to college and mastered Western contemporary forms. Inside his body, the collision of these ways of moving made him move in a way that was thrilling to behold. It was also a timely metaphor for second-generation immigrant identity and multiculturalism. Mr. Khan danced with astonishing speed, and his fame and the scale of his productions grew apace.

title: Boardrooms Rethink Tactics to Defang Activist Investors
description: Executives and board members used to fear hostile bids above all else. In response, they devised defense mechanisms like poison pills and staggered boards to thwart attacks.

title: Early Beatles on the BBC, Bantering and Bluesy
description: In the summer of 1971, one of the first Beatles bootlegs turned up, packaged in a white sleeve with The Beatles  Yellow Matter Custard  Previously Unreleased Studio Material rubber-stamped across it. It offered an odd lineup of tracks (performances of Ray Charless I Got a Woman; Buddy Hollys Crying, Waiting, Hoping; Carl Perkinss Sure to Fall (in Love With You); Arthur Alexanders Shot of Rhythm and Blues), 14 in all, in decent, if slightly tinny, quality.

title: Plan to Finance Philanthropy Shows the Power of a Simple Question
description: What if?

title: Marty Ehrlich and Luscious Jackson Have New Albums
description: LUSCIOUS JACKSON

title: Honoring Female Pioneers in Science
description: Florence Nightingale, a statistician? Marie Curie, driving to the front during World War I to X-ray wounded soldiers?

title: Colbert Recites the Gettysburg Address
description: Stephen Colbert is among the celebrities who are encouraging Americans to memorize Lincoln's famous speech.

title: Three Days of Dancing, Starring D.J.s
description: Dance music has its hegemonies, its mainstream history, but in the last few years especially, mutation has complicated and diversified that narrative. Now in its sixth year, the Brooklyn Electronic Music Festival has been an incubator for these styles, often capturing rising D.J.s and producers before they make wide impact.

title: Surveillance Leaves Writers Wary
description: A survey by the writers organization PEN American Center has found that a large majority of its members are deeply concerned about recent revelations regarding the extent of government surveillance of email and phone records, with more than a quarter saying that they have avoided, or are seriously considering avoiding, controversial topics in their work.

title: The Quiet Before the Shots
description: Next to birthdays of prominent public figures, nothing engenders mass reflection and artistic endeavor as readily as big, round anniversaries of historical milestones. Were just 10 days away from one such date: Nov. 22, the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedys assassination in Dallas, which after half a century continues to take a dramatic toll on the collective American psyche.

title: The Gettysburg Address, as Recited by Colbert and You
description: The filmmaker Ken Burns has found one way to bring together Republicans and Democrats in this politically divided time: Ask them to recite the Gettysburg Address, which Abraham Lincoln delivered on Nov. 19, 1863, at the dedication of the cemetery at the Civil War battlefield. The website Learn the Address features videos of notable names reciting the speech, including all the living American presidents and dozens of celebrities like Taylor Swift, Usher, Steven Spielberg, Uma Thurman, Shane Victorino and Bill OReilly. Other well-known reciters include Stephen Colbert and Gabrielle Giffords.

title: Estonian Master, Through Lens of Compatriots
description: If any artist is emblematic of the spirit manifest in Lincoln Centers White Light Festival, it might be Arvo Prt. An Estonian composer based in Berlin for much of his career, Mr. Prt achieved wide renown in the mid-1980s through a series of recordings on the German label ECM. His rise to prominence was also abetted by the conductor Neeme Jrvi, a countryman whose continued advocacy was evident in a festival concert by the Estonian National Symphony Orchestra and the Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening.

title: Watch Out for Falling Space Junk and Asteroids
description: Fiery chunks of a European satellite fell from the sky, the latest in a parade of what scientists worryingly call uncontrolled entries. And new research showed that asteroids like the one that exploded over Russia in February will probably hit Earth more often than previously expected. All in all, not a bad week to begin a long journey to Mars.

title: The Universes End
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Weekend Gun Report: November 8-10, 2013
description: A Texas company has made the worlds first metal gun using a 3D printer. The fully functioning, semi-automatic .45-caliber pistol made by Austin-based Solid Concepts is modeled on on the Browning 1911 firearm. Its been safely fired 50 times, and as for accuracy, the gun was able to strike a target bulls-eye at more than 30 yards.

title: Two Weeks That Kindle Hope
description: No ballet ensemble has a soul more divided than that of American Ballet Theater. Some people think its one of the worlds greatest companies; others think its not really a company at all. Both arguments make sense, and they largely correspond to which side of Lincoln Center Plaza the troupe is playing.

title: Monday Motorsports: Jimmie Johnson Eyes Sixth Title
description: Kevin Harvick won the battle, but Jimmie Johnson may have won the war on Sunday in Nascars Sprint Cup Series race at Phoenix International Raceway. On the white flag lap, Harvick passed the leader, Carl Edwards, who was running out of fuel, and then held on for the final lap to take the checkered flag. Kasey Kahne came in second. Johnson was third, earning a decisive number of points in the quest for his sixth Sprint Cup season title.

title: From the Philippines to Haiti, Disaster Recovery is a Way of Life
description: For many millions of people living in the planets poorest, most populous places, a state of recovery from what used to be called natural disasters has become the norm, not some exceptional circumstance. The central Philippines, now reeling from the impact of Typhoon Haiyan, a super storm if ever there was one, are just the latest place in which huge human losses follow a disaster that, in a rich country, would almost assuredly mainly exact a financial toll. See Keith Bradshers wrenching reports here and here for details on the damage. And the immediate search and rescue efforts are just a warmup for years of relocation, recovery and rebuilding.

title: Supper Club to Reopen With Carnal Take on Magic Flute
description: A famed theater-district supper club will reopen on New Years Eve with a high-tech carnal reimagining of The Magic Flute that aims to blur the lines between the audience and the performers. Queen of the Night is created by Randy Weiner, a founder of The Box burlesque space on the Lower East Side and a producer of the smash success Sleep No More downtown. Like The Donkey Show, the disco adaptation of A Midsummer Nights Dream that Mr. Weiner created with his wife, Diane Paulus, in 1999, Queen of the Night puts the audience into the middle of a reconfigured classic theater piece  in this case Mozarts opera.

title: T WINTER TRAVEL
description: The Renaissance wunderkammer, or cabinet of curiosities  a personal collection of fabulous, rare, sometimes grotesque relics  inspires tableaus of the seasons most opulent baubles and fanciful curios.

title: Germany to Form Task Force on Looted Art
description: After an avalanche of criticism at home and abroad, the German government announced late Monday it will establish a task force to investigate, as quickly and as transparently as possible, the provenance of a cache of more than 1,400 artworks that are suspected of being traded or looted during the Nazis reign and that are now in the hands of authorities in Bavaria.

title: The Only Certainty Is That He Wont Show Up
description: Maybe Godot never appears because everyone is mispronouncing his name.

title: Welcome, in Mandarin
description: Mandarin television channels. Congee rice porridges. Smoking rooms.

title: He Struts, but His Comb Is Trembling
description: Year of the Rooster at the Ensemble Studio Theater isnt merely entertaining. Its astonishingly entertaining, partly because the playwright, Eric Dufault, is only in his mid-20s and partly because who would have thought that a barnyard bird could make such an intriguing stage character?

title: Art Matters | Bruce Weber on the Intimacy of Portraiture
description: As Bruce Weber releases a new installment of his All-American photo anthology and a box set of his films, he reflects on the intimacy of taking pictures.

title: In Music Piracy Battles, Lyrics Demand Respect Too
description: When the forces of the music industry go after websites for using copyrighted content without permission, that content tends to come in the form of MP3 files or YouTube videos.

title: Lennons School Detention Sheets Head to Auction
description: John Lennon always described himself as a cut-up during his school years, an authority-baiting revolutionary in the making. But even keeping in mind the wisecracking assertiveness he cultivated during the Beatles years, and beyond, you always suspected that he was exaggerating.

title: Crystal Bridges Museum Conducts Ambitious Survey of Contemporary American Art
description: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, the institution founded in Bentonville, Ark., by Alice L. Walton, the Walmart heiress, is only two years old. But it has embarked on a mission that even more established museums might fear to take on: a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art, formed by visits to hundreds of artists studios, large and small, successful and almost unheard-of, across the country.

title: For an Upgrade, Skip the Vegetarian Meal
description: IM an entrepreneur in the promotional clothing and products business. That entrepreneurial spirit is in my blood.

title: Art Survey Planned
description: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, the institution founded in Bentonville, Ark., by Alice L. Walton, the Wal-Mart heiress, is only two years old. But it has decided to set out on a mission even more established museums might fear: a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art, formed by visits to hundreds of artists studios across the country. The resulting show, State of the Art, will bring together the work of 100 artists for a show that will open on Sept. 13and continue through Jan. 5, 2015. For the last several months, the museums president, Don Bacigalupi, and an assistant curator for special projects, Chad Alligood, have been traveling by plane and car to almost every part of the country, relying on an initial list of 10,000 artists, to find works they will include in the show. They have visited more than 400 studios and artists so far, in dozens of cities, but also in rural places so small that the roads to them have not shown up on the curators GPS devices. Weve come to recognize that many extraordinary artists may be known in their own locales, but have yet to emerge on the national stage, Mr. Alligood said. Their work, however, deserves consideration from a national audience. State of the Art could be seen as a traditionalist alternative to a show like the Whitney Biennial, but there are currently no plans to make it a recurring event.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Messaging Apps Threaten Facebook, and $4 Toast
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Godot Variations
description: A look at different interpretations of Samuel Becketts play.

title: Irans Foreign Minister Subtweets Kerry
description: As my colleague Mark Landler reports, Secretary of State John Kerry insisted on Monday that it was unfair to blame last-minute objections from his French counterpart, Laurent Fabius, for scuttling a potential deal with Iran over its nuclear energy program last weekend in Geneva. The French signed off on it, we signed off on it, Mr. Kerry said of the final proposal presented to Irans negotiating team. There was unity, but Iran couldnt take it.

title: How to Respond to Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds That Fly on Digital Wings
description: Spatial music has been around for over 400 years, with composers from Gabrieli to Stockhausen exploiting the acoustic effect that results from separating performers in space. Technological advances of recent decades have made it possible to move sound about a room  and even enhance, distort or multiply it as it travels about  while keeping the musician rooted in place.

title: Is the Letter Dead? Not on This Page!
Amuse the Children. Now.
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance: Brian Cross
description: Brian Cross in a scene from Sharr Whites new play The Snow Geese, now on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: Objects | A Magical Array of Many-Splendored Things
description: The Renaissance wunderkammer, or cabinet of curiosities  a personal collection of fabulous, rare, sometimes grotesque relics  inspires tableaus of the seasons most opulent baubles and fanciful curios.

title: Maneuvering Begins as Three Yankees Rebuff Offers
description: In an off-season filled with uncertainty, the Yankees passed the first phase with no surprises as three players turned down qualifying offers from the team. The Yankees had made the offers  set by Major League Baseball at $14.1 million  to Robinson Cano, Curtis Granderson and Hiroki Kuroda.

title: Silent Sentinels at Center of Lithuanian Debate on Bygone Era
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania  Watching over one of this citys busiest thoroughfares are the sentinels of a loathed regime.

title: For de Blasio, Contract Talks Offer Problem
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has promised all sorts of assistance to ease Bill de Blasios transition, but the mayor has nonetheless bequeathed one particularly thorny, potentially explosive issue to his successor: New York Citys 300,000 municipal workers are angry that their contracts expired years ago, and they are demanding more than $7 billion in retroactive pay to make up for their years without a regular raise.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Montral, Quebec; Pennsylvania; Madrid
description: Salon des Mtiers dArt deMontral, QuebecMore than 400 regional artisans will gather at Place Bonaventure in Montreal from Dec. 6 to 22 to display their latest creations. Established in 1955, the event is described by its organizers as the most important annual professional crafts exhibition in Canada. Jewelry, musical instruments, games, toys, kitchen utensils, office accessories and other utilitarian and decorative objects (above) are among the original crafts for sale.

title: Etsys Industrial Revolution
description: PASADENA, Calif.  HAND-KNIT sweaters? Hand-thrown pots? How about quilts stitched on a sewing machine? In an age when artisanal items can be sold at a premium, what products should qualify as handmade?

title: Ex-Mob Boss Gotti Stabbed on Long Island
description: John A. Gotti, the former boss of the Gambino crime family, was stabbed in the stomach over the weekend in Syosset, N.Y., the authorities said on Monday.

title: The Extra Legroom Society
description: For our time off together around Christmas, my siblings, their children and I recently began plotting an excursion to the Six Flags amusement park in the Los Angeles area. The discussion turned quickly from roller coasters to perks. To status. To just how high were prepared to fly in this service-obsessed, luxury-laden, class-fractured era of ours.

title: Saudi Arabia: MERS Virus Found in Patients Pet Camel
description: The virus that causes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome  an often-lethal lung disease related to SARS  has been found in a pet camel belonging to a recent human victim, Saudi Arabias Health Ministry announced Monday. The discovery adds credence to the prevailing theory that the virus originates in bats but usually reaches humans through camels. In three earlier clusters of MERS cases, the first patient to fall ill in each was reported to have had contact with a sick camel. Although antibodies to the disease had been found in camels before, the virus itself had not. Genetic tests will be done, the ministry said, to see if the camels strain is identical to that found in the patient, a 43-year-old man in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, who is still hospitalized. MERS has killed 64 people since it was first isolated a year ago, 53 of them in Saudi Arabia. It can also spread from human to human, but seems to do so less readily than SARS  severe acute respiratory syndrome  did.

title: Skeptics See Euro Eroding European Unity
description: LONDON  Europes slow emergence from its second recession in the last five years is raising new questions about whether the euro currency is doing more harm than good.

title: Citys Plan to Relocate 2 Agencies Stirs Anger
description: The city official attempted a half smile as the baby was held before him, her tiny feet dangling in little pink striped socks. But her mother was in no mood for niceties.

title: Russia: Four Are Sentenced for Airport Attack
description: The Moscow Regional Court sentenced three men on Monday to life in prison for their role in the 2011 suicide bombing at the Domodedovo airport in Moscow that killed 37 people and wounded 172, the court said. The men, Bashir Khamkhoyev and the brothers Islam and Ilez Yandiyev, were convicted of providing explosive materials to the bomber, Magomed Yevloyev, 20, and for organizing his stay in Moscow before the January attack. A fourth man, Akhmed Yevloyev, the bombers brother, was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Doku Umarov, the leader of an Islamist terrorist group carrying out an insurgency in the countrys North Caucasus region, later claimed responsibility for the bombing. Mr. Umarov, who remains a fugitive, has since called on his followers to disrupt the 2014 Winter Olympics, which Russia will host in Sochi, a resort city on the edge of the turbulent region.

title: Problems With Federal Health Portal Also Stymie Medicaid Enrollment
description: WASHINGTON  Problems with the federal health insurance website have prevented tens of thousands of low-income people from signing up for Medicaid even though they are eligible, federal and state officials say, undermining one of the chief goals of the 2010 health care law.

title: Boycotting Israeli Universities, Part Two
description: The responses to my column on the call by some academics to boycott Israeli universities in the name of academic freedom were impassioned and polarized. I was pleased to find more readers than usual on my side, but one argument favored by those who agreed with my negative view of the boycott is, I think, beside the point. That is the argument that the boycott is wrong because it is selective, because it singles out Israel when there are so many other countries in the world whose policies and actions are just as bad or worse. Actually, this is not an argument; it is a debating point (as some who offer it know): it is a form of reductio ad absurdum, the rhetorical trick of extending an opponents claim until it yields an absurd result, in this case the absurd result that follows if we are required to break off relations with universities housed in nations whose human rights record we find questionable: on this reasoning, we would have to break off relationships with everyone and there would be no academic exchange at all.

title: An Author Reveals a Twist in His Tale
description: Martin Cruz Smith, author of thrillers like Gorky Park, recently revealed his diagnosis of Parkinsons disease, which he hid for years.
