title: Russia: Greenpeace Detainees Are Transferred
description: Russias prison authorities began transferring 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship from Murmansk to St. Petersburg on Monday, nearly two months after they were arrested following a protest at an offshore oil rig in the Arctic. The move came a day after Foreign Minister Frans Timmermans of the Netherlands, where the ship is registered, expressed hope for a diplomatic resolution to the case but indicated that it could still be weeks away. Russias investigative committee explained the transfers by saying that the courts in Murmansk did not have jurisdiction over the hooliganism charges the 30 face and that the investigating body in charge of the case was in St. Petersburg. The Netherlands has appealed to the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea for the release of the crew and the ship. The courts decision is scheduled for Nov. 22, but Russia has said it would not accept its jurisdiction in this case.

title: New York Looks to Cut Emissions by Private Trash Haulers
description: As aging garbage trucks rumble down the streets of New York, their fumes draw protests from residents and environmental advocates and raise concerns about asthma and other health effects.

title: Why Do Female Chefs Get Overlooked?
Michelle Obama Edges Into a Policy Role on Higher Education
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obama, after nearly five years of evangelizing exercise and good eating habits, will begin a new initiative on Tuesday that seeks to increase the number of low-income students who pursue a college degree. The goals of the program reflect the first ladys own life and will immerse her more directly in her husbands policies.

title: In Challenge, Former Rebels in Libya Form Own Oil Company
description: Former rebels who fought the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and are now challenging Libyas shaky central government have announced the creation of their own oil company to sell crude from oil fields and port terminals they currently occupy.

title: List of 25 Artworks Seized in Germany Released
description: The German authorities early Tuesday released a list of 25 of the 1,400 or so works of art the authorities confiscated from a Munich apartment said to be that of the son of a dealer who had been hired to acquire artworks for the Nazis during World War II.

title: Lawyer for Ukraine Opposition Leader Is Questioned
description: Prosecutors in Ukraine on Monday questioned the chief defense lawyer of the main political opposition figure, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, on suspicion that he beat his former wife, a development that a spokeswoman for Ms. Tymoshenko called absurd and just another example of the government abusing its prosecutorial powers.

title: Where Credit Is Due
description: Starting from a simple loan, credit markets have featured many innovations as well as costly crises.

title: Super PAC Gets Early Start on Pushing for a 2016 Clinton Campaign
description: In the 2008 presidential primary campaign, Mitch Stewart devoted himself to defeating Hillary Rodham Clinton, overcoming the advantages of a well-funded Democratic front-runner through grass-roots organizing, and propelling Barack Obama to victory.

title: Emotions High at  a Celebratory Lunch for the Mets  James Levine
description: James Levine was wrapping up his remarks at the Metropolitan Opera Guilds Welcome Home, Jimmy! lunch on Monday, which celebrated his return to the Met after an injury sidelined him for two years, when, with a flourish, he ripped his prepared text in two.

title: De Blasio Honors Soldiers and Notes His Familys Military Service
description: Switching gears from the political to the ceremonial, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio saluted Americas soldiers on Monday, while enthusiastically marching in his first official parade since his landslide victory last week.

title: The Next Step in Stop-and-Frisk
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit created a public-policy crisis earlier this month when it stayed the remedies ordered by Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court to correct civil rights violations associated with the New York Police Departments stop-and-frisk policy. And by wrongly removing Judge Scheindlin from the case, the panel sent a chilling message to district court judges who challenge the practices of the police and other government entities. Instead of letting this matter linger, the full court should agree to review the panels ruling.

title: An Overdue Ban on Trans Fats
description: The Food and Drug Administration is moving to ban virtually all artificial trans fats from the American food supply. This long-awaited move should save thousands of lives and potentially billions of dollars in medical and economic costs a year.

title: A Media Services Agency Rides the Health and Wellness Wave
description: THE largest independent media services agency in advertising is expanding its purview again, this time into the booming field of health and wellness marketing.

title: Running in the Dazzle of Neon
description: As fall marathon season unfolds, tens of thousands of runners thud along trails across the country.

title: Redefining the Minimum Wage
description: Business has been brisk at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, with a record number of passengers spending record amounts of money eating and shopping. But for an estimated 6,500 workers at the airport and its nearby hotels, car rental agencies and parking lots, the activity has not translated into economic security, let alone prosperity. Wages for airport-related jobs average an estimated $11 an hour, ranging from less than $10 an hour for airline contractors, like baggage handlers and cabin cleaners, to about $13 an hour for car-rental employees.

title: Iran Nuclear Talks: Unfinished, but Alive
description: The inconclusive negotiations over the weekend on Irans nuclear program were disappointing, but two critical points have mostly been ignored. First, diplomacy takes work, and agreements rarely flow seamlessly from beginning to end. Second, if all those inveighing against any deal  namely members of Congress, Israel and Saudi Arabia  see the weekend results as a new opportunity to sabotage it, what is the alternative?

title: New Consoles on the Way, but Gaming Isnt the Same
description: The new video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft about to hit store shelves are almost certain to be hot holiday gifts this year. The uncertainty for the games business is: What happens after Santa leaves?

title: Jury to Decide How Much More Samsung Must Pay Apple in Patent Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Samsung Electronics lost an important patent battle with Apple last year. A new trial expected to start this week will determine how much Samsung has to pay for that loss.

title: After Ugly Campaign, Finding Little Grace in Brooklyn District Attorneys Exit
description: Sam Kellner, a voluble whistle-blower against child sexual abuse in Brooklyns Hasidic community, received a much-dreamed-of phone call last week.

title: U.N. Relief Official to Help Coordinate Aid Efforts
description: The top United Nations relief official flew to the Philippines on Monday to help lead the global response to the powerful typhoon that killed thousands and upended the lives of nearly 10 million people in the countrys midsection. International aid groups mobilized to rush food, water and sanitation supplies to the victims, a struggle in the face of impassable roads, obliterated seaports and severely damaged airstrips.

title: Unlearning Gun Violence
description: In 1995, an epidemiologist named Gary Slutkin returned to the United States from Africa where he had spent the previous decade helping Africans stem the spread of diseases like tuberculosis, AIDS and cholera. I was exhausted, he said in a TED Talk earlier this year. I wanted to come home and take a break.

title: Djokovic Wins Final, but Its Not Last Word
description: LONDON  After a year-end tennis championship that was played amid debate over playing surfaces, host cities and the length of a drug suspension, perhaps a new debate will emerge over who should end the season as No. 1.

title: Typhoon in Philippines Casts Long Shadow Over U.N. Talks on Climate Treaty
description: The typhoon that struck the Philippines produced an outpouring of emotion on Monday at United Nations talks on a global climate treaty in Warsaw, where delegates were quick to suggest that a warming planet had turned the storm into a lethal monster.

title: Oklahoma: Senators Son Dies in Crash Near Tulsa
description: Dr. Perry Inhofe, the son of Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma and ranking member of the Armed Services Committee, was killed in a plane crash on Sunday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel confirmed Monday. Aaron Sauer, an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board, said at a briefing on Monday that only one person was on board the twin-engine plane when it crashed in Owasso,. The plane had taken off from Salina, Kan., and was approaching the Tulsa airport for landing at the time, he said.

title: Yellow Dogs, Iranian Band, Earned Fans Through Intensity and Promise
description: For most aspiring young rock stars, the night two years ago when a music critic walked into a music club in Brooklyn and laid eyes and ears on the intense, dark-haired foursome on the stage might have been their first significant break.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 11, 2013
Knicks Scrimmage Hard and Seek Answers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks reconvened Monday morning at their practice facility, and none of their planned activities turned out to be much fun.

title: Friday, Nov. 8, 2013
description: Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms ever to make landfall, hit the Philippines and began to cut a path of destruction through several islands.

title: Saturday, Nov. 9, 2013
description: The day after Typhoon Haiyan swept through the Philippines, the bodies began to be recovered, and the displaced survivors tried to figure out what to do next.

title: Monday, Nov. 11, 2013
description: Aid crews struggled to get to survivors three days after a storm that was feared to have left tens of thousands of people dead.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 12, 2013
description: Some of them were able to hold on, some were lucky and lived, but most did not.

title: Filipinos in U.S. Feel Helpless as They Try to Contact Kin
description: LOS ANGELES  When the typhoon hit the Philippine city of Ormoc on Friday, Joy Malinao scrambled to get in touch with her brother, who still lives there. But communications in the area were dead.

title: Behind New Yorks New Antismoking Law, a Persistent Councilman
description: A judge had just struck down New Yorks limits on large sugary drinks last March when a fairly obscure city councilman, James F. Gennaro, cornered Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his health commissioner near the refrigerator at Luckys Cafe on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Revitalized Line Boosts Rangers Offense
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault is tinkering daily to carve an identity for his new team. Perhaps his best move early in his first season has been a line combination one would not have predicted in September.

title: Great Expectations for Female Lawyers
description: Twelve years after being interviewed by The New York Times Magazine, five women, who all started their law careers at Debevoise & Plimpton, reflect on ambition, leadership and success.

title: Great Expectations for Female Lawyers
description: On the bright summer morning of Sept. 9, 2001, I picked up the newspaper from my Brooklyn doorstep, just as I did every Sunday. I was 29, newly wed and relocated from Paris.

title: Misery Did Not Work, but Vanity Saved Him
description: As a child, John Cox, 44, did not like getting dirty; he did not like to roughhouse; he did not like a lot of the activities that other boys seemed to love.

title: Giants Face Big Decision Over Nickss Future
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Midway through the second quarter of the Giants victory over the Oakland Raiders on Sunday, the second-year wide receiver Rueben Randle broke to the back of the end zone, where Eli Manning lofted a delicate touch pass over a defender.

title: Kermit Moore, Cellist, Conductor and Composer, Is Dead at 84
description: Kermit Moore, a cellist, conductor and composer who in all three capacities was concerned with music rooted in the black experience, died on Nov. 2 in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: A New Firm Sets Out to Secure Womens Votes for a Vulnerable G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  After months of deliberating over how to better appeal to Hispanic and other minority voters, some Republicans believe their party is overlooking another dire demographic challenge: women.

title: Corrections: November 12, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Domo Arigato
description: Todays constructor, Mike Doran, created an alliterative theme with one sucker punch of an ending. I was able to waltz through most of the theme answers except for the last one, and I think youll see what I mean after you solve it.

title: Alderson Delivers More Laughs, but Few Definitive Answers
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Sandy Alderson stood there grinning, surrounded by a group of reporters in a hotel lobby Monday night, at the start of the annual general managers meetings. The off-season the Mets had pointed toward, the one their fans had been waiting for, was getting going. Alderson was asked what he had done thus far.

title: Insurers Press for Way Around Healthcare.gov
description: Some major health insurers are so worried about the Obama administrations ability to fix its troubled health care website that they are pushing the government to create a shortcut that would allow them to enroll people entitled to subsidies directly rather than through the federal system.

title: One Step Forward, One Step Back
description: The double doors part to reveal five dancers, looking right at you, drenched in bright white light. From left to right, they are Robert Steijn, Biba Bell, Hristoula Harakas, Andros Zins-Browne and the choreographer, Maria Hassabi.

title: Spying Scandal Alters U.S. Ties With Allies and Raises Talk of Policy Shift
description: BERLIN  Just as European and American negotiators resumed work on a groundbreaking trade accord meant to tie their two continents closer together, Ren Obermann, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, the German telecommunications giant, told a cybersecurity conference in Germany on Monday that his company was working to keep electronic message traffic from unnecessarily crossing the Atlantic, where it could fall into the hands of the National Security Agency.

title: New York City Putting Bus Routes Out for Bid
description: The Bloomberg administration said on Monday that the city would save $400 million over several years by awarding new contracts for thousands of school bus routes, the focus of a bruising fight with the drivers union and a monthlong strike this year.

title: Mauritania Confronts Long Legacy of Slavery
description: BOUTILIMIT, Mauritania  The protesters gathered in front of the low-slung police station, yelling No to Slavery and Freedom. They had come from across the country to demand the arrest of a family accused of holding a slave since childhood, but they elicited little more than dispassionate stares from the police officers sitting silently before them. The subprefect of the district went to take a nap in the afternoon heat.

title: Bishops Are Urged to Expand Priorities
description: BALTIMORE  Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, in his final address as president of the nations Roman Catholic bishops, called on them Monday to take up the cause of Christians in places like Iraq, Syria, Nigeria and India who are persecuted and killed for their faith.

title: Messages to and From Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan
description: Updated 7:35 a.m., Nov. 12 The messages to loved ones from survivors of Typhoon Haiyan were scrawled on paper plates and scraps of paper. Jiggy Manicad collected them as he reported on the devastation from Tacloban for a Philippines television station and took them back to Manila on Sunday. When GMA News broadcast and posted them online, he delivered what some families, unable to reach friends and relatives since Friday, were desperate to hear.

title: 3 People Are Killed in Car Crashes
description: Three people were killed on Monday in car crashes in Queens and East Harlem, the police said.

title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Collective Bargaining Law
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Monday heard arguments on the constitutionality of a 2011 law that all but eliminated collective bargaining for most public employees.

title: Nets Polish Up Their Brooklyn
description: The Nets are beginning their second year as Brooklyn tenants, and their effort to blend in took them to a far corner of the borough Monday.

title: Back and Forth in Undecided Virginia Attorney General Race
description: In the week since Election Day, the lead in Virginias razor-thin, still undecided attorney generals race has seesawed. First the Democrat, Mark R. Herring, was up by 32. Then the Republican, Mark D. Obenshain, went ahead by 55 as of Saturday night. He was ahead by 17 Sunday night.

title: After Watching Rivals, Jets Turn Focus to the Bills
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets bye week over, Willie Colon returned to the teams practice facility Monday feeling revitalized, a little Bahamian sand in his dreadlocks, and thinking about advice he considers relevant at this point in the season. Colon spent seven years in Pittsburgh, where his coach, Mike Tomlin, would tell the Steelers, Theres no reason to look into your neighbors house.

title: Pictures of Typhoon Haiyans Wrath
description: Typhoon Haiyan, which cut a destructive path across the Philippines, is believed by some climatologists to be the strongest storm to ever make landfall.

title: Official at Health Site Says He Didnt Know of Potential Risk
description: WASHINGTON  The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace has told congressional investigators that he was not aware of tests that indicated potential security flaws in the system, which opened to the public on Oct. 1.

title: Early Phillips Auction Draws Solid Sales for Contemporary Pieces
description: This weeks high-stakes contemporary art auctions got off to a solid, though unexciting, start at Phillips on Monday night. Although there were some disappointments, there were also some record prices for artists, including the Japanese avant-garde painter Kazuo Shiraga; the American installation artist, performance artist and sculptor David Hammons; as well as some of todays trendier names, like Jacob Kassay, Nate Lowman and Lucien Smith.

title: A Face-Off Outside Dallas in the Escalating Battle Over Texas Gun Culture
description: HOUSTON  A small meeting of a group seeking tougher gun laws was interrupted Saturday at a suburban Dallas restaurant when the woman who helped organize it saw something outside that startled her: at least two dozen men and women in the parking lot with shotguns, hunting rifles, AR-15s and AK-47s.

title: Poverty, Government and Social Class
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Word of the Day | vigor
description: vigor \vi-gr\ noun

title: Destroying in Order to Build
description: As the populations of many former industrial cities dwindle, buildings are being razed rather than raised to better position the cities for growth.

title: Blighted Cities Prefer Razing to Rebuilding
description: BALTIMORE  Shivihah Smiths East Baltimore neighborhood, where he lives with his mother and grandmother, is disappearing. The block one over is gone. A dozen rowhouses on an adjacent block were removed one afternoon last year. And on the corner a few weeks ago, a pair of houses that were damaged by fire collapsed. The city bulldozed those and two others, leaving scavengers to pick through the debris for bits of metal and copper wire.

title: Intersection: New York City Union Square
description: Cara Araneta, 32, said the style of Union Square is a mix of uptown and downtown. Her personal wardrobe is influenced by mens wear and Wong Kar-wai films.

title: Iranian Musicians Shot Dead in Brooklyn
description: The Iranian indie band the Yellow Dogs fled Tehran so that they could live and play their music free of fear and repression. But in New York, two of the band's members met sudden, violent deaths.

title: With Hard Sell, Big-Ticket Art Comes to Auction
description: The pressure to sell was so great that Christies used the word masterpiece three times in the first three paragraphs of its catalog essay promoting a Francis Bacon triptych that it hopes to auction on Tuesday for at least $85 million.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 1:30 A.M. (Sundance) SWIMMING POOL (2003) An icy English mystery writer (Charlotte Rampling, above) in a midcareer rut is plunged into hot water under the Mediterranean sun when her editors wanton teenage daughter (Ludivine Sagnier) and then a dead body show up at a vacation home in France in this thriller directed by Franois Ozon. Swimming Pool, Mr. Ozons first English-language film (with a bit of French thrown in for local color), is simultaneously a thoroughly mannered, mischievously artificial confection and an acute piece of psychological realism, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Whose psychology, and which reality, remain ambiguous even after the tart, delicious final twist. The movie, he added, is alluringly insubstantial, like the light and air of the Luberon. You cant hold onto it, but it lingers in your senses and plays tricks with your memory.

title: Michigan: Autopsy Shows Fatal Wound to the Face
description: Renisha McBride, a 19-year-old black woman whose death in a Detroit suburb has sparked protests from civil rights groups, was killed by a shotgun wound to the face, but not at close range, according to an autopsy report releasedMondaythat ruled it a homicide. Ms. McBride was killed Nov. 2 on the porch of a home in Dearborn Heights. Her family believes she was seeking help after an accident. Demonstrators have called for the arrest of the homeowner, who is white, but no charges have been brought. The Wayne County prosecutor is expected to review evidence this week.

title: Google Glass Will Expand Its Features Into Music
description: To sell Glass, its augmented-reality form of eyewear, Google has already tried to make it a fashion accessory and a must-have video device for any parent or sky diver. Now it is also presenting this $1,500 piece of wearable technology as a way to interact with music.

title: Germanys Lack of Reciprocity
description: Huge tensions over the ECB rate cut, with a split on the board and many German economists protesting. As usual, a lot of it is about the perception that those lazy southern Europeans are getting a free ride:

title: News Quiz | November 12, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Israel Increasingly Courting China as an Ally
description: As an Israeli diplomat, Dore Gold has sat down with his countrys prime ministers, United States presidents and Palestinian negotiators, all in search of that elusive solution to the Middle East conflict.

title: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 12, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: Seeking Maos Matrimonial Blessing
description: Shaoshan, the birthplace of Mao Zedong, is no stranger to visitors: Last year, 8.5 million tourists journeyed to this small, county-level city in the mountains of Hunan Province. But on the morning of Nov. 10, with just over a month until the highly anticipated 120th anniversary of the chairmans birth, Shaoshan hosted a new kind of pilgrim: 50 couples from across China who came to the city to participate in a Collective Red Wedding.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Obamas Portable Zone of Secrecy
description: In Obamas Portable Zone of Secrecy (Some Assembly Required), Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt write about security precautions that the president and other senior officials must take when traveling abroad.

title: Iranian Official Faults Kerry and France for Breakdown in Talks
description: LONDON  The Iranian foreign minister turned to a Twitter account late Monday to challenge Secretary of State John Kerry over the failure of weekend talks in Geneva to produce agreement on Tehrans nuclear program.

title: Rising Despair as Officials Struggle to Get Aid to  Typhoon Victims
description: CEBU, the Philippines  An American aircraft carrier headed to the Philippines on Tuesday on an emergency mission to help victims of Typhoon Haiyan as the situation on the islands became increasingly desperate, with food and water supplies running low and bodies lying uncollected in the streets of at least one devastated city.

title: Mayor Ed Lee: Tech Workers Are Not Robots
description: One of your first encounters with San Francisco city government was when you fought against the demolition of an S.R.O. hotel.  Four chains of people wrapped their arms around the block to prevent its destruction. Horses came in, nightsticks, everything. We never allowed the development to happen, by the way.

title: Shales Effect on Oil Supply Is Forecast to Be Brief
description: WASHINGTON  The boom in oil from shale formations in recent years has generated a lot of discussion that the United States could eventually return to energy self-sufficiency, but according to a report released Tuesday by the International Energy Agency, production of such oil in the United States and worldwide will provide only a temporary respite from reliance on the Middle East.

title: Switzerlands Proposal to Pay People for Being Alive
description: This fall, a truck dumped eight million coins outside the Parliament building in Bern, one for every Swiss citizen. It was a publicity stunt for advocates of an audacious social policy that just might become reality in the tiny, rich country. Along with the coins, activists delivered 125,000 signatures  enough to trigger a Swiss public referendum, this time on providing a monthly income to every citizen, no strings attached. Every month, every Swiss person would receive a check from the government, no matter how rich or poor, how hardworking or lazy, how old or young. Poverty would disappear. Economists, needless to say, are sharply divided on what would reappear in its place  and whether such a basic-income scheme might have some appeal for other, less socialist countries too.

title: Do You Worry Colleges or Employers Might Read Your Social Media Posts Someday?
description: Facebook, Twitter and other social media sites have become an integral part of teenage culture. Yet the snarky comment or inappropriate picture we share with our friends just might not project the image we want the rest of the world to see, especially as we get older. How careful are you online?

title: Checking In to a New Life in America
description: The rooms and the corridors are all the same, said the photographer Gabriele Stabile, but the stories that inhabit these rooms are all different.

title: Indonesia Central Bank Increases Rate, Again
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias central bank made a surprise move on Tuesday to contain the countrys current-account deficit by raising its benchmark interest rate by 0.25 percentage point, to 7.5 percent.

title: Chinas Leaders Urge More Market Control of Economy
description: Chinese Communist Party leaders emerged from a four-day conference on Tuesday with vows to push through changes that will give market competition a decisive role in the economy and a plan to establish a new committee to oversee national security.

title: New York Today: A Hispanic Police Commissioner?
description: Updated 12:34 p.m. | Heard of Rafael Pieiro?

title: Quebec's Tea Party Moment
description: MONTREAL  In Quebec, Canadas second most populous province, the governing Parti Qubcois plans to prohibit government employees from wearing overt and conspicuous religious symbols while on the job. Everyone from judges to teachers would have to doff their hijabs, kippas, niqabs, turbans and outsize crucifixes. Day care centers would be forbidden to serve kosher or halal foods. Government workers would be allowed to cover their faces only for weather-related  not religious  reasons.

title: Rineke Dijkstras Moments of Photographic Transformation
description: For last weekends article about the impact earlier puberty is having on the Leipzig boys choir, we asked the Dutch photographer Rineke Dijkstra to take pictures of the singers. She has a longstanding interest in what she calls moments of transformation in people. Her past projects have included, for example, a series of portraits of Almerisa, a Bosnian girl she has photographed every couple of years since meeting her at a refugee center in the Netherlands nearly 20 years ago, as well as Olivier, whose training as a French Foreign Legion officer she documented over several years. This time, in addition to taking pictures of members of the boys choir, Dijkstra also made a short film of some of them rehearsing Mendelssohns Jauchzet dem Herrn, alle Welt.

title: Another Blow for Dolphins Already Shaky Line
description: Off the field, the Richie Incognito-Jonathan Martin dispute has dominated the headlines in Miami. On the field, the absence of the two players allowed the Tampa Bay Buccaneers defensive line to dominate the Dolphins offense on Monday night.

title: Daily Report: New Consoles Enter a Changed Gaming Market
description: Consoles have been the thumping heart of the video game industry for decades. But the new PlayStation 4 from Sony and the Xbox One from Microsoft, both almost certain to be hot holiday gifts this year, will enter a landscape reshaped by tablets, smartphones and Facebook, all of which provide games at a lower price and in greater abundance, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: Distress Grows for Philippine Typhoon Victims Who Cant Get Aid, or Get Out
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Increasingly desperate survivors of Typhoon Haiyan mobbed the shattered airport here on Tuesday, begging for food, water or a flight to escape the chaotic aftermath of the storm, which flattened this city of 220,000 last week and ravaged vast swaths of the countrys midsection.

title: Murder in Goa Shakes Tourist Paradise
description: Oh, you have moved to Goa! You must be having so much fun. This is the first reaction from most of my friends, who instantly picture me sitting on a beach and sipping beer in my home state.

title: Business for Sale: Would You Pay $170,000 for This Restaurant?
description: In my posts, I occasionally take a look at businesses for sale, which can offer interesting lessons for both buyers and sellers. For this post well look at a restaurant thats on the market in Floridas Tampa Bay area. As with my earlier posts on businesses for sale, I have no stake in the sale of the business. Nor do I certify that any of the information provided by the broker, Paul Gorny, is accurate.

title: Cornelius Gurlitt Seen Headed to Munich Airport
description: MUNICH  Cornelius Gurlitt, the 80-year-old recluse who kept roughly 1,400 artworks hidden in his Munich home, left his apartment building Tuesday and took a taxi to the airport, witnesses said. It was not clear where he was heading. A woman who escorted Mr Gurlitt to the taxi and then drove off with him appeared to be Ozlem Gezer, an investigative journalist for Der Spiegel, Germanys leading news magazine. The magazine declined to comment.

title: Obama Nominates Treasury Official as Top Derivatives Regulator
description: Timothy G. Massad swept up the mess of the last financial crisis.

title: South Africans Didn't Die for This
description: Cape Town  Theres a reason photographers like to take pictures of Cape Town, South Africas second largest city, from out over the Atlantic Ocean. From this vantage point, cerulean waters give way to a long line of luxurious sea-facing apartments that hug the Atlantic seaboard. Others nestle on the cliffs of Bantry Bay and overlook the sandy beaches of Clifton. To the left, the harbor, city center and manicured parks nestle at the foot of citys most famous peak, Table Mountain.

title: The Poverty and Population Factors Behind Vast Typhoon Losses
description: I encourage you to read every word in Seth Borensteins excellent Associated Press overview of the factors behind the vast toll in the central Philippines from Typhoon Hainan  most of which are related to population density and poverty in a disaster hot spot. Heres an excerpt and link:

title: More Style Choices
description: In our recent stylebook revisions, we have accepted as standard a few forms that until now were still treated as colloquial or informal. In some cases, these changes just formalize what we had already been doing in practice.

title: In Performance: Brian Cross of The Snow Geese
description: Sharr Whites new play The Snow Geese stars Mary-Louise Parker as a World War I-era widow dealing with her fractious family after the death of her husband. In this scene her 18-year-old son, Arnold, played by Brian Cross, chastises his mother for the familys questionable financial decisions. The show, directed by Daniel Sullivan, continues through Dec. 15 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: Obamas Pick to Lead Trading Commission
description: President Obama will nominate Timothy G. Massad as the new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Tuesday, choosing a senior Treasury Department official to run an agency that polices some of Wall Streets riskiest activity, Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Protess report in DealBook. Mr. Massad, if confirmed by the Senate, would succeed Gary Gensler, who is credited with turning one of Wall Streets laxest regulators into one of its most aggressive.

title: The Gun Report: November 12, 2013
description: On Saturday, four members of the Texas chapter of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America held a lunch meeting in Arlington, and nearly 40 armed members of Open Carry Texas, a gun rights advocacy group, waited outside. Police monitored the incident at the Blue Mesa Grill,but took no action because state law allows people to openly carry guns.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Shinola Macbook Sleeve
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Nomura to Add More Bankers to Its Americas Arm
description: With more Manhattan office space at its disposal, Nomura of Japan seems intent to keep trying to fill it.

title: Robin Hood in Varanasi
description: On an August afternoon I arrived in Varanasi for the shooting of a film. I was returning to the fabled city after eight years.

title: Rescuing a Towed Car
description: Dear Diary:

title: Diller on Banks, Snowden and His Broadcasting Start-Up
description: Barry Diller is not known to be particularly shy about speaking his mind. And as the leadoff speaker on Tuesday at DealBooks Opportunities for Tomorrow Conference, he held true to form.

title: Trouble for the Contraception Mandate
description: With a ruling on Friday by the Seventh Circuit, a total of five federal circuit courts have weighed in on religious challenges to the health care laws contraception mandate.

title: U.N. Appeals for $301 Million Toward Typhoon Relief
description: GENEVA  The United Nations appealed Tuesday for $301 million in emergency assistance to help millions of people in the Philippines affected by the typhoon that struck on Friday.

title: Lawsuit Over Sale of Dia Artwork Is Withdrawn
description: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation who have been vehemently opposed to the organizations decision to raise money by selling several notable pieces from its collection have decided to withdraw a lawsuit filed last week to block the sale. The founders, Heiner Friedrich and Fariha de Menil Friedrich, said in a statement through their lawyers Tuesday morning that while they consider the sale utterly wrong and against Dias mission, the foundation is our precious child, and we do not wish to continue to oppose it through legal action.

title: The Wild Feathers Pay Tribute to Tom Pettys Listen to Her Heart
description: al Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Michigan Senator Critical of Continuing Litany of Deception on Wall Street
description: Senator Carl Levin has some choice words for Wall Street.

title: To Honor an Artist in Miami Beach, Sandals and a T-Shirt
description: Tracey Emin, one of Britains most prominent contemporary artists, will have her first United States museum exhibition beginning on Dec. 4  the day before the start of Art Basel Miami Beach  at the Museum of Contemporary Art North Miami.

title: The Inequality of Climate Change
description: Typhoon Haiyan has left an estimated 10,000 dead and hundreds of thousands homeless in the Philippines. And it has once again underscored for many development experts a cruel truth about climate change: It will hit the worlds poorest the hardest.

title: Fighting to Stop an Entitlement Before It Takes Hold, and Expands
description: WASHINGTON  Underlying fierce Republican efforts to stop President Obamas health care law and the White House drive to save it is a simple historical reality: Once major entitlement programs get underway, they quickly become embedded in American life. And then they grow.

title: Justices Weigh Role Drug Played in a Fatal Cocktail
description: WASHINGTON  Joshua Bankas prodigious appetite for drugs killed him. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court considered whether to hold a drug dealer who had sold heroin to Mr. Banka responsible for his death.

title: A Fine or Do Time?
description: JERUSALEM  The Knesset is nearing a moment of truth: It has to vote by the end of the month whether to finally draft ultra-Orthodox men into the Israeli army. A proposed law that would lift a long-standing exception allowing Haredi men to avoid military service while they studied the Torah seemed all but ready to pass. Until a last-minute dispute over what to do with anyone who tries to dodge their duty.

title: Scion of Art Family, in Court, Admits Role With a Gambling Ring
description: Hillel Nahmad, the jet-setting scion of a family whose gallery is a pivotal force in the art market, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to a single federal gambling charge, part of a sweeping racketeering indictment handed up in the spring that also charged several reputed Russian mob figures.

title: After Hours | At Performa, Ryan McNamaras Pop-Rock Haunted House
description: The artist Ryan McNamara has become known in recent years for twisting uber-familiar pop references into his party-ready performance pieces. At Robert Wilsons annual Watermill Benefit in 2011, he and a partner sang Islands in the Stream, the Dolly Parton-Kenny Rogers duet, while buried up to their necks in the ground. At the 2010 Whitney Biennial he transformed a corner of the museum into a karaoke jam called the Whitney Houston Biennial. McNamara billed MEM: A Story Ballet About the Internet, the elaborate, multidancer piece he created for this years Performa festival as a choreographic exploration of the online world as a space of engagement.

title: Justice Dept. Clears Merger of 2 Airlines
description: After months of setbacks and delays, the merger of American Airlines and US Airways to create the worlds largest airline became all but certain on Tuesday after the airlines reached a settlement with the Justice Department just two weeks before a scheduled trial.

title: Image of the Day: November 12
Bishops Select Two Leaders Who Reflect New Tone Set by Pope
description: BALTIMORE  The nations Roman Catholic bishops on Tuesday chose as leaders of the bishops conference two prelates whose pastoral approach evokes the new tone for the church set by Pope Francis.

title: A Husbands Fertility Journey
description: After asking about how Im doing with I.V.F., my friends and family always want to know, how is Solomon handling this? Although my husband considers himself a private person, he agreed to answer some questions.

title: Today in Small Business: Tracking Online Ads
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Make It Whiskey in a Barrel, Neat
description: The old-fashioned served at Middle Branch, a stylish two-tier cocktail bar in Midtown Manhattan, is unlike any other old-fashioned in the world. Its not the recipe that makes it special, or the house-made cherry or the custom ice, or the way the bartender prepares the drink. Its the whiskey: Elijah Craig bourbon.

title: Loeb Discusses His Strategy, Discloses Stake in FedEx
description: Updated, 3:22 p.m. | Despite a public scolding from George Clooney, the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb does not have too many regrets about his activist investment strategy.

title: Cant Go Without: Garrett Oliver
description: The brewmaster of Brooklyn Brewery shares his packing list for a visit to Stockholm.

title: Drinking Beer in Sweden
description: In the mid-1980s, before microbrew was even a term, let alone a trend, in the United States, Garrett Oliver, a brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, began creating beer in his home in New York City just so he could drink something other than the thin, fizzy yellow liquid that bars served at the time.

title: Settlement in Airlines Merger Lawsuit
description: A merger of the American Airlines and US Airways, announced earlier this year, would create a new behemoth and would help lift Americans parent company out of a two-year-old bankruptcy case.

title: Sequoia Capital Invests in Berlin Start-Up
description: LONDON  For many European start-ups, connections to Silicon Valley are still viewed as a sign of success.

title: A Vacant Icon
description: The last full-time employee in the tallest building in Rhode Island has grown accustomed to the 26 stories of emptiness.

title: Pivotal Steps Up to the Cloud
description: Pivotal, the company that EMC formed to build applications in the cloud computing era, is starting to deliver the goods. Now well see if theres a market for what it wants to sell.

title: Storied Providence Skyscraper, Now Empty, Seeks a Future
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  The last full-time employee in the tallest building in Rhode Island has grown accustomed to the 26 stories of emptiness. He doesnt even hear the absence anymore  that silent roar of business not transacted.

title: How Do We Judge Books Written Under Pseudonyms?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Daniel Mendelsohn on what readers and critics reactions say about pseudonymous works.

title: First Snow, 8:30 A.M.
description: New York saw its first snow of the season on Tuesday morning, as small flakes fluttered from the sky during the morning commute. There was no accumulation, and temperate sidewalks and above-freezing air temperatures quickly turned the flakes into a mere memory. Fortunately, our photographers were quick on the draw.

title: By a Spire, Manhattan Regains a Title From Chicago
description: For four decades, Chicagoans have been able to one-up New Yorkers on at least one measure: The City of the Big Shoulders had the tallest building in the United States.

title: Rubenstein Not Planning a Retirement Party Just Yet
description: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder and co-chief executive of one of the worlds largest private equity firms, the Carlyle Group, may be 64 years old, but he says he doesnt plan to retire soon.

title: YouTube Cleaning Up Its Comments
description: Its sometimes a little frightening to read the comments on a YouTube video. Lets say youve just watched a cat video and want to find out how others responded to that moment when one kitten massaged another. You scroll down and find  a large helping of inanity as well as racism, sexism, anti-Semitism, homophobia and pure nonsense. Its well known that the YouTube comments section is a virtual septic tank. In the immortal words of BuzzFeed: YouTube IS the room with the million monkeys and the million typewriters.

title: Obama in Bind Trying to Keep Health Law Vow
description: WASHINGTON  Under intense bipartisan pressure to answer mounting consumer complaints about the botched health care rollout, White House officials are struggling to make good on President Obamas promise that Americans can keep their insurance coverage without undermining the new health law or adding unaffordable costs.

title: Bharara on His Wealth, Prosecutions and Pulp Fiction
description: Updated, 1:56 p.m. | Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, has no plans to retire in the near future.

title: Despite Bumps, Tire Deal Still Makes Sense
description: The buyout of Cooper Tire and Rubber hasnt gone flat yet.

title: Not Giving In to Age or Rangers, Brodeur Tops Lundqvist
description: The old guy still has it. Martin Brodeur was superb in goal Tuesday night in a long line of duels with Henrik Lundqvist. He robbed Ryan Callahan and Derek Stepan alone in front, headed away a batted shot from Chris Kreider, got into a brief slap fight with Mats Zuccarello and all night long looked like a goalie far younger than his 41 years.

title: In Our Pages: November 13
description: 1938: Typhoid Mary Dies

title: Chicago for Kids
description: Child-friendly attractions in Chicago.

title: Three Journalists at The Times Are Departing
description: Three journalists at The New York Times on Tuesday announced plans to leave the newspaper.

title: Food Matters | The Professional Women Who Hunt, Shoot and Gut Their Dinners
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Steel Hammer and The Christians Planned for Humana Festival
description: Steel Hammer, a new play built around the composer Julia Wolfes kaleidoscopic set of variations on the folk song John Henry, is among the works to be performed at the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., next year.

title: Whats In It | Pumpkin Flavor
description: Pumpkin-flavored products are on pace to have their best sales year yet. But the industrys biggest secret about these products is that there is often little or no pumpkin in them.

title: That Pinch of Pumpkin
description: THE FLAVOR CALLED PUMPKIN is surging toward a record season in processed foods, with Mars introducing Pumpkin M&Ms, Planters dusting pumpkin spice on its almonds and Starbucks bringing back its annual Pumpkin Latte. Sales of last years pumpkin offerings climbed nearly 20 percent to more than $290 million, Nielsen reports, and people in the flavor business say the trend has a powerful demographic wind at its back: strong popularity among millennials.

title: Fairy Tale Opera Leads to Fairy Tale Career Break
description: The machine is coming back to the Metropolitan Opera, which plans to mount a revival of Robert Lepages high-tech, polarizing and glitch-prone Ring cycle in the 2018-19 season to showcase its next Brnnhilde: the soprano Christine Goerke. She was offered the role after her breakout success last week in Strausss fairy tale opera Die Frau Ohne Schatten.

title: Excerpt: 'Patron Saint of Sea Monsters'
description: A scene from Marlane Meyers new play at Playwrights Horizons.

title: Finally, a Place to Buy a Condo and a Basquiat
description: Walk into Aby Rosens new gallery at 530 Park Avenue and you might think youre in a real estate sales office.

title: Silent Night, Pulitzer Winner, to Air on PBS
description: Silent Night, the opera by Kevin Puts that won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 2012, will have its television premiere on Dec. 13, when PBS broadcasts a performance by the Minnesota Opera, recorded during the works world-premiere run in 2011.

title: A Quiet Release for the iPad Mini
description: The release of Apples new iPad Mini on Tuesday lacked the finesse of a typical Apple product release. It also lacked a lot of the pomp.

title: Twitter Introduces Tool to Make Collecting and Sharing Tweets Easier
description: Twitter introduced a tool Tuesday, called custom timelines, that allows its users to drag and drop tweets to form custom lists of Twitter messages on whatever topic interests them.

title: To Top JPMorgan Deal Maker, Mergers Still Look Strong
description: Many in the deal sector have been pessimistic about a recovery in the business of mergers and acquisitions.

title: Program Seeks to Nurture Data Science Culture at Universities
description: The modern flood of data comes in a many forms  sensor data, genomic data, web click streams and credit card transactions, to name a few. The disparate data sources are often called silos, suggesting the challenge of mingling different data sets to generate insights.

title: Rich Risotto, Full-Bodied Wine
description: A dish this rich requires a similarly broad, full-bodied wine, like a sumptuous chardonnay, something from the Cte de Beaune, Pouilly-Fuiss, California or Oregon, even Australia, rather than a whipsaw Chablis or other lean example. Within that group,the best choices would be textured and mineral rather than overtly oaky or flamboyantly fruity.

title: Michelle Obama Talks Education
description: The first lady, Michelle Obama, spoke to students at Bell Multicultural High School in Washington about the importance of education.

title: Fink Worries About Implications of Health Care Law
description: Many Americans are worried about how their health care will change under the Affordable Care Act. Laurence D. Fink, the chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, one of the largest money management firms, is worried about those worries.

title: Poets Remember Seamus Heaney
description: When Seamus Heaney died in August, at 74, he was hailed as a poet of unusual grace and humility, an ambassador for poetry whose reach stretched far beyond the rural Ireland of his most famous verse. And since then, the tributes have kept coming, most recently on Monday night at Cooper Unions Great Hall, where some 20 poets and friends gathered to read favorite Heaney poems to a packed house.

title: When Facing Activist Investors, Fight Has Gone 24/7
description: When Carl C. Icahn sought to oppose a buyout of Dell this year, he turned to his classic playbook, issuing impassioned proclamations to shareholders.

title: What Should Hillary Fear?
description: Noam Scheibers big New Republic essay on the idea of an Elizabeth Warren challenge to Hillary Clinton in 2016 is an illuminating window into the liberal mind circa 2013 and a fascinating political portrait-cum-psychobiography of Warren herself. What it is not, however, is a convincing argument that the presumptive Democratic nominee has anything significant to fear from a Warren candidacy right now, let alone that the Massachusetts Senator is anything like a nightmare for Team Clinton. Dave Weigel does a good job highlighting one of the key factors that Scheibers analysis (rather oddly) leaves out: The demographics of the Democratic primary electorate, which made the Obama insurgency different from pretty much every liberal primary insurgency before it:

title: Wheelies: The Mexican Sentra Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

title: Rising Despair as Officials Struggle to Get Aid to Victims
description: The people of Tacloban, the hardest hit city, have been struggling largely on their own as they wait for relief operations to reach them.

title: Israeli Move Over Housing Poses a Threat to Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  The troubled Middle East peace talks that started this summer threatened to collapse on Tuesday over what the Israeli government described as a routine bureaucratic move by its housing ministry to start long-term planning for 20,000 new apartments in West Bank settlements.

title: An iPhone Case Hemingway Would Love
description: Ive been a fan of Moleskine notebooks for years because of their rugged appearance and warm textures, which invite me to jot my thoughts down. But with the advent of smartphones, carrying the notebooks around seemed redundant because I could make notes digitally. So I ditched the notebooks for a smooth, cold iPhone.

title: Investor Says Mens Wearhouse Will Review Merger With Jos. A. Bank
description: Mens Wearhouse and its investment bankers plan to review a number of strategic options, including an unsolicited $2.3 billion takeover bid by rival Jos. A. Bank, a big investor in the retailer said on Tuesday.

title: Headphones Turn Up the Bass, Their Way
description: Headphone manufacturers may finally realize that imitating the thumping bass sound of Beats headphones does not automatically lead to Beats-size success.

title: Fall Fashion for the iPhone
description: Fall is the season when tweed jackets become fashionable outerwear again, and thats apparently the case for phones too.

title: Art Matters | A Medieval Romanian City With Major Art Talent
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The View From Saturn
description: On July 19, NASAs Cassini spacecraft looked back from the shadow of Saturn to take a picture of the ringed planet in all its glory and indeed the entire inner solar system. Knowing that the Earth would also be in the field of view  the third time that our planet has sat for its portrait from the outer solar system, Cassinis managers asked everyone to smile. Apparently, many of us did, although you might not be able to pick yourself out of the cosmic crowd in this image released by NASA and the Cassini team on Tuesday.

title: Sushi Dojo and Kurumazushi
description: Inside two sushi restaurants: a new place leaning toward poppy neo-disco in the East Village, and an older, more sedate establishment in Midtown.

title: Living Along Central Park North
description: The areas population, historically dominated by blacks, has diversified at an even faster clip than Central Harlem as a whole.

title: How the Word North Affects Prices
description: The moment Gary Davis popped his head out of the subway station on Central Park North and Lenox Avenue in 2004, he understood he was looking at an extraordinary spot. An architect and real estate developer, he had been invited to the block by a lawyer for the owner of a two-story corner building there, and though Mr. Davis recalls not being very excited about Harlem, he was quick to see the sites potential. He then sent a photographer 120 feet above the street in a bucket attached to a crane arm; the resulting pictures showed breathtaking panoramic views of Central Park and miles beyond.

title: Philadelphia Schools See Cash in Old Classrooms
description: PHILADELPHIA  The financially troubled school district here is seeking buyers for more than two dozen school buildings that it shuttered last summer in one of the countrys biggest school closing programs.

title: Dance Moves From the Deep Sea
description: Disco music with raw fish in the East Village may not strike you as a winning formula unless you remember when Avenue A had what was probably the only sushi bar in the city with a mirror ball and a D.J. booth. Everybody called it Disco Sushi, and I loved it for reasons that had nothing to do with the food. I had eaten enough good sushi to know I couldnt afford it. But cold rice, fake wasabi and sinewy fish mattered much less when vinyl records and the mirror ball were spinning, the tables were filling up with musicians waiting for a 1 a.m. gig at Brownies, and we were all on our third round of sake bombs.

title: Murder in the Midwest
description: The shooting occurred about 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Aug. 4, 1863, halfway between sundown and dark, as one witness described it. The day had been a typically hot one in Indianapolis, but a rain shower in the early evening cooled the air and knocked down the dust. Residents came out of their houses and shops onto the streets. Others ate their suppers or relaxed on their porches after a long day of work.

title: Scene City: Fashion Industry Crowns Young Designers
description: Public School takes top prize at the 10th annual CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund dinner.

title: In a Lemonade Stand, a Transformation of the Corporation
description: Did you see the three guests of honor who rang the opening bell at Twitters debut on the New York Stock Exchange last week?

title: Rethinking the Rise of Inequality
description: Many Americans have come to doubt the proposition that college delivers a path to prosperity.

title: Text to Text | The Gettysburg Address and Why the Civil War Still Matters
description: Updated: Nov. 20, 2013

title: Experts Reshape Treatment Guide for Cholesterol
description: The nations leading heart organizations released new guidelines on Tuesday that will fundamentally reshape the use of cholesterol-lowering statin medicines, which are now prescribed for a quarter of Americans over 40. Patients on statins will no longer need to lower their cholesterol levels to specific numerical targets monitored by regular blood tests, as has been recommended for decades. Simply taking the right dose of a statin will be sufficient, the guidelines say.

title: When Doctors Share With Their Patients
description: At our very first visit, I was overwhelmed by all of the issues my new patient faced. She was nearly 300 pounds and her diabetes was raging out of control. She had asthma, but smoked to ease her anxiety. Her obesity severely limited her mobility, but the constant stress in her life led her to overeat.

title: S.E.C. Tries New Tack in Hedge Fund Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has for the first time employed a new tool to encourage individuals involved in fraud investigations to cooperate by deferring their prosecution.

title: In Sweden, the Fika Experience
description: Coffee is a way of life in Sweden. It is not simply a beverage you grab to go, or something used for a jolt in the morning. Coffee is an experience.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: An Academic Divide
After the Typhoon, the Heartbreak
description: To the Editor:

title: Auction Highlights From Christies
description: Some of the notable works at the Christies sale of postwar and contemporary art on Tuesday night.

title: Finding Fault Everywhere He Looked
description: The radical Irish-American journalist Alexander Cockburn  he called himself Marxish, not Marxist  liked to bomb around Americas blue highways in large, decrepit cars, preferably convertibles, faxing in and later emailing his rowdy political columns (for The Nation, The Village Voice and elsewhere) from the road.

title: 3 Things to Know About the New Cholesterol Guidelines
description: The American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association just released new cholesterol guidelines to reduce atherosclerotic cardiovascular risk - and the change from the previous version, last updated in 2004, is profound. Here are three things you need to know about these new guidelines.

title: Penn Kimball, Journalist Who Sued U.S., Dies at 98
description: Penn Kimball, a journalist and teacher who successfully sued the federal government in a 10-year quest to clear his name after he discovered that secret government files had identified him as a national security risk, died on Friday at a nursing home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 98.

title: Mini-Pies, Smoked Bourbon Sugar and More
description: To Shop: ABC Carpet & Home Adds to Its Menu

title: A Candid Discussion of Dodd-Frank
description: Gary Parr, the vice chairman of Lazard, called the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul law broadly the right approach, but several industry figures still think one of its biggest problems is clarity.

title: First Ladys New Initiative: College, Whatever It Takes
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obama urged high school students on Tuesday to increase the opportunities available to them by pursuing higher education as she kicked off an initiative that seeks to increase the number of low-income students graduating from college and signaled her plans to focus more on administration policy during the presidents second term.

title: Using Food to Make an Off-Campus Area More Inviting
description: Redevelopment along the streets south of Columbia University has long been difficult. Urban renewal schemes, police sweeps and wars on rats have all been deployed since the 1950s with little success.

title: Kennedy Is Sworn In as Japan Envoy, a Post Long Held by Political Notables
description: WASHINGTON  Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of John F. Kennedy and one of President Obamas most prominent supporters, was sworn in Tuesday as the United States ambassador to Japan.

title: A Recharging Industry Rises
description: WASHINGTON  Tens of thousands of new electric cars are zipping into traffic this year, and with them come a trunkful of strategies about how to recharge them.

title: What a Paychecks for Pulses Plan Could, and Couldnt, Do for Families
description: In Switzerland, activists have delivered enough signatures to the government to trigger a public referendum on an audacious proposal: the government would provide a monthly income to every citizen, no strings attached. As Annie Lowrey writes in Switzerlands Proposal to Pay People for Being Alive for The New York Times Magazine:

title: Emotional Speech by Philippine Delegate
description: Excerpts from a statement about Typhoon Haiyan by Naderev Sao, the chief representative of the Philippines at the Warsaw Climate Change Conference.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, Somalia, Cambodia and Vietnam.

title: Elon Musks Next Blue-Sky Idea
description: Elon Musk has built rockets and electric cars. In the future, he may be building airplanes.

title: Italy at a High Speed
description: Test driving a Ferrari in Italy at high speeds may be a dream many car enthusiasts (and adrenaline junkies) share, especially after seeing Ron Howards recent film, the Formula One racing drama Rush.

title: Miki Naftali
description: Mr. Naftali, 51, is the chairman and chief executive of the Naftali Group, a development company focused largely on high-end residential projects in Manhattan. Before starting the company more than two years ago, Mr. Naftali served as the chief executive and president of the Elad Group, a development company based in New York whose projects include the redeveloped Plaza Hotel.

title: No R.S.V.P.? In Rajasthan, India, No Worries
description: In the tiniest of tailor shops in Udaipur, in the northwestern Indian state of Rajasthan, a squad of tailors chaotically fussed over me. It was the peak of autumn wedding season in 2011 and I was being fitted for a sherwani, the traditional Indian garment worn among Rajput aristocracy at Rajasthan weddings. My friend Dianne was standing in a nest of chiffon and georgette, trying on colorful saris. She was debating between the sequined turquoise and the glittery hot pink.

title: Citadels Griffin Advocates Breaking Up Banks
description: Big banks should hope that Kenneth C. Griffin, the founder and chief executive of Citadel, never gets his hands on a magic wand.

title: Pressure Is on Germany to Narrow Its Trade Gap
description: FRANKFURT  Germanys huge trade surplus, a source of pride for Germans but an irritant to the rest of Europe, could undergo much tougher European Union scrutiny, officials in Berlin acknowledged on Tuesday.

title: Rtisserie Georgette Opens on the Upper East Side
description: Headliner

title: Danger to T.S.A. Officials Hovers Over Memorial Service
description: LOS ANGELES  At a memorial service for the federal security official who was killed in a shooting at Los Angeles International Airport, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. promised Tuesday that federal officials would work to hold those responsible accountable and to prevent tragedies like this from happening ever again.

title: Reworking Their Soviet Past
description: The celebrated Conceptual artist Ilya Kabakov, now 80, has spoken extensively about his idea of the total installation, an art form that can bear some resemblance to a meticulously dressed movie set. Its an idea that the art critic and filmmaker Amei Wallach confronts head-on in Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here, a dynamically shot documentary that keeps journeying into the Soviet past as it is remembered and reworked by Mr. Kabakov and his wife and partner, Emilia.

title: In Europe, Thousands of Requests for Facebook Data
description: BRUSSELS  Online surveillance by the United States was the main subject of a hearing on Monday evening organized by the European Parliaments civil liberties committee. But one of the more noteworthy parts of the session was a presentation by a senior Facebook employee who described demands by European Union governments.

title: Live Nation Nears a Deal for Managers of Music Acts
description: Live Nation Entertainment, the giant concert company that includes Ticketmaster, is in advanced negotiations to buy the management companies behind U2 and Madonna, according to several people with direct knowledge of the talks.

title: Fantasy Football Week 11: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
description: Those pesky bye weeks are finally coming to an end soon as fantasy footballs homestretch nears. While you cannot afford to look too far ahead if youre just trying make the playoffs, a smart owner will keep an eye on the waiver wire with those important fantasy playoff weeks in mind.

title: A Singer Whose Context Is Love and Heart
description: SEATTLE  The day in May 2012 that Mary Lambert received the phone call inviting her to collaborate with the hip-hop duo Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, she popped a bottle of Champagne with a saber, kissed the picture of President Obama in her house here, and set to work.

title: For Tumblrs Young Founder, Education in Wall Streets Ways
description: David Karp, the 27-year-old founder of Tumblr, may be a creature of the tech world. But he has had a rapid education in the ways of Wall Street.

title: A Public Memorial Set for Lou Reed
description: For fans of Lou Reed who want to pay tribute to the hard-edged singer, guitar and songwriter who died on October 27: There will be a memorial for him on Thursday at Lincoln Center. A message on Mr. Reeds Facebook page announced that there would be a gathering open to the public  no speeches. No live performances, just Lous voice, guitar music & songs  playing the recordings selected by his family and friends. The memorial is scheduled to last three hours, starting at 1 p.m., at the Paul Milstein Pool and Terrace at Lincoln Center.

title: Essential Roast Turkey
description: There are many ways to prepare a turkey, says Melissa Clark, but none of them will make a better bird than if you rub it down with salt and put it in the oven.

title: Dias Auction of Artworks Is to Proceed
description: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation, who oppose the auction of notable pieces from its collection, have withdrawn a lawsuit filed last week to block the sale. The founders, Heiner Friedrich and Fariha de Menil Friedrich, said in a written statement through their lawyers on Tuesday morning that while they consider the sale utterly wrong and against Dias mission, the foundation is our precious child, and we do not wish to continue to oppose it through legal action.

title: Afghan Companies With Insurgent Ties Still Receive U.S. Contracts
description: WASHINGTON  Facing a well-financed insurgency in Afghanistan, the United States has struggled for years to cut off the main contribution American taxpayers make to Taliban coffers: the hiring of Afghan contractors with ties to the insurgents.

title: Chegg Prices Its I.P.O. at $12.50 a Share
description: Chegg, a start-up focused on textbook rentals and academic services, priced its initial public offering on Tuesday at $12.50 a share, exceeding expectations.

title: How to Spatchcock a Turkey
description: Mark Bittman demonstrates how to spatchcock a turkey. This method keeps the meat moist, and you can cook your whole bird in less than an hour.

title: Mashed Potato Casserole
description: Mashed potatoes have never been so easy or delicious.

title: Hashed Brussels Sprouts With Lemon Zest
description: The combination of citrus and cruciferous in this recipe makes it essential, and if you have a food processor, its a breeze to make.

title: A Lively Requiem, Without the What-if-Hed Lived
description: Theres no getting around the fact that the first third of Mozarts Requiem  the part he composed and orchestrated in full  is better than what follows. If this final masterpiece, written in the months leading up to his death in December 1791, had been a secular cantata, no doubt subsequent generations would have trimmed off the latter movements, in which Mozarts pupil Franz Xaver Sssmayr filled in the bits left incomplete to the best of his modest abilities. But a Requiem is a liturgical unit that demands to be performed in full  no matter how dull the Sanctus.

title: Stuffing With Mushrooms and Bacon
description: Learn to make this fast and delicious stuffing recipe.

title: From USA, a Mystery Series Shot in Old Jerusalem
description: In recent years, executives at the USA Network have stood on the sidelines, watching cable dramas like AMCs Breaking Bad and Showtimes Homeland collect the critical raves and awards. Now they want to get into the game.

title: Love, Like a Bombing Plot, Is Complicated
description: The line between truth and lies is nicely blurred in The English Bride, a mystery wrapped in a love story  or the other way around  by Lucile Lichtblau, at 59E59 Theaters. And three solid performances keep the interest level up, despite the limits of the plays structure.

title: The King of the Strip Evades Revenge
description: A lot of news was made on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera, most of it good, when the Rat Pack Rigoletto, Michael Mayers glitzy, inventive production of the Verdi classic, returned. It included the company debuts of a fast-rising young conductor and an impressive soprano, and two veteran artists brought significant roles from their repertory to the Met.

title: Back Injury Puts Football Player on I.P.O. Delayed List
description: Some companies cancel initial public offerings for lack of demand. Others are delayed because regulators require more disclosure.

title: In L.A., Lari Pittman Takes on American Violence and Identity
description: Three large paintings that Lari Pittman refers to as flying carpets serve as cornerstones of his new exhibition, From a Late Western Impaerium, at Regen Projects in Los Angeles. Like all of the work he has produced during his nearly four-decade career, these pieces are vibrant and ornate, crammed edge to edge with references both historical and contemporary. Flying Carpet With a Waning Moon Over a Violent Nation contains five large circles with cross hairs, which seem to be targeting a soft-focus landscape. Theyre interspersed with dangling nooses. The implied violence of the composition represents the effects of advanced capitalism, according to Pittman. I hate to sound so old-school Marxist about it, he adds.

title: The Book of Revelation, With Some Teeth to It
description: The French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj has been careful to clarify that his 2010 dance And then, one thousand years of peace is not a literal reading of the Book of Revelation. Rather, it is an impressionistic rendering of the emotions and sensations evoked by reading the New Testaments finale. In its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this past weekend, the dance seemed to reveal one thing: Mr. Preljocaj finds the Apocalypse a turn-on.

title: Bank Records Sought in Offshore Tax Inquiry
description: A federal judge gave the government permission to seek data from five Wall Street banks on American clients suspected of hiding assets at an unrelated Caribbean bank.

title: A Park for Moscow With New York Roots
description: A team headed by the New York design studio behind the High Linehas won an international competition to build a park in the shadow of the Kremlin. The team, led by Diller Scofidio & Renfro, presented a concept for the park, in the Zaryadye neighborhood of Moscow, that was based on the theme of wild urbanism, with descending terraces reflecting Russias four typical land types: tundra, steppe, forest andwetlands. The renovation of the park is the latest in a series of beautification efforts under Mayor Sergei S. Sobyanin, who has invested heavily in expanding green space in the city amid demands from Moscows increasingly vocal middle class. The 13-acre lot has stood vacant since 2006, when the Rossiya Hotel, a landmark of Soviet Moscow, was demolished.

title: Fiddling That Inspired a Piano Quintet
description: During a postconcert talk in the Kaplan Penthouse, the pianist Gilles Vonsattel spoke about the difficulty of bringing character to complex and difficult music like Peter Liebersons Piano Quintet (2001).

title: Fallon, Nearing Tonight Debut, Says He Has First Guest in Mind
description: Jimmy Fallon, host of Late Night and soon to be host of NBCs Tonight show, has been making the rounds of the networks affiliates in advance of his ascension in February to the chair now held by Jay Leno, the top-rated host in late night. On Tuesday, he took a quick break to offer some early thoughts on the coming transition. Among them:

title: Adobe Breach Inadvertently Tied to Other Accounts
description: This week,Ammon Bartram, a software engineer and co-founder of SocialCam, was talking to a friend about a recent security breach at Adobe in which hackers were able to gain access to tens of millions of encrypted passwords and email addresses.

title: The College Premium
description: The growth of the earnings gap between college and high school graduates slowed in the last decade, after expanding sharply over the previous 20 years. The long rise followed a dip in the supply of college graduates, especially among men.

title: Republicans Again Reject Obama Pick for Judiciary
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas latest choice to fill one of the vacancies on a powerful appeals court went down in a filibuster on Tuesday as Senate Republicans blocked another White House nominee  the third in two weeks  and deepened a growing conflict with Democrats over presidential appointments.

title: Johnson & Johnson Said to Agree to $4 Billion Settlement Over Hip Implants
description: Johnson & Johnson has tentatively agreed to a settlement that could reach up to $4 billion to resolve thousands of lawsuits filed by patients injured by a flawed all-metal replacement hip, said two lawyers briefed on the plan.

title: Extended Stay America Prices I.P.O. at $20 a Share
description: Shareholders seem to have given Extended Stay America a warm, but not luxurious, welcome to the public markets.

title: Mascara Ads: Thick Lashes, Fine Print
description: In recent years, thanks in part to the rise of Latisse, the prescription drug that promises longer eyelashes, and the refinement of false lashes, a full fringe around the eyes has come to be one of beautys holy grails. Which may be why, when it comes to advertising, mascara marketers have been laying it on a bit thick.

title: Using Hurricane Sandy as a Lesson for Future Elections
description: Hurricane Sandy prompted elected officials to consider many ideas to prepare for storms, as varied as building protective dunes and fortifying subway stops.

title: Eyelash-Boosting Mascaras Tested
description: As some mascara ads draw fire for hyperbolic claims, we put a few of the newest lash boosters to the test.

title: On State Television, Irans Foreign Minister Defends Nuclear Negotiations
description: Late Monday, after he posted a series of tweets blaming divisions among Western allies for the failure to strike a deal over Irans nuclear program last weekend, the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, went on state television in Tehran to discuss the state of the negotiations.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Confessions of a Fake Web Traffic Buyer, and the False Promise of Classroom Technology
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Jarrett Promises Outreach to Business Leaders
description: A number of speakers at Tuesdays DealBook conference addressed the Affordable Care Act, but the laws fumbled rollout has arguably been the biggest headache for Valerie Jarrett, a senior adviser to President Obama.

title: Roasted Butternut Squash With Onions
description: This recipe from Yotam Ottolenghi and Sam Tamimis, Jerusalem: A Cookbook is a twist on a classic Thanksgiving dish.

title: William Pollack Dies at 87; His Vaccine Saved Infants
description: William Pollack, a medical researcher who helped develop a vaccine that virtually eradicated a disease once responsible for 10,000 infant deaths a year in the United States, died on Nov. 3 in Yorba Linda, Calif. He was 87.

title: Czech Politician Faces Claims of Aiding Secret Police
description: PARIS  Andrej Babis, a populist billionaire who handed out doughnuts to voters at subway stations, emerged as a surprise kingmaker in the recent Czech elections by fashioning himself as a self-made outsider who would stamp out corruption and sleaze.

title: Let Them Eat Cake
description: No doubt demands to hold down wages and expenses are perfectly reasonable in many instances.

title: Sorry, Wrong Jonathan Martin
description: WASHINGTON  I was confused when I started receiving tweets directed at Miami Dolphins lineman Jonathan Martin.

title: Why S.&P. Faulted France
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamacare and Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts to Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Inequality in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: John Tavener Dies at 69; Composer With Eye on God
description: John Tavener, a British composer known for his meditative, sometimes passionate sacred works and colorfully scored orchestral pieces  including the popular cello concerto The Protecting Veil, and the haunting Song for Athene, which was performed at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales  died on Tuesday at his home in Child Okeford, in southern England. He was 69.

title: Born in Protest, a Soccer Team Hailed by the People and the Government
description: ALGIERS  They have a reputation for smashing everything in their wake. Their nickname is the Chnawa, literally the Chinese, a politically incorrect reference not only to their large numbers but also to their reputation as an unstoppable horde.

title: The Passion (and the Politics) of an Algerian Soccer Team
