description: Mouloudia Algiers, called the beating heart of the nation, is deeply tied to Algerias history and politics. The club is by far the most popular team in the country.

title: At $142.4 Million, Triptych Is the Most Expensive Artwork Ever Sold at an Auction
description: It took seven superrich bidders to propel a 1969 Francis Bacon triptych to $142.4 million at Christies on Tuesday night, making it the most expensive work of art ever sold at auction. William Acquavella, the New York dealer, is thought to have bought the painting on behalf of an unidentified client, from one of Christies skyboxes overlooking the auction.

title: Private Donors Funds Add Wild Card to War in Syria
description: AL SUBAYHIYAH, Kuwait  The money flows in via bank transfer or is delivered in bags or pockets bulging with cash. Working from his sparely furnished sitting room here, Ghanim al-Mteiri gathers the funds and transports them to Syria for the rebels fighting President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate
description: RECENT SALE

title: How to Carve a Turkey
description: Ray Venezia, master butcher and Fairway Market meat consultant, shows how to carve a turkey.

title: Federal Regulators Unveil Rules on Their Sometime Proxies, Bank Consultants
description: Private bank consultants, long known as Wall Streets shadow regulators, are now facing some regulation of their own.

title: Bloomberg Says News Service Did Not Kill Articles on China
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday insisted that Bloomberg News, which he owns, did not censor itself by killing two articles related to China. But he also asserted that, for at least a couple more months, he is not involved with the news service because of his role as mayor.

title: In Court, Baldwin Tells of Stalker Out of Hitchcock
description: Alec Baldwin can always be counted on to give a good performance, whether on television or on the witness stand, and his testimony in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday was no exception.

title: When the Police Enter a Home
description: The home is at the very core of the Fourth Amendments protection against unreasonable government intrusion, as the Supreme Court has said repeatedly. It is where a persons expectation of privacy is greatest.

title: New U.N. Brigades Aggressive Stance in Africa Brings Success, and Risks
description: KIWANJA, Democratic Republic of Congo  When Martin Kobler, the newly appointed United Nations representative, arrived this summer for his first visit to this small but strategic town, armed members of the M23 rebel group lined the airstrip, silently watching him land and disembark. Their presence sent an unmistakable message: the rebels, not Congolese officials, controlled Kiwanja.

title: Hands Off the Ball, or Risk a Technical Foul
description: Professional basketball players can contort their bodies like acrobats and power through defenses like bulldozers, but many of these athletes have found themselves completely flummoxed this season by a rule so fundamental that it sounds as if it were designed for third graders: Leave the ball alone.

title: Agony in the Philippines
description: Five days after one of the worst typhoons on record hit the Philippines, the magnitude of the catastrophe is barely captured in the preliminary statistics: nearly 2,000 people listed as dead and many thousands more missing; more than 600,000 people displaced; countless homes and roads crushed by surging water.

title: A Living Wage in Bangladesh
description: The government of Bangladesh is expected to soon announce an increase in the minimum wage for workers in the countrys clothing factories, which are big suppliers to Western retailers like Walmart and H&M. Its decision could improve the lives of millions of families that struggle to eke out an existence on as little as the equivalent of about $38 a month, the current minimum wage.

title: Fairness for College Athletes
description: The amateur model in college sports is in serious trouble, with a federal district judge on Friday certifying a class-action suit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Under N.C.A.A. rules, student athletes may not receive compensation  a policy that effectively blocks players from entering into group licensing agreements. The N.C.A.A., however, sells the names and images of players for use in game footage, photographs and video games.

title: Tribe Claims Approval for Marthas Vineyard Casino, Reviving Fight
description: BOSTON  An Indian tribe on Marthas Vineyard said Tuesday that it had obtained approval from a federal agency to open a casino on tribal land on the resort island, but others challenged that conclusion and said the tribe had no such authority.

title: Goodbye, Boston; Hello, Manager of the Year
description: In his eight eventful seasons with the Boston Red Sox, Terry Francona never received a first-place vote for the Manager of the Year award. This was mostly a function of the way voters judge managers, rewarding those perceived to do more with less. The Red Sox always had high payrolls and thus high expectations.

title: Missouris Governor Calls for End to Contest of Incentives
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The long-running competition for jobs between Kansas and Missouri that has elicited all manner of battlefield imagery about arming and disarming, border wars and turf battles now has Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri signaling for a new one: truce.

title: Stop Penalizing Poor College Students
description: THE Pell grant program is the federal governments main strategy for helping low-income students finish college, but the way the program is designed makes it harder for those same students to graduate on schedule.

title: End of Proposal to Raise Skyline on the East Side
description: Opposition in the City Council and an incoming mayor intent on imposing a more liberal vision have dealt a fatal blow to the Bloomberg administrations final plan to recast the New York City skyline with a new crop of office towers in East Midtown that would rise higher than the Chrysler Building.

title: What About US?
description: It goes without saying that the only near-term deal with Iran worth partially lifting sanctions for would be a deal that freezes all the key components of Irans nuclear weapons development program, and the only deal worth lifting all sanctions for is one that verifiably restricts Irans ability to breakout and build a nuclear bomb.

title: Rethinking Parent-Teacher Conferences
Starbucks to Pay Kraft $2.75 Billion, Ending Broken-Deal Dispute
description: Starbucks said on Tuesday that it would pay Kraft Foods $2.75 billion, ending a long-running spat over an agreement the two food titans had for distribution of Starbucks packaged coffee in grocery stores.

title: Most Federal Storm Aid Still Undistributed in New Jersey
description: As the anniversary of Hurricane Sandy approached, the Christie administration had distributed only about a quarter of the $1.2 billion that the federal government had awarded to help New Jersey homeowners and renters recover from the storm.

title: As the Living Receive Aid, Bodies Remain Uncollected in the Philippines
description: The corpses of Typhoon Haiyan, which have been part of the ravaged landscape of the central Philippines for days and nauseated survivors as they walk past, are among the stark images from the disaster that struck last week. But medical experts say the unburied dead are not a significant public health hazard.

title: Scorned by His Fellow Musicians, a Refugee From Iran Was Looking to Kill
description: They were so tight-knit that some thought they were brothers, and in a way, they were: Fleeing Iran together to pursue music and art in Brooklyn, the bandmates of the Yellow Dogs and their friends had formed a fraternity of Iranian expatriates who lived, sang and cooked together.

title: Doping Rules Are Tougher Only if Applied
description: JOHANNESBURG  The World Anti-Doping Agency, the organization that oversees the antidoping effort in Olympic sports, is set to adopt a new set of rules when it meets here this week for its World Conference on Doping in Sport.

title: Essential Thanksgiving
description: Your guide to the years most important meal, with our best recipes, videos, techniques and tricks.

title: Chinese Leader Gets More Sway on the Economy and Security
description: HONG KONG  President Xi Jinping of China emerged from a Communist Party leadership conference on Tuesday with a mandate to give the market a decisive role in the worlds second-largest economy and to consolidate new decision-making authority in his own hands.

title: Yellens Challenge at the Fed: Speaking Persuasively to Investors
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, President Obamas choice to lead the Federal Reserve over the next four years, has championed the idea that the Fed can stimulate the economy simply by speaking clearly.

title: In Policing Tactics Decline, Gift to Next Commissioner
description: Im on my way into the American Embassy in Trinidad, William J. Bratton said by phone on Tuesday afternoon. So I only have a few minutes.

title: Health Law Rollout Provides Rich Target for Oversight Chief
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Darrell Issa has long been known on Capitol Hill as one of the most aggressive  some would say overzealous  thorns in the side of Obama administration, using his seat as chairman of the House oversight committee to trumpet any missteps that can be traced to the White House.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 12, 2013
Rivals Unite in Jordans Surprising World Cup Run
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Jordans royal past, present and future look down on the grass field at Amman International Stadium from all angles. Below huge color portraits of King Abdullah II, his father, King Hussein, and his teenage son, the crown prince, the national soccer teams players trained Tuesday ahead of the game of their lives: a World Cup intercontinental playoff against Uruguay, the South American champion, on Wednesday night.

title: In Milan, Fashion on Two Wheels
description: Highlights from the 71st edition of the International Motorcycle Exhibition in Milan, which included more than 1,000 manufacturers of machines, riding gear and accessories.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 13, 2013
description: Go ahead. There are a lot more Scalias and Thomases that wed love to put on the bench.

title: 4 World Trade Center Opens
description: It is the first tower completed on the original World Trade Center site.

title: Iran Talks Face Resistance in U.S. Congress
description: WASHINGTON  After having come tantalizingly close over the weekend to an agreement to freeze Irans nuclear program, the Obama administration is gingerly weighing a threat to the talks potentially more troublesome than the opaque leadership in Tehran: Congress.

title: House Stalls Trade Pact Momentum
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is rushing to reach a new deal intended to lower barriers to trade with a dozen Pacific Rim nations, including Japan and Canada, before the end of the year.

title: The Joy of Cooking
description: Were up to Wednesday already and now were cooking with oil, as Jean OConor serves up a puzzle with a full recipe inside. The recipes instructions are broken up into five parts with the sixth and final theme answer revealing the mystery dish. So lets gather round the TABLE and get started.

title: Corrections: November 13, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Funny, How Gravity Pulls Us, and the Safety Net Is an Illusion
description: The most liberating laughter to be heard these days cascades from 59E59 Theaters, where a staged version of Samuel Becketts radio play All That Fall opened on Tuesday night. That raucous, wide-open sound comes from the mighty throats of two of the finer actors on the planet, Eileen Atkins and Michael Gambon.

title: Why Is This Thing Called Love?
description: Is there a patron saint of befuddled theatergoers? Had I known of one, I would probably have been fervently praying at intervals throughout The Patron Saint of Sea Monsters, a wayward, Gothic comedy-drama by Marlane Meyer that opened on Tuesday night on Playwrights Horizons smaller stage.

title: Kjell Qvale Dies at 94; Married U.S. to Sports Cars
description: Kjell Qvale, who fell in love with a forest-green, wire-wheel MG sports car in the 1940s and went on to become one of the earliest American importers of European cars, ultimately selling a million automobiles as a distributor and dealer, died on Nov. 1 in San Francisco. He was 94.

title: Protecting Your Childrens Credit, Even Before They Have Any
description: IF you want to make sure your personal information isnt at risk from identity thieves, you can ask to have a security freeze placed on your credit file at the three major credit bureaus  Experian, Equifax and TransUnion. That prevents lenders or credit card companies (that you arent already doing business with) from gaining access to the information and in effect shuts down the chance of unauthorized credit being issued.

title: The Day My Son Went Missing
description: NOW in its sixth week, the search for Avonte Oquendo, a 14-year-old boy from Queens with autism, is shining a light on the issue of wandering among people with autism. On Oct. 4, Avonte managed to slip away after lunch from his school in Long Island City  even though he was known to wander during classroom transitions.

title: Around the World for a Ticket to the World Cup
description: The qualifying process for next years World Cup, which began almost unnoticed more than two years ago with Belizes 5-2 victory over Montserrat, will conclude over the next week with 22 teams playing 17 matches for the final 11 spots.

title: World Cup Playoffs on TV
description: Submitted for your approval (and viewing pleasure) a list of the various outlets that will be carrying the final week of qualifying matches for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil (a handful of friendlies, including the United States games at Scotland and Austria are not included here).

title: Egypt: Government Delays Ending State of Emergency and Curfew
description: Egypts interim government said that it would abide by a judicial ruling on Tuesday ending a three-month state of emergency, which was imposed after the authorities stormed two Islamist sit-ins in August. Late Tuesday, however, the government said the state of emergency, as well as a nighttime curfew, would remain in place until it had received formal notice of the decision. The curfew and the state of emergency were aimed at curbing demonstrations by supporters of President Mohamed Morsi, who was ousted by the military in July. Human rights activists have expressed concern that the military-backed government intends to simply replace the state of emergency with legislation aimed at stifling dissent, including an antiterrorism law, as well as a protest law that rights groups have warned would essentially criminalize demonstrations.

title: Mobsters Trial Opens in 97 Killing of Officer
description: It is among the strongest tenets of the Mafia code: Never kill a police officer. But a prosecutor told jurors in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday that a former mobster ordered his hit men to do just that.

title: New U.N. Rights Council Members Are Elected
description: The United Nations General Assembly elected China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Vietnam, Cuba and nine others on Tuesday to fill 14 seats for three-year terms on the 47-member Human Rights Council, the body that evaluates and investigates the rights records of United Nations member states. Western rights groups were particularly offended that China, Russia and Saudi Arabia won seats even though those countries have refused to allow the councils investigators to examine complaints of abuse. The council, based in Geneva, has often been accused of hypocrisy and double standards, depending on the countries targeted for investigation. The other nations chosen on Tuesday were Algeria, Britain, France, the Maldives, Macedonia, Mexico, Morocco, Namibia and South Africa.

title: Massachusetts: Hearing in Marathon Bombing Case
description: Government prosecutors said Tuesday that United States Attorney Carmen Ortiz would recommend to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. this week whether the marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev should face the death penalty. Mr. Tsarnaev faces 30 charges related to accusations that he worked with his older brother, Tamerlan, to detonate bombs at the marathon on April 15, killing three people and injuring more than 260. (Tamerlan Tsarnaev was killed after a firefight with the police). Prosecutors asked Judge George A. OToole Jr. of Federal District Court for a fall 2014 date for Mr. Tsarnaevs trial, which they estimated would take 90 days, but Judge OToole declined to set a start date. Mr. Tsarnaevs defense lawyers argued that prosecutors were withholding evidence, including information about a 2011 triple murder in Waltham to which Tamerlan Tsarnaev has been linked. Judge OToole took that matter, and a motion that would ease some prison restrictions on Mr. Tsarnaev, under advisement.

title: Holyfields Mansion Is a Home Sale Heavyweight
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ga.  Immense and opulent, the home seems fit for a king. Its address leaves no doubt about the identity of its longtime owner and resident: 794 Evander Holyfield Highway.

title: Some State Insurance Exchanges Continue to Battle Technical Problems
description: Six weeks into the rollout of President Obamas new health care law, some of the online insurance exchanges run by states are continuing to have serious technological problems, often mirroring the issues plaguing the much larger federal exchange.

title: Weisbrod Brings Long Rsum to Advise the Mayor-Elect
description: Carl Weisbrod can barely walk a block in Times Square without being hailed by an old friend.

title: Experience has Taught Jones Austin the Power of Community
description: On Sept. 11, 2001, Jennifer Jones Austin, six months pregnant, emerged from the subway with her 3-year-old daughter, Kennedy, to find that one tower of the World Trade Center had fallen.

title: Dont Call Her a First Lady; Browns Wife Is His Top Aide
description: SACRAMENTO  Anyone who spends time with Gov. Jerry Brown is familiar with his penchant for referring to philosophers, Latin or an obscure tome he has recently read, often in the same sentence. A speaker who uses what he deems an imprecise word should be prepared to listen to a soliloquy on its meaning.

title: Ahead of Yellens Confirmation Hearing
description: Before Janet L. Yellen can take the helm of the Federal Reserve, she will have to field questions on the Feds stimulus plans and maintain that its policies are working.

title: Executives Talk Goalies and Overtime
description: TORONTO  Two things are clear after the N.H.L.s general managers meeting Tuesday: Fights between goaltenders and modifying the overtime format will be on the agenda when they reconvene in Florida in March.

title: A Senator Lays Out His Positions on the Military, Very Carefully
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  A few months after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, President George W. Bush came to the Citadel, the military college here, to lay out his plans to reconfigure the armed forces for his interventionist posture known as the Bush Doctrine.

title: Hugs and Kisses Bridge an Emotional Distance
description: Kim Lemon worked hard to stay in her Brooklyn apartment, even after the father of her three children slammed her head into one of its crumbling walls. But then the man returned, threatening to do worse.

title: Two Prep School Stars Meet, and a College Rivalry Gets Under Way
description: CHICAGO  Next March will mark the 35th anniversary of the 1979 N.C.A.A. title game between Larry Birds Indiana State Sycamores and Magic Johnsons Michigan State Spartans. The game remains one of the few instances when the undisputed top two players in college basketball competed against each other, and it is the highest-rated televised college basketball game ever.

title: What if Race No Longer Matters in City Politics?
description: The most significant development in the mayoral election in Boston earlier this month was hardly discussed: the absence of open racial animosity.

title: Colorful History of a Power Hotel in Beijing
description: To the untrained eye, the Jingxi Hotel, with its box-like, Soviet-style architecture dating to the late 1950s, is just like any number of buildings that line Beijings central east-west boulevard. But beneath its deceptively gray and drab exterior, the Jingxi may be the most concentrated unofficial seat of power in China: For the last four days, it was the site of the Third Plenum of the Communist Partys Central Committee, where Chinese leaders tried to hammer out a reform agenda for the coming decade and beyond.

title: The Fading Light
description: John Ashberys evocation of American ennui inspired the French artist Xavier Veilhan to create a paean to loved ones blurred in memory.

title: Word of the Day | awry
description: awry \-ri\ adverb and adjective

title: Doctors Identify a New Knee Ligament
description: Last month, knee surgeons from the University Hospitals Leuven in Belgium announced that they had found a new knee ligament, one that had not previously been specifically identified despite untold numbers of past knee dissections and scans. This surprising announcement, in The Journal of Anatomy, should improve our understanding of how the knee works and why some knee surgeries disappoint and also underscores the continually astonishing complexity of human anatomy.

title: The Slow Death of the Employer Mandate
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Eliot H. Lumbard, 88, Dies; Pursued Mob Leaders
description: Eliot H. Lumbard, a New York prosecutor and law-enforcement leader who helped expose organized crime through his investigation of the infamous Apalachin meeting of mob leaders in 1957, died on Nov. 6 in Nashua, N.H. He was 88.

title: Logistical Hurdles Paralyze Relief Effort at the Center of a Typhoons Fury
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Typhoon gridlock threatened rescue operations in the most devastated part of the Philippines on Wednesday, with aid piling up but few ways to distribute it, plentiful gasoline but no merchants willing to sell it, and an influx of emergency volunteers but no place to house them.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: NOON (HBO2) LOVE, MARILYN (2012) Actors and various contemporaries recite from recently discovered diaries and letters written by Marilyn Monroe, above, in what David DeWitt, writing in The New York Times, called a respectful love letter to Monroe, who is presented by the director, Liz Garbus, as a sexpot, feminist and Tennessee Williams heroine come to life, noble in her respect and need for a sensitive, considerate humanity. Some, like Glenn Close, Viola Davis and Uma Thurman, nail their readings. Others, like Ben Foster, get a bit cringe-worthy, Mr. DeWitt said. But the intelligence and dynamism of Ms. Garbuss approach could hardly fail to make you appreciate Monroes growth as an actor. The documentary includes footage of Monroe performing or giving interviews. More so, Mr. DeWitt added, youll have sympathy for the hard-working woman whose self-improvement lists included exhortations of things she must do and never should do.

title: Afghan Opium Cultivation and Production Seen Rising
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite years of international effort to reel back Afghanistans opium culture, cultivation and production hit record levels this year, and programs to counteract them have floundered, according to a new United Nations study.

title: Chinas Vow on Market Gets Tepid Reception in Asia
description: HONG KONG  The Asian business communitys initial reaction on Wednesday to the highly anticipated pronouncement of Chinas Communist Party leaders on how to overhaul Chinas economy was basically this: long on goals and short on details, broad-brushed, falling some way short of expectations.

title: News Quiz | November 13, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: New Bravo Deal Means More of Andy Cohen
description: Andy Cohen is the most identifiable talent on the Bravo cable channel, thanks to his successful weeknight talk show, Watch What Happens Live. But while talk-show host has been his public identity, he also has worked full time as one of the top corporate executives at Bravo.

title: China Elected to United Nations Human Rights Council
description: China has won a seat on the United Nations Human Rights Council for three years starting in January 2014, one of 14 countries chosen to join the 47-member council on Tuesday, the United Nations said. It was selected in a single, secret ballot by 176 of 193 nations in the organizations General Assembly, according to a press release.

title: Staying on the Farm
description: Over the past decade, a common story in China has been of nail houses  of homeowners who refuse to leave their houses even as the rest of their neighborhood is torn down. Often these are solitary holdouts, and their houses look like a nail sticking up on a board.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 13, 2013
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Fun Facts About Female Science Pioneers
description: In Honoring Female Pioneers in Science, Denise Grady writes about a new exhibit full of tantalizing and little-known details.

title: Typhoon Haiyan and the Climate Talks
description: Pushing for a stronger treaty on climate change, some participants are arguing that global warming is responsible for the strength of the typhoon that struck the Philippines.

title: Chinatown Surprise
description: On the advice of two friends, I wandered one day into Spicy Village, in Manhattans Chinatown, a restaurant that politeness prevents me from describing as anything other than modest. I stopped by a couple of years ago to have the not-at-all-bad $2 pork sandwich, a pile of sloppy-Joe-ish pork served on light, crisp bread baked by the proprietors  Wendy Lian and her husband, Ren Fu Li  but I rarely thought of it again.

title: What Is the Value of Stolen Art?
description: Making money from stolen paintings  particularly famous ones  is not a straightforward matter, and those who try to do so fall broadly into two categories. The first, most common type is the naf, who steals a painting but has laid few plans beyond the theft itself. He soon discovers that the paintings notoriety has rendered it toxic, and he cant sell it. The work of art becomes burdensome and worthless  to him at least. A more sophisticated criminal, on the other hand, recognizes that a pilfered masterpiece is a unique commodity and that in order to profit from it, he needs to think more like a derivatives trader than a pickpocket.

title: Sikh Farmers in Stalins Birthplace
description: When Ivor Prickett first heard that hundreds of Sikh farmers were moving from northern India to the former Soviet republic of Georgia, all sorts of images came into his head. He had spent time with ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a disputed breakaway region, and had trouble picturing Sikhs mixing easily.

title: What Would You Outsource if You Could?
description: A recent column in The Times Magazine argues that we shouldnt consider paying someone to do tasks for us to be a privilege reserved only for royalty or oil sheikhs. Instead, economists say it might be worth our money to free up some time spent on drudgery to be used instead for activities that can advance our educations or careers.

title: Final Innings for a Cricket Giant
description: The Indian cricket star Sachin Tendulkars ability to generate mind-numbing statistics has survived to the very end of his prodigious career. When tickets for his 200th and final five-day test match went on sale on Monday, 19.7 million hits within the first hour crashed the website selling them.

title: New York Today: Skyward
description: Updated 11:33 a.m. | This morning, Mayor Bloomberg will cut a ribbon and declare 4 World Trade Center open for business.

title: U.S. Investigates Anti-Semitism Claims at Pine Bush Schools
description: The United States attorneys office for the Southern District of New York has opened a civil rights investigation into allegations of anti-Semitic harassment of children in the Pine Bush Central School District.

title: Where the Gods Live On ... and On
description: A POPULAR Indian historian once remarked to me that India is a country where men dont age well, and of no one is this observation truer than of Sachin Ramesh Tendulkar, a man who is, at 40 years and some 200 days, the oldest member of Indias cricket team.

title: A Conversation With: Former Indian Army Chief Gen. Vijay Kumar Singh
description: Gen. Vijay Kumar Singh was the chief of the Indian Army from March 2010 to May 2012. His tenure ended on a bitter note after a dispute over his date of birth and consequent date of retirement from the military service. Mr. Singh disagreed with the Indian government and went to the Supreme Court of India, where he lost his case.

title: New Chinese Panel Said to Oversee Domestic Security and Foreign Policy
description: BEIJING  Chinas new national security committee is mainly based on the Washington model. It will put at the disposal of the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, a highly empowered group of security experts who can work the levers of the countrys vast security apparatus  and presumably respond more nimbly than the countrys multilayered party, police and military bureaucracies have been known to do.

title: U.S. Offers Reward in Wildlife-Trade Fight
description: BANGKOK  Taking a page from the battle against international drug cartels, the United States announced on Wednesday a $1 million reward for information to help dismantle one of Asias largest wildlife-trafficking syndicates.

title: Microsoft Abolishes Employee Evaluation System
description: SEATTLE  Imagine getting a grade-point average, but instead of being judged by a teacher who has worked with you throughout the year, you are evaluated by a bunch of teachers, some of whom may not know you very well.

title: Attack on Israeli Worsens Tensions With Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian teenager fatally stabbed a 19-year-old Israeli soldier on a bus in northern Israel on Wednesday, according to the police, shocking Israelis who have grown unused to such killings in their cities and further clouding a peace process that was already severely strained by Israeli settlement plans in the West Bank.

title: Airline Merger on Track to Close
description: The planned merger of American Airlines and US Airways became all but certain on Tuesday after the airlines reached a deal with the Justice Department two weeks before a scheduled trial, Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew report in The New York Times. The deal, coming after months of setbacks and delays, paves the way for the creation of a third major global airline that can compete with United Airlines and Delta Air Lines.

title: The Gift at an Ending
description: On a morose Sunday afternoon, my husband and I arrived at my mothers apartment. Earlier that morning we had received the call. This is it, my sister said. Moms in a coma. The family had assembled in a somber vigil.

title: Damien Hirst and Alexander McQueen, Together at Last
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: In Our Pages: November 14
description: 1938: Trotskys Expulsion Sought

title: Document | How a Rock n Roll Star Does Selfies
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Gun Report: November 13, 2013
description: The victims of gun violence we write about in this space are strangers. We feel for their plight and empathize with their loved ones, but we do not know them. That changed for me on Monday, when I pulled up the Times homepage and read about the death of someone I knew.

title: A Moment of Love, Before a Goodbye
description: Dear Diary:

title: Petrobras of Brazil Sells Peruvian Unit to Chinese Company
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Brazils state-controlled oil company Petrobras announced on Wednesday that it was selling all of its Peruvian subsidiary, Petrobras Energia Peru, to the China National Petroleum Company for $2.6 billion.

title: Hector Sants Resigns From Barclays
description: Updated, 10:38 a.m. |

title: Fifty Shades Film Release Is Pushed to 2015
description: LOS ANGELES  The movie masses will have to wait a little longer for Fifty Shades of Grey.

title: Motorola to Offer Moto G Smartphone Aimed at Emerging Markets
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Motorola Mobility, the handset maker owned by Google, is still trying to find its niche in the smartphone market.

title: The Fallen Hero of Serbian Tennis
description: The first time Serbia was in a Davis Cup final, Viktor Troicki won the decisive match in Belgrade and experienced what he still calls the biggest moment of his life.

title: Bank of England Hints at Rate Increase, Citing Recovery
description: LONDON  The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it might consider raising interest rates earlier than previously expected because Britains economic recovery was gaining speed.

title: Germanys Neighbors Admonish It Over Surplus
description: FRANKFURT  Germany, which has often scolded other countries for accumulating too much debt and not being competitive enough in the global economy, now finds its own economic policy under heavy attack.

title: Daily Report: Motorolas Low-End Smartphone Faces Challenges
description: Motorola Mobility, the handset maker owned by Google, is still trying to find its niche in the smartphone market, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: An Entrepreneur Who Manufactures Entrepreneurs
description: Conventional wisdom holds that some 90 percent of start-ups fail. After years of observation, Adeo Ressi  a serial entrepreneur who founded TheFunded.com, an online community where entrepreneurs rate investors; Methodfive, a website developer; and Total New York, which became AOL Digital Cities  concluded that the high failure rate was the result of the wrong people starting businesses and not getting the right training.

title: How I Made My Biggest Mistake in China (So Far)
description: Every book on doing business in China touts the importance of building personal connections and guanxi.

title: Ukraine Delays Bill to Free Ex-Leader
description: MOSCOW  In a move that could derail plans for Ukraine to sign political and free trade agreements with the European Union this month, the countrys Parliament on Wednesday postponed consideration of a bill that would free the jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, and allow her to seek medical treatment in Germany.

title: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 2
description: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members. Part 1 of her answers is here. [Update: Part 3 is here. Part 4 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

title: Is This the Way to Teach Entrepreneurship?
description: The Times has just published a conversation with Adeo Ressi, who created the Founder Institute. In the conversation, Mr. Ressi reports that more than 1,000 aspiring entrepreneurs have graduated from his start-up incubator, each with a new company idea. Of those companies, about 10 percent have failed and 15 percent have gone dormant, Mr. Ressi said, while the rest are moving forward.

title: In Experienced Hands
description: Compared with parents, who are sometimes stressed, distracted and short of sleep, grandparents are, at least by reputation, a relaxed and indulgent set; tolerant of youthful enthusiasm and well rested at last after their own adventures in child rearing.

title: Attacks Across Iraq Kill Dozens
description: BAGHDAD  A series of bomb blasts and gunfire attacks swept Iraq on Wednesday, mostly targeting Shiites who were marking one of their holiest religious events.

title: Image of the Day: November 13
Holiday | The Daily Gift: Dior Scorpio Necklace
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Former Lobbyist Becomes Biden Chief of Staff
description: WASHINGTON  Steve Ricchetti, a former lobbyist and Clinton administration veteran, will replace Bruce Reed as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s chief of staff next month, the White House announced Wednesday.

title: Zombies in His Past, Now Onto Cops
description: In preparing for Mob City, a fictional look at the seedy underbelly of 1940s-era Los Angeles and his first new television series in three years, Frank Darabont has had to excise other favorite TV shows and movies from his regular cultural diet.

title: Residents Suing to Stop Fortresslike Plan for World Trade Center
description: To the question, How much security apparatus is needed on city streets? the agencies charged with guarding public safety seem to answer, As much as we say.

title: 1929: Seal on The Loose in Paris
description: The New York Herald dedicated a fair amount of space to the smaller, curious events in its pages. When a seal escaped onto the streets of Paris, the most serious of frivolous newspapers reported on an argument between bystanders:

title: Maxed Out Author Thought Readers Would Critique Her Ideas. Instead, They Judged Her Choices.
description: When KJ DellAntonias article about my book, Maxed Out: American Moms on the Brink, was published on Motherlode last week (Being a Working Mother Means Always Having to Say Youre Sorry), I was thrilled to see it generating passionate discussion in the comments section. This is, after all, the main reason I wrote Maxed Out  to get people talking about the structural issues holding women back in their careers and their lives.

title: Memory of a Mass Killing Becomes Another Casualty of Egyptian Protests
description: CAIRO  The police arrested the girls, interrogated them for hours, and then strip-searched and detained them for 10 days. They were charged with serious crimes, including endangering national security, for what the authorities regarded as an act of subversion: passing out yellow balloons.

title: Off the Coast of Chile, an Island Getaway
description: With only the vaguest of plans, I pulled my rental car onto the ferry to Lemuy Island, 37 square miles of hills and farms and dirt roads and ocean views. As I headed out from the main island of the Chilo Archipelago, off the Chilean coast, I had a simple agenda for that afternoon: drive around, visit one of the old wooden churches the islands are famous for, see what else happens.

title: Live Music Gains as a Hotel Amenity
description: From guitars in rooms to full-on concerts in the lobbies, hotels are making music a major amenity.

title: Schools That Separate the Child From the Trauma
description: Recently, I reported on the damaging effects that prolonged stress can have on young children who lack adequate protection from adults. Over the past 15 years, researchers have learned that highly stressful  and potentially traumatic  childhood experiences are more prevalent than previously understood. Now scientists are shedding light on the mechanisms by which they change the brain and body. These insights have far-reaching implications for schools, where its still standard practice to punish children for misbehavior that they often do not know how to control. This is comparable to punishing a child for having a seizure; it adds to the suffering and makes matters worse.

title: Why Stay in High School, When You Could Be Out Drinking?
description: Coarse language, loose women, good-for-nothing men and rampant alcoholism are all dragging down Derby Street, the skid row of an unnamed Northern industrial city. So, unfortunately, is terrible direction.

title: Classical Playlist: Andras Schiff, Janine Jansen, Rebekah Heller and More
description: Times critics share what theyve been listening to lately.

title: In Britain, an Unlikely Call to Redistribute Cultural Capital
description: Imagine planning a trip to Britain with a stop to hear a new opera by Mark-Anthony Turnage at a newly built version of the Royal Opera House, not in Covent Garden, but in Liverpool. And from there, you might drive northeast to savor antiquities at the British Museum, which will have painstakingly rebuilt Sir Robert Smirkes grand Greek Revival building in Morpeth, the county seat of Northumberland.

title: Roundup: Staff Departures, an Incorrect Promise and More
description: Heres a roundup of items from all over that may be interesting to Times readers and to the readers of this blog:

title: Health Website Official Tells of White House Briefings
description: WASHINGTON  The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace said Wednesday that he met periodically with White House aides to discuss the status of the website over the last three years, but he said the meetings focused narrowly on specific technical issues and therefore gave the president no clear warning of the disaster that ensued on Oct. 1.

title: Out of Europes Long Jobs Crisis, Voices of the Young
description: The Times asked young people in Europe to share their stories about how the crisis has affected their lives. Here is a selection of the responses.

title: Murder as Musical Punch Line
description: Its a surprisingly fertile season on New York stages for witty variations on the nail biter, what with Beth Henleys Southern Gothic The Jacksonian, the musical Murder for Two and John Pollonos comic thriller Small Engine Repair. Now comes another show to remind us, as Alfred Hitchcock was so fond of doing, that dark and deadly intrigue need not be deadly serious.

title: Does Individual Insurance Work?
description: Amid this weeks hints that the federal exchange still wont be anywhere close to functional on December 1st, Matt Yglesias offers the latest noble attempt to explain to Americans losing their individual-market coverage why theyre actually better off paying higher premiums for new, Obamacare-era plans. Instead of focusing on the more comprehensive benefits that the new plans offer, he takes a different tack suggesting that most people with cheapish individual-market coverage didnt really have insurance at all:

title: An Old Guitar Finds New Life on the Internet
description: Connor Millican and Corey Pane, two friends from Connecticut who were playing music together and dabbling in video production, had an idea: They wanted to put a funky old guitar in the hands of some funky young musicians and ask them to pluck out a tune. While the players would vary, the guitar would be the constant, becoming a shared tool between artists with different styles and methods.

title: Reviewing Opera Fan Fiction
description: The premise behind my article Liberating the Librettos was that opera-lovers inevitably become so involved with the stories of our favorite operas that we cultivate elaborate fantasies about what happens to the characters after the curtain goes down. My conviction was borne out by the insight, thoughtfulness and wit of the many comments that readers, all fellow opera-lovers, sent in.

title: Video: Annie Hall, the Sequel
description: Recently, Cara Araneta, 32, a brand designer, was strolling along Broadway in Union Square with a friend, her hands tucked into the pockets of her high-waist jeans. Not that far from Midtown and with the East Village only a couple of blocks away, Union Square is a mix between uptown and downtown, Ms. Araneta said. You see a lot of young people hanging out, like skateboards, that kind of N.Y.U. school vibe, and then you see businesspeople coming here for lunch or going to work.

title: Skiers Tame the Magic Kingdom
description: In this first episode of Behind the Line, Ian McIntosh and Sage Cattabriga-Alosa make first descents in the Neacola Mountains of Alaska.

title: Video: Skiers Tame the Magic Kingdom
description: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

title: Ruschas Archives Go to the Ransom Center in Texas
description: The Harry Ransom Center, a museum and research library at the University of Texas, Austin, has acquired the archives of Ed Ruscha, the prolific Pop Art master who is best known for his quirky thematic photography books, like Twentysix Gasoline Stations(1963) and Every Building on the Sunset Strip (1966), and for his word paintings, in which words are manipulated in ways that transform their meanings or suggest amusing tangential underpinnings.

title: Wheelies: The Magnificent Mazda Edition
description: A roundup of automotive news from around the web:

title: House Hunting in ... Toronto
description: A HISTORIC NEO-ROMANESQUE HOME IN ROSEDALE, TORONTO

title: House Hunting in Toronto
description: A red-brick semidetached home in the Rosedale neighborhood of Toronto is on the market for $3.7 million.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: The Great Beauty
description: The director Paolo Sorrentino narrates the opening sequence of his film.

title: Woman Accused of Stalking Alec Baldwin Takes Stand to Give Her Side
description: A woman accused of stalking Alec Baldwin took the witness stand on Wednesday to tell her story, saying Mr. Baldwin seduced her on a romantic New York date in February 2010, then wrote her for months afterward suggesting he cared for her.

title: Perella Weinberg Hires Goldman Sachs Managing Director
description: Perella Weinberg Partners has hired Jonathan Prather, a managing director in Goldman Sachss global industrials group, as a partner in its advisory business.

title: Chegg Falls in Debut, but Chief Remains Ebullient
description: Updated, 4:56 p.m. |

title: At Bloomberg, Special Code Keeps Some Articles Out of China
description: It is called Code 204. Editors at Bloomberg News append it to an article to ensure that it does not appear on Bloomberg financial data and news terminals in mainland China. Little known outside Bloomberg, the system has been in place for more than two years, and it is used regularly to keep articles on Chinese politics and social issues away from the eyes of powerful people in China who might be offended, Bloomberg employees say.

title: Hotel Review: Rosa Et Al Townhouse in Porto
description: Rates

title: Listen Up | Three Indie Music Fixtures Venture Out on Their Own
description: This fall, individual members of three of indie musics most inventive bands release their own solo projects that push the limits of their signature sounds.

title: Which iPad? It Depends. What Do You Want to Do?
description: Apple is now selling the new iPad Mini, the smaller brother of the pleasing iPad Air, which I reviewed a couple of weeks ago. Somehow, Apple has squeezed all of the Airs capabilities into the Mini  and by doing that, Apple has made the process of choosing an iPad easy.

title: Coffey to Join Kramer Levin in a Return to Law Practice
description: John P. Coffey stood behind the lectern in a federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan this summer, firing off pointed questions and composing hand-drawn diagrams to defend his client, the former Goldman Sachs trader Fabrice Tourre.

title: 60 Minutes Is Reviewing Discredited Benghazi Report
description: 60 Minutes announced on Wednesday that it was conducting an internal review of its now discredited report on the terrorist attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of The Great Beauty
description: The latest film from Paolo Sorrentino follows a journalist (Toni Servillo) in Rome as he reflects on his life. The film, much like its lead character, wanders around the city and focuses on many of its landmarks. In this video, Mr. Sorrentino narrates a look at the opening sequence, which suggests that the city can be so stunning to take in, that it can be deadly.

title: Senator Joe Manchin: In His Own Words
description: In selections from a recent interview with Jonathan Weisman, Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, talks about sticking to his principles and the worst that can happen to a politician.

title: A Lesson From Grandfather
description: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia told The Times's Jonathan Weisman in a recent interview that he first learned the importance of financial responsibility when he was just a child.

title: Distress Grows for Philippine Typhoon Victims
description: Even as an enormous global aid effort gathered momentum, international officials expressed concern that delays could prevent supplies from reaching survivors of Typhoon Haiyan for days.

title: Dropbox Aims at Business
description: Dropbox, an online storage service that has gained 200 million consumers in five years, is heading to the office.

title: Stand-Alone Food Section Faces Demise in Bay Area
description: In the food-obsessed Bay Area, The San Francisco Chronicles food section has been as much of a city institution as the cable car, and to many San Franciscans, more useful. Over the years it has won many awards and developed a dedicated following.

title: Today in Small Business: The Secrets of Sriracha
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: A High Five and a Handshake for Aether and Icebreaker
description: A theory I toy around with is that the most attractive people wear the ugliest workout clothing. Maybe its because beautiful people have to give less thought to what they swaddle their glorious forms in, or maybe its because if youre inclined to think about how good your athletic gear looks, you probably arent getting the maximum use out of it, or getting the item thats designed for maximum use.

title: Senator Manchin Takes On Democratic Party Leaders in Pursuit of a Middle Ground
description: WASHINGTON  In late August, Senate Democrats gathered on a conference call with President Obamas national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, to hear why the administration had to respond militarily to a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government.

title: App Smart: Teaching Kids Math
description: Children can learn math skills, from addition to algebra, through an array of apps for tablets and smartphones.

title: With Apps, Children Can Play the Game of Math
description: My 5-year-old son recently explained to my 3-year-old son that they were two years apart. Three years old plus 2 years old equals 5 years old, he explained.

title: OTB, a Bar in Williamsburg
description: A string of less scene-y bars has opened up in Williamsburg, one of the latest being OTB, on a sleepy stretch of Broadway next to the Williamsburg Bridge. Unlike its rowdier neighbors on the north side, this place is notable for what it lacks: hype, high prices and members of the maligned social subset that begins with the letter H.

title: In Statement From Prison, Morsi Accuses Egypts Military Leaders of Treason
description: CAIRO  In a statement he dictated from prison and made public through his lawyers on Wednesday, Mohamed Morsi, the former Islamist president of Egypt, accused his opponents in the military-backed government of treason and warned that Egypt would not recover from its crisis until the coup that removed him from power was reversed.

title: Police Say Spy Found in Bag Probably Died by Accident
description: LONDON  The bizarre death of a British intelligence analyst whose body was discovered inside a sports bag in a bathtub was called a probable accident by the London police on Wednesday, an inconclusive ending to one of the most puzzling investigations in recent years.

title: Toronto Mayor Admits to Buying Drugs
description: At a Toronto City Council meeting, Mayor Rob Ford said he bought illegal drugs in the last two years. When asked if he had an addiction to illicit drugs, the mayor said absolutely not.

title: Global Warming, College and Partisanship
description: Its well known that Democrats and political independents are more likely than Republicans to believe that global warming is mainly due to human activity. But heres something from the latest Pew poll on climate change: College has a significantly larger effect on Democrats understanding of the issue than on Republicans.

title: Tables Turned, Victims Relatives Get Their Chance at Bulger
description: BOSTON  David Wheeler stood in the well of a federal courtroom here Wednesday, gesturing toward James (Whitey) Bulger, the elderly man who was once the overlord of the Boston underworld and who had ordered his fathers murder.

title: New Catfish Inspections Are Posing a Problem for a Pacific Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON  A curious hurdle is threatening to complicate efforts by the United States to reach a major trade agreement with 11 Pacific nations by the end of the year: catfish.

title: Wylie Dufresne's Turkey Hash
description: Wylie Dufresne, the owner of WD-50, doesnt contribute to Thanksgiving dinner; he makes breakfast the next day. He shows Mark Bittman how he makes his fried eggs and turkey hash.

title: Goldman Sachs Promotes 280 to Managing Director
description: Goldman Sachs has promoted 280 executives to managing director, one step down from the brass ring of partner. Promotions are up 5 percent over last year, when the firm named 266 employees managing director.

title: The East Village: To Escape the Sirens
description: It wasnt until the summer  his first in a large one-bedroom at Seventh Avenue and 14th Street  that Jeff Greenspan realized how noisy his home was. Maybe the racket came through the air-conditioner vents. Sirens shrieked by in an endless parade.

title: Finance Lessons, From the World of Art Auctions
description: The record-busting $142 million sale on Tuesday by Christies of Francis Bacons triptych of Lucian Freud  not to mention the unprecedented New York auction total of almost $700 million  shows a contemporary art market in heady territory. Its possible, if a bit tenuous, to extract a matching trio of lessons for the broader world of finance.

title: Ask Well: Table Salt or Sea Salt?
description: The differences between table salt and sea salt explained, both in nutrition and taste.

title: President Aquino on Typhoon Aftermath
description: A sample of President Benigno S. Aquino IIIs statements on Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines.

title: Remixing a Pulitzer Prize-Winning Work
description: New Amsterdam Presents, the feisty alt-classical label and concert-presenting organization that the composers William Brittelle, Judd Greenstein, and Sarah Kirkland Snider started in 2007, is collaborating with the Q2 Music web page on an unusual fund-raising project for the company. Every Wednesday for eight weeks, starting Nov. 13, Q2 will stream a remix of Caroline Shaws Partita, for which she won the Pulitzer Prize this year. The streaming tracks are freely available, but if you want to download one, or all eight, the page provides a link to New Amsterdams fund-raising page, where you can make a donation (the amount is not specified, but it is tax deductible) and download the tracks.

title: Were Buds, Right? Its Hard to Tell.
description: Is it possible for the characters in a play to wrest control of it from the playwright? How to Make Friends and Then Kill Them, a very dark comedy by Halley Feiffer at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, starts out intriguingly but eventually spirals out of control, the three characters in it seeming as if they are trying to make you regret attending.

title: A Swan Leaps Off the Page and Onto the Stage
description: A swan puppet makes an early appearance in certain versions of Swan Lake, illustrating the heroines ensnarement at the hands of an evil magician. Its a big moment in the narrative, obviously, but that bird has it easy compared with Sophie, who carries on her feathered wings the entire production of Ballerina Swan, a childrens book by the former ballerina Allegra Kent that has been turned into a childrens dance-theater work by Making Books Sing.

title: Egyptian Soccer Star Banned for Expressing Sympathy With Massacred Islamists
description: Updated, Thursday, 2:03 p.m. | Just days after he scored a crucial goal to clinch the African Champions League title for his club, Al Ahly of Cairo, an Egyptian soccer player has been suspended by the team and put up for sale because of the way he celebrated his strike, by raising four fingers in the air.

title: What You Get for ... $1,300,000
description: MADISON, N.J.

title: Homes for $1,300,000
description: A 1903 house in New Jersey, a stone cottage near Dallas and a midcentury modern near Detroit are featured this week.

title: Only 106,000 Pick Health Insurance Plans in First Month
description: WASHINGTON  Just over 106,000 people picked health plans in the first month of open enrollment through the state and federal insurance marketplaces established by the Affordable Care Act, President Obamas health secretary said Wednesday, a fraction of the administrations initial estimate for enrollment during that period.

title: Fantasy Football: Analyzing Matchups of Top Wide Receivers
description: One of the most-used metrics in predicting fantasy football performance is matchup analysis (player versus opposing defense). A particular team gives up a certain amount of fantasy points per game to this position, which is presumed to be a relevant statistic when deciding which player to start that week.

title: Teaching About the Typhoon in the Philippines
description: Please preview this Times video as there are many graphic images.

title: NBCUniversal Takes Full Ownership of Sprout Cable Network
description: The NBCUniversal Cable Entertainment Group said on Wednesday that it had acquired full ownership of the fast-growing preschool cable network PBS Kids Sprout, signaling its intent to more aggressively build up its childrens and family entertainment business, which already encompasses theme parks and movies.

title: Health Care Enrollment Numbers
description: The Department of Health and Human Services released the number of people who have enrolled in the health insurance market place in November.

title: Farm-to-Click
description: The Timess Jenna Wortham reviews Good Eggs, a new food shopping website that delivers locally sourced farmers market products right to your door.

title: Elegance in Auction Country at the Arizona Concours dlgance
description: PHOENIX  Its not as if Kevin Cornish didnt have enough to keep him busy. Hes an executive with a company that consults with hospitals, pharmaceutical manufacturers, health insurers and others in the industry on issues including legislation and litigation.

title: Red Bulls Wrap-Up: Coach Looks Ahead
description: A week after the Red Bulls season came to an abrupt end in the first round of the Major League Soccer playoffs, Coach Mike Petke on Wednesday took part in what is likely to be his final teleconference call this year with reporters.

title: Good Eggs, a Virtual Farmers Market, Delivers Real Food
description: When I was growing up, my father was fond of ordering steaks through the mail. When they arrived, my sister and I gleefully danced around the icy packages and argued over who got to open them. I can still remember marveling at the novelty of meat arriving in the same pile as regular letters, and our amazement that it tasted as good as  if not better than  the beef we purchased in the supermarket.

title: New Rules for Dolphin-Watching
description: As part of its sustainability program, the Six Senses Laamu resort in the Maldives has adopted a code of conduct for its dolphin-watching trips.

title: Eminem Tops Album Chart; Lorde Signs a Deal for Songs
description: If you bought an album last week, there is a 1 in 7 chance that it was The Marshall Mathers LP 2, by Eminem.

title: Till Baby Comes, Keep Smiling
description: LOS ANGELES  Puuuush!

title: A Chef in the Field | Cauliflower
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Bloomberg Issues Final Letter Grades for New York Schools
description: Nothing came to epitomize the era of education reform under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg like the A-through-F letter grades he gave New Yorks schools.

title: Sothebys Contemporary Evening Sale
description: Notable works for sale at Wednesday nights contemporary evening auction at Sothebys in New York.

title: The Traditional Chorus That Keeps Bach Young
description: To comprehend the legacy of the St. Thomas Boys Choir of Leipzig, consider this: When Bach became its music director, called Thomaskantor, in 1723, this eminent institution had already been around for 511 years. Last year, the choir celebrated its 800th anniversary. Currently it is finishing an American tour, presenting 11 concerts over 16 days.

title: E.U. Identifies Problems in Its Members Economies
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions top economic policy chiefs, invoking new oversight tools, warned Germany, France and 14 other member countries on Wednesday to address problems with their economies.

title: Holding Joy Close, and Age at Bay
description: No Evidence of Failure sounds like a phrase from an accident report in which the remains of a crashed vehicle give no clue as to what went wrong. At the Joyce Theater on Tuesday it was the title of a dance celebrating something that has gone mysteriously right: how the 51-year-old dancer Natalie Rogers, who returned to the Garth Fagan Dance company last year after an eight-year break, can still look so amazing.

title: Book Deal or No Book Deal
description: Masterpiece is a new Italian reality show in which writers compete to have their work published.

title: Tired Metaphors? Ciao, Contestant!
description: TURIN, Italy  A novelist craves solitude. Reality TV craves intrusion. So, what happens when writing becomes a broadcast spectacle?

title: A Hostile Bank Takeover
description: The government of Bangladesh has played its trump card in its long-running campaign against Grameen Bank and its founder Muhammad Yunus. Last week, legislators passed a law that effectively nationalizes the bank, which pioneered the idea of making small loans to poor women, by wresting control of it from the 8.4 million rural women that own a majority of its shares.

title: Clip: '12-12-12'
description: A clip from the documentary.

title: Clip: Remembering Moms Mabley
description: A clip from the documentary "Whoopi Goldberg Presents Moms Mabley," airing on HBO Nov. 18.

title: A Writer Thrives in Two Cultures
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In 2010 the novelist Daniel Alarcn was included on The New Yorkers 20 Under 40 list of promising young American writers. Three years earlier his name had appeared on a similar list of Latin American novelists, the Bogot 39, but as a Peruvian.

title: Carlyle-Backed Brazilian Tour Operator Plans Stock Offering
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  A planned stock offering of a Brazilian tour agency and operator backed by the Carlyle Group could raise as much as 1 billion reais, or $428 million, for its existing shareholders, according to a filing on Wednesday.

title: Navigating the Constraints on Reporting from China
description: I ask myself why I stay on here, William L. Shirer wrote in Berlin on Sept. 20, 1940, as World War II deepened and Nazi censorship of his CBS radio broadcasts became intolerable.

title: Gwyneth Paltrows Goop Inspires Famous Imitators
description: In 2008, Gwyneth Paltrow, the actress everyone loves to hate (or so it seems sometimes), decided she wanted to be more than just an actress. She started a nourishing website called Goop to pass along her wisdom of the good life.

title: With Enrollment Slow, Some Democrats Back Change in Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Anxious congressional Democrats are threatening to abandon President Obama on a central element of his signature health care law, voicing increasing support for proposals that would allow Americans who are losing their health insurance coverage because of the Affordable Care Act to retain it.

title: Keynesian Economics and the Journals
description: Brad DeLong takes on John Cochrane again; I dont have the heart or the time to do a full takedown myself. But I do want to make five points.

title: Always an Air of Sorrow, Even in Songs of Love
description: Daniel Woolhouse set the tempo early on Tuesday night. Wearing a ski cap and black T-shirt, he sat down on the Mercury Lounge stage behind a pair of keyboards, pressed a couple of buttons, and there was that bass: sticky, gritty, creepy, oozy.

title: The Crazy Lower Bound
description: John Holbo makes a really interesting point  its a bit subjective, but I suspect that smart political scientists could find a way to quantify it.

title: The Lederer Memorial Trophy in London
description: All top players like to receive an invitation to the Lederer Memorial Trophy in London. It is a most enjoyable weekend, with a social atmosphere and top-level bridge.

title: Going Backstage at a $50 Million Benefit Concert
description: The documentary filmmaker Amir Bar-Lev has made features about the fog of war and the follies of the fine art world, but he had always wanted to make a movie about a music scene. Last year he was given that chance and then some.

title: A Rugged Tablet, but Not for Consumers
description: TOKYO  Would you try this with any tablet, be it an Apple iPad, Microsoft Surface or Samsung Galaxy? Dunk a tablet computer into a bucket of water and keep it submerged for half an hour? NEC, the Japanese electronics company, says you could do it with the NEC Shieldpro H11A tablet. It also says you could drop it from a five-foot height onto a concrete floor.

title: A Stars Tale Reveals Lore of Old Hollywood
description: Victoria Wilsons gargantuan biography of Barbara Stanwyck manages to fill 860 glittering pages of text with only the first half of Stanwycks story. It ends after Stella Dallas (1937) but before The Lady Eve (1941) is even a twinkle in Preston Sturgess eye. And it ends with a cliffhanger, creating eager anticipation for Ms. Wilsons concluding volume. What kind of Parkinsons law, about how work expands to fill available time, can possibly have expanded the Stanwyck story to these proportions?

title: A Corporate Upstairs Downstairs With an Express Elevator to Bed
description: In Ground Floor, a workplace sitcom that begins Thursday on TBS, Bill Lawrence oddly duplicates the template of Cougar Town, the successful series he helped create in 2009.

title: Distortion and Reverberation as a Force of Nature
description: My Bloody Valentine brought its gorgeous onslaught to Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night  its last show, the bands guitarist and leader Kevin Shields announced onstage, for a long time. It was the end of the tour associated with m b v, this Irish bands first album since 1991, which it released in February. My Bloody Valentines sense of timing is entirely its own.

title: Roll With It, Baby
description: It was 10 p.m., and the floor of the basketball court in a Bedford-Stuyvesant Salvation Army center was a blur of roller skate-powered counterclockwise motion.

title: Roller Skating Goes Underground
description: A dance party on wheels attracts even roller disco denizens who never gave up.

title: Reading a Violinist From the Arm, Not Fingers
description: Casual observers tend to concentrate on a violinists left arm: the one, in most cases, with the hand moving crazily up and down the fingerboard, fingers moving like little pistons. But its the right arm  the one with the bow  that makes music, finessing a series of notes into colors and phrases poetic or piquant.

title: Yellen to Back Stimulus Plan in Remarks to Senators
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, President Obamas choice to lead the Federal Reserve for the next four years, plans to tell senators at her confirmation hearing on Thursday that continuing the Feds enormous stimulus campaign is the best way to revive the economy and hasten the programs end.

title: April Bloomfield's Clam Chowder
description: Mark Bittman describes April Bloomfields clam chowder dish as a very fall, New England dish. She demonstrates how to make this coarse-chopped soup.

title: Lou Reeds New York Was Hell or Heaven
description: He wrote about hustlers, drag queens and speed freaks, and about the ordinary dreamers, misfits and down-and-outers who populated the hotels and nighttime streets of New York City  native-born New Yorkers like himself, and all the lost or marginal seekers who came to the city to become somebody else or take a walk on the wild side. Pearly Mae, who cant tell the night from the day; Jackie, who thought she was James Dean for a day; the small kid standing by the Lincoln Tunnel, selling plastic roses for a buck; the druggy downtown kids who spray-paint walls and trains.

title: Chihuahuas Catch a Flight to Their New Homes
description: Virgin America offered a group of California Chihuahuas a lift to the New York area on Wednesday, the fifth time the airline has assisted the San Francisco Department of Animal Care and Control with getting dogs to new homes on the East Coast.

title: Andr Soltner's Pumpkin Soup
description: For Thanksgiving, Andr Soltner prepares a version of pumpkin soup that he watched his mother make over 75 years ago. The creamy soup is served in a pumpkin and garnished with croutons.

title: Rachel Comey Aims for a Bigger Slice of Fashions Pie
description: One brisk afternoon this fall, a few weeks after Rachel Comey showed her spring collection at a dinner in Red Hook, Brooklyn, a few fans dropped by her studio on lower Broadway to browse the new designs.

title: Fashions Royalty Pays Tribute to Its Successors
description: The designer Tom Ford has cultivated a hedonistic image, but who knew that among those to have seen him naked is Anna Wintour. When Mr. Ford was vacationing on St. Barts in the early 1990s, Ms. Wintour was staying near the nude beach, and  whoops  there she was when he sauntered by in the buff.

title: Paper Dolls With Military Stories to Tell
description: The story of American women can be told through paper dolls.

title: William T. Vollmann: The Self Images of a Cross-Dresser
description: SACRAMENTO  As far as writers go, William T. Vollmann is a mans man. In pursuit of a story, he has roughed it with the mujahedeen in Afghanistan and survived a land mine explosion in Bosnia. He singed his eyebrows off and nearly froze to death exploring the magnetic North Pole. In Thailand, he rescued a teenage girl from sex slavery by kidnapping her from a pimp.

title: An Ensemble, in Its 15th Season, Reimagines and Interprets
description: Character pieces, a staple of romantic repertory, traverse a range of often blissful or atmospheric moods and scenes. But there are no dreamy moments in Bernhard Ganders Schlechtecharakterstcke (Bad Character Pieces), a savagely wry, contemporary take on the genre.

title: The Homey Side of Louis Kahn
description: The architect Louis Kahn, who died in 1974, is known for his spare, geometric institutional work like the Salk Institute for Biological Study in the La Jolla section of San Diego and the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. The 2003 documentary My Architect, directed by his son, Nathaniel Kahn, highlighted those buildings, along with Kahns romantic life. The architect had three children, with three different women, two of whom were professional collaborators. A new book, The Houses of Louis Kahn (Yale University Press, $65), provides an architectural bridge between the personal and the professional stories, focusing on the nine houses Kahn completed, and designs for two dozen more. The story told by the authors, George H. Marcus and William Whitaker, is one of warm client relations, attention to the smallest domestic detail and a philosophical search for the best arrangement of rooms to call home. Mr. Marcus, an adjunct assistant professor in the history of art at the University of Pennsylvania, spoke about it by phone late last month. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

title: Factory Farming, From an Animal Point of View
description: Part philosophy lecture, part animal-rights expos, Speciesism: The Movie is a painfully gauche, galumphing attack on factory farming, meat eating, animal experimentation and human supremacy. So many evils, so little time.

title: Opening Statements in Damages Phase of Patent Trial
description: SAN JOSE  Apple and Samsung Electronics this week started the second round of their big patent battle in California. The trial, which is to determine the remaining damages that Samsung will have to pay Apple for infringing on patents, so far feels like Groundhog Day.

title: A Holiday Home to Take Home
description: The banisters of the townhouse at 19 East 75th Street are wrapped in magnolia leaf garlands, and a peek into parlor floor windows reveals a home decked out for the holidays. Except that everything in this home is for sale. It is the Holiday Works, a pop-up shop filled with new and vintage items designed or sourced by Bronson van Wyck, an event planner, and his good friend the interior designer Celerie Kemble. Some goods, like Mr. van Wycks salad dressings and napkin sets, are cash-and-carry. Others, like a bar cart from Ms. Kembles new furniture line for Henredon, must be ordered. But the indisputable stars are two glittering Christmas trees decorated by Mr. van Wyck, which can be assembled in ones home by the so-called Van Wyck Elves (prices start at $17,500). It is meant to be bewitching and engaging, Ms. Kemble said of the shopping experience. Information: 212-861-6160 or theholidayworkshop.com.

title: For D.I.Y.ers, Designer Hardware
description: When Henry Wilson, a 28-year-old Australian designer, ordered hardware online for a sawhorse he was building, he was so disappointed with the quality that he decided to make his own.

title: Bringing Beauty to Hand
description: The Danish designer Kay Bojesen, who was born in 1886 and died in 1958, believed that objects must be nice to hold and a pleasure to look at. Trained as a silversmith at Georg Jensen, he created a flatware pattern in 1938 that won the grand prize at the 1951 Milan Triennale, a biennial design showcase. It has been called Grand Prix ever since. Mr. Bojesens granddaughter, Susanne Bojesen Rosenqvist, lately reintroduced the pattern, which has been in and out of production since its inventors death. Ms. Rosenqvist, who said she has eaten with her grandfathers utensils ever since she could hold a spoon, praised details like the small hump between the knifes shaft and blade, which supports your forefinger when you cut, and the spoons milled edges, designed to capture drips. A five-piece place setting in stainless steel is $150 from Anise, 212-933-1406 or kaybojesen.dk.

title: Deals on Pillows, Rugs and Sofas
description: During Kartells warehouse sale, through Monday, floor samples and some new pieces are up to 70 percent off (the Masters chair by Philippe Starck, originally from $269, is now from $161); 39 Greene Street (Broome Street); 212-966-6665; kartell.com.

title: In the Belly of the Blue Whale
description: More than a year ago, Andy Romanoff, a photographer, was invited to show at a gallery in the Pacific Design Center and became fascinated by the massive Cesar Pelli-designed complex, which opened in 1975 in West Hollywood. I think everybody in L.A. knows the Blue Whale, Mr. Romanoff said, using the centers nickname. But very few people know the inside. Theres a Wolfgang Puck restaurant, a gym  its this secret city.

title: The Nanny Recipes: Skip the Microwave
description: Like other 5-year-olds, Erela Yashiv likes pizza and cupcakes and detests food that contains green specks of vegetables.

title: A Dancer Tries Out Many Moves
description: If it werent already taken, How to Be a Player would probably be a better title for this movie about a 29-year-old Queens man named Julian whose womanizing ways are filmed for an instructional video. In Sex, Love & Salsa, Julian (Adrian Manzano) is a salsa-dancing stalker of dance floors and a crusher of hearts. He cant settle for one woman, so he juggles a few: a nave free spirit played by Sofia Rodriguez; an older woman (Susan Quinn) whos also a friend and wants a baby; and a confident salsa dancer, played by the talented Gabrielle Ruiz, who initially (and wisely) resists his overtures.

title: Brought to Your Knees by a Wood Floor
description: I finally understand how pregnant women feel when others bombard them with birthing horror stories, because I recently attempted the home-improvement equivalent of childbirth: refinishing wood floors.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, Spain, India and Afghanistan.

title: Home Wireless Network Keeps the Snoops Away
description: LIKE most people, Kim Thomas has a broadband connection at home that she uses to check email, surf the Internet and stream music and video.

title: Cindi Leive: Nonstop Days, a Red Carpet Night
description: On Monday, Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour magazine, was sitting in a mostly empty Carnegie Hall, discreetly sipping a smuggled-in container of coffee. She had just run through a rehearsal of her speech onstage for the magazines annual Women of the Year Awards due to start in a few hours, and was debating with a handful of her staff members the merits of using the word Gaga-licious in reference to the honoree Lady Gaga.

title: Art Is Hard to See Through the Clutter of Dollar Signs
description: As our troubled age becomes ever more gilded, art auction prices soar with bone-numbing regularity. A new high-water mark was reached on Tuesday, when a 1969 triptych by the British painter Francis Bacon sold for $142 million while the Christies auction in which it was featured took in $692 million. Both figures exceeded recent highs: One arrived in spring 2012, when Edvard Munchs The Scream sold for $119 million at Sothebys; the other came last spring, when a Christies auction total reached $492 million. It seems that people really, really like art these days.

title: Scenes From the Health Care Hearing
description: Obama administration officials, including the chief technology officer of the United States, testified before Congress about the progress being made to fix the online health insurance exchange.

title: Another Day, Another Catalog Shoot
description: Westport? So 90s. TriBeCa? Over. Brownstone Brooklyn is ground zero for aspirational living now. Just count the ads.

title: Its That Brownstone. Again.
