description: Margaret Reid Boyers photographs are arresting explorations of the evidence of family life and privilege: the domestic litter on a white marble bathroom sink; a patchwork of bright green sod in an expansive, lozenge-shaped backyard; a teenage girl with an inscrutable expression, a Parcheesi game laid out before her on an Indian print-covered table flanked by yellow Eames chairs.

title: Bar Carts: Wheels With a Buzz
description: When a guest orders a martini at Dukes Bar in London, the 105-year-old establishment once frequented by Ian Fleming where the shaken not stirred line is said to have originated, a barman will prepare the drink tableside using provisions from a cart. If the guest is especially lucky, the barman will be Alessandro Palazzi, who has been the bar manager for seven years.

title: Destruction and Dazed Survivors Found in Remote Philippine Areas
description: Updated 1:35 p.m., Nov. 14 The effects of Typhoon Haiyans destructive path on remote areas of the central Philippines are being pieced together as the authorities, journalists and relief workers are finally reaching hard-hit small towns and island fishing villages in eastern Samar Province.

title: Tax Wizardry Accomplished With an Offbeat Merger
description: It used to be easier to avoid paying corporate taxes. Back in the 1990s, many corporations used tax shelters that had little economic substance other than to dodge tax liability. Aggressive enforcement actions by the Internal Revenue Service, coupled with changes in accounting and reporting requirements, have combined to make these shelters unattractive to most companies.

title: Carlyn Cerf de Dudzeele: A Legend Whos Unafraid to Say So
description: TRENDS? PFFT. They mean nothing to Carlyne Cerf de Dudzeele. She prefers the staying power of a Chanel jacket, an Herms Birkin bag and jeans. Like Manolo Blahnik pumps, navy turtlenecks or little black dresses by Azzedine Alaa, these things are never dmod, she said in her Gallic gargle, never, never, neverrh!

title: Spotless Where Others Go Topless
description: For years, Alex Lerner, the host of a Brazilian television show, has taken vacations on St. Barts, where he and his friends rented a house. Eventually, he decided he wanted to live the same way he did on vacation when he was at home.

title: Purist Paradise
description: A fastidious Brazilian gets the house of his dreams, with ocean views and not a speck of dust in sight.

title: Should I Place Furniture in Storage?
description: Q. Should I put some of my furniture in storage to make my apartment look bigger?

title: Famed Austin Nightclub Is Sold
description: Antones, a nightclub in Austin, Tex., that played a big part in establishing that citys reputation as one of the nations centers of live music, has agreed to be bought by a consortium including a National Geographic scientist and a former member of the Dave Matthews Band.

title: Anchorman Spoof of 1970s TV News Is Basis for Newseum Exhibition
description: WASHINGTON  I dont know how to put this, but Im kind of a big deal. ... People know me. ... Im very important. Uh, I have many leather-bound books, and my apartment smells of rich mahogany.

title: Shopping Events Starting Nov. 14 in New York City
description: Openings

title: Tax Authorities in Italy Put Apple Under Investigation
description: ROME  Italian prosecutors have opened an investigation into whether Apple paid all its taxes in the country, an official in Milan said on Wednesday.

title: Winners and Losers From Stimulus
description: As Wall Street tries to gauge when the Federal Reserve might start tapering its stimulus program, a new study from the McKinsey Global Institute illustrates just how deep the impact of such efforts has been since 2007. But it also makes clear that the benefits havent been distributed equally.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: A Snapchat Spurn, and Yahoo to Shed Sandwich.com
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Syrian Forces Recapture Damascus Suburb From Rebels
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian government forces recaptured a suburb south of Damascus on Wednesday and continued battles to push insurgents out of long-held territory outside the northern city of Aleppo, in what appeared to be a major push to gain ground ahead of proposed internationally sponsored peace talks.

title: Caution: Danger in the Traffic Lanes
Marianne Williamson, New-Age Guru, Seeks Congressional Seat
description: REDONDO BEACH, Calif.  Many in the audience at Marianne Williamsons appearance here the other night thought they had come to a book signing: They arrived at the Mysterious Galaxy bookstore clutching her texts, expecting a lecture on the journey to inner peace.

title: F.D.A. Ruling on Trans Fats
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge to Review Files on Brooklyn Detective Scarcella
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered the Brooklyn district attorneys office on Wednesday to produce any documents regarding wrongdoing alleged by inmates, witnesses, lawyers and others against a former homicide detective who is the subject of a wide-ranging review.

title: The Postal Services Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: After Twitter #Fail, JPMorgan Calls Off Q. and A.
description: JPMorgan Chase helped take Twitter public last week. But on Wednesday evening, the banking giant got a taste of the social networks power  in a very negative way.

title: U.N. Rights Hypocrisy
Negotiating With Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Considers Neutrality Agreements Between Unions and Employers
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a major labor case that, depending on how it is resolved, could hamper the ability of unions to mount successful campaigns to organize workers.

title: Crayons Down. Now Dig Into That Healthful Parfait.
description: The 22 children in a Head Start class in East Harlem shopped for plastic carrots and tomatoes at their own version of a New York City green cart, counted backward from five with a picture of blueberries, and jumped up and down to a song about bananas.

title: Jewish Aid to the Philippines
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Give More Patients Statins
description: ON Tuesday, the American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology issued new cholesterol guidelines that essentially declared, in one fell swoop, that millions of healthy Americans should immediately start taking pills  namely statins  for undefined health benefits.

title: Todd Christensen, Record-Setting Tight End, Dies at 57
description: Todd Christensen, a sticky-fingered, record-setting tight end for the Oakland and Los Angeles Raiders who made five Pro Bowl teams and played on two Super Bowl champions, died on Wednesday in Murray, Utah, near Salt Lake City. He was 57.

title: Raising a Sick Daughter Was Hard Enough, Then They Lost Their Jobs
description: When Megan McSween learned her second-grade class was scheduled to take a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge, she was ecstatic.

title: Obamacare and Character
description: The presidents job approval numbers have hit new lows. Thats actually not the worst news in a new round of polling. The worst news  or what the White House should find most worrisome  is that the presidents character has taken a hit.

title: Boehner Rules Out Negotiations on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  Signaling an end to the push for major immigration legislation this year, Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday ruled out negotiations between the House and the Senate on an expansive immigration overhaul similar to one approved by the Senate with bipartisan support in June.

title: M.T.A. Sees Smaller Fare Increases in 15 and 17
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Wednesday that it expected to scale back fare and toll increases planned for 2015 and 2017, potentially tempering the effects of what has become an unwelcome biennial ritual for riders.

title: Four Marines Are Killed in Camp Pendleton Accident
description: LOS ANGELES  Four Marines were killed Wednesday in an accident during maintenance of an artillery range at a base outside San Diego, military officials said.

title: State Dept. Calls Group in Nigeria Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department on Wednesday branded Boko Haram, the homegrown Islamist insurgent movement in Nigeria that has ties to Al Qaedas regional affiliate in North and West Africa, as a foreign terrorist organization.

title: Three Students Are Shot Near Pittsburgh School
description: Three students were shot near a Pittsburgh high school minutes after dismissal on Wednesday, and police officers who surrounded two nearby homes took six people into custody for questioning.

title: Jets Consider Adding Reed at Safety
description: Coach Rex Ryan said he was pleased with the Jets safeties. Pleased enough to pass up a chance to add perhaps the best safety ever, Ed Reed?

title: Car Mechanic Dreams Up a Tool to Ease Births
description: The idea came to Jorge Odn as he slept. Somehow, he said, his unconscious made the leap from a YouTube video he had just seen on extracting a lost cork from a wine bottle to the realization that the same parlor trick could save a baby stuck in the birth canal.

title: Bring Me a Case
description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wasnt persuaded last week by a petition that asked the Supreme Court to review the fairness of the settlement of a lawsuit against Facebook. He joined his eight colleagues in deciding against hearing the case. No big deal there. The case, Marek v. Lane, was one of nearly 300 appeals the justices turned down upon their return from a two-week recess.

title: New Cholesterol Advice Startles Even Some Doctors
description: Steven L. Zweibel has been taking a statin drug to lower his cholesterol for seven years. It has worked, and he has suffered no problems or side effects.

title: Lin Is Better Off (and Better)
description: PHILADELPHIA  No one, least of all Jeremy Lin, would be so presumptuous to call it a last laugh. But it is fair to say that Lin has earned, at the expense of his former team and its impetuous owner, a well-timed chortle.

title: Serving Life for This?
description: So youre a judge, and Sharanda P. Jones comes before you for sentencing for conspiracy to distribute crack cocaine.

title: Kerry and Biden Ask for Room to Reach a Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. pressed senators on Wednesday to give the Obama administration some breathing room to reach an accord with Iran to freeze its nuclear programs, warning that a new round of sanctions could mean war instead of diplomacy.

title: California Health Exchange Beats All Others in Enrollment, Officials Say
description: In its first month of business, Californias insurance exchange enrolled more people than any other state-run exchange and more than the federal exchange serving 36 states, which has been paralyzed by technological failures.

title: Iran and Western Powers Clash Over Why Nuclear Talks Failed
description: TEHRAN  Less than a week before the next round of nuclear talks in Geneva, it is still not clear why the last round failed, and who exactly walked away from the deal. Irans foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, has laid the blame on the Western powers, saying they were divided. He says he has little to do now but wait for the world powers to get their act together.

title: No Complete Games but a Cy Young Award
description: The Detroit Tigers Max Scherzer did something on Wednesday that no starting pitcher had ever done before. He won a Cy Young Award before registering his first career complete game.

title: Brazil: Forensic Team Exhumes Leaders Remains
description: A team of forensic experts on Wednesday began exhuming the remains of Joo Goulart, the Brazilian president ousted in a 1964 coup supported by the United States, to examine whether he was poisoned by spies while living in exile in Argentina. The authorities carried out the exhumation in So Borja, a city in southern Brazil, at the urging of Mr. Goularts family. They are seeking to examine a claim by a former Uruguayan intelligence operative that Mr. Goulart was assassinated by agents of Operation Condor, a joint campaign by South American military dictatorships in the 1970s and 80s to eliminate political dissidents. Mr. Goulart had long been thought to have died from natural causes. Officials said that his remains would be flown to the capital, Braslia, to undergo testing.

title: Imbruvica, Drug to Treat Blood Cancer, Gains F.D.A. Approval
description: A new cancer drug that has attracted considerable attention from doctors and investors won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday.

title: Texas Universitys Race Admissions Policy Is Debated Before a Federal Court
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  An affirmative-action program at the University of Texas at Austin that takes applicants race into account was unnecessary because the campus had achieved a critical mass of minority students, lawyers for the white applicant who sued the university told a federal appeals court here on Wednesday in a case with high stakes for the future of race-conscious admissions policies at public colleges and universities.

title: Saudi Arabia Officially Rejects U.N. Security Council Seat
description: Saudi Arabia has officially rejected in writing the United Nations Security Council seat it won last month, clearing the way for a replacement country to be chosen, diplomatic officials said Wednesday.

title: From Practice Squad to Starter
description: GREEN BAY  Until two weeks ago, Green Bay Packers quarterback Scott Tolzien dressed in the N.F.L.s version of a bus station, the auxiliary locker room at Lambeau Field reserved for the practice squad. Occupants change weekly. Anonymity is never a problem.

title: Council Asks Toronto Mayor to Step Down Temporarily
description: OTTAWA  Shortly after Torontos City Council voted Wednesday to ask Mayor Rob Ford to step down temporarily, a court released documents that painted a salacious picture of a combative, drunken mayor who assaulted staff members and entertained suspected prostitutes.

title: Les Brown, Pioneer in Television Journalism, Dies at 84
description: Les Brown, who was one of the first journalists to cover television comprehensively from its early days, reporting on it for The New York Times, founding and editing a groundbreaking magazine about the industry and producing an authoritative TV encyclopedia, died on Nov. 4 at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 84.

title: HSN Joins With Univision to Reach the Hispanic Market
description: HSN, the home shopping network, is turning its sights toward Hispanic consumers with the announcement of a new e-commerce partnership with Univision Communications that will begin on Thursday.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 13, 2013
Europes (Low) Inflation Problem
description: Just a quick chart that I think illustrates the problem of German non-reciprocity especially clearly.

title: Sri Lankas Climate of Fear
description: Since the end of Sri Lankas civil war in 2009, the government of President Mahinda Rajapaksa has had a record of serious human rights violations and failed to provide accountability for wartime abuses.

title: An Unwise Airline Merger
description: In August, the Justice Departments antitrust division filed a lawsuit to block the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, which would create the worlds largest airline and concentrate 80 percent of the domestic air-travel business in the hands of four companies.

title: A New Alliance on Climate Change
description: In an effort to compensate for the failure of central governments to address the dangers of climate change with comprehensive national policies, cities, states and regions have developed their own strategies to rein in emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. Californias ambitious plan aims to reduce emissions 80 percent by 2050 by requiring cleaner cars, more energy-efficient buildings and renewable fuels. Nine northeastern states have joined in a regional trading program aimed at reducing power-plant emissions.

title: Resistance to Marriage Equality
description: This is wrong. That was Defense Secretary Chuck Hagels blunt response late last month to states defying his order in August that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given full spousal and family benefits, including health care coverage and housing allowances, on an equal, nondiscriminatory basis.

title: At a Philippine Hospital, Survivors Face Quiet Despair
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Richard Pulga, a 27-year-old farmer with thick black hair and a gentle manner, has been lying on a hard steel bed in a dark hallway of the main hospital here since Saturday with a shattered lower right leg, abdominal pain and his right eye filling with blood.

title: Future Unclear for Towers on East Side
description: The day after the Bloomberg administration withdrew its plan for a swath of glass towers in Midtown because of an absence of support in the City Council, a developer, David W. Levinson, was fielding phone calls at his office near Carnegie Hall.

title: Does My Virginity Have a Shelf Life?
description: When I was 20, one of my close friends was killed in a car crash. At the funeral, as I watched her coffin carried down the aisle, another friend leaned over to whisper: At least she wasnt a virgin.

title: Twisting and Turbulent Case for Formula One Chief
description: LONDON  As 11 Formula One teams prepared recently to head for Austin, Tex., where the penultimate round of this years 19-race championship will take place Sunday, it was not the domination of the German driver Sebastian Vettel, winner of 11 of this years races and a strong favorite in Austin, that spurred the most fevered talk among grand prix racing insiders.

title: The Art of Senate Stoppage
description: When were choosing a leader for the nations central banking system, one of the important things to consider is whether Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has heard enough testimony about the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Federal Panel Softens Tone on Judge It Removed From Stop-and-Frisk Case
description: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan that had abruptly removed Judge Shira A. Scheindlin from New York Citys high-profile stop-and-frisk litigation and questioned her conduct in the case issued a lengthy explanation on Wednesday, saying it had made no findings of misconduct, actual bias or actual partiality by the judge.

title: Bernanke the Teacher, Talking to Teachers
description: Janet Yellen will take the stage Thursday morning in what is effectively her debut as the Federal Reserves new leader. But the job still belongs to Ben S. Bernanke, who on Wednesday night held a low-key question-and-answer session with teachers.

title: Philippines President Faces Growing Anger
description: MANILA  Five days after a devastating typhoon swept through the midsection of this impoverished island nation, Filipinos are losing patience with the slow relief effort, increasingly angry with their president, Benigno S. Aquino III, a popular figure who has until now navigated multiple crises during his three years in office.

title: Rejecting Billions, Snapchat Expects a Better Offer
description: What business makes no money, has yet to pass its third anniversary and just turned down an offer worth billions of dollars? Snapchat, a social media service run by a pair of 20-somethings who until last month worked out of a beachfront bungalow in Venice, Calif.

title: Giants, With a History of Losing to Backups, Are Wary of Tolzien
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants on Sunday will face quarterback Scott Tolzien, who threw his first N.F.L. pass just a few days ago. If this bodes well for the Giants, they are not buying it.

title: Yes, Youve Heard the Joke Before, but Thats Exactly the Point
description: Songs can get stuck in your head, but what about jokes?

title: Should Politicians' Spouses Shape Policy?
Echo Chamber
description: Tom McCoy, a college freshman, makes his debut today with a crossword full of clever INTERPLAY between the clues. Certain items have an echo, like the duplicate entries about 007 (the ALIAS for British spy extraordinaire James BOND), and the repetition of knight, with clues about a knights title (SIR) and activity (QUESTING.)

title: JPMorgans Fruitful Ties to a Member of Chinas Elite
description: To promote its standing in China, JPMorgan Chase turned to a seemingly obscure consulting firm run by a 32-year-old executive named Lily Chang.

title: From the Shadows, a Rebel Group Vexes Paraguay
description: The Paraguayan Peoples Army is evolving from a ghostlike irritant for the authorities into a broader security threat.

title: Guerrillas Step Up Campaign in Paraguay
description: TACUAT, Paraguay  The guerrillas appeared at dusk.

title: Lawyer Concedes Mistakes in Chevron Case
description: For the last month, Chevron has presented a parade of witnesses against Steven R. Donziger, the freelance lawyer who has been suing the company for 20 years over pollution of the Ecuadorean Amazon jungle. One after another, the witnesses, including some of his closest allies and financiers who are now estranged from his cause, have testified that Mr. Donziger committed witness tampering and fraud.

title: Nash Skates, but Return to Rangers Is Not Set
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rick Nash, symptom-free, looked great in practice Wednesday, his first with his Rangers teammates since sustaining a concussion in a game at San Jose on Oct. 8.

title: JPMorgan and the Wen Family
description: The banks primary ties to the family of former Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China and its colleagues.

title: Shopping, Before the Turkey Gets Cold
description: Teenagers and college students can spend only so much time cooped up with their families on a holiday like Thanksgiving.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 14, 2013
description: I dont have any money, Ive lost everything, even my house is gone. Thats what is on my mind.

title: Corrections: November 14, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: India: Official Criticized for a Reference to Rape
description: One of Indias top law enforcement officials drew criticism on Wednesday for making an offhand reference to rape during a public debate on gambling, remarking that arguing to legalize betting is like saying if you cant prevent rape, enjoy it. In a country newly sensitized to sexual violence, the remarks by Ranjit Sinha, director of the Central Bureau of Investigation, immediately echoed on Twitter and were covered by television news channels. Some activists called on Mr. Sinha, who heads a bureau supervising corruption and other grave crimes, including rape and murder, to step down. Mr. Sinha swiftly released a statement of apology: I regret any hurt caused, as the same was inadvertent and unintended, it read, explaining that he was condemning such reasoning, and adding, I reiterate my deep sense of respect for women and commitment to gender issues.

title: After Strong Growth in First Half of 2013, the Japanese Economy Hits a Snag
description: TOKYO  After a surprising spurt of strong growth in the first half of the year, the Japanese economy seems to be running out of steam as exports and consumer spending show signs of weakening.

title: IBM to Announce More Powerful Watson via the Internet
description: LAS VEGAS  Welcome to the age of supercomputing for everyone.

title: Concession in Airline Merger Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON  When the Justice Department announced in August that it had filed suit to block the proposed merger of US Airways and American Airlines, it maintained that airline consolidation had gone too far and the proposed merger would lead to higher fares for consumers.

title: Up in the Air
description: Developer SL Green Realty had hoped to build a massive structure across from Grand Central Terminal.

title: Secret Service Officer Is Demoted From Presidential Detail
description: WASHINGTON  A Secret Service supervisor has been removed from President Obamas security detail and demoted after being accused of leaving a bullet in a womans room at a luxury hotel near the White House this year, senior federal law enforcement officials said Wednesday.

title: Redfin Raises $50 Million in Latest Financing Round
description: While the online home information space may be crowded, investors seem to believe that Redfin has a good chance of standing out.

title: Grisly Warhol Painting Fetches $104.5 Million, Auction High for Artist
description: One of Andy Warhols more powerful and provocative images  a lifeless body amid the gruesome wreckage of a car crash  sold for $104.5 million at Sothebys contemporary art auction on Wednesday night, making it the highest price ever paid at auction for the Pop artist.

title: Boras Has a Few Zingers, and a Few Free-Agent Stars, for the Mets
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Scott Boras entered the hotel lobby here Wednesday afternoon like a rock star, mobbed by reporters. He was about to give what has become his annual unofficial address at the general managers meetings, discussing his clients and baseball in general. One of the first questions posed to him was about the Mets.

title: Shaking Up Strategy, Knicks Shake Off Woes and Hawks
description: ATLANTA  The Knicks arrived here accompanied by their usual turbulence. Starting guard Iman Shumpert, perhaps the player with the most upside on the roster, was mentioned in trade rumors. The teams owner, James L. Dolan, guaranteed a win onstage with his blues band, and the teams toughness on defense was questioned without the injured Tyson Chandler. Coach Mike Woodson was receiving blame for the teams uneven start.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Colts (6-3) at Titans (4-5)
description: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

title: Fair-Housing Case Is Settled Before It Reaches Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  A housing discrimination case scheduled to be heard by the Supreme Court next month has been settled, the parties announced Wednesday night. Civil rights groups, wary of a Supreme Court ruling that they feared could weaken protections for victims of housing discrimination, welcomed the development.

title: N.F.L. Week 11 Game Probabilities: Can Chiefs Finish Undefeated?
description: One of the interesting things to do with game probabilities is estimate the likelihood that a team will finish undefeated. Coming off their bye week, the undefeated Kansas City Chiefs have seven games remaining. Winning all of those games is extremely unlikely, especially considering they have yet to face the formidable Denver Broncos.

title: Tailored for Travel
description: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets  perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.

title: A Pioneering Collaborator of Le Corbusier Finally Gets Her Due
description: As an homage to Charlotte Perriands creative force, Louis Vuitton is building, for the first time, one of the legendary Modernists never-realized designs.

title: Sizing Up the Fiscal Future
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Ask Well: Table Salt vs. Sea Salt
description: Question:

title: Word of the Day | vicissitude
description: vicissitude \v-si-s-td, vi-, -tyd\ noun

title: Nets, Continuing Skid in Sacramento, Offer No Excuses
description: SACRAMENTO  For weeks, the Nets seemed willing to tie their poor play to their newness as a group. The process of adjusting to a new system, to new teammates, justified their string of surprising losses, and few could challenge them on that point.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS (2010) Michael Douglas, below, returns as the reptilian Gordon Gekko who, after eight years in prison, has landed in the spotlight once again for writing a critical and prescient book about the state of the markets. Shia LaBeouf portrays the investment banker Jake Moore, one of Gekkos fans and the live-in love of Gekkos daughter (Carey Mulligan). Frank Langella is the old-school broker who has been like a father to Jake. And Josh Brolin is the newest snake in town. Let the games resume. To the question What went wrong? the film offers an answer that is both irrefutable and unsatisfying: human nature, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And yet, he added, something vital here works. The director, Oliver Stone, is not the man to explain Wall Street, or to stoke public indignation at its crimes, he said. But no one else could turn it into a show like Wall Street.

title: Boeing Workers Reject Labor Deal in Washington State
description: Members of a union representing thousands of Boeing employees voted late Wednesday to reject a controversial labor deal that would have cut compensation but have kept assembly of the companys new 777X jets in Washington State, raising the chance that Boeing will move more production away from its traditional manufacturing base in the Seattle area.

title: News Quiz | November 14, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: China Moving to End Some Cosmetics Testing on Animals
description: YES! wrote Hou Xiaomu, an animal lover, on Weibo, about the news that Chinas food and drug authorities are moving toward ending the testing of cosmetics on animals. About 300,000 animals  rabbits, mice and others  may be used each year in testing cosmetics here, Humane Society International estimates.

title: Northern Chinese Brace for Smog Spike as Winter Heating Kicks In
description: Harbin a metropolis in Chinas northeastern reaches made international headlines last month when it experienced air pollution so abysmal that the government closed all schools and officials urged the citys 11 million residents to stay indoors as visibility dropped to just 10 meters, roughly the width of a typical traffic intersection.

title: Japan Honors Chinese Student for Heroism
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan has honored a Chinese student for his courageous act in rescuing a Japanese boy from drowning, a bright spot in an otherwise tense period in diplomatic relations.

title: Chinese Rights Campaigner Held Hunger Strike, Lawyer Says
description: HONG KONG  A prominent human rights campaigner in southern China won his first meeting with a lawyer on Thursday after more than three months in detention and said he had been on a hunger strike, one of his lawyers said.

title: Overshadowed by Tacloban, Other Devastated Philippine Cities Fear Aid Will Not Come
description: HONG KONG  While relief efforts for Typhoon Haiyan have been focused on the Philippine city of Tacloban, aid groups say other cities in Leyte Province have also suffered vast devastation, with residents facing increasing dangers with the passage of time.

title: A Conversation With: Former Political Editor of Open Magazine Hartosh Singh Bal
description: Hartosh Singh Bal, the political editor of Open magazine, announced on Wednesday that he had received a letter of termination. It was the second high-profile sacking within the Indian media in the space of a month; in late October, Siddharth Varadarajan resigned as editor-in-chief of The Hindu, an influential daily newspaper, when the papers owners told him he would be replaced.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 14, 2013
description: Use context clues to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

title: 6 Qs About the News | 1 World Trade Center Is Named the Tallest Building in the U.S.
description: In By a Spire, Manhattan Regains a Title From Chicago, Patrick McGeehan and Charles V. Bagli write about the new tallest building in the United States.

title: Euro Zone Economy Stalls as Germany and France Backtrack
description: PARIS  The euro zone economy marked time in the third quarter of the year, growing just 0.1 percent from the second quarter, a report on Thursday showed, disappointing hopes that a full-fledged recovery was finally taking hold after five years of recession and stagnation.

title: A Civil Rights Photographer, and a Struggle, Are Remembered
description: Jon Lewis shot thousands of archetypical civil rights photographs in the late 1960s: a picket line snaking along the horizon, children playing in squalor, activists huddled in a strategy session. What makes these photographs different is their location and the subjects. Taken in central California and not in the Jim Crow South, they depict farm laborers of Mexican and Filipino descent, the vanguard of the historic Delano grape strike.

title: When the Doctor Disappears
description: Dr. Daniel Geynisman felt as if he had abandoned his patient, a sickening sensation.

title: God Called Them to Adopt. And Adopt. And Adopt.
description: Misty and her husband, Jon, arrived at a house near Denver one day several years ago to pick up the two boys who would become their sons. A dirt yard led to a screen door dangling from its hinges. Inside, grime coated the linoleum steps to the living room, where a kind, if overwhelmed, single foster mother introduced Misty and Jon to Shon, 2  years old, and his 9-month-old brother, Cory. She gave the couple a tiny suitcase with a broken zipper, a few borrowed clothes  some too big, others too small  and a piece of advice: Dont touch Shons head or lift your hands near him. He will cower. Then she handed Jon a huge bag of frozen fish sticks. The kids love them, she said.

title: How Important Are Parent-Teacher Conferences?
description: A recent Room for Debate feature presented a variety of views on the value of parent-teacher conferences.

title: New York Today: Cabs of a Different Color
description: Updated 2:50 p.m. | A strange species of transport is appearing around the city: taxi cabs painted a sickly sour-apple green.

title: Iceland Is Building a National Team to Watch
description: LONDON  With all due respect to Cristiano Ronaldo and Zlatan Ibrahimovic, whose egos go head to head for Portugal against Sweden on Friday, the good folks of Iceland will not even glance at the score coming from Lisbon.

title: China Increases Aid to Philippines
description: BEIJING  China has announced that it is increasing its humanitarian assistance to typhoon victims in the Philippines, after international groups and a Chinese newspaper criticized an initial government donation of $100,000 as too meager.

title: French Muscle, American Cheese
description: PARIS  French-American relations, often a study in how close love can be to hatred, have taken an interesting turn of late. The cheese-eating surrender monkeys of France, in the phrase from The Simpsons, have become the worlds meat-chomping enforcement tigers. As for the United States, it has, in the French view, gone a touch camembert-soft.

title: Ravaged by Typhoon, Philippines Faces Threat of Serious Diseases
description: The aftermath of the Philippines typhoon is now threatening the country with outbreaks of debilitating and potentially fatal diseases, including some thought to have been nearly eradicated, because of a collapse in sanitation, shortages of fresh water and the inability of emergency health teams to respond quickly in the week since the storm struck, doctors and medical officials said Thursday.

title: Slowdown in Japan Raises the Pressure on Abe
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is now under more pressure to deliver on his much-promoted effort to improve the countrys long-term growth prospects, after a government estimate on Thursday showed that the economy had slowed in the quarter that ended in September.

title: What the Proposed Crowdfunding Rules Could Cost Businesses
description: A small business that elects to raise money from the masses should prepare for a lifetime of disclosure and fees. According to the recently proposed rules from the Securities and Exchange Commission, a crowdfunded company will have to file annual reports until either all of its crowdfunded securities have been bought out, it goes public or it is dissolved.

title: India Pays Homage as Its Greatest Cricketer Nears Retirement
description: Long before Sachin Tendulkar arrived at the Eden Gardenscricketground in Kolkata for the penultimatecricketmatch of his career, a wax statue of the greatest Indiancricketerwas placed outside the Indian dressing room. The statue reproduced an image embedded in the psyche of every Indiancricketfan. It was the gesture the 40-year-old Mr. Tendulkar adopted whenever he reached a scoring landmark: cricketbat raised in one hand, helmet in the other.

title: What to Watch For at the Yellen Hearing
description: Janet L. Yellen is widely expected to win confirmation as the Federal Reserves first chairwoman. Her appearance before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday morning is mostly a chance for senators to probe what kind of leader she will be.

title: Daily Report: Snapchat Waits for a Better Offer Than Facebooks
description: What business makes no money, has yet to pass its third anniversary and just turned down an offer worth billions of dollars? Snapchat, a social media platform run by a pair of 20-somethings who until last month worked out of a beachfront bungalow in Venice, Calif., Jenna Wortham reports.

title: The Jon Stewart of Egypt Is Gagged
description: CAIRO  When the Egyptian comedian Bassem Youssef came back on the air late last month, everyone wondered whether he would have the courage to mock the army and its leader, Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, as he once did the Islamists and former President Mohamed Morsi  and whether hed get away with it.

title: Hezbollah Chief Says His Forces Will Stay in Syria
description: LONDON  The head of Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite militant group whose armed followers are fighting in Syria on the side of President Bashar al-Assad, pledged on Thursday that his forces would remain there as long as necessary.

title: Former German President Goes on Trial
description: BERLIN  For the first time in modern German history, a former president, Christian Wulff, went on trial on Thursday in a state court in Hanover, charged with illegally accepting favors while he was governor of the state of Lower Saxony.

title: Morning Agenda: A Member of Chinas Elite Tied to JPMorgan
description: JPMORGANS TIES TO A MEMBER OF CHINAS ELITE |

title: Amy Errett of Madison Reed, on Finding Your Genius
description: This interview with Amy Errett, chief executive and co-founder of Madison Reed, a provider of in-home hair color, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Food and Fuel Prices Push Indian Inflation Higher
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias benchmark inflation rate increased to 7 percent in October, the highest in eight months, driven primarily by higher fuel and food prices, according to government data released on Thursday.

title: European Banking Unity Is No Easy Target
description: FRANKFURT  Low interest rates have a dark side, the German central bank warned on Thursday, sounding a gloomy note as European finance ministers gathered in Brussels to discuss the politically tricky question of how to share responsibility for fixing sick banks.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: The Rise and Fall of Paramount Records, Volume One (1917-1927)
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Hungry and Panhandling
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Holidays: A Bit More Giving, a Bit Less Getting
description: Some people react to my obsession with parenting, money and values by assuming that it has little to do with them. Take my friends in a low-key Midwestern state, who are both public-sector employees. Wasnt this topic, they wondered, something that only affluent suburban parents or private-school people needed to worry about?

title: Storied French Piano Manufacturer to Close
description: PARIS  Ending an era on a mournful chord, Pleyel, the storied French piano manufacturer whose pianos were once favored by Frdric Chopin and Maurice Ravel, has announced that it will close its workshop after two centuries of production.

title: Air France-KLM Signals Wavering Faith in Alitalia
description: PARIS  Air France-KLM, the French-Dutch airline, said Thursday that it would not take part in a plan to inject 300 million euros into Alitalia, arguing that the faltering Italian flag carrier was not prepared to take sufficient steps to reduce its mounting debt.

title: Homeless Kids in Rough Schools
description: Working-aged adults who lost their jobs, homes and savings to the recession will have a difficult enough time establishing normal lives when the economy rights itself. The trauma will be especially deep and long lasting for the burgeoning population of children who were driven into homelessness  or even given up by their parents  when the world turned upside down in the Great Recession of 2008.

title: Yellens Confirmation Hearing
description: Janet L. Yellen, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testified Thursday before the Senate Banking Committee at a hearing on her nomination to succeed Ben S. Bernanke as Fed chief. In her opening statement, released by the Fed on Wednesday, Ms. Yellen made the case for the Feds current stimulus program, declaring, I believe that supporting the recovery today is the surest path to returning to a more normal approach to monetary policy. A running account of the hearing follows.

title: Knee or Hip Replacement Cuts Heart Risks
description: For people with severe arthritis, knee or hip replacement may have an added benefit: a reduction in the risk for cardiovascular disease.

title: Census Shows Shift in New Yorks Population Dynamic After Recession
description: The recession, which officially ended in 2009, affected New York Citys population dynamic in two ways. People who might have left the city didnt, in part because they couldnt sell their homes or werent lured to jobs elsewhere. Also, the influx of foreigners from abroad slowed.

title: Can We Outgrow Growth (as the Metric That Matters)?
description: Im running a discussion this morning at the United Nations focusing on a core issue on this blog: Do We Have to Outgrow Growth?

title: Groups Mobilize to Aid Democrats in 14 Data Arms Race
description: Liberal and Democratic-leaning groups, facing difficult midterm elections next year without the technological muscle of the Obama campaign behind them, are preparing a major effort to improve their data infrastructure.

title: Ireland Is to Exit Its Bailout, and Without a Safety Net
description: LONDON  Ireland announced on Thursday that it would make a clean break from its international bailout program next month and do it without first seeking a precautionary credit line.

title: Starboard Joins Fight Over Fate of Compuware
description: Compuware has already spent the better part of the year fending off one activist shareholder. Now, it faces another.

title: With Bulls, Its No Walk in the Park
description: Images from the Great Bull Run in Conyers, Ga., which included an event called the Tomato Royale.

title: Running of the Bulls Comes to America
description: Thousands risked themselves during the Great Bull Run, an Americanized version of Spains running of the bulls.

title: Crime Boss Bulger Gets 2 Life Terms and Is Assailed by Judge for His Depravity
description: BOSTON  James (Whitey) Bulger, Bostons most notorious gangster, was condemned on Thursday to spend the rest of his life in prison, receiving two life sentences plus five years.

title: For Thrill Seekers, a Bull Run With a Different Hook
description: CONYERS, Ga.  The 600 runners were limbering up for what they had been assured would be the most awesome adventure of their lives. And what might that be? They were paying for the opportunity to be chased around a dusty, quarter-mile track by an angry herd of stampeding bulls.

title: Obama Moves to Avert Cancellation of Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, trying to quell a growing furor over the rollout of his health care law, bowed to bipartisan pressure on Thursday and announced a policy reversal that would allow insurance companies to temporarily keep people on health plans that were to be canceled under the new law because they did not meet minimum standards.

title: Players, Heres the Drill
description: Less than an hour before he was due to roar onto the stage on a motorcycle in Romeo and Juliet, Orlando Bloom strode along the gilded balcony of the Richard Rodgers Theater, contorting his mouth and making peculiar noises. Imagine managing an imaginary menagerie, he said so fast that the words blurred together, then repeated the tongue twister, more complex this time. He fluttered his lips like a horse, exhaling.

title: Poetry Pairing | Forever  Is Composed of Nows
description: This Poetry Pairing pays tribute to Emily Dickinson (1830-86) and the scholars and archivists whose efforts ensure the poems, letters and other materials she left behind are preserved and accessible. We pair her poem Forever  Is Composed of Nows  with the article Enigmatic Dickinson Revealed Online by Jennifer Schuessler.

title: In Our Pages: November 15
description: 1938: Rich Jews Told to Pay Fines

title: What Makes a Great Shakespearean?
description: Tastes in acting, as in everything else, certainly vary, but a great Shakespearean performance is easy to spot. You know one when you see one, although its probably more accurate to say that you know one when you dont see one: when the language no longer feels remote, when the humanity of the actor and the character seem indivisible, when the emotion being expressed is no longer veiled by poetic phrasing but revealed by it, creating a shock of recognition in your own heart.

title: Some Help on the Nonrefundable Front
description: Nonrefundable hotel rates  theyre often the downfall of the thrifty traveler. While cheaper rates can be alluring, there is almost nothing more maddening than paying for a room you are not sleeping in owing to circumstances beyond your control.

title: Amy Tan: By the Book
description: The author of The Valley of Amazement and The Joy Luck Club fantasizes about catching up on reading in prison: No email, no useless warranties, . . . no invitations to fund-raisers.

title: Robert Plant Produces a Documentary Series About Malian Music
description: When the singer Robert Plant visited Mali to perform at the Festival in the Desert, in 2003, he brought a video camera and documented Malian life, both in towns and in the desert, as well as the festival itself. Mostly, Mr. Plant was the cameraman; on occasion, Logan, his son, took over. Also with Mr. Plant on the trip, and seen in the footage, were Justin Adams and Skin Tyson, who both played bass and guitars in Mr. Plants band at the time, the Strange Sensation. (With Mr. Plant, formerly of Band of Joy, Led Zeppelin, the Honeydrippers and others  including, most recently, a new version of Band of Joy  you really cant tell the players without a scorecard.)

title: T WINTER TRAVEL
description: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets  perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Matchup Breakdown
description: Remember when there was no safer play in fantasy football than Tom Brady?

title: MARKET REPORT
description: Warm and fuzzy winter pieces range from the bold to the understated, all with extra fluff this season.

title: Image of the Day: November 14
A Sign of Desperation in Facebooks Snapchat Offer
description: Facebooks Snapchat bid shows triple the desperation. The social network paid $1 billion for no-revenue Instagram a little over a year ago. Now, its said to be dangling as much as $3 billion to lure a mobile app that sends self-destructing digital images. Facebooks apparently escalating need to buy off marauders at its moat suggests its defenses may be scalable.

title: Siding With Google, Judge Says Book Search Does Not Infringe Copyright
description: Googles idea to scan millions of books and make them searchable online seemed audacious when it was announced in 2004. But fast-forward to today, when people expect to find almost anything they want online, and the plan seems like an unsurprising and unavoidable part of todays Internet.

title: Furniture by Lockwood de Forest and His Peers
description: The plutocrats of 19th-century New York relied on a handful of furniture makers who all knew one another. The connections among patrons and artisans have become more traceable in recent months, since rooms full of original commissions  with Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Moorish and Egyptian motifs  are being reassembled around the country. Its the most incredibly interlocking society, Sarah D. Coffin, the lead decorative arts curator at the Smithsonians Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, said in an interview. She was leafing through images of works by Lockwood de Forest and his cousin-in-law and business partner Louis Comfort Tiffany, made for the museum buildings first owner, Andrew Carnegie.

title: JFK
description: TKTK

title: On Philippines Relief, Comparing the U.S. and China
description: American marines landed in the Philippines this week, the vanguard of an operation to help thousands of desperate victims of the worst typhoon in recent decades. The United States is also sending an aircraft carrier, other ships, 5,000 sailors and $20 million, just to start. Meanwhile, China, the worlds second largest economy and the rising power that so many countries in Asia fear, initially donated a paltry $100,000 to the rescue effort. According to Xinhua, it then bumped the number to $1.4 million, still pretty meager.

title: Reed, Not Ready for End, Joins Jets and Reunites With Ryan
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Ed Reed, a nine-time Pro Bowl safety, did not have the right uniform number, the right shoes at practice, or the right look for his first on-camera interviews as a member of the Jets.

title: Acrostic
description: Acrostic puzzle for November 17, 2013

title: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Player Tiers
description: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

title: Travel Guide: Chicago for Kids
description: Much of Chicago is surprisingly easy to visit with children, maybe even too easy. There is an array of kid-friendly museums, shops, shows, trolleys and tours, centrally located and positioned so close that they require little transportation or street smarts. And you will get few dirty looks when someone spills something or throws a tantrum. Chicago is used to that.

title: Wheelies: The Electro-Wagen Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

title: Acrostic Answer
description: Acrostic answer for November 17, 2013

title: BY THE NUMBERS
description: The interior designer Timothy Corrigan has spent years overseeing the restoration of a 40,000-square-foot estate in the Loire Valley. Heres how he keeps tradition alive.

title: Your Tips for Tackling Chicago With Kids
description: In Part 3 of our continuing series on traveling in big cities with children, we took a jaunt to Chicago to explore the citys must-see attractions for little ones.

title: Backing Off  Wanting It All  From a Spouse
description: In last weeks Unhitched, Ed and Arlene Petty discussed some of the issues that led to their divorce after 28 years of marriage, including her feelings of discontent after their last child left for college (When Nest Emptied, Discontent Entered). As a follow-up, we asked a couples therapist about the role of expectations in a marriage. Did you face a similar issue in your divorce? Or were you faced with other challenges? If so, wed like to hear from you for this series.

title: The Great Writ, North and South
description: During the Civil War both the federal and Confederate governments had to deal with a pressing question far from the battlefield: how to balance the rights enshrined in their respective constitutions against effectively fighting the war.

title: For Filipino Workers Abroad, There Is Nothing Worse Than the Waiting
description: The first thing I read about the typhoon was actually on Facebook. Posted on one of my friends status updates was something about the wind getting stronger in our part of the Philippines. After that, all of my friends began to panic.

title: Speculation, Spoilers and Sequels: Making Inferences to Predict What Happens Next
description: Overview | How do great authors build suspense and keep us engaged? What skills do readers need to make predictions? In this lesson, students will discuss how they read their favorite television shows in order to make predictions about what will happen, then apply these skills to speculate about what happens to literary characters after their favorite novels or plays end. Finally, they will use the inferences they gain through close reading to create imagined futures for these characters in comic strips, next chapters, letters, journals or videos.

title: Today in Small Business: Corporate Welfare Queens
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Amazon Web Services Gets Personal and Pretty
description: LAS VEGAS  Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing part of Amazons sprawling online empire, is known for its globe-spanning system of millions of computer servers, data storage systems and complex software, estimated to be five times larger than 14 other cloud computing providers combined.

title: Acrostic
description: Acrostic puzzle for November 17, 2013

title: Poems Against Loss: Joan Naviyuk Kane Talks About Hyperboreal
description: The poems of Joan Naviyuk Kane are lyrical blasts from a far northern landscape of history and myth. From the first lines of her second book, Hyperboreal, just published by the University of Pittsburgh Press, Ms. Kane transports us: Arnica nods heavy-headed on the bruised slope./Peaks recede in all directions, in heat-haze,/Evening in my recollection. The poet Arthur Sze, who picked the book for the 2012 Donald Hall Prize in Poetry, calls her poems vivid, disturbing and mysterious. Ms. Kane, 36, is Inuit/Inupiaq and lives a few miles from where she grew up in Anchorage. Her family originally came from King Island and Marys Igloo, Alaska. Recruited by Harvard, she attended the university as an undergraduate, and then earned an M.F.A. from Columbia. Below are excerpts from an email interview.

title: In Yellen Hearing, Senators Push for Fed Changes
description: WASHINGTON  The questions that Janet L. Yellen faced on Thursday from senators considering her nomination to lead the Federal Reserve made two things fairly clear: The job is hers, and its not going to be easy.

title: Woman, Guilty of Stalking Alec Baldwin, Gets 6-Month Term
description: After a week of courtroom drama, featuring a star turn from Alec Baldwin and tearful histrionics from a woman accused of stalking him, it was a judge who had the last and defining word on Thursday: guilty on all charges.

title: They Call Me Dr. Kevorkian
description: The patient had a severe pneumonia of advanced AIDS. Hed been lying in our intensive care unit for three weeks, a breathing tube thrust into his raw airway, his face a mixture of pain and resignation. His weakened lung tissue had popped in several areas, requiring chest tubes to drain the pockets of pressurized air. He looked like a sea creature with multiple tentacles.

title: Yellens Opening Remarks
description: Janet L. Yellen, at her confirmation hearing before Congress to become the Federal Reserves first chairwoman, defended the Feds steps to spur economic growth.

title: Skal
description: Inside the Nordic restaurant where the cooking tilts toward Noma.

title: Following Nordic Tracks
description: At Skal, three little smelt lie in a chipped bowl, crispy tails flipped upward. You expect crunch and maybe a whiff of the sea, nothing more. But what you get is subtler and stranger: a texture like sopped bread and a burst of brine, both from within (the smelt are stuffed with capers) and without (a splash of apple cider vinegar after the smelt are dusted with rye flour and fried).

title: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Running a Fabulous French Chateau
description: Timothy Corrigan works hard when hes home in Los Angeles, but no less so when hes on vacation at his chateau in Frances Loire Valley. For the past four years, the interior designer has overseen a meticulous restoration of the 40,000-square-foot country house he purchased there in 2004 for an undisclosed amount, driven by his passion for what the French call lart de vivre. Most people who could live this way today opt for convenience instead. But recently, Downton Abbey has ignited a fascination with how estates like this one, which was built between 1760 and 1764 and has hosted everyone from Voltaire to Lee Radziwill, operate in the modern world. (Its the subject of Corrigans new book, An Invitation to Chateau du Grand-Luc: Decorating a Great French Country House, $65.) Heres a look at how Corrigan keeps tradition alive, and at what cost.

title: In Iraq, a Day of Religious Observance, and of Blood
description: BAGHDAD  A wave of attacks against Shiite Muslims in Iraq killed at least 47 people and wounded dozens on Thursday, security officials said, as they were marking the holy day of Ashura, which commemorates the killing of Imam Hussein, a grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, 1,300 years ago.

title: Wolf to Dog: Scientists Agree on How, but Not Where
description: Where did dogs come from? That simple question is the subject of a scientific debate right now. In May, a team of scientists published a study pointing to East Asia as the place where dogs evolved from wolves. Now, another group of researchers has announced that dogs evolved several thousand miles to the west, in Europe.

title: New Interactive Tool Helps Track Earths Forests
description: As carbon emissions build and environmentalists grow more certain of the consequences, scientists have been searching for more precise ways to track the state of Earths vast expanses of forest.

title: Google Employees Speak Out About Government Spying
description: Googles canned responses to reports of government spying have ranged from concerned to outraged. But some of its employees have been more outspoken.

title: A Touch of the Toxic, for Good or Ill
description: Vampire bat saliva and a zebra longwing butterfly, devils gardens and fossilized fish teeth, golden-frog secretions and the sap of a manchineel tree: Pity the poor witches of Shakespeares Macbeth who had to settle for tooth of wolf and tongue of dog. Their boiling caldron makes an appearance in an exhibition opening Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History  The Power of Poison  and so do they, black robed and stirring the pot as green smoke rises. But they dont possess even a fraction of the esoteric ingredients the museum has assembled for this elaborate show, nor do they have the museums powers to brew something so alluring out of such potentially grim material.

title: Hotels, a Place to Lay Your Head, or Bury It in a Book
description: Traditional brick-and-mortar bookstores have proved vulnerable to e-books and the web, but many new hotels aim to distinguish themselves with old-fashioned pages that guests can actually turn, housing libraries that range from historic collections to trendy ones.

title: Dylan Joins Frances Legion of Honor
description: Bob Dylan added a new ribbon and pendant to his bucket of medals on Wednesday, when he was awarded the Legion of Honor, Frances highest prize, in a ceremony in Paris. The award was presented by the French minister of culture, Aurlie Filippetti, who praised him as an inspiration for young listeners who crave justice and independence, the BBC reported.

title: Fairy Tale Ending in the Horror Realm
description: In the 1980s, when the home-video revolution turned backyard directors into VHS auteurs, Chester Novell Turner lived his childhood dream of making horror movies. He bought a video camera, borrowed money from his mother and enlisted the help of buddies, a girlfriend and a preacher to make two ultra-low-budget movies that looked as if they were shot in a basement, because, in some cases, they were. Black Devil Doll From Hell was about a kindly woman who is raped by a ventriloquists dummy; Tales From the Quadead Zone was a trilogy of shorts that featured a killer clown and the ghost of a dead child. As word slowly spread about Mr. Turners gritty movies with African-American casts  a rarity in the very white horror world  bootleg copies of his films spread like crazy along the VHS underground.

title: Obama Calls for Patience in Iran Talks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama made a vigorous appeal to Congress on Thursday to give breathing space to his efforts to forge a nuclear deal with Iran, and the prospects for an interim agreement may have improved with the release of a report by international inspectors who said that for the first time in years, they saw evidence that the Iranians have put the brakes on their nuclear expansion.

title: A Traumatized City Begins to Bury Its Dead
description: A group of firefighters lowered unidentified bodies into a mass grave outside Tacloban on Thursday, six days after the city was heavily damaged by Typhoon Haiyan.

title: Jeter Prepares to Turn a Page and Publish Many Others
description: Derek Jeter, nearing the final act of a storied athletic career, is ready to talk about his life after baseball. He wants to be a book publisher.

title: A Feast for the Senses at the R Lounge in Times Square
description: IT was hard to decide just which was the most memorable sight to be seen from the R Lounge, the second-level bar at the Renaissance Hotel that provides a wow of a panorama of Times Square.

title: The Gun Report: November 14, 2013
description: There is no official set of criteria or definition for a mass shooting, but the F.B.I. considers mass murder to be a spasm of violence perpetrated by one person that takes at least four lives in the same location. By that metric, weve already had several just this month. And if the wounded are counted, the tally grows even higher.

title: Obamas Health Care Promise
description: There are important questions about whether the fix President Obama offered today for Americans whose insurance policies were cancelled will help them, whether it will hinder the broad goals of the health insurance reform law, and whether it will satisfy the opponents of reform. We will start to address them later on the editorial page.

title: Getting Up to Speed With an Apple TV, and Ditching Android Widgets
description: Q. How fast does my Internet connection have to be to stream movies on an Apple TV?

title: Outsourcing Chores: The Economic Impact
description: My Its the Economy column last Sunday explained how you too can live like an economist: by outsourcing lower-value services in order to give yourself more time to work, do rewarding things with your children or otherwise play. Outsourcing household production usually smacks of something only a hedge-fund billionaire or perhaps the Monopoly Man would do, but it is probably a good investment for plenty of middle-class people, too, since doing so can improve their future expected earnings.

title: Selections From Obama on Health Care
description: President Obama announced a fix to his signature health care law that will allow existing customers to keep their insurance plans.

title: The Console as Concierge
description: THE video game console is dead, and the body has been cold for a long time. Sure, Sony and Microsoft are releasing what everyone describes as new game consoles, but the term is a misnomer. The Sony PlayStation 4, released on Friday, and Microsofts Xbox One, due next Friday, are game consoles in the same way that the iPhone is a telephone.

title: From Roman Gladiators to Marauding Goblins
description: Here are quick looks at a few games available on the new video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft.

title: T WINTER TRAVEL
description: As an homage to Charlotte Perriands creative force, Louis Vuitton is building, for the first time, one of the legendary Modernists never-realized designs.

title: Train in India Hits Elephants Crossing Track
description: NEW DELHI  A passenger train speeding through northeast India barreled into a herd of elephants as they crossed a set of tracks late Wednesday, killing five. Their bodies were scattered in pieces, so the authorities were at first unable to count them and reported that seven had died.

title: Young African Writers Hold Forth in Brooklyn
description: The Miser has always felt that New Yorks public libraries constitute the kind of cultural and civic asset thats so obviously valuable yet often taken for granted. In a city of world-class art institutions, museums, performance halls, film festivals and athletic stadiums, some of the most vital programming unfolds among the stacks, as it were, in branches across the five boroughs, and is typically free and open to the public.

title: Speculation Looms Over Sale of Cohens Artworks at Auction
description: It was a question whispered throughout this weeks contemporary art auctions at Sothebys and Christies: Hows Steves stuff selling?

title: Things Didnt Go as Planned
description: Alan Greenspan is one of the most famous living economists. But he is not what you would call an economists economist.

title: Kljestan Seeks to Impress U.S. With His Play, Not His Mustache
description: GLASGOW  Furry facial hair seems to be a perpetual topic in American sports these days, but it also has its moments in the spotlight abroad. During a recent Champions League game between Paris St.-Germain and Anderlecht, United States midfielder Sacha Kljestan, who is a mainstay for the Belgian team, found himself chirping back and forth with the P.S.G. star Zlatan Ibrahimovic.

title: 50 Years Later, CBS and Grammys to Commemorate Beatles Appearance on Ed Sullivan
description: The 50th anniversary of the Beatles first visit to the United States is shaping up to be nearly as noisy as the original event, but without crowds of screaming fans congregating at Kennedy Airport and the Plaza Hotel and, of course, without the Beatles themselves. CBS announced on Thursday that it would show a two-hour special, The Night That Changed America: A Grammy Salute to the Beatles, on Feb. 9 at 8 p.m.  the same date and time slot (and on the same network) as The Ed Sullivan Show, on which the Beatles made their live American television debut. The show will include covers of Beatles songs by current stars (none of which have been announced) in performances to be taped Jan. 27.

title: Heroes and Crusaders
description: If you find the grubby spectacle of todays Washington cause for shame and despair  and, really, how could you not?  then I suggest you turn off the TV and board Doris Kearns Goodwins latest time machine. Let her transport you back to the turn of the 20th century, to a time when this country had politicians of stature and conscience, when the public believed that government could right great wrongs, when, before truncated attention spans, a 50,000-word expos of corruption could sell out magazines and galvanize a reluctant Congress. The villains seemed bigger, too, or at least more brazen  industrial barons and political bosses who monopolized entire industries, strangled entire cities. And change was not just a slogan. There are but a handful of times in the history of our country, Goodwin writes in her introduction, when there occurs a transformation so remarkable that a molt seems to take place, and an altered country begins to emerge. The years covered in this book are such a time. It makes a pretty grand story.

title: At Memorial for Lou Reed, Just Music
description: Lou Reed lived what was often a loud rock n roll life filled with loud rock n roll songs. So it was only fitting that an outdoor memorial service held in Manhattan on Thursday began with an unannounced burst of guitar feedback, startling pigeons and passers-by alike, before it coalesced into the opening chords of his song The Blue Mask, on which Mr. Reed defiantly sang, I loathe and despise repentance.

title: Attack Ravages Power Grid. (Just a Test.)
description: WASHINGTON  In windowless rooms from here to California, nearly 10,000 electrical engineers, cybersecurity specialists, utility executives and F.B.I. agents furiously grappled over 48 hours with an unseen enemy who tried to turn out the lights across America. The enemy injected computer viruses into grid control systems, bombed transformers and substations and knocked out power lines by the dozen.

title: In Bordeaux, Art, Music  and Dance Parties
description: Bordeaux may largely be known for its wine and history, but under the citys classical facade, a vibrant contemporary art and performance community, fleeing the high cost of living in Paris, has established itself.

title: Danny Bowiens Thanksgiving Pastrami
description: Hanukkah and Thanksgiving coincide this year, so the chef Danny Bowien of Mission Chinese Food and Mark Bittman demonstrate how to make holiday pastrami, no smoker necessary.

title: Philippine Official Fired for Estimate of 10,000 Dead From Typhoon
description: As the desperate search for survivors continued in the Philippines on Thursday, a senior police commander was fired for telling reporters last weekend that the death toll from the typhoon that devastated the nation could exceed 10,000, according to a government news agency.

title: He Wrote Himself a Ticket to New York
description: John Pollono said he was knee deep writing a play about 19th-century Boston, the art of dueling and the myriad rules that govern such gunplay, when it suddenly occurred to him to lighten up.

title: Harmony Hammond
description: Alexander Gray Associates

title: Songs of Experience, the Two-Hearted Kind
description: Hey, all you hard-core Stephen Sondheim devotees, bet you cant place this immortal lyric from the musical theaters master of the mot juste: Skeedoobeeeewahoowapawayskeebopooeee.

title: Eileen Quinlan: Curtains
description: Miguel Abreu Gallery

title: Cyprien Gaillard: Today Diggers, Tomorrow Dickens
description: Gladstone Gallery

title: Brad Kahlhamer: A Fist Full of Feathers
description: Jack Shainman Gallery

title: Malerie Marder: Anatomy
description: Leslie Tonkonow

title: Alison Elizabeth Taylor: Surface Tension
description: James Cohan Gallery

title: A Haitian Boys Needless Death From Diabetes
description: JEAN-PAUL was 12 when he died. A diabetic, he might well have lived if not for a tragically simple problem, common in rural Haiti: the glucose test strips available did not match the only glucometer we had access to in our rudimentary district hospital.

title: A Spectators View of J.F.K.s Funeral Procession
description: With the 50th anniversary of President Kennedys assassination approaching, Donald Hughes, a retired builder in North Carolina, thought someone might be interested in a roll of film he took back when he was a high-school senior. He got in touch with a photographer friend of his in New York, Chris Verene, who in turn reached out to us. We were indeed interested.

title: How the Russians Discovered America
description: Since 1981, Russian theatergoers have thrilled to the throbbing romance and power chords that have put the rock opera Juno and Avos on course to overtake The Fantasticks in a decade or so as the worlds longest-running musical. A cross between Eugene Onegin and Madama Butterfly, it tells the story of Nikolai Rezanov, a courtier and adventurer in the Napoleonic era, and his doomed love for the fetching Conchita Arguello, finest flower of the Spanish mission in San Francisco. The album of the shows songs, on its release, sold 10 million copies.

title: Police Shoot Man Fleeing With Gun in Wisconsin Childrens Hospital
description: Police in a Milwaukee suburb shot and wounded a man brandishing a handgun inside a childrens hospital on Thursday after officers had tried to arrest him on a warrant inside the hospitals neonatal care unit, the authorities said. No one else was injured during the shooting.

title: Rap Genius Says It Will Seek Licenses for Lyrics
description: Rap Genius, a website that was accused by music publishers on Monday of reprinting thousands of song lyrics without permission, revealed that it had a major licensing deal all along  and also indicated that the site was likely to pursue more such deals in the future rather than fight with publishers over copyright.

title: Rogers Reflects on Season in the Spotlight as a Gay Athlete
description: Robbie Rogers generally prefers to avoid reminiscing. Even this week, as he considered all that had happened over the past 12 months  his decision to announce his sexual orientation, his brief retirement and his return to soccer as the first openly gay male athlete in a prominent North American professional league  he interspersed his memories with sizable dollops of excitement about what lies ahead.

title: Record Label Owner Playing Along With Tech
description: When Alan Chan, the chief executive of Bre.ad, a link-shortening service, gave himself a 30th-birthday party in October, the event took place on a Sunday night  hangovers be damned  in a stylish loft in SoHo. Mr. Chan, who had just sold Bre.ad to Yahoo, had arranged, in the extravagant manner of the New York City tech world, for the Sugarhill Gang, an 80s-era hip-hop group, to perform. Equally in keeping with local start-up fashion, he had also arranged for his gathering to be managed musically by the D.J. and independent-record-label owner Sean Glass.

title: Kimberly-Clark to Spin Off Health Care Unit
description: Kimberly-Clark said on Thursday that it would pursue a potential spinoff its health care business, becoming the latest company to slim down its operations to help bolster its stock price.

title: Health Law Rollouts Stumbles Draw Parallels to Bushs Hurricane Response
description: WASHINGTON  Barack Obama won the presidency by exploiting a political environment that devoured George W. Bush in a second term plagued by sinking credibility, failed legislative battles, fractured world relations and revolts inside his own party.

title: John Oliver to Leave The Daily Show to Host Weekly Show on HBO
description: John Oliver has turned his widely praised stint this summer filling in for Jon Stewart on The Daily Show into a regular program of his own on HBO.

title: Full Transcript of Obamas News Conference on Health Care
description: The following is the complete transcript of President Obamas press conference on Thursday in Washington. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service.)

title: Northern Illinois Says It Belongs With the Best
description: DeKALB, Ill.  Three weeks ago, Northern Illinois opened the Chessick Practice Center, a $9.5 million building with a full-size indoor turf field that will help its football team cope with Midwestern winters and perhaps further its rise from an anonymous team on the prairie to a national powerhouse.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: the female orgasm, knee ligaments and birthing babies. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Virtual Money Draws Notice of Regulators
description: Updated, 8:15 p.m. | New Yorks top financial regulator is looking at issuing a BitLicense for businesses that conduct transactions in virtual currencies like bitcoin.

title: Chicago Said to Weigh Suit Over Marketing of Painkillers
description: Lawyers for the city of Chicago are investigating marketing claims by producers of narcotic painkillers as a prelude to a possible lawsuit against them, according to interviews and a court filing.

title: Information on Art Trove to Start Going Online
description: German authorities, trying to speed the identification of some of 1,400 works apparently lost during the Nazi era, said that they would soon begin posting information on 590 of those with questionable provenances on the website lostart.de, a database of art looted or missing since World War II. Publication will start next week, according to a statement issued by the Culture Ministry that quoted Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, who spent decades in government service helping to run cultural institutions in Germany and who was appointed to lead a group of art experts tasked with researching the history of the works. So far 25 works have been posted. Possible rightful claimants can now more quickly identify missing art works and in relevant cases make their claims heard, the statement said. Such news is welcome to claimants like David Toren, an 88-year-old New Yorker who recognized one of the works, a painting by Max Liebermann, as having once hung in the home of a great-uncle. State prosecutors took possession of the art in February from the apartment of Cornelius Gurlitt as part of a tax case.

title: Modern Love | Broken Heart Doctor
description: After Thomas Hooven graduated from medical school, his girlfriend of 12 years ended their relationship. It was only three weeks before they planned to marry.

title: Wines for Thanksgiving: Mixing Without Trying to Match
description: When I first came to The New York Times nearly 30 years ago (good God!), I worked with an editor who kept a file labeled How We Did It Last Time. Inside were detailed instructions for covering events that occurred regularly but infrequently, like elections. Rather than trying to reconstruct his procedures every time, he simply kept careful track of best practices and pulled out the file when necessary.

title: Hyperbole and a Book
description: Allie Brosh, whose blog Hyperbole and a Half attracts as many as five million readers a month, has published her first book.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Court Orders German Firm to Pay Victims of Defective Breast Implants
description: PARIS  A French court on Thursday ordered a German quality-control company to compensate 1,600 victims of defective breast implants made by a French company about $4,000 each, according to news reports.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, Iran, Gaza and Turkey.

title: Nursing a Wound in an Appropriate Setting
description: I started my pediatrics residency on the cardiology unit, which was appropriate: my heart had a giant hole in it. Just after I graduated from medical school, as I was moving into my fiances New York apartment, she ended our relationship. We went out to dinner that night, and after we came home, she told me we were through.
