His was the first pro-sports team to co-opt an American Indian identity with such fervor: The Redskins halftime band marched in tribal regalia; the coach wore feathers on the sideline; and Marshall had an Indian-head logo printed across the center of their uniforms.

title: Today in Small Business: Health Care Fixes
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: A Road Trip in Western China
description: From Kashgar to Tashkurgan in the southern crescent of Xinjiang.

title: Let Go of the College Essay, and Let Your Teenager Speak for Herself
description: Recently I told the story in the Wall Street Journal of a father who offered me, an independent college applications counselor, a $10,000 check to write his sons college essays. Never mind that his son was standing right there. I didnt take the check. Instead I took the boy: We fled his fathers Midtown Manhattan office and went for a walk, along sidewalks crowded with people who had gone to Ivy League colleges, non-Ivy League colleges and no colleges at all, to the park, where we could really talk.

title: In Our Pages: November 16
description: 1888 Chamberlains Wedding

title: A Few Tips on Trident Management
description: Before it was announced who would play the muscly, green-eyed, trident-wieldingFinnick Odair in The Hunger Games: Catching Fire, the second installment of the film adaptation of Suzanne Collinss post-apocalyptic trilogy, fans made it clear that picking the right actor was serious business. (One Does Not Joke About Finnicks Casting was the title of one of many obsessed Tumblr pages.) Sam Claflin, 27, won the part, which still seems to be sinking in for this classically trained British actor. Pre-Finnick, his biggest credits were minor roles in Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides and Snow White and the Huntsman. Now he has a more central role in a thriving power franchise. When hes done promoting Catching Fire, hell begin shooting Mockingjay, the final chapter of the Hunger Games series, which is being split into two parts.

title: Taking the High Road
description: For a few disconcerting moments, the gridlock that ensnared our minivan on the highway linking China to Pakistan sent my mind reeling to the countless hours Id wasted on Beijings perpetually congested, smog-choked ring roads.

title: Conductors Prize Goes to Jeffrey Milarsky
description: The Ditson Conductors Award, a prize for distinguished contributions to American music, given annually by Columbia University, will be presented to the conductor and percussionist Jeffrey Milarsky at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night, during a concert by the Juilliard Orchestra that Mr. Milarsky is conducting. The $5,000 award, which was established in 1945, will be presented by the pianist Gilbert Kalish, the head of the Ditson advisory committee.

title: High Schoolers Against the Redskin Name
description: Such mainline media as Slate and Mother Jones have stopped using the name of Washingtons professional football team, finding Redskins a racist slur for all its rah-rah fondness among hometown fans at kick-off time. No less offended, the editorial board of the student newspaper at Neshaminy High School in Bucks County, Penn., has voted to banish the word from their pages, arguing that its time for their own Neshaminy Redskins (10-and-1 and a state powerhouses) to be called something less insensitive toward genocidal history. The word Redskin is racist and very much so, the board explained in its decision to drop the name from editions of The Playwickian. It is not a term of honor, but a term of hate.

title: Submit Your Real Estate Questions
description: Got an upstairs neighbor who thinks theres nothing wrong with coming home at 3 a.m. and hurling her three-inch heels across the uncarpeted hardwood floor? Or maybe youre wondering if your co-op can really just decide to ban pets and tell you to find a new home for your 55-pound bulldog. Or you want to know what to do about the next-door neighbor who installed an eight-foot fence that youre certain has veered into your backyard.

title: Vivien Leigh, Before Tara Called
description: David O. Selznicks much-publicized search for the star of Gone With the Wind culminated in early 1939 when he presented to the world one Vivien Leigh.

title: N.Y. State Comptroller Invests in Lerer-Backed Tech Company
description: The New York State comptrollers office said on Friday that it had invested in a website backed by Kenneth Lerer, the veteran venture capitalist, as it continues to support homegrown technology companies.

title: Out of Economic Chaos, an Indie Spirit Is Forged
description: Konstantinos Kontovrakis was a programmer for the Thessaloniki Film Festival until 2009, when he quit to become a film producer. Unfortunately, that was the year the whole mess started, as Mr. Kontovrakis put it. He meant the Greek economic crisis that continues to send shivers through the global economy. Since then, I havent made a lot of money.

title: Murder Charge in a Shooting on Doorstep
description: DETROIT  After a two-week investigation, the prosecutor here charged a white suburban homeowner on Friday with second-degree murder in the killing of an unarmed young black woman. The prosecutor rejected the mans assertion that he had been acting in self-defense when he opened his front door and fired a shotgun at the woman through a locked screen door, striking her in the face.

title: A Daring Film, Silenced No More
description: LOS ANGELES  The dark tale begins with a concert violinist infatuated with a young student and ends with blackmail and suicide. In between there are visits to bars and brothels, brawls in swanky digs, creepy shakedowns and a cameo by Oscar Wilde. It sounds like a slightly experimental indie project. In reality, the movie, Different From the Others, opened in the summer of 1919 to sold-out houses across Germany.

title: 36 Hours in Chianti, Italy
description: Theres made-to-measure fashion, new standout architecture and contemporary art worth a detour.

title: Volkswagen Announces Global Recall of 2.6 Million Vehicles
description: Volkswagen will recall about 62,000 Tiguan sport utility vehicles from the 2009-11 model years because they can lose exterior lighting, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The action is part of a worldwide 2.6 million vehicle recall for lighting and transmission problems, Volkswagen announced Thursday morning in Germany.

title: Coachs Career: Heights to Depths, and Everything in Between
description: ATLANTA  The zigzag of a chart tracking the career of a typical football coaching lifer tends to mirror the charts that record the long-term performance of the stock market. For the coach, the lines overall ascent is periodically interrupted by a flat line or a downturn, reflecting the inevitable firing or nonrenewal of a contract.

title: Sizing Up the Better Business Bureau, and Its Rivals on the Internet
description: OVER the years, when writing about subjects as varied as driving schools and air duct cleaners, Ive given the seemingly benign advice to check out companies with the Better Business Bureau.

title: Footage of Death Plays On in Memory
description: Before Nov. 22, 1963, Abraham Zapruder was an ordinary citizen of Dallas: a 58-year-old prosperous manufacturer of womens clothing who had arrived in the city from Russia by way of Brooklyn. If that day had unfolded differently, that is most likely what he would have remained. But like a small but growing number of Americans at the time, he was also a home-movie hobbyist. With his receptionist, Marilyn Sitzman, as location scout and technical support, Zapruder took his 414PD Director Series Bell and Howell 8-millimeter camera to a spot on Elm Street, not far from his office, hoping to film the presidential motorcade as it drove past.

title: 36 Hours in Chianti, Italy
description: Stretching between Florence and Siena in the heart of Tuscany, the Chianti wine region is the romanticized Italy of daydreams: terra-cotta-roofed towns, wine-soaked dinners and vineyards stitching sun-dappled hillsides. But hidden amid Chiantis winding roads and rolling hills are some surprisingly modern attractions. Theres made-to-measure fashion, new standout architecture, and contemporary art worth a detour. Certainly, there are copious amounts of red wine waiting to be drunk, but dont expect kitschy straw-wrapped bottles or pizza-parlor reds. Today Chianti vintners are producing excellent, nuanced wines that are worthy of these scenic surroundings.

title: Streaming and Cable Deal for The Simpsons
description: In one of televisions biggest syndication deals, The Simpsons, the longest-running scripted show in TV history, will finally be moving to cable television  and, not too surprisingly, it is staying in the family.

title: Movie Review: 'Nebraska'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Nebraska."

title: Jury Finds Pipe Maker Defrauded Governments
description: A federal jury in California found on Thursday that the nations largest maker of plastic pipe defrauded states and municipalities over a decade by knowingly selling them defective pipe for use in their drinking water, firefighting, irrigation and other essential public systems.

title: Movie Review: 'Faust'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Faust."

title: Movie Review: 'The Great Beauty'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews the movie "The Great Beauty."

title: Kelly Attacks Mayoral Candidates for Criticizing Police Dept.
description: New York Citys police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said he resented the way the Democratic candidates for mayor criticized him and the Police Department while they were campaigning, according to an interview in Playboy magazine that was released this week.

title: How Do You Teach Kids to Eat Well When Youre Not With Them?
description: You are what you eat, from your head down to your feet! Growing up in the 1970s, I had the benefit of having Time for Timers advice on healthy eating drummed into me weekly during Saturday morning cartoon binges. I may endlessly hanker for a hunka, a slab, a slice, a chunka cheese, but I also knew that no kid could survive on sugar alone, because all those motors in your body need a lot of fuel to go on, like a healthy breakfast and a balanced snack.

title: Photography Fair Arrives in Paris
description: PARIS  If light is the key ingredient of photography, there was no lack of it at the Paris Photo preview earlier this week. The 17th edition of the annual photography fair, which runs through Sunday under the dome of the Grand Palais, includes 136 international galleries from 24 countries.

title: ValueVision Rejects Demands From Activist Investor
description: ValueVision, the Internet and television shopping network, has rebuffed demands from the activist investor Clinton Group to overhaul its board, saying that the investor has no legal basis to make those demands.

title: Traveling to Find Your Roots
description: It was lunchtime at the Outlaws Shack in Poiana Brasov, a mountain resort in Transylvania, and we were washing down chunks of kashkaval cheese and peasant bread with sips of tsuica, a Romanian plum brandy. At a neighboring table, a man picked up a red onion and bit into it as if it were an apple  something I had seen only my father do.

title: Image of the Day: November 15
And the Crowd Goes ... Well, You Know
description: Lady Gagas strategy at the new H&M Times Square store: to inject her wayward artistry into a staunchly corporate setting.

title: Lady Gaga Drops In at H&M and the Crowd Goes ... Well, You Know
description: LADY GAGAS ARRIVAL on Wednesday night atop a pink Skyline sightseeing bus was cheeky, all right. Fanning out her waist-length hair and wearing a paint-streaked H&M cat suit, she worked the public like a flaxen Cleopatra waving from her barge.

title: The Gun Report: November 15, 2013
description: * The first 3D-printed gun, the Liberator .380, the design of which is widely available online, could emerge as a national security threat when a law banning undetectable firearms expires next month. The Undetectable Firearms Act, first passed in 1988, requires guns to have enough steel to set off a metal detector, but the Liberator uses only the smallest bits of metal for ammunition and a firing pin the size of a roofing nail. Some senators have proposed an updated version of the bill that would ban the design, manufacture, sale, import, export and possession of the plastic guns. The blueprint for the Liberator .380 has been downloaded 100,000 times since it was designed last year. The fact that anyone with the right equipment can make a fully-functioning weapon from their own home with the click of a mouse is a truly frightening concept, Sen. Bill Nelson said in a statement.

title: Restaurant Report: State-Run Food Shop No. 37 in Hanoi
description: The dining scene in Hanoi has flourished in recent years. Travelers can feast on international fare like sushi and tapas, as well as on innovative takes on Vietnamese cuisine. But this tiny restaurant, which opened in the fall of 2012, evokes a simpler time: the decade starting in 1976, when the state controlled the economy so tightly that restaurants were barred from having names, and privately owned businesses were illegal.

title: Love in the Time Before the Internet
description: Its been noted that in the age of cellphones, the romance between Romeo and Juliet would not end in tragedy. But add the Internet to the plot of The Most Happy Fella, and the romance never happens. An immigrant farmer might still be captivated by a young, pretty hash-house waitress on his visit to San Francisco. He might still leave a piece of jewelry  although it wouldnt be a tie pin  as a tip, along with a charmingly effusive love note.

title: A Road Trip Through Alexander Paynes Nebraska
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Air Pollution as a Heart Threat
description: Bit by bit over the past few decades, scientists have been building a new understanding of the ways that air pollution threatens human health. Much of their attention has been focused on lung diseases, including cancers. With good reason, it turns out: just last month, the World Health Organization declared air pollution to be one of the planets most dangerous environmental carcinogens.

title: Book Review Podcast: Doris Kearns Goodwins Bully Pulpit
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Bill Keller reviews Doris Kearns Goodwins Bully Pulpit: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism. Mr. Keller writes:

title: The Impossible Refugee Boat Lift to Christmas Island
description: By LUKE MOGELSONMore than a thousand refugees have died trying to reach Christmas Island. But faced with unbearable conditions at home, they keep coming.Photographs by JOEL VAN HOUDT

title: Exclusive | 18 East 74th Street
description: An opulent seven-story Neo-Renaissance-style mansion built in 1871 is about to enter the market at $34 million.

title: Upper East Side Mansion, Ornate, Yet Cozy
description: An extravagantly appointed Upper East Side mansion that recalls the gravitas and gilding  if not quite the square footage  of Highclere Castle, which became a character in its own right on the PBS series Downton Abbey, is poised to enter the market at $34 million.

title: Deflating Tescos Blow-Up Friend
description: A-Rod reality TV; rejected baby names; Bellamy Youngs leonine streak.

title: Window Displays of Affection
description: Over the three days that followed the assassination of John F. Kennedy 50 years ago, 250,000 people viewed his flag-draped coffin in the Capitol Rotunda; dignitaries from more than 100 countries visited Washington to attend the funeral, procession and burial service at Arlington National Cemetery. On the eve of Kennedys burial, Dan Budnik, a photographer for Magnum at the time, was walking around downtown Washington and taking note of the framed portraits of the president that had been placed in store windows, often incongruously among office furniture or mannequins. People were trying to figure out how to honor the fallen president, says Budnik, who is now 80. They incorporated the tragedy. I was just taken by the aspect of turning commercial into memorial. I was very moved by the individual gestures. Julie Bosman

title: Window Displays of Affection
description: Impromptu memorials to J.F.K.

title: The 11.3.13 Issue
description: BROCCOLIS EXTREME MAKEOVER

title: What Cynthia Ozick Taught Me About My Grandfather
description: Cynthia Ozick and I have long differed on the name of my grandfather. Every decade or so, we run into each other at some New York gathering, and after exchanging pleasantries, I say, again, that the first name of my paternal grandfather, an immigrant from Ukraine, was Kusel (pronounced kSEEL.) She informs me, once more, that it was Yekutiel, a name Id never heard before I met her. Our discussions have always been cordial. Considering the fact that she is someone who is celebrated for her erudite essays as well as for her novels, she has been admirably free of condescension. I would compare the tone of our disagreement to a respectful difference in interpretation by two scholars  or maybe between one scholar and another person.

title: Put Me in, Coach  Im Ready to Pay
description: My granddaughter is being asked to pay more than $2,000 to be on a traveling sports team. The coach of her high-school team, who also coaches the unaffiliated traveling team, is asking for the payment as a condition of my granddaughters participation on the regular high-school squad. Is this unethical behavior by the coach? Is it proper for the person paying the fee (me) to bring this issue to the attention of the school system? How do I avoid retribution by the coach against my granddaughter?CHET M., ORINDA, CALIF.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Milwaukee; Jasper, Alberta; California
description: Exposed! Harley-DavidsonsLost Photographs, 1915-1916,MilwaukeeMore than 50 black-and-white photographs documenting the early years of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company are on displaythrough Jan. 1, in Milwaukee at theHarley-Davidson Museum. The photos, printed from a collection of more than 400 fragile glass-plate negatives, provide a glimpse back nearly 100 years ago and include employee portraits, depictions of the companys 1916 racing team and images used for marketing.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Reports Increased Traffic Deaths
description: More people died on United States roads in 2012 than in 2011, according to a report from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Motorcyclist and pedestrian deaths each increased for the third year in a row, and deaths of bicyclists reached the highest level in six years. Over all, however, traffic deaths continue to be at historic lows.

title: Gut-Wrenching
description: A woman suffers bouts of extreme abdominal pain that come and go and come again.

title: Analyzing Obama on Health Care in The Times
description: It didnt take long for Michael Shears news analysis on Fridays front page to cause what he termed an email and Twitter explosion for the White House correspondent.

title: Printed Books Are Alive and Sometimes Weird
description: The news about books today is often centered on the shift from print to digital, from paper to electronic devices. At the Islip Art Museum, entirely different kinds of transformations are on display, and none of them are electronic.

title: Above, Below and Around Paris, on Foot
description: We drew a deep breath before entering the tunnel. The garbage strewn around the entrance was about as inviting as the prospect of walking nearly a mile under one of Pariss most famous parks not knowing what, or whom, to expect. We were in the heart of the city, but completely removed from it.

title: Facebook Reasserts Posts Can Be Used to Advertise
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If you post something on Facebook, let there be no doubt that it can end up as an ad shown to your friends and acquaintances.

title: Seeing and Being Seen, Across Millenniums
description: Faces are everywhere at the Katonah Museum of Art. Some gaze boldly across the galleries, cheery, confrontational, sly; others turn aside, pensive and enigmatic. All hold stories of humanity, a gathering of characters, cultures and colors.

title: Video: Hyperbole, Comedy and Angst
description: Allie Broshs blog, Hyperbole and a Half, has a devoted following, attracting as many as five million readers a month. Her first post, in July 2009, had no pictures at all, but her drawings have become increasingly prominent. Although theyre somewhat crude, they reflect raw emotion and seamlessly blend comedy and pain. Ms. Brosh tells stories about her childhood, her life in Oregon with her husband and two dogs, and her struggles with depression, which caused a 19-month hiatus from her blog that ended in May.

title: Forbes Says It Is for Sale
description: Forbes Media, which publishes Forbes magazine and has been making an extensive push into digital media and native advertising, is up for sale, the company confirmed in an email to the staff Friday morning.

title: On the Path to Personalization: Part 1
description: This is the first in a series of posts exploring the underlying technology of our new recommendations engine. The second post is here.

title: More Cities Consider Using Eminent Domain to Halt Foreclosures
description: New cities are joining the effort to head off home foreclosures by using a twist on the power of eminent domain, despite threats of financial retaliation from Wall Street and Washington.

title: Glafkos Clerides, Greek Cypriot Leader Who Sought Unification, Is Dead at 94
description: Glafkos Clerides, the president of Cyprus from 1993 to 2003, who as leader of his nations Greek Cypriot majority was a frustrated peacemaker in futile talks with Turkish Cypriots to reunify their long-divided Mediterranean island, died on Friday in Nicosia, the capital. He was 94.

title: Antidoping Labs Flaws Put Olympics in a Bind
description: JOHANNESBURG  Less than three months before the opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics, the antidoping laboratory in Russia charged with conducting drug screenings at those Winter Games has been deemed unreliable and may lose its authority to test Olympic athletes.

title: Predicting a Falls Aftermath
description: For an elderly person, a bad fall can mark the difference between between walking and wheelchair, between living in ones own home and moving to a nursing home. It can be a life-changing event.

title: T WINTER TRAVEL
description: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

title: Baffling About-Face in American-US Airways Merger
description: Did the Justice Department cave?

title: New Grove Dictionary Broadens Scope on American Music
description: For classical music fans and scholars  and increasingly, for those devoted to other musical genres, including non-Western forms as well as jazz and popular music  the various editions of the Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians have been the principal resource for generations. Originally published in 1878 as a four-volume set, edited by Sir George Grove (but without his name in the title), the Grove took a huge leap with its sixth edition, which was so thoroughly revamped that when it appeared in 1980, New was added to the title. The current New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, published in 2001, fills 29 volumes.

title: Finding Strength in Humility
description: Humility doesnt get much respect in the corporate world. How often do you hear a leader say publicly, Im sorry, I got that wrong, or, I didnt do that very well, or even something as simple as, I dont know.

title: General Electric Finally Gets Past the Jack Welch Era
description: General Electric is finally putting the ghost of its former chief executive Jack Welch out to pasture. On Friday, the conglomerate said it intended to spin off its North America retail finance business. That will help return GE Capital to its roots of lending to midmarket companies and its parents industrial concerns.

title: Houseful of Handfuls
description: One Fifth Avenue, the 27-story Art Deco apartment tower built in the late 1920s at the corner of Eighth Street, has a reputation as a Hollywood building. The directors whove called it home include Brian De Palma, Paul Mazursky, Ira Sachs and Tim Burton. Its no wonder that Peter Newman, a film producer and a professor at New York University, and Antonia Dauphin, a casting agent who is about to direct her first feature, are so comfortable there.

title: In Brooklyn, Friday Night Rites
description: They moved to the beat of a drum in the backyard, flames jumping from a caldron set in a circle drawn in the dirt. One by one they placed pieces of paper into the fire  with words of a burden they wanted to shed  and watched sparks rise into the Brooklyn night sky.

title: Art Matters | From Matmos, a Musical Libretto Performed by Random Strangers
description: Theres something suspicious about the work we do, said Drew Daniel of the Baltimore experimental duo Matmos, because it has an eerie ability to seem alien. Daniel and Martin Schmidt, his partner in creativity and in life, are known for pulling sounds from unorthodox sources: squishing organs on operating tables, rats pattering across cages, rose petals being crushed. To create the sounds for their last album, The Marriage of True Minds, the duo conducted a Ganzfeld experiment  a parapsychological technique used to test for ESP  on subjects in Baltimore and Oxford, England. Participants were asked to lie on the floor, cover their eyes with Ping-Pong balls and listen to blasting white noise, then describe what they saw in their minds eye. Weve had some ideas that other people may object to or find a little odd, Daniel admitted.

title: Fewer Choices in the Air
description: The merger between American Airlines and US Airways comes after airlines have struggled for decades, cutting costs and slimming down service to turn around a trend of diminishing profits.

title: Programmers Find New Way to Navigate Health Plans
description: The stumbling rollout of the federally run online health exchange has frustrated tens of thousands of Americans and sent some looking for alternative sources of information on where they can buy health insurance, and what it will cost them, under the Affordable Care Act.

title: Abuse Accusations Overshadow Commonwealth Meeting in Sri Lanka
description: NEW DELHI  Sri Lankas president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, tried to pre-empt criticism of his governments human rights record on Friday as he welcomed leaders of Commonwealth countries to a summit  meeting in the Sri Lankan capital, Colombo, that was overshadowed by persistent allegations of state-sponsored abuse during a long civil war by the Sinhalese-dominated government against ethnic Tamils.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Nov. 15, 2013
description: Janet Yellen is poised to become the new head of the Federal Reserve. If she is confirmed by the Senate, she would arguably become the most powerful woman in the U.S. economy, with the power to keep interests rates low, prevent inflation and attack unemployment. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss Yellens confirmation hearing, as well as whats going on at the regional Federal Reserve banks.

title: Vocal Instructor Commands Enough Nonsense, Sing!
description: Maria Zhorella recently turned 98, and if only she would just slow down and give her vocal students a break.

title: Their Harmony Is Loud and Clear
description: Huai-Bin Mabel Ko is someone who revels in the chance to find beauty in places others would never think to look.

title: Zulily Surges in Market Debut
description: Updated, 4:15 p.m. | It may not be a globally popular social network or a highly regarded human resources software company. But Zulily is finding plenty of demand from investors all the same.

title: Bring On the Juggling Act
description: Even before they were married in 1999, Terry Williams and Patrick Cashin had an understanding about who would be their future childrens primary caretaker.

title: Bill Moyers Will Stay on TV
description: The fans of Bill Moyers spoke, and he listened. Mr. Moyers announced late last month that his public television show Moyers & Company would end with the Jan. 3, 2014, program. But on Friday, the programs executive producer, Judy Doctoroff, told a meeting of public television officials that the program would stay on the air after all, after receiving thousands of heartfelt and well-written messages saying dont go.  New funding was also lined up, she said.

title: The Story of Manhattans Rectangular Street Grid
description: Q. When did Manhattans rectangular street grid first begin appearing?

title: Isay Weinfeld Exhibition in TriBeCa
description: Isay Weinfeld, an architect, designer and filmmaker for 40 years, has built a following in his native Brazil. But now his reputation should ripple with the opening of the first show in the United States devoted to his multifaceted career. Called A to Z, the exhibition is on view through Dec. 1 at Espasso, a TriBeCa showroom of Brazilian design.

title: Amazon Bares Its Computers
description: LAS VEGAS  However big and ambitious you think Amazons plan to run the worlds computing may be, you should probably think bigger.

title: Reading, Walking and More Reading for Writer
description: If you are an attentive walker in New York City, any block might open up to you as a story: about the immigrants who once lived there, about the forces that moved them, about the direction of change and the people driving it. Pete Hamill, 78, the journalist and novelist, provided the language for many of those stories. So it is only fitting that for him, Sunday is a day of long walks, starting from the apartment in TriBeCa that he shares with his wife, Fukiko Aoki Hamill, 65, a writer. The paperback edition of his most recent book of short fiction, The Christmas Kid: And Other Brooklyn Stories, was published last month.

title: Hells Kitchen Real Estate: Hot
description: Not so long ago, Hells Kitchen drowsed in the shadow of nearby Midtown. But now residential projects popping up left and right.

title: Hells Kitchen: Sizzling
description: In the race to develop the West Side of Manhattan, Hells Kitchen can seem the tortoise to the Hudson Yards hare. Yet if Hudson Yards suddenly seems to be going up all at once, its neighbor to the north has been moving ahead in slow, deliberate steps, year after year.

title: U.S. Appears More Open to Finance Discussions in Trade Talks With Europe
description: LONDON  American negotiators appear to be softening their resolve to keep financial services out of trans-Atlantic trade talks with the European Union.

title: Big Ticket | A Limestone Swan for $26 Million
description: An ugly duckling townhouse that was the beneficiary of an ambitious $10 million neo-Roman makeover to restore its original 1879 panache with a striking facade of imported Italian limestone and a cornice that hides a rooftop soaking pool sold for $26 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The annual taxes on the 20-foot-wide property are $110,000.

title: Convoluted Language Makes Cooper Tire Deal Harder to Execute
description: Cooper Tire is facing more legal issues in its snarled deal with Apollo Tyres Ltd. of India.

title: Gluten-Free Pies for Thanksgiving
description: Im by no means a gluten-free girl, and not much of an expert when it comes to gluten-free cooking. But Thanksgiving is coming up and what is Thanksgiving without pie? Since many of you may be stuck when it comes to pies and gluten-free family members and guests, I decided to tackle a gluten-free pie crust this week.

title: For Some Aid Workers, Rescues Must Wait as Bodies Are Removed
description: Volunteers from the Philippine Red Cross searched for bodies in Tacloban as thousands of residents remain hungry and homeless.

title: General Motors Recalls 2013-14 Chevrolet Malibus Over Electrical Problems
description: General Motors will recall 14,909 Chevrolet Malibus from the 2013 model year in the United States equipped with the eight-way power front seat and passenger seat option. G.M. says that in certain vehicles, the wiring harness may wear against the frame. If this happens, the insulation of a circuit on the wiring harness may become worn through to the conductor and a short to the grounded seat frame may occur.

title: An Ice Rink Opens in Brooklyn
description: The ice skating rink at McCarren Park, north Brooklyns first and only outdoor skating rink, opened today. The rink is nestled atop the beach plaza at the center of the pool area. It will be open through January, from 11 a.m. to 10 p.m., seven days a week.

title: Raising Healthy Eaters, with SNAP or American Express
description: A study in contrasts:

title: Claudia Fleming's Apple Crumb Crostata
description: When Claudia Fleming was at Gramercy Tavern, she was known for her all-American desserts. Mark Bittman invited her to share her Thanksgiving specialty: apple crumb crostata with bacon toffee.

title: A Downton Weekend in Georgia
description: Sea Island resort in Georgia is celebrating the Jan. 5 debut of the fourth season of the British series Downton Abbey with a weekend inspired by the series and hosted by Allen Leech, who plays the character of Tom Branson, the outspoken former family chauffeur and widower of Lady Sybil.

title: Probe May Help Solve Riddle of Marss Missing Air
description: NASAs next mission to Mars aims to answer one question: What happened to the air that once made the surface habitable?

title: Cutting the Heart Out of Health Reform
description: Its easy to be mad at President Obama over health care reform  the broken website, the confusing choices, his false promise that everyone could keep their current plans.

title: A New Era for Progressives
description: On the corner of Canal and Varick Streets at the moment sits a 15,000-square-foot plastic tent, one that required a weeks worth of construction, the kind of edifice that typically at this time of year is given over to the sale of hand-knit scarves and tiny things made of wood. The purpose of this particular tent is outside the scope of holiday crafts: The project, called Talking Transition, was developed by a consortium of nonprofit groups, including the Revson Foundation, to allow New Yorkers to voice their opinions about what sort of direction the city should take in the aftermath of Bill de Blasios victory in the mayors race.

title: Review: 2014 Kia Sorento
description: A vehicle refresh normally means a new grille and taillights. Kia gives the 2014 Sorento an entirely different chassis structure, a new engine and an improved suspension. Who does that?

title: Seventh Heaven
description: The polished seventh-generation Corvette Stingray is a world-class sports car that, unlike its brutish, twitchy predecessor, requires no compromises.

title: Weekend Reading: JPMorgans Strategy in China
description: The daughter of Chinas former prime minister used the alias Lily Chang while working for JPMorgan Chase. In fairness, we should reveal that DealBook sometimes comments anonymously under the pseudonym of Bargain Literary Work.

title: Simon & Schuster & Jeter
description: At one point this past baseball season, Derek Jeter, out injured, revealed that he wasnt watching Yankees games regularly. He didnt have the Extra Innings package, he said, and the games were blacked out in Tampa. (Why the YES Network would say NO to Tampa like that, I have no idea.) Now we know what he might have been doing instead of watching TV  reading manuscripts!

title: 22-Year-Old Wins a Big Game in Chess Championship
description: Magnus Carlsen has already accomplished more in his brief career as a chess player than almost anyone in the games history.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, Nepal, Myanmar and India.

title: A Bird of Courage and Success
description: If Benjamin Franklin had gotten his way, a gold-plated turkey would have presided atop every flagpole where the American bald eagle now stands. Franklin considered the bald eagle a bird of bad moral character, while the turkey was a much more respectable bird, and though a little vain and silly, a Bird of Courage.

title: The Well-Concealed Newness of the Kia Sorento
description: In the hypercompetitive automotive industry, a car is often produced for four to six years, getting an update halfway through its life. Visually, this is the new grille and taillights phase. While full sheet metal overhauls are expensive, a new schnoz and back end can be done efficiently. These cosmetic revisions are a good way to ignite new sales.

title: Bated Breath, as a Baton Is Raised for a Specialty
description: When the San Francisco Symphony canceled an East Coast tour in March because of a players strike, one event that went by the board was a Carnegie Hall performance of Mahlers Ninth Symphony, to have been led by the ensembles music director, Michael Tilson Thomas. The loss disappointed many, since this combination of orchestra and conductor is typically potent in Mahler.

title: Modern Love Child of a Renaissance Spirit
description: My Days is the title of a program of mostly Renaissance works for voices and viols that was presented Tuesday at St. Thomas  by that churchs Choir of Men and Boys and the wonderful English viol consort Fretwork. Its also the title of an arresting new work by Nico Muhly, a touching declaration of fraternity with the great Elizabethan composers that had its United States premiere that evening.

title: In the Air | Lush Landscapes
description: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

title: Compromise May Be Near for Iran Nuclear Deal, U.S. Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Obama administration official said on Friday that a solution could be found for one of the major stumbling blocks to an agreement that would freeze Irans nuclear program, and that the accord might be achieved next week.

title: Blurring Beginnings and Endings and Politics
description: Hofesh Shechters Sun is cheeky. First the voice of the Israeli-born choreographer, a popular success in Britain, announces that before starting, his company will show a bit of the ending, so that you know everything is going to be just fine.

title: In the Air | Strange Paradise
description: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

title: One-Track Mind
description: Unlike the latest Corvette, the 2013 SRT Viper has no need for refinements like an automatic transmission or decent gas mileage. It puts speed above all other considerations.

title: Boy Detective, Gilded New York and Best-Dressed Man
description: That Roger Rosenblatts The Boy Detective (Ecco) has no table of contents will make perfect sense to readers who follow the meandering path that constitutes his charming memoir of growing up around Gramercy Park. Categorizing his musings would be too confining.

title: Stingray Returns With Styling  la Mode
description: Imagine, if you will, that an unnamed manufacturer just released an all-new sports car. It rockets from 0 to 60 miles per hour in 3.8 seconds, pulls more than one lateral g on the skid pad and has a carbon-fiber hood and roof. The interior includes dual high-resolution screens, top-quality materials and the option of racing seats. The manual transmission, with 7 forward speeds, will execute rev-matched downshifts, and its mounted at the rear of the car for optimal weight distribution.

title: The Viper Strikes Back
description: In 2010, I entered the Spectre 341 Challenge, a terrifying 5.2-mile hill climb outside Virginia City, Nev. The official results show Lou Gigliotti winning with his 700-horsepower Chevrolet Corvette ZR1, and second place going to Steve Millen, a legendary rally racer, in a 620-horsepower Nissan GT-R. But Mr. Gigliottis Vette wasnt really the quickest car on the mountain that weekend.

title: Lincoln Joins the Crossover Party
description: Ford Motor took another step toward revitalizing its moribund Lincoln division in Manhattan on Wednesday when it unveiled a production version of a new small crossover utility, the MKC.

title: Tortured Souls
description: Samuel Beckett has been everywhere this season: a Hoi Polloi production of three short plays in Brooklyn; a take on All That Fall at the 59E59 Theaters; and versions of Waiting for Godot at the Castillo Theater and now in previews on Broadway, at the Cort.

title: Hacker Receives 10-Year Sentence for Causing Mayhem
description: A federal judge in New York on Friday delivered a 10-year prison sentence to Jeremy Hammond , a prominent member of the hacking group Anonymous who pleaded guilty earlier this year to breaking into the computer servers of a string of corporations, government agencies and law enforcement advocacy groups.

title: French Say Kidnapped Priest Was Moved to Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  The kidnappers of a French priest seized in northern Cameroon shouted for joy and fired celebratory shots in the air, one of his church superiors there said Friday, but only after crossing the border into Nigeria, in a region rife with members of the Islamist sect Boko Haram.

title: At Auction, Masterpieces of the Drivable Kind
description: With paintings and sculptures selling for record prices in recent weeks, it makes sense for auction houses to market cars as artworks, too. That would seem to be at least part of the logic behinda coming sale by Sothebys and RM Auctions ambitiously titled Art of the Automobile.

title: Tiptoeing Around the Music Video
description: The music video is in black and white. It consists entirely of women dancing in high heels, wearing identical, flesh-hugging outfits that expose their upper thighs. It is not Beyoncs Single Ladies, probably the most famous dance video of this century. It is Stop, by the choreographer Susan Marshall.

title: Weaponized Keynesianism, Historical Edition
description: In my last post, I showed that Europe is at this point doing worse  at least as measured by industrial production, and probably in terms of overall output  than it did in the Great Depression.

title: Art of the Automobile
description: A look at a few of the prized lots from the coming New York sale of high-end cars by Sothebys and RM Auctions.

title: A Seminar on Suspense, in Service of the Blues
description: Gary Clark Jr. began his encore at the Apollo Theater on Thursday night in an air of pensive solitude, perched on a chair with a harmonica and his guitar. Unhurried, calmly self-possessed, he drifted through In the Evening (When the Sun Goes Down), in an arrangement that subtly acknowledged Big Bill Broonzy and Lightnin Hopkins, among other stewards of that song. Its so lonesome when your lovers not around, he sang in a soft, clear voice, trusting that pitiful line to do its own work.

title: Tripleheader to Open Show Season
description: As 2013 is winding down, a fresh season of auto shows is booting up. Three big international salons  in Los Angeles, Tokyo and Guangzhou, China  are opening this week more or less on top of one another.

title: Friday Night Music: More San Fermin
description: I know, its only Friday afternoon, but Im deeply jet lagged, and ready to collapse.

title: If It All Doesnt Fit, Build a Bigger Box
description: The classical-music recording industry is collapsing. Right? Thats what weve heard.

title: The Space Shuttle That Fell to Earth
description: The Challenger Disaster, the Science Channels first dramatic feature film, tries hard to make the search for those faulty O-rings into a pulse-quickening thriller along the lines of All the Presidents Men. That it succeeds as well as it does can be credited largely to William Hurt, who manages to make the physicist Richard P. Feynman interesting all over again.

title: Trying to Outrace Scientific Advances
description: Before he created the futuristic TV cop show Almost Human, J. H. Wyman faced a recurring challenge as producer of the sci-fi series Fringe. Actual scientists continually spawned projects that rivaled the wildest imaginary ones dreamed up in the writers room.

title: Red Carpet Watch: Lupita Nyongos Fashion
description: Ms. Nyongo, a sure bet for a supporting actress Oscar nomination for her role in 12 Years a Slave has emerged as a red carpet star.

title: Seven Days of Style | Christies Highest Art Bid Ever, Tim Gunns New Series and H&Ms New Lady Gaga-Christened Flagship
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTURENov. 9  15

title: The Cautionary Tale of an Investment Adviser Gone Astray
description: IN the world of Ponzi schemes, Mark Spangler was a small-time crook. But his early career, as a respected investment adviser in Seattle and onetime head of a national adviser organization that pushes its members to act in their clients best interest, gives his recent conviction on 32 criminal counts a twist.

title: An Elusive Mystery Man of Music
description: On a recent Saturday night, a boisterous crowd jammed into Buka, a Nigerian restaurant in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, spilling out onto Fulton Street. This wasnt the restaurants usual weekend clientele, primarily expat Nigerians already familiar with specialties like goat-head stew and giant land snails. Instead, the throng had gathered for a record-release party, listening to African-flavored D.J. sets by Steve Shelley, formerly of Sonic Youth, and Lizzi Bougatsos of Gang Gang Dance. Just past the bar, revelers took turns posing for selfies standing next to a six-foot-high cardboard cutout of an imposing man in a disco-era cream-colored tuxedo.

title: Lupita Nyongo Impresses on the Red Carpet
description: WHO Lupita Nyongo

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 15
description: Subjects include the seasons first snow, renovations at City Hall and the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan.

title: An Interrogation Routine of Real Cop, Robot Cop?
description: In the future, your artificial limbs and joints will talk to you. Holographic gizmos will augment all those desktops, laptops and tablets were so fond of. And proper balance will be everything.

title: The Devil Is Running for a Seat in Parliament
description: A radio talk show broke the news on Oct. 28: Nana Kwaku Bonsam will run for a seat in the Parliament of Ghana in 2016.

title: Visiting the Island of the Dead
description: On Tuesday morning, the first snow flurries of the season fell on New Yorks potters field, drifting down into an open trench, dusting the dirt next to hundreds of corpses in bare wooden caskets.

title: Excerpt: 'Almost Human'
description: The new futuristic cop show on Fox pairs a detective with an android.

title: Women Gain in Some STEM Fields, but Not Computer Science
description: A few weeks ago, I wrote about ways to get more women interested in computer science. One of the points that came up frequently in my reporting is that some other STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) have actually been quite successful attracting more women. A report this week from the National Science Foundation lays out these trends nicely:

title: Inspiration Is Everywhere, Even in the Bargain Bin
description: Even if you dont know Dev Hyness name, youve likely heard his music. At 27, Mr. Hynes has been an in-demand producer and songwriter for years, recording tracks for the Chemical Brothers, Sky Ferreira, Florence and the Machine and Solange. Hes also been in the studio with Britney Spears, Kylie Minogue, Jessie Ware and Grace Jones.

title: Will Play for Health Care (at Least at One Music Event)
description: The O+ Festival in San Francisco this weekend would seem a typical indie arts event, with performances by local musicians and displays of funky art. But in a twist that highlights a longstanding problem in the creative economy, the artists involved will be paid not in cash but rather in something they may need just as badly: health care.

title: Students Try to Occupy Bulgarian Parliament Building
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Student protesters tried but failed to occupy the Bulgarian Parliament building here on Friday, then marched through the city center and broke through four police cordons in the latest of a series of angry demonstrations against the center-left government of Prime Minister Plamen Oresharski.

title: Blithely Crossing the Boundary Between Country and Hip-Hop
description: Country as a genre is both reverent and historically minded, so of course Florida Georgia Line, a young band thats quickly emerged as a reliable hitmaker after several journeyman years, peppers its shows with covers.

title: Where Witches Dance in Bushwick
description: Catland, a store and event space, draws Wiccans, pagans and devotees of occult books and full-moon rituals.

title: Death After the Typhoon: It Was Preventable
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Richard Pulga lay on a hard steel gurney for five days with only a saline drip after being seriously injured in the typhoon that devastated his country.

title: A Book Fair That Grew, Propelling the Arts in Miami
description: MIAMI  Three decades ago, the notion of a book fair in this city seemed wildly implausible.

title: The Payoff in Waiting to Collect Social Security
description: If an insurance salesman offered a product with a guaranteed income of nearly 7 percent for life, it would be foolish not to question whether it was too good to be true.

title: A Place for Work and Introspection
description: His name is Andy Bragen, and welcome to his office. He is a playwright, and good thing youre here, because theres a story he wants to tell about an artists residency he got: nine months in a Lower Manhattan office to do with as he wished.

title: Amber Batchelor: Mayor of Womens Hoops
description: On Sunday mornings, Amber Batchelor clears the men off a basketball court on the Upper West Side and runs one of the only all-female pickup games in the city.

title: Michael Chu: Mayor of New Arrivals
description: Michael Chu runs a small travel agency in Queens but spends most of his time helping members of the community deal with landlords, government agencies and employers.

title: Young and Jobless Across Europe
description: Charts of the unemployment rate.

title: Jewels by JAR
description: Joel A. Rosenthal, the first living jeweler to have a retrospective at the Met, will present 400 pieces in a single 3,000-square-foot gallery.

title: Young and Educated in Europe, but Desperate for Jobs
description: MADRID  Alba Mndez, a 24-year-old with a masters degree in sociology, sprang out of bed nervously one recent morning, carefully put on makeup and styled her hair. Her thin hands trembled as she clutched her rsum on her way out of the tiny room where a friend allows her to stay rent free.

title: For JPMorgan, $4.5 Billion to Settle Mortgage Claims
description: The checks from JPMorgan Chase just keep on coming as the nations largest bank works to move beyond its mortgage-related troubles.

title: Bill Cunningham | Winter Fashion Begins
description: The first blast of cold changed the look of fashion overnight.

title: A Masters Bubbles and Panels, in Depth
description: In museums, we look all the time at drawings, prints and illustrated books from the past, art forms that entertain us with stories but also embody history. Modern comics, at their best, do this too, often with immense sophistication. Do we see them in museums? Hardly ever.

title: Responding to a Typhoon on the Web
description: Every week, readers of The New York Times share thousands of comments in response to our reporting. What you keep telling us is that your fellow readers can be as illuminating as the news articles we produce. So were working on new ways to highlight your most notable comments, and introduce you to the readers behind them.

title: For a Jeweler, All That Bedazzles
description: Every decade or so, when Joel A. Rosenthal comes out of his velvet-lined shell in Paris to show his magnificent jewels, as he will do starting Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the same chorus of words appear.

title: American Contract Bridge League Qualifier
description: The North American Open Pairs Flight A final takes place next March, in the two days before the Spring North American Championships get into full swing in Dallas.

title: Snapchat, How Quickly You Have Grown
description: While some might have been shocked this week by the multi-billion dollar offers the start-up Snapchat turned down, I found something else entirely perplexing about the valuation of this little company: just how quickly it grew.

title: T WINTER TRAVEL
description: The designer Faye Toogood finds exceptional beauty in unexpected arrangements of objects, and uses them to create installations for fashion houses  and her own house.

title: A View Inside the Art World
description: The author Henry Alford attended the record-breaking auctions of modern art at Christies and Sothebys, but to watch, not buy.

title: For First Time, E.P.A. Proposes Reducing Ethanol Requirement for Gas Mix
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday proposed reducing the amount of ethanol that is required to be mixed with the gasoline supply, the first time it has taken steps to slow down the drive to replace fossil fuels with renewable forms of energy.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Understanding Candy Crush Addictions, the Rise of Twitter Bots and #SFBatkid
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Bill Cunningham | Winter Fashion Begins
description: Madison Square Park was a shower of golden leaves, a backdrop for the Veterans Day Parade. The first blast of cold changed the look of fashion overnight. Mens coats with brass buttons echoed the military theme, as did trench coats (but not cyclamen-pink fur). Black offset the leaves. Braided scarves from Loopy Mango appeared, too.

title: House Tour | Faye Toogood
description: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.

title: Washington Comes Out
description: Ten percent of adults in the District of Columbia identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender, nearly three times the national average. What makes the city such a gay-friendly place?

title: Player Ratings: Scotland (0), U.S. (0)
description: No Clint Dempsey. No Landon Donovan. Nothing at stake, in terms of a result.

title: Performance Art That Looks a Lot Like Theater
description: Alexandre Singhs The Humans has its ups and downs, but it is still one of the outstanding achievements of the Performa 13 performance art biennial. Commissioned in collaboration with the Witte de With Center for Contemporary Art in the Netherlands, it is less performance art than classical theater with all the benefits of a highly skilled, well-rehearsed cast.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 15
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the seasons first snow, renovations at City Hall and the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan.

title: Out in D.C.
description: The capital as the backdrop of a thriving gay scene.

title: Think Big
description: I had the odd coincidence of reading Lawrence Osbornes piece on Burma  in which he examines the country today alongside the one George Orwell wrote about in his first novel, Burmese Days  at the same time my husband happened to be reading Orwells 1984 aloud to our children.

title: The Gayest Place in America?
description: WASHINGTON  My earliest sense of what it meant to be gay in the nations capital came more than a decade ago when I was a summer intern. I was a few blocks from Union Station when a congressman walked by and gave the reporters I was standing with a big, floppy wave hello.

title: Oops. I Left My Millions at Home.
description: Behold the swirl. At the brunch last Sunday at Christies auction house for bidders and attendees of this past Tuesdays history-making sale of postwar and contemporary art, hundreds of well-dressed art lovers sipped Champagne and nibbled party food while standing just inches from canvases, some of them valued for millions of dollars.

title: The Biggie: A Tainted Status Symbol
description: The rise in violent fashion-related crime has coalesced around the growing cachet of streetwear and fashions embrace of celebrity culture  as the crowd skating at the Bryant Park ice rink on Nov. 9 can readily attest to.

title: Justices to Revisit Securities Fraud Suits
description: The Supreme Court agreed Friday to hear a case that could make it harder for investors to win class-action lawsuits for securities fraud. The court also agreed to consider when police officers could be sued for using excessive force to stop fleeing suspects.

title: Jay Zs Blueprint Didnt Call for This
description: This is how it usually happens.

title: Together, at Home and at Work
description: I spent much of the last six months helping my wife with a rare professional opportunity. When friends heard how many days, nights and weekends we spent in the same room, they had the same reply: Whoa! When are you getting divorced?

title: Beheading in Syria Is Called a Mistake
description: It was a deadly case of mistaken identity set against the chaotic, sectarian backdrop of the Syrian conflict.

title: Ts Winter Travel Issue
description: The latest issue of T takes us to many destinations in many different ways. In our cover story, we provide a relaxed, versatile wardrobe with clean lines that are tailor-made for travel. Sometimes travel can simply be a state of mind; lovely interiors can transport a home. The designer Faye Toogood brings the English countryside to her London house, with her unexpected arrangements of objects. These days, travel envy happens with a few clicks. Instagram offers a fresh means to peek into others carefully curated lifestyles all around the world. Next, we travel to France by way of Miami; the designer Charlotte Perriand, who created furnishings, interiors and buildings with Le Corbusier, is being recognized at Design Miami this December for her ahead-of-the-curve sensibility. Sometimes its all about the journey  Alexander Payne shares his love for the wholesomeness of hometown Nebraska in a road trip with the novelist Kurt Andersen. In Montana, the investment banker-turned-hunter Georgia Pellegrini offers a weekend retreat for urban women like herself to get in touch with their primitive selves. Last but not least, Lawrence Osborne travels to Myanmar to search for the inspirations behind George Orwells books. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Tennessee Pastor Disputes Wildlife Possession Charge by State
description: JACKSBORO, Tenn.  In a mix of old-time religion, modern media and Tennessee law, a 22-year-old preacher who has become a reality television star because of his experience in handling poisonous snakes pleaded not guilty on Friday to illegally keeping dozens of them that he and his congregants routinely touch during worship services.

title: Former Marcos Aide Is Stricken at Her Conspiracy Trial
description: A former aide to Imelda Marcos who is accused of selling a Monet masterpiece that she did not own was wheeled out of court during the prosecutions closing arguments on Friday morning after experiencing chest pains and nausea.

title: Immigrants Closely Tied to Military Get Reprieve
description: The Obama administration issued a new policy on Friday that will allow immigrants in the United States illegally who are close relatives of active military troops and veterans to stay and move toward becoming permanent residents.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: An enormous online shopping spree, the rejection of a Boeing contract and a confirmation hearing for a potential Federal Reserve chairwoman.

title: She Doesnt Expect Anything, and Hasnt Been Disappointed
description: There is a photograph taped to the front of a building on Eighth Avenue in Chelsea that gives pause to people walking by. It shows a smiling old woman holding a striped cat. But any warm feelings fade upon reading a handwritten sign below.

title: Holiday
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: How Liberals and Conservatives See the Pope
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Site Infighting Detailed in Emails
description: WASHINGTON  Senior federal officials involved in building the HealthCare.gov website were deeply concerned this summer about delays as well as weaknesses in the quality and size of the contractor teams assigned to parts of the project, emails released by congressional investigators on Friday show.

title: Holiday
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Addiction Specialists Wary of New Painkiller
description: Addiction experts protested loudly when the Food and Drug Administration approved a powerful new opioid painkiller last month, saying that it would set off a wave of abuse much as OxyContin did when it first appeared.

title: Access to College
description: To the Editor:

title: To a Philosopher-General in Israel, Peace Is the Time to Prepare for War
description: ON THE ISRAEL-LEBANON BORDER

title: Compromise in Arizona Defers a Solar Power Fight
description: In voting to impose a modest charge on new residential solar customers, Arizonas power regulators have ended, for the moment, a bitter fight between the rooftop solar industry and the states main electric utility.

title: Health Rollout: Troubles and Fixes
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Protest Turns Deadly as Militias Open Fire
description: CAIRO  Dozens of people were killed in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, on Friday after militiamen opened fire on unarmed protesters, setting off some of the worst violence in the capital since the revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi almost three years ago.

title: Off the Court, a Films Lens on Asian-American Faith
description: During his years getting started as a film producer, Christopher Chen took a great many meetings. He had his favorite places, like the Griddle Cafe in Hollywood and Nate n Al in Beverly Hills. Even if the movie he was pitching never came together, the deli served great corned beef hash.

title: Judd Hirschs Wind-Power Plan Unsettles Catskill Town
description: DENNING, N.Y.  Blanketed by the stillness of stone-faced mountains and endless trees now shaded rust and gold, the town of Denning is quiet, so quiet, one longtime resident likes to say, you can hear your heartbeat.

title: Holiday
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: When Boys Lose a Haven, a Grandmother Gets Vocal
description: When her grandchildrens refuge was taken away, Mable Moody didnt just get mad. She got loud.

title: Holiday
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: In a Bean, a Boon to Biotech
description: A new federal push to purge artery-clogging trans fats from foods could be just what the doctor ordered  not only for public health but for the unpopular biotechnology industry, specifically, two developers of genetically modified crops.

title: African Call to Delay Kenyans Trials Fails at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  An African-led attempt to postpone the trials of Kenyas top two leaders at the International Criminal Court collapsed on Friday when it failed to gain enough support on the United Nations Security Council, an outcome bitterly criticized by Kenya and other African nations that accused the Councils majority of a patronizing mistrust.

title: Tough Way to Lose a Friend
description: Every writer knows that unless you were born gifted with either supreme confidence or outsize ego, handing in your work holds, in some cases, admitted terror. If thats too strong, at least fairly high anxiety. Even if what you wrote seems unusually good to you, part of you is vulnerable to the suggestion that you may have laid an egg. A bad one. As W.C. Fields might have put it as your editor, Sadly, my little lad, you have contrived in this instance to produce a specimen of odoriferous hen fruit.

title: Whos Sorry Now?
description: Barack Obamas loyal supporters are heavy of heart. Perhaps their chief source of comfort is that the Obamacare mess hit the headlines at about the same time as the crack-smoking mayor of Toronto. At least the president didnt claim he was drunk when he wrote the health care bill.

title: Prosecutor Plans to Interview F.S.U. Quarterbacks Accuser
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  William N. Meggs, a state attorney for Floridas Second Judicial Circuit, said he was not certain how a sexual assault complaint from almost a year ago involving Florida State quarterback Jameis Winston had just crossed his desk, but he promised he would get to the bottom of it.

title: Conservation Group Keeps Buying Land, Helping State Parks Grow
description: MINNEWASKA STATE PARK, N.Y.  Over the last 25 years, this park in upstate Ulster County has doubled in size. Farther south, in Putnam County, Fahnestock State Park has grown even more, and in Orange County, Sterling Forest State Park has gained almost 15,000 acres.

title: Holiday
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Brazil: Arrests Begin in Vote-Fraud Case
description: The federal police on Friday began arresting a dozen powerful political figures, bankers and businessmen convicted in a vast vote-buying scandal that surfaced more thaneight years ago. More than a year ago, Brazils highest court set the prison sentences for officials from the governing Workers Party, but the courts consideration of appeals in the landmark corruption trial and what appeared to have been bureaucratic problems had delayed sending those found guilty in the scheme to prison. It is rare for high-profile Brazilian politicians convicted of crimes to serve time in prison. But this week the Supreme Federal Tribunal ruled that the convicted officials must soon start their prison terms. On Friday, Jos Genoino Guimares Neto, a legislator who is a former president of the Workers Party, turned himself in at a police building in So Paulo and thrust his fist in the air in an act of defiance.

title: After Obama Meeting, Insurers Question Plans Workability
description: A day after they were caught off guard by President Obamas proposal to prevent cancellation of insurance policies for millions of Americans, top executives of some of the biggest insurance companies emerged from a meeting at the White House on Friday, expressing mixed feelings about whether the idea could work in every state.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 15, 2013
On Track and Off, Vettel Sets His Own Pace
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Nobody in Formula One racing isin a bigger rush than Sebastian Vettel, known for hisblisteringstarts on the track and in his raceto the recordbooks.

title: Emotional Support, With Fur, Draws Complaints on Planes
description: LOS ANGELES  Gigi Griffis, a writer who travels around the world as she works, and Luna, her sprightly 4-year-old Schnauzer-Yorkie mix, are nearly inseparable. They have dined in Mexican cafes near Puerto Vallarta, navigated the Paris Metro and hiked the alpine foothills of the Matterhorn.

title: Canada: Toronto Council Curbs Mayor
description: After Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto, a self-confessed crack cocaine user, binge drinker and impaired driver, refused to step down, the Toronto City Council began stripping away his powers on Friday. A special session of the Council removed the mayors power to appoint the members of the citys executive committee as well as the deputy mayor. It also transferred any powers Mr. Ford would have as mayor during a declared emergency to the deputy mayor. On Monday the Council will consider measures to eliminate the budget and staff for Mr. Fords office. Mr. Ford said he would challenge the sanctions in court. The Council has no legal means to remove the mayor from office.

title: Disrespect, Race and Obama
description: In an interview with the BBC this week, Oprah Winfrey said of President Obama: There is a level of disrespect for the office that occurs. And that occurs, in some cases, and maybe even many cases, because hes African-American.

title: Obama Gives San Franciscos Batkid a Six-Second Shout-Out
description: All Miles Scott wanted to do was to put on his Batman costume and fight crime on the grimy streets of Gotham City.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 16, 2013
description: On the bad days, its really hard to get out of bed. I ask myself, What did I do wrong?

title: McBrides Family on Murder Charge
description: The family of Renisha McBride, who was shot and killed on a front porch in a Detroit suburb, held a news conference to discuss the second-degree murder and manslaughter charges against the home owner.

title: A Closer Look at a Centuries-Old Text
description: The Bay Psalm Book was the first book printed in the colonies and the first book printed in English in the New World. A copy will be auctioned on Nov. 26 and is expected to fetch $15 million to $30 million.

title: Let Bidding Begin for the Bay Psalm Book From 1640
description: David N. Redden recited the opening of the 23rd Psalm the way he had memorized it as a child: The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want. He maketh me to lie down in green pastures.

title: France: 4 Said to Recruit for Syrian War
description: French authorities near Paris have arrested four men suspected of involvement in a network sending fighters to Syria to join radical Sunni Islamist groups operating there, the Paris prosecutors office said Friday. The domestic intelligence service said three of the men had fought in Syria alongside the Nusra Front, which has links to Al Qaeda, and returned to France, said Agns Thibault-Lecuivre, a spokeswoman for the prosecutors office. The fourth man is believed to be the networks organizer. All four were to be charged on Friday with conspiring to commit terrorist acts, Ms. Thibault-Lecuivre said. More than 100 French residents or citizens are fighting in Syria, French officials say.

title: Voter Suppressions New Pretext
description: IRVINE, Calif.  ITS the latest fad among state officials looking to make voting harder: Were not racist, were just partisan.

title: Corrections: November 16, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: From G-Funk to Geometry
description: David Steinberg may still be a teenager, but hes proven that he has top talent as a crossword constructor. Hes already published a puzzle for every day of the week, and hes back today with a Saturday.

title: Not the Time to Squeeze Iran
description: A rare opportunity for a diplomatic resolution to the dispute over Irans nuclear program is at risk because many lawmakers, urged on by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, are insisting that Congress impose tougher economic sanctions, perhaps next week as an amendment to the defense bill.

title: Gun Tragedies Without End
description: The latest woeful lesson in gun mayhem is playing out in Michigan, where a 54-year-old man in Dearborn Heights was charged Friday with second-degree murder in the shotgun slaying of a 19-year-old woman presumed to have knocked on his door in the middle of the night, seeking help after a traffic accident.

title: A Leap for Equality
description: On Wednesday, Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii signed a bill that will allow same-sex couples to marry in the state, starting Dec. 2. The measure, ending a two-decade legal and political battle, caps a remarkable year of progress toward ensuring the basic civil rights of gay Americans.

title: Starting Over After Hurricane Sandy
description: As Hurricane Sandy approached, Joseph Duodu, his wife and two daughters evacuated from their home on the Rockaway Peninsula and drove to a motel on Queens Boulevard. The family had packed only an overnight bag with a change of clothes because they thought they would be back home the next day. They ended up living in the motel for five months.

title: Mike McCormack, Hall of Fame Browns Lineman, Dies at  83
description: Mike McCormack, a Hall of Fame tackle for the Cleveland Browns in the 1950s and early 60s who protected quarterback Otto Graham and opened holes for fullback Jim Brown and then became an N.F.L. coach and executive, died on Friday in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 83.

title: Saturdays Games to Watch
description: 12 OKLAHOMA STATE at

title: The Little Agency That Could
description: One of the big criticisms of the original team of financial regulators brought in by President Obama is that too many of them had worked in Bill Clintons Treasury Department. That, of course, was the Treasury Department run by Robert Rubin and then by Lawrence Summers  an agency with a bias toward deregulation. Those regulators had supported the elimination of Glass-Steagall, the 1930s law that separated investment banks from commercial banks, and were disinclined to regulate derivatives, those financial weapons of mass destruction, as Warren Buffett liked to call them.

title: Elmer Lokkins, Symbol of Same-Sex Marriage Cause, Dies at 94
description: Elmer Lokkins and Gustavo Archilla kept their relationship private for nearly 60 years. Some knew; some just wondered. Most did not discuss the situation. Uncle Gus and Uncle Elmer, their family called them.

title: MSNBC Suspends Alec Baldwin and His Talk Show
description: MSNBC suspended Alec Baldwin on Friday after a furor stirred by a gay slur that he made in a confrontation with reporters this week.

title: The Rise of the Union Leagues
description: In the spring of 1863, a group of ardent Republicans in Centralia, a railroad town in south central Illinois, sought to revive the moribund local party newspaper. Needing an editor, they poached one from nearby Sparta. John W. Fletcher, a western New Yorker then 44 years old, was their man. On May 28 he took up his pen for the new weekly, The Centralia Sentinel.

title: House Members React to Health Care Bill
description: The House of Representatives passed a bill that would allow people to keep their health care plan. Insurers would continue to sell plans that did not meet the new guidelines for one more year.

title: As Knicks Hunt for Wins, Anthony Rarely Finds a Seat
description: In a quest to prevent his body from crumbling into a cartoonish pile of parts, Carmelo Anthony has turned to a between-games conditioning routine that runs the gamut from conventional to space age. There are ice packs and massages, cryogenic chambers and NormaTec compression sleeves.

title: Bitterness Is Gone as Nolan and the Sabres Reunite
description: BUFFALO  Ted Nolan was traveling to Latvia last week when one of his former players, the Hall of Famer Pat LaFontaine, reached him by phone.

title: Top Teenage Runner Is Turning Pro
description: Mary Cain, one of the most promising female American high school middle-distance runners in decades, has chosen to turn professional rather than run for a collegiate team.

title: Asserting the Right to Handle Snakes
description: A 22-year-old preacher who has become a reality television star because of his experience in handling poisonous snakes is facing charges in Tennessee.

title: Nets Lose Williams in Overtime Win
description: PHOENIX  The Nets worked themselves to full throttle on Friday night, just a couple of hours after the player meant to be their engine this season was stalled on the court.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 6:25 P.M. (Flix) MALLRATS (1995) A couple of recently dumped neer-do-wells (Jason Lee and Jeremy London) try to get over their girlfriends (Shannen Doherty and Claire Forlani) by wandering around the local mall. Writing in the The New York Times, Janet Maslin said this comedy, written and directed by Kevin Smith, mixes clever bits and an appealing quirkiness (which goes a long way) with gross-out practical jokes, needless repetition and obvious padding, since it has no real plot. She added: Mr. Lees Brodie has the grunge and surliness to give him credibility here, but he also has a sweet, funny indignation over lifes little outrages, which are actually this films most heartfelt concerns.

title: In Worst-Hit Area of Tacloban, a Killer From Two Sides
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  In the corner of what used to be her living room, Mary Grace Golondrina, 20, dug through the mud and recovered a trophy  first-place runner-up in a fund-raiser for Santo Nio Church. There is little else here.

title: Deadly Kabul Bombing Sends Message on Security Pact Vote
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A powerful car bomb that exploded near the site where Afghan elders are set to vote on a long-term security agreement with the United States killed at least 10 people on Saturday, rattling central Kabul and underscoring the insurgencys desire to prevent an American presence in Afghanistan beyond 2014.

title: Fix Fix Fix The Debt Debt Debt
description: Ahem:

title: Bookshelf | The World of Gilles Mendel, According to Enoc Perez
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Room for Agreement on Next Steps for Nuclear Power?
description: Room for Debate has posted a useful new discussion on whether and how nuclear power can safely contribute to advancing energy options without climate regrets. I can think of lots of other experts and practitioners to engage, of course.

title: The Daily Gift: Santa Maria Novella Talcum Powder
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Geithner to Join Private Equity Firm
description: Timothy F. Geithner will join the private equity firm Warburg Pincus as president, the firm announced on Saturday. It would be his first prominent position since leaving office as Treasury secretary this year.

title: Variety: Ancient Philosophy
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Its curious that two of the most memorable villains in fiction share a fondness for Marcus Aurelius. In Richard Connells 1924 short story The Most Dangerous Game, General Zaroff, the unhinged sophisticate who hunts humans on his island, unwinds at the end of the night with a bottle of chambertin and the writings of Aurelius. In The Silence of the Lambs, Hannibal Lecter quotes from The Meditations during a cellblock interrogation: First principles, Clarice. Simplicity. Read Marcus Aurelius.
