Of each particular thing ask: what is it in itself? What is its nature? What does he do, this man you seek?

title: Vows: In Sickness and in Health
description: Breast cancer sidelined Virginia Wettlaufer just six months after she and Walter Tomenson started dating.

title: Defection of Longtime Ally Splits Center-Right in Italy
description: ROME  Silvio Berlusconis center-right political movement, a powerful force in Italy, split Saturday, dealing another blow to the former prime minister as Italian lawmakers prepare for a final vote this month on whether to expel him from the Senate.

title: Russian Manhunt Ends as Bus Bombers Husband Is Killed
description: MOSCOW  Ending a nearly monthlong manhunt, security forces killed the husband of a suicide bomber who blew up a public bus last month in the city of Volgograd, Russian officials said Saturday.

title: A Lesson in Perseverance for a Giants Running Back
description: Shrouded in darkness, Michael A. Cox Sr., a plainclothes Boston police officer, sprinted after four murder suspects cornered on a dead-end street in a seedy neighborhood. As sirens wailed nearby, one of the suspects scaled a fence, with Cox in close pursuit.

title: Mets and Yanks Must Swing for Fences
description: The Mets have fallen into a strange pattern lately. One player commands attention with a fantastic, must-see individual season  and then disappears the following year.

title: Bob Pittman of Clear Channel, on the Value of Dissent
description: This interview with  Bob Pittman, chairman and chief executive of Clear Channel Communications, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: An Artist Uses Humor as a Salve for an Illness
description: If surgeons had to remove her left eye, it wouldnt be so bad, Katie Commodore had reasoned. Think of the party tricks she could perform with a glass eye! Maybe she could stud it with diamonds, even fit it with a camera or a laser sight.

title: A Tool Meant to Keep Her Safe Makes Her Feel Like a Target
description: Cynthia Gibbs-Pratt would rather walk into walls than use a cane to guide her. And often, she does.

title: Petty. Earnhardt. Johnson? A Debate Expands.
description: If Richard Petty, Dale Earnhardt and Jimmie Johnson were placed in identical racecars side by side, who would win?

title: Answer to Blindness Was Hidden in the Genes
description: Jasmine Carrero has big doelike eyes, an almond-shaped face and a willowy frame that she calls boyish. She also has Stickler syndrome, a group of genetic disorders whose hallmarks are these elongated features; it is responsible not just for the elegant tapering fingers possessed by nearly everyone in her family, but also for the familys history of blindness.

title: FIFAs Puskas Award
description: Everyone has his favorite goal of the year.

title: Rebuilding Strength
description: Katie Commodore, 35, a printmaking artist whose multiple sclerosis has caused her to lose some motor functions, has hired a physical trainer to rebuild her strength.

title: Still on Facebook, but Finding Less to Like
description: Just a few years ago, most of my online social activity revolved around Facebook. I was an active member of several Facebook groups, including one that helped me and others find apartments and sell used items. Another group was wonderful for organizing midnight movie screenings. And I used Facebook to stay up-to-date on the latest achievements of my sisters and their children, and the many members of my extended family.

title: Tennessee Governor Hesitates on Medicaid Expansion, Frustrating Many
description: NASHVILLE  Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee describes it as trying to thread a needle from 80 yards.

title: Who Has Your Back? Hard to Tell
description: What is the duty of a trustee to protect investors?

title: In the Zone With Peyton Manning
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  As the Denver Broncos ran out the clock in their win over the San Diego Chargers last weekend, football fans gasped as Peyton Manning, the undisputed face of the N.F.L., got up limping after being tackled around his legs.

title: Ken Mobley
description: Ken Mobley, a jailer in Whitley County, Ky., talks about the difficulty of keeping Suboxone out of prisons.

title: Buprenorphine Explained
description: Dr. Andrew Kolodny, the president of Physicians for Responsible Opioid Prescribing, describes the pharmacology of buprenorphine and the drugs effect at the brains receptor level.

title: Shawn Schneider
description: Over the past two years, Shawn Schneider, 38, has been taking buprenorphine to maintain his sobriety after an addiction to painkillers.

title: Melissa Iverson
description: Melissa Iverson was transformed after doctors put her on buprenorphine following a psychotic break.

title: House Tour | Faye Toogood
description: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.

title: Dr. Jeffrey T. Junig
description: Dr. Jeffrey T. Junig discusses the questions he asks himself when it comes to discharging patients from addiction treatment programs.

title: The Pacers Perfect Beginning Will Not Guarantee Them a Happy Ending
description: When an N.B.A. team starts the season on an unbeaten run, curiosity always kicks in. What is the longest streak without a loss to start the season? What does a soaring start say about a teams chances when the playoffs arrive six months down the road?

title: Painting Picketts Charge
description: Like other Northern states, Pennsylvania had much business to attend to in the weeks and months that followed the end of the Civil War: there were regiments to be dissolved, soldiers to be mustered out, and wounded, widowed and orphaned to be provided for.

title: Addiction Treatment With a Dark Side
description: For Shawn Schneider, a carpenter and rock musician, the descent into addiction began one Wisconsin winter with a fall from a rooftop construction site onto the frozen ground below. As the potent pain pills prescribed for his injuries became his obsessive focus, he lost everything: his band, his job, his wife, his will to live.

title: Dont Mess With My Sacred Values
description: ACCORDING to news reports, a key factor in last weekends diplomatic impasse over Irans nuclear program was Irans insistence on what President Hassan Rouhani has called its right to enrich uranium. National interests are our red line, he declared, echoing earlier statements by other Iranian leaders.

title: Reining in Payday Lenders
description: At some point  soon, we hope  the Federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will issue regulations for the payday lending industry. The bureau took an important step in that direction when it announced earlier this month that it would begin collecting complaints from borrowers who may have been hit with unreasonable fees, unauthorized withdrawals from their checking accounts or other abuses. The bureau should rein in all of these practices, but its most important task is to ensure that the loans are affordable  which means requiring lenders to determine in advance that the borrower has the ability to repay.

title: My Education, Repossessed
description: Like many post-grads, Ive been struggling for years to keep up with my student loan payments. I can just about make it each month, with some modest sacrifices. For instance, doing my own dental work. But last night I had a terrible dream. In it, I fell so far behind in my payments that the government decided to move against me. They could have taken legal action, but they did something much more diabolical: They repossessed my education.

title: Prudence or Cruelty?
description: WHEN members of Congress debate whether to slash the food stamp program, they should ask if they really want more small children arriving at school having skipped breakfast.

title: Sentenced to a Slow Death
description: If this were happening in any other country, Americans would be aghast. A sentence of life in prison, without the possibility of parole, for trying to sell $10 of marijuana to an undercover officer? For sharing LSD at a Grateful Dead concert? For siphoning gas from a truck? The punishment is so extreme, so irrational, so wildly disproportionate to the crime that it defies explanation.

title: Something for Barack and Bibi to Talk About
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA and Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel spoke on the phone for 90 minutes the other day. Wow  90 minutes! I wonder if Obama has ever spoken to John Boehner for 90 minutes?

title: Chinas New Agenda
description: In one of several surprising and potentially welcome shifts in policy, Chinas leaders announced Friday that they would relax Chinas draconian one-child policy and end its brutal re-education through labor camps. They also outlined several ambitious economic initiatives that could make the country more hospitable to private enterprise in the coming years.

title: The Three Burials of Obamacare
description: THE first time Obamacare seemed finished, doomed, doornail-dead, the voters of Massachusetts played the would-be executioner. In January 2010, they sent a pickup-driving Republican to the Senate to fill Ted Kennedys seat, apparently depriving the health care bill of its crucial 60th vote and sending Democrats scrambling for a Plan B.

title: More Fun With Bill and Hill
description: BEFORE President Obama administered his fix to the Affordable Care Act last week and even before it was clear that he was leaning that way, Bill Clinton piped up, opining that Obama should honor his claim that Americans with insurance they liked could keep it. This advice wasnt exactly solicited. And inasmuch as it gave detractors of Obama and Obamacare a fresh cudgel, it wasnt terribly helpful, either.

title: Billy Collins
description: Billy Collins is a best-selling poet who served as poet laureate of the United States from 2001 to 2003. His latest collection of poetry is Aimless Love.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Academias Two Tracks
description: Are adjuncts better teachers than tenure-track faculty?

title: Waiting to See if Ukraine Tilts East or West
description: Curiously, the ferocious tug-of-war between Russia and the European Union over Ukraine has come down to whether Yulia Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister who is serving a seven-year prison sentence, is freed in the next few days.

title: Youre So Self-Controlling
description: WHAT do you do if, when you get to a subway platform, you see that it is already packed with people? Do you join the throngs to wait for the train, or do you shake your head and seek an alternative way to get where youre going?

title: The Insanity of Our Food Policy
description: American food policy has long been rife with head-scratching illogic. We spend billions every year on farm subsidies, many of which help wealthy commercial operations to plant more crops than we need. The glut depresses world crop prices, harming farmers in developing countries. Meanwhile, millions of Americans live tenuously close to hunger, which is barely kept at bay by a food stamp program that gives most beneficiaries just a little more than $4 a day.

title: To Fight Obesity, a Carrot, and a Stick
description: Childhood obesity, at long last, may have peaked  even among the poor, where the problem is most prevalent. Between 2008 and 2011, according to a study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 19 states and territories saw a small but significant drop in obesity rates among low-income preschoolers.

title: Alzheimers Anxiety
description: PHILADELPHIA  ALMOST every day I worry about whether my parents have Alzheimers. My dad is 86 and my mother is about to turn 80. Just because of their age they are at high risk for the disease, and I constantly wonder if their forgetfulness is normal or a sign of the worst.

title: Recovery and Reconstruction
description: The rural hinterland of the Philippines has been largely left to fend for itself since Typhoon Haiyan hit.

title: Kidd Is Finding His Coaching Style (the Suit and Tie Are Just the Start)
description: PHOENIX  It has yet to feel natural seeing Jason Kidd fastened inside a coachs workday attire. His players have joked that his suit jackets look too tight. His neckties never seem to hang at a proper length. If, somehow, these represent conscious sartorial decisions, they are unusual ones.

title: I Was a Portrait by Francis Bacon
description: MILAN  MY bookshelves have a bad habit: They eat books. Especially the books I care most about. My books seem to vanish, and where theyve gone nobody knows. So I find myself buying the same book, once, twice, even three times in certain cases. One night not long ago, around midnight, I set out, unsuccessfully, to find the book of David Sylvesters interviews with the painter Francis Bacon. I wanted to verify a quote I use frequently that I suspected might be his, a quote that exemplifies my view of life in general and, sadly, also the less-than-Apollonian way I run my own:

title: More Freedom on the Airplane, if Nowhere Else
description: It is sometimes the small events that reveal the really big problems lurking beneath the surface. Thats the case with the Federal Aviation Administrations recent decision to grant airlines the liberty of allowing the use of electronic devices during takeoff and landing.

title: The City With a Death Wish in Its Eye
description: FOR 50 years, Dallas has done its best to avoid coming to terms with the one event that made it famous: the assassination of John F. Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963. Thats because, for the self-styled Big D, grappling with the assassination means reckoning with its own legacy as the city of hate, the city that willed the death of the president.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 17
description: There were times I thought we got slapped around unjustly. This one is deserved. Its on us.

title: Ground-Shaking Noise Rocks N.F.L., and Eardrums Take Big Hit
description: National Football League teams are racing this season to secure the title of loudest outdoor stadium in the world.

title: A Talk With Lars Peter Hansen, Nobel Laureate
description: Lars Peter Hansen, an economist at the University of Chicago, is one of three winners of this years Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, along with Eugene F. Fama, a fellow professor at the University of Chicago, and Robert J. Shiller, a professor at Yale.

title: Lars Peter Hansen, the Nobel Laureate in the Middle
description: Lars Peter Hansen understands why he is being asked, but he isnt comfortable with the question. Are financial markets efficient or irrational? repeats Professor Hansen, a University of Chicago economist. I dont really know how to answer that.

title: Why Food Stamps Are a Great Investment
description: My Sunday column looks at the issue of food stamps, subject of a forthcoming battle on Capitol Hill. The program will be cut, but its unclear by how much. My column argues that it would be short-sighted, as well as cruel, to slash the program, for a couple of reasons. First, almost two-thirds of recipients are children, elderly or disabled. Second, particularly with the children who are recipients, the malnutrition is real and there is mounting evidence that it has long-term effects that leave those children less equipped to succeed at school and live productive lives. Im particularly swayed by the NBER study that my column cites and links to, indicating that when children under five get food stamps, their long-term health outcomes are better, and they are less likely to end up on welfare. Read the column, but Id also encourage you to read the study.

title: In a North Face Jacket, a Reversible Appeal
description: It started when I bought a North Face jacket.

title: Secular Stagnation, Coalmines, Bubbles, and Larry Summers
description: Im pretty annoyed with Larry Summers right now. His presentation at the IMF Research Conference is, justifiably, getting a lot of attention. And heres the thing: Ive been thinking along the same lines, and have, I think, hinted at this analysis in various writings. But Larrys formulation is much clearer and more forceful, and altogether better, than anything Ive done. Curse you, Red Baron Larry Summers!

title: Childs Play in a Days Work
Syrian Governments Forces Gain, but a Siege War Goes On
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian government forces have recently ousted rebels from a string of suburbs outside Damascus, threatening their yearlong control of territory south of the capital city, cutting supply lines and surrounding strongholds that one fighter called their last castle in the area.

title: Reaching for Silicon Valley
description: Joy Laskar was not what youd typically think of as a threat to public safety.

title: Academic Innovators
description: An incomplete, eclectic list of university-spawned companies and innovations.

title: Periods of Joblessness
description: The number of people who have been unemployed for short periods has fallen close to its pre-recession level, but high rates of long-term unemployment persist.

title: Caught in a Revolving Door of Unemployment
description: On a cold October morning, just after the federal government shutdown came to an end, Jenner Barrington-Ward headed into court in Boston to declare bankruptcy.

title: Alex Calderwood, Creator and Face of the Unconventional Ace Hotel Chain, Dies at 47
description: Alex Calderwood, a founder of the Ace Hotel chain, whose quirky vintage interiors influenced the industry and became the backdrop for countless Instagram pictures, died on Thursday in London. He was 47.

title: Success of Chinese Leaders Ambitious Economic Plan May Rest on Rural Regions
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Communist Party has burnished President Xi Jinpings plans for an economic overhaul with exultant propaganda about a historic turning point. But the success of his proposals, and the long-term health of the Chinese economy, could rest on policy battles reaching down into thousands of towns and villages over land, money and a misshapen fiscal system that has bred public discontent and financial hazards.

title: New Syrian Refugees Descend on Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Refugees poured into Arsal, a Lebanese town in the Bekaa Valley near Syria, on Saturday amid reports that a battle was beginning along the mountainous border, a sign that the government was broadening its offensive against rebel strongholds.

title: For Yankees Sabathia, It Appears Less (Weight) Is Less (Success)
description: Theories about C. C. Sabathias declining performance the last two seasons include the effect of his heavy workload  an average of 227 innings over 16 seasons  and his operation for bone chips in his pitching elbow after the 2012 season.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Jets Hill, Receptions Are a Waiting Game
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It happens all the time to Stephen Hill. He will be leaning over his pregnant fiance, talking to her belly, when their dog, a Shih-poo named Boss, bounds over to compete for his attention. Boss barks. Boss snatches a toy and drops it at their feet. Boss barks some more.

title: Week 11 Matchup: Jets (5-4) at Bills (3-7)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: With Dominating Offense, Princeton Trounces Yale and Gains Share of Ivy Title
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Princeton clinched at least a share of its first Ivy League title since 2006 and re-established a long if inconsistent football tradition with a 59-23 homecoming victory against Yale on Saturday.

title: Challenger Takes Lead Over World Chess Champion
description: For more than three years, Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, has been the uncrowned king of chess. It appears increasingly likely that within the next few days, he will officially wear the crown of world champion.

title: For U.S., Scotland Game Was Chance to Evaluate Young Talent
description: GLASGOW  While much of the soccer world focused on the critical European World Cup qualifying playoff matches Friday night, the United States national team played an exhibition game here that seemed meaningless to just about everyone but a few American players.

title: Foless Resilience Fortifies What Was a Fragile Position
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Michael Vick retreated to the end of Philadelphias bench after aggravating his strained left hamstring in the second quarter of the Eagles defeat against the Giants on Oct. 27, it seemed more than a game would be lost.

title: Stretching Field Has Been Challenging for Manning and the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants were nursing a 13-10 lead against the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field when Eli Manning launched a desperation pass toward Hakeem Nicks in the left side of the end zone on the last play of the second quarter.

title: Runoff Vote Is Completed in Maldives
description: NEW DELHI  The half brother of a former leader of the Maldives appears to have won that countrys runoff election for president on Saturday, defeating a popular favorite and ending a tumultuous voting process halted three times by court orders.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 17
description: President Obama encouraged Americans to blame him  not his party  for the problems with the rollout of the national health care law. Still, some top Democrats are taking to the Sunday shows to defend him and ask for more patience. Plus, one network will dedicate its program to the 50th anniversary of John F. Kennedys assassination.

title: Week 11 Matchup: Packers (5-4) at Giants (3-6)
description: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, FOX

title: Vowel Play
description: If part of your Sunday morning routine is to sit down to solve the crossword over a cup of tea, you might have a hint to one of todays clues right under your nose. Thats because a lot of popular breakfast blends include tea grown in ASSAM, a state in northeastern India known for its heavy rainfall and, as a result, prodigious tea output. English breakfast tea, a blend, includes Assams offerings. The region comes up today at 42 Down, one of several clues about Indian geography.

title: With Braves Set to Move, a Broader Look at Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  A collective gasp rose here last week when the Atlanta Braves announced that they were moving to the suburbs. The franchise, after all, has been not only a sports team, but also a mirror of Atlantas aspirations.

title: Fossil-Fuel Emissions by Country
description: The debate over how to address the effects of climate change intensified at a United Nations meeting, but determining each countrys responsibility is a complicated task.

title: A Russian GPS Using U.S. Soil Stirs Spy Fears
description: WASHINGTON  In the view of Americas spy services, the next potential threat from Russia may not come from a nefarious cyberweapon or secrets gleaned from the files of Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor now in Moscow.

title: William Weaver, Influential Translator of Modern Italian Literature, Dies at 90
description: William Weaver, whose translations of works by modern masters like Italo Calvino, Umberto Eco and Primo Levi helped lift Italian literature to prominence among readers of English, died on Tuesday in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 90.

title: How Do Hurricanes Happen?
description: We explain how hurricanes form  and grow  when cold and warm air merge.

title: Growing Clamor About Inequities of Climate Crisis
description: WARSAW  Following a devastating typhoon that killed thousands in the Philippines, a routine international climate change conference here turned into an emotional forum, with developing countries demanding compensation from the worst polluting countries for damage they say they are already suffering.

title: Relief Supplies Pour Into Philippines, but Remote Areas Still Suffer
description: QUINAPONDAN, the Philippines  Day after day, the mayor of this storm-shattered town makes the two-hour drive past flattened villages and splintered palm groves to the nearest functioning airport, where he begs for provisions from those who run the relief supply staging area for eastern Samar Island.

title: Joaqun Hernndez Galicia, Oil Workers Chief, Dies at 91
description: Joaqun Hernndez Galicia, a sometimes brutal Mexican power broker who earned the loyalty of his countrys vast army of oil workers as both their union boss and benevolent patriarch and who was later imprisoned, some say unjustly, died on Nov. 11 in Tampico, Mexico. He was 91.

title: Keith Bradsher Answers Readers Questions on the Philippines
description: Keith Bradsher, the Hong Kong bureau chief for The New York Times, has been reporting on the aftermath of the powerful typhoon that hit the Philippines on Nov. 8, mostly from Tacloban, the city that was flattened when the storm made landfall. Mr. Bradsher answered a selection of readers questions, submitted via Facebook and Twitter.

title: Life After Exoneration: Building a Business, and Helping Others
description: Christopher Scott planned it all from an uncomfortable state prison bed at the Coffield unit in East Texas, where he would kick back, listen to R & B and daydream:

title: A Legal Case Waits as Florida States Winston Drives Another Rout
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Jameis Winston walked into his postgame news conference Saturday night without the look of someone carrying a burden. His suit fit loosely, he wore flip-flops, his shirttail was out, and his smile was wide. He looked at ease as he sat in a metal folding chair surrounded by reporters.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 16, 2013
A Long Shot for Governor Is Suddenly a Presence in the Polls
description: She is barely a blip in the polls, and the odds of her securing the Republican nomination for Texas governor are viewed as vanishingly small. But Lisa Fritsch, a conservative activist, author and former radio show host, suddenly has bragging rights among second-tier candidates trying to make a respectable showing against the primary favorite, Attorney General Greg Abbott.

title: In Fracas on Health Coverage, Some Democrats Feel Exposed
description: CONCORD, N.H.  The awards ceremony on Friday evening for New Hampshires police forces was full of pomp (a bagpipe band in full Scottish regalia), circumstance (tales of heroism and tragedy told to standing ovations), officers in dress uniforms and a show of support from the states full congressional delegation.

title: Corrections: November 17, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Poses via Postcard Lead to Dances on the Stage
description: Theres a fine line between honoring the past and clinging to it.

title: She Wont Talk, but Everyone Else Does
description: Score one for sincerity.

title: Aleksandr Serebrov, 69, Dies; Cosmonaut Who Persevered
description: The Soviet Union led humanity into the heavens, sending the first satellite, man and woman into space, and all were duly celebrated by their country. The cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin, the first person to orbit the Earth, on April 12, 1961, received his nations highest award, Hero of the Soviet Union.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: CONNOR HALLIDAY The Washington State quarterback threw for 319 yards and 2 touchdowns to lead the Cougars to a 24-17 victory at Arizona. It was his seventh 300-yard passing game of the season.

title: In One County, the States Political Future
description: FOREST HILL  As she entered a Lubys on Monday morning in this Democratic enclave southeast of Fort Worth, State Senator Wendy Davis drew a warm welcome from the roughly 100 attendees at a Veterans Day breakfast. Ms. Davis, Democrat of Fort Worth, had filed to run for governor of Texas two days earlier. The sacrifices youve made on behalf of each of us will not be forgotten, she said. I will make sure to fight that we do a better job, a dramatically better job.

title: Looking Ahead, Perry Turns to the Middle
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Cant Tell the Players Apart? The Knicks Are the Ones Not Scoring
description: From afar, for much of Saturdays game, it was hard to tell the Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks apart, so analogous were their play, their body language and their attire.

Podolsky and Dr. Daniel K. Podolsky of Dallas. Rabbi David C. Kraemer officiated at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

Clark Brown, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the golf course at Pebble Beach Resorts in Pebble Beach, Calif.

description: Virginia Sharpe Wettlaufer, a daughter of Catherine Talley Wettlaufer of Buffalo and the late Conrad Penn Wettlaufer, was married Monday morning to Walter Scott Tomenson III, the son of Leslie A. Tomenson and Mr. Tomenson Jr. of the Village of Golf, Fla. Justice Donna M. Siwek of State Supreme Court in Buffalo officiated at the home of the brides mother and stepfather, Arthur J. Bronson.

Kaplan and Dr. Ronald B. Dennett of New York. Rabbi Marci Jacobs Aronchick officiated at the Chevy Chase Club in Chevy Chase, Md.

description: Diana Michelle Cornely, the daughter of Helen Zwiep Cornely and C. Michael Cornely of Palmetto Bay, Fla., was married in Brooklyn Saturday evening to Theodore Dayton Clement, a son of Sally Dayton Clement and Stephen M. Clement III of Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Lucy Forster-Smith, a Presbyterian minister, led the ceremony in the Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Pavilion and Lobby at the Brooklyn Museum.

description: Eliza Lindsay Gray, the daughter of C. Boyden Gray of Washington, was married Saturday to Nicholas Robert Summers, the son of K. C. Summers and Robert K. Summers of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Washington.

Fauth IV of Naples, Fla., was married there Saturday to Kevin Patrick Coleman Jr., a son of Lisa Cullen Coleman and Mr. Coleman of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Michael P. Basden performed the ceremony at Trinity by the Cove Episcopal Church, where he is the rector. The Rev. Leo J. ODonovan, a Roman Catholic priest and the former president of Georgetown University, took part.

title: Lauren Kay, Adam Soufleris
description: Lauren Elizabeth Kay and Adam Mark Soufleris were married Saturday by the Rev. J. Howard Edington, a Presbyterian minister, at the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Katina Pappas, Nicholas Dermatas
description: Katina Christopher Pappas and Nicholas Spyros Dermatas were married Saturday evening by the Rev. Michael J. Lambakis at the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Houston.

title: U.S.C. Erases Stanford From the National Title Picture
description: LOS ANGELES  As it turns out, a loss to Utah, once the lone blemish on Stanfords sterling rsum, will have little effect on sorting out the Bowl Championship Series title contenders over the final weeks of the regular season.

title: Nets, Missing Four Starters, Come Up Short Against Clippers
description: LOS ANGELES  Preventing mass attrition over an 82-game season was always expected to be a lofty challenge for the Nets, a very talented but veteran-heavy team. The injury bug, though, was probably not expected to bite so soon.

title: Hurdles Seen for Change to Chinas One-Child Rule
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese governments decision to relax a decades-old one-child limit on couples has already encountered two problems likely to test dozens of social and economic changes promised by President Xi Jinping  vagaries about implementation and magnified public expectations of even bigger changes ahead.

title: For Son of a Nazi-Era Dealer, a Private Life Amid a Tainted Trove of Art
description: MUNICH  As an expert in works of art that the Nazis called degenerate and in the dealers who traded them during World War II, Vanessa Voigt often wondered what had become of Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of a prominent Nazi-era art dealer and a figure she had come to view as a phantom.

title: With Great Reluctance, India Bids Farewell to Tendulkar
description: MUMBAI  The moment arrived shortly on the stroke of noon on Saturday, as the last West Indian batsman was dismissed at Wankhede Stadium  a moment that had gripped, and been dreaded, by a nation.

title: New Boeing Jet, 777X, Hits $95 Billion in Orders
description: Three Middle Eastern airlines signed up on Sunday to buy 225 of Boeings new 777X jets, helping to bring the initial batch of orders for the plane to $95 billion, a strong start for sales of the commercial jet.

title: My Father Didnt Know Best. How Will I?
description: Im sure he thought he was doing the right thing. Father knows best and all that. Or at least better than his 3-year-old son. And his 3-year-old son was afraid of the dark and had to get over it.

title: 9 Attackers and 2 Officers Reported Killed in Tense Western China
description: BEIJING  Nine assailants were shot and killed Saturday night after they tried to storm a police station in the restive western province of Xinjiang, the state-run Xinhua news agency and Radio Free Asia said. Two police officers also died in the attack.

title: Childhood Cancer Tied to Heart Risks
description: Children who undergo chemotherapy treatments for cancer have an increased risk of developing early heart disease, a new study suggests.

title: In Our Pages: November 18
description: 1888: Lack of pocket money pushed soldiers to suicide

title: U.S. Military Considers a Mission to Train Libyan Security Forces
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  The United States military is considering a mission to train Libyan security personnel with the goal of creating a force of 5,000 to 7,000 conventional soldiers and a separate, smaller unit for specialized counterterrorism missions, according to the top officer at the United States Special Operations Command.

title: Exiting President Reflects on Georgia
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Mikheil Saakashvili, now the former president of Georgia, was still working his famously late nights, apparently intent on squeezing every last minute from the final days of his term. In an interview late last month that began after midnight and could well have stretched until dawn, Mr. Saakashvili boasted that in his decade in office, Georgia had made huge strides toward becoming an established democracy. He profanely dismissed allegations of heavy-handedness and authoritarian abuses, and voiced regret that he had not spent more money on education and less on weapons.

title: Doris Lessing, Author Who Swept Aside Convention, Is Dead at 94
description: Doris Lessing, the uninhibited and outspoken novelist who won the 2007 Nobel Prize for a lifetime of writing that shattered convention, both social and artistic, died on Sunday at her home in London. She was 94.

title: Disruptions: A Digital Underworld Cloaked in Anonymity
description: SAN FRANCISCO  So this is where they collared the man they call the Dread Pirate Roberts.

title: Once a Temple of Corruption, Now a Landmark
description: Tammany Hall is history. Shortly before a Democrat was elected mayor for the first time in 24 years, the former headquarters of the Manhattan Democratic Party organization was declared an official New York City landmark.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Svbscription Luxury Parcel Service
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Me Too! Blogging
description: Aha. I thought Id been saying something quite a lot like Larry Summerss remarks at the IMF conference. But these days I write so much that I have trouble keeping up myself.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 3 P.M. (MTV) CLUELESS (1995) Alicia Silverstone (above left, with Stacey Dash) plays a Beverly Hills teenager who doubles as a matchmaker and a makeover expert for the new girl in school (Brittany Murphy), much to the chagrin of her strait-laced stepbrother (Paul Rudd) in this comedy written and directed by Amy Heckerling. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said that Ms. Silverstone makes a delectable teen queen in Clueless, a candy-colored, brightly satirical showcase for her decidedly visual talents. Ms. Heckerling finds herself on friendly territory with the worst Californian academic talent this side of Ridgemont High, Ms. Maslin wrote. Surfer burnouts held center stage in that earlier comedy of Ms. Heckerlings, but this time she has gone hilariously upscale.

title: Philippine Community Groups Fill Vacuum in Typhoons Aftermath
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Ofelia Casio could be called the mayor of the Tacloban City Convention Center. She was not elected to the position, but there is not much competition for the job.

title: Best Man Has Strong Start at Box Office, but Cant Overpower Thor
description: Demonstrating the importance of the right release date, The Best Man Holiday radically outdid expectations over the weekend to take in about $30.6 million at North American theaters. Universal Pictures, which spent about $17 million to make the R-rated comedy, had hoped for an opening of around $20 million.

title: Doris Lessing Has Died
description: Here. Yes, I had a cat named after her (and I just found myself crying thinking about that small loss); I like to think that Lessing, a cat lover, would have approved.

title: What To Do When Youre Wrong
description: Barry Ritholtz reminds us that weve just passed the third anniversary of the debasement-and-inflation letter  the one in which a whos who of right-wing econopundits warned that quantitative easing would have dire consequences. As Ritholtz notes, they were utterly wrong. Also, rereading the letter now, you have to wonder what kind of economic model they had in mind. They asserted that

title: Dispute Over Gay Marriage Erupts in Cheney Family
description: Updated, 10:09 p.m. | WASHINGTON  They were the towheaded sisters who tagged along on campaigns, polite and smiling, as their father rose through Wyoming and then Washington politics to become one of the most powerful men in the country.

title: Bloomberg News Suspends Reporter Whose Article on China Was Not Published
description: BEIJING  A reporter for Bloomberg News who worked on an unpublished article about China, which employees for the company said had been killed for political reasons by top Bloomberg editors, was suspended last week by managers.

title: Doris Lessing on the Nobel Prize
description: When reporters in 2007 told Ms. Lessing that she had won the Nobel Prize for literature, she said, I couldnt care less.

title: Passenger Jet Crash in City East of Moscow Kills 50
description: MOSCOW  A passenger jet crashed Sunday evening while landing in Kazan, a regional capital east of Moscow, killing all 50 people on board, emergency officials said.

title: Guerrilla Group Says It Killed 2 From a Greek Extremist Party in an Athens Suburb
description: ATHENS  A previously unknown guerrilla group has claimed responsibility for killing two members of Greeces neofascist party Golden Dawn this month and has threatened more attacks against the party.

title: PlayStation 4 Starts Strong Despite Reports of Defects
description: Sonys latest video game console, the PlayStation 4, hit the market with a bang, even as the company said it was investigating reports of defective consoles.

title: Shifting Gears to Explore the Realm of the Oboe
description: Rarely will I spare a thought for a different orchestra while awaiting a performance by the New York Philharmonic. Comparisons are pointless; best to be fully in the moment. Still, glancing through the program notes before a Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, I couldnt help but reflect on the state of the Minnesota Orchestra, now locked in an acrimonious, costly conflict between management and players.

title: 50 Years Matter, Even to a Time Lord
description: On Nov. 23, 1963, a Time Lord from the planet Gallifrey landed his blue police box in a British junkyard, and the universe has never been the same. This week, the BBC celebrates the 50th anniversary of Doctor Who, ranked as the most successful science-fiction television series by Guinness World Records, as it prepares for the arrival of the Twelfth Doctor (Peter Capaldi) in this years Christmas special.

title: The Commentary of Found Objects
description: Over the past decade and more, the sculptural assemblages of the German artist Isa Genzken have become fixtures on the international circuit  and deservedly so.

title: Kanye Wests Torment, Onstage
description: A reading from the Gospel according to John: In the world ye shall have tribulation: but be of good cheer; I have overcome the world. It wouldnt be a stretch to see somebody hawking that verse on a T-shirt outside Kanye Wests irreverent Yeezus tour, which stops in New York this week.

title: One Composer, Two Boroughs
description: Embracing a landscape where cross-genre collaboration is the rule, the contemporary chamber music series Ear Heart Music continues its season at Roulette on Monday with the Brooklyn dance company Skybetter & Associates, joined by the new Ear Heart Music Ensemble in works set to music by Johann Johannsson, Henryk Gorecki and David Lang. (8 p.m., 509 Atlantic Avenue, near Third Avenue, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, roulette.org, 917-267-0363.)

title: Gathering What Another Spills
description: The image of people scavenging in trash heaps to survive has enticed documentarians before and resulted in memorable films like Lucy Walkers Waste Land, about a dump outside Rio de Janeiro. But Good Garbage, which shows on Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan as part of the Other Israel Film Festival, has an added dimension. The dump pickers it looks in on are Palestinians from the city of Yatta, and the trash heap they work, in the Hebron Hills, includes the discards of more prosperous Israelis.

title: An Ode to Joy, Choreographically
description: Mark Morris created LAllegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato during the three years his company was resident at the Thtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels. It was 1988, he was 32 and, for the first time, had an 1,100-seat opera house, an orchestra and a costume department at his disposal. He used it all with relish. LAllegro, which returns to Lincoln Center this week, wasnt immediately acclaimed by the local critics. (Mr. Morriss biographer, Joan Acocella, quotes one review: Where is the profundity?) But it has become Mr. Morriss most famous piece, celebrated for its innocence, exuberance and how it suggests the physical embodiment of ideal worlds. The work is set to the 1740 Handel oratorio from which it takes its title, and which uses the texts of Miltons LAllegro and Il Penseroso, portraits of the joyful and contemplative minds. Filled with nymphs and shepherds, gods and humans, hunters and lovers, the dance is beautiful, lavish and funny. It is, as Ms. Acocella writes, a hymn to the unity of poetry, music and dance. (7:30 p.m. Thursday to Saturday, David H. Koch Theater, 212-496-0600, davidhkochtheater.com.)

title: Ravaged Philippine City Ponders a Grim Road Ahead
description: GUIUAN, the Philippines  The Swedish Air Force brought German relief workers. The Australians delivered hulking pallets of water and food. The United States Navy dispatched so many supplies-laden Ospreys, Seahawks and C-130s on Sunday that the commanding officer in charge of the airport here lost count.

title: A New Home for Recycling
description: A look inside the new Sims Municipal Recycling Facility in Brooklyn.

title: A Grace Note for a Gritty Business
description: Recycling in New York is a scrappy business. Billions have gone toward building water tunnels, power plants, subways and sewage treatment facilities, but little toward an infrastructure of recycling. In turn, New Yorkers have been slow to separate bottles and cans the way they flip a light switch or swipe a MetroCard: Recycling remains less an everyday fact of life than a do-good option, like tipping the mail carrier at the holidays.

title: On the Ark, Two by Two, Creatures (and Performers) Great and Small
description: Benjamin Britten loved composing pieces for children, not just for children to enjoy but also to perform. There is no better example that Noyes Fludde (Noahs Flood), a 60-minute opera based on a 15th-century mystery play, written for amateurs, especially children, with professionals mixed in. This telling of the biblical story was first performed in 1958 at Orford Church in Suffolk, England. It was presented as part of Brittens Aldeburgh Festival with artists from the English Opera Group along with a large local cast, including a childrens choir.

title: Scores of Tornadoes Slam Midwest States
description: Severe storms moved through the Midwest on Sunday, leveling towns, killing at least six people in Illinois and injuring dozens more, and causing thousands of power failures across the region.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Element of Surprise
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Washington Insurance Official Is Ousted
description: The insurance commissioner for the District of Columbia was dismissed from his job just a day after he publicly questioned a decision by President Obama to reverse a provision of the Affordable Care Act, a person with knowledge of the events said on Sunday.

title: After Night of Fun and Games, Jets Find Game Is No Fun
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  The night before the Jets first game in two weeks, Coach Rex Ryan addressed his players and canceled their offensive and defensive meetings. He had a surprise: a trip to Dave & Busters for some arcade fun.

title: Bitcoin Scandal Reflects Popularity of Virtual Currency in China
description: On Oct. 26, the website of Global Bond Limited, a Chinese exchange platform for bitcoins, the booming digital currency, suddenly went dead. Then, without warning, GBLs roughly 500 remaining investors were kicked out of the companys official QQ group, a social media platform that the company was using for investor relations. By nightfall, the scale of the swindle was made public  25 million renminbi, or $4.1 million  making it one of the largest bitcoin fraud cases since the currencys inception four years ago.

title: Playing in Six Hearts After West Leads a Diamond
description: Some players have an eye for a good deal for a column. One is Karen Allison of Las Vegas, a winner of five national championships and a silver medal in the 1994 McConnell World Womens Teams Championship.

title: Carol Channing to Celebrate Hello, Dolly! Anniversary
description: Carol Channing, above, is set to return for a one-night engagement commemorating the 50th anniversary of the opening of Hello, Dolly! The events producer, Daniel Nardicio, announced on Sunday that the transgender performer Justin Vivian Bond would host the celebration on Jan. 20 at Town Hall in Manhattan, and that it would include filmed celebrity tributes, footage from Ms. Channings career and video questions submitted in advance. Tickets go on sale on Monday. Ms. Channing, 92, was previously interviewed by Mr. Bond in August at the Ice Palace in Cherry Grove, on Fire Island, as part of Mr. Nardicios Icon Series.

title: A Rookie Going Through Initiation With the Nets Is Proving to Be an Inspiration
description: LOS ANGELES  With reporters crammed around him, the Nets rookie Mason Plumlee was a dozen words into his first response when the discussion was punctured from afar.

title: A Glittery Prelude to Oscars Big Night
description: LOS ANGELES  Dark horses. Underdogs. Some who would be thrilled just for a nomination.

title: Warnings of New Turmoil as Pakistan Pursues a Treason Case for Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans government said Sunday that it was initiating a treason prosecution of the countrys former ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, in what would be a groundbreaking, if politically charged, assertion of civilian supremacy over the powerful Pakistani military.

title: Turning Sleuth, With Reliable Dog in Tow
description: Theresa Schwegel is an Edgar-winning crime writer whose Chicago police stories are more nuanced and impassioned than most books of their genre. None of that has brought her much attention, and neither will the nondescript title of her fifth novel, The Good Boy  until readers figure out what it means. The story is well-woven enough to contain three contenders for Good Boy honors.

title: Bacardi Campaign Focuses on Resilience, Rather Than Rum
description: IT is the time of the year when Bacardi typically promotes its recipe for holiday punch, but a new advertising campaign is instead promoting how the rum brand rolls with the punches.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 18
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Optimism Outlasted a Lifetime of Horrors
description: The Czech writer Ivan Klimas new book, a memoir, is called My Crazy Century. It begins in 1941, when together with his family Mr. Klima, who until then hadnt even been aware that he was Jewish, was imprisoned in the Nazi camp at Terezin, and it concludes with the Velvet Revolution of 1989, ending years of dictatorship and repression. Sometimes, it was funny crazy, Mr. Klima said last week, while visiting New York. But mostly, it was crazy crazy.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 18
description: SAC TRIAL Jury selection is scheduled to begin Tuesday in the trial of Michael S. Steinberg, the most senior employee at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors indicted in insider trading. Federal prosecutors have accused Mr. Steinberg of trading on secret information about technology companies. Though SAC has been at the center of the governments insider trading investigation for years, Mr. Steinberg is the first former SAC employee to stand trial. Six others, including the fund itself, have pleaded guilty.

title: A Kentucky Singer Faces Down a Manhattan Crowd
description: There is no end to the variety of night life in New York, but it remains an open question whether this city could ever be home to a genuine honky-tonk. Native to the South, that would be loosely defined as part bar, part performance venue, part staging ground for a battle royal. The music matters, but its only one element of the tapestry.

title: A Love Affair That Burned for Centuries, at Least in Song
description: At a concert of late medieval and early Renaissance vocal music presented in a church, you might expect to hear churchy music. And there was much of that in the second half of the Orlando Consorts program at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square on Saturday evening, presented by the Miller Theater.

title: History Comes to Life With Tweets From Past
description: LIKE watching a building collapse in slow motion, a Twitter account run by a group of German historians provides hour-by-hour updates of the horrors of Kristallnacht, which culminated in a night of anti-Jewish terror 75 years ago in Nazi Germany that plunged the country on a path to the Holocaust.

title: Tapping Unseen Forces in the Dungeon
description: The Underground Theater at the Abrons Arts Center often goes by affectionate characterizations like dungeon and cave. Its subterranean aura, murky lighting and pockmarked concrete walls ensure that whatever happens will seem a little bit creepy. So it was a fitting location for Arturo Vidichs 142241, a duet (or quartet, if you count the audience participants) that attempted, as a news release put it, to tune in to the invisible worlds that influence this world, if you believe in that sort of thing.

title: To the Sounds of Stevie Wonder, a Dance Baptism for a New Theater
description: BRIC House, the snazzily redesigned headquarters of BRIC, the venerable Brooklyn arts organization, opened last month, but it wasnt until Wednesday night that the buildings flexible performance space had its first dance show. There couldnt have been a better first choice than the Brooklyn company of Ronald K. Brown. This is dancing that consecrates. The warmth and artistry and infectious joy made this house into a home.

title: Put Another Layer On
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Greetings! Did everyone have a good week? Thanks again to Tom Trust Me, Hes Dapper Gaffney for the chance to take some much-needed R&R.

title: Offense, Not Defense, May Be the Knicks Biggest Concern
description: Ever since the Knicks elevated Mike Woodson to head coach after the March 2012 dismissal of Mike DAntoni, Woodson has preached defense, toughness and rebounding. These are terms that resonate with Knicks fans, who cherished the gritty success of the teams led by Pat Riley and Jeff Van Gundy. After a 110-90 home loss to the Atlanta Hawks on Saturday, Woodson and the Knicks returned to the theme of defensive identity.

title: Former President of Chile Poised to Regain Her Seat
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Michelle Bachelet, who was president of Chile from 2006 to 2010, far outpolled her opponents for the office in the general election on Sunday, after campaigning on promises of major changes in education, health, social security and taxes. But she fell short of the majority needed to avoid a runoff election in December.

title: In the Maelstrom of Harlems Gentrification, and Nothing Is Sacred
description: We should not like Napoleon, a vicious Harlem landlord.

title: How I Met Your Mother to Get a CBS Spinoff
description: The CBS comedy How I Met Your Mother may be ending this spring, but the show could continue at least in spirit: CBS has ordered a pilot for a spinoff, How I Met Your Dad. The development was first reported by Deadline.com and was confirmed by the series creators Carter Bays and Craig Thomas on their Twitter feeds. Mr. Bays said the show would feature a new setting and new characters. The pilot will put a female spin on the original concept and is to be written by Emily Spivey, who created the NBC comedy Up All Night. Its no surprise that CBS want to keep How I Met Your Mother going in some form. The ninth and final season has averaged 8.2 million total viewers this fall and has remained among the 10 highest-rated broadcast programs in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the category most cherished by advertisers. It is also the third highest-rated comedy in that demographic, finishing behind only The Big Bang Theory on CBS and Modern Family on ABC.

title: Fresh Life via Netflix for The Killing
description: The Killing, the twice-canceled AMC cop drama, has been renewed  this time by Netflix  for a fourth season. Netflix announced that this six-episode season would be a streaming exclusive and would be made available simultaneously around the world; AMC is not involved in the deal. The first three seasons are already available on Netflix, and the company said that the fourth would be the last one. The principal creative team and cast are set to return, including the series creator and show runner, Veena Sud, and its stars Mireille Enos and Joel Kinnaman. The Killing was canceled by AMC for the first time in July 2012 after its second season, but it was resurrected in January for a third season. It returned with little fanfare both critically and in the ratings  the last three episodes of Season 3 on AMC hovered around 1.5 million total viewers  and was promptly canceled again in September. The Killing was originally based on the Danish series Forbrydelsen.

title: Facebook, Still Dominant, Strives to Keep Cachet
description: When Evan Spiegel peered into a crystal ball to divine a future for his company, Snapchat, he did not see Facebook.

title: A Tiny Label Is Behind an a Cappella Groups Success
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  If you stopped 100 people on the manicured Sony Pictures lot here and asked them to point you toward Shelly Bunges office, they would most likely give you the same blank stare. Who?

title: Larger Prize for Tucker Award
description: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation said on Sunday that it had increased the size of the cash prize given to the winner of the annual Richard Tucker Award to $50,000 from $30,000. As previously announced, the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard is the 2013 recipient at the ceremony, scheduled for Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center; this year is the centenary of Tuckers birth. The award goes to an artist considered on the verge of a major international career. Ms. Leonard is a regular at the Metropolitan Opera and has recently performed in productions of Mozarts Cos Fan Tutte and Poulencs Dialogues of the Carmelites.

title: Disney Struggles to Make Its Free Gaming Apps Pay
description: LOS ANGELES  Two months ago, Disney released a sequel to Wheres My Water?, a hit smartphone game about a showering alligator. Hopes were high: Disney had pointed to the original game as evidence of overdue traction in mobile gaming.

title: In Charge of the Macys Parade, but Not the Thanksgiving Dinner
description: Amy Kule spent a couple of afternoons with Maureen OHara in the late 1990s.

title: A Lesson From Cuba on Race
description: In a recent article for The Stone, Gary Gutting posed a challenge. He urged readers to look past the outrage on race provoked by the Trayvon Martin case and to focus on what he aptly described as the deeper issue that sustains the edifice of racial inequality our unjust economic system. Under this system, people compete for basic goods and services in what seems to be a fair and non-discriminating market. But since they enter this market from vastly different social circumstances, competition is anything but fair. Those who already possess goods have a much better chance of renewing their access to them, whereas those who dont have little chance of ever getting them.

title: The Real Mayors of New York
description: Voters elected Bill de Blasio, but New York has always been a city of unofficial mayors.

title: Suzanne Bianchi, 61, Who Analyzed Family Time, Dies
description: Suzanne M. Bianchi, a social scientist who explored the changing landscape of late-20th-century American families, tracing how divorce, the shrinking gender gap and womens careers affected children, parents and their households (Is Anyone Doing the Housework? was the title of one of her papers), died on Nov. 4 in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 61.

title: Estimating Risk
description: New guidelines recommend statins for people whose risk of a heart attack or stroke in the next 10 years is 7.5 percent or higher. But calculators to estimate a persons 10-year risk may overestimate the actual risk of heart attack or stroke, according to an analysis of three large studies.

title: At 70, Still Fighting to Live Independently
description: James Leak turned 70 last week, but he only recently started learning to read and write.

title: Afghan Talks at Impasse Before Vote, Officials Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite recent optimism about talks over a future American military presence here, two senior Afghan officials said on Sunday that the negotiations were at a profound impasse, days before an Afghan grand council is scheduled to meet to seek popular support for a deal.

title: Extension of Benefits for Jobless Is Set to End
description: WASHINGTON  Unless Congress acts, during the last week of December an estimated 1.3 million people will lose access to an emergency program providing them with additional weeks of jobless benefits. A further 850,000 will be denied benefits in the first quarter of 2014.

title: Rescuing the Philippines
description: Aid to typhoon victims comes in at a trickle.

title: An Inadvertent Paean to Jerry Bruckheimer, From the Studio That Ousted Him
description: LOS ANGELES  Its not just a matter of size, though a new coffee-table retrospective of Jerry Bruckheimers film and television career  Jerry Bruckheimer: When Lightning Strikes, Four Decades of Filmmaking  certainly has heft.

title: Pressure Builds to Finish Volcker Rule on Wall St. Oversight
description: The Obama administration, currently stumbling through the health care overhaul, has reached a critical stage in its other signature effort: reining in Wall Street.

title: Vote on Alcohol Sales Divides a Utah Town Where Few Drink
description: HYDE PARK, Utah  When a convenience store chain approached city officials here last year about selling beer, people knew a fight was coming.

title: From Winless Start to Winning Streak, Giants Have Climbed Back Into Division Race
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants had a fourth-quarter lead but Green Bay had whittled the edge to a single touchdown. As the Packers offense took over again, a tension was developing inside MetLife Stadium, the kind of unease that has dogged a season that began with comprehensive, aggregate failure.

title: The Lasting Legacy of John F. Kennedy
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Path
description: Amanda Rogers, 32, became addicted to painkillers after both her mother and stepfather died from overdoses. Now, she is stable in her recovery and taking buprenorphine daily.

title: Todd Smith
description: Todd Smith on taking buprenorphine after an addiction to painkillers.

title: N.B.A. Will Try to Avoid Repeat of Fashion Faux Pas at Garden
description: It did not take long on Saturday night for fans and commentators at Madison Square Garden to realize something was amiss between the Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks. Their uniforms looked alike. Too alike.

title: The Existential Stress of Waiting for ...
Joellen Trippett
description: In a therapy session at Chestnut Ridge, Joellen Trippett explains how her life has changed since becoming a buprenorphine patient and why she never wants to return to a life of addiction.

title: Dr. Carl R. Sullivan III
description: Dr. Sullivan explaining how he gauges a patients recovery.

title: Sea Level Rise in Florida
description: To the Editor:

title: At Forums, New York State Education Commissioner Faces a Barrage of Complaints
description: He has been shushed, booed, called imperious and mocked as the incomprehensible teacher who bleated on and on in Charlie Browns classroom.

title: Hypocrisy About Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Who Are Lawyers: Expectations and Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Allan Clark
description: Dr. Allan Clark discussing how his experience with addiction has helped him relate to his patients.

title: At Clinics, Tumultuous Lives and Turbulent Care
description: PITTSBURGH  The patient is an addict. His doctor is an addict, too. Over the last decade, both men hit their own versions of rock bottom. For the patient, it was the concrete floor of a jail where he writhed in withdrawal. For the doctor, it was the food stamp office where, his career as a child psychiatrist in tatters, he ashamedly sought help.

title: Developing a Fax Machine to Copy Life on Mars
description: MOJAVE NATIONAL PRESERVE, Calif.  J. Craig Venter, the maverick scientist, is looking for a new world to conquer  Mars. He wants to detect life on Mars and bring it to Earth using a device called a digital biological converter, or biological teleporter.

title: Toy Story
description: MY model American entrepreneur of the moment is Cheong Choon Ng. He has not attracted a $3 billion bid from Facebook, like the young inventors of the photo-sharing service Snapchat. Wall Street is not cooking up an I.P.O. But Ng is a star in my household. He is the creator of the Rainbow Loom, which in the middle-schooler market is the hottest device not called iSomething. If you have noticed that half the children in America  and a fair number of adults  seem to be sporting bracelets that are braids of brightly colored rubber bands, then you have seen the fruits of the Rainbow Loom.

title: Crashing the Boards and Cracking the Books
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Her Olympic hopes seemingly extinguished, Kate Buessers idea of mucking it up in the corners involved a lobster boat, not hockey.

title: West Faces Challenge in Moving Syrian Chemical Arms Through Battlefields
description: WASHINGTON  A plan announced over the weekend for getting the bulk of Syrias chemical weapons out of the country in coming weeks has raised major concerns in Washington, because it involves transporting the weapons over roads that are battlegrounds in the countrys civil war and loading them onto a ship that has no place to go.

title: A Permanent Slump?
description: Spend any time around monetary officials and one word youll hear a lot is normalization. Most though not all such officials accept that now is no time to be tightfisted, that for the time being credit must be easy and interest rates low. Still, the men in dark suits look forward eagerly to the day when they can go back to their usual job, snatching away the punch bowl whenever the party gets going.

title: Week After Shooting, Life Goes On at Bryant Park
description: The line outside the Bryant Park skating rink on Saturday night was at least 100 deep, the soon-to-be skaters waiting their turn as a seemingly endless flow of people circumambulated the ice, racing, kissing, all bathed in a pink light.

title: At U.S.C., the Cookie Doesnt Crumble; It Bonds
description: LOS ANGELES  It started with dessert. When Ed Orgeron stepped in as the interim coach at Southern California after Lane Kiffin was fired in late September, one of the first moves he made was restoring sweets to the football teams training table.

title: Lincolns Sound Bite: Have Faith in Democracy
description: The surprisingly short story of the Gettysburg Address is that it was a surprisingly short speech  270 words or so  delivered by Abraham Lincoln as part of the dedication ceremonies for the Soldiers National Cemetery at Gettysburg, on Nov. 19, 1863, four and a half months after the climactic battle of the American Civil War.

title: Where St. Nicholas Has His Black Pete(s), Charges of Racism Follow
description: AMSTERDAM  St. Nicholas entered Amsterdam twice this weekend.

title: Lesson Is Seen in Failure of Law on Medicare in 1989
description: WASHINGTON  Angry Americans voice outrage at being asked to pay more for health coverage. Lawmakers and the White House say the public just doesnt appreciate the benefits of the new health law. Opponents clamor for repeal before the program fully kicks in.

title: For Assaulted Veterans, a Second Battle
description: For military veterans, the trauma of rape, sexual assault or sexual harassment can be as devastating as combat wounds. But these injuries, while real, are often invisible, and the circumstances behind them shrouded in secrecy and denial. The men and women who endure such crimes often have to fight a second battle, to convince the Department of Veterans Affairs that they are disabled and entitled to compensation for post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety and other afflictions resulting from service-connected sexual violence.

title: A Deep-Water Diver From Brooklyn Dies After Trying for a Record
description: LONG ISLAND, Bahamas  As Nicholas Mevoli lay on his back, floating in the azure sea, attempting to relax, his exhales were audible. The countdown had begun, and he prepared to dive into Deans Blue Hole, hoping to reach 72 meters on a single inhalation, with no fins or supplemental oxygen. He began sipping the air, attempting to pack as much oxygen in his lungs as possible.

title: Popular Demand
description: For most cooks, Thanksgiving is the most complicated meal of the year.

title: Lincoln at Gettysburg Long Ago
description: Garry Wills once wrote that all modern political prose descends from the Gettysburg Address, which was read aloud by a bareheaded man, exhausted and ill, before a black-suited crowd 150 years ago. Mr. Wills chose the right word: descends. Lincolns speech is the pinnacle of American civic utterance. His words honoring the dead at Gettysburg on Nov. 19, 1863, do what words are only rarely able to do. They invoke an eloquent silence.

title: Libyan Official Abducted Amid Unrest in Capital
description: CAIRO  The deputy chief of Libyas intelligence service was abducted from the parking lot of the airport in Tripoli on Sunday afternoon as a standoff between militias and a general strike against militia rule virtually shut down the city.

title: Princeton University Considers Use of Foreign Meningitis Vaccine
description: Fearing the spread of a meningitis outbreak that has caused seven people at Princeton University to be hospitalized this year, university officials have warned students to stop sharing drinks and to avoid kissing. Bright orange posters urge students to keep healthy and carry on, and red cups labeled Mine. Not Yours serve as reminders not to share drinks at parties.

title: The Shame of American Health Care
description: Even as Americans struggle with the changes required by health care reform, an international survey released last week by the Commonwealth Fund, a research organization, shows why change is so necessary.

title: Thailands Latest Troubles
description: Thailand is again on the verge of political turmoil. An ill-conceived amnesty bill pushed through the lower house of Parliament by Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra earlier this month brought many thousands of demonstrators for and against the government into the streets of Bangkok, putting the countrys fragile democracy in peril.

title: Bomb at Base Kills at Least 31 Syrian Troops
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At least 31 Syrian troops, including four senior officers, were killed on Sunday in a bombing that collapsed a building on a government military base just north of Damascus, the Syrian capital, an antigovernment monitoring group said. It was one of the deadliest attacks on government soldiers in recent months.

title: Just for Chiefs Fans, a Welcome Taste of Kansas City in Queens
description: Few bar-stool debates are more tiresome than arguments over which teams fans have suffered the most. But its hard to imagine a season much worse than the one Kansas City Chiefs fans endured last year. On the field, the team had the N.F.L.s worst record; off it, a starting linebacker killed his girlfriend before shooting himself in front of the coach and general manager.

title: Design Contest Seeks Just the Right Chair for Battery Park
description: One looks like a pale blue flower with five round petals. Another evokes a piece of playground equipment. A third shape shifts as needed  upright chair one direction, chaise longue the other. They are designs for a movable, stackable, weatherproof chair, one of which will eventually grace a new three-acre green at the Battery, the 22-acre park at the tip of Lower Manhattan.

title: Dozens Are Killed in Iraq Bombings
description: BAGHDAD  Explosions targeting public markets and security checkpoints killed 44 people across Iraq on Sunday, including 20 in a northern Turkmen-dominated city, and wounded over 100, police and medical officials said.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Risk Calculator for Cholesterol Appears Flawed
description: Last week, the nations leading heart organizations released a sweeping new set of guidelines for lowering cholesterol, along with an online calculator meant to help doctors assess risks and treatment options. But, in a major embarrassment to the health groups, the calculator appears to greatly overestimate risk, so much so that it could mistakenly suggest that millions more people are candidates for statin drugs.

title: Bumping Off Kin, a Song in Your Heart
description: Serial killers may be all the rage on bookshelves and television screens  so ubiquitous, youd think they made up a major demographic of the world population  but they are comparatively rare in the peppier precincts of musical theater. Now, after a long dry spell, Broadway has a deadly sociopath to call its own. Please give a hearty welcome to Monty Navarro, the conniving killer who helps turn murder most foul into entertainment most merry in the new musical A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 17, 2013
The Revolution Will Have Live Music
description: Among the shouts and chants from a picket line on the Upper East Side on a recent evening were a few sounds of a less discordant nature: the thump of a bass drum, the toot of a trombone, the melodious drone of a clarinet.

title: Inland, No Aid for Survivors of Typhoon
description: JARO, Philippines  Even as a major international aid effort has begun to take hold around the coastal city of Tacloban, the situation grimly differs just a few miles inland, where large numbers of injured or sick people in interior villages shattered by Typhoon Haiyan more than a week ago have received no assistance.

title: When Medical Experts Disagree
Start-Up Leaders Recall Choice to Cash In or Stay Independent
description: Nine start-up founders recounted the moment they had to decide whether to sell or stay independent  when the money was on the table and the future was unpredictable.

title: Rangers Have Lots of Chances but Dont Capitalize on Any of Them
description: For all their strong play of late, the Rangers still have trouble beating good teams. Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, they took 37 shots against the Los Angeles Kings and sometimes dominated the game. But they could not produce a goal against the Kings, the 2012 Stanley Cup champions, despite having two separate two-man advantages, and lost, 1-0.

title: French Leader Assures Israel He Will Keep Pressure on Iran
description: JERUSALEM  As France and other world powers prepared to resume talks with Iran this week on its disputed nuclear program, the French president, Franois Hollande, arrived in Israel on Sunday for a three-day visit and was warmly embraced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has been conducting a lonely campaign against a deal he calls bad and dangerous.

title: Pakistan Has Export Plans for Jet Fighter Produced With China
description: The market for the JF-17 fighter appears to be expanding in unexpected ways. At the Dubai Airshow, which opened on Sunday, the Pakistan Aeronautical Complex had a freshly minted example on display, complete with an array of Chinese-made missiles and bombs.

title: Giants-Packers Replay, Nov. 17
description: A look at the Giants 27-13 victory over the Green Bay Packers at MetLife Stadium.

title: Inequalitys Roots: Beyond Technology
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: A Pain Thats Hard to Discuss
description: Anal fissures are not exactly a topic for cocktail party conversation, and the reluctance to discuss them often leaves sufferers thinking they are the only ones affected.

title: Word of the Day | capillary
description: capillary \ka-p-ler-e, -le-re\ noun and adjective

title: Whats on Monday
description: 1 P.M. (TMC) THE FRIGHTENERS (1996) Michael J. Fox, left, stars as Frank Bannister, a private detective who can see and interact with ghosts in this spook fest directed by Peter Jackson. Frank normally uses his paranormal skills to cheat the unsuspecting people of a small town out of their money. But when he is blamed for a series of mysterious deaths, he searches for the real killer and ends up face to face with the grim reaper. With material for a half-dozen different movies here, Mr. Jackson has no trouble keeping The Frighteners spinning, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Phantoms skitter across the screen in record numbers, and Mr. Fox presides over the story with dependable skill.

title: Narendra Modi Casts B.J.P. as Tech-Friendly Party During Bangalore Rally
description: BANGALORE  In his first campaign stop in southern India, Narendra Modi, the opposition candidate for prime minister, appealed to voters in this outsourcing hub on Sunday by characterizing his Bharatiya Janata Party as the champion of information technology and the governing Congress Party as the enemy of social media.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 10-16
description: Portraits of athletes during competition that capture the nature of their sports and the individuals personalities.

title: Manning and Broncos Hand Chiefs First Defeat
description: DENVER  Two months ago, nobody thought the Denver Broncos and the Kansas City Chiefs would be on a collision course toward a midseason showdown with sole possession of the A.F.C. West lead on the line.

description: With local governments greatly diminished, churches, community groups and individuals have expanded their roles to help typhoon victims.

title: Week 11 N.F.L. Quick Hits: Paytons Faith in Saints Defense
description: Saints 23, 49ers 20

title: Death of Pragmatic Leader Further Muddles Syrian Rebellion
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  He was a Syrian rebel commander who led homegrown fighters like himself and had a prescient view of the conflict: a Syrian insurgency with nowhere else to turn, he said nearly a year ago, would tilt toward foreign fighters and Al Qaeda.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Are You Ready for Some Earplugs?

title: Celebrating Elsa Schiaparelli
description: PARIS  I would come in and she would be in her bed, with all these heart-shaped, shocking pink pillows, the actress Marisa Berenson said about her grandmother Elsa Schiaparelli, the great couturier of the 1930s. She had beautiful skin and beautiful shoulders and sexy nighties that were all embroidered.

title: How Good Are You at Waiting for What You Really Want?
description: A cookie before dinner, news that is sure to affect your future, an invitation to spend time with a new friend or love interest: it can be hard to wait for the things you want.

title: Bill Gates Cant Build a Toilet
description: IN addition to eradicating polio in India and starting the personal computer revolution, the Seattle Superman of our age has managed to make going to the bathroom a cause clbre. Five years ago, if Id told people I worked on toilets, they would have surely assumed I was a plumber. Now, they exclaim: Oh! Isnt Bill Gates into that?

title: Challenge for the Government: 4 Million Are Displaced, and Hunger Grows
description: BASEY, the Philippines  When Typhoon Haiyan hit this coastal town, residents ran for Saint Michael the Archangel Church. Now, 10 days later, more than 100 of them remain.

title: Lloyds Bank to Sell Asset Management Unit for $1.06 Billion
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its asset management arm to Aberdeen Asset Management in stock and cash deal worth up to 660 million pounds, or $1.06 billion.
