description: Updated, 5:30 p.m. | Luke Mogelson, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about Afghan and Iranian migrants attempting to reach Australia from Indonesia by boat. He last wrote for the magazine on the Afghan National Army. He is the co-founder and editor of an online magazine called Razistan.

title: The Sleeper Cell That Wasnt
description: Six days after 9/11, the F.B.I.s raid on a Detroit sleeper cell signaled Americas resolve to fight terrorism. But, despite a celebrated conviction, there was one problem  theyd gotten it wrong.

title: The Demise and Afterlife of the Detroit Sleeper Cell Case
description: This weeks Retro Report video tells the story of the Detroit Sleeper Cell, the first terrorism trial after 9/11. Here, a reporter who covers terrorism for The Times recalls the charged atmosphere at the time and the consequences for the Justice Department.

title: Hooligans, Hooligans, Everywhere
description: MOSCOW  There are many hooligans in Russia, apparently, and judging by the way the state deals with them, they are extremely dangerous people. With jail sentences averaging three years and potentially reaching seven, they are treated as though they pose a greater threat to Russian society than drunk drivers and possibly as great a threat as murderers, who get sentences in the same range.

title: R.B.S. Seeks Buyer for Unit
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Monday that it was in talks to sell its structured retail investor products and equity derivatives business.

description: Start-Up: Goodsnitch.

title: A Conversation With: Novelist Tash Aw
description: Tash Aw is a writer of Malaysian origin who was born in Taiwan, grew up in Kuala Lumpur and currently resides in London. He is the author of The Harmony Silk Factory (2005), which won the Whitbread Book Award, given to authors based in Britain and Ireland, as well as the Commonwealth Writers Prize, and of Map of the Invisible World (2009). His most recent novel, Five Star Billionaire, which was released this year, was placed on the long list for the Man Booker Prize, Britains top literary award. The book captures the changes sweeping across China through the lives of five Malaysian-Chinese immigrants who move to Shanghai in pursuit of the Chinese dream.

title: Abducted Libyan Official Is Released
description: CAIRO  The deputy chief of Libyas intelligence service was temporarily abducted from the parking lot of the airport in Tripoli on Sunday as a standoff between militias and a general strike against militia rule virtually shut down the city.

description: Updated, 5:08 p.m. |

description: Salesforce.com on Monday made what could turn out to be one of the biggest changes in the cloud computing pioneers history.

title: Pressure to Finish Volcker Rule Quickly
description: The Obama administration has reached a critical stage in its effort to rein in Wall Street, Peter Eavis and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The push to reshape financial regulation hinges on negotiations in the coming weeks over the Volcker Rule, which bans banks from trading for their own gain.

title: Japan Pitches Its High-Speed Train With an Offer to Finance
description: TSURU, Japan  As the worlds fastest train raced through central Japan, former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York hoisted his 6-foot-5 frame into the aisle and marveled at the smoothness of the ride.

title: Daily Report: For Start-Up Leaders, to Sell or Hold Is a Tough Call
description: Were the young founders of Snapchat, a mobile-messaging start-up, delusional for turning down a multibillion-dollar buyout offer? Greedy to think they might get more later? Or courageous to chase their dreams?

title: Top U.N. Official Warns of Coal Risks
description: WARSAW  Most of the worlds coal needs to stay in the ground if greenhouse gas emissions are to be held in check, the United Nations top climate change official said Monday in a speech to coal industry executives here in Poland, one of the most coal-dependent nations on Earth.

title: Weighing Free Speech in Refusal to Photograph Lesbian Couples Ceremony
description: WASHINGTON  A New Mexico law forbids businesses open to the public to discriminate against gay people. Elaine Huguenin, a photographer, says she has no problem with that  so long as it does not force her to say something she does not believe.

title: Chief of Newark Arts Centers Development Unit Is Stepping Down
description: Lawrence P. Goldman, the founding chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark, is stepping down as president and chief executive of Theater Square Development Company, a subsidiary of the center that is focused on developing adjacent land.

title: High Winning Bid for Photo by Maos Wife
description: A black-and-white photograph of a landscape snapped by Mao Zedongs fourth wife, Jiang Qing, has sold for 391,000 renminbi, or $64,000, about 20 times the presale estimate, at Huachen Auctions in Beijing. The unexpectedly high price provides another sign of a bullish market for Mao-era art, driven by the competition among private collectors and public museums and libraries that are seeking to enhance their holdings.

title: Tibetan Monasterys Prayer Hall Lost in Fire
description: The main prayer hall of a 16th-century Tibetan Buddhist monastery burned to the ground in a fire set off by a short circuit in an electrical appliance, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

title: Advent International to Take Dutch Firm Private for $1.58 Billion
description: Updated, 9:51 a.m. | LONDON  The private equity firm Advent International has reached a deal to take private Unit4, a software provider based in the Netherlands, for 1.17 billion euros in cash, or $1.58 billion.

title: The New Keynesian Case for Fiscal Policy (Wonkish)
description: Its been a bit funny on the academic front being a Keynesian during a Keynesian crisis. Much of the academic profession decided more than 30 years ago that the whole thing was nonsense and what we needed was an equilibrium model of the business cycle. By the time the utter failure of the equilibrium project became apparent, you had a whole generation of economists who knew that Keynesianism of any form was nonsense based on what they had heard somewhere, so they didnt read any of the stuff, old or new  and were flabbergasted to learn that there was in fact an extensive New Keynesian literature that provided a justification for fiscal policy at the zero lower bound.

title: Justices Reject Challenge to N.S.A. Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday turned away an unusual challenge to a National Security Agency surveillance program.

title: On Global Terror and the Fukushima Fuel Move
description: Heres a quick update on efforts to clean up the tsunami-damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant complex. (Ill be following up with a post on efforts to track the radioactive material that flowed into the Pacific Ocean after the calamity and clarify its implications for public and ecosystem health.)

title: Fuel Removal Underway at Crippled Plant in Japan
description: TOKYO  The operator of the crippled Fukushima Daiichi power plant on Monday began removing nuclear fuel assemblies from a storage pool atop one of the sites blown-out reactor buildings, a delicate yet critical operation that could help reduce risks at the plant.

description: Morrison & Foerster said on Monday that Howard Morris, a former co-chief executive of SNR Denton, was joining the law firm as head of the bankruptcy and restructuring group in London.

Rodriguez Returns to Hearing Over His Suspension

description: PARIS  Police officers fanned out in the French capital on Monday in search of the man responsible for a shooting at a newspaper headquarters that left one man gravely wounded and the city on edge.

title: New Prize Goes to Author of Book on Vietnam
description: Fredrik Logevall has won the first American Library in Paris Book Award for his Embers of War: The Fall of an Empire and the Making of Americas Vietnam. The library was founded and originally run by American expatriates in Paris in 1920, with books that had been sent by American libraries to soldiers fighting in World War I. It plans to offer the $5,000 award annually for what its jury considers the most distinguished book of the year about France or the encounters between France and the United States.

description: WASHINGTON, Ill.  As the sky went black and sirens wailed, Ella and Phil Bolam lay together in a bedroom closet, pillows covering their heads, as the storm passed and the house went away, Ms. Bolam said.

title: Dried Porcini Consomm
description: I could drink this refreshing consomm for lunch every day. It makes a very light and satisfying appetizer soup or first course.

title: Pured Mushroom Soup
description: Thick and creamy, with no cream, this tastes so much richer than it is. I use a small amount of milk to thin out the soup, but you can also use stock to thin it, if you dont want to include any dairy.

title: Walkabout: Europe Is Expected to Loosen Restrictions on Electronic Devices
description: Power Up Passengers with smartphones and music players flying on European airlines will no longer have to turn off their device on take-off and landing. Thats just one of the new rules being developed by the European Aviation Safety Agencythat will bepublished by the end of the month. (Bloomberg)

title: Tate Britain Completes Renovation
description: LONDON  The $72 million renovation of the Tate Britain museum by the architectural firm Caruso St. John is complete, on time and on budget, said Penelope Curtis, the director of the museum, at a showing on Monday, the day before the museum will open its new areas to the public.

description: Brad DeLong continues the pile-on over Barry Ritholtzs roll of dishonor  the people who signed the currency debasement letter and havent shown any sign of learning anything from being completely wrong.

title: New Leader Is Named for ArtPlace America
description: ArtPlace America, an organization that awards grants in the hope of encouraging what it calls creative placemaking  that is, the inclusion of arts and cultural projects in community development and renovation plans  has appointed Jamie L. Bennett to be its executive director, starting in January.

title: Presumed Innocent, but Caged in Court
description: MOSCOW  Under the Russian Constitution, Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, the star dancer charged with arranging an acid attack on the Bolshoi Ballets artistic director, is innocent until proven guilty. But in court, Mr. Dmitrichenko sits in a locked iron cage, guarded by security officers and, at times, a nasty-looking dog.

title: Measuring the Might of Haiyan
description: Typhoon Haiyan, which ravaged the Philippines earlier this month, might have been one of the strongest tropical cyclones ever to hit land, but its exact strength was a matter of dispute. Forecasting agencies said it would pack winds of up to 195 miles (about 315 kilometers) an hour, but meteorologists in the Philippines said that top measured speeds were closer to 150 m.p.h., or 240 k.p.h.

title: A Dirty Secret Lurks in the Struggle Over a Fiscal Grand Bargain
description: WASHINGTON  The long-sought bipartisan grand bargain on the nations fiscal future is not going to happen this year, and probably not for the rest of President Obamas term. There is the simple, familiar reason. And then there is the dirty secret.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Nathy Aviram joined McCann Erickson New York as executive vice president and director of integrated production. He assumes duties from Diane Hill, who had been senior vice president and director of integrated production; she left to return to BBDO New York, where she had previously worked, and is now senior vice president and group executive producer there. Mr. Aviram has worked for agencies that include TBWA/Chiat/Day New York and Y&R New York. McCann Erickson New York is part of the McCann Erickson Worldwide division of the McCann Worldgroup, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Before the Wedding, the Histrionics (but Not the Brides)
description: The cause of Annabell Armstrongs latest panic attack seems petty: Annabell (a frenetic Polly Lee) is at Neiman Marcus in Dallas, and she cannot find the perfect dress for a cousins wedding. But as Helen Sneeds 95-minute play explains again and again, her histrionics are but a manifestation of a lifetime of accumulated anxieties and emotional traumas, as evidenced by the memories that wander, unwanted, into the stores dressing room.

title: The Power of Two (Extra Wonkish)
description: This seems to be wonk Monday. But anyway, one commenter raised what may have been a complaint about my tendency to do New Keynesian models that say they have infinite horizons, but whose analysis always seems to boil down to just two periods, now and forever after.

title: With More Indictments, New Clues in A.T.M. Robbery Case
description: When eight men from Queens were indicted last spring as part of a global network that looted $45 million from A.T.M.'s, an unanswered question was what happened to the money.

title: The Read Around: Terry McMillan
description: In The Read Around, a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Terry McMillan, the author of Waiting to Exhale and, most recently, Who Asked You?, talks about why she prefers writing in the first person, how she gets to know her characters and why its important for writers to be diverse readers.

title: Quitting the N.F.L.: For John Moffitt, the Money Wasnt Worth It
description: SEATTLE  John Moffitt chugged mugs of black coffee and talked almost giddily about how, the week before, he called John Elway, the head of football operations for the Denver Broncos, to tell him he was quitting the National Football League, leaving behind the money and the fame, but also the constant pain and the danger.

title: The V.A. and Sexual Trauma
description: An editorial in todays Times cites disheartening discrepancies in how the Veterans Affairs Department handles disability claims involving post-traumatic stress disorder. According to a report released this month by advocates for women and men who were sexually harassed and attacked while serving in uniform, survivors of sexual trauma are far less likely than other veterans to have their disability benefits approved.

title: Surveillance Video of Suspected Paris Gunman
description: As my colleague Scott Sayare reports, French police are scouring Paris for a gunman who shot a journalist at the headquarters of the newspaper Libration on Monday morning. The same man is suspected of shooting at a bank in another part of the French capital 90 minutes later, and of having menaced an editor at a television news channel late last week.

title: Confused About Holiday Travel? Submit Your Questions Here
description: The Wednesday before Thanksgiving is one of the busiest travel days of the year, according to the Department of Transportation. And no matter how youre getting to grandmothers house  by air, rail or road  you probably have a few nagging questions that could get answered in the form of a rude awakening on the road. In order to reduce the number of known unknowns, wed like to answer your questions about holiday travel before you set off.

title: Vegetarian Too Young
description: When my daughter chose to become a vegetarian at age 4 after I read her Charlottes Web, I thought it was a passing phase, much like needing to receive a confidential sprinkle of fairy dust on her way to school. Her pediatrician approved her nutritional plan without hesitation, and we have Hindu friends whose children have been vegetarian from birth, so the idea hardly seemed radical in our household, where we consumed a modest amount of meat to begin with.

title: A Hurdle to Winding Down a Failing Global Bank
description: A seemingly small derivatives detail could sink global bank wind-down plans. American and European regulators want to standardize contracts to help cross-border lenders fail smoothly. If the problem isnt fixed, investors could undermine financial stability by calling in swaps. Its a reminder of how much work still needs to be done to end too big to fail.

title: In Washington State, Selling to the Sellers With a Lighthearted Touch
description: Theres a moment in the movie Written on the Wind when a character played by Robert Stack tells a character played by Lauren Bacall, You advertising people, so clever with words. But just how clever do advertising people have to be when creating advertising aimed at other advertising people?

title: Congress and Courts Weigh Restraints on N.S.A. Spying
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional critics of the National Security Agency program that collects the telephone records of millions of Americans stepped up their efforts as the Supreme Court on Monday turned away an unusual challenge to the scope of the surveillance.

title: Here Lies Love Cast to Reunite for Benefit Performance
description: David Byrne is reconvening the cast of Here Lies Love, his immersive musical about Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, for a single performance on Nov. 25 at Terminal 5 to raise money for relief efforts in the Philippines in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, which struck on Nov. 8. All proceeds from the performance will be donated to Doctors Without Borders, the Paris-based physicians group.

title: More Explorations in Space
description: With or without Kepler, the quest for habitable real estate in the galaxy will go on.

title: Former Marcos Aide Is Convicted in Attempted Sale of Missing Paintings
description: Vilma Bautista was patient. She waited more than a quarter of a century before discreetly trying to sell the paintings she had in her New York apartment: Impressionist masterpieces that had once hung on the walls of a townhouse used by Imelda Marcos.

title: New Plan for a Disabled Kepler
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The little spacecraft that could may still have some life left in it.

title: Real Honor for Fake Newsman
description: Plenty of journalists have received honorary degrees. But Ron Burgundy, the bumbling fictional television newsman played by Will Ferrell in Anchorman, will go one better next month when the Emerson College School of Communication is temporarily named after him.

title: Medical Care Improves in Storm-Hit Areas, Though Many Are Still Out of Reach
description: PALO, the Philippines  Rosalina Doyola, a cheerful 22-year-old with an accounting degree and an air of youthful confidence, woke up on Monday morning in a field hospital tent, lucky to have kept both her legs.

title: 3 From Greenpeace Ship Free on Bail in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A court in St. Petersburg on Monday granted bail to three of 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship seized during a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic in September. Some see this as a first sign of leniency in an investigation that could continue through the Olympic Games that Russia is hosting in Sochi.

title: Weekend Gun Report: November 15-17, 2013
description: No charges will be filed in the shooting death of a 13-year-old girl at a friends home in Las Vegas, Nev., in June. Brooklynn Mohler was shot when her friend was holding a gun, which had been retrieved from a kitchen cabinet, and it accidentally discharged.

title: G.M.s Opel Unit Reaches Deal to Close a German Plant
description: FRANKFURT  The Opel unit of General Motors said on Monday that it reached a preliminary agreement with workers to close a factory in Bochum, Germany, at the end of next year, another example of the effort by hard-pressed European automakers to slowly close superfluous manufacturing plants.

title: Lady Gaga Concert Prompts Fine for Russian Concert Agency
description: The Russian concert agency that presented a Lady Gaga concert in St. Petersburg in December has been fined 20,000 rubles  the equivalent of $614  because, a St. Petersburg court ruled, Lady Gagas show promoted homosexuality and alcohol consumption.

title: Arguments for Trusting the Data
description: Why dont we trust data? More to the point, why dont we act on what data tells us?

title: Scores Killed in Tribal Clashes in Darfur
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Nearly 200 members of two Arab tribes that signed a peace treaty in July were killed in fighting in southwest Darfur over the past three weeks, a local tribal chief said.

title: Sochi Games Doping Lab Provisionally Suspended
description: The Russian laboratory that has been assigned the task of processing drug tests for the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi will have its accreditation suspended for six months if it does not make operational improvements to ensure its reliability by Dec. 1.

title: Pacers Have Built a Consistent (if Imperfect) Winner
description: CHICAGO  Several hours before his Indiana Pacers met the Chicago Bulls Saturday night at United Center, General Manager Kevin Pritchard lounged in a courtside folding chair during the afternoon shootaround.

description: The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported on Monday that a Walmart in Canton, Ohio is organizing a food drive for its employees.

description: Mr. Adler has taken the affable-neighborhood-retiree gig to a whole new level with the Kew Gardens Musicians.

title: Obamas First-Term Finance Team: Where Are They Now?
description: Timothy F. Geithners move to the private equity firm Warburg Pincus is a big shift by a finance official from the Obama administrations first term to the private sector.

title: In Store | Balenciagas Newest, Oldest-Looking, Store
description: With its dark green Verde Ramegiatto marble walls and a skylight ceiling covered with a lattice metal inlay, the new Balenciaga flagship in SoHo feels like it has been around for centuries. Alexander Wang designed it that way, working closely with his longtime friend and collaborator, the interior designer Ryan Korban, to turn the bilevel space on Mercer Street into something that felt like it had already stood the test of time. I wanted to mix modern and classical materials to create a timeless space, said Wang, who cited historic museums as inspiration for the store, his first as the brands creative director. The interiors are also a testament to Wangs point of view for the brand, full of references to his debut collection for Balenciaga, which took place on a faux marble runway back in February. Even the chairs that dot the grand, open floor plan  which also includes several intimate rooms that each house different kinds of goods (ready-to-wear in one room, shoes in another, etc.)  have been upholstered in the same black caviar embroidery he applied to gowns in the fall 2013 collection. Combined with the sofas, they seem to beg shoppers to stay awhile. I thought back to the time of the couture salon presentations in the Cristobal Balenciaga era, when clients had the luxury of time to view fashion in a leisurely way, but with an elevated sense of ceremony, Wang said. The Balenciaga flagship opens on Nov. 22; 148 Mercer Street; (212) 206-0872.

title: The Dow, Adjusted for Inflation
description: The Dow Jones industrial average broke through 16,000 on Monday for the first time on record  well, at least in nominal terms. If you adjust for inflation, technically the highest level was on Jan. 14, 2000 (both for closing price and intraday trading):

description: Africans may become susceptible to a type of malaria that they had long been thought to be immune to because the parasite appears to be evolving, scientists said last week.

title: Challenge for the Philippines: 4 Million Displaced
description: As the Philippines begins to clean up after the worst typhoon in memory, it is faced with the huge challenge of feeding and housing its displaced population.

title: Deadly Tornadoes Rip Through Midwest
description: Scenes from the aftermath of the tornadoes that caused widespread destruction across the Midwest.

title: Filming of Movie Wont Close Clearwater Aquarium
description: After turning away scores of disappointed visitors, the Clearwater Marine Aquarium, in Clearwater, Fla., has reversed its decision to close weekends during the filming of Dolphin Tale 2 and will also remain open during the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays.

title: Sleep Therapy Seen as an Aid for Depression
description: Curing insomnia in people with depression could double their chance of a full recovery, scientists are reporting. The findings, based on an insomnia treatment that uses talk therapy rather than drugs, are the first to emerge from a series of closely watched studies of sleep and depression to be released in the coming year.

title: A Business Travelers View of the Latest Airline Merger
description: WHEN discussing the airline business, Michael Boyd uses the term raw, naked economics as if it ought to be followed by a shriek off a movie screen.

title: A Cold War Fought by Women
description: How aggressive is the human female? When the anthropologist Sarah B. Hrdy surveyed the research literature three decades ago, she concluded that the competitive component in the nature of women remains anecdotal, intuitively sensed, but not confirmed by science.

title: Monday Motorsports: A Week of Triumph, Tragedy and Controversy
description: Jimmie Johnson clinched his sixth Nascar Sprint Cup championship with a ninth place finish in the season finale on Sunday at Homestead-Miami Speedway. Matt Kenseth finished the season in the runner-up position, 19 points behind Johnson, with a second-place finish in the race, behind the winner, Denny Hamlin. Dale Earnhardt Jr. took third in the race.

title: A Singapore Crew Cut to Get Past the Hair Police
description: IVE been flying regularly for about 40 years. Im 62 years old, or, as I prefer, 62 years young, and fly once a week. I have a line of skin care products named after me, and that means that I have to meet with people, do events, find new avenues for business in the United States and abroad, and even travel so I can keep up with the trends and learn new things.

title: Sony Entertainment Is Said to Hire Bain & Company for Cost-Cutting
description: LOS ANGELES  Sony Entertainment, under pressure to make its moviemaking operation more profitable, has hired Bain & Company to help it identify $100 million or more in additional overhead cuts, a move that would almost assuredly result in layoffs, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: A Conversation With Leander Kahney, Author of Jony Ive
description: Jony Ive, the designer behind some of Apples most successful products, became even more important to Apple after the death of Steve Jobs.

title: Inequality of Feelings
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Agriculture as Solution
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Fennel and Lemon Turn Swordfish Into a More Complex Meal
description: Whats for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: Zimmerman Is Charged With Aggravated Assault
description: ATLANTA  Barely four months after he was acquitted in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager that spurred demonstrations across the country, George Zimmerman was arrested on Monday in Florida following a dispute with his girlfriend, the authorities said.

title: Watchful Eye in Nursing Homes
description: A pretty nightie, a new lipstick, a fresh toothbrush: Doris Racher noticed that small things she had bought for her 96-year-old mother, Eryetha Mayberry, a dementia patient at a nursing home in Oklahoma City, had been disappearing. Ms. Racher assumed the culprit was another resident who sometimes wandered into her mothers room and fell asleep in her bed.

title: German Chancellor Makes Plea for Ukraine
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel demanded on Monday that Russia allow its onetime subjects  particularly in Ukraine  to exercise the sovereign right to make alliances as they choose.

title: Toronto Mayor Knocks Over City Council Member at Meeting
description: The embattled Toronto mayor, Rob Ford, knocked over a City Council member during a tense special session on Monday called to debate a motion that would strip him of almost all mayoral powers, according to The Globe and Mail, a Toronto newspaper. The meeting came after a string of reports that included an admission by Mr. Ford that he bought and used crack cocaine while in office.

title: Cheneys Defend Elder Daughter in Feud on Gay Marriage
description: Breaking their silence about the public feud between their two daughters, former Vice President Dick Cheney and his wife, Lynne, said Monday that the situation had pained them, but offered some political cover for their elder child, who is seeking a United States Senate seat in Wyoming.

title: A Rare Sample of a Much Saltier Time
description: Seawater retrieved from a crater deep under Chesapeake Bay is 100 million to 145 million years old, researchers say, offering a rare glimpse of ancient ocean conditions in the North Atlantic.

title: Vienna Visit Is a Home Game for a U.S. Assistant
description: Almost everywhere that the United States national soccer team goes, Coach Jurgen Klinsmann is the most recognized member of the traveling party. Whether it is San Pedro Sula or Sarajevo, Klinsmann, a World Cup-winning striker with Germany, is catnip for soccer fans, autograph-seekers and admirers.

title: In Performance: Zachary Quinto
description: Zachary Quinto as Tom in a scene from the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williamss Glass Menagerie, on Broadway at the Booth Theater.

title: Officials Were Warned About Health Site Woes
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Obama administration officials, including several in the White House, were warned by an outside management consultant early this year that the effort to build the HealthCare.gov site was falling behind and at risk of failure unless immediate steps were taken to correct the problems, according to documents released by House investigators.

title: Not Much of an Appetite at 80
description: Q. Why would I totally lose my appetite at the age of 80, with no apparent medical problems?

title: After Hours | An Irishmans Inner Marcel Proust
description: Bush Moukarzels first line in the one-man play Souvenir, now playing at the Abrons Arts Center in New York, is, For a long time, I went to bed early. Its also the very famous first line of Marcel Prousts Remembrance of Things Past, published a century ago this year. Moukarzels hourlong piece, which was a sold-out hit in Dublin and London for the theater company Dead Centre, aims not so much to relive Prousts epic, seven-volume story of social climbing, desire and memory as to distill its yearning, nostalgic essence into fragments of narrative and images. When the show begins, Moukarzel is running on a treadmill, his back to us, instantly conjuring images of being borne back ceaselessly into the past (or, stuck in the present). A giant diptych of Proust hangs overhead. Everywhere, theres a clutter of half-opened packing boxes, marked cheekily with labels like Mum, Apologies, Bacon, Broken Glass and (inevitably) Madeleines.

title: Celtic Paths, Illuminated by a Sundial
description: BEWCASTLE, England  The road leading north from Carlisle through the low, windswept hills stretching to the Scottish border traces Hadrians Wall, once a remote outpost of the Roman Empire. Nearby is the tiny outcropping of Bewcastle, where a broken Celtic cross with one of the oldest sundials in England stands in a lonely churchyard.

title: New Scrutiny for Medical Devices
description: Wayne Schneiders heart stopped beating late last year while the Minneapolis paramedic was out on an emergency call. Another medic performed CPR for a few minutes, and then used a medical device that delivered cardiac compressions mechanically for 64 minutes, until Mr. Schneiders heart started beating normally on its own.

title: Bill on Drug Compounding Clears Congress a Year After a Meningitis Outbreak
description: A bill that would give the Food and Drug Administration more power to police compounding pharmacies passed its final hurdle in Congress on Monday, in what experts said was an important step to a safer drug supply in the United States.

title: Jay Z and Barneys Announce Substantial Changes in Their Partnership
description: Over the weekend, Barneys New York and Jay Z reaffirmed their plans to go ahead with a collaboration that involves, among other things, the introduction of a fragrance this Wednesday, but announced some substantial changes in their partnership.

title: Baddest Man on the Planet (and His Vulnerable Side)
description: For many years, Mike Tyson lived a life without brakes.

title: For a Tenors Centennial, Celebrating His Legacy With a Cast of Opera Stars
description: A dream team of opera singers assembled at Avery Fisher Hall for the Richard Tucker Gala on Sunday, an evening that included Stephanie Blythe, Joyce DiDonato, Rene Fleming, Susan Graham and Eric Owens. But before any of them sang a note, it was the voice of Tucker that filled the hall in a recording of Thine Alone, in which cantorial ardor and classical training blended into that combination of polish and popular appeal that made him one of the best-loved tenors of his time.

title: A Historical Elephants New Identity
description: In 1752, King Adolf Fredrik of Sweden acquired a remarkable curiosity: an elephant fetus preserved in a jar. It did not take long for a fellow Swede, the famed naturalist Carl Linnaeus, to pay an eager visit to Drottningholm Palace to examine the withered specimen.

title: Healthy Trips to Exotic Places
description: Long ago, I carried two seatbelts in my luggage. When the car that we rented for a month to drive around Turkey had no seatbelts in the back, as my husband and I had been warned, we took the two in my baggage to a body shop, paid to have them installed, and strapped our children in.

title: U.N. Agency Seeks Details on American Held in Iran
description: The family of Amir Hekmati, a former American Marine who has been incarcerated in Iran for more than two years even though his espionage conviction was overturned, has been contacted by the United Nations for details on his case, Mr. Hekmatis sister said Monday.

title: Exploring Spirituality, and Ending on a Prayer
description: The British composer John Tavener, who died last week at 69, frequently collaborated with the Tallis Scholars, the superb a cappella ensemble founded and conducted by Peter Phillips. It seemed fitting that as an encore to the groups impressive concert of Renaissance and contemporary music on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, it offered a Tavener work as a tribute: his setting of the Lords Prayer.

title: Hearing What Radiohead Has Inspired
description: David Bowie, Tortoise, the Orb, Sufjan Stevens, Dan Deacon: The list of pop and rock performers and groups who have shown the composer Steve Reichs influence is lengthy and continuing. On Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Reich turned the tables, as Alarm Will Sound presented the New York premiere of his Radio Rewrite, based on two songs by the British rock band Radiohead. The performance was part of this adventurous new-music ensembles season-long residency, which includes formal events like this one, as well as unusual programs, like a pop-up concert that would unfold without warning in the museums Charles Engelhard Court on Monday at noon.

title: Pictures of the Day: Illinois and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Illinois, the Philippines, Pakistan and France.

title: Clues to the Origins of Big Cats
description: A newly discovered set of big-cat fossils, believed to be the oldest ever found, belonged to a previously unknown species, and may help solve a longstanding mystery about the origins of big cats likes tigers, leopards and lions, researchers say.

title: An Old Chinese Novel Is Racy Reading Still
description: When David Tod Roy entered a used-book shop in the Chinese city of Nanjing in 1950, he was a 16-year-old American missionary kid looking for a dirty book.

title: Serving a Challenging Meal by Starting Off Easy
description: When it comes to ambitious, fearless orchestral programming, there is Leon Botstein, the music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, and then there is everyone else. Say what you will about Mr. Botsteins esoteric tastes, professorial inclinations or limitations as a conductor. Its all been said before, endlessly, and its not indicative of the edifying experiences his concerts tend to be for anyone whose tastes extend past the safety zone in which most other orchestras huddle.

title: Israelis Embrace French President for Iran Position
description: JERUSALEM  President Franois Hollandes trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories, like all state visits, was planned months ago. But coming days before France and other world powers prepared to resume the nuclear talks with Iran in Geneva, the three-day visit that started on Sunday could not have come at a more opportune time for Israel  or for France, according to some Israeli officials.

title: Question Fed Policy? Sure. Audit It? No.
description: Mike Konczal has a very good piece on why Rand Pauls proposal that the Fed be audited is a bad idea. You should read it; Id just like to offer a complementary take.

title: Reptilian Smarts
description: New research is showing that lizards, turtles and snakes are more intelligent than previously believed.

title: Coldblooded Does Not Mean Stupid
description: Humans have no exclusive claim on intelligence. Across the animal kingdom, all sorts of creatures have performed impressive intellectual feats. A bonobo named Kanzi uses an array of symbols to communicate with humans. Chaser the border collie knows the English words for more than 1,000 objects. Crows make sophisticated tools, elephants recognize themselves in the mirror, and dolphins have a rudimentary number sense.

title: Broader Pool of Madoff Victims to Benefit From Fund
description: The largest category of victims in the vast Ponzi scheme run by Bernard L. Madoff  those who lost cash through accounts with various middleman funds  will be first in line for compensation from a $2.35 billion fund collected by the Justice Department.

title: Crossing the Ocean to Discover the Personal
description: The work of Devont Hynes radiates a thorough, passionate, forgetting-to-eat-or-sleep love for the last 30 years of pop. His current project, Blood Orange, is a trans-Atlantic notion of urban dance music from the early 80s to the early 90s: freestyle, Prince ballads, Janet Jacksons Control, Neneh Cherry. It reads now, on balance, as a New York sound. But its a New York as experienced by an outsider, exotic and blurry, with an indeterminate time stamp.

title: An Earlier Exodus Amid Climate Change
description: Birds are migrating earlier and earlier each year, and scientists have long suspected that climate change is responsible. A new study by researchers at the University of East Anglia in England shows that individual birds migrate like clockwork, but nesting and hatching are happening earlier as a result of warmer temperatures, and this appears to be linked to the advancing of overall migration patterns.

title: Eli's Championship M.O.
description: The Giants play some horrible football, then string together some wins and make the playoffs. William C. Rhoden has seen this movie twice before. It always ends with a Super Bowl victory parade.

title: Video Sports of The Times: Elis Championship M.O.
Need Condo Cleaned? Consider the Superintendents Family
description: When Ilir Topalli gets that yearly Christmas card from the management of the small Upper East Side building where he has lived for 10 years, the one that gently nudges residents to tip the staff, it contains the names of the superintendent, the doorman and the porter who trudges out with the trash. Also listed is someone who is not on the co-ops payroll: the superintendents wife, who is the de facto housekeeper for many of the apartments.

title: Excerpt: Love and Math
description: Theres a secret world out there. A hidden parallel universe of beauty and elegance, intricately intertwined with ours. Its the world of mathematics. And its invisible to most of us. This book is an invitation to discover this world.

title: Brilliance Triumphs Over Rejection
description: In 1984, when he was 16, Edward Frenkel was subjected to a malicious interrogation. Already a brilliant budding mathematician, he had applied for admission to Mekh-Mat at Moscow State University, the top mathematics program in the Soviet Union. But when he attended the critical oral entrance exam, his dream of becoming a professional mathematician came crashing down.

title: Vibrating Along With Live Music
description: Some dancers execute movement; others breathe it. In Gina Gibneys Dividing Line, which had its premiere run from Thursday through Saturday at Gould Hall, Amy Miller fell into the second category.

title: A Romantic Evening
description: When David Ludwig wrote his Swan Song for violin and piano, he wanted to evoke the ghosts of 19th-century composers. He was particularly inspired by Schuberts Fantasy for Violin and Piano, which opens with an elegiac melody over bustling piano figurations. The title of Mr. Ludwigs contemporary reimagining refers to Schuberts Swan Song cycle, written shortly before Schubert died of syphilis at 31.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: On Googles Driverless Car, and Poking Fun at Downed YouTube
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Hurricanes and Climate, Helping Stuck Babies, Changing Forests
description: The typhoon that struck the Philippines this month prompted questions about a possible link between natural disasters and a warming planet. Delegates at the United Nations talks in Warsaw on a global climate treaty were quick to make the connection. And the head of the United Nations meteorological agency cited Australias severe summer heat and raised water levels around the Philippines as among the effects, reported ABC News. Still, most scientists remained cautious, saying there was not enough data to draw a direct connection.

title: Pynchon Wont Be Surfacing for National Book Awards
description: On Wednesday evening, the publishing industry will gather in black tie for the National Book Awards, where some of the most prestigious literary prizes in the business will be handed out.

title: YouTube Website Goes Down
description: YouTube, the worlds third most popular website, went down for a short period on Monday, giving the millions of people who depend on the service for videos of news and kittens a heavy sense of withdrawal.

title: Obama Pick for Court Is 3rd in a Row Blocked by Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Monday blocked President Obamas third consecutive nominee to the countrys most powerful and prestigious appeals court and insisted they would not back down, inflaming a bitter debate over a presidents right to shape the judiciary.

title: On View | An Artists Dueling Landscapes
description: What do the streets, storefronts and bodegas of South Williamsburg, Brooklyn, have to do with the deserts of southern California? Its a question that the sculptor Halsey Rodman, who grew up in Davis, Calif., has been considering a lot lately, with two related projects in these radically opposed environments.

title: Maria Bartiromo to Leave CNBC for Fox Business
description: Maria Bartiromo, one of the first women to become a star on television by reporting on business news, is leaving her longtime home at CNBC for its rival, the Fox Business Network.

title: U.S. Poised to Announce $13 Billion JPMorgan Settlement
description: The Justice Department is set to announce a $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over the banks questionable mortgage practices in the run-up to the financial crisis, people briefed on the deal said on Monday, as prosecutors and the bank hashed out the final details of the deal.

title: Commercial Breaks That Keep a Story Going
description: A YEAR after an innovative marketing effort for the Christmas shopping season brought together Target and ABC, the retailer and the network are teaming up again.

title: Slowdown in Carbon Emissions Worldwide, but Coal Burning Continues to Grow
description: Global emissions of carbon dioxide are slowing somewhat from the rapid pace of the last decade, new figures show, but growth in coal burning continues to outstrip the growth in other forms of energy, and experts said the world remains far from meeting international goals on climate change.

title: Inmate Buses Sit at Rikers; New York City Courts Stalled
description: Dozens of New York City corrections buses that were supposed to take prisoners to court on Monday never left Rikers Island, grinding many criminal courts in the city to a near halt.

title: Researchers Work to Add More Anonymity to Bitcoin
description: In my column this week, Disruptions: A Digital Underworld Cloaked in Anonymity, I noted that the Deep Web, orDark Internet, had mushroomed in recent years because of a growing belief that it was possible to remain anonymous online.

title: Princeton University to Use Foreign Vaccine
description: Princeton University plans to offer students a meningitis vaccine not usually approved for use in the United States in an attempt to prevent an outbreak at the school from spreading, officials said on Monday.

title: Dropbox Is Said to Seek $250 Million in Funding, Doubling Its Valuation
description: Online storage, once a backwater of the Silicon Valley technology scene, is suddenly a hot commodity.

title: Bloomberg Lays Off Staff in Sports and Culture
description: Bloomberg News started laying off and reassigning employees on Monday, seeking to emphasize areas that promote growth and focus more on core subjects like finance and government.

title: Cause of Gas Leak That Killed 2 Colorado Miners Is Sought
description: DENVER  Federal mine safety inspectors on Monday were trying to determine the cause of an accident that killed two miners and injured 20 others near the mountain town of Ouray in southwestern Colorado.

title: Egyptian Protesters Destroy Tahrir Square Monument Erected by Interim Government
description: Updated, Tuesday, 9:56 a.m. | Just hours after Egypts military-led interim government tried to cement its claim to revolutionary legitimacy  with the dedication of a memorial to the uprisings that toppled two authoritarian presidents in two years  protesters swarmed the monument in the center of Tahrir Square on Monday night and defaced it, chanting, The revolutions returned to Tahrir.

title: Plan to Redevelop South Street Seaport Includes Marina and 50-Story Tower
description: South Street Seaport, an often-neglected corner of Manhattan dedicated to enshrining New Yorks seafaring past, has been battered by storms, recessions and poor management.

title: A Lifesaving Treatment, and a Killer
TV Series Will Focus on N.H.L. Players in Olympics
description: The N.H.L., once ambivalent about breaking up its 2013-14 season to enable players to participate in the 2014 Sochi Olympics, has come to embrace the break in its schedule. The league announced Monday that it has hired producers to make a seven-hour series that will track teams and players through the Olympics and five outdoor stadium games.

title: At Swarovskis New Outpost, a Look on the Bright Side
description: Until recently, I believed that Swarovski was just a manufacturer of rhinestones, or bling: used to jazz up cellphone cases, waxed bikini lines and other assorted fripperies that began to emerge in developed countries as the previous millennium waned.

title: As the 50th Anniversary Nears, Dallas Reflects
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising the Cigarette-Buying Age to 21
description: To the Editor:

title: Jefferson in Quebec
description: To the Editor:

title: Google to Pay $17 Million to Settle Privacy Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google agreed on Monday to pay $17 million to 37 states and the District of Columbia in a wide-reaching settlement over tracking consumers online without their knowledge.

title: Colorado Governor Proposes Strict Limits on Greenhouse Gas Leaks From Drilling
description: Gov. John W. Hickenlooper of Colorado proposed on Monday tough new limits on leaks of methane and other gases from well sites and storage tanks. Supporters called the limits, which would exceed existing federal rules, the most sweeping in the nation.

title: Cheney Family Values
description: If Liz Cheney, whose bid for the Senate has always had a stench of extreme opportunism, wants to discuss traditions and values, Im all for it. Lets start here: Isnt there a tradition of close-knit family members taking care not to wound one another? Is there not value in that?

title: Yankees Set to Resume Cano Negotiations, With Sides Still Far Apart
description: Hal Steinbrenner said last week at the owners meetings in Orlando, Fla., that the Yankees would resume negotiations this week with the free-agent second baseman Robinson Cano. But it does not seem as if there is a great deal to talk about, at least not yet.

title: New Market Benchmarks Show a Lack of Options
description: Stocks rallied past two psychological barriers Monday morning, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average over 16,000 and the Standard & Poors 500-stock index beyond 1,800 for the first time, as investors still saw opportunities in the market.

title: Alabama Judges Retain the Right to Override Juries in Capital Sentencing
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday turned down a challenge to an unusual Alabama capital-sentencing practice that has sent 95 defendants to death row despite jury determinations calling for life sentences.

title: Many Wheels, but No Place to Ride Them
description: Dirt bike and A.T.V. enthusiasts find it hard  to find places to ride without interference from the authorities.

title: Kenya: New Details on Mall Attackers
description: The attackers behind the siege of the Westgate shopping mall that left more than 60 people dead in September had been living in Nairobi and plotted the attack for several months, a Western official briefed on the investigation said Monday. Kenyan officials say they believe they have determined the identities of the four attackers who stormed the mall. All four of the men are Somali citizens, though one of the men, previously identified as Hassan Abdi Dhuhulow, grew up in Norway. Remains recovered from the mall that are believed to be those of the attackers are still undergoing forensic testing at an F.B.I. laboratory, the Western official said. A Somali militant group, the Shabab, claimed responsibility for the attack. The four men entered the country from Somalia in June and lived in Nairobis Somali neighborhood, Eastleigh. Kenyan authorities initially said that up to 15 assailants were involved in the attack, but only four are visible on mall surveillance tapes. Four other men have been charged as accomplices.

title: For New York Citys Dirt Bikers, There Is No Place to Ride
description: The young man tore down the asphalt, the roar of his dirt bike trailing like a comets tail. When it seemed he could not go any faster, he went higher, hauling the bike into a near-vertical wheelie but never slowing down. A dozen other riders crisscrossed his path, their own front wheels aloft to the perfect fall sky.

title: Venezuela: Former Bank Official Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: A former executive at a Venezuelan bank pleaded guilty in a New York federal court on Monday to charges stemming from a scheme in which she took bribes in exchange for steering millions of dollars of the banks business to an American brokerage firm. The executive, Mara de los Angeles Gonzlez, 55, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, suggesting there could be further revelations about corruption at the government-controlled bank, the Economic and Social Development Bank of Venezuela, known as Bandes. A plea agreement signed by Ms. Gonzlez indicated that the corruption she was involved in went much further than previously revealed and that she admitted involvement in several other payoff schemes at Bandes and another government-run bank where she worked as an officer, Industrial Bank of Venezuela. The agreement said that the charges that Ms. Gonzlez pleaded guilty to carried sentences totaling up to 55 years in jail. Ms. Gonzlez was arrested in Miami in May.

title: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints
description: When United Airlines Flight 175 hit the South Tower, the windows in Mark Scherzers apartment collapsed inward in a fine spray of glass shards. Then the tower collapsed and a metal beam flew in, true as an arrow. Dust, inches thick, covered his floors, bed and shelves.

title: Chile: Former Presidents Coalition Kept in Check
description: Former President Michelle Bachelet, a socialist who is favored to win a runoff election in December against a conservative candidate, Evelyn Matthei, was unable to elect enough lawmakers from her coalition to pass sweeping political proposals, but she still may be able to push through many of her social and economic policies if she is elected. Although the conservative Alliance bloc lost a considerable number of representatives in the lower house, its members retained their seats in the Senate, making it difficult for Ms. Bachelets New Majority coalition to pass constitutional amendments or overhaul the electoral system. Ms. Mattheis far-right party, the Independent Democratic Union, suffered a serious blow in the lower house, losing nine of its 38 seats, while the Communist Party doubled its seats to six. Fewer than half of Chiles potential 13.5 million voters turned out for the presidential election, the first one after voting was made voluntary.

title: Egypt: Security Official Assassinated
description: Gunmen killed a senior Egyptian security official whose responsibilities included investigating Muslim extremists, the Interior Ministry said Monday. The official, Lt. Col. Mohamed Mabrouk, was driving to work in Cairo on Sunday when gunmen fired on it, striking him seven times, according to state media. In September, the interior minister survived when a bomb blew up his convoy. Shootings of lesser security officers around the country have become a near daily occurrence, especially in the relatively lawless Sinai. Egyptian officials have attributed the attacks to Islamist extremists retaliating for the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and the repression of his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood. Colonel Mabrouk had been involved in the investigation and arrests of senior Brotherhood members in recent months, state media reported.

title: Quickly Gaining Value
description: The price of a bitcoin on an exchange that converts them to dollars rose to $780 on Monday, a meteoric gain from its beginnings in 2010.

title: Prosecutor in Racially Charged Shooting Case Near Detroit Is No Stranger to Spotlight
description: DETROIT  For two weeks, the pressure on the prosecutors office here steadily grew.

title: Regulators See Value in Bitcoin, and Investors Hasten to Agree
description: The virtual currency bitcoin took a big step toward the mainstream on Monday as federal authorities signaled their willingness to accept it as a legitimate payment alternative.

title: Central African Republic Stirs Concern
description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, raised the possibility on Monday that thousands of international peacekeeping troops in Africa might have to be temporarily redeployed in the Central African Republic, one of the most unstable on the continent. In a dire report, Mr. Ban said an African Union force that was set to assume peacekeeping and security responsibilities in the Central African Republic might not be ready in time for its December deployment schedule. If there were a precipitous deterioration, Mr. Ban said, the United Nations could respond by moving soldiers from neighboring peacekeeping missions, like those in the Democratic Republic of Congo or Sudan, with the approval of the Security Council and countries contributing troops. Outside Bangui, the capital, government authority is nonexistent, Mr. Ban said, and clashes between rebels and their opponents have become increasingly brutal and sectarian. This cycle, if not addressed now, threatens to degenerate into a countrywide religious and ethnic divide, with the potential to spiral into an uncontrollable situation, including atrocity crimes, with serous national and regional implications, he said.

title: Syd Field, Who Wrote the Book on Writing Screenplays, Dies at 77
description: The term plot point appeared in The New York Times fewer than 10 times during the century or so before 1979. Since then, it has appeared more than 200 times.

title: Despite Storms and Injuries, Bears Stay on Playoff Track
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  Monday morning dawned sunny and bright in the Chicago area, a day after a series of tornadoes touched down across Illinois and high-powered wind and heavy rainfall pummeled the city.

title: A New G.O.P. Excuse for Doing Nothing
description: With unrestrained glee, Republicans are using the calamitous debut of the Affordable Care Act as their latest justification for undermining all of health care reform. But theyre not stopping there. The Obama administrations fumbling is apparently a good excuse for them to do nothing on immigration reform, on a budget agreement, and on any other initiative coming out of the White House.

title: Barbara Park, Author of Junie B. Jones Series, Dies at 66
description: Barbara Park, whose childrens books starring Junie B. Jones, a 6-year-old dispenser of abundant opinions, Runyonesque wisecracks and dubious syntax, have sold tens of millions of copies and delighted all but the most grammatically puritanical parents and teachers, died on Friday at her home in Scottsdale, Ariz. She was 66.

title: The Internet: A Welcome Distraction
description: Every time somebody says to me, Its so impressive how you manage to get writing done despite being on Facebook/Twitter/etc. all the time, I cringe. Ive been hit by a backhanded compliment. Im surfing, tweeting and emailing  leaving my digital prints everywhere and probably picking up some nasty computer viruses  while serious writers are working pristinely, heroically beyond the clutches of the Internet.

title: Death Meted Out by Politicians in Robes
description: In nearly all of the 32 states that permit capital punishment, a jury makes the final decision on whether a defendant will live or die. Not so in Alabama, where elected judges may override a jury verdict of life in prison and unilaterally impose a death sentence.

title: Europeans Fault American Safety Effort in Bangladesh
description: Tensions broke into the open on Monday involving two large groups of retailers  one overwhelmingly American, the other dominated by Europeans  that have formed to improve factory safety in Bangladesh.

title: Flawed Gauge for Cholesterol Risk Poses a New Challenge for Cardiologists
description: This week, cardiologists learned that a new online calculator meant to help them determine a patients suitability for cholesterol treatment was flawed, doubling the estimated risk of heart attack or stroke for the average patient. But fixing it would not be easy, because it is based on older data, and heart attack and stroke rates today are much lower than in decades past, meaning that people are at less risk than might be expected from historical extrapolations.

title: Cholesterol Guidelines Under Attack
description: Patients in good cardiovascular health would be well advised to stay away for now from following the cholesterol guidelines issued last week by the nations two leading heart organizations.

title: She Vanquished a Cruel Addiction, but Challenges Remain
description: Della Murray just didnt care.

title: A Conflict in Geithners New Job? Not Exactly
description: Within 24 hours of Timothy F. Geithners announcement on Saturday that he would join Warburg Pincus, the private equity firm, a parade of naysayers emerged, almost like clockwork, to criticize the former Treasury secretarys move as a prime example of the evil of the governments revolving door.

title: Labor Panel Finds Illegal Punishments at Walmart
description: Walmart illegally disciplined and fired employees over strikes and protests, the National Labor Relations Board said on Monday.

title: Are We Alone in the Universe?
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  THE recent announcement by a team of astronomers that there could be as many as 40 billion habitable planets in our galaxy has further fueled the speculation, popular even among many distinguished scientists, that the universe is teeming with life.

title: Hollywood Studios Facing Upheaval at Highest Levels
description: LOS ANGELES  Advice for the power players at Hollywoods coming round of black-tie galas: Dont leave your seat to table-hop.

title: One Breath, One Last Dive
description: Nicholas Mevoli died at a championship free-diving event in the Bahamas after he returned to the surface from his record attempt.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 18, 2013
Police Give New Meaning to Taped Confession
description: Taped confessions are increasingly common in Chinese police stations. But inventive police officers in Huizhou, far southern China, added a singular twist: literally taping up the would-be confessors.

title: A Divers Rise, and Swift Death, at the Limits of a Growing Sport
description: Nicholas Mevoli saved money from an assortment of jobs to pay for the bottomless pursuit of holding his breath and sinking his body as far as possible into the ocean.

title: Split on Accord on Iran Strains U.S.-Israel Ties
description: WASHINGTON  To the Israeli government, the preliminary deal with Iran that the Obama administration is trying to seal this week is a giveaway to a government that has spent two decades building a vast nuclear program. It enshrines the status quo  at a time when the Iranians are within reach of the technical capability to build a bomb  and rewards some unproven leaders with cash and sanctions relief.

title: Police Say Officer Killed Man Who Threatened With Knife
description: A police officer shot and killed a 22-year-old man in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon after he lunged at the officer with a knife, the authorities said.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 19, 2013
description: Wood cracking, walls falling, you cant imagine what that sounds like.

title: Giants Volunteer for Extra Cowboys Preparation
description: On Monday morning, the Giants were obliged to go to the teams practice complex for only a weight-lifting session. Then the players were free to do as they wanted. Since Tuesday is their customary day off, the Giants were staring at what amounted to almost a two-day break from practice, meetings or film study.

title: Corrections: November 19, 2013
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: A Reunion With an Agenda, for Buddies Going Nowhere
description: A casual reunion of three longtime buddies slouching unprofitably through their 30s ultimately betrays a darker purpose in Small Engine Repair, a raw, funny and well-tooled new play written by and featuring John Pollono, who is making an impressive, double-barreled Off Broadway debut.

title: Take the Bait
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  FOUR SCORE AND SEVEN YEARS AGO  it was 1926, which has absolutely nothing to do with todays puzzle by David J. Kahn. Lets try this a different way.

title: His Honor? Torontos Mayor Rampages On, to Citys Shame
description: TORONTO  The end did not come for Rob Ford, the mayor of this city, when he proclaimed his proclivity for oral sex on live television.

title: Brooklyn Diver Dies After Record Attempt
description: Nicholas Mevolis life and death reflect the spirit, and dangers, of a niche sport that has grown exponentially.

title: Hollandes Assertive Role in Foreign Policy Is a Good Fit for France
description: PARIS  In the past few weeks, President Franois Hollande of France has been booed at a solemn national ceremony and forced to retreat on an element of his economic agenda. He has seen his nations credit rating downgraded and watched as his already-low public support continued to erode.

title: Knicks Demote Smiths Brother
description: The Chris Smith story took another turn Monday when the Knicks assigned him to their N.B.A. Development League affiliate, the Erie BayHawks.

title: Another Website, Another Problem for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Some supporters who tried to log in to hear President Obama defend his embattled health care law on Monday night were unable to hear him because the website of the group behind the call, Organizing for Action, failed to work for them.

title: Libration Under Fire
description: PARIS  Here at Libration, we have blood in the hall. A war zone in the middle of Paris, right by the Place de la Republique. In 2013.

title: Spider-Man to Close on Broadway
description: The $75 million Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, the most expensive theatrical production in history, will close in early January after months of declining ticket sales, one of the lead producers said on Monday night. A somewhat revamped version of the show is being planned for Las Vegas in 2015, according to the producer, Jeremiah J. Harris.

title: Stop Animal Circus Shows, Advocates Tell Government
description: With Bengal tigers, Asian elephants, chimpanzees, parrots and poodles among dozens of animals due to perform at an international circus in southern China starting on Wednesday, more than 30 animal rights organizations have petitioned the government, a partner in the event, to cancel the shows because of cruelty to the animals.

title: Felton Is Missing Shots, and Those He Guards Are Not
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Raymond Felton was a spectator for most of Mondays practice. He sat on a training table next to Tyson Chandler, whose fractured right leg was no longer encased in a protective boot. This counted as progress for the Knicks, whose training facility has doubled as a sanitarium this season.

title: Frackings Achilles Heel
description: Its not very often that someone starts his career as a geologist and then winds up as governor, but John Hickenlooper, the governor of Colorado, can make that claim. We had fracking when I was a working geologist in 1981, he told me on Monday. It was very primitive. What really changed the world is when we got horizontal drilling. It was a technique that allowed you to recover a lot more natural gas.

title: Songs of Remembrance for Voices Now Silenced
description: The photos showed them as they had been: Arash Farazmand, 28, bent over his drums; his brother, Soroush Farazmand, 27, with his guitar; their friend and roommate, Ali Eskandarian, 35, smiling as he sang into a microphone. Candles burned below their names, illuminating messages of love and remembrance left for them in English and Persian: I love you; thank you for the beautiful moments; three hearts.

title: A Talk That Stirred Fear of Antigay Bias Is Postponed at a Bronx High School
description: Ever since Pope Francis spoke compassionately about gay people last summer  saying, Who am I to judge?  Roman Catholics around the world have debated the meaning of his words.

title: Billy Hardwick, Hall of Fame Bowler, Dies at 72
description: Billy Hardwick, the first bowler to win all three of the most prestigious Professional Bowlers Association tournaments, or the triple crown, died Saturday near his home in Bradenton, Fla. He was 72.

title: Natural Disasters or 'Acts of God'?
Investment Gives Rise to Youth in Mexico
description: In Guanajuato, Mexico, foreign investment and local enrichment are cultivating a young, upwardly mobile middle class.

title: In Middle of Mexico, a Middle Class Rises
description: GUANAJUATO, Mexico  A decade ago, Ivan Zamora, 23, might have already left for the United States. Instead, he graduated in May from a gleaming new university here, then moved on to an engineering internship at one of the many multinational companies just beyond the campus gates.

title: With His Career Winding Down, Iginla Focuses on Winning a Stanley Cup
description: WILMINGTON, Mass.  Jarome Iginla calls it the driver. It has nothing to do with golf clubs or chauffeurs, but instead refers to a mind-set, a laserlike pursuit of the missing item on an almost certain Hall of Fame rsum: a Stanley Cup title.

title: Latest Release of Documents on N.S.A. Includes 2004 Ruling on Email Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration released hundreds of pages of newly declassified documents related to National Security Agency surveillance late Monday, including an 87-page ruling in which the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court first approved a program to systematically track Americans emails during the Bush administration.

title: John Edwards Revisits His Past, Hanging Law Shingle Again
description: Before he served as a United States senator, before he made a run at the presidency and before his political career collapsed amid a sex scandal and fraud trial, John Edwards was a trial lawyer.

title: Casting Light on Little-Known Story of Albania Rescuing Jews From Nazis
description: There were a handful of European nations where the Nazi killing machine sputtered, but few seem more remarkable and less illuminated than Albania.

title: Nets Start Fast but Lose Momentum and the Game
description: Up and down the Nets fortunes have bobbed through the early part of this season. Good vibes have remained ephemeral. Success has been fleeting.

title: Sticking With Quarterback Grows More Risky for Ryan
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan has been burdened with turnover-prone quarterbacks during his tenure as the Jets coach, and he has handled them with incredible patience. Only once, after the Week 15 mess in Tennessee last year, has he benched the starter.

title: After N.S.A. Disclosures, Yahoo Moves to Encrypt Internal Traffic
description: Thanks to the revelations of Edward Snowden, technology companies are feverishly enabling new security features in an effort to assure users, particularly abroad, that they are doing everything possible to secure their data from hackers and the National Security Agency.

title: Medicare Part D: Republican Budget-Busting
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Word of the Day | defrock
description: defrock \()de-frk\ verb

title: Hawkins Leaves Mets for Rockies
description: LaTroy Hawkins, 40, followed Marlon Byrds lead, becoming the latest Met to play well enough to price himself out of the teams plans. Hawkins agreed to a one-year, $2.5 million contract with the Colorado Rockies, and will have a chance to be the teams closer, according to a source with knowledge of the negotiations. In 72 relief appearances with the Mets, Hawkins compiled a 2.93 earned run average and had 13 saves.

title: Another Animated Take on Bloomberg News
description: Next Media Animation of Taiwan is staying at the vanguard of coverage of the Bloomberg News self-censorship saga. It has posted its second take on the scandal  which, of course, Bloomberg says is not a scandal. Top Bloomberg editors have denied killing a story on a Chinese tycoon and his ties to Communist Party leaders for political reasons, despite accounts from several Bloomberg employees that that was the case.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 4:45 P.M. (IFC) JACKIE BROWN (1997) Pam Grier, above, stars as Jackie Brown, a flight attendant who makes ends meet by smuggling money from Mexico to the United States for a gun dealer named Ordell Robbie (Samuel L. Jackson) in this adaptation of the book Rum Punch, by Elmore Leonard, written for the screen and directed by Quentin Tarantino. When she is caught by a government agent (Michael Keaton), Jackie seeks to escape her menial existence with the help of a kindly bail bondsman (Robert Forster). Among the best news about the film is that Samuel L. Jacksons role is even splashier than the one he had in Pulp Fiction and that his performance is even more of a treat, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. The film more than justifies its long, happy stretches of simply watching Ordell work his scams on the unsuspecting.

title: News Quiz | November 19, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Conversation With: Indias Chief Climate Change Negotiator Ravi Shankar Prasad
description: WARSAW, Poland  The annual United Nations climate change conference, which runs from Nov. 11 to 22, started with an emotional appeal from the Philippine negotiator Yeb Sano, who declared that he would be fasting until a meaningful outcome is in sight in the wake of the staggering devastation from Typhoon Haiyan in his country.

title: Beirut Bombs Strike at Iran as Assads Ally
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A double bombing struck the Iranian Embassy compound in Beirut on Tuesday, in the deadliest assault on Irans interests since it emerged as the most forceful backer of the Syrian government against an armed insurgency. The frontal attack struck a symbol of the countrys powerful influence in Lebanon and neighboring Syria.

title: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 19, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Tweets From the Past Make History Come Alive
description: In History Comes to Life With Tweets From Past, Noam Cohen writes about current historical tweeting projects.

title: Chinese Nobel Winner Appealing Subversion Conviction
description: HONG KONG  Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned Chinese dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, will challenge his 2009 conviction on subversion charges in court, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

title: Dutch Firm to Spin Off Drug-Making Business in $2.6 Billion Deal
description: LONDON  The Dutch life and materials sciences company Royal DSM said on Tuesday that it would spin off its pharmaceutical manufacturing business into a $2.6 billion joint venture with the New York private equity firm JLL Partners.

title: What Does Cancer Smell Like?
description: On a lab bench in Philadelphia sits a tiny box lined with nearly invisible nanotubes and gold. A clear plastic pipe runs through it, and a thicket of pins, each sprouting a red or blue wire, protrudes from its end. As air from the pipe wafts over the nanotubes, electrical signals surge out of the box along the wire threads. The whole apparatus is situated near a vial of blood, sniffing the air above it through the pipe.

title: Why Is Turkey Cheaper When Demand Is Higher?
description: When you do your Thanksgiving shopping this week, you will encounter two vastly different options for the centerpiece: an expensive heritage, organic, antibiotic-free, freshly killed turkey; or a relatively cheap, mass-produced, rock-solid-frozen bird. The frozen birds are a pretty attractive deal  especially because this time of year, they are unusually cheap. According to government data, frozen whole-turkey prices drop significantly every November; over the last decade, retail prices have fallen an average of 9 percent between October and November.

title: Has Facebook Lost Its Edge?
description: Last week Facebook offered billions of dollars to buy Snapchat, the social media app that lets users send posts that disappear shortly after being viewed. When the yet-to-be-profitable upstart refused the whopping 10-digit offer, many have started asking the same question: Is Facebook losing its edge? What do you think?

title: Josef Koudelka: Formed by the World
description: We highly recommend viewing the slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: For Young Typhoon Survivors, Return of Play Is a Sign of Hope
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  At a typhoon refugee center on Samar Island in the Philippines, the traumatized children have slowly begun adjusting to their new normal.

title: U.S. Budget Battles Seen as a Global Drag on Growth
description: FRANKFURT  Nervousness about United States monetary policy and fears of a budget and borrowing breakdown in Washington are creating a bigger drag on the global economy than expected, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned on Tuesday. The report was a more pessimistic view of global growth than six months ago.

title: Daily Report: Dropbox Said to Seek $250 Million in New Funding
description: Online storage, once a backwater of the Silicon Valley technology scene, is suddenly a hot commodity, Quentin Hardy and David Gelles report.

title: New York Today: Beware of Leaves
description: Updated 11:53 a.m. | Every year around this time, a silent menace threatens the regions transit system.

title: Voter Turnout in Nepal Is Heavy Despite Violence
description: NEW DELHI  Voters crowded polling stations across Nepal on Tuesday, defying attempts by a powerful Maoist group and other parties to disrupt or prevent new elections for an assembly to write a new constitution.

title: Can Right-Wing Grandparents Views on Homosexuality Be Changed?
description: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Assessing a Kevin OLeary Investment on Shark Tank
description: Recently, when I sat down to watch the ABC reality show Shark Tank with my children, I was surprised to see a merchant cash advance lender, Total Merchant Resources, pitching the Sharks. Typically, the companies that present on the show offer a unique service or product. Instead, Total Merchant Resources is a me too player in the highly commoditized and competitive alternative-lending industry.

title: Storm Brings Flooding and Destruction to Sardinia
description: ROME  Streets and fields were flooded, homes and cars were submerged, and at least 16 people were killed on the Mediterranean island of Sardinia after 17 inches of rain  half a years worth  pummeled the island over a 24-hour period.

title: Take Me to the River, From Al Green to Song Dogs
description: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Edwards Opens Law Firm
description: Before he served as a United States senator, before he made a run at the presidency and before his political career collapsed amid a sex scandal and fraud trial, John Edwards was a trial lawyer, Peter Lattman and Kim Severson write in DealBook. Now, Mr. Edwards is returning to his roots and opening a new law practice. The plaintiffs firm, Edwards Kirby, reunites him with his former partner, David F.
