Kirby, and includes on its payroll his eldest daughter, Cate Edwards.

title: Fujifilm Finds Niche With Old-Style Cameras That Mask a High-Tech Core
description: TOKYO  Like many professional photographers, Irwin Wong, who shoots pictures for Japanese magazines, relies on digital single-lens reflex cameras for the bulk of his work  bulk being the operative word.

title: My Mother, the Secret Communist
description: In 1928, my mother, Mary, dropped out of Hunter College to enter the family business: the domestic and international advancement of communism.

title: International Style
description: This week, a few more highlights from the recent revisions in The Timess stylebook.

title: In Performance: Zachary Quinto of The Glass Menagerie
description: In the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williamss memory play The Glass Menagerie, Zachary Quinto plays Tom Wingfield, an aspiring writer and warehouse worker  and the plays narrator  who lives in a cramped St. Louis apartment with his mother, Amanda, and his sister, Laura. In this scene, Tom talks about watching couples at a dance hall across from their home. The show, directed by John Tiffany, continues through Feb. 23 at the Booth Theater.

title: China Offers Hospital Ship to the Philippines
description: Updated, 2:04 a.m. ET | After an outsized international effort to help the Philippines that has been notable for Chinas slow response, it appears the Chinese authorities are trying to reverse the damage to their countrys image.

title: After 3 Fires, Safety Agency Opens Inquiry Into Tesla Model S
description: DETROIT  A federal safety investigation of the Tesla Motors electric Model S sedan announced on Tuesday comes at a critical juncture for the car and the company.

title: No Money, and a Growing Line at Starbucks
description: Dear Diary:

title: Mapping Bitcoin
description: Bitcoin, the popular Internet currency, is on the map in more ways than one.

title: Obstruction of Gossip
description: Updated, Nov. 20, 2013 | The singer mentioned in this post can now be named; the gag order has been lifted. He is Eyal Golan.

title: Guwahatis Cosmetic Development
description: I come from Guwahatia small town in the northeastern part of India, I used to tell my friends in Minnesota, until one person asked me how large is Guwahati. When I answered, he looked at me shocked, A small town ofonly1.4 million people? I smiled sheepishly because it was partly true, and partly untrue. Untrue because I had grown up believing that my Guwahati is a small town. True because, nowadays even I suspect that during my absence over the yearslike a young girl in a large family  Guwahati has as if stealthily grown up without my notice.

title: The Geezers Are Not Alright
description: The Washington Post editorial board wants to cut Medicare and Social Security. That has been its consistent position as long as I can remember. And what it advocates, always, are cuts in benefits, not costs  that is, while it may give lip service to efforts to control health-care costs (which seem to be going surprisingly well, in one of the untold success stories of Obamacare), what it has pushed repeatedly are things like a rise in the Medicare age. These are the kind of moves that are considered serious inside the Beltway. And as you might imagine, the Post has gone wild over recent suggestions that Social Security should be expanded, not cut.

title: Changing Coaches Has Improved Fortunes in N.F.L.
description: N.F.L. teams are rarely patient. Owners and general managers are more apt to replace a struggling coach than to support him. This past off-season, eight teams switched coaches, not including New Orleans, which welcomed the return of Sean Payton after his one-year suspension. A coaching hire typically takes years to evaluate, but through 12 weeks, all eight coaches are either exceeding expectations or providing hope for the future.

title: Carriers Reject a Kill Switch for Preventing Cellphone Theft
description: Lawmakers in San Francisco and New York are pushing cellphone makers to adopt a so-called kill switch that would allow users to deactivate their phone remotely, discouraging criminals from stealing phones. But the cellphone carriers are not on board.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Uniform Wares Watch
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Sunday Style in Johannesburg
description: At the Maboneng Precinct in South Africas largest city, locals find style inspiration from their parents and African prints worn in a modern way.

title: Progressive Caucus Seeks to Influence Race for New York Council Speaker
description: The populist groundswell that swept Bill de Blasio to victory in New Yorks mayoral election is reshaping the City Council as well, with a cadre of fiercely liberal council members demanding a voice in choosing that bodys next speaker.

title: The Catch an Illegal Immigrant Game
description: The chapter of Young Conservatives of Texas at the University of Texas at Austin is planning on doing a silly thing on Wednesday. It has announced a game it calls Catch an Illegal Immigrant, in which students will walk around campus with the words Illegal Immigrant pinned to their clothing. People who spot and escort these students back to Y.C.T. will be given a $25 gift card.The organization says it means to provoke a thoughtful discussion of a hot-button issue, but that is just a straight-faced put-on for what is really a sophomoric provocation.

title: Another Taylor Rule
description: Or at least it seems to be a new rule  namely, pick whatever price index makes the point you want, even if its not at all the price index you would normally use.

title: Chairman of Co-Operative Group Resigns Amid Scandal
description: Updated, 12:05 p.m. | LONDON  The chairman of the British food and financial services conglomerate Co-operative Group resigned on Tuesday amid media reports that the former top executive of its banking business was purportedly caught on video buying illegal drugs.

title: Waging War on a Shoestring
description: SIMI VALLEY, Ca.  The four-star commander of all Air Force combat jets earned an audible gasp from the audience of national security specialists with his disclosure about American vulnerabilities brought on by the spending stalemate back in Washington.

title: Photo of Palestinian Mother Was the Wrong Choice
description: Hundreds of readers wrote to me in recent days to protest the prominent use of a photograph that accompanied an article in The Times last Thursday.

title: Report Documents a Rise in Fatal Shootings by New York Citys Police Officers
description: A knife-wielding man shot dead by New York police officers in the doorway of his Harlem apartment. An officer struck by a bullet in the base of his skull. A marked police van rattled by seven bullets as a group of officers sat inside.

title: Whom or What Are Literary Prizes For?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Jennifer Szalai on the value of literary prizes.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving 2013: Find Your Favorites
description: Every fall, Well pays tribute to the best part of the Thanksgiving table  the vegetable side dishes!

title: Grace Club Gets a Redesign by Thom Filicia
description: Grace Bay Club, an upscale hotel in the Turks & Caicos, is giving itself a 20th-birthday present: a remodeling job by the celebrated designer Thom Filicia.

title: Image of the Day: November 19
A Short Sneak Peek at a New Robert Mitchum Documentary
description: For the last 12 years, by his own count, the photographer and filmmaker Bruce Weber has been assembling a documentary about Robert Mitchum, the movie star (and sometime recording artist) who died in 1997. It sounds like a natural counterpart to Mr. Webers gossamer 1988 masterpiece, Lets Get Lost, about the jazz trumpet player Chet Baker.

title: U.S. Striker Keeps Eye on His Next Target
description: VIENNA  The United States national soccer team will conclude its 2013 schedule with an exhibition against Austria on Tuesday. The result of the game will be of little consequence, but for many players it will be an important opportunity to make a case to be on next years World Cup roster.

title: Israel Rejects Bid to Free Suspected Qaeda Operative
description: JERUSALEM  Israels Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected an appeal for the release of a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian who has been held in Israel without trial for more than three years, accused by the Israeli authorities of being a biological weapons expert in the service of Al Qaeda.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Equity in the Workplace
Typhoon Haiyans Epicenter
description: The Timess Andrew Jacobs travels to Guiuan, on Samar Island, the Philippines, where residents are trying to resume normal life amid the devastation.

title: On YouTube, Iranian Minister Says Join Us in Ending Crisis
description: As soft piano music plays in the background, the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, strides through a vast, elegant hallway, skips down carpeted steps and pushes through glass-paneled doors. Then, seated, he looks directly at a video camera and asks: What is dignity? What is respect? Are they negotiable? Is there a price tag?

title: The Other Gettysburg Address
description: Even before the address was given, Americans knew that a great speech was coming, and that it would come at Gettysburg. The battle had been so comprehensive, and its result so profound, that a lasting statement was needed to mark the burial of the dead. That the final resting place of the soldiers was in the North, conveniently close to media outlets, only added to the logic of a solemn utterance for the ages. Accordingly, an invitation went out to the person most likely to give it.

title: Johnson & Johnson in Deal to Settle Hip Implant Lawsuits
description: Johnson & Johnson and lawyers for patients injured by a flawed hip implant announced a multibillion-dollar deal on Tuesday to settle thousands of lawsuits, but it was not clear whether the deal would satisfy enough claimants.

title: Night Falls, and 5Pointz, a Graffiti Mecca, Is Whited Out in Queens
description: Graffiti is often denounced as vandalism, but the deliriously festooned, sprawling warehouses at the western edge of Queens rose far above that. Blanketed with giddy images, drawing street artists from around the world, 5Pointz was a decades-old legal haven considered both a United Nations of Graffiti and a semi-rebellious statement in a city some feel is growing too antiseptic. Save 5Pointz, the infamous British street artist Banksy urged in his final message to New Yorkers, after he wrapped his monthlong spree clandestinely decorating the citys streets in October.

title: From the Makers of Bonobos, a Shopping Site for the Ladies
description: Since 2007, men have been ordering pants from Bonobos.com, trying them on at home and returning them if they dont fit. It was a way of shopping that fit the lifestyle of 20- and 30-somethings: without ever setting foot in a store or having to pay shipping costs. Today, the team behind Bonobos introduces Ayr.com, the womens version of their successful mens wear clearing house. Initially, the site will offer two styles of denim: skinny jeans ($175) and a cigarette leg ($165), each available in either a light or a dark wash. I like to say you could do yoga in these jeans, said the design director Jac Cameron, a veteran of Calvin Klein and Madewell. I wanted to recreate a silhouette working with the stretch of the fabric to create a jean that molds to the body as you wear it.

title: Dallas, 50 Years After an Assassination
description: Half a century after President John F. Kennedy was killed, the city has been coming to grips with the worst moment in its history.

title: Contest Aims for a Cleaner-Burning Wood Stove
description: WASHINGTON  Only blocks away, the Energy Department manages the search for quarks and NASA scours the heavens for Earth-like planets. But inside a big white tent on the National Mall, the focus is on something simpler: oak, ash and elm, and how to make them heat a house with as little pollution as possible.

title: Four Principal Dancers at City Ballet to Retire
description: Four principal dancers with New York City Ballet  Jenifer Ringer, Janie Taylor, Sbastien Marcovici and Jonathan Stafford  will retire during the 2014 winter and spring seasons, the company announced Tuesday.

title: 50 Years Later, a Changed Dallas Grapples With Its Darkest Day
description: DALLAS  When President John F. Kennedys motorcade left the airport here shortly before noon on Nov. 22, 1963, the man seated in the lead car was the county sheriff, Bill Decker, 65, a storied Texas lawman who led the hunt for Bonnie and Clyde. Fifty years later, the badge belongs to Lupe Valdez, 66, the daughter of Mexican migrant farmworkers. She is the only sheriff in America who is an openly gay Hispanic woman. Voters re-elected Sheriff Valdez, a Democrat, to a third term last year.

title: Monty Python Troupe to Reunite for Live Shows
description: A certain Norwegian Blue parrot is still dead, nearly 44 years after it shuffled off its mortal coil and joined the choir invisible in a famous television comedy sketch. But there is life yet in Monty Python, the singularly influential British troupe, whose surviving members are to announce this week that they will join together for their first live performances in more than a decade.

title: Selfie Trumps Twerk as Oxford Dictionaries Word of the Year
description: Selfie  defined as a photograph that one has taken of oneself, typically one taken with a smartphone or webcam and uploaded to a social media website  has beaten out twerk, bitcoin and other comers to claim the title of Oxford Dictionaries 2013 Word of the Year.

title: An Art Teacher Preserves the History of Harlem, While Creating Her Own Legacy
description: She was only 6 years old and a first grader at a Catholic school in Harlem. But stepping into an art class at St. Aloysius taught by Alice Mizrachi steered Chayse Sheppards life at a young age in ways she did not fully appreciate until she was older.

title: Today in Small Business: Turkey Shortage?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: In Our Pages: November 20
description: 1913: Dog Rescues Starving Lost Pet

title: Nashs Return From Concussion Isnt Enough as Rangers Fall to Bruins
description: Tuukka Rask and his Boston teammates were too much for the Rangers and a returning Rick Nash to surmount Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, where the Bruins skated to a 2-1 victory.

title: Afghans Demand That U.S. Admit Military Errors
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Months of fraught negotiations and public posturing over how a long-term American military force could remain in Afghanistan have suddenly come down to a demand for a single personal gesture: a display of contrition by President Obama for military mistakes that have hurt Afghans.

title: Start-Up Founders Look Beyond the Usual Options of Selling or Going Public
description: Successful tech entrepreneurs eventually face a choice, known in Silicon Valley as an exit: either sell their start-ups to bigger companies or take them public. As we wrote on Monday, that decision can be painful and personal. And like Snapchats rejection of Facebooks billion-dollar offer, it is often a high-stakes bet.

title: Whos Putting a Roof Over Parents Heads
description: Do you really need that in-law suite?

title: Virginia Political Figure Stabbed as Son Takes Own Life, Police Say
description: State Senator R. Creigh Deeds, a leading Virginia political figure who ran unsuccessfully for governor in 2009, was stabbed repeatedly on Tuesday at his home during an altercation with his son, who then apparently took his own life, the authorities said.

title: Senator Offers Overhaul of Corporate Tax Code
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the powerful Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday released a long-awaited plan to overhaul the tax code for multinational corporations, trying to jump-start an effort to stem the flow of jobs and money abroad.

title: The Illusions of Employer-Based Health Insurance
description: My Sunday column closed with a warning to conservatives that Obamacare at least in some form may turn out to be more durable than its disastrous rollout would seem to suggest, because the nature of the welfare state means that even programs that dont live up to their promises can be awfully hard to dislodge. (As a case in point, see the outcome of the weekends House election in Louisiana, where the anti-establishment, right-wing, Duck Dynasty-endorsed winner was also  in favor of Obamacares Medicaid expansion.)

title: McKinsey & Company Report on the Health Care Law and the Website
description: A report by McKinsey & Company warned in March that HeathCare.gov was at risk of failure.

title: S.E.C. Official Charged With Making False Statements
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission official was criminally charged on Tuesday with making false statements about stock holdings that he wasnt allowed to own under the agencys ethics rules.

title: Caring for Aging Parents, Even From a Distance
description: THROUGH the 1990s, Patrick Quirkes career was sailing along. Every few years, he would be promoted at the transportation company where he worked and move to another city. He said he had every reason to believe that he would be promoted to the companys headquarters in a few more moves. Then, his parents health started to decline.

title: John Hodgman to Highlight Under the Radar Festival
description: John Hodgman of Daily Show and Apple commercials fame, is heading downtown as a first-time participant in the Under the Radar festival, the Public Theaters annual program of experimental works, which runs Jan. 8 to 19.

title: Police Station Is Attacked by the Shabab in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Attackers from the Shabab militant group assaulted a police station in a Somali town north of Mogadishu on Tuesday, leaving at least 28 people dead and scores more wounded.

title: A Bob Dylan Video 47 Years in the Making
description: Promotional video clips were hardly unknown when Bob Dylan released Like a Rolling Stone as a single in 1965, but Mr. Dylan never made one for the song. Now Columbia, his record label, is making up for that oversight with a newly produced web video for the song, mainly to promote The Complete Album Collection, Volume 1, a 47-CD set that includes all of Mr. Dylans studio albums, six live sets and a two-disc rarities compilation. But in the process, the company is redefining the way promotional clips are viewed.

title: The Gun Report: November 19, 2013
description: A California law prohibiting anyone convicted of domestic violence from possessing a gun is a legitimate and constitutional measure to keep firearms out of the wrong hands, a federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Wheelies: The Turbo Honda Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Grace Kelly on J.F.K.: An Animated Interview
description: In keeping with the (rightfully) bottomless wellspring of Kennedy retrospectives this month, the web series Blank on Blank made its own contribution today with an excerpted interview with Grace Kelly recorded not long after the presidents assassination. Set to video and accompanied by the animation of Patrick Smith, Princess Grace speaks of Kennedys fashion sense and youthful optimism, and she strains to find meaning in the tragedy that had just played out in front of the world.

title: What Is Harry Reid Waiting For?
description: For the third time in as many weeks, Senate Republicans have blocked a judicial nominee to the second most powerful court in the country, and for the third time it is not because they doubt his qualifications  how could they? Hes a sitting district court judge who was unanimously confirmed by the Senate just three years ago. Nor is it because they fear he harbors an extreme ideology.

title: Perks Ease Way in Health Plans for Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress like to boast that they will have the same health care enrollment experience as constituents struggling with the balky federal website, because the law they wrote forced lawmakers to get coverage from the new insurance exchanges.

title: Antiquated Trades Endangered in a Rapidly Changing Myanmar
description: In every society, professions disappear in the name of progress. But Myanmars rapid modernization has accelerated that process for roadside phone shops, rubber stamp businesses and other trades.

title: As Myanmar Modernizes, Old Trades Are Outpaced by New Competitors
description: YANGON, Myanmar  For years they poured out their hearts on the broken pavements of Myanmars cities and towns, young lovers desperate for privacy yet with no choice but to use what the Burmese call roadside phone shops.

title: Handset Unit Nearly Sold, Nokia Now Looks to an Uncertain Future
description: HELSINKI, Finland  Nokias shareholders took a major step on Tuesday to reshape the company, voting overwhelmingly in favor of selling the companys handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion.

title: Opposition Voiced to Return of Klimt Work to Heirs of Former Owner
description: Two groups connected to theSecessionbuilding in Vienna, where Gustav Klimts monumental Beethoven Frieze is housed, have spoken out against aclaim by heirsof its former owner to recover the artwork. Last month heirs of the Lederer family, Jews who owned the four-ton frieze before the Nazis annexation of Austria in 1938, filed a claim with Austrias Art Restitution Advisory Board, arguing that after World War II the government had in effect used its power to grant export licenses to compel the family to sell the work at a cut-rate price to the state.

title: Living in Island Park, L.I.
description: Though pummeled by Hurricane Sandy, this affordable South Shore community is rebounding.

title: Island Park: Sandy as Mother of Reinvention
description: Last year, two days after Hurricane Sandy walloped the islet of Island Park, Rosmarie T. Bovino, the school superintendent, along with her principals and teachers, walked the square mile of the school district to see what each of its families needed. Though the two schools, the administration building and the public library had been devastated, Dr. Bovino, who calls the schools the heart of the village, wanted to make sure the children had food to eat.

title: An Odd Spinoff by Royal DSM
description: Royal DSM has come up with an odd formulation to solve its drug-production headache. The company, which is the worlds biggest vitamin maker, is merging its DSM Pharmaceutical Products business with a private equity-backed rival.

title: Israeli Military Stalls a College Career
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.  For months, Tom Maayan had been the focal point of an international tug of war, pitting the Israeli military against a major American university, while clouding what looked to be a bright basketball career. But when Maayan, a sophomore at Seton Hall, returned to the bustling campus here Aug. 16, after five months of army service in Upper Galilee, the northern Israeli province where he was raised, it was with a sense of relief.

title: Grand Vision for Former Home of Walter Reed Hospital
description: WASHINGTON  The boxy Brutalist hospital built in the late 1970s stands virtually vacant, as do brick buildings erected during World War I, officers quarters dating to the 1920s or before, and myriad other structures that together make up the former Army medical center named for Walter Reed, the physician who linked mosquitoes to yellow fever at the turn of the 20th century.

title: Pratt Institute Celebrates Four Leaders in Design and Culture
description: On Nov. 11, more than 350 people, including the singer Judy Collins, attended Pratt Institutes Legends 2013 gala benefit, which honored four eminences in design and culture and raised nearly $800,000 for student scholarships. Held at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in New York, the event was hosted by Ted Allen, of the Food Network series Chopped. The honorees were the writer Pete Hamill; the artist James Turrell; David Easton, an interior designer; and Margaret Russell, the editor in chief of Architectural Digest.

title: Jury Selection Begins in SAC Insider Trading Trial
description: Updated, 5:36 p.m. | Selection of a 12-member jury from a pool of about 100 people began on Tuesday at the insider trading trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager.

title: Now With High-Tech Gifts for the Holidays
description: For a moment, you might think youre in Oz. Nine huge, shining, transparent spheres rise into the air and drift inexorably toward you, as if nine versions of Glinda the Good Witch were about to burst forth.

title: Taking Aspirin at Night May Boost Heart Benefits
description: Millions of adults take an aspirin every morning to ward off heart disease. But a new study suggests that the pills might be most effective if taken right before bed.

title: Will Forte on the Glories of the Great Plains
description: In the new film Nebraska, Will Forte plays the dutiful son to Bruce Derns curmudgeonly father who is convinced he has become a sweepstakes millionaire.

title: In Extracting Deal From JPMorgan, U.S. Aimed for Bottom Line
description: Updated, 9:44 p.m. | When Tony West arrived in a Justice Department conference room to put the finishing touches on a lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase, he saw a familiar number flash on his cellphone.

title: Jostens Agrees to Buy Rival in Commemorative Paraphernalia
description: Jostens, a seller of yearbooks and class rings to students across the United States, is looking to gain a bigger piece of the business of school spirit.

title: Calico, Google Health Venture, Names New Hires
description: The new Google-backed venture to extend the human lifespan has hired away the head of global product development from Roche, the pharmaceutical giant, as well as a noted molecular biologist from Princeton.

title: Brenda Fryson: Mayor of Stoops
description: Brenda Fryson manages a long list of community organizations, committees and revitalization and development projects from a home office she calls The War Room.

title: The Bats Blog Is on the Move
description: Thank you for visiting Bats. This blogs regular features, including live game analysis, news and notes from Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and others, and other coverage, can now be found on the baseball section of our website. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely baseball news.

title: Holiday
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Charlotte Zolotow, Author of Books on Childrens Real Issues, Dies at 98
description: Charlotte Zolotow, a distinguished author and editor of childrens books whose work  both her own titles and those of the writers in her stable  offered even the youngest readers a forthright view of emotionally fraught subjects like anger, envy and death, died on Tuesday at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 98.

title: Devon Said to Be Near Deal to Buy GeoSouthern for $6 Billion
description: Devon Energy is near a deal to buy GeoSouthern Energy, a privately held oil and gas driller, for about $6 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Craig Bierko Wont Return to Matilda
description: Weeks after announcing a lengthy medical leave from the plum role of Miss Trunchbull in Matilda the Musical, Craig Bierko has bowed out of the Broadway production entirely.

title: Senate Majority Leader Backs Gillibrand on Military Assault Measure
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, on Tuesday threw his support behind a measure that would give military prosecutors the power to decide which sexual assault cases to try, rather than commanders.

title: Murdoch Divorce Said to Be Almost Final
description: Rupert Murdoch and Wendi Deng Murdoch are negotiating the final details of their divorce settlement, a deal that will officially end the 14-year marriage of the media mogul and his third wife, according to people with direct knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Relief Efforts Improve in Storm-Hit Areas
description: Medical care is beginning to take hold, with 62 foreign or Filipino medical teams now working in areas with the most damage.

title: Bipartisan Assent to Hold Off New Iran Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  In a meeting with Senate leaders on Tuesday, President Obama failed to sway critics of his effort to sign an interim nuclear deal with Iran. But in a modest concession, they agreed to hold off on a vote to impose new sanctions on Iran until after talks in Geneva later this week.

title: Making Healthy Treats of Halloween Leftovers
description: Am I the only one with Halloween candy still hanging around the house?

title: No Budget, Because HealthCare.gov
description: After they were blamed for causing a disastrous shutdown, many Republicans seemed to want to get the years budget fights behind them. As of a few weeks ago, some of them seemed open to relieving the sequester, which is widely hated by lawmakers in both parties, and Congressional appropriators thought they had a chance to enact real spending bills instead of running the government with yet another continuing resolution.

title: Update for a Global Medical App
description: HTH Worldwide, which offers health insurance and other products to those travelling internationally, has made updates to its mobile application, mPassport, adding more translations of drug names and medical phrases and providing regional health alerts.

title: $13 Billion JPMorgan Settlement
description: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department finalized a $13 billion settlement, punctuating a long legal battle over the risky mortgage practices that became synonymous with the financial crisis.

title: Piora
description: Inside the West Village restaurant where Korean flavors dart in and out of the menu.

title: A Marriage of Ingenuity
description: You can put up with mediocre food in a restaurant that has other things going for it. When an exciting chef works in a terrible dining room, though, you feel the way you do when a friend hooks up with somebody you cant stand. You may visit the two of them once or twice to savor the full extent of the new partners awfulness, but then you run for cover while you await the end.

title: Monetary and Fiscal Implications of Secular Stagnation
description: Since I gave Larry Summerss endorsement of secular stagnation theory a plug, Ive been getting a lot of commentary in various forms. Some of it is the usual Keynes-hatred and/or incomprehension, and not worth going into. But there are also some questions/complaints that call for some serious further exegesis.

title: Minis 3rd-Generation Hardtop Shows Subtle Aesthetic Changes
description: Next years calendars are already out, including one called Pug Mugs, which displays police-style headshots of adorable dogs. Mini could produce a calendar like that, now that the bulldog of cars has unveiled its third generation since BMW rolled out the first of the reborn Minis 13 years ago.

title: Kids These Days: Theyre All Older Than 50
description: When did mature get so immature?

title: Woman Says Zimmerman Choked Her During Fight
description: George Zimmerman, whose February 2012 killing of an unarmed black teenager propelled him to the center of an emotional national debate about self-defense laws, choked his girlfriend during an argument this month, a Florida prosecutor said on Tuesday.

title: How the Safety Net Held Up in the Recession
description: Finally, some kind words for government. Robert A. Moffitt, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, says in a new paper that the countrys social safety net did a good job during the recession, expanding by half a trillion dollars.

title: Ronaldos 3 Goals Carry Portugal to World Cup Berth
description: The original pool of hopefuls had 207 teams, a diverse group of soccer nations ranging from minnows to monoliths that nonetheless had a common destination in mind. Now, more than 800 qualifying matches later, the field of 32 teams that will take part in the World Cup next year in Brazil is all but complete.

title: Fantasy Football Week 12: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
description: As if the 2013 N.F.L. season were not strange enough, we are now at the point where 4-6 is a respectable record in the A.F.C. Unfortunately, 4-6 will probably not get you into your fantasy football playoffs, so it is time to buckle down with leagues a few weeks away from the postseason.

title: Enduring Nazi Law Impedes Recovery of Art
description: HALLE, Germany  Wolfgang Bche was amazed this month when a watercolor seized by the Nazis from the small museum in this eastern city, where he is the curator, reappeared, part of a vast trove uncovered in a Munich apartment.

title: Gotham West Market, a New Food Hall, Opens on the West Side
description: Headliner

title: Vatican Unveils Revamped Catacombs Museum
description: ROME  Celebrating the meeting of ancient and modern worlds, the Vatican on Tuesday presented a revamped museum of antique funerary remains in Rome, while inviting the rest of the world to peek inside that space by computer.

title: One Bach Influencing the Other
description: In his new book, Bach: Music in the Castle of Heaven, the conductor John Eliot Gardiner persuasively expands our sense of the influence that the brilliant composer Johann Christoph Bach (1642-1703) may have had on his young cousin Johann Sebastian (1685-1750). The two mens music, Mr. Gardiner writes, shares a subtle blend of intense subjectivity and polyphonic distance.

title: Hotel Review: The Graham Hotel in Washington, D.C.
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Guild & Company in Burlington, Vt.
description: As a restaurant concept, farm-to-table steakhouse comes off as so buzzwordy that its like a Portlandia sketch begging to be written. So perhaps its not incidental that Guild & Company, which executes the conceit with unfussy charm, sits along the outskirts of Burlington, Vt., the East Coasts best facsimile of that tongue-in-cheek television utopia.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Lebanon, the Philippines, Nepal and Egypt.

title: Mike Lee and the Republican Opportunity
description: One of my recurring themes in this space is the weakness of the Republican Partys policy agenda; another is the limitations of the Bloombergist/donorist style of moderationthats regularly offered as the obvious direction for the G.O.P. to take. So Im grateful to Ron Fournier of National Journal for taking on the first issue in a way that lets me talk, at length, about the second. Heres Fournier, attacking Republicans for remaining the party of zilch amid the Obama administrations recent flailings:

title: France Is Heading to Brazil and Can Make Amends
description: PARIS  Defying the bitterly low expectations of a populace that had largely written them off as prima donnas, the French national soccer team defeated Ukraine, 3-0, on Tuesday night and secured a place at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

title: Judges Must Warn About Deportation, New York Appeals Court Rules
description: New York judges must warn immigrant defendants that they face deportation if they plead guilty to a felony, the states highest court ruled on Tuesday.

title: A Writer Thanks Her Lucky Stars
description: Eleanor Catton was all but swallowed up the other day by the buzz and hum of a Midtown hotel lobby, with its chattering tourists. In the midst of a victory tour after winning the 2013 Man Booker Prize for her second novel, The Luminaries, Ms. Catton had not yet fully adjusted to being an object of attention, or even to being allowed to stay in a fancy hotel, as she described it.

title: Advanced Maternal Age Mother Seeks a Big Fat Positive Pregnancy Test
description: Im no fertility authority, despite what my husband might think.

title: Spider-Man Investors Shaken by Projected $60 Million Loss
description: Investors and executives with the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark said on Tuesday that the show will have historic losses of up to $60 million when it closes on Jan. 4. The closing follows a sharp decline in ticket sales because of competition from hotter musicals and a lack of star attractions in the cast.

title: Need for Speed Rivals, Phoenix Wright, Skylanders and Device 6
description: NEED FOR SPEED

title: Unavoidable Answer for the Problem of Climate Change
description: Japans announcement last week that it would not meet its promise to sharply reduce its carbon emissions met a chorus of disapproval from around the world.

title: Son of Israel, Caught in the Middle
description: If you want everyone to love you, Saul Bellow wrote, dont discuss Israeli politics. Yet when Bellow went to Israel for several months in 1975 to research a nonfiction book, all he did was talk politics  and everything else. It was what he loved best about Israel, the gale of conversation.

title: Obama Speaks at Executive Summit
description: President Obama talked about economic progress despite the government shutdown and problems with the rollout of the health care website.

title: Annual Firearms Discharge Report From the New York Police Department
description: More people died from police gunfire last year than during any previous year of the Bloomberg administration, according to a Police Department report released Tuesday.

title: Arthur W. Zeckendorf
description: Mr. Zeckendorf, 54, is a principal, along with his brother, William Lie Zeckendorf, of Zeckendorf Realty, developer of luxury condominiums and retail space in Manhattan, like 15 Central Park West and 18 Gramercy Park, both in partnership with Global Holdings.

title: Emotion at Final Shareholder Meeting for Microsofts Ballmer
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.  The turnout at Microsofts annual shareholder meetings is often sparse, with loads of empty seats in a conference hall in this Seattle suburb.

title: Attack in Beirut Through the Lens of Hezbollah TV
description: As our colleagues Hwaida Saad and Anne Barnard report from Beirut, the deadly bombings at the gate of the Iranian Embassy in the Lebanese capital on Tuesday were immediately interpreted there as a form of retaliation for Irans intervention in the civil war in neighboring Syria.

title: Teaching About J.F.K. With The New York Times
description: Updated: Nov. 22, 2013

title: GDay From Bushwick
description: Standing in the dining room of the early 1900s-era brick rowhouse, deep in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn with not a frozen yogurt shop or Starbucks to be found, Alan Dixon, an investor from Australia, struggled to tally the houses he had bought in the area over the last year.

title: Weighing the Risks of Going Without Health Insurance
description: FOR many people, complying with the new health care law will become a financial decision: Should I buy the insurance, or simply pay the penalty and take my chances?

title: Navigating a Transformed Insurance Marketplace
description: ESSENTIAL benefits. Flexible benefits. High deductibles. Coinsurance. Bronze, silver, gold, platinum.

title: Pushing Patients to Seek Value, Whatever That Is
description: PETER KREUTZER is, in many ways, an ideal patient. Mr. Kreutzer, a 57-year-old Brooklyn writer, is in good health, eats well and follows his doctors instructions.

title: Medicaid Help Without Falling Into Poverty
description: WHEN Colin Sandler was in high school in the mid-1980s, her grandparents legally separated after 45 years of marriage. This was not because their marriage was troubled, but because her grandfather had fallen ill and medical bills threatened to consume their entire life savings and all their income, leaving Ms. Sandlers grandmother penniless.

title: Private Exchanges Rise as Health Care Options
description: THE troubled rollout of the federal health insurance marketplace this fall has given the word health exchange a bad name. Nonetheless, some companies are choosing to offer their employees health benefits via private exchanges  online insurance marketplaces that are separate from the federal system.

title: Planning for a Future in the Face of Terminal Illness
description: PATRICK SKELDON, a commercial airline pilot, started having trouble walking in the autumn of 2003. His doctor thought he had a vitamin deficiency and prescribed supplements. When those didnt work, the doctor referred him to a neurologist. The next year, he was told he had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, more commonly known as Lou Gehrigs disease. He was 59.

title: You Plan Your Retirement, Then You Get the Health Bill
description: JEFF STRACK, a 61-year-old sales manager in Charlotte, N.C., enjoys his work and is in good health. But the prospect of paying for health costs after he retires weighs on him.

title: How Doctors Die: Showing Others the Way
description: BRAVE. You hear that word a lot when people are sick. Its all about the fight, the survival instinct, the courage. But when Dr. Elizabeth D. McKinleys family and friends talk about bravery, it is not so much about the way Dr. McKinley, a 53-year-old internist from Cleveland, battled breast cancer for 17 years. It is about the courage she has shown in doing something so few of us are able to do: stop fighting.

title: For Those at Deaths Door, a Case for Life Panels
description: AT the beginning of 2012, my mother was 95 years old. She lived in an assisted-living center, with hospice care, in a hospital bed 24/7. She was hollow-eyed and emaciated. Though she had moments of clarity, she was confused, anxious and uncomfortable. Her quality of life was minimal, at best. And the cost to keep her in this condition had risen to close to $100,000 a year.

title: ABC Shuffles Its Prime-Time Lineup
description: ABC, the network that has struggled most in the ratings this fall, announced a series of changes to its prime-time schedule Tuesday, which included the addition of five new series and the cancellation of one flop. The network also unveiled a new entrant in its long-running effort to fashion a hit comedy in the half-hour following its biggest hit, Modern Family.

title: Art Matters | Art, Underground Music and Basketball Collide in Queens
description: Last Sunday afternoon, two different rhythms resounded through the VW Dome in the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Queens. One was provided by Future Brown  a new D.J. supergroup made up of the genre-bending artists and musicians Fatima Al Qadiri; Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda of Nguzunguzu; and J-Cush of Lit City Trax. The second, which synced well with the first, came from the steady bounce of basketballs.

title: Go Elsewhere, Young Scientist
description: Its hard to measure the economic consequences of sequestration, but surely this is not a good thing:

title: Reid Preparing to Move for Limits on Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, is prepared to move forward with a vote that could severely limit the minority partys ability to filibuster presidential nominees, possibly as early as this week, Democrats said Tuesday.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Honoring the Selfie, and Questioning Dropboxs Valuation
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Comparing Costs of Three Conditions
description: Expected costs for a year of medical care without insurance and under different tiers of coverage  silver, bronze or a high-deductible catastrophic plan that insures against major expenses.

title: Estimating Retiree Health Costs
description: Total needed for the average couple retiring today at age 65, with average life expectancies (woman lives to be 85; man, 82).

title: London Cyclist Fatalities Bring Calls for Truck Limits
description: LONDON  Public transport in London is always expensive, often crowded and sometimes unreliable, so there is no mystery about why bicycle trips here in Britains capital increased by around a third in the decade up to 2011.

title: A Graphic Novel With Teeth (and Claws)
description: Comic book publishers have embraced the digital realm, incorporating entertaining features like motion and sound to attract new readers. But one start-up, Anomaly Productions, is taking a bigger step, adding augmented reality to the pages of its sci-fi graphic novels.

title: Enhanced Sound, With Wi-Fi and Android
description: The Sceptre Speaker SoundBar SB301523 is a smart idea at a reasonable price  a soundbar with Wi-Fi and the Android operating system built in, so you can get TV shows and video from the Internet without adding another box. While the idea is good, the execution is half-baked.

title: Engineered for Sound, at a Price
description: Is a pair of headphones worth $1,250? Shure thinks so.

title: Justices Reject Bid to Block Texas Law on Abortions
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday turned away an emergency application asking it to block a Texas law that requires doctors performing abortions to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.

title: Egyptian Police Clear Tahrir Square With Tear Gas on Anniversary of Deadly Clashes
description: Last Updated, Wednesday, 1:30 p.m. | As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, protesters were cleared from Tahrir Square on Tuesday night, after a day of demonstrations dedicated to the memory of dozens of activists who were killed by the security forces on this date two years ago.

title: Options Narrowed, U.S. Is Said to Weigh Destroying Syrian Chemicals at Sea
description: WASHINGTON  Unable to find a country willing to dispose of Syrias chemical weapons, the United States is considering plans to place the chemical components of the weapons on a barge where they would be dissolved or incinerated, according to senior American officials.

title: Baucus Corporate Tax Proposal Takes Aim at Merger Inversions
description: Theres lots for big companies to like about a proposed overhaul of the corporate tax code, put forward on Tuesday by Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana.

title: A Divided City
description: Murders have declined substantially in St. Louis, but violence remains persistent in the citys majority-black areas.

title: Shiller vs. Fama vs. the Skeptics
description: Robert Shiller and Eugene Fama, sharing a stage for the first time since it was announced last month that they would share the 2013 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, sparred with languorous familiarity Tuesday about the efficiency of financial markets.

title: An Underground Drink Cast as a Film Star
description: A tall plastic soup container is filled with ice, over-proof rum, cheap liqueurs and fruit juices and stashed in a brown paper bag. Some money changes hands. What happens after that, at least for the buyer, can get blurry.

title: Salesforce.com and HP Buck Common Wisdom of Cloud Computing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Are Hewlett-Packard and Salesforce.com onto something?

title: Ahead of Anniversary, Promoting All Things Kennedy
description: ON a recent morning, pedestrians on Columbus Circle walked by a newsstand stocked with boxes of nickel candy bars like Hi-Noon and Tofy-Nut; cartons of Kent and Tareyton cigarettes; and periodicals that carried photographs of President John F. Kennedy on their covers or front pages.

title: The End of 5Pointz
description: Works of graffiti artists at 5Pointz, a warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, were painted over during the night.

title: Confronting the Specter of Alzheimers
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel on Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Losing War Against Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: California: Los Angeles Airport Shooting Suspect Leaves Hospital
description: The man accused of killing a federal agent at Los Angeles International Airport was released from Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center on Mondayand taken to a federal holding facility, the authorities saidTuesday. The suspect, Paul A. Ciancia, 23, is believed to have opened fire in the crowded terminal on Nov. 1, killing Gerardo I. Hernandez, 39, aTransportationSecurity Administrationagent, and wounding two others. A spokesman for the United States attorneys office said that no details about his custody status or location are being released at this time. Mr. Ciancia led police officers through a chase in the terminal and was shot in the head and leg. He was listed in critical condition for more than 10 days, and federal investigators were not able to question him. Mr. Ciancia could face the death penalty if convicted.

title: Concise at Gettysburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising Wages at Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Party Challenges the One That Has Run India for Most of Its History
description: NEW DELHI  Snaking down one of this citys dusty back streets on a recent afternoon was a line of auto-rickshaws, the motorized buggies that course through this city by the tens of thousands, carrying ordinary citizens on their daily rounds. Unless you looked closely, you could miss the fact that they were part of a political insurgency.

title: Celebrities Beckon Indians to Travel Sites
description: Indias most revered athlete, Sachin Tendulkar, swung his final cricket bat on Friday ahead of one of the most watched and  talked-about retirements from athletics in India  or, for that matter, anywhere.

title: Jane Pratt Fitzpatrick, 89, Savior of Pre-Revolutionary Inn, Dies
description: Jane Pratt Fitzpatrick, who with her husband saved the Red Lion Inn, the pre-Revolutionary hostelry in Western Massachusetts immortalized by Norman Rockwell in his painting Stockbridge Main Street at Christmas, died on Nov. 9 at her home in Stockbridge. She was 89.

title: Florida Congressman Faces Charge of Cocaine Possession
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, was charged Tuesday with misdemeanor possession of cocaine after having been arrested here last month, according to District of Columbia Superior Court documents.

title: Beware Marauding Carp
description: EARLIER this month, researchers demonstrated that a Eurasian species of fish, the grass carp, had begun reproducing in Lake Erie. This may not sound like alarming news, but unless we take steps to prevent its spread, this animal is poised to disrupt the ecology of the Hudson River and New Yorks other inland waters.

title: Bringing an End to a Senseless Policy
description: SHANGHAI  CHINA announced last week that it would loosen its famous one-child policy, enforced since 1980. The worlds most controversial birth-control policy, initially imposed as an emergency measure at the start of the economic reforms of Deng Xiaoping, seems to finally be on its way out, more than a generation later.

title: Doctors Say Heart Drug Raised Risk of an Attack
description: Cardiologists have accused a small drug company of withholding data from a clinical trial showing that the companys drug, meant to reduce the risk of heart attacks, increased the risk instead.

title: Energy Dept. Is Told to Stop Collecting Fee for Nuclear Waste Disposal
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that the Energy Department must stop collecting fees of about $750 million a year that are paid by consumers and intended to fund a program for the disposal of nuclear waste. The reason, the court said, is that there is no such program.

title: Vonn Crashes While Prepping for Return
description: Lindsey Vonns World Cup comeback from major knee surgery may have been delayed by a training crash Tuesday in Colorado. Vonn, the reigning Olympic downhill champion, was being evaluated by a team orthopedist after the crash, the United States Ski Team said. The team did not disclose what kind of injury Vonn had sustained.

title: Mentally Ill, and Jailed in Isolation at Rikers Island
description: From the annals of Rikers Island comes a document titled, Three Adolescents With Mental Illness in Punitive Segregation in Rikers Island. Punitive segregation means solitary confinement for 23 hours a day. Schoolwork, if it comes, is passed through a slot in the cell door. Toothpaste is available once a day.

title: N.S.A. Spying Scandal Hurts Close Ties Between Australia and Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The relationship between Indonesia and Australia, Pacific neighbors with a long history of cooperation and trade, has in recent years been marked by disagreements on a range of issues, including human rights, terrorism and asylum seekers. But relations reached a new low over the weekend over the latest bombshell from the surveillance scandal involving a third country, the United States.

title: As Traders Trial Begins, Name of One Insider Stands Out
description: From his cubicle at Dells headquarters in Round Rock, Tex., Rob Ray shared insights about the computer maker that ricocheted across the country, reaching a trust company in California, a mutual fund in Manhattan and hedge funds in New York and Connecticut.

title: Koch Brothers Group Uses Health Care Law to Attack Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  Americans for Prosperity, the political group backed by the billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch, is targeting three of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats who are up for re-election next year. The groups efforts are part of a new $3.5 million attack advertising campaign that hammers lawmakers for supporting President Obamas health care law.

title: Russians and Bach, With Equal Keyboard Energy
description: After playing Shostakovichs Piano Sonata No. 2 in B minor at Zankel Hall last Tuesday evening, the pianist Olli Mustonen wiped the sweat from his brow and looked at the audience with an expression that hovered between exhaustion and resignation. He had just offered an impassioned rendition of this tormented piece, composed in 1943 after Shostakovich had been evacuated during the Siege of Leningrad. The composer dedicated the work to an important mentor, his teacher Leonid Nikolayev, who had died the previous year. Mr. Mustonen played the opening movements frenzied surges with powerful clarity, beautifully contrasting them with the yearning melody that unfolds between demonic outbursts. He brought a searching insight to the second movement Largo, with an emotionally subdued character that offers a respite between the angst of the outer movements. Mr. Mustonens judicious use of pedal and vivid touch created an impressive range of colors in the turbulent concluding section, in which a ruminative melody unfurls over rumbling bass chords and later, in the left hand, under intense right-hand patterns.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Calls for Transforming the Technology Used by Phone Systems
description: WASHINGTON  Americans could soon be one step closer to getting that videophone they were promised in the 1960s.

title: A Municipal Bankruptcy May Create a Template
description: Jefferson County, Ala., which just became the first municipality to tap the public bond markets while bankrupt, will go to court on Wednesday to seek approval for its plan to exit bankruptcy by the end of this year.

title: Its a Fashion Show for Sports Teams
description: Sports teams once had simple fashion rules. Wear one uniform at home, usually white, and another on the road.

title: Health Insurance Marketplace Is Still About 40 Percent Incomplete, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace said Tuesday that 30 percent to 40 percent of the project was still being built.

title: Lets Make a Deal
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  The Middle East once again proves that if you eat right, exercise regularly and dont smoke, youll live long enough to see everything, including a day when the Jews controlling Jerusalem and the Sunni Saudi Custodians of the Great Mosques of Mecca and Medina would form a tacit alliance against the Shiite Persians of Iran and the Protestants of America  with the Hindus of India and the Confucians of China also supporting America, sort of, while the secularist French play all sides.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate
description: RECENT SALE

title: Vladimir Putin Clings to the Past
description: The former republics of the Soviet Union have been sovereign, independent countries for almost 22 years, free to develop economic and political relations with any foreign nation or trading bloc they choose. That point appears to have eluded President Vladimir Putin of Russia, who is doing everything he can to prevent these countries from developing closer ties with Europe  even threatening to cut off the gas that one country needs to get through the winter.

title: Small Protest in Tahrir Square Restores Dissent to Cairos Heart
description: CAIRO  The protesters numbers were small, compared with the millions who have marched through Egypts streets in recent months. And at one point, a soccer game on television seemed more urgent than the chants.

title: A Long-Running Trial
description: Nearly 40 years after the murder of 15-year-old Martha Moxley of Greenwich, Conn., people are still fascinated about the details of the case.

title: Familys Tenacity and Wealth Put Skakel at Cusp of Freedom
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Since Michael C. Skakels conviction in 2002 in the 1975 murder of his Greenwich neighbor Martha Moxley when they were both 15, Mr. Skakel and his family have spared no expense in their efforts to clear his name.

title: Advertisements for the Common Core
description: The country is engaged in a fierce debate about two educational reforms that bear directly on the future of its schoolchildren: first, teacher evaluation systems that are taking hold just about everywhere, and, second, the Common Core learning standards that have been adopted by all but a few states and are supposed to move the schools toward a more challenging, writing-intensive curriculum.

title: The Expiring Ban on Plastic Guns
description: Even after the Newtown, Conn., massacre, Republican opponents of reasonable firearms restrictions in Congress blocked proposals for strengthened background checks and other steps to make future gun tragedies less likely. Now the question is whether anti-gun-control extremists will allow a federal ban on the manufacture, sale, import or possession of guns that are undetectable by metal detectors and X-ray machines to expire on Dec. 9.

title: Citing Feds Efforts, Bernanke Says U.S. Economy Is Growing Stronger
description: WASHINGTON  A few months of scrambled economic data have not altered the Federal Reserves basic view that the American economy is gaining strength, nor its intention to start pulling back soon from its stimulus campaign, the Feds chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Tuesdayevening.

title: Sounds From the Sky
description: Among the phrases I have never trusted are the collective nouns associated with animals  a murder of crows, a scurry of squirrels, that sort of thing. They turn up mostly when people are making lists of collective nouns associated with animals, and their roots  if they have roots  are usually never mentioned. All in all, they reek of a kind of linguistic cleverness I find far too cute. Plus, theyre all too easy to make: a puddle of poodles, a terrine of terriers, a rumpus of reptiles, etc.

title: JPMorgan Settlement Offers Look Into Mortgage Machine
description: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department reached a record $13 billion settlement on Tuesday, wrapping up a series of state and federal investigations that offer a rare glimpse into Wall Streets mortgage machine before the financial crisis, when it churned out billions of dollars in securities that later imploded.

title: A Mothers Pain Fed That of Her Daughter
description: On a recent afternoon, Khalilah Hyde-Peyrefitte was bustling around the 20th floor of a towering office building in Midtown Manhattan, greeting colleagues with a wide, beaming smile. A small-business coordinator for McKissack & McKissack, a construction and design firm, she has the bearing of any bright, ambitious, recent college graduate, enthusiastic and eager to excel. But Ms. Hyde-Peyrefitte, 21, also carries the weight of the pain and disillusionment she had to overcome.

title: In Places Like North St. Louis, Gunfire Still Rules the Night
description: ST. LOUIS  The unmistakable pop of a gunshot ricocheted through the park in the humid air, and Montez Wayne could only hope that the bullet did not have his name on it. He sprang from his seat beneath a sprawling bald cypress, ready to make his move.

title: Charge Is Dropped in Beating Death in Harlem
description: Prosecutors on Tuesday moved to dismiss misdemeanor charges against a Harlem man accused in the beating death of a transgender woman in August, citing confusion over who exactly was involved in the assault.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 20, 2013
description: Todays event demonstrates the political and economic costs of Syria for Iran. Syria is a kind of flytrap for the Iranians. Theyre just stuck to it.

title: Twisted Sister, and Brothers
description: WASHINGTON  And I thought my family Thanksgivings were rough.

title: Sanctions' Successes and Failures
Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 19, 2013
Attorney General on JPMorgan Settlement
description: Eric H. Holder Jr. talks about JPMorgan Chases $13 billion agreement for its  risky mortgage practices.

title: Corrections: November 20, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Story to Question, Word for Word
description: Oscar Wildes warning that the truth is rarely pure and never simple should be affixed to all documentaries, whatever their form or content. Most television watchers are, by now, savvy enough to understand that there aint much reality in reality shows.

title: Handy Way of Communicating
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Now this  this puzzle is the sound of my teen years. Sorry, did I say puzzle? I meant the album that the puzzle highlights. When you went to school dances where I lived, you did the Hustle and other disco horrors when you were in public but  if you were to be considered a teen of good taste  when you got home, it was Jackson Browne who lived on your turntable*.

title: In Stance on Renewal of Old Health Policies, States Run the Gamut
description: Just a few days after President Obama said that millions of consumers should be able to keep their old insurance plans for another year  even if they did not meet the requirements of his health care law  he is finding support among states that would not exactly be described as allies.

title: Chevron Assails Lawyer Who Led Multibillion-Dollar Suit Against It
description: For two years Chevron has said that a multibillion-dollar judgment in a pollution case against the company in Ecuador was rigged by an American lawyer, Steven R. Donziger, asserting that he tampered with witnesses and bribed an Ecuadorean judge. On Tuesday, the companys lawyers confronted Mr. Donziger in a Manhattan federal courtroom.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,276 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Pierce, Now Surrounded by Scorers, Seeks a Role
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Three weeks ago, after the Nets secured a galvanizing victory at home over the Miami Heat, Kevin Garnett bestowed upon his longtime teammate Paul Pierce the nickname Picasso, reasoning that every night on the court, Pierce seemed to produce affecting artistry  a beautiful painting, Garnett said.

title: Typhoon Response Highlights Weaknesses in Philippine Military
description: GUIUAN, the Philippines  As American cargo planes and military helicopters zipped across the sky above this decimated city, ferrying badly needed supplies to typhoon survivors, Philippine soldiers were working with what little they had  relying on motorcycles and boats to ferry messages between the armys provincial headquarters and stricken municipalities along the eastern coast of Samar, some of them more than a hundred miles away.

title: A Dynasty Strained
description: Michael C. Skakels legal defense has been supplemented by trust funds set up for the family by his grandparents.

title: Cano to the Mets? Unlikely at His Price
description: If the Mets were going to puff out their chests and declare themselves spenders this off-season, they might as well act like it, at least once in a while. So on Monday night, Sandy Alderson, the Mets general manager; Jeff Wilpon, the chief operating officer, and John Ricco, the assistant general manager, met for dinner in Manhattan with Jay Z and associates and listened to their pitch on Robinson Cano, the Yankees second baseman who has become the highest-priced item on baseballs free-agent market.

title: Pockets of Crime Persist in St. Louis Neighborhoods
description: Life on the North Side of St. Louis can be marked by shockingly violent interludes on seemingly ordinary days.

title: The Obamacare Crisis
description: Health care as a necessity comes only after food, shelter and income security. The mismanagement of the website HealthCare.gov and the cancellation of millions of policies pushes an underlying question out into the open: Is the federal government capable of managing the provision of a fundamental service through an extraordinarily complex system?

title: Toronto Residents Have Funny Feeling About Mayor, and His Longevity
description: TORONTO  When your city becomes the punch line of an international joke, it pays to keep your sense of humor too.

title: Knicks, Running Out of Options, Fall Short Again
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  By the time Coach Mike Woodson called a timeout after an emphatic Andre Drummond dunk, there was not much left in the Knicks tank. They trailed the Detroit Pistons by 15 points with 9 minutes 20 seconds remaining as Woodson sat in the huddle. There was time for a comeback, but around Woodson, the options were limited.

title: A Brutal Feud Emerges in Uzbekistans Fractured First Family
description: MOSCOW  Truth be told, Gulnara Karimova, the eldest daughter of the strongman leader of Uzbekistan, never did seem particularly well qualified to succeed her father at the head of their impoverished and troubled Central Asian nation.

title: Canada: Doctor Convicted of Molesting Female Patients
description: An anesthesiologist at a Toronto hospital was convicted on Tuesday of sexually molesting 21 women after sedating them. Once he had put the women, who ranged in age from 25 to 75, into a state of semi-consciousness, Dr. George Doodnaught kissed and groped them and, in comes cases, forced them to perform sexual acts. Justice David McCombs of the Superior Court of Ontario said that expert witnesses effectively refuted claims by Dr. Doodnaughts lawyers that the women were suffering from sexual hallucinations brought on by anesthesia drugs. Dr. Doodnaught will be sentenced early next year and faces another hearing about his medical license.

title: Russia: Judges Grant Bail to Nine Greenpeace Activists
description: Russian judges in St. Petersburg granted bail to nine more crew members of a Greenpeace International ship who were arrested in September after a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic, all of them foreigners. The rulings came a day after three Russian crew members from the ship, the Arctic Sunrise, were also granted bail, though the detention of yet another activist, Colin Russel of Australia, was extended until February, as the investigation into the protest against an off-shore oil rig in the Pechora Sea continues.

title: Venezuela: Assembly Hands More Powers to President
description: The National Assembly on Tuesday voted to give President Nicols Maduro decree powers for one year, which will allow him to create laws on his own, without going through the legislative process. The so-called special powers permit Mr. Maduro, a socialist, to make laws aimed at fighting corruption and regulating the economy, but critics say that in practice those areas are broad enough that there may be few limits over the reach of his decrees. Many Venezuelan presidents have been given similar decree powers, including Mr. Maduros predecesor and mentor, Hugo Chvez, who died in March. Mr. Maduro, who is grappling with runaway inflation and severe shortages of many basic goods, has said that he will quickly move to create a law widening price controls and capping business profits.

title: Zimbabwe: Sanitation Crisis Causes New Cholera Risk
description: Millions of Zimbabwe residents are at risk of waterborne diseases including a resumption of cholera because of a water and sanitation crisis in the capital, Harare, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Tuesday. The report, issued five years after cholera killed more than 4,000 Zimbabweans and sickened 100,000, described a collapse in water and sanitation services. Residents must often drink from shallow, unprotected wells befouled by sewage, according to the report, which was based on research conducted over the last two years.

title: U.S. Player Ratings: Austria (1), U.S. (0)
description: VIENNA  On a cold night at Ernst Happel Stadium, the United States mens national soccer team ended its 2013 year Tuesday with a sloppy exhibition loss against an Austria team that failed to qualify for the World Cup.

title: The Labor Market and Labor Policy Since Kennedy
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Mothers Exercise May Boost Babys Brain
description: If a woman is physically active during pregnancy, she may boost the development of her unborn childs brain, according to a heart-tugging new study of expectant mothers and their newborns. The findings bolster a growing scientific consensus that the benefits of exercise can begin to accumulate even before someone is born.

title: Word of the Day | virile
description: virile \vir-l, vir-i(-)l\ adjective

title: For Those in Their 20s, a Finding That They Dont Manage Debt Well
description: Youre a young adult, starting to build your career. Youre trying to juggle student loan payments, pay your rent and cover other bills, so its tempting to make an occasional late payment on your credit card. No big deal, right?

title: Albuquerque Voters Defeat Anti-Abortion Measure
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Voters here on Tuesday defeated a ballot question that sought to ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, delivering a critical setback to an anti-abortion movement that had sought to use this progressive city to recalibrate the national debate around womens reproductive rights.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 11 P.M. (NBCSN) COSTAS TONIGHT SPECIAL  NO DAY FOR GAMES: THE COWBOYS AND J F K  Bob Costas, above, examines the assassination of President John F. Kennedy through the eyes of the 1963 Dallas Cowboys and Roger Staubach, then a college quarterback for Navy. Other former players, including the defensive tackle Bob Lilly, the linebacker Lee Roy Jordan and the tight end Pettis Norman; the Cowboys longtime personnel chief Gil Brandt; Dan Rooney, the chairman of the Pittsburgh Steelers; and the historian Michael Beschloss weigh in.

title: Top Filmmaker Reportedly Sought for Bucking Family Planning Rules
description: Family planning officials in the eastern coastal city of Wuxi are apparently at wits end with a nationwide effort to find the internationally acclaimed director Zhang Yimou, according to a report by the state-run news agency Xinhua.

title: States Where Insured Could Renew Plans Before Change by Obama
description: Some states have said they will not follow President Obamas recently announced policy.

title: News Quiz | November 20, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Conversation With: British Climate Economist Lord Nicholas Stern
description: WARSAW, Poland  Even as the annual United Nations climate change conference is nearing its end on Friday, negotiations are obstructed by longstanding disputes over responsibilities of combating the crisis.

title: Gary Locke to Leave as U.S. Ambassador to China
description: The American ambassador to China, Gary F. Locke, the first Chinese-American to hold the post, announced Wednesday that he was stepping down to rejoin his family in Seattle.

title: Xi Puts Himself at Center of Chinas Economic Makeover
description: Short, perhaps, of handing out autographed copies of the Chinese Communist Partys plans for change, there is little more President Xi Jinping can do to show he has wagered his credibility on restructuring the economy while cleaning up and entrenching one-party rule.

title: Property Taxes Hoped to Curb Chinas Real Estate Excesses
description: Housing prices in Chinas major cities continue to soar, according to a report released by the National Bureau of Statistics on Monday. With the exception of Wenzhou, in the eastern province of Zhejiang, housing prices rose in 69 of the 70 major cities in the survey during the first 10 months of 2013. In 21 cities, prices jumped more than 10 percent, and in 26 cities, they climbed by 8 percent to 10 percent. Shanghai and Beijing topped the list, with increases of 21.4 percent and 21.2 percent, respectively.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 20, 2013
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: Thai Court Rejects Bid for Direct Elections of All Senators
description: BANGKOK  A Thai court ruled on Wednesday that a major initiative by the ruling party was an attempt to overthrow the countrys democratic system, increasing pressure on a beleaguered government already made fragile by weeks of antigovernment protests.

title: 50 Years Later
description: The assassination of John F. Kennedy changed the world forever.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Graffiti Mecca Is Gone
description: In 5Pointz, a Graffiti Mecca in Queens, Is Wiped Clean Overnight, Marc Santora and Cara Buckley write about the surprise that greeted fans of street art on Nov. 19.

title: A Small-Scale Thanksgiving
description: Christmas persecutes the lonely and rejected, the New York newspaperman Jimmy Cannon wrote in a syndicated column in 1962. Perhaps it does. But the holiday holds nothing on Thanksgiving.

title: How Is Hamid Karzai Still Standing?
description: The Karzai family graveyard lies a few miles outside Kandahar, on the edge of the village of Karz. On the day I drove there, burned-out cars stood rusting by the sides of the road, children splashed through open drains and bullet holes riddled the mud walls opposite checkpoints. Amid all this, the graveyard stood out  gleaming, immaculate. Straggling bougainvillea and mulberry trees blossomed over the calligraphic tiles topping the cream-colored walls. Through the double gates were lines of cypresses. In the middle stood a domed enclosure containing the graves of the clan elders.

title: The Search for the Lost Marines of Tarawa
description: We had been on the island for about an hour when we found the first skeleton. It was a pile of yellow bones tucked inside a cardboard box. Mark Noah squatted down for a look. He is a stocky man of 48, with a light buzz of blond hair and the wind-beaten eyes of a lifelong outdoorsman. Since 2008, he has been traveling to the tiny Pacific atoll of Tarawa to search for the remains of more than 500 Marines who died there in World War II. Sometimes locals dig up their bones and leave them in his storage locker.

title: Josef Koudelka: A Restless Eye
description: We highly recommend viewing the slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: A Misunderstood Directive
description: The old man lashed out the first night he spent in the nursing home. His behavior was so alarming that staff transferred him to a nearby hospital for evaluation.

title: Who Is the Mayor of Your School or Neighborhood?
description: New York has always been a city of mayors. Every block has one. So do industries, underworlds and dog parks, begins a new interactive that features nine New Yorkers nominated by readers for their role in different city communities  including Cheyanne Smith, whom the feature calls the mayor of teenagers.

title: Egyptian Soldiers Killed in Sinai Attack
description: CAIRO  At least 11 Egyptian soldiers were killed on Wednesday after suicide bombers drove an explosives-laden car into a convoy of military buses traveling in the Sinai Peninsula, according to a spokesman for the armed forces.

title: ScienceTake: Sea Slug Love
description: In the mating game, males and females can have different agendas even when they inhabit the same body.

title: Bomb Attacks Kill Dozens in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  A wave of apparently coordinated bombings hit bakeries and public markets in Baghdad on Wednesday, killing at least 42 people and wounding more than 90, many of them as they rushed to shop during a break in heavy rainstorms, according to the police, residents and medical officials.

title: New York Today: J.F.K. in the Bronx
description: Updated 12:05 p.m. | Let us now visit the house where a 10-year-old John F. Kennedy lived.

title: Toyota Shows Off Fuel-Cell Automobile
description: TOKYO  Hydrogen-powered cars are finally being readied for their Prius moment  at least, that is what promoters of the environmentally friendly technology hope.

title: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at 6 a.m.
description: Iranian nuclear talks resume in Geneva; reaction to the painting over of a graffiti mecca in Queens; and love among sea slugs.

title: A Different Kind of Mating Dance
description: A sea slug from the Great Barrier Reef, so small that one would never notice it with the naked eye, has been caught on video in a mating behavior so extreme that it appears to be a scientific first.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Ethan Koh: Inspired by Home
description: The designer behind Ethan K sits down with Suzy Menkes to discuss the inspiration behind his handbags.

title: How One Small Business Got Big
description: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners were joined by a guest, Rebecca Cenni, who founded Atrium Staffing in 1995. Atrium is a staffing and payroll firm with about 130 employees, $140 million in annual sales, and offices in New York, Boston, San Francisco, Pittsburgh, and fourcities in New Jersey. Ms. Cenni talked about the challenges of growing and managing her business, offering insights she has gained since starting Atrium at age 23.

title: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 3
description: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members. Part 1 of her answers is here. Part 2 is here. [Update: Part 4 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

title: Cost Aside, JPMorgan May Have a Good Deal
