description: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase on Tuesday agreed to a mortgage settlement that will cost the bank $13 billion, a large number that will bolster the governments claims that justice was done.

title: The Two Lucknows During Muslim Holy Month
description: The raised sign for Avadh Point on Victoria Road in Old Lucknow is missing two letters, the O and the I. The D in Avadh also hangs precariously, as if it is ready to become the third. The three-story building was constructed in 2005, but it stands dilapidated, walls thinning and paint peeling, as if it is as old as the Awadh culture its named after.

title: Crime and No Punishment
description: MEXICO CITY  On the night of Jan. 30, 2010, in the border city of Ciudad Jurez, in a neighborhood called Villas de Salvarcar, a birthday party full of teenagers was interrupted by a commando. A group of about a dozen barged in shooting and ended up killing 15 people and wounding 10.

title: Daily Report: Nokia Considers Its Uncertain Post-Handset Future
description: Nokias shareholders took a major step on Tuesday to reshape the company, voting overwhelmingly in favor of selling the companys handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion, Mark Scott reports.

title: Deal May Be Near as New Iran Nuclear Talks Open
description: GENEVA  Senior diplomats from six world powers and Iran opened a new round of talks on Wednesday in Geneva amid expectations that they were closing in on an agreement to freeze Tehrans nuclear program.

title: A Gift From Steve Jobs Returns Home
description: On a recent night at an elegant Beaux-Arts ballroom in San Franciscos financial district, Laurene Powell Jobs received a computer with an unusually rich history. Around 1980, Ms. Powell Jobss husband, Steven P. Jobs, donated the computer to a nonprofit organization, the Seva Foundation, to help the group manage data from its efforts to restore sight in the developing world.

title: Morning Agenda: A Glimpse Into JPMorgans Mortgage Machine
description: JPMORGAN SETTLEMENT OFFERS LOOK INTO MORTGAGE MACHINE | The record $13 billion settlement between JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department on Tuesday wraps up a series of state and federal investigations that offer a rare glimpse into Wall Streets mortgage machine before the financial crisis, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

title: Cooperating Witness a Key in SAC Insider Trading Case
description: The Justice Department has had a perfect record in winning insider trading cases since it began its most recent campaign in 2009. Now, it will put that record to the test as the trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, begins this week. The case will highlight the crucial issue in most white-collar crime prosecutions: What did the defendant know about the illegal nature of the transactions?

title: Giving a Subway Hog the Business
description: Dear Diary:

title: Republican Leads San Diego Mayors Race
description: LOS ANGELES  A year after Bob Filner became the first Democratic mayor of San Diego in two decades, Republicans feel they are poised to reclaim the citys top office.

title: High Losses for Penney, but Shares Jump
description: J. C. Penney may have reported a bigger-than-expected loss on Wednesday, but investors say they are seeing signs that the retailers business is improving.

title: Too Old to Get Rich?
description: I wonder why nobody has ever asked me to write a personal finance column, given that Ive done so well in this area. The mortgage on my apartment is paid off. I have no debts. I have enough money in the bank that I can live decently until 93, unless Im flattened by a truck and the hospital doesnt take my secondary insurance:

title: White Supremacist Convicted of Several Murders Is Put to Death in Missouri
description: Joseph P. Franklin, a white supremacist who killed at least eight people in a shooting spree from 1977 to 1980 and confessed to being the sniper who wounded the Hustler magazine publisher Larry Flynt and the lawyer and civil rights activist Vernon E. Jordan Jr., was executed on Wednesday, the Missouri Department of Public Safety said.

title: Polish Prime Minister Replaces Top Cabinet Officials
description: WARSAW  Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland on Wednesday overhauled his cabinet apparently in an effort to bolster his flagging poll numbers, replacing Polands top finance official and changing environment ministers in the middle of a United Nations climate conference his country is hosting.

title: Devon Clinches Deal for GeoSouthern Assets
description: Updated, 2:59 p.m. | Devon Energy, an independent drilling company, reached a deal to buy GeoSouthern Energys holdings in southern Texas for $6 billion, the two companies announced on Wednesday, in the biggest takeover in the oil and gas industry this year.

title: Political Questions About the Jobs Report
description: With the economy dominating the campaign for the White House last fall, did the government cook the books to make the unemployment rate move lower and help President Obamas re-election chances? Was manipulation responsible for lowering the unemployment rate to 7.8 percent in September 2012 from 8.1 percent in August, a big deal when the numbers came out in October 2012, just weeks before the election?

title: Spike Lee, Still Gliding to Success
description: Rage doesnt have to fester for years, but revenge? the director Spike Lee said, as he rapidly autographed 50 movie posters in a downtown Manhattan hotel suite. That stuff takes time. Its the oldest staple of films, in stories. It goes back to the Bible.

title: Gina Cecala: Mayor of the Block
description: Gina Cecala, 82, sits sentinel in front of a building in Little Italy, bantering with mail carriers, delivery people, beggars, friends and strangers.

title: Elevated Park at Trade Center Site Comes Into View
description: The World Trade Centers best-kept secret has finally come to light.

title: Tiptop Pop-Ups
description: THE LITTLE MERMAIDA Pop-Up Adaptation of the Classic Fairy TaleBy Robert Sabuda12 pp. Little Simon/Simon & Schuster. $29.99. (Pop-up book; ages 4 to 11)

title: Frederick Sanger, 95, Twice a Nobel Laureate and a Genetics Pioneer, Dies
description: Frederick Sanger, a British biochemist whose discoveries about the chemistry of life led to the decoding of the human genome and to the development of new drugs like human growth hormone, earning him two Nobel Prizes, a distinction held by only three other scientists, died on Tuesday in Cambridge, England. He was 95.

title: Image of the Day: November 20
The State of Obamacare
description: I havent been writing about the healthcare.gov thing, for the simple reason that I have nothing to say. Whats going on isnt a policy question: we know from the states with working exchanges (including California) that the underlying structure of the law is workable. Instead, its about an implementation botch, which is an incredible mess, and reflects very badly on Obama. But the future of the reform depends not on policy per se but on whether the IT issues can be fixed well enough soon enough, a subject on which I have zero expertise.

title: Today in Small Business: 577 Million Vacation Days
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Rolling Stones to Tour in Australia and New Zealand
description: Even before the Rolling Stones played what appeared to be the finale of their 50th anniversary tour, at Hyde Park in London on July 13, word was spreading among Stones fans that the band would reconvene after a hiatus, and Stones-related web pages buzzed with speculation about where the concerts would be: Germany, the Netherlands, Finland and Norway were all floated as likely, as were both North and South America.

title: British Regulators Said to Be Reviewing Gold Benchmarks
description: LONDON  Regulators in Britain are reviewing whether global benchmarks tied to gold trading were improperly influenced as part of a wide-ranging investigation of potential manipulation of the $5 trillion-a-day currency market, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

title: Feeling For | At Long Last, a Perfectly Designed Tote
description: I am on a perpetual quest for the perfect tote bag. My dream bag is boxy, so that nothing gets lost. It feels substantial, with handles that are sturdy but not clunky-looking. It has a couple of pockets, including one with a zipper. And it has no logos. Such a bag is not, I can assure you, available on every street corner.

title: Consecrating Hallowed Ground
description: On the morning of Tuesday, Nov. 19, 2013, a small army of Civil War re-enactors, a well-known Lincoln impersonator, federal government representatives, the governor of Pennsylvania and its two senators, its congressional representative and a host of municipal officials gathered at the Gettysburg National Cemetery to mark the 150th anniversary of Lincolns famous address.

title: DeVos Institute of Arts Management to Relocate to the University of Maryland
description: Michael M. Kaisers arts management institute is moving from the Kennedy Center in Washington to the University of Maryland and Mr. Kaiser is moving with it  four months earlier than his originally announced departure.

title: Top Japanese Court Stops Short of Nullifying 2012 Vote
description: TOKYO  In a widely watched ruling, Japans Supreme Court on Wednesday called last years parliamentary elections out of compliance with the Constitution because of inequalities in the size of voting districts, but stopped short of declaring the results invalid.

title: Ann Demeulemeester Leaves Her Company
description: Ann Demeulemeester, one of the Antwerp Six designers who brought an original, if gloomy, look to fashion in the 1980s, has decided to leave her company, she said on Wednesday.

title: Helping Out Cats and Dogs in Hawaii
description: Miss Fido while on vacation? In Hawaii, the Maui Humane Society offers two new fixes for pet-lonely travelers: afternoon visits with the shelters cats and dogs, and the opportunity to escort a pet off the island for adoption.

title: Social Security and Secular Stagnation
description: A brief thought inspired by the suddenly prominent debate over secular stagnation.

title: In Our Pages: November 21
description: 1938: Killer Frets Over Lack of Soap

title: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at Noon
description: Attacks in Baghdad kill dozens; Spider-Man to go dark on Broadway; and dressing athletes in an array of uniforms.

title: Message From Insurance Commissioners
description: Insurance commissioners from a handful of states, including North Carolina and Kansas, sent the following email to their counterparts in other states late Tuesday regarding the meeting between insurance commissioners and President Obama today to discuss the Affordable Care Act.

title: States Are Left to Decide on Health Plan Change
description: A group of state insurance commissioners emerged from a meeting with President Obama and other federal officials on Wednesday saying that state regulators would continue to decide on their own whether to go along with his recent proposal to let consumers keep older insurance plans for an extra year, even if the plans did not comply with regulations under the new health care law.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: The 1950s, Roiling Under the Surface
description: For more than five decades, the prolific playwright A. R. Gurney (The Dining Room, Love Letters and many more) has been a probing storyteller, peeking behind curtains into the homes of families  many of them white Anglo-Saxon Protestant, upper-class types living the lifestyle of the country club set.

title: Classical Playlist: Isabelle Faust, Philippe Quint, Cecilia Bartoli and More
description: Times critics share what theyve been listening to lately.

title: In Obamas Pick to Lead a Financial Regulator, an Enigma
description: President Obama has nominated Timothy G. Massad to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. If you thought, who?  well, that may be the point.

title: Florida Congressman in Cocaine Case Will Take a Leave of Absence
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, announced late Wednesday that he would take a leave of absence from office after pleading guilty earlier in the day to a misdemeanor charge stemming from his purchase of cocaine here last month. He was sentenced to one year of probation.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

title: Wheelies: The R.I.P. Wankel Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Snowboard Legend Explores the Obscure
description: In the first episode of Higher Unplugged, a new series by Teton Gravity Research, snowboarder Jeremy Jones reveals why he has abandoned iconic peaks for obscure terrain.

title: A Dublin Neighborhood Pushes Its Boundaries
description: The cobbled quarter of Temple Bar has long maintained its tourist-destination status with overpriced pints of Guinness and a reputation for wild bachelor parties. While these traits endure, entrepreneurs have begun to reclaim the historic streets flanking the south side of the Liffey River. Now, locals are being lured back into the compact neighborhood. The common theme is pushing boundaries, from a secret cocktail bar to restaurants showcasing flavors beyond the typical Irish canon. With fallen prices and available real estate from the economic downturn, the heart of city center Dublin is experiencing a creative revival.

title: Finding a Luxurious Home Away From Home
description: Websites like Airbnb and Couchsurfing have long helped travelers save money by renting and swapping their homes (or merely their couches) rather than pay for hotels. But as the sharing economy evolves, and as luxury travel grows, rental and home swap sites are increasingly catering to travelers with the desire (and budget) for a more sumptuous home away from home.

title: Amid the New, Glasgow Looks to the Past
description: In September, the Foster and Partners-designed Hydro arena opened to much ado in Glasgows gritty Docks area. The translucent ultramodern building  Wi-Fi-enabled for up to 12,000 users  glowed a thousand colors and beamed spotlights up and down the River Clyde. Outside, vendors hawked rainbow wigs and tartan clan mugs. Inside, live Twitter feeds scrolled across 145 oversize high-definition screens. Rod Stewart opened the space with a bang of a show that brought out plaid-clad Glaswegians and their teenage children (and grandchildren). Mr. Stewart closed with a ripping Da Ya Think Im Sexy? but rather than a crooners finale, it seemed more like a question the newly tarted-up city was asking itself.

title: Times Announces Changes in Washington
description: The New York Times on Wednesday announced a reorganization of its Washington bureau, including the elevation of Carolyn Ryan to bureau chief and the start of two new ventures.

title: Another American Citizen Is Arrested in North Korea
description: BEIJING  An 85-year-old American veteran of the Korean War was detained in North Korea last month as he was about to depart after having visited the country on a tourist visa, his son said on Wednesday.

title: Italian Oil Giant Eni Plans to Sell Gas Field in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Eni, the Italian oil company, said on Wednesday that it intended to sell its stake in a natural gas field in the far north of Russia for about $2.9 billion and focus instead on a subsea pipeline and another Arctic Ocean venture.

title: For Some, Paying Sales Commissions No Longer Makes Sense
description: At the start of 2012, ThoughtWorks, a software company based in Chicago, decided to upend one of the sacrosanct principles of sales. It eliminated commissions and placed its entire sales force, a team of 40 stretching across 12 countries, on straight salary.

title: Bronx Tale of a BB Gun and Infamy in the Making
description: Nearly 30 years ago, a seventh grader at the East Midwood Hebrew Day School in Brooklyn needed to complete a social studies assignment, something along the lines of what was it like in the olden days. She set down a cassette tape recorder in front of her saba, her grandfather, and pressed a button.

title: Can You Attract Top Sales Representatives if You Dont Pay Sales Commissions?
description: An article just published in The Times looks at companies that have decided to stop paying sales commissions to its sales representatives.

title: Thompson Finds Job at Old Office
description: William C. Thompson Jr., the former New York City comptroller who this year waged an unsuccessful bid for mayor, announced on Wednesday that he was returning to the municipal bond underwriting firm where he had previously worked.

title: Rodriguez Walks Out of Hearing and Pleads Case on Radio
description: Alex Rodriguez, locked in a fight with Major League Baseball over his 211-game doping suspension, slammed down his hand and walked out of his arbitration hearing Wednesday morning, saying he was disgusted with this abusive process.

title: Student Crossword | Under the Sea: Marine Life
description: Learn more about marine life by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Wall Street Could Benefit From Tax Proposal
description: Changes to the tax code always create winners and losers. An ambitious plan to revise the system for taxing multinational corporations, released on Tuesday by the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Max Baucus, would hit technology companies and large pharmaceutical companies especially hard. Companies like Pfizer, Apple, Hewlett-Packard and Microsoft have become masters at reducing their tax liability in the United States by shifting income overseas.

title: Mens Wearhouse Investor Continues to Push for Deal With Jos. A. Bank
description: One of the biggest investors in Mens Wearhouse made clear on Wednesday that it saw no better future for the retailer than a merger with its smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank.

title: Jaguar Introduces F-Type Coupe With a Laser Show
description: Celebrities, such as Simon Cowell and Adam Carolla, gathered with a horde of largely unknown journalists Tuesday night to greet the new Jaguar F-Type Coupe, which the automaker unveiled at an event near the Los Angeles Auto Show.

title: The Chronicles of C. S. Lewis Lead to Poets Corner
description: LONDON  C. S. Lewis was a noted polymath: philosopher, theologian, professor, novelist, childrens writer, literary critic, lecturer. But he was not much of a poet.

title: In Westchester, an End to Elevator and Subway Commutes
description: Megan Zinger tried her very best to be a city mouse.

title: On Day of Symbolism, Honoring Kennedy, and Successor He Inspired
description: WASHINGTON  Standing wordlessly before a flickering flame, their faces etched in the sunlight slanting through a canopy of thinning trees, two Democratic presidents came together Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery to honor the memory of a third.

title: App Smart: Making Art With a Stylus
description: The Timess Kit Eaton reviews painting and sketching apps where using a stylus, instead of just your finger, can come in quite handy.

title: The Unemployment Rate at Full Employment: How Low Can You Go?
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. Dean Baker is a co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research. They are the authors of Getting Back to Full Employment: A Better Bargain for Working People, being published this week.

title: 24,000-Year-Old Body Shows Kinship to Europeans and American Indians
description: The genome of a young boy buried at Malta near Lake Baikal in eastern Siberia some 24,000 years ago has turned out to hold two surprises for anthropologists.

title: Painting With a Stylus, Despite What Steve Jobs Said
description: When he introduced the iPhone and iPad, Steven P. Jobs asserted the touch-screen devices didnt need a stylus because humans come with 10 great touch-screen controllers sticking out of our palms: fingers. He was proved right, and most new smartphones and tablets dont require a stylus to work their touch screen.

title: Q. & A. | Kathleen Hanna on Love, Illness and the Life-Affirming Joy of Punk Rock
description: As the incendiary lead singer of the band Bikini Kill, Kathleen Hanna became the most famous face of the riot grrrl movement, the early-90s feminist counterpart to grunge. (She coined the phrase smells like teen spirit, which her friend Kurt Cobain would make famous.) Later, she moved from the Pacific Northwest to New York City, where she fronted the socially conscious dance-rock outfit Le Tigre, and most recently she founded the band the Julie Ruin, which released the kinetic record Run Fast in September.

title: Albuquerque Rejects 20-Week Abortion Ban
description: Earlier in 2013, the House proposed a ban on abortion after 20 weeks, and twelve states have gone ahead and enacted such bans. But when Americans are asked if legislators should be spending their time restricting the abortion window, most respondents say no. And the more Americans hear about what a 20-week bans really entail, the more they grow wary of them.

title: Russia Revokes License of a Bank With Ties to Putin
description: MOSCOW  Russias central bank on Wednesday revoked the license of a midsize Russian bank, Master Bank, and accused its management of siphoning off assets in insider deals, in one of the larger bank failures here in recent years.

title: Broadcasters Fight Against Aereo Doesnt Serve Their Interests
description: The latest TV industry technophobia is just as repetitive as a 1980s rerun. American broadcasters, including Walt Disney-owned ABC, have garnered support in their Supreme Court bid to shut down the online video start-up Aereo. The arguments echo those used 30 years ago when networks tried to block the VCR, after which business boomed. For a creative profession, media firms sure can lack imagination.

title: Egyptian Nazi Will No Longer Participate at Georgetown Conference
description: Georgetown University has come under fire for inviting a founder of the Egyptian Nazi Party to a conference planned for December on the future of Egypt, which will feature a keynote speech by Representative Keith Ellison of Minnesota, the first Muslim member of the United States Congress, and Dalia Mogahed, a former adviser to President Obama.

title: Aid Distribution and Rebuilding in the Philippines
description: Food and water remain scarce, but aid is beginning to reach typhoon-affected areas.

title: Turkey Economics, Annotated
description: My Its the Economy column for this Sunday looks at an economic puzzle: why whole frozen turkey prices typically fall just when demand is highest, around Thanksgiving. Below Ive compiled some of the data and theory that went into my reporting for those interested in digging a bit deeper into turkey economics.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 12 Matchup Breakdown
description: Eli Manning, we just cant quit you.

title: Video: Snowboarder Explores the Obscure
description: Higher Unplugged looks at the making of the film Higher, which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

title: The Gun Report: November 20, 2013
Illegal Immigrants Are Divided Over Importance of Citizenship
description: Glendy Martnez is waiting anxiously to see if Congress will ever pass legislation to allow immigrants like her, without papers, to stay in the country legally. But frankly, she says, she does not care if it will include any promise of citizenship.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Is the Man...
description: The director Michel Gondry narrates a scene from his animated documentary interview with Noam Chomsky, Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?

title: Fed Looks for Other Ways to Aid Economy
description: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve officials, many of them reluctant to continue the Feds economic stimulus campaign in its current form, wrestled at their most recent meeting with other ways of supporting an economy that still needs help.

title: What You Get For  $2,500,000
description: Properties include a Garden District house in New Orleans, a converted barn in Connecticut and a midcentury modern in Los Angeles.

title: What You Get for ... $2,500,000
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Dad Was a Film Giant, Mum Was Mona Lisa. Perfect, Right?
description: Anjelica Huston grew up in such a bedazzlingly beautiful place that she couldnt see beyond its magic. At least thats the impression created by A Story Lately Told, the first half of Ms. Hustons life story. In this charm-filled but often oddly opaque book, she writes of life at St. Clerans, the grand estate in County Galway, Ireland, full of pets, flowers, exotic treasures and her parents famous friends. Ms. Huston presents lovely inventories of the things that made St. Clerans special, but she never says much about the elephant in the room.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?
description: For his new documentary, the director Michel Gondry interviewed the linguist and philosopher Noam Chomsky. The interview blends live-action footage and animated sequences  many of them drawn by Mr. Gondry. In this video, Mr. Gondry narrates an early sequence in which he asks Mr. Chomsky about his first memory.

title: The True Accountability in the JPMorgan Settlement
description: The watchword in the Justice Departments $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over the sale of questionable mortgage-backed securities is accountability. References to accountability appear 11 times in the news release detailing the resolution of federal and state cases against the bank over how it packaged faulty mortgages and sold them to investors.

title: Tribune Company to Cut 700 Newspaper Employees
description: The Tribune Company, owner of The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times, will lay off 700 employees at those newspapers and the six others it owns, it said in memos to the staff on Wednesday.

title: Fighting Hearing Loss From the Crowds Roar
description: Earlier this fall, Seattle Seahawks fans at CenturyLink Field broke the world record for loudest stadium crowd with a skull-splitting 136.6 decibels.

title: Global Fund Suspends 2 Mosquito Net Makers
description: The two top producers of mosquito nets for the war on malaria have been temporarily banned as suppliers by a global disease-fighting fund after admitting that they paid bribes to health officials in Cambodia.

title: Afghan Migrants in Iran Face Painful Contradictions but Keep Coming
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  They have few rights, can be arrested on sight and deprived of a trial, and are often deported four, five or more times  and no sooner are they across the border than they head back.

title: 10 Awesome Geek Gifts for Girls
description: Theres lots of online love for this GoldieBlox commercial (hat tip to Katy Waldman at Slate), with its Rube Goldberg use of dozens of pink toys and renegade rewrite of the Beastie Boys Girls song:

title: Paul Ryan, Marxist
description: Groucho Marxist, that is.

title: House Hunting in Sweden
description: Although vacation-home prices remained steady in Sweden during the downturn, very few homes have changed hands in the last three to four years.

title: House Hunting in ... Sweden
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM TIMBER HOME IN STOCKSUND

title: Lady Gaga Hits No. 1
description: The big winners on the music charts this week: Lady Gaga, Lorde and the Universal Music Group.

title: Rob Ford, Americas Mayor
description: The senior Washington correspondent of Canadas CBC News, Neil Macdonald, has been dutifully filing on the serial misbehavior of Torontos crack-smoking, binge-drinking mayor, Rob Ford, finding comfort in the fact that Mr. Ford at least has toppled Canadas reputation for monotonous, self-effacing reserve.

title: After Another Knee Injury, Duration of Recovery for Vonn Is Uncertain
description: In February, days after she sustained the first major knee injury of her career, Lindsey Vonn vowed to return to ski racing in record time. To Vonn, rehabilitating her reconstructed right anterior cruciate ligament became another competition  and she sped past every milestone in her recovery.

title: New Minibar Offerings: Handbags and Jewlery
description: The Quin, a new luxury art-themed hotel on Manhattans West Side, has a unique take on the minibar. In addition to a traditional fridge with snacks and drinks, the 208 rooms have a provisions cabinet selling high-end items like jewelry, handbags and cuff links.

title: 23 Weeks Pregnant, With No Good Choices
description: I was 23 weeks pregnant with my first child when we had our anatomic ultrasound here in Chile. In a darkened examination room, the doctor drew the wand over my belly, and our beautiful baby appeared on screen. His body flickered of his own volition, and I squeezed my husbands shoulder in relief. The doctor measured the circumference of our babys head, drew digital white lines down each limb, and examined the kidneys, stomach and spine. He confirmed the gender of our boy and sent his heartbeat to travel across the bottom of the screen at 142 beats per minute.

title: Republican Talking Points on Obamacare
description: The House Republicans response to the Affordable Care Act is increasingly organized and orchestrated, including collections of stories about people who say they were harmed by the health care law.

title: Presidential Medal of Freedom Awarded
description: President Obama presented the award to 16 Americans, including former President Bill Clinton.

title: De Blasio Talks With 3 Candidates for Police Commissioner
description: Breaking several days of silence, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio offered a glimpse on Wednesday into his efforts to form a new administration, acknowledging that he had met with three leading contenders for New York Citys next police commissioner.

title: Pact May Extend U.S. Troops Stay in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Wednesday that the United States and Afghanistan had finalized the wording of a bilateral security agreement that would allow for a lasting American troop presence through 2024 and set the stage for billions of dollars of international assistance to keep flowing to the government in Kabul.

title: Romeo and Juliet Will Close on Dec. 8
description: The producers of Romeo and Juliet have announced that the show, which was the Broadway debut of Orlando Bloom (Lord of the Rings), will close on Dec. 8, more than a month earlier than had been previously planned.

title: Where Does JPMorgans $13 Billion Go?
description: They were some of the biggest losers in the 2008 financial crisis: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, federal taxpayers, state pension funds, credit unions and, of course, homeowners.

title: Talking Health Insurance Over Thanksgiving Dinner
description: Heres a hypothetical scenario: Youre the president. Youve just botched the roll out of what should have been your signature accomplishment, a major reform of the health insurance system. The publics hopping mad because you said anyone who liked his insurance plan would be able to keep it, but that wasnt true.

title: In an Attack Ad, an Alaskan Voter Is Really an Actress From Maryland
description: WASHINGTON  In a tough new advertisement from the Koch brothers-backed Americans for Prosperity, an unnamed woman looks directly into the camera and upbraids Senator Mark Begich, Democrat of Alaska.

title: E.C.B. Nominates New Banking Regulator
description: FRANKFURT  The governing council of the European Central Bank nominated Danile Nouy on Wednesday as head of the new central bank regulator for the euro zone. With the move, the council fills one of the most prominent job openings in Europe while answering criticism that it has no women in senior leadership positions.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Kaufmann Mercantile Ceramic Growler
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Emblematically Yours
description: Logo culture reaches the next frontier as design elements for fashion.

title: Surveillance Camera Captures Embassy Blast in Beirut
description: As the death toll continued to rise from the double bombing at the Iranian embassy compound in Beirut on Tuesday, surveillance video was released showing the moment of the first explosion. The footage was posted online by Al Mayadeen television, which highlighted what it identified as one of the explosives-laden vehicles used in the attack. It was also broadcast by Al Manar television and LBCI.

title: Video: Fashion Diversity in Africa
description: Sporting overalls, yellow tinted glasses and arms covered in tattoos, Spleef Mczaul was recently walking along the street in the Maboneng Precinct in Johannesburg. Mr. Mczaul, who is opening a vintage store in the area, credits the neighborhood for bringing diversity in fashion to South Africa. Its people from different places coming together, Mr. Mczaul said. Youll see someone who is wearing an English coat but with an African-print T-shirt.

title: J.F.K. Through the Pages of The Times
description: Fifty years after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, a new book showcases The Timess coverage of his era.

title: Right Stuff? The Library Thinks So, and Buys It
description: Tom Wolfe has long been a gleeful scourge of New Yorks cultural institutions and the people who make them hum, from novelty-seeking museum curators and the mandarins of The New Yorker to the Wall Street buckaroos and social X-ray wives who swan around at all those galas.

title: AT&T and Verizon Pressed to Detail Roles in U.S. Surveillance Efforts
description: Shareholders are putting AT&T and Verizon Wireless on notice: Tell the public more about the companies role in government surveillance efforts or risk a ding to the bottom line.

title: Scene City: Balenciaga Opens a Marbled Store in SoHo
description: Alexander Wang, Julianne Moore and others unveil the brands flagship store in New York.

title: The Return of Logo Culture
description: There are 17 logos on Heron Prestons signature long-sleeve T-shirt: M&Ms and Trix; Google and Remington; Home Depot, huge, on the back; Nascar, upside down, on the front.

title: John F. Kennedy Presidential Library
description: The John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston emphasizes Kennedy as a president whose promise was cut short.

title: Recalling Kennedys Death, or Life
description: DALLAS  Looking through the window next to the snipers perch, you can just make out the grassy knoll through the trees branches. It seems inconsequential, mundane  certainly not as imagination pictured it. A knoll? There are no rolling English hillocks in Dealey Plaza. There is a one-way, three-lane road that curves under an overpass, with plots of lawn on either side.

title: After Kennedy Tragedy, Finding Solace in Art
description: In 1961, Jacqueline Kennedy created the office of the White House curator, transforming the nations most famous residence for the first time into a collecting art institution, which it remains to this day. But that same year, she also reached out for a handful of artworks that would come to play a profoundly personal role in her life before and after her husbands death.

title: Developing Nations Stage Protest at Climate Talks
description: WARSAW  The United Nations climate talks here are bogging down over the old divide between rich and poor nations on the question of who should pay when climate-related disaster strikes, with developing nations staging a symbolic walkout early Wednesday in protest at what they consider inadequate financial support from wealthy countries.

title: Who Do You Want to Be (Besides a Playful Codger)?
description: Ending up in a retirement home could be joyous  if youve always wanted to relive dorm life and would like it even better with everybody having gotten cranky and lost both their youthful good looks and their hearing. (You have to say everything twice in this place.) And with no choice about which drugs you take or when. Richard Abrons apparently gave this prospect some thought before writing Every Day a Visitor, which Woodie King Jr.s New Federal Theater is presenting at the Clurman Theater with a colorful, lovable and mostly mature cast.

title: For Sale: Digital Camera. Estimated Price: $500,000 to $750,000.
description: Are you in need of a new digital camera? I have a deal for you. Its a one-of-a-kind Leica that will cost an estimated $500,000 to $750,000. What about a new Mac computer? I know where you can pick one up for about $60,000. Need some new headphones? I have a deal on those, too. A pair of solid rose gold iPod earbuds for about $25,000.

title: Improvising in Total Darkness
description: Darkness enveloped me as I listened to the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haass String Quartet No. 3 on Tuesday night at Lincoln Centers Clark Studio Theater. This is the way the composer intended for the piece to be performed. As much as I was engrossed by the music, the performance by the JACK Quartet and the rare experience of hearing music with others in darkness, I could not help feeling that some uncomfortable assumptions were being made for this event, called In the Dark, part of the centers White Light Festival.

title: Bodies That Spin, Sway and Swerve in Shadows
description: In Complexions Contemporary Ballet, dancers kick their legs to make a show of it. They swivel their hips with insouciance. Their swaying bodies might look as if theyre about to tip over, until a breath  irritatingly visible in a heaving chest  forces them upright. They are skilled technicians. The issue with Complexions, led by the founding artistic directors Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, is how far the repertory is from actually being contemporary.

title: Michael Cappelletti and His One-No-Trump Opening
description: Michael Cappelletti of Alexandria, Va., died on Nov. 14, at 71. In national championships, he won the 1967 Master Mixed Teams and the 2013 Leventritt Silver Ribbon Pairs and had seven seconds. He amassed 24,317.23 master points, placing him 49th on the lifetime list.

title: Memoir to Musical: Five-Year Journey
description: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has presented his share of complicated new musicals. But Fun Home, he said, was in a class by itself.

title: Techies Striving for the Next Big Thing
description: Betas represents such an amalgam of digital story lines  its about a Silicon Valley start-up, and its bankrolled and hosted by an Internet behemoth, Amazon  that its tempting to review it as if it were a new app rather than an online comedy. Such as: While it lacks some features found in big-budget television sitcoms, and it can be glitchy when it comes to racial and sexual humor, it provides a better user experience than a majority of online series. A solid three-and-a-half stars.

title: Roasted Turkey Stock
description: Julia Moskin makes roasted turkey stock adapted from a recipe by Suzanne Goin of A.O.C. restaurant.

title: Pictures of the Day: The Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from The Philippines, Virginia, Lebanon and Bulgaria.

title: Food Stamp Spending and Caseload Are Declining, Report Says
description: The money spent on food stamps and the number of people who receive them are declining as the economy has improved, according to a report released Wednesday, even as the program remains a source of contention in congressional negotiations to complete a five-year farm bill.

title: Ballet Dancers as Brands
description: LONDON  They are the new jet set.

title: Empowering Girls to Build the Future
description: GoldieBlox, a toy company, produced a commercial featuring three young girls that turn an average home into a massive, magical contraption.

title: Whats He Really Like? Check the Lulu App
description: Not long ago, after Alexandra Amin, an assistant at Warner Brothers, broke up with an agent she had been dating for a year, her friend told her about a new, free, female-friendly social networking app that lets women anonymously review men who are their Facebook friends.

title: Making Turkey Stock With Suzanne Goin
description: Updated | Nov. 25, 2013

title: For Alexander Wang, a SoHo Housewarming Party
description: On Tuesday night, Alexander Wang, the new designer for Balenciaga, arrived for the opening of its SoHo store at 148 Mercer Street. It was heavy on the Italian green marble and limestone.

title: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at 6 p.m.
description: President Obama awards Medals of Freedom; a study compares daily quizzes with exams; and a 'real' mayor of New York City.

title: Egypts Revolution Was Stolen by Muslim Brotherhood, Kerry Says
description: Secretary of State John Kerry argued on Wednesday that Egypts 2011 revolution was started by tech-savvy young people with no ideological aims before being stolen by Islamists from the Muslim Brotherhood, who behaved autocratically after winning parliamentary and presidential elections.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Rupert and Wendi Murdoch Reach a Divorce Settlement
description: Rupert Murdoch and Wendi Deng Murdoch appeared in court Wednesday morning and announced they had reached a divorce settlement, an agreement that effectively ends the 14-year marriage of the media mogul and his third wife.

title: Building Luxury Villas for Poor Neighbors
description: When 26-year-old Tang Guo left his hometown in Sichuan Province for the neighboring province of Yunnan in 1993, all he had was 2 renminbi in his pocket and, as Mr. Tang put it, a willingness to eat bitterness, a Chinese term for resilience and toughness. Twenty years later, Mr. Tang is the head of a real estate construction group with 20 subsidiaries and fixed assets worth more than 2 billion renminbi, or about $328 million.

title: Art Furniture: A Form-Function Twofer
description: Kelly Behun is an interior designer with the eye of a gallerist. The way I look at things, she said, designing a space is an exercise in curating: the chairs, the lamps and all that stuff is sculpture.

title: Sales at DDC, Park Avenue Garage and Others
description: DDC has opened a temporary outlet shop, with furniture and decorative accessories discounted up to 70 percent (the Andersen sofa by Rodolfo Dordoni for Minotti, originally $11,935, is $8,354); 33 East 33rd Street, 212-685-0800, ddcnyc.com.

title: At 89, a Pioneering Street Photographer Finally Gets His Due
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Styling Black Jumpsuits
description: Bored with the L.B.D.? Here is the L.B.J. for holiday parties this year.

title: Time to Take the Leap
description: Ah, the L.B.D.  so simple, so sensible, so ... snoozy. This holiday season, may we suggest the L.B.J.?

title: Do As He Says, Not As He Does
description: The landscape architect Thomas Rainer defends his garden.

title: Hell Try Anything
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Dont look at the garden in the pictures. This is no place Thomas Rainer wants exposed to the world.

title: City (Manchester) in the City (N.Y.)
description: What do Brooklyn Bridge Park, the High Line, Yankee Stadium and Rucker Park have in common, besides being part of the fabric of New York City?

title: What Would Sister Parish Do?
description: The beauty of a boxy apartment is that you can do anything you want with it, including turning it into an homage to the most celebrated decorators of the 20th century.

title: The Peak of Chic: Borrowing From the Best
description: Jennifer Boles lives in a two-bedroom apartment in a brutalist high-rise on Peachtree Road. This stark, bunkerlike setting is worth noting because Ms. Boles, 41, is the creator of the Peak of Chic design blog, a love letter to  nay, an epic poem in celebration of  the sort of effusive, ebullient and, yes, very traditional decorating practiced by Dorothy Draper, Nancy Lancaster, Albert Hadley and Sister Parish, among other 20th-century greats. A more stark contrast between Ms. Boless highly embellished, high-gloss interiors, with their faux finishes, leopard prints, tufted wallpaper and Porthault sheets, and the buildings gritty concrete skin can hardly be imagined.

title: Ryan McGinley, the Pied Piper of the Downtown Art World
description: The social orbit surrounding the photographer Ryan McGinley can sometimes feel like the worlds most exclusive nightclub, populated by good-looking and talented 20-somethings, who with their perfect skin and classic faces all seem to have walked out of a Kerouac novel, an idyllic Midwestern town or an American Apparel ad.

title: Catering to the Masses: A New Edition of Cooking for Crowds
description: In Merry Whites Boston high school, lunch was a class called Gracious Living, where all the food was beige and served by maids, and pepper was considered too heating for young ladies. From then on, she writes in the foreword to the new 40th-anniversary edition of her 1974 classic, Cooking for Crowds (Princeton University Press, $29.95), my life has been a search for the heat and pleasure of food. Her book, made up of recipes she collected as the caterer for the Harvard Center for European Studies, suggested a new way of entertaining, with self-serve spanakopita, petite shrimp quiche and that savior of the anxious cook, the casserole that can be made a day ahead. Edward Korens woolly illustrations set the tone: vegetables are our friends, and food tastes best in groups. Even though pesto and vindaloo are no longer exotic, during the holidays her attitude (and her meatballs) may be what every stressed-out host needs.

title: Belated, Yes; Forgotten, No: A Tribute to Dan Kiley
description: Imagine not celebrating the 100th anniversary of the architect Mies van der Rohes birth, said Charles Birnbaum, the founder of the Cultural Landscape Foundation. But in September 2012, thats precisely the fate that befell Dan Kiley, the seminal postwar landscape architect behind the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial in St. Louis, featuring Eero Saarinens Gateway Arch, and Patterns, the garden of the du Pont home in Wilmington, Del.

title: A Loft Thats a Real Showplace
description: When Diego Paccagnella, the president of Design-Apart, a company that sells custom Italian furnishings, wanted to display samples in New York, he found someone in Manhattan with a 2,600-square-foot loft who was willing to move out for a year and give it to him rent-free. Mr. Paccagnella; his wife, Livia; and their 16-month-old son, Giulio (all at top right), moved in and redecorated the apartment as a live-in showroom. In a year, the Paccagnellas will move out, leaving about a half-million dollars in furnishings for the owners to keep, while they find and redo another New York home.

title: Treasures, but Only to You?
description: A few months after my mother died in 2011 at the age of 93, I put her Manhattan apartment on the market and was lucky enough to have a deal within days. The buyers were paying cash and seemed certain to be approved by the co-op board.

title: Should Americans Fear Their Furniture?
description: The pet hairs and red wine stains on sofas across America, it turns out, should be the least of our concerns. The real issue is what is in the foam cushions we curl up on every day: up to two pounds of flame retardants.

title: Soaking Up the Local Color
description: Deborah Osburn began making colorful tiles to brighten up a mostly beige-dominated industry nearly 30 years ago. And though in recent years she has been selling other artists designs, she has returned to her creative roots with the Watermark Collection for Tilevera, her artisan tile company. Inspired by Japanese techniques, she produced the ombr-stained tiles by placing unglazed porcelain into a cup of indigo and waiting for the dye to be absorbed.

title: Should I Install Professional-Style Appliances?
description: Q. Would putting professional-style appliances in my kitchen increase my homes value?

title: The Nakeds Next Door
description: Shannon Sessoms has never been so ready for winter. Cold weather brings the promise of several months without awkward sightings of the neighbors whom her family refers to as the Nakeds.

title: How Smart Is Your Smoke Alarm?
description: The Timess Jenna Wortham considers whether the bang is worth the buck for a combination smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector called Nest Protect.

title: Ad Takes Off Online: Less Doll, More Awl
description: Who said girls want to dress in pink and play with dolls, especially when they could be building Rube Goldberg machines instead?

title: A Smart Smoke Alarm That Keeps Its Cool
description: The last apartment I lived in was a certifiable fire hazard. It was mostly my fault  I ripped out the smoke detector my landlord had installed because it was so sensitive that even a steamy shower would set off its earsplitting beeping.

title: A Camera That Offers Instant Gratification and Prints
description: Its great to see party pictures instantly on your smartphone, but you cant easily hang those shots on your refrigerator or tuck one into the frame of a mirror. You can order prints, of course, if you dont mind waiting.

title: Money Traders Fret Over Possible U.S.-Iran Pact
description: TEHRAN  Sitting atop a bronze statue in the center of Tehrans modest Manoucheri Square, where a group of illegal money changers gathers every day, a bald man waved a thick stack of dollar bills, as dozens of others shouted figures and numbers.

title: Paul Sevigny Brings a New Bar to TriBeCa
description: Could this be (another) new Beatrice Inn? Since being silenced by griping neighbors in 2009, Paul Sevignys fashionable West Village bar has been endlessly imitated: Pyongyang door policies, shabby chic furniture, swirls of celebrities and downtown dirtbags. Pauls Baby Grand, his first solo offering since Beatrice closed, has rejiggered an auxiliary space at the Tribeca Grand hotel into a lounge-like spiritual successor (albeit a smaller and less decadent incarnation).

title: Fall Fashion, Its all About the Details
description: The holidays are upon us  time to break out the pearls. They may have shed their patrician pedigree some time ago, but this season the makeover is almost decadent, though in the nicest way: a fat pearl hiding under the sole of Nicholas Kirkwood pumps; a single strand attached to dresses at Valentino; pearls as trim running up and down and around tailored Alexander McQueen separates. In jewelry, theyre affixed in surprising new ways to necklaces, rings and cuffs by Aurlie Bidermann, Delfina Delettrez and others. Earlier this year, everyone was head over heels about the Dior pearls worn as a single earring, on the back and front of the earlobe. Now, for resort, they come in pretty pink and bright blue. Seriously, they could become a girls best friend.

title: Robert Bowie, 104, Adviser to Truman, Eisenhower, Johnson and Carter, Dies
description: Robert R. Bowie, a Harvard foreign policy expert who served four postwar administrations as an adviser on the Cold War, national security and conflicts around the globe, died on Nov. 2 in Towson, Md. He was 104.

title: Condom Contest Produces 812 Ideas for Improvement
description: The condom of the future might be made of cow tendon or fish skin. It might have shape memory to instantly mold to a specific man. Or it might come with pull tabs so a man could slip it on with little fuss.

title: In October, a Day for the New York City Subways Ridership Record Book
description: The weather was mild on the subway systems perfect day  clear skies to coax New Yorkers outdoors, paired with a breeze that discouraged long walks.

title: Readers React to Death of a Diver, and an Image of Him
description: When the free diver Nick Mevoli, 32, emerged Sunday from an attempt at diving 72 meters below the ocean surface in the Bahamas, the photographer Lia Hyun-Joo Barrett caught him in a frame. In the photo, Mr. Mevoli, accompanied by three safety divers, looks startled, his eyes bulging.

title: John Varvatos: His Runway Has a Backbeat
description: Last Thursday night around 7, the designer John Varvatos was in his Chelsea showroom, about to head up to Harlem with a few staff members and his wife, Joyce. They were going to the Apollo Theater, where the guitarist Gary Clark Jr. was on the bill.

title: Shopping Events Starting Nov. 21 in New York City
description: Openings

title: Raw Sewage and Anger Flood Gazas Streets as Electricity Runs Low
description: GAZA CITY  Raw sewage has flooded streets in a southern Gaza City neighborhood in recent days, threatening a health disaster, after a shortage of electricity and cheap diesel fuel from Egypt led the Hamas government to shut down Gazas lone power plant, causing a pump station to flood.

title: New Approach to Treating Cholesterol
description: To the Editor:

title: Andris Nelsons to Conduct During Tanglewoods 2014 Season
description: His efforts to make it there last summer were thwarted by injury. But Andris Nelsons will head to the Berkshires this summer for his first appearances at the Tanglewood Festival since he was named the music director designate of the Boston Symphony Orchestra  with plans to conduct music by Dvorak, Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Rolf Martinsson and Christopher Rouse.

title: Applicants Find Health Website Is Improving, but Not Fast Enough
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa.  Tilda Elias had reason to be optimistic when she opened the HealthCare.gov website on Monday, ready to help her first client of the week find health insurance. Technicians had made fixes to the online insurance exchange over the weekend. Even more promising, her client, Giovanna Romano, had managed to complete an online application at home with no problems.

title: The Dog on the Plane: Annoyance or Helper?
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Grandmothers Skin Care?
description: As you gaze exasperatedly around the Thanksgiving table next week, perhaps you should consider that Aunt Sue or Granny Esther may be a potential font of beauty wisdom.

title: Philip Glass Is Among the Offerings at Nashvilles New Contemporary Arts Center
description: Nashville has long been the capital of a particular strain of country music, and lately the Nashville Symphony has established a reputation for adventurousness (but only narrowly avoided foreclosure proceedings on its spiffy new hall).

title: Reusing Historic Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dissidents Daughter, on Rights and Reform in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Shaping Bushy Eyebrows
description: Thanks in part to the model Cara Delevingne, bushy eyebrows are finding favor this season. Here are a few new products to help prune and shape them.

title: How Bush Let Iran Go Nuclear
description: AMERICAN and Iranian negotiators yesterday began a second round of talks in Geneva, seeking a deal on Irans nuclear program.

title: Firefighters Are Injured in Major Fire in the Bronx
description: A fire tore through a section of the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx late Wednesday morning, destroying crates of tropical fruit and leaving several firefighters injured.

title: Campaign Seeks to Recruit Top Students to Become Teachers
description: If you cant do, teach. The three best things about teaching? June, July and August.

title: The Truth About Tornadoes
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  DOES global warming weaken tornadoes?

title: Bus Stoppage Said to Target Rikers Inmate
description: When an apparent job action by city correction workers stranded dozens of city correction buses at Rikers Island this week, hundreds of inmates failed to make their scheduled court appearances  including one man of particular interest.

title: Frequent Tests Can Enhance College Learning, Study Finds
description: Grading college students on quizzes given at the beginning of every class, rather than on midterms or a final exam, increases both attendance and overall performance, scientists reported Wednesday.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Hitting Stop on Winamp, and Snapchats Women
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Kazakhstans Bet on Rail
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  The railroad locomotive factory here on the outskirts of the capital of Kazakhstan is one of the most modern in the world, with huge yellow overhead cranes and a work force of 1,100. An engine factory being built next door will soon make some of the worlds most fuel-efficient 12-cylinder diesel engines.

title: The Public Needs a Nap
description: One of the many problems with the Senate filibuster rule is that it requires us to think about the Senate filibuster rule.

title: Yankees Best Deal Might Be Letting Cano Go
description: The Yankees have gotten nine excellent seasons and one championship from Robinson Cano. They have paid him about $58 million. Now he wants that much again, and about $250 million more, for a decade that almost certainly will not be as productive.

title: Representative Meng Is Mugged on Capitol Hill
description: Representative Grace Meng was robbed this week in Washington by a person who hit her in the back of the head and stole her purse as she fell, she said on Wednesday.

title: Voting via Twitter, Choosing Jennifer Lopezs Route to an Awards Show
description: HEADING into the shopping frenzy of Thanksgiving week, Kohls is featuring one of its collection celebrities, Jennifer Lopez, in a social media campaign involving a series of commercials that will air during the American Music Awards on Sunday.

title: Aid Groups Get Strong Response to Philippines Appeals
description: The United Nations relief agency has elicited a strong response so far to an emergency financing appeal for overcoming the Philippines typhoon disaster, receiving nearly half the amount requested in the week since the effort was begun, a humanitarian aid database reported in an update on Wednesday.

title: When Children Are Traded
description: A few ads offering free children on the Internet:

title: JPMorgan Pays
description: The long-awaited $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over allegations of misrepresentation in the sale of mortgage securities is hardly a cure-all for the damage inflicted on homeowners, investors and the economy by fraud, predation and other wrongdoing during the bubble. It is, however, a likely precursor of similar payouts from other banks, and it provides at least some cash for investors and a measure of relief for struggling homeowners and communities. Where it falls short is in its failure to hold individuals accountable.

title: United States Can Spy on Britons Despite Pact, N.S.A. Memo Says
description: The National Security Agency is authorized to spy on the citizens of Americas closest allies, including Britain, even though those English-speaking countries have long had an official non-spying pact, according to a newly disclosed memorandum.

title: Skakel Lawyers May Have Challenge Winning Bail
description: When Michael C. Skakel appears in Stamford Superior Court on Thursday to make the case that he be released on bail while prosecutors try to get his 2002 murder conviction reinstated, Judge Gary J. White is the man he will have to persuade.

title: Senate Democrats Poised to Block Filibusters of Presidential Picks
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats are on the verge of moving to eliminate the use of the filibuster against most presidential nominees, aides and senior party leaders said Wednesday, a move that would deprive Republicans of their ability to block President Obamas picks for cabinet posts and the federal judiciary and further erode what little bipartisanship still exists in the Senate.

title: Libyas Resurgent Violence
description: One year ago, officials in the transition government in Libya spoke of making progress toward integrating rival militias into a cohesive security force that could stabilize the country as it seeks to become a democracy.

title: Germany, Austeritys Champion, Faces Some Big Repair Bills
description: PADERBORN, Germany  When inspectors decided a few months ago that the aging bridge over the Kiel Canal in northern Germany was too weak for heavy truck traffic, Holger Dechant, hired to deliver giant wind turbines to the other side, was at a loss.

title: A Brash Young Talent Finds New Focus With Dallas
description: For a while, Tyler Seguin seemed like the N.H.L.s answer to Justin Bieber: a young, talented Canadian whose reported partying sometimes overshadowed his performances.

title: Ex-U.S. Attorney to Join Davis Polk Law Firm in Washington
description: Neil H. MacBride, the former United States attorney in Alexandria, Va., will join Davis Polk & Wardwell as a partner, the firm will announce on Thursday.

title: Warrantless Surveillance Continues to Cause Fallout
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has notified a Somali-American man who was convicted this year of trying to detonate a bomb in Portland, Ore., that his trial included evidence derived from warrantless wiretapping, a move that could disrupt plans to sentence him next month.

title: Major Retailers Agree to Inspection Standards in Bangladesh
description: Two groups of retailers  one dominated by American companies, the other by European brands  announced on Wednesday that they had agreed on joint inspection standards for thousands of garment factories in Bangladesh as part of their effort to improve workplace safety there.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 20, 2013
Texas Women and Abortion Rights
description: In an alarming 5-to-4 ruling, the Supreme Court turned away an emergency application to block a new Texas law that is impeding access to safe and legal abortion care in the state. The ruling leaves in place an order by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit that allowed the law go into effect while it considers an appeal.

title: Active and Improvising, Kerry Is Taking On Tough Problems
description: WASHINGTON  John Kerry has made no secret of his ambitions as secretary of state. On a visit to the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem last March, he watched as two bearded patriarchs pleaded with President Obama to bring peace to the Holy Land. Clasping their hands, Mr. Kerry said, Im going to work as hard as I can to get it done.

title: Beneath the Virgin Prairie
description: Even if you have stood on a remnant of virgin prairie, it is hard to imagine what was lost when the tallgrass prairie was plowed. Settlers were staggered by the scope of the prairies, and they were more amazed by the richness of the soil. The biomass of roots beneath the ground was as dense and tangled as the biomass on top. And when the prairies were plowed, everything changed  the ecosystem, the structure of the soil, and, as it turns out, the microorganisms living in the soil.

title: A Lure to the Classroom
description: A public service campaign to recruit a new generation of teachers features ads that compare teaching to careers like medicine, acting and engineering.

title: SAC Trader Had Secret Pipeline of Information, Prosecutors Say
description: Michael S. Steinberg is successful, steady, serious, said a lawyer for the most senior employee at SAC Capital Advisors to be charged with insider trading. And unlike the hard-charging billionaires who rule Wall Streets top hedge funds, Mr. Steinberg was a history and philosophy major who started at SAC as a low-level clerk, the lawyer said.

title: Rodriguez Isnt the Only One Whos Had Enough
description: Alex Rodriguez walked out of his own arbitration hearing on Wednesday, saying that he was disgusted with this abusive process and that the absurdity and injustice just became too much.

title: Barneys and Macys No-Shows at a City Hearing
description: The City Council hearing was notable for its absences: No representative from Barneys New York or Macys appeared on Wednesday to discuss accusations of racial profiling against shoppers at their Manhattan stores. Nor did anyone show up from the Police Department, which has been criticized by black shoppers who have been detained at the stores.

title: Anti-Abortion Forces Reassess Their Tactics After Ballot Defeat in Albuquerque
description: ALBUQUERQUE  The decisive defeat of a municipal ballot measure here that sought to ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy left anti-abortion forces conceding that some of their tactics had backfired and that they had less support among Catholic Hispanic voters than they had expected.

title: November 22, 1963
description: Will we ever know the truth about the Kennedy assassination? In a film by Errol Morris, Josiah Tink Thompson returns to what has haunted him for 50 years: Frame #313 of the Zapruder film.

title: A Novel Scorned
description: When I was in middle school, I read Margaret Mitchells epic romance, Gone With the Wind. Not once. Not twice. But continuously. Each time I finished the novel, I began again, flipping open the broken-spined paperback so many times the book split in half, yielding two portable sections of text. I preferred a break of at least several hours between readings, but sometimes compulsion forced me to begin again only moments after finishing it.

title: Reconciling a Sports Violent Appeal as a Fighter Lies in a Coma
description: Three men sat inside a Manhattan diner. Their fighter, the Russian heavyweight Magomed Abdusalamov, remained in a medically induced coma at Roosevelt Hospital, across the street.

title: November 22, 1963
description: A brief rsum. Josiah Tink Thompson, the subject of this Op-Doc, graduated from Yale in 1957, became a demolitions expert and frogman for the Navy, and then returned to Yale to get his Ph.D. on the Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaard.

title: Colombia: President, a U.S. Ally, Seeks Another Term
description: President Juan Manuel Santos announced Wednesday that he would run for re-election, saying that he wanted to finish the work he started in seeking a peace deal with the countrys largest rebel group. When you see the light at the end of the tunnel you dont go backwards, Mr. Santos, one of the closest allies of the United States in Latin America, said on television. We will finish the job. The negotiations with the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, have advanced slowly, and there are still significant obstacles to an agreement to end the nearly 50-year-old conflict.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 21, 2013
description: I dont expect you to understand. I mean, how many people go to work and say, literally say, I might die tonight. But thats boxing.

title: Navy Was Warned of Contractor at Center of Bribery Inquiry
description: Leonard Glenn Francis, a wealthy Malaysian contractor at the heart of one of the United States Navys largest bribery scandals in decades, seemed to have stepped right off the set of Casablanca.

title: In a Shelter, and Striving to Help a Child
description: The last few years have been traumatic ones for Juana Rosario, who has been living in the New York City shelter system since 2010, alongside her husband and her disabled granddaughter, Amy Germosen Rosario. But as nightmarish as the experience has been, she prefers it to going back home to the Dominican Republic.

title: Racism in the Age of Obama
Corrections: November 21, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Ready for Publication
description: Updated, 2:28 p.m. | Congratulations to puzzle master Will Shortz, who celebrates 20 years as editor of The New York Times crossword puzzle today!

title: In Her Room, With a View Based on Recollections
description: A grieving widow immures herself in her bedroom, surrounded by little more than stacks of overdue library books and her aching memory, in Too Much, Too Much, Too Many, a subdued but affecting new play by Meghan Kennedy that opened on Wednesday night at the Roundabout Undergrounds Black Box Theater.

title: Bloomberg Lured Donors for New York Programs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is well known for tapping his own fortune to fill in gaps in the citys resources, whether spending millions of dollars to renovate Gracie Mansion or keeping the kitchen in the City Hall bullpen stocked with healthy snacks for his staff.

title: AARP Releases Free Health Cost Calculator
description: William Martin, a financial adviser with Aequus Wealth Management in Chicago, counsels clients to plan for health costs in retirement. Theres a high probability Ill live into my 90s, said Mr. Martin, 52, noting that hes in good health and his grandparents lived into their 90s. So I need to plan for that.

title: U.S. Says Dozens of Americans Have Sought to Join Rebels in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  Dozens of Americans have traveled or tried to travel to Syria to fight with the rebels against the government of President Bashar al-Assad since 2011, American intelligence officials said Wednesday.

title: Carnegie Mellon Bringing Sciences Programs to Brooklyn
description: Joining a club that already includes Cornell University, New York University and Columbia University, Carnegie Mellon University on Wednesday became the fourth institution of higher learning  and the first from out of state  to announce plans for an applied sciences program in New York City.

title: Mr. McAllister Goes to Washington, and He Is Wowed
description: WASHINGTON  Vance McAllister, a 39-year-old college dropout and Army veteran, managed to vanquish a formidable Republican opponent backed by the partys establishment, win a special election in Louisianas Fifth District in a 20-point landslide, and score an endorsement from the star of Duck Dynasty.

title: European Parliament Votes to Choose Single Meeting Site
description: BRUSSELS  The European Parliament voted on Wednesday to choose a single meeting place, showing its frustration with monthly commutes between Brussels and Strasbourg, France, that are seen by many lawmakers and citizens as a colossal waste of money and an embarrassment at a time of painful austerity across the European Union.

title: A Newly Minted Congressman Visits His Office
description: Representative Vance McAllister, the newest member of the House, arrived in the nations capital for the first time on Wednesday.

title: For Nalbandian, a Supporting Role in the Era of Federer and Nadal
description: In tennis, much more often than not, it does not work out as planned.

title: Weve Got to Make Government Work
description: The Timess Ashley Parker interviewed Louisianas newest representative, Vance McAllister, hours after he arrived to start his first term.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Saints (8-2) at Falcons (2-8)
description: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

title: Patenting Their Discoveries Does Not Pay Off for Most Universities, a Study Says
description: Universities try to cash in on discoveries  gene splicing, brain chemistry, computer-chip design  but the great majority of them fail to turn their research into a source of income, according to a new study from the Brookings Institution.

title: Familiar Scenes: Star Hurts Ankle, and Nets Stagger
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The Nets revisited recurring themes of this young season Wednesday night on the way to a dispiriting 95-91 defeat to the Charlotte Bobcats.

title: G.O.P. Maps Out Waves of Attacks Over Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The memo distributed to House Republicans this week was concise and blunt, listing talking points and marching orders: Because of Obamacare, I Lost My Insurance. Obamacare Increases Health Care Costs. The Exchanges May Not Be Secure, Putting Personal Information at Risk. Continue Collecting Constituent Stories.

title: Great Effort by Knicks, for 47 Minutes
description: When Coach Mike Woodson met with his playersWednesdaymorning, he reminded them that nobody was running away with the Atlantic Division. The Philadelphia 76ers were planted atop the standings with a losing record. Everybody else was clustered beneath them with similarly dismal marks.

title: Good Lord Bird Is Surprise Winner for National Book Award in Fiction
description: James McBride won the National Book Award on Wednesday night for The Good Lord Bird, an irreverent, sharp-eyed novel narrated by an escaped slave. It was published by Riverhead Books, part of Penguin Random House.

title: Diane Disney Miller, 79, Keeper of Walts Flame, Dies
description: Diane Disney Miller, Walt Disneys last surviving child, who stood up for Frank Gehrys spectacularly abstract design for the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and co-founded a museum dedicated to the memory of her father as a human being rather than a brand, died on Tuesday in Napa Valley, Calif., where she had a home. She was 79.

title: Great Lakes Recover Substantial Water Levels
description: Water levels in the Great Lakes,which reached historic lows earlier this year, have recovered substantiallybecause of heavy snowfall and spring rains, government scientists said. Lakes Michigan and Huron saw a 20-inch rise this yearnearly twice the normal amount, said Keith Kompoltowicz, who monitors the lakes for the Army Corps of Engineers. Levels remain below long-term averages in some of the lakes, and it is hard to predict whether the gains will hold, said Drew Gronewold, a hydrologist with the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: Online Courses Attract Degree Holders, Survey Finds
description: About 80 percent of people who enrolled in a massive open online course, or MOOC, from the University of Pennsylvania had already earned a bachelors degree, according to a survey of 34,000 students who had at least started one of the 24 courses the university offered on the Coursera platform. Although Courseras founders have presented their MOOCs as a way to democratize higher education by making it available online, free, to anyone in the world, the Penn survey found that in the United States and developing countries alike, most Coursera students were well educated, employed, young and male. Penns courses account for 20 percent of Courseras enrollment.

title: Inside the Winbot 730, a Robotic Window Cleaner
description: The cleaning device figures out the size of your window mirror and then cleans the surface on its own.

title: Gray Gets a Feminine Makeover
description: Gray flannel, a fabric usually reserved for men  in a bankers suit or a hunters henley  has been reimagined for the everyday woman. When combined with leather, it can transform an ordinary baseball cap into a chic topper for any outfit, a basic tablet case into a handsome clutch or a simple duffel into a prim carryall. A basic flannel skirt gets dressed up when paired with punklike jewelry in gray tones. Other gray materials can offer similar impact to flannel as well. Pony hair, as seen on these elegant Chanel loafers, is a feminine alternative that is well suited for ladies who lunch. The ombr effect on this neoprene knit sweater from Proenza Schouler offers a contemporary riff on the idea of gray flannel that looks as at home on the streets as it does surf-side.

title: Limiting the Fed
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Birth Control Pills May Raise Eye Risks
description: Women who use oral contraceptives for several years or longer may want to consider having their eyes checked more regularly as they get older. New research suggests that the pills may double their lifetime risk of developing glaucoma, a degenerative eye disease that can cause blindness if left untreated.

title: Word of the Day | argot
description: argot \r-gt, -()go\ noun

title: Tigers Trade Fielder for Kinsler
description: When the Detroit Tigers signed Prince Fielder to a nine-year, $214 million contract in January 2012, it was considered a swift, bold move intended to bring the aging owner Mike Ilitch a World Series championship.

title: Week 12 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Strange Math for Jets
description: Pythagoras was an ancient Greek mathematician and philosopher. The New York Jets are a modern professional football team. And they dont seem to agree.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (IFC) EYES WIDE SHUT (1999) A doctor (Tom Cruise), enraged by the desire of his wife (Nicole Kidman, above, with Mr. Cruise) for another man, embarks on an odyssey of sexual temptation in this final film by Stanley Kubrick, inspired by Arthur Schnitzlers Traumnovelle (Dream Story). Open-ended vignettes star Sydney Pollack as the unsavory host of a lavish Christmas party, Alan Cumming as a conspiratorial hotel concierge, Rade Sherbedgia as the proprietor of a costume rental shop, and Leelee Sobieski as his naughty daughter. There is consolation for having to read the words The End on the posthumous work of Mr. Kubrick: this astonishing last film is a spellbinding addition to the Kubrick canon, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Despite some abrupt editing in a work that the director never lived to fine-tune, the film moves effortlessly, and it goes straight under the skin. Its powerful and lingering resonance attests to a final compassion and profundity in Mr. Kubrick, the body-and-soul commitment of Mr. Cruise and Ms. Kidman, and the Rorschach-like ability of this material to envelop audiences in ways unexplained and unexpected. She added: Life goes on, Mr. Pollacks character says cynically late in the film. It always does, until it doesnt. Along with that sentiment, Mr. Kubrick left one more brilliantly provocative tour de force as his epitaph.

title: A Conversation With: Author Gaiutra Bahadur
description: In Coolie Woman, the Guyanese-American journalist Gaiutra Bahadur excavates the forgotten story of her great-grandmother Sujaria and a quarter of a million women like her who left eastern India in the mid-1800s as indentured labor. The book, which was released last week in the United States and last month in India, is deeply personal yet assiduously researched. From the treacherous sea voyage to the colonial outpost of British Guiana to the sexual privileges conferred on indentured women as the scarcer sex, Ms. Bahadur reconstructs the coolie womans fate in astonishing detail.

title: News Quiz | November 21, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Prosecutors Detail Attempt to Sway South Korean Election
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Agents from the National Intelligence Service of South Korea posted more than 1.2 million Twitter messages last year to try to sway public opinion in favor of Park Geun-hye, then a presidential candidate, and her party ahead of elections in 2012, state prosecutors said on Thursday.

title: Drone Strikes a Seminary in Pakistan
