description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Missiles believed to have been fired by an American drone struck an Islamic seminary in northern Pakistan on Thursday, in a rare strike outside the countrys volatile tribal regions.

title: Lu Xun Letter Sold for More Than $1 Million
description: China is flush with cash, but even so, some Chinese are marveling at the price of a letter auctioned in Beijing this week at the China Guardian fall auctions: a 220-character missive by Lu Xun, one of the countrys most venerated writers.

title: Suspect Held in Shooting at a Paris Newspaper
description: PARIS  After a two-day manhunt, the French police arrested a man they believe was responsible for a shooting this week at a newspaper office in Paris and gunfire at a bank headquarters nearby, the authorities announced late Wednesday night.

title: As Labor Camp Prisoners Are Released, Questions Remain
description: Local governments in Shanghai and Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, announced this week that they had released all detainees previously held at their re-education through labor camps. The news comes shortly after the central government declared its intention to abolish the labor-camp system  known in Chinese as laojiao  news that came in the report of the Third Plenum, the leadership meeting that wrapped up on Nov. 12.

title: On the Roach to Riches
description: The industry of raising cockroaches has a bright future, said Wang Fuming, a farmer in Shandong Province.

title: Glossy Mens Magazines Piggyback on Change
description: HONG KONG  Fashion spreads shot on location in Europe, news on the latest luxury accessories, articles on personal development and skin care. If you think this sounds like the contents of a womens magazine, then you havent read Elle Men Hong Kong, featuring the Asian pretty boy actor Aarif Rahman on the November cover.

title: Britain Investigates Reports of Citizens Deaths in Syria
description: LONDON  Amid growing evidence that dozens of Americans have traveled or sought to travel to Syria to join rebel forces, the British Foreign Office said on Thursday that it was investigating reports that several Britons had died there while fighting on the side of Islamic militants opposed to President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 21, 2013
description: Use context clues and your knowledge of word parts to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

title: 6 Qs About the News | 24,000-Year-Old Body May Reveal New Clues About Native Americans Ancestry
description: In 24,000-Year-Old Body Shows Kinship to Europeans and American Indians, Nicholas Wade writes about a study published this week that may reveal new clues about Native Americans ancestry.

title: Credit Suisse to Wall Off Swiss Banking Business
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank Credit Suisse said Thursday that it planned to separate its retail and private banking business in its home market from its riskier investment banking and trading operations in Britain and in the United States.

title: J.F.K. Through the Pages of The Times
description: After the twin towers fell on Sept. 11, 2001, Todd Purdum, then one of the senior political reporters in the Washington bureau of The Times, began reciting, America wept tonight, not alone for its dead young president, but for itself. The words belonged not to him but to James Reston, who wrote them on deadline late in the day on Nov. 22, 1963. Reston, known as Scotty, had assembled some of the best talent ever known to journalism in The Timess Washington bureau: Tom Wicker, Anthony Lewis, Max Frankel, Russell Baker and others, all of whom had covered the presidency of John F. Kennedy, when Washington was the epicenter of everything.

title: Preview: 'Out of the Furnace'
description: Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson and Willem Dafoe in a clip from the film.

title: Work, Women and Caregiving
description: Trying to hold onto a job while caring for a family member is a tough juggling act. Caregivers sometimes have to arrive late or leave early, cut back to part-time work, and decline travel or promotions.

title: What Are Your Thanksgiving Traditions?
description: Turkey, stuffing, gravy and cranberry sauce: These are the quintessential Thanksgiving foods that grace the holiday dinner table. Still, each family has its own history and brings its own customs to the holiday season.

title: Casey Affleck Should Be More Famous
description: Before Casey Affleck started filming Out of the Furnace last year, he felt, professionally speaking, as if hed lost his way. Five years earlier, in 2007, he had two breakout roles: Gone Baby Gone, directed by his older brother Ben, and The Assassination of Jesse James By the Coward Robert Ford, in which he played the coward, Robert Ford, and for which he received an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor. In the years following, though, he had starred in only two live-action films (and provided a voice for the cartoon ParaNorman). His most recent and notorious creative project was in 2010, when he poured his heart, brain and wallet into Im Still Here, a passion project he made with his brother-in-law and close friend, Joaquin Phoenix. The hoax-documentary purported to chronicle Phoenixs real-life personal implosion, as he supposedly made the switch from acting to a rap career. The film not only met with many terrible reviews but actually seemed to enrage the media. Dana Stevens of Slate had a not untypical critical reaction: The worst thing about Im Still Here is the fact that it exists.

title: Philippine Citys Residents Describe Rifling of Stores
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  By the time Bjorn Racaza joined the crowds rummaging through Robinsons Department Store, he thought he was too late. It was around 6 p.m. on Nov. 10, two days after Typhoon Haiyan destroyed much of this city of 235,000, and the plundering of its largest department store  some of it for necessities, some of it not  was in full fury.

title: France May Slip Back Into Recession
description: FRANKFURT  Hopes that the euro zone could be emerging from years of torpor suffered another setback on Thursday when an indicator of economic activity in the region slipped unexpectedly and suggested that France could be sliding back into recession.

title: New York Today: Hiring Time at City Hall
description: Updated 11:38 a.m.

description: John Kerrys diplomacy; Michael Skakel back in court; and a congressmans first trip to Washington.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: A Time for Courage
description: HAMBURG, Germany  It being the 100th anniversary of Willy Brandts birth, the image has been much present in Germany: the former chancellor on his knees in the Warsaw ghetto in the silent act that defined German shame for the Holocaust. As Brandt later said, Carrying the burden of the millions who were murdered, I did what people do when words fail them.

title: Chinas Highest Court Seeks to Curtail Abuses of Justice
description: HONG KONG  Chinas highest court issued demands on Thursday that judges bar confessions obtained through torture and avoid applying the death penalty when the evidence is shaky. The directive was unlikely on its own to curb such abuses, but reflected a growing official recognition of the need to stop gross injustices, experts said.

title: India Prepares Evacuations of 100,000 Before Cyclone Helen Hits
description: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh  The National Disaster Management Authority was preparing on Thursday to evacuate nearly 100,000 people in four districts of coastal Andhra Pradesh as Cyclone Helen is expected to make landfall late Friday.

title: Kennedy's Legacy of Inspiration
description: WASHINGTON  Fifty years after John F. Kennedys assassination, he remains an object of almost universal admiration. And yet, particularly this year, his legacy has aroused the ire of debunkers who complain that Kennedy is unworthy of all this adulation.

title: Negotiating Employee Contracts in China
description: Regardless of what business you are in or where you operate, it is great employees that make a great company. While hiring great employees can be a challenge anywhere, the process of recruiting, retaining and terminating employees is especially tricky in China.

title: Poetry Pairing | The New-England Boys Song about Thanksgiving Day
description: With the Thanksgiving holiday just around the corner, this Poetry Pairing features Lydia Maria Childs classic poem The New-England Boys Song about Thanksgiving Day and the article When Phones Come Out Long Before the Turkey by Kim Severson.

title: Daily Report: Pressure Mounts on Wireless Providers Over U.S. Surveillance Efforts
description: Shareholders are putting AT&T and Verizon Wireless on notice: Tell the public more about the companies role in government surveillance efforts or risk a ding to the bottom line, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: Text to Text | Romeo and Juliet and Montague and Capulet as Shiite and Sunni
description: Orlando Bloom performs a scene from the new Broadway production of Shakespeares Romeo and Juliet.

title: Signs of Aging, Even in the Embryo
description: In 1961, two biologists named Leonard Hayflick and Paul Moorehead discovered that old age is built into our cells. At the time, many scientists believed that if healthy human cells were put in a flask with a steady supply of nutrients, they would multiply forever. But when Dr. Hayflick and Dr. Moorehead reared fetal human cells, thats not what they found. Time and again, their cells would divide about 50 times and then simply stop.

title: At Least 32 Killed as Truck Explodes at Iraqi Market
description: BAGHDAD  Explosives hidden under fruit and vegetables aboard a delivery truck detonated in a crowded market selling fresh produce north of Baghdad on Thursday, killing 32 people and wounding dozens a day after a wave of car bombings convulsed the capital, according to medical and police officials.

title: Activist Pushing for Change at Darden Hires Outside Advisers
description: The activist hedge fund pushing for change at Darden Restaurants signaled on Thursday that it was ramping up its pressure.

title: Morning Agenda: Dueling Portraits of SAC Trader
description: DUELING PORTRAITS OF SAC TRADER |According to his lawyer, Michael S. Steinberg is successful, steady, serious. According to federal prosecutors, Mr. Steinberg, the most senior employee at SAC Capital Advisors to be charged with insider trading, tapped into a corrupt insider trading conspiracy to make big money for himself. He also, prosecutors claim, pushed a lower-level employee at SAC to provide edgy and illegal information about technology companies, Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

title: Hard Hearts, Soft Heads
description: Many years ago my colleague Alan Blinder wrote a very good book with, it seemed to me, a slightly unfortunate title. It was way too easy to slip from Hard heads, soft hearts to the reverse.

title: Karzai Says Hell Wait to Sign Security Pact With U.S. Until Next Year
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai stood before thousands of Afghan leaders on Thursday in a watershed moment for his tumultuous rule. Having just come to an agreement with American leaders on a security deal that would commit the two countries to a lasting military alliance, and which would surely define his legacy, he convened the assembly that would decide the deals fate.

title: Real Entitlement Reform
description: Remember all the pundits who stroked their chins, pretended to deliberate, then  completely predictably  came out against health care reform because, they said, it wouldnt control health care costs? Remember all the demands that Obama do something real, like raising the Medicare age (which turns out not to make any significant difference to the deficit)?

title: Did 90 Companies Cause the Climate Crisis of the 21st Century?
description: The Guardian has published a much-discussed story about a new climate study. Heres the headline and subheading:

description: Dear Diary:

title: How Can You Make a Student Care Enough to Work Harder?
description: Its time to address the question Ive been avoiding, the most challenging and most frequent question teachers are asked. I have received emails containing this question in its various iterations at least three or four times a week since I started writing this column, and according to my research, its also the most frequently asked question in a teachers day-to-day life.

title: Jess Lee of Polyvore, on the Value of Simplicity
description: This interview with Jess Lee, chief executive of Polyvore, a fashion website, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

description: SHANGHAI  News that the Chinese government would relax the one-child policy  one of its most sweeping, intrusive and defining  has been widely welcome.

title: Readers React to Unemployments Revolving Door
description: When you lose your job, suddenly nothing feels secure. That was one of the most common themes among more than 700 comments on Annie Lowreys article Caught in a Revolving Door of Unemployment last weekend. Jenner Barrington-Ward, the subject of the article, found herself homeless after decades of employment. Two readers shared their own stories of homelessness.

title: Your Favorite Shakespeare Performances
description: The many reader responses to a tantalizingly tough question  which are the greatest Shakespeare performances youve seen?  left me with a mild case of theatergoers envy, which is unusual for a critic who gets to see a lot of plays.

title: A Divided, Dangerous Camelot
description: The anniversary reverie surrounding President John F. Kennedys death has obscured the anarchic disorder that was present in America.

title: Patricia Cornwell: By the Book
description: The author of the Scarpetta novels, most recently Dust, plans to write her memoirs, but not anytime soon: I will want my story told with glaring, unflinching honesty.

title: New York Bans Under-21 Tobacco Sales
description: New York City is making sales of tobacco products to people under age 21 illegal as part of an effort to curb smoking among teenagers.

title: Facing Russian Threat, Ukraine Halts Plans for Deals with E.U.
description: MOSCOW  Under threat of crippling trade sanctions by Russia, Ukraine announced Thursday that it had suspended its plans to sign far-reaching political and trade agreements with the European Union and said it would instead pursue new partnerships with a competing trade bloc of former Soviet states.

description: The last thing Republicans want right now is to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

title: Video: New Yorkers Weigh In on the Cigarette Age Limit
description: Shortly after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came to office, he passed what he considers one of his signature achievements, the banning of smoking in restaurants and bars in New York City. Now, on the eve of the end of the Bloomberg era, the mayor has signed a law banning the sale of tobacco products to anyone under 21 within the five boroughs.

title: Obamacare and the Medical Cartel
description: Matt Yglesias has kicked up a mini-commotion with a piece hailing any potential Obamacare-driven cuts to physician income as basically exactly the medicine our overpriced medical system needs. Heres his argument:

title: Yellens Fed Leadership Is an Almost-Done Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserves campaign to encourage economic growth was bolstered on Thursday as Janet L. Yellen moved to the verge of confirmation as the next head of the Fed, and a change in Senate procedures made it easier for the White House to fill three other vacancies on the Feds board.

title: Vote Fraud Is Claimed by Maoists in Nepal
description: NEW DELHI  In the face of an apparent electoral drubbing, the leader of Nepals largest Maoist party demanded a halt to the nations vote counting on Thursday because of what he called widespread vote fraud.

title: Why Bungee Jump When Wine Awaits?
description: There is something incongruous about sipping a well-structured, deeply aromatic pinot noir at a beautiful winery while watching people fling themselves off a bridge, even if they are attached by a bungee cord. But in the Central Otago region on New Zealands South Island, adrenaline-fueled adventure sports and leisurely visits to photogenic vineyards are equally popular options.

title: Scenes From a Charleston Weekend
description: Hit a rooftop bar, go shopping and take in river views during a trip around this Southern city.

title: Newsmagazines Handling of Sex Harassment Complaint Draws Criticism
description: NEW DELHI  The newsmagazine Tehelka has made a name for itself through its aggressive investigative journalism, going after corrupt politicians and other lawbreakers. On Thursday, however, the publication was the one on the defensive after the editor in chief stepped down temporarily over a sexual harassment complaint by a staffer.

title: Image of the Day: November 21
In Landmark Vote, Senate Limits Use of the Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate approved the most fundamental alteration of its rules in more than a generation on Thursday, ending the minority partys ability to filibuster most presidential nominees in response to the partisan gridlock that has plagued Congress for much of the Obama administration.

title: As a Specialty Care Hospital Prepares to Close, Patients Wonder Whats Next
description: Frantz Lys enjoys sitting by the water gazing across the East River toward the Manhattan skyline. For the past 21 years, Mr. Lys has been a patient at Coler-Goldwater Memorial Hospital, a specialty care hospital and nursing facility on Roosevelt Island that offers long-term rehabilitation.

title: Turkey, Its Allies Struggling, Tempers Ambitions to Lead Region
description: ANKARA, Turkey  As Egypts Islamist demonstrators faced an imminent confrontation with security forces in Cairo last summer, the advice they received from Turkish officials was adamant: Stand your ground.

title: 92nd Street Y Presents an Online Archive of Recordings
description: If you have attended concerts, poetry readings and public interviews at the 92nd Street Y and noticed microphones suspended over the stage that were clearly for archival recording rather than amplification, you may have caught yourself daydreaming about the treasures the Ys archives must hold.

title: From Game to Reality: The Mercedes-Benz AMG Vision GT Concept
description: Mercedes-Benz designers came up with the AMG Vision Gran Turismo Concept for a starring role in the PlayStation 3 racing game, Gran Turismo 6. But like Pinocchio, the folkloric wooden toy that came to life, the Vision Concept, or something like it, may sooner rather than later become a real-life model in the Mercedes lineup.

description: 1888: Another Murder Feared

title: Is Monty Python Still Funny? Troupe Members Want to Know
description: LONDON  There might not be any silly walks  John Cleese said his artificial knee and hip would not allow it  but Monty Python, the British comedy troupe, is planning to perform many of its greatest hits when it reunites live on stage for its first large-scale public event in more than 30 years.

title: Restricting Content on Netflix, and Leaving a Flickr Group
description: Q. How can I block my children from watching age-inappropriate movies on my Netflix account on the Wii game console?

title: Deutsche Telekom to Sell Stake in Scout 24, an Online Ad Company
description: LONDON  Deutsche Telekom said on Thursday that it would sell a 70 percent stake in the online classified advertising company Scout24 to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman of San Francisco for 1.5 billion euros, or about $2 billion, in cash.

title: After 11 Years in Prison, Skakel Goes Free on Bail
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  After spending more than a decade behind bars for the murder of a teenage girl in Greenwich, Conn., Michael C. Skakel, a cousin of the Kennedys, was ordered free from prison on Thursday to await a possible retrial.

title: Iran Talks Substantial, but Yield No Accord
description: GENEVA  The foreign policy chief of the European Union spent much of Thursday in detailed negotiations with Iranian officials over an agreement to temporarily freeze Tehrans nuclear program.

title: The Village That Benjamin Britten Never Left
description: ALDEBURGH, England  The extreme east coast of England is a place of flat, bleakly poetic marshland, pebble beaches and small fishing towns locked in an ambivalent relationship with an encroaching sea thats been their income and their enemy.

title: Charges Dropped in Cyberbullying Death, but Sheriff Isnt Backing Down
description: MIAMI  In both word and deed, Sheriff Grady Judd of Polk County has long approached crime fighting as a moral quest, a clear-cut fight between good and evil, with no-nonsense punishments for offenders.

title: With New Streaming Deal, Amazon Keeps Pressure on Netflix
description: LOS ANGELES  The Web streaming battles continue: Amazon, a competitor to Netflix, announced an exclusive deal Thursday morning to add releases from one of Hollywoods most attention-grabbing independent film companies to its Prime service.

description: In the Video

title: Times Minute: Nov. 21 at Noon
description: A drone strike in a new area of Pakistan; 'Catching Fire' hits theaters; and a viral ad encourages engineering.

title: Market Report
description: The shade is a staple of mens cold-weather wardrobes  especially when it comes in flannel  but its increasingly well suited for women as well.

title: Remembering the Gettysburg Address
description: John Hay woke with a severe hangover on the morning of Nov. 19, 1863. As one of Abraham Lincolns closest White House aides, Hay had spent the previous evening drinking copiously with the disparate crew of journalists and politicians who converged on the small town of Gettysburg, Penn., for the dedication of a new national cemetery later that day. A bystander remembered seeing the presidential party arrive after a long train ride from Washington, a straggled, hungry set. Lincoln, with that weary smile  Seward, with an essentially bad hat; John Hay, in attendance upon the president, and much to be troubled by the correspondents, handsome as a peach, the countenance of extreme youth.

title: Merely Players? Not These Actors
description: Readers of The New York Times with long memories  many of them frequent visitors to London  were more than happy to share the greatest Shakespearean performance they had ever seen or heard. But they also found acting to savor on screens, large and very small. Heres an edited sampling of their responses. For more, go to nytimes.com/theater.

title: A Companys Double, Double Toiling
description: Theater economics being what they are, actors have grown accustomed to doubling and even tripling up on roles when performing in large-cast plays.

title: The Essential (Other) Affleck
description: Heres what you most likely know about Casey Affleck: He is Ben Afflecks younger brother. He was in Oceans Eleven. (And Twelve. And Thirteen.) He earned an Oscar nomination in 2008 for Best Supporting Actor for a film you probably not only didnt see but also cant remember the entire title of. (The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford.)

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Burberry Gloves
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: An Optimistic View of the United States
description: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

title: Blackstones Version of Peak Oil
description: A $6 billion oil deal signals yet another apex for the Blackstone Group.

title: Nov. 22: Memories of That Awful Day
Striking Where Myth Meets Moment
description: When The Hunger Games: Catching Fire opens, its lethally resourceful teenage heroine, Katniss Everdeen, is crouching in a forest, surveying a terrain as pristine as the one once scouted by American Indians. However pastoral, this isnt the forest primeval but the very edge of free land outside the impoverished zone in which Katniss (Jennifer Lawrence) and her relatives, friends and the other starved souls labor for Panem, the authoritarian state built on the ruins of North America after a catastrophic war. Its here that she hunts game to feed her family and where this startlingly new pioneer  with her bow and arrows, leather jacket and boots, primitive individualism and totally awesome strength of character  was forged.

title: Greek Budget Forecasts Growth, but Skeptics Abound
description: ATHENS  Greece on Thursday outlined a 2014 budget that predicts a return to economic growth after six straight years of recession, putting the countrys prospects in an optimistic light.

title: Typhoon Revives Debate on U.S. Food Aid Methods
description: WASHINGTON  When Typhoon Haiyan slammed into the Philippines, the United States Agency for International Development swung into action: A ship filled with rice positioned in Sri Lanka was sent powering toward the devastated island nation as 55 tons of high-energy biscuits were airlifted from Miami. As much as $100 million more in food aid, the bulk of it from the United States, will still be needed in the coming months for the estimated 2.5 million people displaced by the storm.

title: New York City Opera to Auction Instruments and Other Items
description: One harpsichord, used, a veteran of many a recitative. A five-octave celesta. A whole percussion-section worth of instruments, including drums, a gong and even a cowbell.

title: Pacers and George Pass Knicks on Their Way Up
description: The crowd at Wednesdays game between the Knicks and the Pacers at Madison Square Garden appeared to sense how much had changed since the teams met in the playoffs in May. Then, the Knicks were the higher seed, second in the East, and Carmelo Anthony was widely considered the best player in the series. Most of the players from that series remain on their teams, but six months after the Pacers bruised and bullied the Knicks on the way to a six-game series victory, the dynamic between the teams has irreversibly changed.

title: A Drive Around Los Angeles in the BMW i3
description: Depending on who you are, looking at the BMW i3 electric car will make you either love it or hate it. Its peculiar proportions and appearance, as with other odd-shape cars, seem to be polarizing. Something about it recalls the basic look of a Honda Element, but it is uniquely BMW and its fuel economy is much more impressive.

title: Treasury Seeks an Exit From G.M. by Year End
description: The Treasury Department said on Thursday that it would sell its remaining shares in General Motors by years end, allowing the government to finally sever ties to the bailed-out automaker a few months sooner than expected.

title: Young Immigrants Write Software to Highlight Lack of Legal Status
description: Can 20 young programmers, all of them brought to the United States illegally as children, hack an immigration overhaul out of its deep freeze in Congress?

title: Listening to the Beatles White Album 100 Times, All at Once
description: When the conceptual artist Rutherford Chang presented his idiosyncratic art show We Buy White Albums at the Recess Gallery in SoHo in January, he told a visitor that the exhibition was only part of the project. The exhibition seemed plenty, really: Mr. Chang transformed the gallery into a mock record shop in which the only discs on display were copies of The Beatles  the 1968 double-disc set popularly known as the White Album because of its stark cover.

title: Get Excited! The Movies Issue Is Coming!
description: First came 14 actors acting. Then there were villains, followed by heroines. This year, they speak! Watch the trailer below for the 2014 Movies Issue, coming Monday to a web site near you.

title: Russian Fertilizer War Appears to Wind Down
description: MOSCOW  What was good news on Thursday for the chief executive of a Russian fertilizer company may be bad news for farmers around the world.

title: An Icy Observatory Detects Neutrinos From Far, Far Away
description: At the bottom of the world, an observatory embedded in ice and designed to catch bountiful but elusive subatomic particles could give astronomers a brand-new look at the universe.

title: The Gun Report: November 21, 2013
description: The N.R.A. has suedSan Francisco, Calif., claiming the city is violating citizens constitutional right to possess arms with a new ordinance that bans the possession of high-capacity gun magazines. The suit, brought on behalf of the San Francisco Veteran Police Officers Association and four individual gun owners, is in response to a measure expanding an existing ban on sales of large-capacity gun magazines. Starting Dec. 8, it gives owners of those magazines 90 days to turn them over to police.

title: Shostakovich, the Early Years
description: The maestro Vladimir Jurowski, 41, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, has been winning praise for his performance of Strausss Die Frau Ohne Schatten at the Met. But before the run ends (on Tuesday at 7:30 p.m.), Mr. Jurowski will conduct the Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center.

title: Reversals of Fortune
description: With his insinuating heavy-lidded gaze and a contemptuous smirk, Dirk Bogarde has never been more sinister than in his role of Hugo Barrett, the manservant who takes over the life of Tony (James Fox), a young aristocrat, in the 1963 movie The Servant. The first of three collaborations between the director Joseph Losey and Harold Pinter, who adapted the screenplay from a novelette by Robin Maugham, The Servant is a high point of the Film Society of Lincoln Centers 10-film series Comedies of Menace and Quiet Desperation, which focuses on movies written or adapted by Pinter.

title: Alabama Pardons 3 Scottsboro Boys After 80 Years
description: ATLANTA  More than 80 years after they were falsely accused and wrongly convicted in the rapes of a pair of white women in north Alabama, three black men received posthumous pardons on Thursday, essentially absolving the last of the Scottsboro Boys of criminal misconduct and closing one of the most notorious chapters of the Souths racial history.

title: Remembering a Tragedy
description: The Museum of Modern Arts atrium has been home to any number of weird, wild and wacky goings-on. There was the time the performance artist Marina Abramovic sat there for 700 hours, and another when someone played a baby-grand piano from inside a hole that had been cut into it. There was also an installation of hazelnut pollen, and even a giant garage sale.

title: Sustaining Martha Graham
description: Performa 13, the monthlong festival of cross-disciplinary performance, officially wraps up this weekend. But at least one of its programs keeps on going: Surreal Graham, presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company, which sticks around for an added performance on Monday.

title: Hands-On Journey in Smithsonian
description: Perhaps the Smithsonian Institution has been feeling underappreciated lately. Sure, millions of people visit its museums each year, but they are seeing only a fraction of the material in its collections, and walking past a musty uniform or ancient airplane sometimes doesnt convey the living history behind it. Last month, the Smithsonian Channel enlisted celebrities to help tell the deeper stories behind some pieces from its collection in the engaging three-part Civil War 360, and now ordinary museum visitors assume that role in Seriously Amazing Objects, which begins on Monday at 8 p.m. on the channel.

title: Turning Corners, Guitar in Hand
description: Trixie Whitley could easily have done straightforward roots-rock on Fourth Corner (Strong Blood), the debut album she released in January. She has the pedigree, as the daughter of the bluesman Chris Whitley, and she has the voice, which holds smoke and sorrow, exhortation and ache. But shes not one for established formats. Her mother is Belgian, and Ms. Whitley spent years in Europe, in theater and dance troupes, before settling in New York in her teens. She was a member of Black Dub, led by the producer Daniel Lanois, and her own songs move between confession and conundrum, with shades of Fiona Apple and Alicia Keys. For Fourth Corner, she collaborated with the keyboardist-composer Thomas Bartlett on songs that were orchestrated with string sections and gusts of guitar reverb and distortion. Onstage, with her electric guitar, her music can be cathartic. (7:30 p.m. Saturday, Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com.)

title: The Filibusters Power to Block Nominees
description: Chart showing the proportion that have been used on high-level nominations and table of the nominees currently awaiting confirmation.

title: Herbert Mitgang, Wide-Ranging Author and Journalist, Dies at 93
description: Herbert Mitgang, an author and journalist whose wide-ranging work included Abraham Lincoln biographies and an expos of the F.B.I.s bulging files on Americas most renowned writers  John Steinbecks dossier was 800 pages long  died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Would You Buy the Nest Protect? Readers Respond
description: Updated | Added more reader comments

title: Partisan Fever in Senate Likely to Rise
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will get a short-term lift for his nominees, judicial and otherwise, but over the immediate horizon, the strong-arm move by Senate Democrats on Thursday to limit filibusters could usher in an era of rank partisan warfare beyond even what Americans have seen in the past five years.

title: Afghan Gathering Steeped in Tradition, and Consent
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The loya jirga is a venerable Afghan institution in which representatives of Afghan tribes are summoned, in the absence of formal government, to discuss issues of concern. Afghan rulers used them to ratify their rule whenever they seized power or expanded territory, because if there is one defining characteristic of a loya jirga, it is that it rarely says no.

title: Subway in London Plans to Run 24 Hours
description: LONDON  The London Underground is facing one of the most drastic overhauls in its 150-year history. Starting in 2015, its trains will start running throughout the night, and most of its ticket offices will be replaced by upgraded machines or turnstiles that accept contactless bank cards as part of a plan meant to bring the worlds oldest subway system into the 21st century.

title: Spending More and Getting Less for Health Care
description: The patient, lean and in his 60s, was in the hospital for the second time in a month with blood sugar levels that were out of control and he was not happy. Despite the nurses earnest attempts to cheer him up, he scowled and insisted that all he needed was for us to fix it so he could go back home.

title: A Coed Vision of Professional Basketball
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  When Heather LaCasse heard of a proposed coed professional basketball league, she passed the information to her boyfriend, Jean Marcellus, and suggested he try out. As an inducement, she promised to keep him company on the drive from the Bronx to New Jersey.

title: At Toronto Aquarium, Jellyfish Get a Tank of Their Own
description: Ripleys Aquarium of Canada, now the largest indoor aquarium in the country, opened last month with more than 1.5 million gallons of salt- and freshwater habitats housing 16,000 marine animals spanning more than 450 species of fish, invertebrates and one reptile, the green sea turtle.

title: France Investigating Ikea on Spying Allegations
description: PARIS  Prosecutors have placed three senior Ikea executives in France under investigation amid allegations that they authorized illegal spying on employees and customers.

title: Why Harry Reid Had to Use the Nuclear Option
description: The Senate voted 52-48 on Thursday to eliminate use of the filibuster on executive and most judicial nominees (not including the Supreme Court).

title: Movie Review: The Hunger Games
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.

title: A Trading Tactic Is Foiled, and Banks Cry Foul
description: What country are you in? Where is your business located? In what country did your trade take place?

title: Bonfire of My Vanity
description: Hello, 56!

title: Obama Supports Filibuster Legislation
description: The president makes a statement in favor of the change in filibuster rules.

title: The State of Israel
description: Too much of the discourse on Israel is a doubting discourse. I do not mean that it is too critical: Sometimes it is, sometimes it isnt. I mean that the state is too often judged for its viability or its validity, as if some fundamental acceptance of its reality is pending upon the resolution of its many problems with itself and with others. About the severity of those problems there is no question, and some of them broach primary issues of politics and morality; but Israels problems are too often combined and promoted into a Problem, which has the effect of emptying the Jewish state of its actuality and consigning it to a historical provisionality, a permanent condition of controversy, from which it can be released only by furnishing various justifications and explanations.

title: Democracy Returns to the Senate
description: For five years, Senate Republicans have refused to allow confirmation votes on dozens of perfectly qualified candidates nominated by President Obama for government positions. They tried to nullify entire federal agencies by denying them leaders. They abused Senate rules past the point of tolerance or responsibility. And so they were left enraged and threatening revenge on Thursday when a majority did the only logical thing and stripped away their power to block the presidents nominees.

title: Jury Tells Samsung to Pay Apple $290 Million
description: SAN JOSE  A jury on Thursday said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple $290 million more in damages for violating patents, putting an end to one chapter in the long-running patent struggle between the two tech companies.

title: More Works From German Art Trove Are Shown
description: BERLIN  German authorities on Thursday released images of dozens of graphics by Edvard Munch, Max Liebermann and Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec that were among a trove of art stashed for decades in a Munich apartment, bringing to 79 the number of works now identified to the public.

title: Theres a Flag on the Commercial
description: Its not just the impetuous, bone-crunching hulks on the playing field who commit reckless penalties. The networks and advertisers are often delinquent, too. Heres a sampling of the most common infractions when it comes to N.F.L. ads:

title: Sacked by the Media Blitz
description: The most chilling words heard on any National Football League telecast are: Well return right after these messages.

title: Mario Testino Returns to His Roots
description: The famed fashion photographer Mario Testino has captured the most popular cultural icons, like the British royal family and Lady Gaga, and shot ad campaigns for the biggest names in fashion, like Gucci and Valentino. But for the photographic exhibition Alta Moda (high fashion in Spanish), on view through March 29 at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in New York, Testino turned his lens away from haute couture and toward a less recognized facet of fashion history.

title: He Loves New York, but Cant Drink There
description: For an old soul like Jake Bugg, recording at Sun Studio in Memphis was an ideal fit. Its got the old asbestos walls and pictures of Johnny Cash up, Mr. Bugg, the 19-year-old British singer-songwriter, said excitedly of the space that helped give birth to rock n roll in the 1950s. Its just crazy to think that I was playing my guitar and singing a song in the same spot that all those guys would have been as well, all those years ago. I felt very inspired.

title: American, Now Held, Part of Rising Number Visiting North Korea
description: BEIJING  Merrill Newman is 85 and suffers from a heart ailment, but that did not deter him from fulfilling his wish to return to North Korea, where he fought as a young man, his family and friends say.

title: An Island Outpost for Chinas Maritime Claims
description: A 16-hour boat ride from the Chinese province of Hainan and dependent on supplies shipped in from outside, Yongxing Island, in the South China Sea, may seem an improbable location for any business.

title: A Stillbirths Living Silver Linings
description: This morning, I sent four children off to school trying to wrap their heads around the idea that without a tragedy, their happy lives would be much different  maybe not so happy, or maybe they wouldnt exist at all.

title: Voicing Vietnam
description: Often in a true war story there is not even a point, or else the point doesnt hit you until 20 years later, in your sleep, and you wake up and shake your wife and start telling the story to her, except when you get to the end youve forgotten the point again.

title: Maine Hires Firm to Study Medicaid System, to Democrats Ire
description: Officials in Maine have hired a consulting firm to study the states Medicaid system, to include evaluating the cost of expanding the program under President Obamas Affordable Care Act, a move Gov. Paul R. LePage has in the past rejected.

title: Ellarys Greens
description: Inside the West Village restaurant closing the divide between good for you and delicious.

title: Witnesses at Hearing Urge Congress to Enlist Antidoping Agency and Save Horse Racing
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Anti-Doping Agency is the last and best hope to return safety and integrity to the troubled sport of thoroughbred racing, members of the industry told Congress at a hearing Thursday.

title: Graphic Novels
description: BATTLING BOYWritten and illustrated by Paul Pope  First Second, cloth, $24.99; paper, $15.99. (Ages 8 to 16)

title: Letters: State of the Art
description: State of the Art

title: In Pursuit of Health and Happiness
description: Free detox shots! the waitress called out as she sashayed through the dining room, a tray of tiny glasses at her shoulder. The liquid in them was jungle green and wobbled. It tasted of kale and salvation, with celery and lemon for a bright-eyed, bushy-tailed finish. I downed it and waited for the world to change.

title: Tax Proposal for an Economy No Longer Rooted in Manufacturing
description: A tax proposal released on Thursday by the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus, addresses a topic that tends to make my students eyes glaze over: cost recovery.

title: Micron Shares Rise After Praise From Einhorn
description: Micron Technology can officially call itself a member of the David Einhorn club.

title: Puerto Ricans Molded by New York
description: November is Puerto Rican Heritage Month in New York, giving the city a chance to recognize the ways figures like the Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the Knicks star Carmelo Anthony, the cultural historian Arturo Alfonso Schomburg and the founders of the Nuyorican poetry movement have shaped and been shaped by New York. And the Miser, being the Miser, after all, is happy to note that a number of the programs tied to the celebration are free and open to the public.

title: David Webbs Jewelry on Sale and for Show
description: AN ORNATE LEGACY,

title: Valrie Blass
description: Parisian Laundry Projects

title: Obama Campaign Veterans Start New Advertising Venture
description: A few months after members of President Obamas 2012 advertising and data teams came together to start a new firm called AMG that would bring some of his campaigns technical savvy to corporate America, a rival faction of advertising and data strategists say they are starting a competing effort.

title: Refurnishing a 65-Room House, Piece by Piece
description: An upscale tag sale appears to be underway in the cavernous limestone rooms of Coe Hall mansion, run by the Planting Fields Foundation in Oyster Bay. But no prices are listed.

title: Collecting, Simply for the Joy of It
description: Collecting and investing have eclipsed many other aspects of art, particularly in recent weeks as auction prices soared to absurd levels. When one work sells for $142.4 million, as a Francis Bacon triptych did this month, it prompts questions not only about the cultural and monetary value of art, but also about the unequal distribution of wealth and how such wealth is acquired in the first place. This is why the collectors, and not just the works, in Many Things Placed Here and There: The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection at the Yale University Art Gallery are important within the greater history of contemporary art.

title: A Broken Copier, and Other Calamities
description: You. Are not. Special. So Stan, a 50-ish office drone, informs his young co-worker in a scene from middlemen at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch. You are not important. I know, your parents told you differently, but they were lying. If you were never born, if you had never existed at all, things would have turned out the same way, he says, acknowledging that the same holds true for him.

title: Ex-Journal Tech Writers Are Close to Deal With NBCUniversal
description: The technology writers Kara Swisher and Walter Mossberg, founders of the conference and media business All Things Digital, appear to have found a new home.

title: Katherine Bernhardt and Youssef Jdia: Holiday Services
description: The Hole

title: Liam Gillick / Louise Lawler
description: Casey Kaplan

title: Rosemarie Trockel
description: Gladstone

title: Barbara Probst
description: Murray Guy

title: A New Holiday Face
description: I have officially started to dread Thanksgiving. Every year, I drive several hours to my childhood home to celebrate the holiday with my immediate family: my parents, an older brother and a younger sister. Within 30 seconds of being in the same room, we all assume our old roles. My brother was the brain, my sister was the jock and I was the troublemaker  but Im not anymore. Do you have any ideas for short-circuiting those same old dynamics this year? Its really demoralizing for me.

title: Listen Up | A Brooklyn Disco Orchestra Unleashes Its Inner Barbarian
description: Dance music played with live instruments has become really popular  its not just underground anymore, says Eugene Cho, the keyboardist of the Brooklyn-based band Escort. Indeed, thanks to the surprise Top 40 success of Daft Punks Get Lucky, club grooves evoking the time before computer-made beats have reached mass consciousness anew. Escort, however, has been flying that flag for over half a decade. Founded by Cho and the guitarist Dan Balis, the band hails itself as Brooklyns finest disco orchestra  mixing mirror-ball rhythms and funky cowbell syncopation with club-ready choruses, as heard on the single Barbarians, from their forthcoming sophomore album, out next year. The songs lush textures call to mind Studio 54 classics mixed with the legendary producer Trevor Horns work in the mid-1980s with Frankie Goes to Hollywood. Its not reasonable to expect everyone who listens to us to know the last 30 years of dance-music history, Cho says. We want what we do to translate broadly.

title: National Gallery Acquires a van Honthorst Masterwork
description: A MERRY DUTCH CONCERT, CAPTURED BY A MASTER

title: Photographers Protest White House Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON  A mutiny has erupted among photographers who cover President Obama over what they say is the White Houses increasing practice of excluding them from events involving the president and then releasing its own photos or video.

title: Nasty Nuns Cant Shake a Faith
description: In Philomena, Judi Denchs portrayal of a stubborn, kindhearted Irish Catholic trying to discover what became of the toddler she was forced to give up as a teenager is so quietly moving that it feels lit from within. A major theme of this film from Stephen Frears is forgiveness. Ms. Denchs Philomena Lee glows with the radiance of someone serene in her faith despite inhumane treatment by the church. That she makes you believe her character has the capacity to forgive provides the movie with a solid moral center.

title: Rescued London Women Say They Were Held 30 Years
description: LONDON  The London police announced Thursday that three women had been rescued from a city home where they claim to have been held against their will for about 30 years, and that a married couple who lived there had been arrested.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: My Work Is Very Difficult to Understand
description: A look at the work of the German artist Isa Genzken, the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: No, It Isnt Supposed to Be Easy
description: The German artist Isa Genzken once conducted a minute-long video interview with a fellow artist and titled it, Why I Dont Do Interviews.

title: Carlins Daughter Writing Memoir
description: Kelly Carlin, the only child of the comedian George Carlin, will write a memoir of her relationship with her father, her publisher said Thursday. St. Martins Press, part of Macmillan, acquired A Carlin Home Companion from Ms. Carlin, left, who said that the book developed from her one-woman show by the same name. The man you knew as George Carlin, I called Dad, Ms. Carlin said in a statement. I want to offer readers a rare glimpse of the George Carlin theyve never seen or heard about before. The book is expected to be released in fall 2015.

title: Assembling Brash Wholes From Scraps
description: The Museum of Modern Arts grand, sometimes grating 40-year survey of the German sculptor Isa Genzken is a disturbance in the force of the New York art world. It counters the seasons trend of big retrospectives devoted to male artists and increases from a paltry four to a still paltry five the number of full-dress sixth-floor retrospectives the Modern has bestowed upon women since taking back its expanded building nine years ago.

title: Records Are Dying? Not Here
description: BUZZSAWS were buzzing, hammers were hammering, and a sea of empty display racks awaited their wares one morning this week in a cavernous storefront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It was a typical scene of retail construction in every way except for what was coming: a record store.

title: Rough Trade NYC
description: A new branch of a London record store is scheduled to open Monday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: The largest wholesale cut in SNAP since 1964, when Congress passed the first Food Stamp Act, is driving one in every seven Americans to seek out food pantries. Meanwhile, the median wage is plummeting, and more than 50 Walmart workers and supporters were arrested in downtown Los Angeles last week as they sat in the street protesting the retailers poverty wages.

title: A Silent Partner to Share the Path of Love
description: I have the chance to go to Japan for a year, I told my boyfriend, Randy.

title: A Portrait Painted in Heavy Strokes
description: Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon were rivals as well as friends. That scratching sound you hear is Freud clawing at his coffin at the news last week that Bacons 1969 portrait of him, a triptych titled Three Studies of Lucian Freud, went for $142.4 million, making it the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction.

title: With Pitchfork Review, a Music Site Plants a Flag in Print
description: After 17 years as the definitive online publication about alternative music, Pitchfork is joining the tweedy world of print with a new quarterly journal.

title: With Dad in Jail, a Family Carries on
description: Michael Winterbottoms elusive family drama Everyday was filmed in two-week periods around Christmas over five successive years in a rural Scottish village. Its central character, Karen (Shirley Henderson), is a lean, intense working-class woman whose husband, Ian (John Simm), is serving time for an unspecified drug-related crime.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, India, Pakistan and Nepal.

title: The Ultimate Pinup Queen, With a Peek at the Sad Side
description: In the more than 50 years since the all-American pinup Bettie Page hung up her trusty riding crop, her life has morphed into unlikely legend and a surprisingly durable brand. Bettie mania has gone high with a Florida museum exhibition of images snapped by Bunny Yeager, and its also gone predictably low, with an endless parade of Bettie-related paraphernalia from T-shirts to handbags, lunchboxes, poker chips, beauty products, light-switch plates and a line of shoes that the licensee describes as catering to the Rockabilly, Pin-Up and Burlesque genres.

title: Delinquency Rates on the Decline
description: As the economy improves, the number of borrowers who are seriously behind on their mortgage payments continues to decline. The enhanced outlook is such that even those in delinquency are feeling more optimistic about their circumstances and homeownership in general.

title: As SAC Shrinks, Its Operations Chief Departs
description: In 2007, before the financial crisis and before federal authorities began listening to traders phone calls, the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was in aggressive expansion mode. And a charismatic young executive named Sol Kumin played an important role in its rise.

title: When How It Looks Matters More Than What It Says
description: As you read this, youre probably not paying much attention to what the letters look like. More likely, youre focusing on the words and sentences that the letters spell, and what they are saying. Some artists, however, have made it their business to direct attention to what letters, words, sentences, texts and books look like more or less apart from what they mean. Nine of these are in Drawing Time, Reading Time, a thought-provoking show at the Drawing Center.

title: Verdict in Apple-Samsung Damages Trial
description: A jury said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple nearly $290 million in damages for violating patents.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: How the Original 1 Percent Showed Off
description: The staggering sums spent on art at last weeks auctions were interpreted by dealers and critics alike as evidence of a new Gilded Age. At such a moment, it may be useful to take a hard look at the old one, the late-19th-century period defined by the aggressive buying sprees of a few newly minted industrialists.

title: Europeans Stray From the Vine
description: A recent article in Newsweek bemoaned that Italians, particularly younger Italians, are drinking less wine today than they did five years ago. Fifty years ago, they consumed about twice as much annually. All this, even though no country makes more wine than Italy (which exports a great deal of it, especially to the United States).

title: A Quiz and a Drink
description: Scenes from a pub quiz at Dempseys, an East Village bar.

title: An Abstractionism Shaped by Wounded Ideals
description: In recent years some of our big Chelsea galleries have given us what are basically museum shows. From Gagosian, a while back, came an invaluable retrospective of Piero Manzoni, followed by a survey of late Monet paintings that felt like an impossible dream. David Zwirner now enters the modern-old-masters lists with Ad Reinhardt, a trenchant centennial tribute to a classic American artist, and one of the best exhibitions in or out of a gallery this fall.

title: Challenging Questions on Tap
description: The Beast could not conquer Astoria, thanks in part to a too-hasty guess about a pornographic cat and bad advice about a Mets pitcher. He could not conquer the East Village, where trivia sharks were lying in wait. But he did emerge from Social Bar in the theater district as, for one night at least, king of the inconsequential and obscure.

title: Now From a Global Village, the Vienna Choir Boys
description: The Westchester County campus of Purchase College may not be known for its geological formations. But when the 24 members of the Vienna Boys Choir arrive on campus for their holiday show at the colleges Performing Arts Center on Dec. 7, they will find themselves searching for stones, which promise to play a memorable role in the show.

title: Weighing Costs for the Many Who Hold Sway
description: Be careful what you wish for. The closed hearings into the political activities of a conservative group in Austin are slowly coming into the open.

title: JetBlue Joins PreCheck Program
description: The Transportation Security Administration said Thursday that JetBlue Airways would join its roster of airlines participating in its PreCheck airport security program. JetBlue is the ninth airline to be included, joining Southwest, which announced its participation last week, Alaska, American (which now also includes US Airways), Delta, Hawaiian, United and Virgin America.

title: Star Types and Stereotypes
description: The CW series Nikita begins its fourth and final season on Friday  an abbreviated run to tie up story lines, as the reluctant assassin Nikita stands falsely accused of killing the president  and while theres still a chance, Id like to celebrate a small but significant milestone. For six more weeks, two of the strongest and most interesting female leads on television are being played by Asian-American actresses.

title: Showing That Theyre Glad to Be Live, and Alive
description: The tools of Play/Pause, a New York premiere by the choreographer Susan Marshall that is inspired by music videos, build over time. At first, the stage is bare except for a large, standing piece of plywood, on which Luke Miller places strips of gaffers tape. Ching-I Chang scrapes a microphone on its surface. Christopher Adams pulls on a silver-sequined sock  a nod to Michael Jacksons glove?  and, standing, lashes out an arm while lunging forward.

title: In Oil and Gas Country, Water Recycling Can Be an Extremely Hard Sell
description: MIDLAND  Standing on a sprawling ranch where drilling rigs, cranes and bobbing stripper wells form a makeshift skyline, Jimmy Davis is not thinking solely about sucking up oil. It is not the only precious liquid that is pumped from under the land that he manages.

title: Eclecticism Intact After a 17-Year Interlude
description: Mazzy Star was a throwback to a throwback when it performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night, touring behind its first album in 17 years. When the band emerged in 1990, its singer and lyricist, Hope Sandoval, and its guitarist and composer, David Roback, wrote songs that looked back to the 1960s, using selective memories of folk-rock and psychedelia to define its own sparse, pensive songs. Now  when newer bands from Beach House to the xx have also embraced the still-waters-run-deep aesthetic  Mazzy Star harks back to its earlier self.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Animating the Mind of Chomsky
description: An easygoing, sometimes tough-going meander through the world of ideas, the animated documentary Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy? finds the French director Michel Gondry playing wide-eyed student to none other than Noam Chomsky. Theyre a charmingly unpredictable, appealing match. Mr. Gondry, best known for films like Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and The Green Hornet, has occasionally dipped into documentary, with titles like the expansive Dave Chappelles Block Party (in which the comic hosts a rocking Brooklyn block party) and the considerably more hermetic The Thorn in the Heart (about Mr. Gondrys aunt and her son).

title: Still Restless, 50 Years On
description: The 50th anniversary of Doctor Who is being celebrated all week on BBC America, with episode marathons, documentaries and The Day of the Doctor, a stand-alone story uniting the 10th and 11th Doctors (David Tennant and Matt Smith) that is being broadcast around the world on Saturday.

title: High Court May Clarify Rule on Impairment and Death Penalty
description: The United States Supreme Courts ruling in a Florida death penalty case, in which an inmate argued that his intellectual disability made him exempt from execution, could help answer a decade-old question in Texas and other states about how to establish whether an inmate is too severely impaired to be subject to the death penalty.

title: Times Minute: Nov. 21 at 6 p.m.
description: Moves on the filibuster in Washington; Michael C. Skakel freed in Connecticut; and Monty Python to perform again.

title: Love Machines
description: Its the stuff of science-fiction fantasy, but also of high-tech reality: a personal helper robot with the power to process language and the capacity to learn over time, its responses ever more tailored to the needs of its master.

title: Rethinking Further War
description: In a rich history of preposterous endings in opera, Tiridates awakening to the good and true in Radamisto ranks high.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: 'The Commons of Pensacola'
description: Sarah Jessica Parker and Michael Stahl-David in a scene from Amanda Peet's new play at City Center.

title: F.C.C. to Weigh Allowing Cellphone Use on Flights
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday that it would consider changing its rules to permit the use of cellphones and other wireless-data devices during airline flights. If approved, the change is certain to delight some passengers but frustrate many others.

title: How Do They Like It? Loud
description: At Revel, an elegant restaurant that opened in early September in Garden City, most of the reveling is going on at the back of the place. Patrons going in the front door on Franklin Avenue see a smallish, somewhat modest dining room and a sign directing them to the hostess station in the rear dining room.

title: Singing of the Cartels, and Investigating Them
description: With an AK-47 and a bazooka on my shoulder/Cross my path and Ill chop your head off/Were bloodthirsty, crazy and we like to kill.

title: Lest a Pesky Stable Move In
description: Amos Pinchot would be indignant. So would Reginald De Koven and Lewis Gouverneur Morris and Edward Stettinius. They were all well-to-do townhouse owners at Park Avenue and 85th Street a century ago, and would have been dismayed by the prospect of an apartment house above the 1911 Park Avenue Christian Church, at the southwest corner of the intersection. They all relied on a network of deed restrictions designed to prevent just that kind of thing.

title: Fatherhood, Supersized
description: As artificial as the inseminations it celebrates, Delivery Man is a soggy comedy more focused on stimulating your tear ducts than your funny bone.

title: Vince Prices Above Its I.P.O. Range as Fashion Stays Hot With Investors
description: Fashion is still hot on Wall Street judging by Vince Holdings initial public offering.

title: Love Among the Gas Pumps
description: Detroit Unleaded is about as gentle as comedies come these days, commendably so. Rola Nashef, the director, who was born in Lebanon and raised in Michigan, wasnt interested in the slapstick and vulgarity that pass for humor in most films. By avoiding those noisy distractions and staying within the confines of her sparse story, she has created a surprisingly affecting examination of one aspect of the Arab-American experience: the dissonance between American hookup culture and home-country traditions.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Litigating in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, and Snapchat Video Depositions
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Enemies, Abroad and at Home
description: Early in his presidency, John F. Kennedy feared that in the face of a conflict he might not be in full control of the warmongering operatives in his government. The nuclear threat was palpable, and, as Cory Taylor explains in his well-researched documentary JFK: A President Betrayed, Kennedy had learned his lesson with the Bay of Pigs invasion. (According to the film, narrated by Morgan Freeman, he blamed himself for not asking the C.I.A. the right questions.)

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Homemade Polish Feast at Bargain Prices
description: New Britain, a Polish-American stronghold for many decades, hosts a handful of Polish restaurants with medieval-sounding names: Cracovia, Belvedere, Fatherland, Staropolska. It was at the last of these that I whiled away several pleasurable evenings recently, enjoying the robust delights of Central European cooking Tu Jadamy Jak U Mamy  the way your mother used to do it.

title: Comedy Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: James Murdoch Joins Board of Media Company Vice
description: James Murdoch, a 21st Century Fox executive and the son of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, has joined Vice Media as a director, two people with knowledge of the appointment said on Thursday.

title: Cafes Powered by Coffee and Good Cheer
description: Its hard to imagine a time when a foodies working vocabulary did not include zeppole, macaron, pour over and panini. Halfhearted interpretations of these abound; its harder to find places that get them just right.

title: A Place, and Prescription, of Ones Own
description: Jack, the hero of Jono Olivers debut feature, Home, is balancing his dosage of antipsychotic medicine while seeking an apartment in New York for less than $600 a month. This seemingly impossible hunt is endured with humor and sensitivity, as well as minute pangs of suffering, thanks to a stunning performance from Gbenga Akinnagbe (Chris Partlow in The Wire) in the story of Jacks efforts to leave a group home where hes lived for many years.

title: An Uptick in the Hiring of Women for Tech Jobs
description: There are signs that tech companies are hiring more women, but women still appear to make up far less than half of all new hires in the industry.

title: A Birds-Eye View of Liberation
description: Burkhard von Harders Die Narbe (The Scar) bears witness to the legacy of the Berlin Wall in rather literal-minded fashion by filming the walls perimeter from a helicopter. Far from tapping Germanys especially rich and haunted interplay between architecture and memory, the movie suggests, most immediately, that not all aerial photography is equal.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Record High for Number of Jobs in New York City
description: More than a month after the partial shutdown of the federal government, the New York State Labor Department issued some good news on Thursday about employment in New York City.

title: FIFA Plans Final Test of Vanishing Spray
description: After approving a high-tech solution to goal-line controversies for use at the World Cup in Brazil, FIFA inched closer this week to a low-tech solution for a problem that usually arises farther from the goal.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Working Around Keystone XL, Suncor Energy Steps Up Oil Production in Canada
description: Suncor Energy, Canadas top petroleum producer, announced on Thursday that it would expand its oil production in 2014 by 10 percent in another sign that the Obama administrations delay in approving the Keystone XL pipeline extension is not holding back growth in the western Canadian oil sands fields.

title: In Texas, Inmates and Officers Swelter
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex.  IN August, right around the time when the Texas summer heat was at its brutal worst, the states prison system finalized a bid to replace its aging swine-production facilities with six new climate-controlled modular barns, at a cost of $750,000.

title: Excerpt From Radamisto
description: John Holiday and Virginie Verrez perform Se teco vive il cor, a part of Juilliard Operas presentation of Handels Radamisto.

title: As Syrian War Grinds On, a New Flock of Refugees Takes Flight
description: HACIPASA, Turkey  At an unmarked border crossing here in this village in southwestern Turkey, soldiers were interrogating four Syrian men trying to walk into this country one recent morning. Three, after a few animated minutes, were let in.

title: Cuomo on the Radio
description: Since taking office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has granted interviews to a select few radio hosts. His appearances with Fredric U. Dicker stopped abruptly following Mr. Dickers criticism of the governors gun-control legislation in January.

title: The Souths New Lost Cause
description: Before he was immortalized for saving the union, freeing the slaves and giving the best political speech in American history, Abraham Lincoln was just an unpopular new president handed a colossal crisis. Elected with 39.7 percent of the vote, Lincoln told a big lie in his inaugural address of 1861.

title: Irans Nuclear Program
description: To the Editor:

title: In Manhattan Alleys, Dogs on Rat Hunts Find Bags of Fun
description: It was well after nightfall. The pack of dogs was split into two groups and was led to opposite ends of a desolate alley in downtown Manhattan.

title: For a Tapas Cafe in Princeton, Some Baby Steps
description: Bruno Romero opened the tapas cafe and market Despaa Princeton, a spinoff of the eight-year-old Despaa SoHo in Manhattan, because of parallels he sensed in the two communities.

title: Defendants in a Cage
description: To the Editor:

title: News Cycle Delusions
description: Todays big event was the filibuster busted, and I have absolutely nothing original to say. So instead let me say something about the GOP planned attack on Obamacare  also not original, but maybe blunter than youll read elsewhere.

title: Tom Wolfes Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Conservative View of Pope
description: To the Editor:

title: Flipping the Holiday Switch
description: The residents of the English village Gladbury in the period holiday film The Christmas Candle might as well be bustling about in a snow globe for all their dimples, yuletide obsession and quaint, consumptive coughs. This film  adapted by John Stephenson, a former vice president and creative supervisor of Jim Hensons Creature Shop, from the book by the prolific preacher Max Lucado  relates the weak-tea parable of a town that receives a wish-giving candle every 25 years from an angel.

title: Impact Investing
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape Charge Is Set for Boy Held in Death of Teacher
description: BOSTON  A 14-year-old boy accused of killing his teacher was charged on Thursday with having raped her as well.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Egyptian Classics, and Some Surprises
description: King Tut, subject of museum exhibitions, reverential documentaries and one very silly song by Steve Martin, now has a restaurant named after him in New Jersey. A glance at the website gave an impression of sumptuousness, but the restaurant is in a strip mall, its front windows looking out across Highway 22 in Lebanon.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 22-28
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 22-28
description: Brooklyn Childrens Book Fair

title: U.S. Unveils Letters Insurers Must Send About Health Plans
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said last week that the Affordable Care Act would not stop Americans from keeping their health insurance plans, even if those plans did not meet minimum standards set by the health care law.

title: Expanding Social Security
description: For many years there has been one overwhelming rule for people who wanted to be considered serious inside the Beltway. It was this: You must declare your willingness to cut Social Security in the name of entitlement reform. It wasnt really about the numbers, which never supported the notion that Social Security faced an acute crisis. It was instead a sort of declaration of identity, a way to show that you were an establishment guy, willing to impose pain (on other people, as usual) in the name of fiscal responsibility.

title: U.S. and China Find Convergence on Climate Issue
description: WARSAW  Discord and rivalry between Beijing and Washington have factored in international discussions of global warming since the United Nations climate treaty was established in 1992, contributing to the foundering of the 2009 talks in Copenhagen and much rough sailing since.

title: A Nightmare of a One-Night Stand
description: The moral of Contracted, Eric Englands slight but intelligently assembled horror movie, is hard to miss. After Samantha (Najarra Townsend), a lesbian, meets a man at a party and uncharacteristically has hazy, unprotected sex with him in a car, she awakens the next day with an advancing case of  you remember World War Z, right? Lets call this V.D.Z. Living at home in a fractious relationship with her mom (Caroline Williams) and applying to college, Samantha soon finds to her disgust that her eyes are growing opaque; teeth, fingernails and clumps of hair are coming off; a nasty lesion is growing on her lip; and her appetite for human flesh is mounting.

title: An Old Town With New Problems
description: The ancient city of Acre, Israel, speaks  or at least an Arab subset of its population does  in Its Better to Jump. Gentrification spurred by public policy and private investment is on the march in this walled town (also known as Akka) on the countrys northern coast, leading its longstanding Arab residents to fear a loss of identity. Artists, teachers, a restaurateur and a Brown University professor say their piece, politely but firmly, in this rambling talking-heads documentary directed by Gina M. Angelone, and Patrick Alexander Stewart and Mouna B. Stewart, who are husband and wife.

title: An Unusual Health Care Worker
description: A man of few words is drawn to a family with few blessings in This Is Where We Live, a dusty drama about soldiering on without giving in.

title: An Urban Hunt
description: A group of dog owners who take their pets to Lower Manhattan to kill rats say the activity provides mental stimulation for their dogs.

title: The Way They Used to Race (and Die)
description: The combination of fast cars, gorgeous men and Monte Carlo sounds a lot like heaven, but Frank Simons Weekend of a Champion will appeal mostly to motor-racing enthusiasts and movie archaeologists. Covering four days in May 1971, when the director Roman Polanski accompanied the Formula One champion Jackie Stewart to the 29th Monaco Grand Prix, this newly restored and updated documentary offers a minor sidebar to two major careers.

title: Home for the Dollar Days
description: It might be time for a moratorium on movies in which a family gathers for a revelatory holiday meal. Cold Turkey has some fine actors who put effort into their roles, but its getting harder and harder to care about or laugh at adult characters who have botched up their affluent lives and are still obsessed with events from childhood.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 22-28
description: Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade (Thursday) Sometimes even balloons need a makeover. Snoopy, Woodstock and SpongeBob SquarePants will be sporting new looks as they float along with the other balloon characters, bands, clowns and marchers that are part of this years 87th holiday spectacle.

title: A Directors Own Christmas Miracle
description: Black Nativity, an unapologetically feel-good musical about a familys Christmas miracle, is a stark stylistic departure from Kasi Lemmonss signature film as a director, the brooding 1997 indie hit Eves Bayou. But Ms. Lemmons said that in a weird way the two films are not dissimilar: Both examine complicated families and belief in things unseen through a childs perspective.

title: Master of Sightless Sword Play
description: I was never quite sure what to make of Zatoichi and his backhanded sword grip. Again and again, he would fight, taking down a platoon of opponents with such lightning speed that the slashes could not even be seen, and the victims would stand, stunned, for a few seconds before pitching over dead. Again and again, I wondered: How had he done it? And how could he have done it?

title: Kennedy Has Been Shot: Memories From Nov. 22, 1963
description: It is a moment we cannot forget. On the afternoon of Nov. 22, 1963, people were doing ordinary things: walking to classes, pumping gas or talking politics. For many of the 26 percent of Americans alive today who were at least 5 years old when they heard the news of President John F. Kennedys assassination, it was a time of outrage and grief. Those who were young schoolchildren tend to recall not so much the news itself, but its vivid effect on teachers or parents. Some adults sought refuge in a quiet pastime. And for a few, like me, the demands of work deferred the personal impact.

title: Homeless Tally Taken in January Found 13% Rise in New York
description: New York Citys homeless population increased by 13 percent at the beginning of this year as it continued to buck a national trend, new federal statistics show.

title: Finding Events to Attend, on a Whim
description: There are myriad ways of keeping track of goings-on in New York City: newsletters like The Skint, listings in magazines or newspapers or, increasingly, the growing collection of event apps on smartphones.

title: Princess Marie-Chantal Talks Shop
