description: Suzy Menkes sits with Princess Marie-Chantal of Greece to discuss her childrens brand and working with her father, Robert Miller, the duty-free retail pioneer.

title: Sex, Violence and R Ratings
2 Lions, Their Birth Hailed by Gaza, Die Within Days
description: GAZA  The military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, hailed the birth of two lion cubs at a zoo here this week as a triumph over the proverbial hardships of life in this Palestinian coastal enclave.

title: Rodriguezs Strategy: Sound and Fury
description: Alex Rodriguez sang his innocence aria to Mike Francesa at WFAN on Wednesday, and you could not help wondering what the next step in his media tour would be.

title: This Week's Movies: Nov. 22, 2013
description: The New York Times film critics on The Hunger Games: Catching Fire, Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy? and Philomena.

title: Frank Wood Still Promoting Bands After 40 Years
description: Frank Wood, bar band impresario, lays claim to the best rock n roll Rolodex in town.

title: James H. Steele, Pioneer in Veterinary Public Health, Dies at 100
description: James H. Steele, a veterinarian whose pioneering efforts to prevent the spread of disease from animals to people led him to be called the father of veterinary public health, died on Nov. 10 in Houston. He was 100.

title: Derelict in Detroit, and Hard to Sell
description: DETROIT  It is the ultimate abandoned building in the city that has become Americas unofficial capital of blight.

title: Under Investigation, Utah Attorney General Resigns
description: DENVER  Utahs embattled attorney general, John Swallow, resigned Thursday amid persistent questions about whether he had committed widespread ethics violations, saying the legal fight had become too costly.

title: Witnesses in Trading Trial Give Peek at SACs Operations
description: The insider trading trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former senior employee of SAC Capital Advisors, offered a glimpse inside the wildly successful hedge fund on Thursday as the first two witnesses took the stand.

title: Service Members Left Vulnerable to Payday Loans
description: Petty Officer First Class Vernaye Kelly winces when roughly $350 is automatically deducted from her Navy paycheck twice a month.

title: Navy Moves Against 7th Official in Expanding Bribery Scandal
description: The Navy said Thursday that it had taken action against a seventh Navy official linked to a criminal investigation of ship-supply contracts in the Pacific.

title: Bloomberg Says Hell Leave de Blasio No Deficit
description: The financial picture that New York Citys next mayor will face just got a little brighter.

title: Conducting From the Piano Bench
description: After Itzhak Perlman resigned as the Westchester Philharmonics artistic adviser and primary conductor in the middle of the 2010-11 season, the orchestra began relying on guest conductors and soloists who lead from their chairs. That is likely to change. According to Joshua Worby, the philharmonics executive director, who has been involved in negotiations in recent weeks, the orchestra hopes to install two new conductors soon.

title: Before Oct. 1, a Scramble to Fix Health Site
description: WASHINGTON  Federal officials, seeing that the HealthCare.gov website was failing tests in the days before it was supposed to go live, expressed alarm as they realized that if they did not get the problems fixed they were going to be responsible for a public relations disaster, emails released Thursday evening by congressional investigators showed.

title: Bidding for Super Bowl Trip, Fans Attempt an Option Play
description: With the one-loss Broncos and Seahawks atop their conferences, fans in Denver and Seattle have good reasons to start dreaming about attending Super Bowl XLVIII at MetLife Stadium in February.

title: Justice Not Served: Inmate Buses Grounded by Correction Officers
description: All day Monday, Jose Camillo sat in the criminal courthouse on Staten Island waiting for his 17-year-old son, Joseph, to go before a judge. Late in the day, he heard why Joseph had not appeared: The correction officers had refused to leave Rikers Island with the people who were due in court.

title: Another Banking Scandal
description: As financial investigations go, it literally cant get any bigger than this: The worlds biggest banks are now being investigated for rigging the worlds biggest market.

title: When Utility Power Became Accessible for All of New York City
description: Q. By what year did all homes and businesses in New York City have access to utility power?

title: Aw-Shucks Leader Lifts Giants With a New Scowl
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Maybe it is the beard that Eli Manning has grown in the last month. Maybe it is all the early-season losing, six defeats in the first six games. Maybe it is the interceptions, 17 of them, including at least eight that have not been his fault.

title: Man Indicted in the Killing of Baby Hope
description: The man accused of raping and smothering the little girl who became known as Baby Hope changed his story several times as he was being interrogated by the police, according to a court document released on Thursday.

title: All That Glitters Online
description: Proponents of digital currencies like bitcoins say these currencies provide greater security, lower costs and more stability than traditional forms of money like dollars and euros. But in the real world, bitcoins seem mostly to serve people engaged in illegal activities or speculation.

title: Michael Weiner, Peacemaking Leader of Baseball Union, Dies at 51
description: Michael Weiner, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, who forged agreements with the club owners that enhanced drug testing and brought years of labor peace to the game after decades of strife, died on Thursday at his home in Mansfield Township, N.J. He was 51.

title: Caf Grumpy Delights Coffee Zealots
description: You have to admire the brass of Caf Grumpy, a chain that recently opened its fifth location, on West 39th Street in the garment district, right in the heart of one of the most coffee-shop-saturated ZIP codes in New York. But since it arrived in August, this Grumpy has been consistently filled.

title: California Encouraged by Health Plan Enrollment
description: Nearly 80,000 people have enrolled in health plans through Californias online marketplace, at a rate of several thousand a day in November  a sizable increase over a month ago, state officials said on Thursday.

title: Health Law Is Dividing Republican Governors
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Republicans are planning to use the troubled health law against Democrats in next years midterm elections, but the Affordable Care Act is increasingly dividing their party, too.

title: Elegant Chocolate to Go, and to Make
description: Tache, on the Lower East Side, sells chocolate in exotic flavors, and also holds classes. The aroma is free.

title: Hitting the Sweet Spot for Bonbons
description: One recent Saturday afternoon at Tache Artisan Chocolate, a newish store on Broome Street, a tall, magnetic-looking man named Sean John made his way to the counter of the crowded shop. Mr. John, 38, was a regular; he owns Spur Tree, a Jamaican bar and restaurant around the corner. Before he could order his usual coffee (Ethiopian blend), the owner of Tache, Aditi Malhotra, thrust a tray in front of him. It was a new concoction she was working on: dark chocolate truffles flavored with fennel and mango. Tell me what you think, she said.

title: Outcast Mothers Death, and Questions About Jewish Sects Sway Over Children
description: BRIDGETON, N.J.  Abe Weiss came home on the last Friday in September to find the lifeless body of his girlfriend, Deb Tambor, on the bedroom floor of their ranch house here.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 21, 2013
In Kennedys Death, a Turning Point for a Nation Already Torn
description: Fifty years after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, the nation seems to be experiencing a kind of fairy tale about itself, alternately bright and dark.

title: Corrections: November 22, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Scottish King, Bewitched and Bewildered
description: Its the Witches world. Macbeth just lives in it.

title: An Audit of Family Assets
description: A gaping emotional sinkhole opens under the stylish boots of Becca, a struggling actress portrayed by a well-known one, Sarah Jessica Parker, in the new play The Commons of Pensacola by Amanda Peet  another actress, of course, here making a creditable debut as a playwright with this Manhattan Theater Club production.

title: Joy to the World
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  For some solvers, its the high Scrabble count letters (X, Q, Z, V and J) that make a crossword puzzle more exciting. For others, its the twisty, mind-bending cluing and showstopping entries. Luckily for us, weve got a bit of both today, courtesy of Patrick Berry.

title: Turning Pro at 16 and Finding Work Isnt So Bad
description: NAPLES, Fla.  In anticipation of her professional debut, Lydia Ko met with Phil Mickelson last week during a visit to the Callaway headquarters in California. Ko, a South Korean-born New Zealander, is ranked fifth in the world and would have made nearly $1 million in prize money had she turned pro at the start of the year.

title: The Unrepentant Killer Across the Divider
description: The letter sat on my desk like a dead bird. Just seeing my name written in that familiar handwriting with the capital letters and the loops sent me backing away.

title: Forget TV; to Spread Word, Cuomos on Radio
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was ready to talk. It was the morning after Election Day, and voters across New York State had just approved his proposal to expand casino gambling.

title: Scrutiny Over Bronx Councilmans Demands for Ice Center Plan
description: Bronx residents stand to benefit from new jobs, education programs and even free skating under an ambitious plan to redevelop the Kingsbridge Armory into a nine-rink ice center. But now a Bronx councilman is facing questions about whether he sought to benefit from the ice center, too.

title: Jets Reed Goes From Ultimate Win to Winless Season
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Since Ed Reed walked off the Superdome turf last February, purple confetti clinging to his beard, every week has ended in darkly familiar fashion. The uniform has changed (twice). The results, through eight games he has played, have not. Reed is winless.

title: Planning for the Arrival of Cinderella
description: If you see a life-size dragon flying in the New York City sky on Thursday, chances are youve had either too much family time or sudden exposure to the work of Bill Schermerhorn. If its the former, take a deep breath and a bite of stuffing; if the latter, strap in: After Toothless the dragon adds its name to the list of balloons that have appeared in the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade, there are still miles of floats, cheerleaders, dancers and marching bands to come, all choreographed and curated by Mr. Schermerhorn, the creative director of Macys Parade and Entertainment Group. Im the storyteller, he said. Mr. Schermerhorn, 53, lives in Hells Kitchen with his partner, Dan Dutcher, a publicist.

title: Vanities, and Hungry New Yorkers
description: This past week the New York Public Library acquired the papers of Tom Wolfe for the sum of $2.15 million. The material, which fills about 190 boxes and includes correspondence between Mr. Wolfe and his tailor, was paid for largely with a private donation, and while the figure is hardly exorbitant in the realm of cultural philanthropy, which vastly outpaces social-service philanthropy, it represents more than twice the amount of the biggest gift ever made by an individual to the Food Bank for New York City. The all too obvious irony is that it is just this sort of fracture in the citys psychology that might find trenchant expression in a piece of writing by Tom Wolfe.

title: Plans for College, Made More Likely With a Laptop
description: The journey from home to school is an effortless walk for Xavier Cruz, 14, who just strolls around the corner and down the block. But considering where he is going, he may as well be traveling to another world.

title: Font of Natural Energy in the Philippines, Crippled by Nature
description: ORMOC, the Philippines  Clouds of steam surge from fissures in the earth along the beds of mountain streams here that splash down slopes carpeted with coconut palm forests, hints of the enormous source of renewable energy that lies underground.

title: New Territory, and New Challenges, for HBO in Macau Prizefight
description: MACAU  The boxing match between Manny Pacquiao and Brandon Rios will start at the usual time in the United States (Saturday, around midnight Eastern), will be broadcast on HBO pay-per-view and will look, if all goes well, identical to any other major prizefight.

title: Sylvia Browne Dies at 77; Self-Proclaimed Psychic
description: Sylvia Browne, a self-proclaimed psychic who claimed to be able to see into the past, the future and the afterlife  and who saw many of her books ascend best-seller lists  died on Wednesday in San Jose, Calif. She was 77.

title: Relearning the Ropes
description: HBO is navigating logistical challenges as it prepares for its first pay-per-view boxing event originating outside the United States.

title: Clamoring to Put the City Back in the Game
description: The Knicks and the Nets are 3-8 this season, and the question for the moment is not which team is better, but which one is worse.

title: Louis D. Rubin Jr., Publisher, Scholar and Champion of Southern Writers, Dies at 89
description: Louis D. Rubin Jr., whose wide-ranging career as a man of letters  he was a teacher, novelist, essayist, editor and publisher, among other things  was devoted to the practice and promotion of American Southern writing, died on Nov. 16 in Pittsboro, N.C. He was 89.

title: A Silent Part of History
description: The honor guard that stood watch over President John F. Kennedys coffin hold a special yet nearly unseen place in Americas story.

title: African Rebel Leader Said to Be Considering Surrender
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Speculation has increased in recent days that the elusive rebel commander Joseph Kony might negotiate his surrender, ending a long, murderous rampage

title: A Leader Both Brilliant and Humble
description: The word was reasonable, and it was applied to Michael Weiner, over and over, long before he became the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: Once at Kennedys Side, Now at One Anothers
description: ALLEN, Tex.  In the early morning darkness of Saturday, Nov. 23, 1963, at approximately 04:30 hours, Tim Cheek, a 20-year-old Marine assigned to body bearer duty, was one of eight enlisted men to carry President John F. Kennedys coffin, first into the East Room of the White House, and then back out the next afternoon; up the steps to the Capitol Rotunda and then down the next morning; into St. Matthews Cathedral and, then, out to the horse-drawn caisson waiting in the street.

title: Intels Recovery Realization
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  In the temple of technology, Intel has confessed to straying from the true path. That may prove to be the start of salvation for the company, the worlds largest maker of semiconductors, but at a price that is yet to be known.

title: Scandal Tarnishes a British Banks Reputation
description: LONDON  Britains Co-operative Bank once prided itself on being a beacon of ethical standards in a financial sector blamed for the countrys economic problems.

title: A Conservative Alternative to Obamacare
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Thomas Rees, Plastic Surgeon Who Treated Africa, Dies at 86
description: Dr. Thomas D. Rees, an innovative New York plastic surgeon who helped found the Flying Doctors Service of East Africa, a charity that employs a fleet of small planes to provide medical care and save lives deep in the African bush, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 86.

title: Word of the Day | courier
description: courier \kur-e-r, kr-e-, k-re-\ noun

title: As Holidays Approach, Retailers Fight for Sales
description: Major retailers are bracing for a tough holiday season, reflected again this week in the gloomy third-quarter earnings issued on Thursday by Target and Sears. Targets earnings dropped 46 percent from a year ago, dragged down by a costly expansion in Canada and a bleak outlook for consumer spending in the United States. The company also lowered its forecast for the year.

title: Taking on the Task of 5: A Party Veteran on Xi Jinping
description: Bao Tong was an important official in China during the tumultuous changes of the 1980s. He was a political secretary to Zhao Ziyang, the prime minister and then Communist Party chief, who oversaw the market reforms of that decade. But Mr. Zhao was purged in 1989, after falling out with Deng Xiaoping and party hard-liners over how to deal with student-led protests in Tiananmen Square, and Mr. Bao was purged with him.

title: Running Away From Japanese Cars in Chongqing
description: Last week, a 14-year-old girl in the southwestern megalopolis of Chongqing reportedly ran away from home for three days to protest her parents new car purchase.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 22, 2013
description: You leave no footprints. No one is watching you, but youre part of history.

title: News Quiz | November 22, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Relatives Mystified by Fate of American Held in North Korea
description: BEIJING  Merrill Newman is 85 and has a heart ailment, but that did not deter him from fulfilling his wish to return to North Korea, where he fought as a young man, his family and friends say.

title: Death Toll Rises in Supermarket Collapse in Latvia
description: MOSCOW  The number of people killed in Riga, Latvia, when the roof of a crowded supermarket suddenly collapsed, reached 51 on Friday, and officials said hope was fading for at least 25 more victims believed to be trapped in the rubble.

title: A Karnataka Dance Moves With Modern Times
description: BANGALORE  In a quiet Bangalore home, a group of middle-aged women are learning to walk, talk and dance like men. Only a decade ago, they might have been scoffed at; today the mixed audience of men, women and children cheers them on. They are learning Yakshagana, a 700-year old dance-drama that originated in the coastal regions of Karnataka.

title: Chinese Stealth Drone Makes First Flight
description: Yet another Chinese drone variant has taken wing and this one might be stealthy.

title: Latin Grammys Get Earnest (Showgirls Aside)
description: Where did the pizazz go?

title: Bitcoin Gets a Cautious Nod From Chinas Central Bank
description: This week, the Chinese government issued its most direct statement to date on the legitimacy of Bitcoin, the thus-far-unregulated digital currency that has taken China, the United States and other countries by storm in recent months.

title: Pipeline Blast Kills 35 in Eastern China
description: An explosion in a ruptured oil pipeline killed at least 35 people on Friday in Qingdao, a seaside city in eastern China, where the blast cracked apart streets, upended cars and sent a funnel of smoke into the air, according to Chinese news media reports and photos.

title: Test Yourself | Editing, Nov. 22, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Senate Votes to Limit Filibusters
description: In Landmark Senate Vote Limits Filibusters, Jeremy W. Peters writes about the most fundamental shift in the way the Senate functions in more than a generation.

title: No Release in Sight for Film Exploring Chinas Violence
description: When Jia Zhangke screened his new movie, A Touch of Sin, for a small group of journalists in his office last August, he said the film would make a round of foreign film festivals in the autumn and then, if all went well, be released on Nov. 9 in China. Now, with winter approaching, there is still no indication that the film will be shown in Chinese theaters.

title: Institutional Care: Cue the Laugh Track
description: Im sure the creators of Getting On, the HBO series that premieres Sunday night, see it as a blisteringly dark comedy about a dysfunctional geriatric rehab center, with characters and plot devices exaggerated for the sake of laughs.

title: Why Arent More Girls Choosing to Pursue Careers in Math and Science?
description: Natalie Angier wrote in September about the paradox of why girls who were equally competent and confident as boys in science and mathematics still chose not to enter the STEM fields  science, technology, engineering and math. The statistics are baffling. For example, women earned 37 percent of computer science degrees in 1985, yet only 18 percent in 2010. And only one-fifth of physics Ph.D.s in this country are awarded to women.

title: Being Seen Inside an Unseen World
description: A young man painted in blue fixes his eyes on the photographer before him. But before the portrait is made, he peeks in the mirror, retouches his lipstick and brushes away a few strands of white and blue hair from his face. He spent weeks preparing his wig and outfit  a shimmering handmade gown of plastic shower curtains and yellow buttons  all in hopes of taking home the title, and maybe some money, as Butch Queen Bizarre.

title: N.S.A. Memo Authorizes U.S. Spying on British Citizens
description: A draft classified document states that, under specific circumstances, the American intelligence agency may spy on citizens of Britain without that countrys consent or knowledge.

title: Pneumonia Is New Threat to Storm-Battered Philippines
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Two weeks after Typhoon Haiyan devastated the east-central Philippines, a new problem has emerged: pneumonia.

title: Why India Is Going to Mars
description: NEW DELHI  IF you want to marry in India and are looking for a bride or groom, normally you need to consult an astrologer, to learn whether the position of the planet Mars is favorable on your birth chart. If not, you may find it difficult to get the match of your choice. Lately, some employers have been trying this as well, matching their horoscopes with those of their prospective employees; companies are also comparing horoscopes with their clients for good fortune.

title: New York Today: Losers
description: Updated 11:48 a.m.

title: Times Minute: Nov. 22 at 6 a.m.
description: Remembering John F. Kennedy; another cost of Typhoon Haiyan; and Xbox One debuts.

title: South Korea Is Expected to Buy Lockheed Fighter Jets
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Friday announced revised requirements for a new generation of fighter jets it plans to buy, effectively leaving Lockheed Martins F-35A stealth jet as the only viable bidder for the countrys largest arms acquisition program ever.

title: Week 12 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Broncos (9-1) at Patriots (7-3)

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Kia, Toyota and Porsche Issue Recalls
description: Kia will recall nearly 80,000 Sedona minivans from the 2006-12 model years because of a problem that could cause steering failure, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Toyota and Porsche will also conduct smaller recalls, according to reports the two companies filed with the agency.

title: Why the Swiss Scorn the Superrich
description: WINTERTHUR, Switzerland  Abroad, Switzerland may be best known for its smart ski resorts and discreet banking services for the superrich, but the Swiss themselves are remarkably allergic to the trappings of conspicuous wealth.

title: The Year the Monarch Didnt Appear
description: ON the first of November, when Mexicans celebrate a holiday called the Day of the Dead, some also celebrate the millions of monarch butterflies that, without fail, fly to the mountainous fir forests of central Mexico on that day. They are believed to be souls of the dead, returned.

title: Daily Report: Apple Awarded $290 Million in Patent Dispute With Samsung
description: A jury on Thursday said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple $290 million more in damages for violating patents, putting an end to one chapter in the long-running patent struggle between the two tech companies, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: A Stroll Around the World
description: ON THE GULF OF AQABA, Jordan  I AM walking across the world. In January I set out on foot from Herto Bouri, an early site of Homo sapiens fossils in the Rift Valley of Ethiopia, to retrace the pathways of the first anatomically modern humans who colonized the planet at least 60,000 years ago. My finish line is in Tierra del Fuego, at the chilly tip of South America, the last nook of the continents settled by our ancestors. This long ramble will last seven continuous years. It will span 21,000 miles. (I have logged about 1,700 miles to date.)

title: 1963: Art Buchwald We Weep
description: We weep for our President who died for his country.We weep for his wife and for his children.We weep for his mother and father and brothers and sisters.We weep for the millions of people who are weeping for him.We weep for Americans, that this could happen in our country.

title: On a Day It Can Never Escape, Dallas Tries to Heal
description: DALLAS  At the precise minute when shots rang out at a downtown plaza here 50 years ago Friday, more than 5,000 people paused in silent tribute at the place where this city and the nation were forever changed by the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

title: Chennais Love for Chess and Its Champion
description: As the Indian grandmaster Viswanathan Anand was losing ground to Magnus Carlsen of Norway in the battle for the title of world chess champion in Chennai, Mr. Anands hometown, the agony in the city was palpable.

title: Ukraine Blames I.M.F. for Halt to Agreements With Europe
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Mykola Azarov of Ukraine told enraged opposition lawmakers on Friday that his governments decision to walk away from far-reaching political and trade agreements with the European Union was based on fiscal imperatives, and ultimately prompted by the International Monetary Funds overly harsh terms for an aid package.

title: Service Members Trapped in Cycle of Debt
description: SERVICE MEMBERS VULNERABLE TO PAYDAY LOANS | Congress tried in 2006 to shield military members from payday loans, which come with double-digit interest rates and can plunge customers into debt. But nearly seven years after the Military Lending Act went into effect, government authorities say the law has gaps that threaten to leave hundreds of thousands of service members across the country vulnerable to potentially predatory loans, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis report in DealBook. Authorities say the law has not kept pace with high-interest lenders that focus on servicemen and women, both online and near bases.

title: Central Bank Chief Urges European Unity
description: FRANKFURT  Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, issued a plea for European unity on Friday and criticized what he said was a nationalistic tone in the reaction to recent central bank policy moves.

title: Acers New Chairman Follows a Familiar Tech Path
description: TOKYO  Another computer entrepreneur has returned to lead a company that he founded after it fell on hard times.

title: A 50-Year Timesman Recalls the Most Exciting Moment Ive Had
description: Robert B. Semple Jr. had been at The Times for only a single month when the event of a newsmans lifetime  the assassination of President John F. Kennedy  made itself known to him in the form of a radio announcement. He was getting ready to drive to New Haven for a weekend with friends and had stopped at a carwash.

title: Son of Israeli Ex-President Takes Helm of Labor Party, Urging Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Isaac Herzog, the son of a former president, took the helm of Israels Labor Party and thus Parliaments opposition on Friday, vowing to restore the partys historic focus on promoting peace with the Palestinians and to mount a vigorous challenge to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus right-leaning government.

title: Ripped From the Headlines and Applied to the Classics: Ideas for Pairing Fiction and Nonfiction
Chevron Has Second Thoughts on British Project
description: LONDON  The American oil giant Chevron said Friday that it was putting its flagship British deepwater development project under review, saying high costs might not make it viable to continue.

title: Great Years for Nadal and Murray, One Wincing Moment for Djokovic
description: As it turned out, the Davis Cup final that ended Nov. 17 with the Czech Republic beating Serbia was in perfect harmony with the rest of the tennis season.

title: Trying to Redefine Full-Time Work
description: As if the Affordable Care Act werent having enough problems, a bipartisan Senate foursome is now asking that a bill to weaken the employer mandate be included in any budget agreement that comes out of the Senate in the coming weeks.

title: Restoring Brian De Palma in British and U.S. Versions
description: Overheatedly lurid and clinically chilly at the same time, the 1978 telekinesis-and-paranoia thriller The Fury is, for both devotees of its director, Brian De Palma, and hard-core horror fans (two groups that intersect more than a bit), something of a classic.

title: Silent Fellow Travelers
description: Dear Diary:

title: Europe at Ease With Eyes in the Sky
description: GROSSMITTEL, Austria  Deep within a secluded Austrian military training ground here, an odd, shark-shaped machine hovered just above a stand of windswept pines.

title: When Thought Experiments Encounter the Unthinking
description: No, John Maynard Keynes didnt think that burying bottles full of cash in coalmines was the best way to end the Great Depression.

title: Del Toro Shares His Curiosities
description: Opening Cabinet of Curiosities, the filmmaker Guillermo del Toros oversize new book, is akin to bouncing around inside his hallucinatory brain. In addition to densely illustrated pages from notebooks for movies like Hellboy and Pans Labyrinth, it also includes pictures of Bleak House, where del Toro works and stores hundreds of artworks, figurines and props. Catholics go to church, Jews go to temple, del Toro writes. I come here.

title: Points of Entry
description: At any given moment, millions of people in this country are happily not reading poems, and dozens of poets are happy to say they dont care. I have never been one of the people who feel it essential to increase the audience for poetry, the former poet laureate Louise Glck remarked several years ago. The people who need it find it. Variations on this sentiment are fairly common among poets and critics across the aesthetic spectrum, and for the most part thats to be expected. Every activity generates experts, and experts typically have little time for novices. This is no less true of poetry folk than of photographers or pastry chefs.

title: Paperback Row
description: ALL GONE: A Memoir of My Mothers Dementia. With Refreshments,  by Alex Witchel. (Riverhead, $16.) In this unflinching memoir, Witchel, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, describes how her once vibrant mother slowly began disappearing in plain sight. With its cast of vibrantly portrayed relatives and recipes passed down by Witchels mother and grandmother, All Gone is a powerful affirmation of family bonds, Maggie Scarf wrote in the Book Review.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BULLY PULPIT: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism,  by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $40.) Historical parallels in Goodwins latest time machine implicitly ask us to look at our own age.

title: British Police Say Invisible Handcuffs Restrained Women for 30 Years
description: LONDON  Police detectives investigating the case of three women who claim to have been held against their will for 30 years said Friday that the victims had been brainwashed and imprisoned by invisible handcuffs in an unremarkable house in South London.

title: Whats in Store
description: I hope it will not sound disrespectful if I say that I read this book for fun. Yes, I was assigned to review it, and, yes, I assembled all my usual reviewers equipment (note cards, pen, critical faculties) before sitting down to read. But when I got to the end of the book, I realized I hadnt taken a single note. I had been so engaged by Ann Patchetts multifaceted story, so lured in by her confiding voice, that I forgot I was on the job.

title: Even Madder Men
description: The characters populating Michael Kimmels new book, Angry White Men, are familiar types: Rush Limbaughs dittoheads, neo-Nazis, wife beaters, rampaging shooters and the divorced rageaholics of the mens rights movement. Crowded together under one banner, they make for a scary and unpleasant lot: full of fury and blaming everyone but themselves for their problems. Mostly, they blame women: ex-wives, would-be girlfriends, the phantom black women who stole their jobs. The editor of a mens rights website proclaims, The real question here is not whether these women deserve the business end of a right hook, they obviously do, and some of them deserve one hard enough to leave them in an unconscious, innocuous pile on the ground.

title: Clang Went the Trolley
description: You are walking near a trolley-car track when you notice five people tied to it in a row. The next instant, you see a trolley hurtling toward them, out of control. A signal lever is within your reach; if you pull it, you can divert the runaway trolley down a side track, saving the five  but killing another person, who is tied to that spur. What do you do? Most people say they would pull the lever: Better that one person should die instead of five.

title: O Radiant Future!
description: The stories in this collection by the early Soviet writer Sigizmund Krzhizhanovsky are nearly as fantastic as the crashing combination of consonants at the beginning of his surname. In one, the reflection of a man in his girlfriends eye vanishes down the dark corridors of her pupil and falls into a deep well, where it joins the lonely, miserable reflections of her previous lovers. There the reflections debate their mistresss charms and caprices, as well as their own deficiencies of character. And they plot their escape. The hero of another story, a writer, composes a tale about a hermit whose prayers temporarily close all the cracks in the world  potholes, mountain gorges, facial wrinkles, even the cranial seams hidden under the skin on peoples heads. After reading the yarn to some indifferent friends, the writer is visited by an enthusiastic scientist, a reincarnation of the German philosopher Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, who claims that reality itself, the entire space-time continuum, is no less cracked than our everyday world, riddled with gaps and intermittencies.

title: Serious Listening
description: Were used to it.

title: To Hear Her Tell It
description: Doesnt it seem inevitable that Meryl Streep would one day play the mother of Christ? Lord knows shes played just about everybody and everything else: a Holocaust survivor, a chilly Australian housewife who lost a baby to a dingo, Margaret Thatcher and Isak Dinesen and Karen Silkwood, a Prada-wearing devil, a nun with a mean ax to grind, and, coming soon to a theater near you, the devouring Oklahoma mama of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play August: Osage County.

title: Soup to Start
description: View our searchable database of over 600 vegetarian Thanksgiving recipes.

title: Speaking Gobblefunk
description: With Matilda romping on Broadway, its time to reconsider the collected works for children by that English rapscallion, Roald Dahl. Shall we throw tomatoes or roses? Dahl has been tagged variously as a champion of children, an anti-Semite, a panderer of low and crude humor, an acerbic writer of adult short stories who went slumming in kiddie-book land and found it paid well. Hes beloved by millions. I never quite knew why until now.

title: Norma Times Nine: An Operagoers Report
description: A little over a month ago, I was up in the Balcony section of the Metropolitan Opera watching a performance of Bellinis Norma. Its not a part of the Met I spend much time in anymore, but when I was young, I sat for many nights in my favorite spot at the center of the balconys front row. From up there, I would feel like the captain at the bow of a ship, the empty space of the theater sprawling out beneath me, and the proscenium looming fearsomely high ahead.

title: Up in the Aerie, a Ballet Lovers Perch
description: Americans call them the nosebleeds. We British know them as the gods. Theyre the top tiers of the worlds major opera houses, and during my first years of dancegoing in the 1970s and 80s in London, those cheap seats were where I spent most of my time. (Friends used to suggest that I should just string up a hammock at Covent Garden and spend the night there, too.) When I first visited New York, standing room at the back of the fourth ring of the New York State Theater was where I occupied every evening.

title: Worst-Laid Plans
description: The enigmatic women in Laura van den Bergs strange and lovely new story collection, The Isle of Youth, yearn for secure, uncomplicated lives. Luckily for us, instead of clarity and predictability they end up with secrets and doubts. These characters  magicians assistants, gumshoes, gangsters, twin sisters, abandoned wives and light-fingered daughters  all hope to understand the mysterious world, but they find it hard enough just to understand themselves.

title: Dead Poet Society
description: This short, funny and often beautifully written novel  completed in the early 1970s but just now being published  provides an excellent occasion for remembering the weird wisdom and genuine talent of Janet Frame, who died in 2004 after a startlingly diverse life. Born and raised in New Zealand (her mother worked as a maid for Katherine Mansfields family, her father for the railroad), Frame developed a youthful love of poetry that sustained her through several years spent in and out of psychiatric hospitals  until the publication of her first book, a collection of stories called The Lagoon, in 1951. (After her receipt of a major literary award, her doctor sensibly decided against giving her a lobotomy.)

title: In Full Swing
description: Sometimes, one magnificent season can define an era. At least, thats the view in trade publishing of late, where year books have become something of a mania: 19__: The Year Our World Changed/Began/Ended/Learned to Love the Macarena. But its not hard to argue that the apogee of the wild ride America took in the 1920s came in the summer of 1927.

title: Before the Sun Rose
description: In the Paris spring of 1925, a young American writer sent a letter to his new publisher in which he assessed his chances in the literary marketplace. The only commercial magazine to which he had as yet sold a story was a German number that wanted to translate a piece about a matador, but he nevertheless told Horace Liveright he hoped to become a valuable property. Most readers found modern literature too difficult, and he knew that some wonderful books had been commercial failures; Liveright himself had published more than a few of them. Still, his own collection of stories was different, and he felt he had a good gambling chance to sell. For his work, he thought, would be praised by highbrows and can be read by lowbrows. There is no writing in it that anybody with a high school education cannot read.

title: Secret History
description: Twenty-five years ago, I was part of a team excavating an ancient Greek temple on the beautiful island of Paros. For nearly a thousand years, worshipers at this spot had built walls, knocked them down, dug holes and burned offerings to their gods, leaving behind baffling, ambiguous remains. One day, as I was staring at the dirt in a heat-induced daze, a younger student commented how hard it was to make sense of it all. I could only agree, but as we chatted, I realized  to my deep embarrassment  that we were talking about entirely different things. I was obsessing over the technicalities of decoding this complex deposit, while he wanted to know what it had felt like to stand there 2,500 years earlier, sacrificing to alien gods. I had allowed the intricacies of archaeological methods to blind my imagination.

title: Bygone Bipartisanship
description: Ever since our national politics dissolved into a miasma of polarization and strident punditry  which means either the Clinton pseudoscandals or the John Adams administration, depending on your historical reference point  Washington pontificators have waxed wistful for gentler times. In the glow of nostalgia, even ideologues and scoundrels come to resemble civic-minded statesmen who put aside partisanship to broker compromises.

title: Wine Cellar, Well Aged, Is Revealed in Israel
description: Digging this summer at the ruins of a 1700 B.C. Canaanite palace in northern Israel, archaeologists struck wine.

title: Their Honors
description: Digging last summer through a 2,600-year-old layer of cinders in Ashkelon, Israel, hammered home to me the arguments that Benjamin R. Barber musters in his latest book. If Mayors Ruled the World: Dysfunctional Nations, Rising Cities is not about the distant past. But the connections among ancient Mediterranean seaports like Ashkelon, or later among Hanseatic League members in Northern Europe, resonate in his thesis that modern cities are best poised to meet the challenges posed by the global economy.

title: Remembering Egerton, Who Knew the Power of the Southern Table
description: John Egerton, the Nashville writer who authored a definitive book on Southern food and history, used to tell a tale on me: He said that when I first visited his office back in 1996, he caught me casing the joint. The way he told it, he returned from the bathroom to find me running my fingers down the spines of his books, riffling through his files, making his ideas my own.

title: Image of the Day: November 22
Inside the List
description: The Boxer: In recent years, the former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson has shown up in the Book Review mostly as a metaphor rather than a subject in his own right. Weve had references to a Mike Tyson of capitalism (Friedrich von Hayek), a kind of intellectual Mike Tyson (angry feminists) and a couple of Mike Tysons of womens tennis (the Williams sisters)  even, impressively but mysteriously, the Mike Tyson of Korean grandmothers.

title: Off the Charts: Stars of 2000 Burned Out
description: The Standard & Poors index of 500 stocks traded above 1,800 this week for the first time ever. But after adjusting for inflation, the index still remains well below where it was in 2000.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Provisions Scissors
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: A Record Market Is Not All That It Seems
description: THE stock market flirted with historical highs this week, with the Dow Jones industrial average trading over 16,000 and the Standard & Poors 500 exceeding 1,800 for a time.

title: Video Reviews of The Hunger Games: Catching Fire, Philomena and Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the latest Hunger Games film, the drama Philomena and the documentary Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy? See all of this weeks reviews.

title: A Reason to Root for Dubai on the Hudson
description: It used to be that if you lived in Greenwich Village, one thing you could count on was that a black reflective-glass office tower was not going to be built next door. Well, after half a lifetime of wanting to live in Greenwich Village, I now do, and a black reflective-glass office tower has, in fact, been built next door. Its part of a cluster of shiny futuristic-looking things that surround the old Cooper Union building like enemy spaceships. Emerging from the closest subway stop, at Astor Place, you can be forgiven for wondering how you ended up in downtown Houston.

title: U.N. Talks on Climate Near End
description: WARSAW  The United Nations climate conference ambled toward a conclusion on Friday, with delegates saying that the meeting would produce no more than a modest set of measures toward a new international agreement two years from now. As usual, the biggest dispute was over money.

title: Brazil Raises $9.1 Billion in Privatizing 2 Airports
description: Updated, 1:31 p.m. |

title: Dealer Fees for Arranging Car Loans Are Drawing Scrutiny From U.S.
description: Updated, 3:13 p.m. | When Pedro Lantigua, a 32-year-old truck driver from Oklahoma City, decided to trade in his vehicle last summer, he walked into his local dealership and drove off with a brand-new Chevrolet Silverado. Like millions of Americans, he agreed to a loan arranged by the dealer.

title: Who Said Girls Cant Jump?
description: First there was the struggle to make womens ski jumping an Olympic sport. Now the American team just wants to win.

title: Is It O.K. to Force-Feed Prisoners?
description: I believe medical professionals should act ethically. However, Im not sure its unethical to force-feed prisoners on hunger strike. Setting aside the issues associated with incarceration (and Guantnamo Bay in particular), is it ethical to allow a prisoner to die of starvation, even if that is his/her choice? Or is it more ethical to force-feed them? Most suicides are, at least in part, caused by depression or other mental-health issues. I also realize that prisoners choosing starvation may be making a political statement, and it might be unethical to squelch their political speech. What do you think? SHELLEY MARKS, LOS ANGELES

title: Desperately Seeking Christy
description: It was 2007, and like anyone else with a yoga mat and a DVR set to record Oprah, my sister, Donna, and I were reading The Secret, the best-selling self-help book by Rhonda Byrne that espoused the cosmic law of attraction. Filled with the usual platitudes of the genre, it also held out this tantalizing promise: Whatever you desired  a better relationship, a fatter paycheck  you could draw into your life with the magnet of your mind. You just had to concentrate on what you wanted as if it were already on its way.

title: The 11.10.2013 Issue
description: THE COACH WHO EXPLODED

title: Who Made That 3-D Printer?
description: In the early 1980s, an engineer named Chuck Hull approached his boss with an idea: to build a machine that printed out objects you could hold in your hand. His manager discouraged him  after all, the company produced UV lamps, not Star Trek replicators. But eventually the two men reached a compromise: Hull would dedicate himself to the companys lamps by day; at night hed cobble together his dream machine.

title: In Love With a Selfie
description: A nice neighborhood in prison; Robert Irvine, too dumb for the navy.

title: Motrheads Lemmy Kilmister: Im Paying for the Good Times
description: I know you are having some health issues, and you just canceled Motrheads European tour. How are you feeling?  I just feel really down. Ill never get a job again. Im paying for the good times, I suppose. Its a mixture of all the things I ever did  and I did plenty.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks listings include a TriBeCa condo, a Flatbush brick house and a West Village co-op.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Properties include a Stamford contemporary and a Moorestown Victorian.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel
description: This week, Ari Shavit talks about My Promised Land; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Ann Patchett discusses This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: How Could One Thoughtless Driver Take This Child?
description: Early in the afternoon on Saturday, Nov. 2, Anthony Byrd, 59, narrowly missed two pedestrians walking along a tree-lined Brooklyn street, crashed into a parked car, jumped the curb and hit another vehicle. He turned, police said, sped the wrong way down a one-way street and mounted the curb again, this time pinning 9-year-old Lucian Merryweather under his 5,000-pound S.U.V. Lucian was killed instantly.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel
description: This week, Ari Shavit and Ann Patchett.

title: The Gun Report: November 22, 2013
description: Fifty years ago today, President John F. Kennedy was shot to death in Dallas, Tex. Though conspiracy theories abound, the Warren Commission found that Lee Harvey Oswald owned the rifle that was used to fire the shots from the sixth floor window of the Texas School Book Depository building. And Oswald procured that rifle through a mail-order ad in the February 1963 issue of the N.R.A.s American Rifleman magazine.

title: In Search of Woody Guthries America
description: The Pacific Northwest is one of my favorite spots in this world, and Im one walker thats stood way up and looked way down acrost aplenty of pretty sights in all their veiled and nakedest seasons. The Pacific Northwest has got mineral mountains. Its got chemical deserts. Its got rough run canyons. Its got sawblade snowcaps. Its got ridges of nine kinds of brown, hills out of six colors of green, ridges five shades of shadows, and stickers the eight tones of hell.

title: Seeking Authenticity in Italys Tiny Neighbor
description: The jagged peaks of the Apennines? Vertiginous. The shimmering Adriatic? Azure to turquoise. The hearty cuisine of Emilia-Romagna? As delicious as ever. It all might sound like an ideal Italian vacation. But if youre enjoying the gorgeous scenery and a great sangiovese in the tiny Republic of San Marino, please dont start talking about how much you love traveling in Italy.

title: The Other Downtown
description: Downtown Brooklyn is on the march again.

title: The Original J.F.K. Editorial
description: I was 7 years old when John F. Kennedy was assassinated 50 years ago today  in 3rd grade at P.S. 183 in New York City, newly arrived in the United States after an early childhood spent overseas.

title: A Military Wife No More
description: Today I got divorced.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Ackman Vows to Take Bet Against Herbalife to the End of the Earth
description: The activist investor William A. Ackman said on Friday that he intended to take his high-stakes bet against Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company, to the end of the earth.

title: Times Minute: Nov. 22 at Noon
description: Reaction in Washington to the filibuster vote; photographers protest White House restrictions; and in New York, dog bites rat.

title: Advisory Panel to National Endowment for the Arts Gets New Members
description: Three new members  a choreographer of Indian dance, and the directors of two visual arts institutions  have been appointed to the National Council on the Arts, a panel that advises the National Endowment for the Arts on grant requests and policy guidelines, and recommends nominees for the National Medal of Arts. The appointments were made by President Obama, and have been confirmed by the Senate.

title: Today in Small Business: Forget Consumer Confidence
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Willets Point: Rosa
description: A woman named Rosa makes her living in Willets Point, selling sandwiches and empanadas from the back of her van.

title: Big Investment Banks Still Need to Cut
description: Big has been bad for shareholders in investment banks. Thats according to a report published by the consulting firm McKinsey this week. The 13 largest investment banks made an average return on equity of just 8 percent last year  below the 10 percent achieved by the next 200. Given banks double-digit cost of capital, the bulge bracket is still frittering away shareholders money. More cuts are needed.

title: Individuals Find Ideas in the Institutional Investment World
description: MAYBE the Standard & Poors 500-stock index crossing 1,800 this week is a sign of a stock market bubble, or maybe the companies that compose it will continue to grow. There are arguments for both, but the correct answer will be clear only at some point in the future.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 22
description: Subjects include the real mayors of New York, the whitewashing of 5Pointz in Long Island City and the opening of an ice rink at McCarren Park.

title: Willets Point: Flaco
description: Trying to bring customers to a repair shop in Willets Point, one man takes to the streets.

title: Willets Point: Christopher
description: For one man, the junkyard in Willets Point has been an oasis in New York City.

title: An Ex-Mouseketeers Journey Back to Christianity From Paganism
description: Theyre an august alumni association, the Mouseketeers of The All New Mickey Mouse Club, which ran from 1989 to 1996 on the Disney Channel. Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake top the charts. Keri Russell was Felicity. Christina Aguilera stars with CeeLo Green on The Voice. Ryan Gosling starred with his own abs in Crazy Stupid Love.

title: Closing Time in Willets Point
description: The city could use eminent domain to clear out Willets Point in Queens, which supports hundreds of businesses, to clean up the area.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in New Orleans; Philadelphia; Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
description: Rveillon Dinners, New OrleansDozens of restaurants in New Orleans plan to celebrate the regions culinary past with the annual Creole holiday tradition of Rveillon (French for awakening), a ritual said to date to the 1800s, when a lavish meal was served to break the fast after midnight Mass onChristmas Eve. Nearly 50 of the citys restaurants, includingRestaurant Revolution, above, will serveRveillon prix fixe dinnersthe entire month of December, featuring food similar to what the Creole families who began the custom enjoyed.

title: Mets Start Spending, Sort Of
description: The Mets have signed a free-agent outfielder, but it is not Jacoby Ellsbury or Nelson Cruz or Curtis Granderson or Shin-Soo Choo, or even Carlos Beltran. Instead, they have agreed to a one-year, $7.25 million deal with 30-year-old Chris Young, who was once considered a potential star with the Arizona Diamondbacks but hit just .200 last season with the Oakland Athletics.

title: Big Ticket | Luxury Lodging for $17.3 Million
description: With just a few full-floor units and the distinctive maisonette remaining at the luxury condominium reinvention of a historic Salvation Army lodging house for women at 18 Gramercy Park South, the sale for $17,300,067.50 of the 4,207-square-foot residence that commands the entire eighth floor was the most expensive of the week, according to city records.

title: Greece Says It Is on Track to Repay Bailout
description: BERLIN  Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece, meeting on Friday with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, said that his country was poised to return to economic stability and was on track to repay its international creditors.

title: Condos That Fund a Brooklyn Park
description: Brooklyn Bridge Park has transformed a once-neglected slice of the Brooklyn waterfront into bustling parkland, and now, to continue the public-private venture that created the park, pilings are being driven for the first entirely new residential development designed to help finance its operations and maintenance.

title: Getting to the Bottom of a Digital Lollipop
description: How many licks does it take to get to the bottom of a digital lollipop? Thats the question you could soon be asking yourself thanks to a team of researchers atthe National University of Singaporewho are trying to build a digital lollipop that can simulate taste.

title: Poetry Profiles: University of Pittsburgh Press
description: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Ed Ochester, editor of the Pitt Poetry Series.

title: Skip Hop, Maker of Childrens Gear, Sells Majority Stake to Equity Firm
description: A maker of childrens gear, including popular backpacks with cartoon characters, is planning to grow  with the help of a private equity firm.

title: Movie Review: Philomena
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Philomena.

title: Movie Review: Is the Man...
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?

title: Whats On Friday
description: 2 P.M. (Showtime) STAGE BEAUTY (2004) In this high-end costume drama about theater in 17th-century England, directed by Richard Eyre and based on a play by Jeffrey Hatcher, Billy Crudup, above, portrays Ned Kynaston, among the last of the old-school female impersonators and a specialist in doomed Shakespearean heroines. Claire Danes is Maria Hughes, who starts out as his stage-struck dresser and later becomes his rival as women are allowed to appear onstage. Rupert Everett hams it up as King Charles II; and Tom Wilkinson is Othello to Neds Desdemona. For about two-thirds of its length Stage Beauty is propelled by a complex and fascinating set of ideas about sexual identity and theatrical performance, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But as it rushes toward an upbeat ending, the movie at once recoils from this notion and bizarrely succumbs to its logic. In disowning drag and in straightening out Ned Kynaston, Stage Beauty  absurdly for a work that professes to revel in the love of theater  takes a literal-minded stand for the straight and narrow in both sex and art.

title: Dazzling Juliets Light the Stage of Royal Ballet
description: LONDON  Natalia Osipova, well known in New York from many prestigious appearances with American Ballet Theater, gave a superlative first performance on Thursday as a new member of the Royal Ballet, dancing the heroine of Kenneth MacMillans Romeo and Juliet. For at least five years, Ms. Osipova has proved the most sensational ballerina dancing today; while other ballerinas equal or surpass her in style, beauty and artistry, none cause such excitement.

title: After Hours | Wild West Zombies Walk Into a Burlesque Show
description: For several years, the artist Marianne Vitale has been making rugged sculptures from repurposed materials that walk a line between critique and chic. On one hand, her bridges, structures, train-track crossings and headstones serve as a mournful meditation on the disappearance of the old frontier America; on the other, they resemble the kinds of old-timey, artisanal home furnishings sold in hipster meccas like Brooklyn and Silver Lake.

title: Book Review Podcast: The State of Israel
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Leon Wieseltier reviews Ari Shavits My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel. Mr. Wieseltier writes:

title: Timeline Provides Details for a Grisly Crime Against a Teacher
description: DANVERS, Mass.  On the morning of Oct. 22, Philip Chism, a 14-year-old student and soccer player, took a ski mask, gloves, multiple changes of clothes and a box-cutter with him to school, according to the police.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Anomalous Harmony, Present and Past
description: Darkness delivered sweetly: Thats what drew together the improbable partnership of gentle-voiced Norah Jones and pop-punk arena rocker Billie Joe Armstrong, who leads Green Day. They decided to remake, of all things, an entire album from 1958: the Everly Brothers Songs Our Daddy Taught Us (Cadence).

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: The Day the World Stopped Turning
description: As usual, on that Friday afternoon, Mable Snodgrass, a 19-year-old first-time mother, was at home in Echols, Ky., watching As the World Turns. Ten minutes in, at about 12:40 p.m., the soapy drama was bubbling. Nancy Hughes, played by Helen Wagner, had just told Grandpa (Santos Ortega) that her son, Bob, had invited his ex-wife, the scheming Lisa, and their young son, Tom, to Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Shedding Their Skins
description: Laurel Halo

title: A Spur in the Filibuster Fight: A Courts Workload and Politics
description: WASHINGTON  The overhaul of the Senates filibuster rules was prompted, surprisingly, by an argument about judicial productivity.

title: Colleagues Remember Journalist Missing for One Year in Syria
description: A year has gone by since James Foley, an American freelance journalist working for GlobalPost, was kidnapped near the town of Taftanaz in chaotic and war-torn northern Syria as he drove toward the Turkish border at the end of a reporting trip. It happened during Thanksgiving festivities in the United States, and he has not been heard from since.

title: Cornell Star Finds Inspiration in His Sisters Courage
description: Jeff Mathews has set 44 Cornell and 17 conference records, more than any other quarterback in Ivy League history. Entering this season, he was projected by some analysts as a mid- to late-round N.F.L. draft pick, and professional scouts have been attending his games since his sophomore year, a rarity for a player in the league.

title: Families: A Slide Show
description: Every year, American families are becoming more diverse and their makeup more complex. The Times asked readers to share a favorite photograph and tell us what makes their family special. Here is a selection of the responses.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Toll Confirms Storm Is One of Philippines Deadliest
description: CEBU, Philippines  The official death toll for Typhoon Haiyan has exceeded 5,200, confirming that the devastating storm was one of the Philippiness deadliest ever recorded.

title: A Rare Convergence of Thanksgiving and Hanukkah
description: View our searchable database of over 600 vegetarian Thanksgiving recipes.

title: Cellphone Calls on Planes? Flight Attendants Say No
description: The Federal Communications Commission received immediatepushback on a proposal on Thursday for cellphone use during flights from the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA.

title: Spotify Raises $250 Million, Valuing It at $4 Billion
description: Spotify, the subscription music service, has completed a $250 million financing round that values the company at more than $4 billion, according to a person with knowledge of the deal.

title: A Closer Look at Chinas You First Stance in Climate Treaty Talks
description: While I was in Beijng last month to talk about online communication and climate change at a conference organized by Yale and Renmin University, I visited withZou Ji, the deputy director ofChinas National Center for Climate Change Strategy.

title: Judges Decline to Reverse Stop-and-Frisk Ruling, All but Ending Mayors Fight
description: A federal appeals panel on Friday denied a request by lawyers for New York that it overturn a judges sweeping ruling on the Police Departments stop-and-frisk practices, all but ending the Bloomberg administrations ability to legally challenge the ruling.

title: A Lena Dunham Locale
description: The eclectic TriBeCa duplex loft that took a star turn in Lena Dunhams career-launching indie feature, Tiny Furniture (after its owners, who happened to be her parents, allowed her to film there), is poised to enter the market at $6.25 million. The imaginatively renovated living-and-studio space is in a former textile factory at 16 Desbrosses Street.

title: A Onetime Film Set Poised to Hit the Market
description: The TriBeCa duplex loft that was featured in a Lena Dunham movie is set to be listed at $6.25 million.

title: A Hipster Superstore Arrives
description: Ben Ratliff and Ben Sisario discuss the opening in Williamsburg of Rough Trade NYC, a branch of the famed London music shop.

title: Structural Problems With Economese
description: What we have here is a problem of communication.

title: John Boehner Has Successfully Enrolled In Obamacare
description: And got a great deal.

title: Raffling a Picasso for $135
description: A bit of almost century-old Picasso will be coming to New York next month, and someone could end up owning it for only $135.

title: Today In My U.S. Grant Obsession
description: Just so I dont forget, an important anniversary this weekend. The Food Network is 20 years old!

title: Popcast: Rough Trade Arrives in Williamsburg
description: This week: the advent of Rough Trade NYC.

title: Prison for a State Chemist Who Faked Drug Evidence
description: BOSTON  They were called Dookhan defendants, and there were thousands of them.

title: Powerful Rebel Groups in Syria Announce Creation of Umbrella Alliance
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Seven of Syrias most powerful rebel groups said that they had forged a new Islamic force seeking to topple the government of President Bashar al-Assad and replace it with an Islamic state.

title: Shares of Vince Surge in Market Debut
description: Updated, 5:18 p.m. |

title: After Their First Dance, a Lifetime of Music
description: Gifts for music-loving newlyweds, from a speaker that fits into a shower head to a puppy-shaped radio designed by an artist.

title: New Obstacle to a Nuclear Deal: Taunts From Irans Ruler
description: As my colleague Michael Gordon reports, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that inflammatory statements against Israel and the United States this week from Irans ruling cleric, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, could make reaching an agreement over the Iranian nuclear program more difficult.

title: Kerry to Join Iran Nuclear Talks, in Sign of Progress
description: GENEVA  Secretary of State John Kerry planned to fly to Geneva on Friday to join the talks on imposing a temporary freeze on Irans nuclear program, a sign that the negotiations are edging close to an agreement.

title: In Store | Handsome Wallets for the Minimalist at Heart
description: In September, Vianel introduced a line of simple, streamlined wallets that were only available on its website (including same-day delivery service in New York City, where the brand is based). By Monday, and just in time for holiday shopping, fans of the handsome but affordable leather goods can stop into one of the 11 Barneys New York locations nationwide that will now carry them. In addition to offering Vianels signature cardholders, Barneys will also introduce the companys newest styles: bifold and zip wallets, a zip pouch and folding card holders. Our design revolves around the phrase luxury is simplicity,' says Andrew Brooks, C.E.O. of Vianel. Why carry more than you need? Each of the unisex, minimalist designs are branded simply with a tiny gold logo, and trimmed with an extra pop of color  cobalt blue, dove gray, oxblood  on the sides. $195 to $710; select Barneys locations and barneys.com next week.

title: Kate Baldwins Aprs-Theater Spot
description: Kate Baldwins other stage is the house she shares with her husband and young son in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Extra Time to Sign Up for Health Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that it would give people eight more days, until Dec. 23, to sign up for health insurance coverage that takes effect on Jan. 1 under the new health care law.

title: Her Aprs-Theater Spot
description: Kate Baldwin moved to a new apartment, a light, airy rental in a Park Slope brownstone, late this summer, precisely one week before rehearsals began for Big Fish, the Broadway musical she stars in with Norbert Leo Butz.

title: Weekend Reading: Banks Worried They Might Be Next
description: After JPMorgan Chases $13 billion mortgage settlement emerged this week, Jamie Dimon held a conference call with analysts. It couldve been somebody else, the banks chief executive said. Who is next on the list?

title: Bill Cunningham | Nothing Gold Can Stay
description: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one anothers highly individual style of dress.

title: Review: 2014 Ford Fiesta
description: Some people wont drive anything less than a luxury car. Others just need the luxury of driving. The refreshed 2014 Ford Fiesta offers budget buyers a slice of the good life. For a price.

title: Vonn Does Not Rule Out a Return in Two Weeks
description: Lindsey Vonn on Friday officially withdrew from next weeks World Cup ski races in Beaver Creek, Colo., but in a surprise, she left open the possibility that she would race the next week when the womens World Cup moves to the Lake Louise resort in Canada.

title: Love, Blown on Course by a Storm
description: There was an unacknowledged matchmaker involved in the romance of Marie La France and Ken Jackson: New Orleans.

title: Embracing, Not Resenting, Their Differences
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: A Short Drive in the 2015 Audi A3 E-tron
description: Driving any car in the rush hour traffic that coats Los Angeles roads like a viscous layer of hair gel is a chore. You could have the fastest, fanciest, most cool looking car in the world, and youd still be sitting in the same motoring morass as someone perched behind the wheel of a dented 92 Toyota Corolla.

title: Bill Cunningham | Nothing Gold Can Stay
description: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one anothers highly individual style of dress, who pause on their way to work to inquire of their clothes. The tradition may vanish, as one member of the group is moving to California. At times, they spontaneously try on one anothers look. Last week, nature provided a backdrop only it could create. In Central Park, a Brigadoon mist settled over the lake, and cascades of willows framed the Bow Bridge. All over the city, the ginkgo tree proved once again as the leaves fell that Manhattan streets are indeed paved with gold.

title: An Upscale Bounty, and a Thankful Shopper
description: Since opening its first store in Austin, Tex., in 1980, Whole Foods Market has transformed the way Americans shop for food and eat at home  at least those who live in mostly affluent urban areas. When a branch opened in my neighborhood  theretofore a culinary desert  I wandered wide-eyed through what seemed a paradise of offerings tended by an eager and informed staff.

title: Choosing Child Care When You Go Back to Work
description: The largest financial commitment that many new parents make is also the most emotional: choosing a full-time caregiver for your child as you head back to work.

title: Holiday Finds Congress Well Short of Goals
description: WASHINGTON  The landmark Senate vote this week to end the minority partys ability to filibuster most presidential nominees is just one symptom of the deep level of dysfunction coursing through the 113th Congress as the year before midterm elections draws to a close.

title: Warned on Budget, Italy Is Given Leeway by E.U.
description: BRUSSELS  After Italy rebuffed warnings about its budget, euro-area finance ministers late Friday agreed to give the country additional opportunities to show it can make savings and bolster revenue.

title: Indulging in Miso After the Holiday Feast
description: I dont fast after the Thanksgiving Day eat-a-thon and the long weekend of continued feasting and indulgence; perhaps I should.

title: Twitter Toughening Its Security to Thwart Government Snoops
description: A year ago, hardly anyone, save for cryptographers, had heard of Perfect Forward Secrecy. Now, some customers are demanding it, and technology companies are adding it, one by one, in large part to make government eavesdropping more difficult.

title: The End of Willets Point
description: It is easy to drive past Willets Point, the 62-acre tangle of auto shops, car parts and grease-covered mechanics tinkering with automobiles, that sits hard by the Unisphere of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Passing by is far easier than driving through: The streets that cross each other at odd angles here in the glossy shadow of Citi Field look as if they had been blasted by land mines. They are pooled with dark, oil-slicked water or rutted with knee-deep holes that suck in a cars tires. The chalkboard scrape of chassis meeting pavement sounds through the air here with the regularity of a bell tolling the hour.

title: Heart in Mouth, for a Taxing Rarity
description: Before beginning a Britten program on Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic, the conductor Alan Gilbert welcomed the audience at Avery Fisher Hall to what he called the orchestras small part in the worldwide celebrations of the towering British composer in the year of his centennial. The concert took place the day before what would have been the actual anniversary of his birth. Britten died in 1976.

title: A Dallas Concert Honors a Loss Thats 50 Years Old
description: DALLAS  As many have been reminded or have learned anew in recent days, the visual imagery surrounding the life and legacy of John F. Kennedy, who is often called the first television president, is mightily potent. Whether at work, at play or at rest, whether facing crisis or tragedy, whether flirting or consoling, the man exuded charisma and magnetism, enough so to spawn the myth of a Camelot on Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Remembering President Kennedy in Dallas
description: Dallas gathers to mourn on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

title: Bach and His Italian Kin
description: Unlike many of the great composers of his time, Bach stayed put. In his 65 years, he never left a relatively small corner of Germany, even as Handel, his countryman, traveled to Italy and England and Vivaldi, born in Venice, died in Vienna.

title: A Here-Comes-Trouble Homecoming
description: Back in her Pennsylvania hometown, with her latest letters of rejection in hand  from a publishing house, from her husband seeking divorce  Connie (Adria Vitlar), an English professor and poet, is a mess. As she tells Alexandra (Dee Hoty), the psychiatrist she is seeing, It was a mistake coming back here without knowing why I was coming.

title: Leftovers for Breakfast
description: Ive always had fond memories of cooking Thanksgiving.

title: Principal Auctioneer of Sothebys Is Leaving Post
description: Tobias Meyer, the chief auctioneer for Sothebys, has been the public face and a deal-making catalyst for one of the worlds most powerful auction houses.

title: Caring for the Aging, but Ignoring the Rules
description: The rules for depicting the frail elderly on television are fairly clear: it must be done with a gauzy somberness. Dementia and nursing homes and such are something to be whispered about and handled with kid gloves rather than considered a fact of life.

title: An Early Start for Cyber Deals
description: Updated, 3:33 p.m. | It seems Cyber Monday cant come soon enough for some hotels and resorts this year. Many are getting into the holiday spirit early, offering discounted rooms, spa vouchers and lots and lots of free drinks to travelers before theyve even had a chance to cook their turkey.

title: Bhutan Goes Electric
description: Bhutan, the tiny mountainous country that popularized the concept of gross national happiness, is planning to replace conventional cars with electric vehicles in what could be an interesting, albeit not easily repeatable, experiment for the rest of the world to watch.

title: Actors on Actors Who Act Shakespeare
description: Shakespeare fans have no qualms about debating which Hamlet or Lady Macbeth was better than the rest. Last week Charles Isherwood asked: What makes a master Shakespearean actor? This week readers weighed in with their picks for the best Shakespearean performance theyd ever seen or heard.

title: Pumpkins Beyond Halloween
description: There was a little farm near where we lived, in Alsace, France, in a small town by the name of Thann, where we got our pumpkins. My mother would make soup just this same way; she served it in the pumpkin, too. We kids looked forward to it every year.

title: Questions on Drone Strike Find Only Silence
description: WASHINGTON  Standing on the marble floor just outside the House chamber, Faisal bin Ali Jaber looked lost in the human river of hard-charging lobbyists, members of Congress and staffers. It is not every day that a victim of American drone strikes travels 7,000 miles to Washington to look for answers.

title: The Art of Burning Rubber vs. Steady Wins the Race
description: Television viewers who enjoy a study in contrasts will be served a doozy on Saturday night: stand-up comedy specials by Bill Cosby on Comedy Central and Sarah Silverman on HBO.

title: Breslin and Son of Kennedy Gravedigger Recall the Famous Job
description: Clifton Pollard was pretty sure he was going to be working on Sunday, is the way that Jimmy Breslins famous gravedigger column begins, kicking off a poignant account of Mr. Pollard digging President Kennedys grave at Arlington National Cemetery shortly after the assassination in 1963.

title: Audit Board Finds Flaws in Reviews by Deloitte
description: The regulator of accounting firms in the United States said on Friday that Deloitte & Touche, for the second consecutive year, had failed to correct deficiencies in its audit procedures to its satisfaction.

title: Corporate Incubators Popping Up in Europe
description: LONDON  In an Art Deco office block on a side street in central London, groups of 20-something programmers and engineers sat hunched over laptops in teams of three or four people.

title: Bringing Life to Museums Collections
description: Amid all the reports of a groundswell of disdain for car culture among young people, it may seem that the automobile is entering its twilight.

title: Car Museums Get a Makeover
description: Instead of being relegated to dark corners as curious relics, automobiles are now receiving the kind of display and attention once reserved for fine art.

title: A Deal Defended by Cathy Chen
description: Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., teaches on several bridge cruises each year. So he has a good eye for an instructive deal. The one in the diagram is based on a deal defended by Cathy Chen of East Meadow, N.Y., who is a tai chi instructor on ships.

title: Chowder With an American Accent
description: Fish chowder is the type of dish you may find in England at a country pub or in a fishing village.
