But the addition of Quahog clams and intensely flavorful Long Island sweet corn makes this particular chowder unmistakably American, and, with its hearty vegetables, bacon, potatoes and cream, a great dish for the Thanksgiving table. It also reminds me of what I give thanks for every year: the warmth and comfort of family and friends, who gather around the pot with their bowls.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Virginia, the Philippines, China and Bahrain.

title: Brisket Barley Soup
description: If there was no room for Hanukkah on the Thanksgiving table, you can get a taste of brisket in this hearty winter soup.

title: Brisket Is Coming to Dinner, in a Soup
description: When Hanukkah and Thanksgiving merge at our family table this year, we will keep the turkey and lose the brisket  at least for that one night.

title: Loved by a King, but Doomed by a Hermit
description: When Puccini died in 1924, he left only sketches for the finale of his opera Turandot. A parade of prominent Italian composers were proposed and rejected before Franco Alfano was finally picked to complete it.

title: Red Carpet Watch: Sandra Bullocks Fashion Choices
description: Ms. Bullock, 49, has managed to clamber out of the conventional rom-com rut with gutsy roles that display a surprising versatility.

title: Pastrami on Thanksgiving Turns Heads
description: Thanksgiving pastrami: I know its not traditional, but it is impressive, delicious and bountiful. Hear me out on this one.

title: At Super Bowl, New York and New Jersey Will Be Top Rivals
description: For $9,199, a football fan can buy a sideline-seat-and-hotel-room package to the Super Bowl next year. The seat will be in New Jersey, where the game will be played. But the hotel room will be in New York, where Super Bowl Boulevard will stretch from Herald Square through Times Square with a temporary theme park and a 180-foot-tall toboggan slide.

title: TimesOpen Hack Day 2013
description: Our fourth annual Hack Day drew more than 80 participants who created about 30 projects, many of which used APIs supported by representatives from Bitly, DocumentCloud, Mashery, NYPL Labs, Sunlight Foundation, Twilio and our very own NYT Developers. Together they taught, hacked and answered questions. By demo time, 23 projects were ready to show.

title: Chat With Eric Asimov About Holiday Drinks
description: Eric Asimov, wine critic for The Times, answered some of your questions in a Twitter chat on Monday, Nov. 25, at 1 p.m. Eastern time.

title: An Arty Home for Jazzy Sets
description: Music, as subject or spirit, doesnt leap out of Christopher Wools wordy, designy, process-oriented paintings and silk-screen works. But sometimes it lives as a reference in the text and titles. One black-and-white stencil painting in his retrospective exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum says You Make Me, which is the incomplete outburst written in felt-tip pen on Richard Hells chest on the cover of the album Blank Generation.

title: Mavis Batey, Allied Code Breaker in World War II, Dies at 92
description: After Britain declared war on Germany in September 1939, Mavis Lever, an 18-year-old British university student, volunteered to be an army nurse. Instead, because of her expertise in the German language, she was referred to the intelligence services.

title: Every Picture Tells Anjelica Hustons Story
description: In a sea of Santa Monica whites and tans, it was hard not to stare at the formidably chic woman with the dancers posture dressed in head-to-toe black.

title: Treats Magazine Throws a Party
description: Mr. Shaw threw the kind of Halloween party that Hugh Hefner might have given in his heyday.

title: The Last Days of Willets Point
description: Newer developments will soon replace the stream of auto repair shops that have long lined and defined Willets Point. Those who work there see the city-planned upgrade as a threat to their livelihood.

title: Tale as Old as Time, With Video Projections
description: The divided self assumes ravishing forms in La Belle et la Bte, a show out of Montreal that is as lovely to look at as it is hard to listen to. Individuals split and multiply as if by enchanted atomic fission in Lemieux Pilon 4D Arts modern retelling of that eternal favorite of blind date recaps, The Beauty and the Beast, which runs through Saturday at the Howard Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Strong Rules on Fracking in Wyoming Seen as Model
description: In energy-friendly Wyoming, oil and gas companies are getting a clear message: Drill, baby, drill  but carefully.

title: The Future Is Here. Are Customers?
description: LOS ANGELES  As another auto show season opened Wednesday with nearly simultaneous press previews at big salons in Los Angeles and Tokyo, followed closely by an exhibition in Guangzhou, China, the message from automakers to potential customers seems to be: The future is here.

title: 2013 Los Angeles Auto Show
description: Highlights from the press previews in Los Angeles, which helped kick off another season of auto shows.

title: An Orb of Trash Floats Down the Gowanus
description: The spindly skeletons of discarded umbrellas are a common sight after rainy days. But the collection that drifted down the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn on Friday was something else. The brainchild of the husband-and-wife firm SLO Architecture, Harvest Dome 2.0 is a floating orb made out of 450 cast-off umbrella frames, suspended over a ring of soda bottles.

title: Mark Morriss LAllegro, 25 Years Later
description: Mr. Morriss company performed his masterwork, LAllegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato, on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Heralding the Holidays With an Apple Crostata
description: When I saw my mother making her apple turnover, I knew company was coming. I also knew the dough scraps would be my treat. Shed roll them in sugar and cinnamon and bake them, and wed enjoy the light, buttery morsels together with a cold glass of milk.

title: Times Minute: Nov. 22 at 6 p.m.
description: Magnus Carlsen is crowned the new chess champion; Clive Staples Lewis is honored today; and the oldest wine cellar.

title: Kaleidoscope of Introspection, Joy and Pastoral Tranquility
description: In 1988, Mark Morris was given the break most choreographers only dream of: a three-year residency at the Thtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels, where money and resources flowed like water. He could choreograph his heart out, and he did, creating one of those rare, euphoric dances that make life worth living.

title: Fuel Cells at Center Stage
description: BERKELEY, CALIF.  Like thick-rim glasses, Doc Martens and so many other things that fell out of favor only to spring back to popularity years later, fuel-cell cars have resurfaced.

title: Head of Hawaii Insurance Exchange Steps Down
description: The executive director of Hawaiis state health care exchange announced her resignation on Friday amid delays in getting the insurance marketplace off the ground.

title: Past Perfect
description: After living in what must have seemed like every neighborhood in three boroughs  Coney Island, the South Bronx, East Flatbush, Spanish Harlem (as it was then called), the Lower East Side  my mothers parents, in their oldish age, settled in Astoria, which is where I spent almost all the Thanksgivings of my childhood.

title: Rising With the Stars
description: The Griddle Cafe in Los Angeles serves up pancakes, plenty of sugar and the occasional bed-headed celebrity for the masses to ogle.

title: The F.C.C. Puts Onus on Airlines for In-Flight Calls
description: The Federal Communications Commission rushed on Friday to send Americans a message: Dont blame us!

title: Sandra Bullock Discovers Color
description: WHO Sandra Bullock

title: As the Clothes Come Off, the Magazines Dress Up
description: It was the kind of Halloween party that Hugh Hefner might have given in his heyday. Young, almost-but-not-quite-A-list celebrities like Derek Hough, Russell Simmons, Aaron Paul, Jeremy Piven and Ryan Seacrest mingled among a crowd of barely clad, voluptuous women (some who performed fire-throwing tricks in Indian-themed, barely there costumes) while occasionally flipping through copies of an erotic magazine featuring more barely clad (or not clad at all) women on its glossy pages.

title: The Return of the Tight Squeeze
description: When Sarah A. Chrisman received a blue silk rose-patterned corset from her husband, a librarian and bicycle-shop manager, for her 29th birthday, she reluctantly allowed him to lace her into it. She believed then, she said recently,that corsets deformed, broke bones, tortured and killed.

title: Stars, Yes, but Not Michelin
description: LOS ANGELES  The Chateau Marmont was still passed out. The only activity on the nearby RockWalk, where Tommy Lees paw prints are set in cement, came from a pair of pigeons. Nary a needle was buzzing at Tattoo Mania.

title: An Art and Design Auction You Might Actually Be Able to Afford
description: After nearly 40 years as one of New Yorks most revered generalist appraisers, Michael Capo has opened an auction house, Beaux-Arts Auction, in Long Island City, Queens, which hit the ground running in October with a first sale that brought in $250,000. The inventory is made up largely of finds from liquidated estates, ranging from antique furniture to contemporary art, making it a dream destination for interior designers and collectors. Capo founded Beaux-Arts, which sits in a sprawling 7,500-square-foot gallery, with his longtime friend Marc Lester, a Sothebys veteran who specializes in French and European furniture.

title: Ex-Credit Suisse Executive Sentenced in Mortgage Bond Case
description: A former top executive at the Credit Suisse Group was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday for inflating the value of mortgage bonds as the housing market collapsed.

title: Katie Couric Is Said to Be Close to Taking a Job at Yahoo
description: Katie Couric is in the late stages of negotiations to leave her job as a special correspondent at ABC News for a new, as-yet-undefined role at Yahoo, an executive with knowledge of the talks said on Friday evening.

title: A Momentum Powered by Sudden U-Turns
description: Stormy. Stunning. Visionary. Heroic. Those were some of the words that lingered in my mind after the Pacifica Quartets Tuesday evening concert of works by Leo Ornstein and Beethoven at Zankel Hall. And I wasnt thinking about Beethoven.

title: In the Senate, New Rules to Play By
description: To the Editor:

title: The Video Game Wars, by the Numbers
description: With the release of the PlayStation 4 and XBox One, the latest generation of game consoles has arrived.

title: Pardon of Scottsboro Boys
description: To the Editor:

title: Climate: A Medical Model
Judge Orders Reinstatement of Ousted Philadelphia Inquirer Editor
description: A judge ordered the owners of The Philadelphia Inquirer to reinstate the top editor who was fired last month as the newspapers management feuded.

title: The Cheney Schism Over Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Friday Night Music: Putting It Together
description: Somehow, thinking about the ongoing struggle to fix the Obamacare bugs made me think of this:

title: Abortion in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Adults With Aspergers
description: To the Editor:

title: Week in Pictures for Nov. 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the real mayors of New York, the whitewashing of 5Pointz in Long Island City and the opening of an ice rink at McCarren Park.

title: 3 Found Guilty in CityTime Corruption Trial
description: Three men who a prosecutor said had gotten unbelievably rich at the expense of New York City through a scandal-marred payroll modernization project were convicted on Friday in a federal corruption trial in Manhattan.

title: The Thrill of Breathlessness
description: FREMANTLE, Australia  NEWS of Nicholas Mevolis death during a free-diving competition at Deans Blue Hole in the Bahamas earlier this week has shocked the sports devotees and touched many of us who spend time in the water holding our breaths. Doubtless some readers will have been puzzled as to why a young man put his life at such unnecessary risk in the first place.

title: What the Filibuster Rule Changes, and What It Doesn't
The Long Goodbye
description: New York was no mere city, Joan Didion wrote in her landmark 1967 essay, Goodbye to All That, explaining why she abandoned her adopted home of New York, seemingly for good, at the age of 29. It was instead an infinitely romantic notion, the mysterious nexus of all love and money and power, the shining and perishable dream itself.

title: Founder of Reddit and the Internets Own Cheerleader
description: Alexis Ohanian bounded through the offices of Makers Row, a start-up in Brooklyn that pairs small businesses with manufacturers. At 6-foot-5, dressed in a gingham shirt and jeans, Mr. Ohanian was, in more ways than one, the big man on campus.

title: Sale of T.G.I. Fridays Is Considered
description: Carlson, the global hospitality and travel company, said on Friday that it had authorized a review of strategic alternatives including a possible sale of T.G.I. Fridays restaurants.

title: Seven Days of Style | Thom Brownes Relaxed Style, Jay Zs Negotiating Skills and Alexander Wangs Marble Footprint
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTURENov. 16  22

title: Biographies of the Famous Dont Skimp on the Details
description: The book industry faces many challenges these days, but a rising cost of paper does not appear to be one of them. That, at least, is the conclusion to be drawn from the recent spate of plus-size biographies  tree-killer volumes pushing 1,000 pages  that have been making bookshelves sag.

title: Life of Stanwyck Is an Aerobic Read
description: THE FIRST VOLUME of Victoria Wilsons A Life of Barbara Stanwyck: Steel-True, 1907-1940 ends as Europe erupts in war. Stanwyck herself would probably point out, with a laconic smile, that bigger things were happening than motion pictures.

title: Fighter of Corruption in Nigeria Considers Next Steps
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  The cash was handed over in large sacks containing $15 million in $100 bills, bags so heavy that the stoop-shouldered civil servant needed help carrying them.

title: Veteran Union Activist Fasts to Support Rights for Illegal Immigrants
description: WASHINGTON  As a teenage grape picker, Eliseo Medina learned political action at the feet of Cesar Chavez. In 1968, he watched Mr. Chavez hold a 25-day water-only fast that helped transform the farm workers union into a nationally known force.

title: Editor in India, Known for Investigations Into Corruption, Is Accused of Rape
description: NEW DELHI  The police in the coastal state of Goa filed charges of rape and sexual assault on Friday against Tarun Tejpal, the editor of a liberal-minded magazine that has influenced a generation of young Indian journalists with its exposs of corruption and abuse of power.

title: U.S. Retailers Decline to Aid Factory Victims in Bangladesh
description: One year after the Tazreen factory fire in Bangladesh, many retailers that sold garments produced there or inside the Rana Plaza building that collapsed last spring are refusing to join an effort to compensate the families of the more than 1,200 workers who died in those disasters.

title: N.S.A. Report Outlined Goals for More Power
description: WASHINGTON  Officials at the National Security Agency, intent on maintaining its dominance in intelligence collection, pledged last year to push to expand its surveillance powers, according to a top-secret strategy document.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Instagram Messaging, and Room Reservations Courtesy of Twitter
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Phillip Lim: The Chinese-American Dream
description: Suzy Menkes sits down with Phillip Lim and Wen Zhou, his business partner, to discuss the influence that heritage has had on their brand.

title: Norwegian, 22, Takes World Chess Title
description: Magnus Carlsen, the 22-year-old Norwegian who has been the most dominant chess player since 2010, finally broke through on Friday to win the games most important title, the world championship, for the first time.

title: Japan: Governor of Tokyo Embroiled in Loan Scandal
description: Two months after winning the 2020 Olympics for his city, the governor of Tokyo has become embroiled in a scandal over a half-million dollars that he received from a hospital operator involved in an election-fraud case. The governor, Naoki Inose, has struggled to explain why he took the money from the Tokushukai hospital chain during his campaign to become governor in December. On Friday, he described the money as a personal loan that he hurriedly paid back in September, shortly after prosecutors raided the company in connection with the fraud case. Speculation has focused on whether the money was intended to facilitate the construction of a hospital in Tokyo; it appears to have no connection to the successful Olympic bid, which also took place in September.

title: Gynecologists Run Afoul of Panel When Patient Is Male
description: About two months ago, Dr. Elizabeth Stier was shocked to learn that she would lose a vital credential, board certification as a gynecologist, unless she gave up an important part of her medical practice and her research: taking care of men at high risk for anal cancer.

title: A Complex Love Story, Complete With Bells and a Ring
description: MACAU  Manny Pacquiaos last fight ended with him facedown on the canvas, his arms tucked awkwardly underneath him, his body limp. His wife, Jinkee, was hysterical. She bolted toward the ring and fell into the arms of Pacquiaos promoter and sobbed.

title: Lincoln Looks South of the Border
description: In July 1863, just weeks after the twin Union victories at Gettysburg and Vicksburg, Abraham Lincoln turned his attention to the Rio Grande borderlands of Confederate Texas. On July 31, the president wrote Francis P. Blair Sr., one of his most powerful supporters, Yesterday I commenced trying to get up an expedition for Texas. I shall do the best I can. By November, 6,000 Union troops had landed in South Texas.

title: A Players-Only Meeting? That Cant Be Good News
description: When Chuck Daly was coaching the Orlando Magic in the late 1990s and his team was mired in a rough patch, he learned that a couple of his players were itching for a players-only meeting. Eric Musselman, one of his young assistants, recalled how Daly recruited him to relay a message to Horace Grant: permission denied.

title: A Gamble in Iran Talks: Easing of the Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  In its delicate negotiations with Iran over freezing its nuclear program, the Obama administration is gambling that the gradual relaxation of punishing sanctions will whet Tehrans appetite for greater economic relief, inducing the countrys leaders to negotiate a further deal to roll back its nuclear progress.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: The Dow Jones Industrial average closes above 16,000, the former presidential contender John Edwards opens a law office and European companies develop new drones.

title: Marines Toughen Rules for Makers of Licensed Clothing
description: The Marine Corps trademark licensing office has adopted tougher production standards for manufacturers that produce clothing items like sweatshirts emblazoned with Marine mottos or insignia, after the corps was stung by the discovery of a licensed companys designs in the rubble of a factory fire in Bangladesh a year ago.

title: Saturdays Games to Watch
description: 3 BAYLOR at

title: Obamas Bay of Pigs
description: This week, when we are remembering John F. Kennedy, Id like to touch briefly on the greatest fiasco of his presidency: the Bay of Pigs invasion. No sooner had Kennedy taken the oath of office than he discovered that the Pentagon and C.I.A. were preparing to send 1,500 Cuban exiles to invade Cuba. Though they would be greatly outnumbered by Cuban troops, the American military and the C.I.A. assumed that once the attack began, the Cuban people would rise up and overthrow Fidel Castro.

title: Fears of Violence Loom Over Honduran Elections
description: In a country where the rule of law has all but shriveled, Hondurans head to the polls in hopes of electing a president who will bring stability and security.

title: Racial Abuse Is Alleged at San Jose State University
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Students at San Jose State University were grappling on Friday with accusations that three white students repeatedly abused a black freshman verbally and physically, calling him names referring to slavery and putting a bicycle lock around his neck.

title: Political Doubt Poses Risk to Honduras, Battered by Coup and Violence
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras  When police officers arrived last week after the murder of Felipe Nery Aguilar and his daughter Gladys, they seized on what appeared to be a clue: a childish scribble on a broken television set. A message from local gangs, the officers figured, demanding protection money, known here as a war tax. Case closed.

title: Responding to a Meningitis Outbreak
description: A vaccine approved for use in Europe and Australia but not in the United States will be imported to help quell an outbreak of bacterial meningitis at Princeton University. This is a good example of how two federal agencies  the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration  can collaborate to reach a common-sense solution to protect the publics health.

title: Climbing Out of Albanys Swamp
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has repeatedly promised to clean up Albany, a vow that topped his priority list when he ran for office in 2010. Last January, he took the next step and proposed public matching funds for smaller campaign donations, a system that has worked remarkably well in New York City.

title: Surveillance Goes on Trial
description: There was a lot that was ordinary about the hearing in Courtroom 20B of the Manhattan federal courthouse on Friday morning: a team of lawyers at the plaintiffs table, spectators in the gallery. What was extraordinary was the defendant, the United States government, and the lawsuit it is facing over the National Security Agencys seven-year-old, once top-secret phone-surveillance program, which until this week it never had to defend in open court.

title: Leave an Idea, Take an Idea
description: Saturday is the last day for New Yorkers to give Bill de Blasio, the mayor-elect, a piece of their mind under the big white Talking Transition tent on Canal Street and Avenue of the Americas. Since the Nov. 5 election, inside that tent, in mobile tents that roamed the boroughs and online at talkingtransitionnyc.com, thousands have offered suggestions on stickers and postcards; sent emails; taped videos; and attended forums on topics like food justice, affordable housing and immigrant integration.

title: Comparing Child Care Costs
description: Full-time child care is a large expense, but the cost varies regionally and by state with some scattered outliers among the highest.

title: Texas Education Board Flags Biology Textbook Over Evolution Concerns
description: The Texas Board of Education on Friday delayed final approval of a widely used biology textbook because of concerns raised by one reviewer that it presents evolution as fact rather than theory.

title: Iran Would Eliminate Stock of Some of Its Enriched Uranium Under Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Under the proposed six-month deal that six major powers are negotiating with Iran in Geneva, Iran would eliminate its current stock of uranium enriched to 20 percent by diluting it or turning it into fuel rods or oxide powder, forms that are unusable for weapons, senior Western officials said Friday.

title: A Rural Retreat in China
description: The Times's Edward Wong visits the quiet town of Dali, where writers, artists and other residents have found an idyllic escape from the crowded cities of eastern China.

title: Tension and Flaws Before Health Website Crash
description: WASHINGTON  On a sultry day in late August, a dozen staff members of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services gathered at the agencys Baltimore headquarters with managers from the major contractors building HealthCare.gov to review numerous problems with Presidents Obamas online health insurance initiative. The mood was grim.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 23, 2013.
description: It really puts a human face on the term collateral damage.

title: Police Unsure if Random Attacks Are Rising Threat or Urban Myth
description: Fear swept through Borough Park, Brooklyn, as soon as the news got out: A young man was randomly assaulted by strangers early Friday morning, and the attack was possibly part of the so-called Knockout Game.

title: Singing Arias and Splitting Uprights, a Raven Knows How to Enhance a Score
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Justin Tuckers right leg swung swiftly into the footballs gut, and he watched the ball travel straight and far before smashing off a seat deep in the second deck.

title: North Korea Confirms It Is Holding U.S. Citizen
description: The State Department said Friday that North Korea had confirmed that it was holding an American citizen, whom family and friends have identified as an octogenarian veteran of the Korean War inexplicably detained there last month as he was concluding an officially approved nine-day tour of the country.

title: Corrections: November 23, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 22, 2013
Slam Dunk
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Well. If you thought you were going to relax with the crossword puzzle this weekend, you were clearly wrong. This is a rock em, sock em puzzle if ever I saw one, with a bit of obscurity and variance thrown in to keep us humble.

title: For the Love of the Game
description: Columbia footballs long history of losing seasons, and long rides to the field, do not deter players from coming out for practices and games.

title: Columbia Footballs Dogged Futility
description: Way uptown, at its gleaming new field house on the northern tip of Manhattan, Columbia is trying to win at football  really, it is  even though it may appear otherwise.

title: Wind Energy Company to Pay $1 Million in Bird Deaths
description: Duke Energy agreed on Friday to pay $1 million in fines as part of the Justice Departments first criminal case against a wind power company for the deaths of protected birds.

title: Pentagon Releases Strategy for Arctic
description: WASHINGTON  As a shrinking northern ice cap sets the stage for increased competition over natural resources, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Friday released the Pentagons first Arctic Strategy, intended to safeguard American security interests and the regions environment.

title: A New Dispute Emerges in Brooklyn Prosecutors Office
description: The last several months have unfolded tempestuously for Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. He faces accusations that his office handled a series of wrongful convictions in murder cases, one of which has resulted in a $150 million lawsuit. He was criticized for allowing his office to be the focus of a television show. And he lost a primary and a lopsided general election, forcing him out after 24 years.

title: Despite the Evidence, Trainers Deny a Doping Problem
description: On Thursday morning, representatives of the horse-racing industry told Congress that thoroughbred racings drug problem was a myth. On Thursday afternoon, a report by the California Horse Racing Board revealed that Bob Baffert, a Hall of Fame trainer, had been giving every horse in his barn a thyroid hormone without ever checking to see if any of them had thyroid problems.

title: Urbanites Flee Chinas Smog for Blue Skies
description: DALI, China  A typical morning for Lin Liya, a native of Shanghai transplanted to this ancient town in southwest China, goes like this: See her 3-year-old son off to school near the mountains; go for a half-hour run on the shores of Erhai Lake; and browse the local market for fresh vegetables and meat.

title: Vern Mikkelsen, Hall of Famer Who Won Four Titles With the Lakers, Dies at 85
description: Vern Mikkelsen, a Hall of Fame forerunner of the modern-day power forward who helped lead the Minneapolis Lakers to four N.B.A. championships in the early 1950s, died on Thursday at his home in Wayzata, Minn. He was 85.

title: John Egerton, Who Lent Spice to Social Justice, Dies at 78
description: John Egerton understood that the American South was a region of contradictions, holding both savagery and sweetness, churchgoers and evildoers, good cooking and bad.

title: Completely Different Giants Eager for Rematch With Cowboys
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants enter their rematch against Dallas at MetLife Stadium believing that their season-opening 36-31 loss to the Cowboys proved nothing about the superiority of either team.

title: Rev. T. J. Jemison, Civil Rights Leader Who Organized Early Boycott, Dies at 95
description: The Rev. T. J. Jemison, a civil rights pioneer who organized a 1953 bus boycott in Baton Rouge, La., that foreshadowed the one set off by Rosa Parks in Montgomery, Ala., and who went on to lead the nations largest black Baptist organization into liberal political activism, died on Nov. 15 in Baton Rouge. He was 95.

title: Kerry Opposes Afghan Delay on Security Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry talked with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Friday to express displeasure with his plan to put off signing the two countries security deal until next year, and a State Department spokeswoman said the delay threatened relations between Washington and Kabul.

title: After Conviction, Focus Turns to Ownership of Marcos Artwork
description: The criminal trial concerning four Impressionist masterpieces once owned by Imelda Marcos may have ended this week with a jurys quick conviction of her former personal secretary, but a more daunting question remains: What happens to the artwork?

title: Trouble Dont Last Always
description: Theres an old Gospel song called Trouble Dont Last Always. My mother has repeated that phrase so often that the words are written on my consciousness.

title: Flyers Rescue Season Behind Interim Coach and a Few Good Bounces
description: PHILADELPHIA  On Nov. 1, one month into the N.H.L. season, the Philadelphia Flyers lost to the Alex Ovechkin-less Washington Capitals, 7-0. They took nearly three times as many penalty minutes as shots, and goalie Ray Emery attracted criticism by leaving the crease to fight Washingtons Braden Holtby. The Flyers record fell to 3-9, and their star center Claude Giroux still had not scored a goal.

title: Experts Say Poaching Could Soon Lead to a Decline in the Rhino Population
description: After two decades of gains, the worlds population of rhinoceroses is being killed off by poachers at such a high rate that conservationists fear the deaths could soon surpass the number of rhinos that are born each year.

title: Garnett Has Impact, but Not the Right Kind, in a Rout
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Nights like Friday are when leadership matters in the N.B.A. Four injured players were out for the beleaguered Nets, including their leading scorer Brook Lopez. The situation demanded that the veterans with the championship rings, Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce, assert themselves. Especially Garnett, facing the Minnesota Timberwolves, the franchise where he spent his first 12 seasons.

title: Argument Escalates to Stabbing at Kennedy Airport
description: A man was stabbed in the face during a dispute in a parking lot at Kennedy International Airport on Friday afternoon, the police said.

title: Led by Veterans (in Early 20s), UConn Nips Indiana
description: It is a year featuring one of the deepest and most advanced freshman classes in memory, and Connecticut can seem a bit like a creaky wooden vessel in a flotilla of speedboats. The Huskies do not have that transcendent newcomer. They are led by that most arcane and pass of figures: the upperclassman.

title: Bloomberg Wants Restaurants to Compost
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is slowly bringing New Yorkers around to the idea of recycling their food scraps, is trying to expand his composting campaign by bringing it to large restaurants.

title: After a Long Silence, Dolan Speaks
description: On March 13, 2012, The New York Times published a story by Howard Beck that noted it had been exactly five years since James Dolan, the Knicks owner, had consented to any sort of interview with the reporters who covered his often inept team.

title: Marines at Kennedys Funeral Stand Together Again
description: ALLEN, Tex.  Fifty years without seeing someone is a long time to remember a name, and when Bob DeBardelaben saw Tom Tallick at a reunion here of the Marines who served at President John F. Kennedys funeral, he could not.

title: A Chance to Spend a Bit of Summer in the Country
description: Sitting in the living room of her two-bedroom apartment in the Marble Hill section of the Bronx, Kathleen Hicks, a former messenger service dispatcher, turned up her right wrist. The name Nancy is tattooed, in cursive, on the pulse point.

title: A Strategy for Surveillance Powers
description: A National Security Agency mission statement provides a glimpse of agency officials goals before the Snowden leaks upset their political calculus.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) IDENTITY THIEF (2013) Melissa McCarthy stars as a crazed kewpie doll of a thief sometimes named Diana who wreaks havoc on a milquetoast, Sandy Patterson (Jason Bateman), after stealing his identity just as he lands a job insuring his upward mobility. After leaving his wife (Amanda Peet) and their kids in their meager apartment, Sandy heads toward Dianas home in Florida to regain control over his life. But shes not about to give up the spoils easily. From the moment Diana comes on screen in Identity Thief, sugar-talking Sandy out of his information while shes slurping a soda, Ms. McCarthy owns the movie, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. The character may be drawn in broad strokes, but Ms. McCarthy slips between the saucy and the demonic with exquisite effortlessness, fluttering her lashes and flashing her dimples one minute, unleashing her inner Medusa the next.

title: China Claims Air Rights Over Disputed Islands
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government on Saturday claimed the right to identify, monitor and possibly take military action against aircraft that enter a newly declared air defense identification zone, which covers sea and islands also claimed by Japan and threatens to escalate an already tense dispute over some of the maritime territory.

title: Karzai Insists U.S. Forces Killed Civilians in a Raid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For the second time in less than a week, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has picked a high-profile fight with his American allies, in the midst of a grand council that he convened to support a long-term security agreement with the United States.

title: New Musical Partnership in China
description: One of the biggest, but least-tapped markets for classical music and dance  as both an importer and exporter  is China. So this week IMG Artists, a major representative of classical musicians in the West, announced a new partnership with the China Arts and Entertainment Group, a huge arts and entertainment company in China.

title: Bubblephobia and Monetary Policy
description: How do you know that monetary policy is too loose? The textbook answer is that excessively expansionary monetary policy shows up in rising inflation; stable inflation means money is neither too loose nor too tight. This answer has, however, come under challenge from both sides. One side  the side Im on, and Im pretty sure the side Janet Yellen is on, says that at low inflation rates this rule breaks down: the Phillips curve isnt vertical, even in the long run, at low inflation (perhaps thanks to downward nominal wage rigidity), so stable inflation at a low level is consistent with an economy operating well below potential.

title: Egypt Expels Turkeys Ambassador, Further Fraying Diplomatic Ties
description: CAIRO  Egypt announced on Saturday that it was downgrading its diplomatic relations with Turkey and expelled the Turkish ambassador because of provocative criticisms of Cairo by Turkeys prime minister, a spokesman for Egypts foreign minister said.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Nov. 22, 2013
description: Healthcare.gov launched more than seven weeks ago and the programs problems keep piling up, as hundreds of thousands of people received notifications that their current coverage is being cancelled. There are also concerns over the websites security. Last week, President Obama announced a fix. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine consider if these changes put the entire law at risk and what the uncertainty means for consumers and businesses. Plus, a look at the recent JPMorgan settlement, which forced the bank to shell out a record $13 billion.

title: In Our Pages: November 23
description: 1938: S.S. Vows Fire and Sword

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Tierney Gearons Alphabet Book
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: After Two Decades, a Shrinking Salary at a Job She Loved
description: Police cars were blocking the entrance to the bus yard in Brooklyn when Nicole Bouchotte, 61, arrived at work one day last January. It was at that moment, so early on a cold weekday morning that the sun had yet to rise, that she learned that her union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, was on strike.

title: Arsenals Giroud Receives a Gift
description: Buried deep inside nearly every goalkeeper in the world is a skillful field player fighting to get out. At least that is a theory shared by most of the worlds goalkeepers.

title: Variety: A New Diagramless
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Ill tell you exactly where I had trouble: PARIPASSU.

title: Syrian Rebels Seize Control of Oil Field From Assad
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A group of Syrian rebel brigades, including an affiliate of Al Qaeda, seized a large oil and gas field from government forces on Saturday, opposition activists said, further depriving the government of President Bashar al-Assad of the resources it needs to remain solvent.

title: Teams Are Learning to Keep Their Best Players Off the Market
description: When the Detroit Tigers traded Prince Fielder to Texas last week, they still owed him a staggering $168 million. Only one player had ever been traded with more money still owed to him: Alex Rodriguez, from Texas to the Yankees in 2004.

title: $62 Million in Sales at Art of the Automobile Auction
description: A red Ferrari endurance-racing car that was on display in the lobby of Sothebys on the Upper East Side of Manhattan was the top sale in a closely watched auction on Thursday. The 1964 Ferrari 250 LM, which was been given a presale estimate of $12 million to $15 million, sold for $14.3 million including the buyers premium.

title: Accord Reached With Iran to Halt Nuclear Program
description: GENEVA  The United States and five other world powers announced a landmark accord Sunday morning that would temporarily freeze Irans nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping agreement.

title: Letters to the Sports Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Golf, South Koreans Find a New Model for Success
description: NAPLES, Fla.  Se Ri Pak was the prototype, engineered by her father to be a mentally strong, mechanically sound golfing machine. His blueprint, in which he streamlined Paks existence by eliminating any activity not conducive to shooting low scores, was widely copied by other South Korean fathers of young daughters after Pak won the first of 25 titles on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

title: Lakers Nash Shares Aches of His Elders
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  As Lakers guard Steve Nash speaks in such a clinical manner about nerve root irritation, proper alignment, asymptomatic discomfort and musculature default patterns, listening to him requires a quick reminder that he is a basketball player and not a Pilates instructor.

title: Lynn Good of Duke Energy, on Effective Leaders
description: This interview with   Lynn J. Good, chief executive of Duke Energy, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Cowboys See a Chance to Move Past Troubles
description: IRVING, Tex.  One bye week may not be enough time to cure what ails the Dallas Cowboys, who appear as enigmatic as ever before their showdown with the Giants on Sunday.

title: Almanacs Foresee a Super Bowl to Test Fans Resolve, and Snow Gear
description: When the N.F.L. owners met near Dallas three years ago and chose to hold Super Bowl XLVIII in New Jersey, it was a balmy 90 degrees and dry as a bone. The 80,000 fans who attend the game in February may be happy if it is half as warm.

title: Haitian Photographer Wins Major U.S. Copyright Victory
description: Photographers have struggled financially over the last decade as millions of images have been taken and published on the Web without proper attribution or compensation. And when photographers try to pursue copyright violators, it is often difficult and expensive. On Friday, the Haitian photographer Daniel Morel won a major copyright victory after a four-year fight over images he had originally sent out via social media.

title: Eli Mannings Footballs Are Months in Making
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Eli Manning drops back to throw his first pass Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys, the football in his hands will be as familiar as an old friend.

title: For Sale: Craggy Isle Where Olympic Rocks Are the Stars
description: AILSA CRAIG, Scotland  This stunning volcanic island has been part of Scottish legend for a thousand years, its sugarloaf profile decorating Scottish bank notes and memorialized in a Keats sonnet.

title: In Immigration Battle, Advocates for Overhaul Single Out Republicans
description: PUEBLO, Colo.  Representative Scott Tipton, Republican of Colorado, entered his town hall meeting and quickly began greeting the assembled crowd, including those who did not necessarily share his political views.

title: Ed Reeds Film Study Class Is Mesmerizing an Eager Acolyte
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Josh Bush had but one request soon after being drafted by the Jets in 2012. Bush, a safety, asked his position coach, Dennis Thurman, to put him in touch with Ed Reed, whom he had coached in Baltimore. No way, Thurman said. As much as Bush stood to learn from Reed, he was not ready  not yet.

title: Unsettled in Goal, U.S. Keeps Looking
description: They fan out to the N.H.L.s 30 rinks across the continent, a small group of hockey executives watching game after game, deciding which players might represent the United States at the Sochi Olympics. Of those decisions, none will be more crucial than picking the goaltenders.

title: Bodies Still Being Found Weeks After Philippine Storm
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  A solemn procession walked down the main coastal road here Saturday morning through a light but steady rain, carrying a piece of plywood with a black object securely fastened on top with yellow packaging tape: a body bag holding the remains of Athena Mae Pelingon, age 3.

title: Saddled Together
description: Marley Stone and Timothy Bourke often go head to head at equestrian competitions, but their friendly rivalry on the field hasnt affected their romantic relationship.

title: How Can We Jump-Start the Struggle for Gender Equality?
description: For several decades womens success in the labor market was so breathtaking, so propulsive, that full gender equality seemed inevitable.

title: When the Weather, Too, Was Memorable
description: With two almanacs forecasting a snowy Super Bowl at MetLife Stadium in February, it is worth noting that important sporting events often take place in weather that is less than ideal.

title: Big Games in the Great, Unforgiving Outdoors
description: Some weather prognosticators are warning that the first outdoor Super Bowl in a winter environment could morph into the Snow Bowl. But conducting sporting events in extreme weather is nothing new. Reporters from The New York Times share their tales of meteorologic misery.

title: In Defense of a Loaded Word
description: MY fathers name is William Paul Coates. I, like my six brothers and sisters, have always addressed him as Dad. Strangers often call him Mr. Coates. His friends call him Paul. If a stranger or one of my fathers friends called him Dad, my father might have a conversation. When I was a child, relatives of my paternal grandmother would call my father Billy. Were I to ever call my father Billy, we would probably have a different conversation.

title: Puddleglum and the Savage
description: THEY died in their homes, not from an assassins bullet, and in their 60s, not in their prime. When C. S. Lewis collapsed in his Oxford bedroom, the presidential motorcade was leaving Love Field. When Aldous Huxley requested a final shot of LSD, a TV set in the next room had just blared the news that the president had been shot. And then the coincidence of two of modernitys keenest critics dying on the same November day was lost in a storm of headlines and public grief.

title: Why the Y?
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  EVEN sitting in an M.I.T. classroom made me feel smarter.

title: Christopher Kimball
description: Christopher Kimball is the bow-tied and bespectacled chef and founder of Americas Test Kitchen, which produces television and radio shows of the same name and publishes Cooks Illustrated magazine.

title: Right vs. Left in the Midwest
description: MINNESOTA and Wisconsin share much more than bone-chilling winters: German and Northern European roots; farming; and, until recently, a populist progressive tradition stretching back a century to Wisconsins Fighting Bob La Follette and the birth of Minnesotas Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party.

title: After Changes, How Green Is The Times?
description: EARLY this year, The Times came under heavy criticism from many readers who care deeply about news coverage about the environment  especially climate change.

title: Oh, Brother! Big Brother Is Back
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  IVE never been in a big earthquake, but I know what one feels like now, having spent this past week in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. The American-led interim negotiations in Geneva to modestly loosen some sanctions on Iran in return for some curbs on its nuclear program  in advance of talks for an end to sanctions in return for an end to any Iranian bomb-making capability  has hit the Sunni Arab world (and Israel) like a geopolitical earthquake. If and when a deal is struck, it could have a bigger impact on this region than anything since the Camp David peace treaty and Irans Islamic Revolution in the 1970s combined to reorder the Middle East.

title: Taking Our Selfies Seriously
description: Selfie is the newly crowned champion word of the year by Oxford Dictionaries. It means a photograph taken of oneself by oneself but usually not for oneself  rather for the whole world  on a cellphone camera.

title: Danger Lurks in That Mickey Mouse Couch
description: RESEARCHERS this summer purchased 42 childrens chairs, sofas and other furniture from major retailers and tested them for toxic flame retardants that have been linked to cancer, birth defects, diminished I.Q.s and other problems.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Helping Women Lean In
description: Readers discuss promoting gender equality at work and home.

title: A Most Expensive Book
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  THE first English-language book printed in the New World is scheduled to be auctioned on Tuesday by Sothebys of New York. Its expected to command between $15 million and $30 million  more than anyone, anywhere, has ever paid for a printed book.

title: Art Makes You Smart
description: FOR many education advocates, the arts are a panacea: They supposedly increase test scores, generate social responsibility and turn around failing schools. Most of the supporting evidence, though, does little more than establish correlations between exposure to the arts and certain outcomes. Research that demonstrates a causal relationship has been virtually nonexistent.

title: Bringing Back My Real Self With Hormones
description: IN my early 30s, for a few months, I altered my body chemistry and hormones so that I was closer to a man in his early 20s. I was blown away by how dramatically my thoughts changed. I was angry almost all the time, thought about sex constantly, and assumed I was the smartest person in the entire world. Over the years I had met guys rather like this.

title: $13 Billion, Yes, but What Took So Long?
description: After weeks of pre-deal chatter about its $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase, the Justice Department finally nailed it down last week. And for the first time, the department provided a glimpse of the investigatory findings upon which the settlement was based.

title: More Stand Your Ground Fantasizing
description: Ohios Republican-controlled Legislature is aiming to enact a Stand Your Ground gun law, despite pleas from urban government leaders that this would only compound the risks in inner-city neighborhoods where gun mayhem hits hardest. The measure, approved by the Ohio House and sent to the Senate, would eliminate the traditional requirement that a person prudently retreat in the face of danger before resorting to deadly force. It would make Ohio the latest of more than a score of other states following the foolhardy lead of Florida  where the first Stand Your Ground law has proved to be rife with risks to public safety and effective law enforcement.

title: The Long Goodbye in Afghanistan
description: From his first campaign for the White House, President Obama has vowed to end more than a decade of war, bring the troops home and put America on a less militaristic footing. He has reduced the forces in Afghanistan from about 100,000 in 2010 to about 47,000 today and has promised that all American and international combat forces will be out by the end of 2014.

title: An Oasis of Groceries
description: CHESTER, Pa.

title: Curing Insomnia to Treat Depression
description: Psychiatrists have long thought that depression causes insomnia, but new research suggests that insomnia can actually precede and contribute to causing depression. The causal link works in both directions. Two small studies have shown that a small amount of cognitive behavioral therapy to treat insomnia, when added to a standard antidepressant pill to treat depression, can make a huge difference in curing both insomnia and depression in many patients. If the results hold up in other studies already underway at major medical centers, this could be the most dramatic advance in treating depression in decades.

title: No Phones on My Plane, Please
description: The new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission wants to review and possibly get rid of the agencys outdated and restrictive rules banning cellphone calls on planes. To which, most travelers would rightly ask: Why?

title: Are Kids Too Coddled?
description: AT a middle school near Boston not long ago, teachers and administrators noticed that children would frequently return from a classmates weekend bar mitzvah with commemorative T-shirts, swag that advertised a party to which many fellow students hadnt been invited.

title: A Growing Chill Between South Korea and Japan Creates Problems for the U.S.
description: TOKYO  In the courtly world of diplomacy, the meeting between Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea was something of a shock.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 24
description: No firm, no matter how profitable, is above the law, and the passage of time is no shield from accountability.

title: Forgotten Killer Among the Korean Erased
description: SEOUL, South Korea  He was one of North Koreas deadliest secret agents.

title: In the Health Law, an Open Door for Entrepreneurs
description: In the weeks since the health insurance marketplaces of the Affordable Care Act went online, a well-publicized ripple of alarm and confusion has permeated the ranks of small-business owners. But less well known is the response of another contingent: newcomers to entrepreneurship who see the legislation as a solution to the often insurmountable expense of getting health insurance. Some even view the Affordable Care Act itself as a business opportunity.

title: Swatting at a Swarm of Public Relations Spam
description: The Haggler typically starts his column with a complaint, and this time its the Hagglers turn to complain. Specifically, the Haggler would like to complain about the complaints hes getting.

title: In Fed Policy, the Exit Music May Be Hard to Hear
description: Is it time for the Federal Reserve to start its exit from the extraordinary set of policies it has pursued over the past few years? That crucial question is on the minds of the nations central bankers, as well as the stock and bond traders who follow the Feds every move.

title: A Bitcoin Puzzle: Heads, Its Excitement. Tails, Its Anxiety.
description: Bitcoin isnt ready for popular consumption, and it may never be.

title: McMansions Are Making a Comeback
description: When the housing bubble burst in 2007, there was a glut of unsold inventory on the market, and the size of newly built homes began to shrink. In both 2008 and 2009, Census Bureau figures show, the median size of a new home was smaller than it had been the previous year. It seemed that after more than a decade of swelling domiciles, the McMansion era was over. But that conclusion may have been premature.

title: Beyond 3-D Printers Magic, Possible Legal Wrangling
description: When reports first appeared that computers could produce three-dimensional objects  from toys to auto parts to household items  it sounded like a page from a science fiction novel.

title: Invasion of the Annual Reviews
description: I dont know many people who look forward to performance evaluations  on the giving or the receiving side.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 24
description: Two stories are vying for the top slot on the Sunday news shows this week  one about the so-called nuclear option in the Senate that would limit filibusters, and the other the nuclear talks between Iran and Western nations. The potential fallout for both issues is equally dominating on the political panels this week, with in-depth discussion from experts on which sides may come out on top.

title: Finding Greener Pastures for a Career
For Chess, a Would-Be White Knight
description: If chess were storytelling, Andrew Paulson would be the undisputed world champion, the Bobby Fischer of raconteurs.

title: Pittsburgh Center Honoring Playwright Finds Itself Short on Visitors and Donors
description: PITTSBURGH  The bank has sued to foreclose. The citys philanthropic groups, with names like Mellon and Heinz, have withdrawn support. The $42 million August Wilson Center for African American Culture, a bow-front building inspired by a Swahili sailing ship, is high and dry.

title: Two Gunshots on a Summer Night
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla.  News of the shooting arrived via police radio as Deputy Debra Maynard and two other officers were sipping late-night coffee at the Hess gas station, a brightly lit outpost on a slumbering stretch of Dixie Highway on St. Augustines south side.

title: Departments Slow to Police Their Own Abusers
description: When the police chief in Tacoma, Wash., shot and killed his wife in a parking lot after years of abusing her, the shock from that event 10 years ago mobilized national support for a more aggressive response to domestic violence in police households.

title: How Black Friday Got Its Start
description: The word black in front of a day of the week has almost never meant anything good.

title: In War for Same-Day Delivery, Racing Madly to Go Last Mile
description: Theres a hot new job in tech: delivery guy.

title: Where Curling Stones Are Born
description: Olympic curling stones come from rare granite quarried on the island of Ailsa Craig, an uninhabited Scottish island. It can be yours for $2.4 million.

title: Hits and Ms.es
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Today we get to play that game we all know and love, Sing Along with Gary and Will.

title: Deals at Climate Meeting Advance Global Effort
description: WARSAW  Two weeks of United Nations climate talks ended Saturday with a pair of last-minute deals keeping alive the hope that a global effort can ward off a ruinous rise in temperatures.

title: Study Suggests Link Between Dread Pirate Roberts and Satoshi Nakamoto
description: Two Israeli computer scientists say they may have uncovered a puzzling financial link between Ross William Ulbricht, the recently arrested operator of the Internet black market known as the Silk Road, and the secretive inventor of bitcoin, the anonymous online currency, used to make Silk Road purchases.

title: Pivotal World Title Game Wasnt the One Played Last
description: Magnus Carlsen was crowned champion of the chess world on Friday after the 10th game in his best-of-12 title series with the defending titleholder, Viswanathan Anand. But it was the previous game that basically clinched it for him.

title: An Unrelenting Crisis
description: At 300,000 one year ago, Syrian refugees now total 2.1 million, and the United Nations predicts their numbers could swell to 3.5 million by the end of the year.

title: Syria Seen as Most Dire Refugee Crisis in a Generation
description: KILIS, Turkey  As the boom of shelling resounded along Turkeys border with Syria here on a recent afternoon, Zakaria Deeb had nowhere left to run.

title: Thousands in Pakistan Protest American Drone Strikes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Thousands of people gathered Saturday in the northwestern city Peshawar to protest American drone strikes inside Pakistani territory and vowed to stop NATO supply trucks unless the attacks stopped.

title: Captain of Seized Greenpeace Ship Speaks From Russia
description: MOSCOW  The Russian commandos who boarded a Greenpeace ship in the Arctic two months ago were coldly professional at first, pointing automatic weapons at terrified crew members and forcing them to kneel.

title: Adrienne Asch, Bioethicist and Pioneer in Disability Studies, Dies at 67
description: Adrienne Asch, an internationally known bioethicist who opposed the use of prenatal testing and abortion to select children free of disabilities, a stance informed partly by her own experience of blindness, died on Nov. 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

title: The Delivery Showdown
description: A business reporter for The Times tests eBays new same-day delivery service.

title: Dont Dare Call the Health Law Redistribution
description: WASHINGTON  Rebecca M. Blank was a top candidate in 2011 to lead President Obamas Council of Economic Advisers, but then the White House turned up something politically dangerous.

title: Are You Sitting Down? On a Couch?
description: If you typically read the Sunday paper on a couch, you might want to move before reading my Sunday column. Your couch probably has flame retardants embedded in the foam, theoretically to prevent fires. In fact, flame retardants dont help much with fire prevention (although they do rack up $5 billion in sales for chemical companies that make flame retardants).

title: Custody Battle Raises Questions About the Rights of Women
description: When Bode Miller, the Olympic ski star known for daring Alpine racing, met Sara A. McKenna in San Diego last year through the high-end matchmaker Kelleher International, they were both professing interest in finding a marriage partner, she recalls.

title: Week 12 Matchup: Cowboys (5-5) at Giants (4-6)
description: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Women in Domestic Slavery Case Lived in a Collective With Suspect, Police Say
description: Two of three women who say they were held as domestic slaves for 30 years in a London home had previously lived in a political collective with a suspect in the case, a police commander leading the investigation said on Saturday.

title: Week 12 Matchup: Jets (5-5) at Ravens (4-6)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Ticket Led by Women Shows Where Democrats Pin Hopes
description: State Senator Leticia Van de Puttes announcement on Saturday that she is running for lieutenant governor, adding a second woman to a ticket led by State Senator Wendy Davis, is enhancing Texas Democrats hopes that they could see their first statewide victory since 1994.

title: What Ethnic Diversity Looks Like: Fort Bend
description: SUGAR LAND  Nikhil Sabharwal of Toronto stood outside a hotel, next to a cart piled with luggage, holding a tall stick decorated with gold garland, a bhangra dance prop from an Indian wedding he had attended here. Steps away, at a coffee shop, a woman wearing a hijab sat near the spot where, minutes earlier, Lynne Gabriel, a fashion blogger of Filipino descent, had posed for photos for her website.

title: A Traditionalist and an Upstart, Both Powerful
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: The Kimbells Stylish, Sustainable New Addition
description: The architect behind the expansion of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth is so famous that his name has been affixed to the project like a brand: the addition, which will be unveiled on Wednesday, is called the Renzo Piano Pavilion.

title: Selling That New-Man Feeling
description: One afternoon a few months ago, a 45-year-old sales representative named Mike called The Dr. Harry Fisch Show, a weekly mens health program on the Howard Stern channel on Sirius XM Radio, where no male medical or sexual issue goes unexplored.

title: Yankees Are Said to Be Near $85 Million Deal for Braves McCann
description: With uncertainty about all their infielders, the Yankees acted Saturday to solidify their catching position, agreeing in principle with Brian McCann on a five-year deal worth more than $82.5 million.

title: Badgers Add to Streak, Shutting Down Rivals
description: MINNEAPOLIS  All week, Minnesota Coach Jerry Kill had warned his players about Wisconsins new-look defense. The 3-4 base installed by the defensive coordinator Dave Aranda, whom the first-year head coach Gary Andersen had brought with him from Utah State, made the Badgers unique in the Big Ten and even more formidable than usual, Kill said.

title: Suspect Charged in Attack on Jewish Man in Brooklyn
description: An attack on a Jewish man in Brooklyn on Friday morning was not connected to the so-called Knockout Game, where assailants try to knock someone out with one punch, a lawyer for the man charged in the case said on Saturday. But prosecutors said the victim heard the suspect, Amrit Marajh, 28, of Brooklyn, and his friends talking about the game. During the altercation, prosecutors said, Mr. Marajh said to the victim, Ill knock you out.

title: West Looms as Knicks Keep Going South
description: WASHINGTON  Coach Mike Woodson spoke with Carmelo Anthony for a few minutes after Fridays practice. There was no great significance to the meeting, according to Woodson, who always looks for opportunities to chat with his players. But with Anthony, who has endured more downs than ups this season, Woodson said he felt it was important just to see where his head was.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: JERICK MCKINNON The Georgia Southern quarterback ran for a late 14-yard touchdown, helping the visiting Eagles stun Florida, 26-20, for the Gators first loss to a Football Championship Subdivision team. McKinnon finished with 125 yards rushing.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 23, 2013
A Step, if Modest, Toward Slowing Irans Weapons Capability
description: WASHINGTON  The interim accord struck with Iran on Sunday interrupts the countrys nuclear progress for the first time in nearly a decade, but requires Iran to make only a modest down payment on the central problem.

title: Sleep Therapy Is Expected to Gain a Wider Role in Depression Treatment
description: An insomnia therapy that scientists just reported could double the effectiveness of depression treatment is not widely available nor particularly well understood by psychiatrists or the public. The American Board of Sleep Medicine has certified just 400 practitioners in the United States to administer it, and they are sparse, even in big cities.

title: Christine Pluta and Jeffrey Glasse
description: Christine Lynn Pluta and Jeffrey David Glasse were married Saturday at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. The Rev. J. Elise Brown, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Tracy Massel, Steven Melzer
description: Tracy Ann Massel and Steven Joshua Melzer are to be married Sunday at the Clubhouse at Patriot Hills, an event space in Stony Point, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan Morgenstern will officiate.

title: William Stubing, Ronald Thomas
description: William Charles Stubing and Ronald Lee Thomas were married Tuesday at the Church of the Transfiguration inManhattan. Canon John G. B. Andrew, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, and the Rev. Andrew R. St. John, an Episcopal bishop and the rector of the church, assisted.

title: Stacey Blanck, Barak Kassutto
description: Dr. Stacey Michelle Blanck and Barak Abraham Kassutto were married Saturday evening at Stokesay Castle, an event space in Reading, Pa. Rabbi Yosef Lipsker officiated.

title: The Face in the Wedding Album
description: Dr. Sara Melissa Schonfeld and Raphael Rabin-Havt were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Alan J. Katz at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J.

title: Rachel Swanson and Darren Ortsman
description: Rachel Lynn Swanson and Darren Ezra Ortsman were married Saturday at the Manhattan Penthouse, an event space. David A. Cohen, a friend of the couple ordained by the Church of Spiritual Humanism, performed a ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions.

title: Natalie Barnett, Brian Pavlock
description: Dr. Natalie Renee Barnett and Brian Mark Pavlock were married Saturday at the Westin Key West Resort and Marina in Key West, Fla. Lawrence Edward Honig, the brides stepfather, who was ordained by the the Open Ministry for the event, officiated.

title: Catching Up After a Little Runaround
description: Jennifer Louise Hayes and Clyde Wilton Lee III were married Saturday at the Westin New Orleans Canal Place. The Rev. Fred Luter Jr., a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Making Time for Wine
description: Dr. Michele Renee Roullet and Dr. Matthew Joseph Bak were married Saturday at the George Washington Masonic National Temple in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Bill Cochran, a minister affiliated with the House Church Network, led a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Emil Stalis, Raymond Stephens III
description: Emil Rolf Stalis and Raymond Weathers Stephens III were married Saturday by the Rev. Zachary Polk Drennen, an Episcopal priest, at the Dacor Bacon House in Washington.

title: Jennifer Ludwig, Vikas Bhatia
description: Jennifer Leigh Ludwig and Vikas Bhatia were married Saturday at St. Pauls Chapel in New York. The Rev. Mark Bozzuti-Jones, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Leora Kessler, Adam Rosenberg
description: Leora Miriam Kessler and Adam Ilan Rosenberg were married Saturday evening at the Plaza in Manhattan. Rabbi Edward L. Schecter officiated, with Cantor Robin A. Joseph participating.

title: Jennifer Lerner, Milton-David November
description: Jennifer Beth Lerner and Milton-David November were married Saturday evening in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Daniel T. Grossman officiated at the Princeton Marriott at Forrestal.

title: Marley Stone, Timothy Bourke
description: Marley Elizabeth Stone and Timothy Mark Bourke were married Saturday by Spencer Slate, a Florida notary and a Coast Guard captain, at the Morada Bay Beach Caf in Islamorada, Fla.

title: Robert Berry and Alejandro Cedeo
description: Robert Joseph Berry and Alejandro Cedeo were married Saturday in Washington. The Rev. John H. Finley IV, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Metropolitan Club of the City of Washington.

title: Rachel Berkowitz, Evan Kreiner
description: Rachel Suzanne Berkowitz, the daughter of Lorrie S. Berkowitz and Dr. Lloyd D. Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Evan Ross Kreiner, the son of Stephanie Kreiner and Dr. Steven Kreiner of Harrisburg, Pa. Rosemary Barkett, a retired judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, officiated at the Eau Palm Beach Resort and Spa in Manalapan, Fla., with Cantor Ann Turnoff taking part.

title: Alexa Silverman and Matthew Siegel
description: Alexa Jordan Silverman and Dr. Matthew Jonathan Siegel were married Saturday at Temple Sinai in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Charles A. Klein performed the ceremony.

title: Embarking on a Shared Journey
description: Nadine Jolie Haobsh and Erik William Courtney were married Saturday at the Montecito Country Club in Santa Barbara, Calif. Allison B. Intondi, a friend of the bride and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Martha Goodwin and Adam Zaentz
description: Martha Rose Goodwin, the daughter of Betsey S. Goodwin and George M. Goodwin of Providence, R.I., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Adam Ross Zaentz, the son of Beth Trafton and Paul Zaentz, both of Alamo, Calif. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Providence.

title: Elisabeth Sacks and William Baker
description: Dr. Elisabeth Jessica Sacks, the daughter of Donna S. Sacks and Stephen Sacks of New York, was married Saturday evening to William Cornell Baker, a son of Julie N. Baker of Cleveland and C. Geoffrey Baker of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. David Cobb, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in New Haven, where he is the rector.

title: Shaky Spartans Hold On to Win Tournament
description: Top-ranked Michigan State looked shaky Saturday but withstood a hot start and a late charge by Oklahoma to dispel any upset fantasies with an 87-76 victory in the championship game of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic at Barclays Center.

title: In a Powerful Comeback, Pacquiao Batters Rios Through 12 Rounds
description: MACAU  Say this for Brandon Rios: he hardly ever backed away.

title: Oklahoma State Ends Baylors Unbeaten Run
description: STILLWATER, Okla.  The snap was low and left of Baylor quarterback Bryce Petty and bounded hard down the frigid field. Cornerback Tyler Patmon finally scooped it up, and as he raced 78 yards for a touchdown, he raised his hand to his face mask, as though hushing any talk that Oklahoma States trouncing of Baylor was an upset.

title: Corrections: November 24, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: In South Korea, Delays Drag a Project to Build Homegrown Fighter Jets
description: SEOUL  Facing the threat of North Korea and feeling squeezed by China and Japan on its flanks, South Korea has always dreamed of a self-reliant defense force.

title: Elders Back Security Pact That Karzai Wont Sign
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An angry President Hamid Karzai, at times openly hostile to his American allies, on Sunday rejected the final recommendation of a four-day Afghan grand assembly that he should promptly sign a security agreement with the United States.

title: Israeli Leaders Denounce Geneva Accord
description: JERUSALEM  Having failed to stop Sundays signing of a nuclear deal between Iran and six Western powers despite a relentless campaign of criticism, Israeli leaders say their mission now is to ensure that, as several put it, this first step is not the last step.

title: Far From My Tree
description: My eldest son is 20 years old, lives in a house crammed with seven scrabbly roommates, works part time in a restaurant kitchen, doesnt drive, is a vegetarian, and has homemade tattoos etched into his thighs.

title: Thousands Protest Ukraines Rejection of Trade Pacts
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Tens of thousands of people marched through downtown Kiev on Sunday to protest the governments decision last week to abandon far-reaching political and free trade agreements with the European Union and instead focus on improving economic ties with Russia.

title: Kerry Defends Nuclear Pact With Iran
description: Secretary of State John Kerry offered a robust defense of the interim nuclear agreement with Iran on Sunday, rejecting comparisons to North Korea and insisting that the deal would make Israel and Persian Gulf allies of the United States more secure, not less so.

title: In Our Pages: November 25
description: 1963: Kennedy Assassin Lee Harvey Oswald Shot Dead

title: Pacquiaos Comeback Inspires Hopes, However Dim, for a Mayweather Bout
description: MACAU  It was Sunday afternoon, maybe two hours after a resounding triumph for Manny Pacquiao, and to Bob Arum of Top Rank Boxing, the landscape brimmed with possibility, more so than usual.

title: Understanding the Deal With Iran
description: Understanding the deal that would temporarily freeze Irans nuclear program.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: earHero Headphones
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: Police in India Plan to Question Editor Over Sexual Assault Accusation
description: NEW DELHI  Police officials from the coastal state of Goa in India were expected to question the magazine editor Tarun Tejpal on Sunday to investigate charges that Mr. Tejpal, a prominent anticorruption crusader, had sexually assaulted a staff journalist in a hotel elevator.

title: Already Anticipating Terminator Ethics
description: ATLANTA  What could possibly go wrong?

title: Swiss Voters Decisively Reject a Measure to Put Limits on Executive Pay
description: FRANKFURT  Despite opinion polls showing widespread dismay about huge executive paychecks, Swiss voters on Sunday rejected severe limits on executive pay.

title: New Cape Town Museum to Focus on Contemporary African Art
description: A new museum that will house the largest collection of contemporary African art on the continent, will open in 2016 in the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront in Cape Town, it was announced last week.

title: Praise in Iran All the Way to the Top, Where Efforts Reportedly Preceded a President
description: TEHRAN  The smiling started early in Tehran on Sunday, when President Hassan Rouhani kissed a young schoolgirl in an Islamic head scarf before dozens of cameras, signaling that Irans future had taken a new turn.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) CAROL BURNETT: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Ms. Burnett, the 16th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, is honored at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in this ceremony, taped Oct. 20. In addition to 11 years as the host and earlobe-tugging star of her CBS variety show, Ms. Burnett, above, has appeared in the films Annie and Noises Off, the television show Glee and the Broadway musical Once Upon a Mattress. She has also written three best sellers, including her autobiography One More Time, and received 12 Peoples Choice Awards, eight Golden Globes, six Emmy Awards, a Horatio Alger Award, a Peabody Award and an Ace Award. She was also given the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President George W. Bush in 2006, was named a Kennedy Center honoree in 2003 and was inducted into the Television Hall of Fame in 1985. Among the friends and colleagues cheering her here are Julie Andrews, Lucie Arnaz, Tony Bennett, Tim Conway, Tina Fey, Rashida Jones, Vicki Lawrence, Amy Poehler, Maya Rudolph, Martin Short and Rosemary Watson. I cant believe Im getting a humor prize from the Kennedy Center, Ms. Burnett said when learned she would receive the distinction. Its almost impossible to be funnier than the people in Washington.

title: If Only the Pants Fit Right
description: The 1975 Canadian movie Lies My Father Told Me was a charmer. A coming-of-age story by Ted Allan, about his early-20th-century poverty-saturated Jewish childhood in Montreal, the film was an Oscar nominee even. And now its a musical.

title: Disruptions: If It Looks Like a Bubble and Floats Like a Bubble
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It sounds like heresy around here. But here goes:

title: Japan Rejects Chinas Claim to Air Rights Over Islands
description: TOKYO  Japans foreign minister on Sunday refused to recognize Chinas newly claimed air defense zone over disputed islands, signaling that Japan would not back down as tensions increased in the maritime dispute.

title: Joint Plan of Action on Irans Nuclear Program
description: Negotiators from Iran, the United States and five other world powers signed an accord early Sunday that would temporarily freeze Irans nuclear program.

title: Longer-Term Deal With Iran Faces Major Challenges
description: LONDON  The Obama administrations successful push for an accord that would temporarily freeze much of Irans nuclear program has cast a spotlight on the more formidable challenge it now confronts in trying to roll the program back.

title: Vettel Adds Brazil to His Winning Streak
description: SO PAULO  The ear-shattering, screaming orchestra of 22 of the worlds most powerful normally-aspirated, 2.4 liter, V8 engines howled around a Formula One racetrack for the last time in competition on Sunday.

title: Patriotic Hold Music
description: Via Josh Marshall: While John Boehner was staging his publicity stunt, supposedly demonstrating that it was impossible to sign up for Obamacare, a representative of the DC health exchange was trying to reach his office to complete the transaction. After 35 minutes on hold, listening to patriotic hold music, the representative gave up.

title: Obama on the Iran Accord
description: President Obama hailed the agreement reached on Nov. 24 between six world powers and Iran on its nuclear program.

title: Bid Farewell to Memories Forever Present
description: Like many an American of a certain age, Barbara Apple found herself on Friday trying to reconstruct exactly what happened on that Friday a half-century earlier when President John F. Kennedy was killed. Her tools of investigation werent copies of the Zapruder tapes or charts that graphed a bullets trajectory.

title: My Lawn Guyland Roots Are Showing (Silly)
description: I see that some commentators were wondering why, in an earlier post, I wrote pedal to the medal instead of pedal to the metal. The answer is, typing fast, and writing what I heard in my head. The truth is that sometimes, usually when Im tired, I do hear myself referring to a bottle of water as a boddle of oo-waugh-duh  gotta get the three-syllable pronunciation there.

title: A Bandleader Pulls Teachable Moments From Afro-Latin Crosscurrents of Jazz
