By way of experiment, she took a few deep breaths and declared herself satisfied. Ive had to sing with way worse stuff on my face, she said.

title: Falstaff Costumes
description: Designing opera costumes in an era of high-tech challenges.

title: The Gun Report: November 27, 2013
description: The gun violence we cover fades from the headlines after a day or two, when were onto the next batch. Here are follow-ups to some notable recent shootings weve covered in the report.

title: Letters: The President and the Press
description: The President and the Press

title: Music of the Season Taking Center Stage
description: All across Long Island this month, the holidays are being rung in with music including rock, pop and classical, at venues both traditional and less so. Here is a sampling of what is around.

title: Art and Technology
description: HOVER FLY and MUSHROOM GILLS By Susumu Nishinaga, Japan

title: A Surge in Value for Bitcoin and Currencies Similar to It
description: This has been quite the week for the peer-to-peer digital currencies. Exactly seven days ago, Bitcoin, the digital cryptocurrency, was trading at about $615, but early Wednesday morning it had passed $1,000 on Mt.Gox, the leading Bitcoin exchange, setting a new high. This pushed Bitcoins market capitalization to over $11 billion.

title: Tom Perrotta: By the Book
description: The author of Little Children, Election and The Leftovers had to force himself to finish Lolita: All that sparkling wordplay just got exhausting after a while.

title: How Long Does It Take to Shelve 23,000 Albums?
description: The biggest record store in New York City, Rough Trade NYC, opened in Williamsburg on Monday. The store carries approximately 23,000 CDs and vinyl records, and it took 20 employees plus various friends and family members 30 hours, over three days, to stock the shelves in time for the stores opening party. Theyve still only stocked about two-thirds of their complete inventory, according to Stephen Godfroy, one of the owners.

title: Grief and Heroism as Survivors Struggle in the Philippines
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Jomar Pascual stirred a steel pot full of instant noodles carefully in a typhoon-damaged former kindergarten building. He had already cooked rice. His three younger brothers and a younger sister, suddenly orphans like him, were hungry, and he began to feed them, spooning the pallid meal onto their green plastic plates.

title: Lorde Reigns at No. 1; Lady Gagas Sales Fall Sharply
description: On the music charts these days, its good to be Eminem. And really good to be Lorde. But not nearly as good to be Lady Gaga.

title: Bryant Alone Cant Carry the Lakers
description: As the architect of the 1990s, six-time champion Chicago Bulls, Jerry Krause was quoted as saying that players and coaches do not win championships; organizations do. Krause insisted he was misquoted because, he said, one word  alone, after championships  had been dropped.

title: Saul Leiter, Photographer Who Captured New Yorks Palette, Dies at 89
description: New York at midcentury was a monochrome town, or so its best-known documentarians would have us believe.

title: Stylishly Smooth, Roughly Edged
description: I dont see enough lights, Jaheim said, strutting across the Theater at Madison Square Garden stage on Tuesday night. I got to do Luther right.

title: In Performance: David Harewood
description: The actor David Harewood in a scene as Oberon from Julie Taymors new production of A Midsummer Nights Dream at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the West Bank, India, Ukraine and Egypt.

title: Always an England
description: Jane Ridleys book is timely in a double sense. When the British edition was released shortly after the 2012 Diamond Jubilee summer, America was still perplexed by the high point of that comically un-summery event as an armada-size flotilla of tugboats and garbage barges (Jon Stewarts sardonic description) passed in hours long chugging convoy down the Thames, rain pelting remorselessly. Saluting on the dank royal barge were the freezing 86-year-old monarch and her nearly 91-year-old consort. The riverbanks were crowded with a million sodden subjects, roaring jubilantly. What, had Americans wondered, was that all about? Ridleys book will go some way toward explaining.

title: The Lure of a Brave New World
description: Since my last post dealt with the problems inherent in the various strategies for resisting modern societys potential drift toward a kind of dystopic, Aldous Huxleyan destination, let me add, as a kind of pre-Thanksgiving coda, an example of how that drift tends to be packaged and sold by people who dont see it as something to be resisted in the first place.

title: Broadway Can Hear the Echoes of Jazz Tap
description: Is great tap dance on Broadway a thing of the past? In one sense, apparently not. After Midnight, the jazz revue that opened at the Brooks Atkinson this month, showcases some of the best, most state-of-the-art tapping presented in a Broadway theater in many a year. Funny thing is, its set in 1932.

title: Another Round in Legal Battle Over Firing at El Museo del Barrio
description: The legal battle continues between Margarita Aguilar and officials at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan after her firing as director of the museum earlier this year and her subsequent claim that she was the victim of gender discrimination and a hostile workplace. The New York State Division of Human Rights dismissed her complaints in September. Ms. Aguilar is now calling for that dismissal to be set aside, citing a shoddy investigation.

title: The Vaccination Effect: 100 Million Cases of Contagious Disease Prevented
description: Vaccination programs for children have prevented more than 100 million cases of serious contagious disease in the United States since 1924, according to a new study published in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Hospital Studies Link Heart Device to Clots
description: Doctors at the Cleveland Clinic began to suspect in 2012 that something might be wrong with a high-tech implant used to treat patients with advanced heart failure like former Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Gender Benders
description: As a new crop of cross-dressing actors appears in drag, a fresh look at some of the best in the genre, then and now.

title: New Romanian Cinema
description: Select images from films in the series at the Film Society of Lincoln center.

title: A Defaced Gap Ad Goes From the Subway to the Web to Its Demise
description: As the New York City-based photographer Robert Gerhardt waited last Sunday for the No. 6 subway train to take him from the Bronx to Manhattan, he spotted a poster from Gaps Make Love ad campaign. It featured a female model and a man wearing the distinctive turban of the Sikh religion.

title: Dim Sum, and Much More, in a No-Frills Setting
description: A friend of mine advised caution when I told him I was visiting Great Wall Restaurant in New Haven, noting the tripe and chicken feet on the menu. In fact, both are delicious, but the restaurant also offers pages of less adventuresome options.

title: A Soldiers Nightmare Follows Her Back Home
description: Charles Fuller tackles a searing subject  sexual assault in the armed forces  in his new play, One Night ..., set in a dingy motel room where two former soldiers have taken refuge after the shelter they were staying in caught fire. With increasing attention being paid to the alarming frequency of rape in the United States military  there are three competing pieces of legislation on the issue being considered by Congress  Mr. Fullers play could hardly be more timely.

title: Discovering the D.J. Caroline Corley, Only to Quickly Lose Her
description: On Monday, as I often do, I tuned into Caroline Corleys morning show on the Peak (107.1 FM in New York) during my commute to work.

title: After 35 Years, They Know Their Fish
description: If the server at P.F. Market says to order the halibut, order it. The staff at this hybrid restaurant and fish market in West Caldwell knows whats good, and happily for fish lovers, many of the 16 or so varieties of seafood available daily are fresher and more flavorful than at many inland restaurants.

title: Yes, Survivals Important. But Then What?
description: People do what they need to do in Sunset Baby, Dominique Morisseaus smart and bracing new play about two generations of urban outlaws struggling to stay afloat in the lower depths. That can mean, among other things, lying to, stealing from, blackmailing and pulling a gun on your nearest and dearest.

title: Zeke Jabbours Game at the Truscott Event
description: The American Contract Bridge Leagues Fall North American Championships get underway in earnest on Friday in Phoenix.

title: Some Still Like It Hot
description: Men in frocks, a tradition as ancient as Aeschylus, has been revived time and again onstage, in clubs and sometimes in the broadest strokes, at the suburban megaplex. Wherever she appears, though, the sight of a burly man compressed in a curve-hugging mermaid gown rarely fails to elicit in audiences a queasy mix of empathy and raucous laughter.

title: Robert Hammond: Leaving the High Life
description: On a Sunday morning in early November, as Robert Hammond was taking one of his last official walks along the High Line, the urban park he helped develop 14 years ago, he was approached by a tall, well-dressed man who seemed to recognize him.

title: Kerry and Zarif Turn to Selling Nuclear Deal to Skeptics Back Home
description: Having finally reached an interim agreement to freeze Irans nuclear program in Geneva on Saturday, Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, turned their attention this week to selling the deal to skeptics back home.

title: Thai Classics in a Spot Known for Them
description: For more than a decade, 25 Main Street has been Thai food central in Kings Park. Bangkok Pavilion, which opened in September, is the latest in a series of Thai restaurants there. This one looks like a keeper.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: In Acid-Attack Trial, Dancers Trade Stage for Stand
description: MOSCOW  Dancers of the Bolshoi Ballet occupied a different stage on Wednesday as a procession of performers took the witness stand to defend the reputation of the troupes artistic director, Sergei Filin, who was the victim of an acid attack and  during the trial of those accused of involvement in the assault  the subject of denunciations by present and former company members.

title: A Textbook Lecture With Tropical Heat
description: Three years ago, Patricia Hoffbauer presented  "Para-Dice (Stage 1) at Danspace Project, as part of a platform called certain difficulties, certain joy.

title: Two New Lawsuits Accuse Manhattan Gallery of Having Sold Fakes
description: The lawsuits keep coming.

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: Overlapping Airspace Claims in the East China Sea
description: On Nov. 23, China declared the rights to the airspace above much of the East China Sea.

title: Pecan Shortage Raises Prices
description: Grocery store prices for pecans are up by 30 percent, which is causing Thanksgiving bakers to think twice about their menus.

title: Times Minute: Nov. 27 at 6 p.m.
description: Online health care sign-up is delayed for small businesses; Silvio Berlusconi is expelled from Italy's Senate; and how to carve a turkey.

title: In Search of the Perfect Holiday Drink
description: Whether youre expecting a handful of holiday drop-ins or hosting a spirited party, a well-made cocktail can set the tone. As restaurants around the county are raising their mixology standards, consider enhancing your home efforts with this advice from behind-the-bar pros.

title: Small Business Health Exchanges Delayed Again
description: With little more than a month before the new year  and many small businesses under pressure to make a decision about health insurance plans for 2014  the Obama administration on Wednesday announced that the federally run small-business health insurance exchanges will not accept online enrollments for another year, until November 2014. It also announced that in the meantime, small businesses can enroll in exchange-listed plans through an insurance agent or broker, or directly with the carrier.

title: Wines for Dessert, or Just for Fun
description: Dessert wines, which accompany all sorts of final dinner courses and sometimes serve as such courses in themselves, are a charming feature of Long Island vintners portfolios.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: A Place in Brooklyn, the Hot Borough
description: Suzanne Cooke bought a large and sunny one-bedroom in the Clinton Hill Co-ops in Brooklyn in 2000. She lived there happily while working in the television field.

title: The Vermeer Road Trip
description: Now, 14 of the 36 known Vermeers can be seen at museums on the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: No Charges for Officers Who Killed Harlem Man
description: A grand jury has decided not to bring charges against police officers involved in the fatal 2012 shooting of Mohamed Bah, a 27-year-old Guinean immigrant who apparently had a mental breakdown and lunged at officers with a knife, the Manhattan district attorney said on Wednesday.

title: Navy Suspends 2nd Contractor After Evidence of Overbilling
description: The Navy said Wednesday that it had suspended a ship-supply company for significantly overcharging on a contract, the second such suspension since mid-September.

title: Sales at Alessi, Lumens and Others
description: Alessi will discount some items by 50 percent on Saturday only (The 24h Sentence Maker clock, right, originally $167, will be about $83); 130 Greene Street (Prince Street), 212-941-7300, and 30 East 60th Street, 212-317-9880, alessi.com.

title: Thanksgiving Day Closings in the Region
description: NEW YORK

title: With an Eye for the Artisanal
description: A week ago Monday, Khen Rinpoche, a Tibetan Buddhist monk, blessed Lisa Foxs new store, LF8, in the East Village. Ms. Fox promotes artisans and designers like Natalie Chanin, whose handmade garments and home goods are sold under the Alabama Chanin label.

title: Dreamscapes Are Made of These
description: Ive always had very vivid dreams, dating back to childhood, said Kristin Victoria Barron, an interior and product designer. I started seeing a Jungian analyst in college because these dreams would stay with me in my waking life.

title: Crackdown in Egypt Fuels New Dissent
description: There were street protests in Egypts two largest cites on Wednesday, amid signs that attempts by the military-backed government to stifle dissent were fueling a backlash.

title: Chandeliers That Like a Little Primping
description: Your chandelier need not be a permanent fixture, but can swing with the times. Michael McHale, a lighting designer, has created the Raw Collection, chandeliers whose looks can be easily transformed. The lights are made of black steel pipes covered with a grid of galvanized steel cable. They can be displayed in their naked form, but they are really meant as platforms for adornment. Festoon them with your own decorations, or buy kits from Mr. McHale. Two are available, with the promise of more to follow: an arrangement of plants ($940) by Matthew David, a floral designer, and a concoction of colorful Plexiglas ($680), below, by an East Village resident known as Billy the Artist. Neither version requires tools to install. The chandeliers will be introduced next week at Design Miami. The fixture is $980; 347-688-0070 or michaelmchaledesigns.com.

title: Well-Appointed Kitchens Have Wish Lists, Too
description: Charlotte and Peter Fiell, a couple who have written many books about international design, are now giving advice about what to buy. They recently published Essential Equipment for the Kitchen: A Sourcebook of the Worlds Best Designs (Goodman Fiell, about $30).

title: Inspector Who Pepper-Sprayed Protesters Is Ordered to Appear Before Panel
description: The police commander whose pepper spraying of several women sparked sharp criticism of the New York Police Departments response to the Occupy Wall Street protests has been ordered to appear before investigators and account for his actions, a state judge has ruled.

title: A Talking Mailbox That Growls
description: The product designer Gauri Nanda, 34, is best known for waking up adults, and now she is giving children their first phones. In 2006, fresh out of M.I.T. graduate school, she introduced Clocky, a wheeled alarm clock that noisily runs away if no one turns it off. More than 600,000 Clockys and their spherical cousins, Tockys, have been sold through her company, Nanda Home. Her latest idea, Toymail, is a line of plastic miniature mailboxes with animal faces. They play messages sent from phones, and children can send recorded replies by pressing simple arrow buttons. Ms. Nanda spoke at her all-white Brooklyn apartment about how she and her co-developer, Audry Hill, finalized the creatures (expected to sell for $55, plus a minimal charge per message) and how young testers for Toymail Co. are reacting. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

title: How Do I Tackle Clutter?
description: Q. I have a small bathroom and end up storing my toiletries on the edge of the tub. How do I tackle the clutter?

title: Gifts With a Twist of Nostalgia
description: In 1966, Hans Harald Rath of the Austrian company J. & L. Lobmeyr traveled to New York to present his design for chandeliers for the Metropolitan Opera House at the new Lincoln Center. The buildings architect, Wallace K. Harrison, rejected the proposal outright.

title: The Masculine Mystique
description: Breakthrough ideas often come from the least expected sources.

title: Vonn Hit a Tricky Turn, Coach Says
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  As Lindsey Vonns teammates trained on the downhill course on Wednesday, new details emerged about the crash that reinjured her right knee on Nov. 19 at Copper Mountain, Colo.

title: Arik Einstein, 74, Beloved Israeli Singer, Dies
description: JERUSALEM  Arik Einstein, an Israeli singer and songwriter whose blend of folk and rock helped shape a new Hebrew popular culture and whose ballads became modern Israeli anthems, died on Nov. 26 in Tel Aviv. He was 74.

title: A Scourge of Crops
description: Millions are being spent on stopping the stink bugs rampage.

title: The Benefits of a Trip to the Museum
Wanted Dead or Alive (No, Just Dead)
description: This Thanksgiving, Ill be thanking the bugs, not the turkeys, for sustaining me in the wilderness. In my case, the wilderness was of the stink-bug variety.

title: A Photo That Shocks
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rustic Haven for a Life Remade
description: Most days, Alison Aldrich walks from her co-op in the West Village to the stately old building on Washington Square Park where she works as a professor at New York University. There, each year, she helps train a few hundred new social workers, many of whom will fan out into the city she has adored since moving here as a 19-year-old newlywed in 1965.

title: Warm Spot for a Late Bloomer
description: Putting privilege and addiction behind her, a former debutante comes out and comes home.

title: Aid for Drone Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Carbon Capture
description: To the Editor:

title: Redistribution, Anyone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Increase Teacher Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: The East China Sea Islands Dispute
Christie Is Said to Waffle on In-State Tuition for People Living in U.S. Illegally
description: During his re-election campaign this year, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey made the Latino vote a priority, hiring a full-time director for Hispanic outreach, opening bilingual campaign offices and securing key Latino endorsements.

title: 3 States End Resistance to Spousal Benefits Order
description: Texas, Oklahoma and West Virginia are now complying with an order from Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel requiring state National Guard units to process federal marriage benefits for same-sex spouses of guardsmen, according to the Department of Defense. Mr. Hagel issued the order  which also extended benefits to same-sex spouses of military service members  after the Supreme Court struck down a law this summer that had prevented federal recognition of same-sex marriages. At one point, nine states had objected to Mr. Hagels order, citing conflicts with state laws that do not recognize gay marriages. As a result, same-sex National Guard spouses in those states could sign up for benefits only by traveling to a federal military installation. As ofWednesday, only Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana were still defying Mr. Hagels order, said a spokesman for the National Guard Bureau in Washington.

title: A Local Bakery That Draws From Afar
description: La Tropezienne in East Harlem offers traditional French baked goods, and its sandwiches are particularly popular with West African cabbies.

title: Retirement Secured for Chimpanzees
description: Its a good Thanksgiving for about 300 research chimpanzees headed for retirement. President Obama signed a bill on Wednesday removing a cap on spending for federally owned chimpanzees in sanctuaries. The change does not involve any budget increase. But it allows the National Institutes of Health to spend money to support the chimps in retirement that would have been used to support them in research labs. The institutes announced in June that the 300 would be retired, leaving only about 50 for potential future research needs.

title: Official Quits in Backlash Over Colorado Gun Vote
description: DENVER  A populist backlash against Colorados new gun-control laws claimed its third political casualty on Wednesday as a Democratic state senator resigned her seat rather than face a recall vote that could have cost her party control of the chamber.

title: French Flavor by the East River
description: The customers at La Tropezienne packed in tightly near the counter on a recent Sunday morning, bundled in coats and gently shouting over one another. Babacar Mbaye, 40, gave an assertive Hello! in order to be noticed. Originally from Gambia, he said he drove his cab to this little bakery and patisserie in East Harlem mainly for the coffee (but also for three croissants: two chocolate, one cinnamon).

title: Illinois Lawmakers Say They Have Plan to Fix Underfunded Pension System
description: CHICAGO  Leaders of the Illinois legislature on Wednesday announced that they had found, at long last, a way to repair the states deeply troubled pension system, which has been deemed among the most underfunded public systems in the nation, has jeopardized the states financial stability and has become a political risk for state leaders.

title: For Fervent Fans of the Dutch Masters, Its a Dream Come True
description: Shin-Ichi Fukuoka, a molecular biologist from Tokyo, really  really  loves Johannes Vermeer. He has traveled around the world to visit 34 of the 36 paintings known or believed to be Vermeers.

title: Thursdays N.F.L. Matchups
description: Packers (5-5-1) at Lions (6-5)

title: Democrats in Alaska Praise Palin
description: Democratic lawmakers remember Gov. Sarah Palins oil-profits taxes and oppose efforts by the Republican-controlled legislature to repeal her tax package.

title: Not for Prime Time: Music Video With Irans President
description: TEHRAN  It might not make MTV, but a music video surfaced Wednesday honoring Irans president, Hassan Rouhani, and showing him alongside musical instruments  which are banned on state television  and women singing.

title: Analyst Says SAC Trader Sought Edgy Information
description: Jon Horvath needed to step up his game at SAC Capital Advisors.

title: Persistence in the Genes: Connecting the Dots to the Mayflower
description: A well-worn potato masher was a tantalizing clue.

title: The Magic of Witch Hazel
description: There is something compelling about a plant flowering in autumns frosty grip, but our native witch hazels magic only begins there. Witch hazel (Hamamelis virginiana) is far better known as a bottled astringent than a native shrub. Its medicinal uses date back to the Native Americans, who taught Europeans how to identify the plant and decoct its leaves and stems into the now-familiar tonic.

title: Moore, Rookie Giants Pass Rusher, Finds It Hard to Break Through
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants took defensive end Damontre Moore with their third pick in this years N.F.L. draft, General Manager Jerry Reese defined Moores worth in three words: He is sacks.

title: Alaska Democrats See a Palin Legacy They Can Like
description: ANCHORAGE  For many Alaskans, Sarah Palin is a figure in the rearview mirror, the memories of her time as governor obscured and distorted by the national spotlight she stepped into as Republican vice-presidential candidate, pundit and Tea Party darling. And often as not the memories come with a grumble anyway, since her shooting-star career mostly took off after leaving the state.

title: The Seeming Resurrection of Comet ISON
description: Updated 5:39p.m., Nov. 29 | After astronomers initially believed Comet ISON had melted away following its close encounter with the sun on Thursday, they had second thoughts on Friday, as we report here.

title: Heres to the Better Angels of the Sports World
description: In a sports year often interrupted by sorrow and scandal, more than ever some deserve a Thanksgiving Day thank-you:

title: Deadly Accident at Stadium Raises Worry on Brazils World Cup Aims
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  At least two workers were killed on Wednesday when a construction crane collapsed at the stadium in So Paulo where Brazil plans to hold the opening game of next years World Cup, raising concerns over the countrys ability to finish an array of lavish arenas that have been plagued by delays and cost overruns.

title: A Part of Utah Built on Coal Wonders What Comes Next
description: PRICE, Utah  For generations, coal has been the lifeblood of this mineral-rich stretch of eastern Utah. Mining families proudly recall all the years they toiled underground. Supply companies line the town streets. Above the road that winds toward the mines, a soot-smudged miner peers out from a billboard with the slogan Coal = Jobs.

title: When the First Hurdle Is Remembering
description: Her memory ravaged by damage done to her brain, Nikkiya Simmonds, 32, returned to an apartment that might as well have belonged to a stranger. It was a cozy dwelling, strewn with cute knickknacks and calming artwork that she was tickled to learn that she had chosen, that she was, indeed, home.

title: Where Is the Love?
description: When Ive written recently about food stamp recipients, the uninsured and prison inmates, Ive had plenty of pushback from readers.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 27, 2013
Secret Weapon in Mall Battle: Parking Apps
description: Phoebe Scott of Orange County, Calif., has a new routine before heading to the mall.

title: Giving Thanks
description: Tuesday morning, I got a call about a girl  now a woman  whom I had gone to grade school with. She was gravely ill. Cancer. It had spread to her brain, I was told. From where, it wasnt clear. She was on life support. By early afternoon her childhood friend and next-door neighbor had posted on Facebook:

title: The Hard Charger at Obamas Side Has His Hands Full
description: WASHINGTON  Denis McDonough was pacing the path on the South Lawn of the White House one day this fall, ruminating on the challenges of a second term for his boss, President Obama. Mr. McDonough, the White House chief of staff, likes to stroll outside from time to time. It helps clear his head when he has a lot on his mind.

title: Doesnt Eat, Doesnt Pray and Doesnt Love
description: The question of whether for-profit companies can claim a religious identity, one that exempts them from obeying a generally applicable law, is fully worthy of the attention the Supreme Court is about to give it. But to the extent that much of the commentary about the challenges to the Affordable Care Acts contraception-coverage insurance mandate frames the issue as a debate about the rights of corporations  as a next step beyond Citizens Uniteds expansion of corporate free speech  I think it misses the point. What really makes these cases so rich, and the reason the courts intervention will dramatically raise the temperature of the current term, lies elsewhere.

title: After Football Players Death, California School Team Wavers, but Carries On
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  When DeAndre Thornton stretched every bit of his angular 6-foot-5 frame to catch a pass over the middle of the field, he could not immediately pull the ball down to protect himself. And so, when the hit arrived, with all the fury a 205-pound opponent with a running start could muster, the crunch of shoulder pads and helmets reverberated beyond the sidelines.

title: Survivors Describe Fights and Fear After Haitian Migrants Boat Ran Aground
description: MIAMI  The Haitians piled onto the rickety vessel with visions of a new life in the United States. But five days into the voyage, the overloaded sailboat packed with 150 people ran aground and quickly broke apart. At least 30 people died in the frigid seas.

title: Chinas Move Puts Airspace in Spotlight
description: Chinas proclamation of a new air defense identification zone, an obscure aviation term that became the catalyst for escalating military tensions with Japan and the United States this week, has thrown a broader spotlight on the control of international airspace, an issue that has created confusion, and danger, in other places affected by territorial disputes.

title: End of an Era in Coal Country, Utah
description: The Carbon Power Plant, the states oldest coal-fired power plant, is set to close by April 2015, a result of new stricter federal pollution regulations.

title: Loving Families, Lousy Meals
description: THANKSGIVING 2013 falls on my mothers birthday, so Ill begin by swearing that she was an excellent, ambitious cook who made her own blintzes, challah, marmalade and fudge. Her cakes were baked from scratch, and she had a repertory of five different custards (plain, rice, coconut, bread and Grape-Nut).

title: Grief, Team Spirit and High School Football
description: The season has been one of raw emotions for Arlington High School in Riverside, Calif., after a football player, Tyler Lewellen, 16, sustained a head injury and later died.

title: Silencing Dissent in Egypt
description: The military-backed government that has ruled Egypt for the past five months is looking increasingly like the old dictatorship of Hosni Mubarak without Mr. Mubarak. In the name of crushing all resistance by the Muslim Brotherhood supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the democratically elected president ousted by the military in July, Egyptian authorities have now moved to ban most public protests and threaten those who take part in them with jail or heavy fines.

title: More Money to Treat AIDS Abroad
description: At a time when partisan bickering has crippled Congress, it is encouraging to find agreement on the important issue of curbing the global AIDS epidemic.

title: The Perils of Polystyrene
description: Every year New York City residents throw away about 20,000 tons of plastic foam containers or, worse, the peanut-shaped packaging filler that sticks to anything in its path. Polystyrene foam is a plague on the environment. It is brittle. It breaks into pieces  sometimes very tiny pieces  that are devilishly hard to pick up. And there is no easy or cheap way to recycle it. New York City officials are considering a ban on foam containers and loose packaging. They should make it happen as soon as possible. Earlier this year the City Council speaker, Christine Quinn, made a pointed case for banning the substance. It lives forever, she said. Its worse than cockroaches.

title: Room at the Table
description: There may be a stranger at dinner today  the friend of a friend, the brother of a daughters roommate, a business acquaintance stuck in town, someone who reminds us how expandable this close-knit holiday really is. And there will surely be someone missing for whom we keep a place set in our thoughts. On Thanksgiving Day, we sit down with the memory of everyone who has shared this holiday with us, and perhaps with an unexpected stranger, the person who helps us tell this one Thanksgiving apart from all the others.

title: During Lions Games, Giving Thanks While Gnashing Teeth
description: DETROIT  On Thanksgiving Day, Darin Idyle will be tailgating in a church parking lot, as he has every Thanksgiving for about a decade. Tim Harry will be bonding in Ford Fields stands with his teenage son. And M. G. Shapiros family knows that his overtime rule is in effect once again  a tie score means he will be late for Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Tony Musante, Actor Known for Role in Toma, Dies at 77
description: Tony Musante, a rugged-looking American actor who was seen on television, in films and on stage in the United States and Europe for over 50 years but who was probably best known for a TV series he left after one season, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Cult Classic
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  This puzzle by Loren Muse Smith (who is making her New York Times debut today) and Jeff Chen is very clever. Even if youre easily squicked out by SNAKES, youre going to like this one. And there are two different ways to look at this answer, as it turns out. Ill talk about how my noncaffeinated brain looked at it first.

title: Mystery of Missing Mushrooms Leaves French Blaming Roma
description: PARIS  Guy Sant is distressed about the sorry state of his mushroom business this year. Usually in the autumn, when the weather turns brisk and the leaves begin to fall, his pickers gather 60 tons of wild fungi to satisfy European consumers, he said. This fall, they found only 16 tons. I lost so much this year, I may have to close, he said bleakly.

title: Late to the Parade
description: Late to the parade.

title: Savoring a Steak
description: CHRISTINE and I had been friends in high school  but only friends. Voted Loveliest Lady at the Coronation Ball, the signature social event of the Class of 1968, she was clearly out of my league. Plus, she already had a boyfriend. Tom was a suave older man of 21 who had graduated to that real world for which we high schoolers were being prepared via the manipulation of our slide rules, the firing up of our Bunsen burners, and our allemande-lefting and do-si-do-ing during the square dancing unit in gym. Two years later, Christine was Toms bride. I was a guest at their wedding.

title: Egypt: 14 Female Protesters Receive 11-Year Sentences
description: A judge in Alexandria on Wednesday sentenced 14 women who participated in an Islamist protest last month to 11 years in prison, the state news media reported. In addition, seven girls ranging from 15 to 17 years old were also sentenced to an indeterminate term at a juvenile facility for joining the protest. The sentences, after an uncommonly swift trial, highlighted the severity of the military-led governments crackdown on Islamists since the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi in July. Also on Wednesday, prosecutors ordered the arrests of two of the best known liberal activists in the country, Ahmed Maher and Alaa Abdel Fattah, for organizing what was called an unauthorized protest.

title: The New Pope's New Direction
Even After a Fortuitous Spill, the Nets See an Opportunity Slip Away
description: The tumbling Nets lost again, but this time, at least, the defeat came through bizarrely entertaining means.

title: Bill Foulkes Dies at 81; Soccer Star Survived Teams Plane Crash
description: The date Feb. 6, 1958, has long haunted the British consciousness. It was then that a plane carrying the Manchester United soccer team crashed while taking off from the Munich airport, killing 23 of 44 passengers, including eight starting players.

title: Behind the Chinese-Pakistani Nuclear Deal
description: The prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, announced this week that China would help build two nuclear power reactors in Karachi, a port city with chronic electricity shortages. The deal marks a big step in nuclear energy cooperation between China and Pakistan, but financing and other important parts of the project have yet to be settled. Here is an explanation:

title: The Hague: Eased Rules May Affect Trials of 2 Kenyans
description: Member states of the International Criminal Court eased the trial rules on Wednesday in ways that could enable Kenyas two top leaders, facing prosecution on charges that include crimes against humanity, to avoid personal appearances and even miss parts of the proceedings against them, news agencies reported. The changes, which apply to suspects who hold high office, had been strongly advocated by Kenya and other African members that have criticized what they call the courts unfair focus on prosecuting African political figures. President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto, have pleaded not guilty to charges that they were responsible for deadly violence after the 2007 elections. They have also asserted that the trials interfere with their ability to govern Kenya. Mr. Rutos trial has begun, and Mr. Kenyattas is scheduled to begin in February.

title: Victorian Style Makes a Comeback
description: The Victorian aesthetic  high collars, leg-o-mutton sleeves, pearl trim  is having a renaissance. In the modern interpretation, minimalism is key and military references abound. Metallics are often paired with black so that they pop  as in the oversize brass buttons on a slim Balmain topcoat; the gold hardware on a simple Dolce & Gabbana bag and a Givenchy belt; and the trim around a dainty Phoebe Coleman lacquered pinkie ring. The ornate decoration of a simple Erdem skirt and round Monica Rich Kosann earrings are the essence of restrained elegance. Lace-up booties by Tabitha Simmons and a crown-shaped pendant necklace by Katie Mullally offer especially Anglophilic takes on the trend.

title: 4 Hit and Killed by Cars in New York City
description: Four people were hit by cars and killed across the city on Wednesday, including two women who were hit by a single vehicle while crossing the street on Staten Island, the police said. The circumstances of each of the crashes were still under investigation as of midnight on Thursday. No one was immediately charged with a crime.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 9 A.M. (NBC) MACYS THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE Matt Lauer, Al Roker and Savannah Guthrie host this 87th installment of the parade, with appearances by the Big Apple Circus; Kristin Chenoweth; the Cherokee National Youth Choir; Cirque du Soleil, Gavin DeGraw; Brett Eldredge; Fall Out Boy; Jimmy Fallon; Kellie Pickler; the Roots with the cast of Sesame Street; Florida Georgia Line; Megan Hilty; Joan Jett and the Blackhearts; Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings; Miss America 2014, Nina Davuluri; the retired N.F.L. players Bart Oates, Amani Toomer and Hines Ward; the retired N.H.L. players Cam Neely and Mike Richter; the Robertson family from Duck Dynasty; and the Radio City Rockettes. The casts of the Broadway shows Matilda and Motown: The Musical perform. So does Carrie Underwood, in her role as Maria in The Sound of Music Live!, next Thursday on NBC. Soaring above it all, weather permitting: Spider-Man; a 47-foot-tall balloon featuring portraits of characters from The Wizard of Oz and carrying the Wizard himself, in anticipation of the films 75th anniversary next year; Snoopy and Woodstock, in a 40th-anniversary tribute to A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving; and a spinning dreidel to celebrate Hanukkah.

title: A Second Career as a Pastor, Schooled by the Homeless
description: The airplane that crashed had been heading to Greenville, S.C., where I was a reporter.

title: The Art of the Carve
description: In 2007, The Times asked Ray Venezia, a butcher and then the head of the meat department at Fairway Market, to demonstrate how to carve a Thanksgiving turkey.

title: Yao Ming on Third Year as a College Student
description: On class days, Yao Ming, the 7-foot-6 retired N.B.A. center, wakes up at the crack of dawn to beat the Shanghai traffic. Carrying a lunch prepared by his wife, Ye Li, a 6-foot-3 former player in Chinas professional league, Mr. Yao drives more than an hour to Jiao Tong University, where he sits through his required courses in the economics and management department. According to one Chinese news report, Mr. Yao would prefer to live in the dorms with his 20-year-old classmates, a move that would save time and energy, but the beds are too small.

title: Managing Editor of Newsmagazine Resigns Amid Sexual Assault Controversy
description: NEW DELHI  The managing editor of the newsmagazine Tehelka, whose editor in chief has been charged in the sexual assault of a junior reporter, resigned Thursday morning in an email to the staff, citing the growing controversy over her handling of the initial complaint.

title: Corrections: November 28, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: No Solutions in Sight, Knicks Lose Seventh Straight
description: LOS ANGELES  J.R. Smith flew across the lane, the back of his untucked jersey flapping behind him. He was determined to do something Wednesday night to salvage the Knicks fourth-quarter hopes, and it came in the form of a flat-footed lob that the Clippers DeAndre Jordan batted away as soon as it left Smiths hand.

title: Happy Thanksgiving
description: Were taking a brief break, until Monday, but we leave you with some reminders from Kid President, as well as a few ideas of our own:

title: Protest This!
description: CAIRO  On Monday evening, Mohammed Adel, of the April 6 Youth Movement, and Ali Esam, of the liberal Constitution Party, headed to the Kasr El Nil police station, a pink stucco villa on a leafy side street in central Cairo. They came bearing an official request to hold a protest  against a protest law promulgated just the day before.

title: Corruption Scandal Hits One of Chinas Top Universities
description: Renmin University of China, in Beijing, one of the leading centers of higher learning in the country, conferred its first degrees this year in a new graduate program in combating corruption. Future classes now have a case study close to home to draw from.

title: The Quest to Belong
description: With a grandchild about to be born in Atlanta, another on the way in Ho Chi Minh City, I have been thinking about the beginning of the family odyssey; of my great-grandfather, Isaac Michel, and his decision to leave the shtetl in northern Lithuania and head south from Russian pogroms toward the sun, the ostrich feathers, the gold and the promise of South Africa.

title: Thailands Premier Survives Vote as Protests Continue
description: BANGKOK  Ignoring Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatras victory in a parliamentary no-confidence vote, protesters in Thailand continued their campaign to shut down government offices, cutting power on Thursday to Bangkoks police headquarters.

title: China Patrols Air Zone Over Disputed Islands
description: BEIJING  China sent fighter jets on the first patrols of its new air defense zone over disputed islands in the East China Sea on Thursday, the state news agency, Xinhua, said.

title: Julia Mancuso Carves Her Path in Lindsey Vonns Shadow
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Minutes after watching a helicopter pluck her injured teammate Lindsey Vonn from the super-G track at the Alpine world championships in Schladming, Austria, in February, Julia Mancuso raced down a foggy course to a third-place finish.

title: Other Great Moments in Eating Fish Alone
description: Of the 11 films featured in this weeks Movies Issue, my hands-down favorite is Cate Blanchetts fantastic exchange with a plate of fish, directed by Janusz Kaminski. When I watched it with my spouse at home, it reminded him of a poem by Billy Collins.

title: A Not-So-Festive Season
description: When Zhang Xuyan accepted his cushy entry-level position at a major state-owned enterprise, the salary was not the main draw. Instead it was the unofficial benefits that lured him in: networking opportunities, close proximity to senior Communist Party members and, last but not least, the banquets and luxury gifts that the company regularly showered on its employees.

title: How to Start a Year-Round Family Gratitude Ritual
description: Sometime this Thanksgiving or in the coming weeks, you and yours will probably share notes on the things for which youre thankful.

title: Ignore Karzais Arrogant Insults
description: WASHINGTON  What is going on with President Hamid Karzai? The worlds only superpower, leading a coalition of some 50 nations, is willing to stay on in his country after a war that has already lasted a dozen years and cost the United States more than $600 billion and more than 2,000 fatalities  and yet the Afghan president keeps throwing up roadblocks.

title: Andhra Pradesh Heaves Sigh of Relief as Cyclone Lehar Becomes Deep Depression
description: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh  Cyclone Lehar weakened to a deep depression over the Bay of Bengal on Thursday, to the relief of Andhra Pradesh disaster management officials, but the storm is still expected to bring heavy rain that could add to the damage caused by two previous cyclones over the past eight weeks.

title: In Performance: David Harewood
description: In Julie Taymors new production of A Midsummer Nights Dream, David Harewood plays Oberon, the king of fairies, who is quarreling with his wife, the fairy queen Titania. In this scene he talks with the fairy Puck about a plan to make Titania full of hateful fantasies by having Puck apply the juice of a magic flower to her eyes so she falls in love with the first thing she sees when she wakes up.

title: Linking Genes to Diseases by Sifting Through Electronic Medical Records
description: The days of scrawled doctors notes are slowly coming to a close. In the United States, 93 percent of hospitals are now using at least some electronic medical records and 2.2 percent have given up paper records completely, according to the consulting firm HIMSS Analytics.

title: Giving Musical Thanks on Thanksgiving
description: On Thanksgiving (and Hannukah), heres a quick note  and song  of thanks to you for reading this blog, for attending to the issues and opportunities facing humanity as we come of age on a finite planet and, for those who comment here, trying to maintain a constructive approach.

title: Balloons Fly Low, but Parade Delights
description: To the joy of children and the relief of parents endlessly checking the weather report and bracing for their little ones dashed hopes, New York officials gave the giant balloons the all-clear Thursday morning to fly in the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: T HOLIDAY
description: Evening sandals merge comfort with festiveness, and add a wink of hauteur without the heel.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Virginia Johnson Pouch
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: A Thanksgivukkah Song
description: Dear Diary:

title: UBS Consolidates, and Shifts Executives, in Effort to Shrink Its Investment Bank
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank UBS is combining its currency, interest rates and credit trading businesses into one unit, according to a memo circulated at the bank earlier this month.

title: Image of the Day: November 28
Insert Homeless Headline Here
description: You can call this post: Dont Let Them Eat Cake. Or, Let Them Eat Cake Somewhere Else. Or Hide the Cake Altogether.

title: U.N. Nuclear Inspectors Invited to Iranian Facility
description: LONDON  Days after Iran struck a landmark accord with world powers on its nuclear program, the International Atomic Energy Agency announced on Thursday that Tehran had invited its inspectors to visit a heavy-water production plant linked to the deal  the first tangible step since the agreement was concluded.

title: Getting the Volcker Rule Done
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: E.U. Eases Rules on Liquids on Planes
description: The European Union will begin lifting restrictions on liquids, aerosols and gels at airports in its 28 member countries in phases, beginning in January, with the goal of completely eliminating the ban by January 2016. What is happening in January is a small first step, Dale Kidd, press officer for Transport at the European Commission in Brussels, said in a telephone interview.

title: Europe vs. Amazon: Anger Rising
description: On its home territory, Amazon.com is routinely hailed as a jobs machine. Thanks to its warehouse building spree, it is hiring tens of thousands of workers, plus many more for the holidays. President Obama, speaking at the retailers Chattanooga, Tenn., warehouse in July, called Amazon a great example of whats possible.

title: A Scientist Predicts the Future
description: When making predictions, I have two criteria: the laws of physics must be obeyed and prototypes must exist that demonstrate proof of principle. Ive interviewed more than 300 of the worlds top scientists, and many allowed me into laboratories where they are inventing the future. Their accomplishments and dreams are eye-opening. From my conversations with them, heres a glimpse of what to expect in the coming decades:

title: In Our Pages: November 29
description: 1913: Rebels Destroy Ciudad Victoria

title: Orange to Sell Dominican Telecom Business
description: LONDON  The French telecommunications company Orange has reached an agreement to sell its Dominican Republic operations to the Luxembourg cable and broadband provider Altice for $1.4 billion.

title: Once for Women Only, Georgian Court Looks to Mens Teams to Raise Profile
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J.  Luka Zgonjanin arrived in the United States from Serbia in August, barely able to speak English. He had accepted a scholarship to play basketball at Georgian Court, a small liberal arts university on the outskirts of the Jersey Shore. A few months earlier, he had never heard of the college.

title: 36 Hours in Shanghai
description: What takes most cities eons to build, Shanghai can do overnight. Consider this: Just a decade ago, the city had four metro lines; now there are a dozen. The Jin Mao Tower was the tallest building in the neon-streaked financial center of Pudong; it has since been surpassed by the Shanghai World Financial Center and the nearly completed Shanghai Tower, which will be the second-tallest building in the world (after Dubais Burj Khalifa) when its finished next year. Still, what fascinates about this city is how little seems to have changed in the maze of lanes that have (thus far) eluded the bulldozer in the Old City or the former foreign concessions. Here, residents haggle over freshly caught fish in tiny markets or doze in lawn chairs on summer afternoons, ignoring the pounding jackhammers. Shanghai is remaking itself to become a City of the Future, but whats so alluring is how much old-world character remains.

title: In Cyprus, a New Spirit Animates the Capital
description: Europes last divided capital, Nicosia, Cyprus, is experiencing a renaissance with more and more venues catering to the artistic set. No longer wary of the demilitarized United Nations Buffer Zone that bisects the ancient walled city between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot sides, young Nicosians have reclaimed their old town. Emboldened by falling real estate prices, arty cafes, boutiques celebrating homegrown fashion and buzzy restaurants have opened among the Venetian fortifications and Byzantine churches on the Greek side. While beachgoers have long flocked to the coasts, the rebirth of the inland capital is evidence of a historic city in transition.

title: Who Was Rick of Ricks Place in Prospect Park?
description: Q. On a hill near the Midwood in Prospect Park, an old sign says Ricks Place, without any elaboration. I am a Rick, but not that Rick. Who was the Rick of Ricks Place, and why is this place named after him?

title: On Beauty | A London Spa That Is One With Nature
description: Each of the four areas of the David Chipperfield-designed Akasha Holistic Wellbeing Centre, opening on Dec. 9 in Londons Caf Royal hotel  a favorite among the likes of Miuccia Prada and LWren Scott  corresponds to a natural element: water (Watsu pool), fire (Canadian hemlock saunas), air (personalized yoga) and earth (a food bar that serves Champagne).

title: Fighting Rooster Returns to Ensemble Studio Theater
description: Odysseus Rex the Rooster is back. The Year of the Rooster, the critically lauded play about cockfighting by the 25-year-old playwright Eric Dufault, featuring Bobby Moreno as the central gladiatorial bird, will return to the Ensemble Studio Theater for a four-week run, Jan. 9 through Feb. 2, after a run this fall that Neil Genzlinger writing in The Times called astonishingly entertaining.

title: The World in a Toothpick
description: Impatience is anathema to a toothpick artist, and Steven J. Backman was inoculated against it in second grade when he smashed one of his figures, a molecular model, in frustration, impaling his hand.

title: Medicaid Growth Could Aggravate Doctor Shortage
description: SAN DIEGO  Dr. Ted Mazer is one of the few ear, nose and throat specialists in this region who treat low-income people on Medicaid, so many of his patients travel long distances to see him.

title: South Carolina Threatens Washington Over Cleanup
description: AIKEN, S.C.  The Energy Department began cleaning up an environmental nightmare at the old Savannah River Site nuclear weapons plant here in 1996 and promised a bright future: Within a quarter-century, officials said, they would turn liquid radioactive bomb waste into a solid that could not spill or dissolve.

title: Slowdown in Radioactive Waste Cleanup
description: Officials in South Carolina say the federal government has not met its promise to clean up waste at the old Savannah River Site nuclear weapons plant.

title: A White House Menu, Heavy on the Pies
description: President Obama and his family will have a traditional Thanksgiving meal this holiday, enjoying a menu that will look familiar to many American families: Turkey, ham, stuffing and plenty on the side. Whats remarkable is the dessert menu: the number of pies rivals the number of dishes in the dinner menu itself.

title: Reclaiming Label of a Progressive City
description: If youre terrified, or merely curious, about Bill de Blasios mayoral agenda, then read Toward a 21st Century City for All: Progressive Policies for New York City in 2013 and Beyond, edited by John H. Mollenkopf (City University of New York).

title: The Birth of Thanksgiving
description: Though we most often associate Thanksgiving with Pilgrims and New England Indians, the holiday, at least as an official national event, began 150 years ago, at the height of the Civil War.

title: Taking Flight
description: Balloons floated down the route of the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade after an early scare they might be grounded because of high winds.

title: Feeling For | Decorative Hair Ornaments That Are Perfect for the Holidays
description: Sparkle this holiday season with golden clips, combs and pins that add a flash of decorative romance and make styling a breeze.

title: Salinger Stories  Leaked Online
description: Three previously unpublished short stories by J. D. Salinger have appeared online for the first time, apparently after an unauthorized edition of the stories was sold on eBay and its pages scanned and uploaded, Buzzfeed reported.

title: Ready for Some Football. A Lot of It.
description: What I do on a Sunday impacts what a lot of other people do on a Sunday, said Brian Schwartz, the C.E.O. and co-founder of DraftStreet, a daily online fantasy sports site. Mr. Schwartz, who is 30 and lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan with his wife, Jaime, their year-old daughter, Liv, and a pet puggle, Bascom, wasnt being arrogant; he was being accurate. Since it started in 2010, DraftStreet has acquired more than 350,000 users, he said. Most of them visit the site on Sundays during football season, which tend  at least in part  to be workdays for Mr. Schwartz. The company has its Fantasy Football Championship on Dec. 15.

title: Renaissance and Baroque Bronzes at the Frick
description: BAROQUE AND MODERN,

title: At Large in the Kingdom of Dreams
description: THE SANDMAN OMNIBUS

title: A Film Nudge to Find the Folkie in You
description: Inside Llewyn Davis, the Coen brothers film set among Greenwich Village musicians in the early 1960s, is poised to generate a tidal wave of nostalgia  and stir interest among moviegoers who were unfamiliar with this milieu. Its a safe bet that anyone who sees the film (opening next Friday) will want to know more about the folkie world that the Coens recreate so wittily and well. There are great ways to read, see and hear more about it.

title: Theyre Already Boxed, Now Just Wrap
description: DEEP catalog keeps getting deeper in the annual outpouring of boxed sets. The latest collections are less likely to be anthologies of hits  thats been done  than plunges into the archives. Superstars are represented by alternate versions, outtakes, live tracks, remixes and official versions of long-bootlegged material. Unknowns, meanwhile, get a new hearing, as compilers and collectors work through the holdings of ever more obscure labels and producers. Annotators, for their part, piece together stories, and art directors enjoy creating packages larger than a CD case. Here, the critics of The New York Times delve into the years notable boxed sets. Prices may vary, depending on where the purchase is made.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Holden Caulfield Redux
description: The Goldfinch, Donna Tartts third novel in 20 years, set in an opaquely rendered Manhattan of the 21st century, has followed its predecessors, selling robustly, while its eponym, a 1654 painting by Carel Fabritius, has been drawing crowds to the Frick. In an apparently serendipitous feat of cross-promotion, the painting currently appears at the museum as part of an exhibition of Dutch masterworks from the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis in The Hague, a show that has drawn more than 61,000 visitors since its debut in October.

title: William Kentridge: The Refusal of Time
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Through May 11

title: William Eggleston: At Zenith
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Surrealism and the Rue Blomet
description: Eykyn Maclean

title: Vietnam in Photos
description: Steven Kasher Gallery

title: Jill Magid: Woman With Sombrero
description: Art in General

title: Jacob Kassay: IJK
description: 303 Gallery

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop & Rock Music Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Life on $7.25 an Hour
description: On a recent Friday evening, Eduardo Shoy left work at 6 p.m. Mr. Shoy, a deliveryman for KFC and Pizza Hut, was coming off an eight-hour shift of driving three-cheese pies and crispy chicken fingers, in an automotive blur, to private homes and businesses in central Queens.

title: A Star, More Than Just a Voice, Is Back Onstage With Her Magnetism Intact
description: It wasnt just a club date and the start of a tour; it was also a video shoot. When Lauryn Hill performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night, the camera swiveling over the heads of the audience suggested that the show was something more than Ms. Hills re-emergence after her recent three-month jail term for failing to file taxes. It was gathering the kind of material performers use to promote new releases  which, in Ms. Hills case, would be more than welcome.

title: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: A Dogs Life: A Rowlf Retrospective

title: The High Road Through a Struggle Is Never Easy to Navigate
description: Hard moral decisions weigh heavily. And in Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom, Justin Chadwicks stately screen biography of Nelson Mandela, the British actor Idris Elba conveys the agony as well as the nobility of Mr. Mandelas quest for South African racial equality. Much of that pain is suppressed rage at the cruelty and injustice of apartheid. As Mr. Mandela looks beyond the fury of the moment and calculates the cost of urging violence, you sense his frustration at having to make the only reasonable choice and taking the high road.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Holiday Lighting Displays(Friday through Thursday) Switches will be flipped  or oil lamps lit  in the coming week for Hanukkah and Christmas displays. Since 1977, the Lubavitch Youth Organization has sponsored the lighting of a menorah at Grand Army Plaza, at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. The menorah will be lit at various times daily through Thursday. An outdoor party accompanying Sundays lighting, at 5:30 p.m., will feature music, dancing and latkes. More information: (718) 953-1000.

title: Russia Charges Ex-Defense Minister Over a Road Project
description: MOSCOW  Russian investigators on Thursday charged a former minister of defense, Anatoly E. Serdyukov, with negligence for ordering the Russian military to build a road from a village to a private country residence in the south.

title: Among Rich Twits, Back in the Day
description: Somehow its comforting to know that silly rich people were ever thus.

title: A New Orleans-Inflected Style Puts Some Macho in the Standards Sweet Talk
description: Aw, shucks, folks. That describes the attitude Steve Tyrell imparts to everything he sings. In his ninth holiday season show at Caf Carlyle, Wordsmiths: Lyricists of the Great American Song, he brings an unwavering tone of genial bonhomie to standards by the Gershwins, Rodgers and Hart, Cole Porter and others.

title: One Isnt Like the Other, and That May be the Point
description: Congenial vocal chemistry is where you find it, and sometimes unlikely couples like Tanya Holt, a sultry pop-soul singer, and Marcus Simeone, a hyper-emotional tenor, who performed together at the Metropolitan Room on Saturday evening, have it. The title of their show, Quiet Storm, refers to the simmering romantic radio format first popularized in the mid-1970s. Adapted for cabaret, it embraces everything from Motown to West Side Story to Anita Baker.

title: Britain Reconsiders Cigarette Regulation
description: LONDON  Until recently, the British government appeared to be on the verge of rejecting sweeping restrictions on cigarette packaging. But on Thursday it changed course, announcing a policy review that could lead to curbs on labeling and require the use of neutral colors on packages.

title: To Cool Housing Market, Britain Curtails Loan Help
description: LONDON  In a surprise step aimed at keeping Britains housing market from overheating, the Bank of England on Thursday scaled back a government program that encouraged mortgage lending.

title: After Years of Famine, Lions Have Fall Feast
description: DETROIT  The Thanksgiving Day football game is always marked on the calendar long in advance by fans here, and with hope. But over the last 10 years, the Detroit Lions could not deliver a win, often losing in heartbreaking or spectacular fashion.

title: Holiday Movie or Music Video?
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Daughters Look for a Mother Lost to the Mexican Military
description: EL PASO  Mitzi and Nitza Alvarado Espinoza wear different colors at news conferences, their lawyer says, so people can tell them apart as they talk about their missing mother and the group they have formed to help others in their situation. The Alvarados, 18, are identical twins.

title: A Lo-Fi Idol, Fondly Considered
description: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

title: For Democrats, Luring Voters Is the Challenge
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: If Buses on MoPac Go Faster, More People Will Ride (Maybe)
description: In 2015, an 11-mile stretch of MoPac Boulevard in Austin will expand to eight lanes from six. The two new lanes will require tolls, and drivers will be able to pay a premium to avoid frequent congestion.

title: Build a Beach, Rinse, Repeat
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: A Growth Spurt for Middle Eastern Carriers, Led by Emirates
description: There is little doubting the ambitions of the giant Middle Eastern airlines, but recent large plane orders demonstrated just how aggressively these carriers plan to compete in coming years.

title: When an Adoption Doesnt Work Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Dreaming of a Future Beyond Fossil Fuels
description: To the Editor:

title: Albanians and Serbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Caution on Education
description: To the Editor:

title: The Health Care Rollout
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bison Centennial
description: The year 1913 was a good one for American bison  one of the first good years for bison since the early 19th century. In February, the new buffalo nickel was introduced. And on Nov. 25, two railroad express cars loaded with 14 bison left the New York Zoological Park, now called the Bronx Zoo, for the town of Hot Springs in the Black Hills of South Dakota. On the 28th, the bison were taken overland in their crates 11 more miles and released onto native grassland.

title: The Power of Cigarette Warning Labels
description: A provocative new study has suggested that the Food and Drug Administration greatly underestimated how much graphic warning labels on cigarette packs reduced the rate of smoking among Canadians. As a result, the study says, the F.D.A. vastly underestimated the impact such warnings would have in the United States.

title: Ukraine Backs Down
description: It is difficult to sympathize in any way with Ukraines corrupt and cynical president, Viktor Yanukovich, but the choice before him was indeed nasty. To sign an association and free-trade agreement with the European Union was to invite brutal Russian economic punishment, which Ukraines badly suffering economy is in no shape to absorb. Europe could only offer medium- to long-term advantages. Not signing, however, inevitably meant protests in Ukraine, whose population has consistently expressed support for European integration. Sure enough, tens of thousands of Ukrainians took to the streets as soon as their government announced last week that it was suspending negotiations with the European Union.

title: Government in Slow Motion
description: Last week, in a fit of fury after they lost the ability to filibuster President Obamas nominees, several Congressional Republicans threatened to retaliate by slowing things down on Capitol Hill. Democrats will have trouble in a lot of areas because theres going to be a lot of anger, said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, specifically warning that a United Nations disability treaty was now in danger of being rejected for the second time.

title: A Long Walk for Glaciers
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Rooting for Failure
description: I just spent 15 minutes on my local health care exchange and realized that I could save a couple hundred dollars a month on my familys insurance. Of course, I live in Washington State, which has a very competitive market, a superbly functioning website and no Koch-brothers-sponsored saboteurs trying to discourage people from getting health care.

title: The Many Shapes of Time
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Mighty Love, and Mighty Anger, in a Night of Song
description: I Got Thunder (and it Rings), a proudly self-assertive anthem written by Abbey Lincoln and belted by Baby Jane Dexter in her new show, More Rules of the Road, at the Metropolitan Room, distills the resilient spirit of this venerable cabaret singer. Love is an emotion, and it moves things, announces the chorus of a song whose opening verse warns the faint of heart, better run when I start coming. Applying her formidable contralto to the song, Ms. Dexter tosses thunderbolts, but they wont hurt you; their big, crashing sound is driven by a big heart.

title: Mortgages Without Risk, at Least for the Banks
description: There was no single cause of the financial crisis, but a chief one was surely the way mortgage loans were made by people who believed they had no reason to care if the loan was repaid.

title: GTT
description: DALLAS

title: Flynns Encore Features Little to Applaud
description: DETROIT  To most of the N.F.L., Matt Flynn is just another journeyman quarterback, moving from team to team, starting a game here and there. His name hardly signals fear.

title: Shop First, and Eat Later
description: Before most Thanksgiving turkeys even approached the oven on Thursday, a small line of tents had formed in front of a Best Buy in Falls Church, Va., their inhabitants waiting for the holiday deals to begin. First in line was William Ignacio, who pitched his tent at 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

title: Afghan Leader Lashes Out at U.S. Allies After NATO Drone Strike
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai lashed out at his American allies again on Thursday after word came that at least one, and possibly two, NATO drone strikes had killed civilians in southern Afghanistan.

title: B. Altman, a Store From Yesteryear, Still Makes Its Presence Felt in the City
description: There was a time when shoppers would crowd into B. Altman & Company on the Friday after Thanksgiving. That imposing Fifth Avenue department store still had a certain specialness as it aged gracefully, perhaps too gracefully  by the 1970s, it seemed almost fusty. And then, after a listless going-out-of-business sale that began on the day after Thanksgiving in 1989, it closed.

title: Photographs Tell a History of Palestinians Unmoored
description: JERUSALEM  There is one picture of Palestinian children studying around a small table by the dim light of gas lamps in the Beach Camp in Gaza, and another of children peeking over a sandy dune, with rows of small, uniform shacks of a desolate refugee camp in the background. In a third, a family walks across the Allenby Bridge, the father carrying two bulging suitcases, a young son clutching a white ball, heading east over the Jordan River.

title: Two Marilyns, Six Scotches and 20 Hamburger Toppings
description: Can it be time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, the media and popular culture? (O.K., that one was free.)

title: Despite Filibuster Limits, a Door Remains Open to Block Judge Nominees
description: WASHINGTON  The decision by Senate Democrats to eliminate filibusters for most judicial nominations only marginally enhanced President Obamas power to reshape the judiciary, according to court watchers from across the political spectrum, because Republican senators can still veto his nominees to most currently vacant appeals court seats.

title: Paper Tying Rat Cancer to Herbicide Is Retracted
description: A food safety journal has decided to retract a paper that seemed to show that genetically modified corn and the herbicide Roundup can cause cancer and premature death in rats.

title: How Will AIDS Be Eradicated?
Russia: Court Grants Bail to Last Detainee in Greenpeace Case
description: The last of the 30 people on board the Greenpeace International ship seized in September after a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic was granted bail on Thursday. A court in St. Petersburg had initially ordered the crew member, Colin Russell of Australia, held for 90 more days, even as the others were released on bail of roughly $60,000 each. The foreign crew members, from 17 countries, are now required to remain in St. Petersburg as the investigation on charges of hooliganism continues.

title: Russian-Backed Free-Trade Zone May Expand Its Borders
description: MOSCOW  Today, a train car loaded with coal in Kazakhstan can rumble thousands of miles across the Eurasian steppes to a factory in Belarus, all without once clearing customs.

title: Week 13 N.F.L. Matchups: Browns Try Going Back to the Future
description: Jaguars (2-9) at Browns (4-7)

title: Reporting on Motorcycle Clubs
description: Serge Kovaleski of The New York Times shares anecdotes from his reporting on motorcycle clubs around the country, including the Hells Angels.

title: Syrian Forces Press Rebels With Gains
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian government forces battling alongside fighters from the Lebanon-based Hezbollah have nearly broken the rebels hold on a strategic region north of the capital, Damascus, Syrian state news media and opposition activists said Thursday.

title: On Registers Other Side, Little to Spend
description: In many stores around the country, the workers stocking the shelves and ringing up the gifts are at the very heart of this seasons retail lament many Americans are so financially strapped that projections for holiday sales have grown bleaker by the week.

title: Law Limiting Plastic Guns Set to Expire
description: WASHINGTON  In the movie In the Line of Fire, a deranged killer smuggles a homemade gun past the Secret Service and tries, unsuccessfully, to shoot the president.

title: Disillusionment Grows Among Syrian Opposition as Fighting Drags On
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  In a terrace cafe within earshot of army artillery, a 28-year-old graduate student wept as she confessed that she had stopped planning antigovernment protests and delivering medical supplies to rebel-held towns.

title: Hard Times for a Small (and Fuzzy) Group of Europeans
description: PARADELA, Portugal  Its not easy being a donkey today.

title: Giants and Jets, Super Bowl Hosts, Have Already Been Richly Rewarded
description: Even if the two teams that call it home do not have a championship season, their three-year-old, $1.6 billion stadium in New Jersey will soon have its biggest moment: staging the first Super Bowl in the New York City area.

title: Obamacares Secret Success
description: The law establishing Obamacare was officially titled the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. And the affordable bit wasnt just about subsidizing premiums. It was also supposed to be about bending the curve  slowing the seemingly inexorable rise in health costs.

title: Ire in Canada Over Report N.S.A. Spied From Ottawa
description: OTTAWA  Canadian opposition politicians expressed shock and anger on Thursday over a report that the National Security Agency conducted widespread surveillance during a summit meeting of world leaders in Canada in June 2010.

title: Retirement Ends 4-Decade Career of Drafting Big Plans for New York City
description: You have never heard of him, but he was a modern Robert Moses. As a strategic thinker for the Department of City Planning, under eight chairmen since 1975, Samuel Hornick was instrumental in a number of initiatives that have changed the face of New York.

title: Bangladeshis Build Careers in New York Traffic
description: Above a Korean fried chicken restaurant in Jackson Heights, Queens, Showkat Khan worked the room of mostly Bangladeshi men, speaking Bengali with a few English phrases mixed in, his enthusiastic message of opportunity broadcast through a crackling amp. At one point, he held aloft a copy of New York Citys Civil Service newspaper, The Chief.

title: Some Big Public Pension Funds Are Behaving Like Activist Investors
description: Activist investors like Carl C. Icahn, Daniel S. Loeb and William A. Ackman are getting deep-pocketed imitators.

title: Tortorella Returns, Relentless as Ever
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  As long as John Tortorella coaches the Vancouver Canucks and Alain Vigneault coaches the Rangers, the comparisons will be inevitable.

title: Protecting the Brand
description: The Hells Angels have grown increasingly litigious, learning to employ the legal system to protect the recognizable symbols of their club.

title: Secrecy Bill Could Distance Japan From Its Postwar Pacifism
description: TOKYO  Brushing past angry street protests and apocalyptic editorials in leading newspapers, Japans conservative prime minister, Shinzo Abe, appears set to achieve one of the first items on his legislative agenda to roll back his nations postwar pacifism: passing a national secrets law.

title: Despite Outlaw Image, Hells Angels Sue Often
description: PHOENIX  Fritz Clapp, a 67-year-old lawyer with a bright red mohawk, practices intellectual property law. Years ago, his clients were small-time businesses that nobody had ever heard of. Then he found something bigger. Today, Mr. Clapp, an eloquent and irreverent man known to wear a purple fez during negotiations with other lawyers, represents the interests of a group not commonly associated with intellectual property: the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club.
