His main role is not as a bulldog criminal defense counsel for the notorious group but as a civilized advocate in its relentless battle to protect its many registered trademarks.

title: Retailers Sly Message: Get Yourself a Gift, Too
description: Even the most clueless and bumbling gift-giver probably knows that it is not a good idea to give wrinkle cream, an electric toothbrush or a vacuum cleaner to anyone for Christmas or Hanukkah.

title: At European Meeting on Partnership, Ukraine and Armenia Balk
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania  A European summit meeting that opened here on Thursday was supposed to celebrate the achievements that put former Soviet republics on a path to Western integration  a program that would ultimately fulfill the more than half-century pursuit of a truly Continental economic and political alliance.

title: True to Form, Cowboys Tantalize Fans With Late-Season Signs of Life
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Dallas Cowboys should know better than to take success for granted. Mired in mediocrity for several seasons, they have teased and tortured fans while manufacturing playoff runs late into December.

title: Americans Views on the Minimum Wage
description: Should the federal minimum wage be raised or not?

title: Mixed Legacy for Departing Pakistani Army Chief
description: LONDON  When he leaves his post on Friday, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, the inscrutable Pakistani Army chief and former spymaster, will end a nearly decade-long chapter as the focus of American fears and frustrations in Pakistan, the reluctant partner in a contentious and often ill-tempered strategic dance.

title: No Longer a King, but Always an Artist
description: When Sam Shacked was up, he was way up.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 28, 2013
Nets Kidd Fined for Spilling Soda
description: Jason Kidds drink-spilling tactic late Wednesday night was considered both devious and ingenious. By Thursday, it had also proved costly.

title: Borough President for Not Much Longer, but a Brooklynite Always
description: If Marty Markowitzs grand entrance at the annual Borough Hall Thanksgiving turkey giveaway this week seemed less sprightly than usual, his wisecracks more muted, his smile less dazzling, well, it was hard to blame him. After 12 years as Brooklyns borough president and chief cheerleader, Mr. Markowitz is relinquishing what he has repeatedly proclaimed is the only job he ever wanted.

title: Shortage of Doctors Accepting Medicaid
description: As people sign up for Medicaid under the new health law, some may find it challenging to find doctors.

title: Opponent Highlights Knicks Weakness From 3-Point Range
description: LOS ANGELES  As J. J. Redick moved from spot to spot along the perimeter, he had a number in mind: 106. It never changes. He caps every pregame shootaround with a routine that requires him to make 106 shots at a series of locations, most of them from beyond the 3-point arc, and he was at it again as he prepared on Wednesday morning for the Clippers game against the Knicks later that night.

title: Where to Take Stock
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Has everyone recovered from turkey coma? I hope everyone is looking forward to leftovers. Thanksgiving leftovers is a favorite meal of mine.

title: Keeping Ball on the Ground, Auburns Offense Still Soars
description: AUBURN, Ala.  Auburn Coach Gus Malzahn squinted through his glasses to see the spot of the ball, studied plays on a clipboard and gave commands through his headset to his staff. The play was then signaled to the players on the field. It all appeared to be the normal functioning of a no-huddle offense.

title: A Timeline of the Hells Angels
description: The Hells Angels, in less than 70 years, have become a part of counterculture lore  American antiheroes exported to the rest of the world with dubious effect.

title: Bloomberg Code Keeps Articles From Chinese Eyes
description: In early 2011, during a period of heightened tension between the Chinese government and foreign journalists, Bloomberg News created coding to give editors the ability to categorize stories under a new class, called 204. Such stories would not show up on Bloomberg terminals in mainland China. Managers did this after Chinese officials stressed to top editors in Hong Kong that the license granted to Bloomberg by the State Council allowed the company to publish only financial data and news on its terminals, not political news, employees said.

title: Australia Blocks A.D.M.s $2.7 Billion Bid for GrainCorp
description: In the first major test of the pro-business platform of Australias new government, the countrys treasurer rejected on Friday a $2.7 billion takeover bid for GrainCorp Ltd. by Archer Daniels Midland, the American agribusiness giant, saying the deal was against the national interest.

title: Reducing the Impact of Too Big to Fail
description: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

title: Spoleto Festival USA Announces Lineup
description: Entering its 38th year, the Spoleto Festival USA announced its 2014 lineup, which will feature 152 performances of opera, music, theater and dance from May 23 through June 8. The festival, in Charleston, S.C., will include a new production of John Adamss opera El Nio. Janaceks Kata Kabanova, will be staged by Garry Hynes, above, who in 1998 became the first woman to win a Tony for directing, for her production of The Beauty Queen of Leenane. The festival will also feature the American premiere of the opera Facing Goya, by Michael Nyman, below, in a new version to be performed without amplification. The Spoleto Festival USA Orchestra, conducted by John Kennedy, will pair Beethovens Seventh symphony with Louis Andriessens The Nine Symphonies of Beethoven and Michael Gordons Rewriting Beethovens Seventh Symphony. The festivals theatrical productions will include Joseph OConnors adaptation of My Cousin Rachel, drawn from the Daphne du Maurier novel, in a production by the Gate Theater of Ireland, as well as the American premiere of Ravi Jains autobiographical play, A Brimful of Asha, and a multimedia work by Laurie Anderson called The Language of the Future. Dances will be performed by Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, Dorrance Dance, Keigwin & Company and Gregory Maqoma.

title: Ohio Turnpike Shut Down After High-Speed Crash
description: The Ohio Turnpike was shut down near Fremont, the police said late Thursday, after what local reports described as a high-speed crash that may have left more than one person dead.

title: Q. & A.: Adam Minter on Why Chinas Scrap Trade Helps the Environment
description: In his new book Junkyard Planet: Travels in the Billion-Dollar Trash Trade (Bloomsbury Press), Adam Minter paints a Dickensian portrait of Chinas massive garbage and recycling dumps. And then he tells us why theyre so vital to the environmental movement.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) BARBRA STREISAND: BACK TO BROOKLYN In this Great Performances presentation, Ms. Streisand, above, sings with Il Volo, Chris Botti and her son, Jason Gould, at the Barclays Center in her first hometown concert since childhood. The two October 2012 performances from which this special was culled were a sentimental homecoming and a royal act of noblesse oblige in which a show business monarch regaled the adoring subjects of her native province in a concert that was steeped in Brooklyn lore, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Appetite, yearning, curiosity  whatever you call it  is a quality embedded in Ms. Streisands voice. Like few singers of any age, she has the gift of conveying a primal human longing in a beautiful sound. She is hungry still.

title: Daring the Audience to Not Laugh
description: LOS ANGELES  Like those apocryphal monks who spent the Middle Ages quarreling over the number of angels per pinhead, stand-up comics endlessly obsess over the minutiae of their lives.

title: Corrections: November 29, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: China Eases Rules on the Coveted Pilots License
description: The Civil Aviation Administration of China has said it will relax requirements for obtaining a private pilots license, a move that is likely to unleash pent-up demand in the countrys civil aviation sector. The new regulations make it considerably easier for individuals to acquire a license, a coveted status symbol within Chinas burgeoning class of business moguls and millionaires.

title: A Friendship Is Rekindled With Albania
description: Educators, politicians and diplomats from China and Albania gathered last week to celebrate the opening of a new Confucius Institute at the University of Tirana, which welcomed the Chinese government-backed program whose mission is to promote Chinese language and culture abroad.

title: Creating a Photo Market Afterlife
description: Every artist needs a champion  someone who can turn raw aesthetics into gallery-ready art. Granted, the relationship between creator and curator can be fraught, as they tussle over competing interpretations, edits or even visions.

title: Tepid Data From Euro Zone Leaves Open Debate on Price Downdraft
description: FRANKFURT  The euro zone, suffering from years of stagnation or worse, reached another milestone in its stumbling recovery on Friday when the official unemployment rate fell for the first time since 2011. But a separate report showing a slight rise in inflation was not enough to quell fears that the 17 nations that rely on the euro as their common currency were at risk of being sucked into a potentially ruinous downward price spiral.

title: Migration Hurts the Homeland
description: OXFORD, England  Liberals have long fought for the rights of immigrants. Businesses have long fought for the right of people to immigrate. Its a crucial distinction.

title: New York Today: Beware of Parking Tickets
description: Updated 11:07 a.m.

title: Isolation Under House Arrest for Wife of Imprisoned Nobel Laureate
description: Liu Xia, the wife of the imprisoned Chinese Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo, says she feels completely isolated living under house arrest in Beijing and finds rare happiness in reading, according to a July letter.

title: U.S. General Apologizes After Afghan Drone Strike
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American military commander called President Hamid Karzai to apologize for a drone strike in southern Helmand Province, which the military conceded had killed and wounded civilians, a coalition official said on Friday.

title: Ukraine Faces E.U.s Dismay on Turnabout on Accords
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania  Undoubtedly, it was an uncomfortable moment. President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, who last week ditched plans to sign far-reaching political and trade agreements with the European Union, found himself confronted Thursday night by the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and by the host of a summit meeting here, President Dalia Grybauskaite of Lithuania.

title: Ukraine's Battle for Europe
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  On Nov. 21, summoned by a Facebook post by a journalist named Mustafa Nayem, more than 1,500 Ukrainians showed up in Independence Square in Kiev to protest their governments decision to pause preparations for signing an association agreement with the European Union. The next day, more crowds gathered, in Kiev and other cities. Soon, the protesters numbered over 100,000.

title: In Bihar Village, an Enduring Love for Lalu Prasad Yadav
description: My Bihar village of a few hundred is just a few miles from Phulwaria in Gopal Ganj, where the populist leader Lalu Prasad Yadav was born. The leader, who charmed everyone with his wit and simplicity, ruled Bihar for almost 15 years starting 1990 - seven years himself as chief minister, eight years through his homemaker wife, Rabri Devi, as proxy.

title: Power Claims in the East China Sea
description: China, Japan and South Korea test each other.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: This weeks homes include a five-bedroom in New Rochelle in a gated waterfront community and a three-bedroom townhouse with a boat slip in Nassau County.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks homes include a condo in the South Street Seaport area; an Upper West Side condo; and a Williamsburg loft.

title: Dr. Ruth Westheimer: Her Bedrooms Are Off Limits
description: When Ruth Westheimer first saw that three-bedroom rental in Washington Heights almost half a century ago, her attraction was instant and intense.

title: Stair Masters
description: Robert Peruzzi was so determined to rent the fifth-floor walk-up he had seen on Irving Place that he was willing to outbid another potential tenant and pay $150 more than the original asking rent.

title: Choosing Between Mortgage Broker and Bank
description: Disparaged by some as the bogeymen of the housing crash, mortgage brokers have taken a beating over the last few years.

title: Miami Project Off to Arty Start
description: What do Tennessee Williams, Alexander Graham Bell and Madonna have in common? They all once lived in Coconut Grove, one of Miamis oldest and most storied neighborhoods.

title: College on the House
description: Parents who want to pay for their childrens college education but havent saved enough may consider tapping into either their home equity or their retirement accounts. Which is the smarter way to go?

title: The Public Life of Hamid Karzai
description: Be fair, urged Hamid Karzai at the conclusion of his long talks with William Dalrymple, which stretched over three evenings in July, during the fasting month of Ramadan. It had been about four years since Karzai sat down with a reporter for The New York Times Magazine, and he was slightly skeptical about the outcome of the meeting. As long as youre fair, Im good Karzai said. Criticize where Im weak, recognize where Ive done right.

title: At Home With Dr. Ruth
description: Dr. Ruth Westheimer has lived in Washington Heights for almost half a century. Her apartment is home to a myriad of cherished objects collected over her lifetime.

title: The Threat to British Curry
description: LONDON  Upon first moving here from Pakistan two years ago, I was inundated with restaurant recommendations: Tayyabs and Lahore Kebab House, Daawat and Brilliant. I spent many weekends sampling curries and kebabs in the east and halwa in the south. In the end, I settled on a Drummond Street standby.

title: U.N. Warns of Lasting Harm to Syrian Refugee Children
description: GENEVA  Syrias conflict is creating a generation of damaged children, the United Nations warned Friday in a report on the plight of more than a million children who are refugees in neighboring countries, many of them deprived of access to education and of any semblance of a normal family life or childhood.

title: One-Thing Shops: Specialty Stores Around the World
description: Bringing craftsmanship, devotion and unparalleled expertise to a single extraordinary item, these stores prove that less is often much, much more. Our contributors offer their favorites.

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Maximum Henry Belts
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: The New York Collective
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pearson to Sell Financial News Group for $623 Million
description: LONDON  Funds affiliated with the private equity firm BC Partners have reached an agreement to acquire the Mergermarket Group from the British publisher Pearson for 382 million pounds, or about $622.7 million.

title: Exhausted Shoppers Head Home, Replaced by the Next Wave
description: With nine family members  adults, teenagers and a toddler in tow  Ludivina Zuniga stretched her shopping spree over two days and never left the Harlem Irving Plaza mall in a Chicago suburb.

title: 18 People, Abducted in Baghdad, Are Found Shot to Death
description: BAGHDAD  Eighteen people were found dead in what appeared to be an execution-style killing on Friday, their bodies dumped on a farm near the predominantly Sunni neighborhood where they had been rounded up the night before, according to the police.

title: At Bolshoi Trial, Prosecutors Ask for Sentence in Labor Camp
description: MOSCOW Russian prosecutors on Friday requested a sentence of nine years in a labor camp for Pavel Dmitrichenko, once a star Bolshoi Ballet dancer, who is charged with ordering an acid attack that disfigured and nearly blinded the companys artistic director, Sergei Filin.

title: Spoleto Festival Will Include New John Adams Opera
description: Entering its 38th year, the Spoleto Festival USA announced the schedule for its 2014 iteration in Charleston, S.C., which will feature 152 performances of opera, music, theater and dance from May 23 through June 8. The festival will include a new production of John Adams opera El Nio. Janaceks Kata Kabanova, will be staged, directed by Garry Hynes, who in 1998 became the first woman to win a Tony, for her production of The Beauty Queen of Leenane.

title: Talking Turkey
description: Matthew Yglesias is completely wrong.

title: Recent Drone Strikes Strain U.S. Ties With Afghanistan and Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two separate but similarly bitter disagreements over drone strikes in Pakistan and Afghanistan have complicated relations between the United States and those two countries at a delicate moment, again highlighting the political complications from Americas persistent reliance on the lethal remote-controlled weapons.

title: Defending the Queen
description: Britains Queen Anne (who reigned from 1702 to 1714) has not been treated kindly by historians. Consensus has it that Brandy Nan was obese and of limited intelligence, with a predilection for the bottle. More dangerously, she is supposed to have put herself under the thumb of domineering women favorites with political agendas: first the Whig partisan Sarah Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough, and subsequently the duchesss upstart cousin Abigail Masham, a Tory sympathizer. (It is suggested from the surviving correspondence that Anne might have had lesbian leanings, though whether these were ever acted upon is unknown.) She is seldom given any credit for the great events of her reign, which included the 1707 Act of Union and the glorious victories over the armies of Louis XIV.

title: Oscar Hopeful Revives Searing Memoir
description: The success of the director Steve McQueens 12 Years a Slave, a likely Oscar nominee, has also given new life to a classic autobiography, Solomon Northups now best-selling 1853 memoir. Movie adaptations are reliably good news for the books on which theyre based, and McQueen says he believes few sources are more worthy of the attention than Northups narrative of his experience as a free man kidnapped into slavery.

title: Anthologies
description: THE COOL SCHOOL  Writing From Americas Hip UndergroundEdited by Glenn OBrien  The Library of America, $27.95.

title: Hungry, Hungry Voters
description: Hammertime with Gary Shteyngart; Rob Ford or Ford Focus?

title: Who Made That Spork?
description: The last time you picked up a spork  whether a plastic one for your fast-food meal or the titanium one you took on your camping trip  you might have had the fleeting thought that the clever spoon/fork feels almost futuristic, or at least from a not-so-distant past. Actually, it has been around for centuries.

title: Did I Fence a Sign?
description: Looking for artwork for my home, I recently bought a used road sign online  a bright blue one advertising a campground ahead. I liked it and ended up buying a second one. Only after I purchased those two signs did it occur to me that they may have been stolen. Now I feel guilty. Throwing them in the recycling bin doesnt really make the situation right. Selling them to someone else is no better. Reporting the sellers seems hypocritical  plus, I have no evidence. What is my obligation as an ethical citizen? BEVERLY BARTLETT, LOUISVILLE, KY.

title: The 11.17.13 Issue
Danica Patrick on Racing Cars and Building Brands
description: You dropped out of school when you were 16 to pursue racing. Do you think you would be where you are had you not done that?  I took the opportunity that was in front of me, which meant moving to England and leaving school. I did get my G.E.D.  I call it my Good Enough Diploma  but I dont know, I think I showed my dedication by doing that.

title: Inside the List
description: Choose Kind: Its been exactly 52 weeks since the Book Review modified its childrens best-seller lists, splitting the former chapter books category into two new lists  middle grade and young adult  to better reflect the different ages of those books primary readers. In that time, only one book has stayed on the middle-grade list all 52 weeks: R. J. Palacios debut novel, Wonder, about a boy with a facial deformity trying to fit in at school. (This week, its No. 2.)

title: My Man Bertie
description: What, ho? A new Jeeves and Wooster novel? Steady on. Your faithful reviewer may not be the brightest bulb in the old marquee, but dash it, isnt this anno dom 2013, and didnt the Master  yclept Pelham Grenville Wodehouse (Plum to his chums)  shove off across the old Rio Styx back in 1975?

title: The Art of Celebrity
description: Just in case weve been wondering how important a painter Lucian Freud was, or what an enormous celebrity he became, or why the British journalist Geordie Greig has written a book about him, Breakfast With Lucian answers these questions in its opening pages. Freud was so well known that he was allowed into Clarkes  a small upmarket restaurant frequented by Bryan Ferry, Salman Rushdie, Dame Maggie Smith, and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge  before it opened in the morning, and invited to enjoy a leisurely meal in what functioned as his private salon. Over dinner at Londons more glittering establishments, he could pelt strangers with breadsticks, spew obscenities, pummel a waiter, grope the waitresses, amuse his companions by imitating a masturbating whale  and be welcomed back the next evening. At Clarkes, Lucians conversation ranged from dating Greta Garbo to the best way to land a punch without breaking your thumb, to how he had popped in to 10 Downing Street to see Gordon Brown, or had been to a nightclub with Kate Moss. Oh, the life of an artist!

title: Calls to Arms
description: In Churchills Bomb, Graham Farmelo recounts two related but distinct stories: the British role in the development of nuclear weapons from the 1920s through the 1950s and Winston Churchills relationship with cutting-edge military science generally, and the Bomb specifically.

title: A Ski Spot Thats Remote, No Frills and Not for Profit
description: The community of Terrace, British Columbia, has taken a purists approach to the ski season the last few years, forming My Mountain Co-op, Canadas first nonprofit ski community cooperative, a no-frills outfit where amenities are secondary to the sport itself.

title: Time Was on Their Side
description: As the 50th-anniversary milestones for the Beatles and the Rolling Stones fly off like calendar pages in an old film, even the stuff of barroom debates gets elevated into book-length exegeses. At least thats true on the evidence of Beatles vs. Stones, by John McMillian, and Rocks Off: 50 Tracks That Tell the Story of the Rolling Stones, by Bill Janovitz. The good news is that despite some flaws, each of them justifies its extended treatment of essentially irresolvable disputes. They manage to make their cases in balanced, informed, yet still passionate terms. And, best of all, when youre done, you dont need to worry about a crippling hangover.

title: Twisted Spinster
description: Ronald Frames fast-moving new novel makes use of the eccentric Miss Havisham from Great Expectations, but the first two-thirds of it is much more Trollopian than Dickensian. Right from the start, Catherine Havisham suggests she was born into a world she might never understand: I killed my mother. That she was a breech birth, that the death of women in childbirth was a given in early 19th-century England, are simply facts. What is important is that the machine of her life is already operating full tilt, and the most she can do is keep her eyes open and attempt to understand its workings.

title: Imperial Rhymes
description: Kipling was a conundrum even to himself. One of the first modern writers to live in the fraught intersections of empire, he wrote between two worlds. Born in Bombay, named after the picturesque Staffordshire lake where his parents had courted, he enjoyed a pampered childhood among the Anglo-Indians, as they called themselves, with a native ayah and loads of Indian servants. At 5, he was banished from this paradise and sent back to the mother country to be raised by a placid English couple. The husband had the bad manners to die, leaving the boy in the charge of the wife, who was secretly a monster. Kipling suffered, as did Dickens, a Dickensian childhood whose cruelties could never be erased.

title: The Help and the Helped
description: Downton Abbey fans may be disappointed to find that Lucy Lethbridges lively history of British servants concludes with Upstairs, Downstairs, the 1971-75 television series created by the children of a housemaid and an under-butler. On-screen, this costume drama may have looked like a period piece, but behind the scenes, class tensions persisted. Upon arriving at the set, the actors playing the downstairs roles discovered they had been allotted inferior dressing rooms, with showers monopolized by the actors playing their masters.

title: Kind Regards
description: Once there were letters: handwritten, typewritten, carefully crafted, dashed off, profound or mundane, tinged with expectancy. Correspondence required waiting. I need you more and more, and the great world grows wider, and dear ones fewer and fewer, every day that you stay away, Emily Dickinson wrote to her future sister-in-law, Susan Gilbert, in 1852. Were they alive today, would Dickinson and Gilbert merely G-chat?

title: Materfamilias
description: Alison Weirs new biography documents the life of the Tudors other Queen Elizabeth. Weir has already produced biographies of Elizabeth I, Henry VIII and Eleanor of Aquitaine, all better known than Elizabeth of York, whose obscurity belies the high profile of her connections. She came of age during the Wars of the Roses, the dynastic rivalry between the Houses of York and Lancaster. As the daughter of a Yorkist king, Edward IV, and the wife of the first Tudor (Lancastrian) king, Henry VII, she united these warring houses. For this alone, she deserves a prominent place in English history.

title: Murder at the Vicarage
description: NO MANS NIGHTINGALE (Scribner, $26) is Ruth Rendells 24th Inspector Wexford procedural mystery in almost 50 years, so were naturally curious about how that venerable detective may have mellowed in retirement. Well, his mind is still sharp enough to solve a murder case bungled by Mike Burden, his old deputy and now detective superintendent of the Kingsmarkham constabulary. Always a tolerant man, Wexford is ever more alarmed by the racism and bigotry that have taken root in his little patch of England and were a factor in the murder of the Rev. Sarah Hussain, a biracial single mother raising an out-of-wedlock child. And, if anything, hes grown more caustic about barbaric insults to the mother tongue, like the Alternative Service Book that replaced the Book of Common Prayer in Anglican churches.

title: Cold Comfort
description: Why are wealthy Britons so entertaining to read about? Maybe it has something to do with the collision of crisp formality and a kind of babyish loopiness  looming over every well-manicured herbaceous border and syntactically rigorous sentence is an eccentric uncle named Birtwhistle. Or, more darkly, maybe fans of the Patrick Melrose novels and Downton Abbey are drawn like moths to the flame of scandal: To learn of an illustrious familys secret shame is to put a human face on a glamorous abstraction.

title: Dealing With Burnout, Which Doesnt Always Stem From Overwork
description: ITS the end of the year, and lots of us are feeling a little overwhelmed. Tired, unfocused and ready to take a nice break with our families (or away from our families in some cases).

title: The Class of Its Class, Again
description: The all-new 2014 edition of the Mazda 3 continues to stake its claim as the front-runner among affordable small cars.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE WORLD UNTIL YESTERDAY: What Can We Learn From Traditional Societies?,  by Jared Diamond. (Penguin, $18.) In Guns, Germs, and Steel (1997) and Collapse (2005), Diamond offered sweeping descriptions of how geography and environment shape the destiny of nations. The World Until Yesterday holds up tribal societies of the Amazon, New Guinea and elsewhere as natural experiments that have much to teach us about child rearing, eldercare, fitness and conflict resolution.

title: Thai Protesters Enter Army Headquarters as Government Avoids Violence
description: BANGKOK  Antigovernment protesters broke into and briefly occupied the grounds of Thailands army headquarters on Friday, capping a week of dramatic and provocative gestures against the countrys most influential political family.

title: In Our Pages: November 30
description: 1888: Revolution-era Fashion in Paris

title: Editors Choice
description: MY PROMISED LAND: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel,  by Ari Shavit. (Spiegel & Grau, $28.) Shavit, a columnist for Haaretz, expresses both solidarity with and criticism of his countrymen in this important and powerful book.

title: Shopping for a Girl? Consider Science and Engineering Toys
description: Sofia the First, a new Disney princess decked out in a lavender gown, is high on most retailers list of the hottest toys this holiday season. But if youre shopping for a girl, why not skip the doll aisle for toys that encourage science and engineering?

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Edward VII
description: This week, Jane Ridley talks about The Heir Apparent, her new book about Edward VII; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen discuss Hannah Arendts Eichmann in Jerusalem; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Edward VII
description: This week, Jane Ridley, Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen.

title: Turning Leftovers Into Latkes
description: Planning ahead, I was all set to devote this weeks recipes to potatoes, which I have always defended against the anti-carb brigade because potatoes are a wholesome food, high in B vitamins and vitamin C, potassium and fiber, with some protein and lots of complex carbohydrates. A plain, seven-ounce baked potato eaten with the skin contains half the daily amounts of Vitamin C and Vitamin B6 recommended for adults. I had Thanksgiving in mind, the most popular time of the year for this tuber; or is Hanukkah the most popular time?

title: Off the Charts: Fewer Firings, but Long-Term Joblessness Is Still High
description: The rate of firings in the United States has fallen to the lowest level since the government began measuring it more than a decade ago. But the number of people being hired has only slowly increased since the bottom of the recession, leaving many long-term unemployed workers still unable to find jobs.

title: The Magical Allure of a Shop That Sells Only One Kind of Thing
description: Bringing craftsmanship, devotion and unparalleled expertise to a single extraordinary item, specialty stores prove that less is often much, much more. Our contributors offer their favorites.

title: For Long-Term Jobless, a Stubborn Trend
description: IN 2006, with the American economy booming, the proportion of workers who were laid off or discharged over a 12-month period fell to 15.5 percent. That was the lowest rate since the government began collecting the data at the end of 2000  and a sign that the job market was exceedingly strong.

title: Airlines Urged by U.S. to Give Notice to China
description: WASHINGTON  Even as China scrambled fighter jets to enforce its newly declared air defense zone, the Obama administration said on Friday that it was advising American commercial airlines to comply with Chinas demands to be notified in advance of flights through the area.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Life of Edward VII
description: In The New York Times Book Review, John Sutherland reviews Jane Ridleys The Heir Apparent: A Life of Edward VII, the Playboy Prince. Mr. Sutherland writes:

title: Times Minute: Nov. 29
description: Black Friday begins early; Syrian refugees in Sicily; and Hells Angels lawyer up.

title: A Rescue at Sea
description: Smugglers left 150 Syrians adrift with a satellite phone and an emergency number in Italy. Save us, they pleaded before the phone went dead. We are lost.

title: In Subways, Suddenly, 2 Glimpses of History
description: One is a century-old transit hub permitted to age gracefully beneath Lower Manhattan, its chandeliers, terra-cotta tiles and ceiling of Guastavino vaults carefully preserved.

title: Review: 2014 Mazda 3
description: The 2014 Mazda 3 has swoopy sheet metal, a rich interior, and a fun-to-drive dynamic. Why is it not the best-selling car in its class?

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: Same-sex parents. Cohabiting couples. Voluntary kin. Children with parents in prison. Immigrant-Americans. How much do you know about todays changing family structure?

title: The New York Times Minute
description: In the Video

title: A Thaw for Frosty Toes
description: Audis that need a new crankcase pressure valve and Corvettes low on differential oil are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Performer Available for Private Parties
description: Mazda fans are like the denizens of a cool underground speakeasy, hidden behind a false door and a mounted antelope head. Theyd love people to know how much fun theyre having, but they may not want the masses to force their way inside.

title: In Formula One, Its Already 2014
description: The competition for the 2013 Formula One drivers championship may have officially ended last Sunday with Sebastian Vettels victory in the Brazilian Grand Prix, but as a practical matter this years campaign was over soon after it began.

title: To Bring Back the Drivers, Rallies Add Brain-Teasers
description: ISLANDIA, N.Y.  One by one, the cars rolled out of the parking lot and onto the Long Island Expressway for the start of the 2013 Vintage Rally:

title: A Chevy So Exclusive That You Can Only Borrow, Not Buy
description: Rental cars are rarely anything special. And thats just fine. All you really need from a rental is unlimited miles, long-term shelter for a few stray curly fries and a hassle-free ride from A to B and back again before those martinets at the counter charge you for an additional day.

title: Image of the Day: November 29
Offerings From Nashville, the Kitchen and This Side of Twisted
description: Throwing Muses

title: Angela Lansbury Returning to London Stage in Blithe Spirit
description: After a four-decade absence from the London stage Angela Lansbury, best known for her portrayals of the detective Jessica Fletcher in the television series Murder, She Wrote and the murderous pie-maker in Sweeney Todd, plans to make her return in March in a new production of the  Nol Coward comedy Blithe Spirit. She will reprise her portrayal of Madame Arcati, the medium who communicates with Elvira, the deceased ex-wife of the novelist Charles Condomine. She won a Tony Award when she played the role on Broadway in 2009.

title: Big Ticket | Outdoor Living, in NoHo for $23 Million
description: A statement-making condominium that monopolizes the eighth floor at 40 Bond Street, the 11-story emerald-green-glass apparition that brought a dash of Oz downtown to NoHo in 2007, sold for $23.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: A Night Watchman With Wheels?
description: The night watchman of the future is five feet tall, weighs 300 pounds and looks a lot like R2D2  without the whimsy. And will work for $6.25 an hour.

title: Helping a Shy Guy Build Up His Nerve
description: While having a cocktail at a bar with my sister and her boyfriend, a woman walked in alone, looked around and took a seat at the bar. I thought it might be the woman Id chatted with the night before on OkCupid (a dating website), but I wasnt sure. And even if I was, we had only exchanged a couple of short messages. I didnt even know her name. Well, it turns out, it was her. But instead of a fortuitous encounter with an attractive woman, I was the creepy guy who wasnt confident enough to say hello. What should I do the next time something like this happens?

title: Coming Out as a Modern Family (Updated With Podcast)
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress and writer Maria Bello in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below or subscribe on iTunes or Stitcher.

title: Increased Global Demand Aids Indias Mild Recovery
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias economy is showing signs of a gradual recovery as gross domestic product increased at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the three months that ended in September.

title: Diamond-Paved, Deal-Obsessed
description: The diamond district, on a block of West 47th Street, pulses with the competition of the jewelry sellers, who are always looking for a way to make a deal.

title: Diamond-Paved, Deal-Obsessed
description: The diamond district, on a block of West 47th Street, pulses with the competition of the jewelry sellers, who are always looking for a way to make a deal.

title: Timing of Babys First Solids May Affect Allergy Risk
description: Breast-feeding exclusively for four to six months, and introducing solid foods while breast-feeding continues, may be a good way to reduce the risk for food allergies in children.

title: Out of Syria, Into a European Maze
description: SYRACUSE, Sicily  As war rages on, more refugees are risking a journey to what they hope will be prosperous new lives.

title: Jim Harrisons Upper Peninsula
description: About 10 years ago, before we sold our farm in northern Michigan and moved to Montana, I was accustomed to driving the five hours north to a cabin we kept near Grand Marais on Lake Superior in the Upper Peninsula. I made the drive countless times over the 25 years my wife, Linda, and I owned the log cabin that sat in the middle of 60 acres bisected by the Sucker River. If youd been spending a month at a time in Hollywood, which I frequently was as a screenwriter in those years, theres nothing like returning to a farm with horses and chickens, and then on to a fairly remote cabin off a two-track road where when you try to sleep at night you hear a river flowing, probably the best sound on earth.

title: Shore, Snow and Sky in the Upper Peninsula
description: Scenes from Michigans sparsely populated north country.

title: This Is Las Vegas?
description: Just after dawn, when the steady clang of slot machines slowed to an irregular heartbeat and most of Las Vegas was soused or sleeping  I was jogging. The sidewalks were empty. They no longer belonged to hucksters, heartbreakers and flocks of friends, decked out and glassy-eyed. They belonged to me. I ran past the hushed fountains of the Bellagio, over eye-popping cards for escorts and strip clubs that littered the streets like ticker tape on my way to the first of several weekend fitness classes: Yoga Among the Dolphins.

title: Week in Pictures for Nov. 29
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include autumn leaves, the first book printed in the new world, and the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: A Marriage Tests an Advice Columnist
description: When Amy Dickinson, 54, and Bruno Schickel, 57, married five-plus years ago, she imagined their marriage would be like a good romantic comedy.

title: Another Flap Over Justin Biebers Art
description: Justin Bieber is discovering that growing up in public just isnt the fun you might expect it to be. Having spent recent weeks creating a ruckus in Latin America, where he upset fans in Brazil and Argentina by cutting short concerts, had to apologize to Argentine fans for dragging their countrys flag across the stage, and angered authorities in Colombia and Brazil by spray painting graffiti on public walls, the 19-year-old singer has taken his entourage to Australia, where hes found trouble again.

title: Cardinals Pitcher Joins a New Team
description: Some say that the pitchers mound can be the loneliest place on earth, with so much resting on the pitchers rhythm, arm and accuracy. For Shelby Miller, a 23-year-old player on the roster of the St. Louis Cardinals, not being selected to pitch for his team in this years World Series put him in an even lonelier place.

title: Brash C.E.O. Keeps the Giants of Mobile Off Balance
description: As recently as two years ago, T-Mobile had all but been given up for dead. It was losing subscribers and struggling to upgrade its aging cellular network. Its owner, Deutsche Telekom, said it wanted out of the competitive North American market, agreed to sell T-Mobile to AT&T for $39 billion and was already describing T-Mobile as a discontinued operation in its financial statements. In lobbying the government to approve the merger, AT&T warned ominously that a stand-alone T-Mobile would probably fail and consumers would suffer.

title: When Coaching Gamesmanship Gets in the Way
description: HOUSTON  Jason Kidd came clean on Friday, two days after he contrived to spill a cup of soda on the court so that he could buy some time to draw up a final play in a game in which his Nets team was trailing and out of timeouts.

title: A Joyous Reunion
description: Tragedy is common, when the refugees come ashore. But there is also joy, as there was when a man named Jaffar came to the harbor to look for his brother and two nephews.

title: A Rescue at Sea
description: A boat packed with Syrian refugees fleeing the war bobbed in the sea about 50 miles off the southeastern coast of Sicily as the Italian Coast Guard approached.

title: On the Importance of Little Arrows (Wonkish)
description: A new post by Stephen Williamson has both Nick Rowe and Brad DeLong fulminating  and rightly so. But my sense is that they are so shocked at the level of misconception on the part of a guy who imagines himself more sophisticated than crude neoKeynesians that theyre not managing to convey whats really going on.

title: Document | Who Let the Bengal Tiger Inside the Palace?
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Cast Change for Met Operas Fledermaus
description: Christine Schfer, the soprano who was to have sung Adele in the Metropolitan Operas new production of Johann Strauss Jr.s Fledermaus, has withdrawn from the production because of illness, the Met said.

title: The Spectacle and Sales of Black Friday
description: Market analysts researching the buying habits of Americans have noted a growing trend in online shopping on Black Friday, the frenetic day after Thanksgiving when retailers try to boost annual sales with steep discounts.

title: On New Buses, It Will Be Buckle Up
description: A new seat belt rule is meant to make buses safer than ever.

title: Abrupt End to Players Misery in Qatar
description: Zahir Belouniss Qatari ordeal ended not with a letter or a visa stamp or even with a visit from an official delivering news of his impending departure from the emirate. It ended with a phone call telling him to leave the country, and quickly.

title: Wheelies: The Claiming Carolina Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: The Ways of Lust
description: HOW does lust affect the way we think about people?

title: Martha
description: Inside the Fort Greene restaurant named after the patron saint of cooks.

title: A Jam Session in the Kitchen
description: Rarely have I been so captivated by gruel.

title: Without Vonn, Americans Struggle in Beaver Creek Downhill
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Missing Lindsey Vonn, who skipped the race after reinjuring her right knee Nov. 19, the United States womens ski team failed to deliver podium results in the season-opening downhill event on Friday.

title: Wired: Putting a Writer and Readers to a Test
description: Writers working on new books often complain about the pressure. But on a recent evening, the Dutch novelist Arnon Grunberg was sitting at a cluttered desk in his shoe-box apartment in Midtown Manhattan, with more reason to kvetch than most.

title: London Mayor Raises Eyebrows, and Ire
description: LONDON  Boris Johnson, the flamboyant, self-mocking and ambitious mayor of London, has put his gilded foot in his mouth once again, suggesting that the poor of Britain are victims of low I.Q. and that greed is good.

title: Market Report | Feminine Flats With a Little Extra Dazzle
description: Evening sandals merge comfort with festiveness, and add a wink of hauteur without the heel.

title: Takeda Hires Glaxo Executive for a Top Post
description: TOKYO  Japans largest drug maker, Takeda Pharmaceutical, announced on Friday that it had hired a GlaxoSmithKline executive to be its next chief operating officer.

title: Dark Chocolate and Pomegranate Bark
description: Tom Faglon makes homemade gifts for the holidays. His gift to Melissa Clark: a dark chocolate and pomegranate bark with just a hint of ginger and sea salt.

title: In London Slaves Case, 3 Women Isolated Under a Maoist Gurus Sway
description: LONDON  They have become known as the Brixton slaves, three women who say they were held against their will for 30 years in a South London home.

title: Treats From Their Kitchens to Yours
description: Chocolate bark is the workhorse of homemade holiday gifts: easy, crowd-pleasing, expected.

title: Consumer Safety Chief Leaves a Small Agency With Bigger Powers
description: WASHINGTON  When Inez M. Tenenbaum took over the Consumer Product Safety Commission in 2009, she found an agency in turmoil and uncertain of its mission to ensure that tens of thousands of products on American store shelves did not present a danger to buyers.

title: Insurance on the Person Who Makes the Business Run
description: WHEN Richard Manfredi was running his familys manufacturing business, the company took out a large insurance policy on him. If he died, his partners would use the money to buy out his familys interest. This is how these policies, known as key-man insurance, are typically used.

title: Shying From Fames Spotlight
description: Lorde, the 17-year-old pop prodigy from New Zealand whose real name is Ella Yelich-OConnor, is suddenly quite famous. Her first full-length album, Pure Heroine, entered the Billboard charts in October at No. 3. Its breakout single, Royals, (a.k.a. Bill de Blasios victory anthem) has sold over 3.7 million copies in the United States alone during nine weeks atop the Billboard Hot 100; she is the youngest solo artist to hit No. 1 since Tiffany in 1988. And just recently, Songs Music Publishing secured the publishing rights to her songs in a reported multimillion-dollar deal.

title: At Art Basel Miami Beach, Squeezing Art Out of the Picture
description: Lets play a game: Are the following parties taking place during New York Fashion Week or Art Basel Miami Beach?

title: Roseanne Barr and Mindy Kaling: Funny Women, Serious Talk
description: ON A RECENT Saturday, the weather California-perfect, Roseanne Barr, the star and co-creator of the groundbreaking sitcom Roseanne, which ran on ABC from October 1988 to May 1997 (and now in heavy rotation on TVLand), and Mindy Kaling, the TV writer and actress (The Office), best-selling author (Is Everybody Hanging Out Without Me?) and now the creator and star of The Mindy Project on Fox, met for lunch at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: Moving Beyond the Sad and the Angry to Write a Valediction for New Orleans
description: HBOs Treme was an unlikely proposition from the start. It was predicated on a natural disaster, Hurricane Katrina, that happened five years before the show started, and that lag has always been awkward. The meticulous re-creation of not quite recent outrages  perpetrated by politicians no longer in office and cops already indicted  has made the show seem to be in a weird time warp all its own.

title: Rat-a-Tap-Tap: From Minneapolis, Fast, Furious Footwork and a Beatboxer
description: The phrase Feet Dont Fail Me Now! might evoke a cartoon character in a tough spot, lower extremities spinning. Or it might call to mind the title song of a Little Feat album. Both associations apply to Feet Dont Fail Me Now!, the harmlessly entertaining display of music and tap-dancing skills finishing a run at the New Victory Theater.

title: Bill Cunningham | Reasons for Gratitude
description: Thanksgiving in New York City is a warm family experience.

title: Comet ISON, Presumed Dead, Shows New Life
description: Astronomers are marveling at the death and apparent resurrection of a comet that dove close to the sun on Thanksgiving.

title: Bill Cunningham | Reasons for Gratitude
description: Thanksgiving in the city is a warm family experience. Even in Wednesdays winds, outdoor food markets were filled. A woman (above) carried a 36-pound turkey. Piles of cranberries awaited shoppers, who were stylish but practical. The first holiday evergreens arrived, and a traveler burdened with a duffel could only wish for some help from a parade balloon.

title: Twelfth Night
description: Musician Arngeir Hauksson plays a hurdy-gurdy at the Belasco Theater before a performance of Twelfth Night.

title: Is This a Sackbut I Hear Before Me?
description: It is no ordinary Broadway pit band. Its period instruments  sackbuts, shawms and rauschpfeifes  are decidedly more Akademie fr Alte Musik Berlin than Irving Berlin.

title: Posole Offers a December Warm-Up
description: Gathering during the winter holidays is a universal rite for most people, no matter what our religious or secular persuasion.

title: From Behind the Canvas
description: As the art mob descends on South Florida this week for the 12th edition of the cross-platform marketing frenzy that is Art Basel Miami Beach  private jets disgorging art sharks and their adviser remoras  one slight and fashionable figure will stand out.

title: Looking Back at Last Years Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams
description: The premier event at the Fall North American Championships being held in Phoenix is the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, which take place over the last three days, beginning on Friday. It is generally considered the hardest of the Big Three (Spingold Knockout Teams, Vanderbilt Knockout Teams and Reisinger) to win.

title: Single Mother Needs a Man: It Must Be Christmas on TV
description: Back in 1965, Linus stepped forward and calmed the chaos of A Charlie Brown Christmas, the classic animated special, by reciting verses from the Gospel of Luke about the birth of Jesus. Thats what Christmas is all about, Charlie Brown, he concluded.

title: The New Giggler Behind Late-Night Interviews
description: Pete Holmes was talking about his divorce on his new late-night talk show, and not for the first time. He had already told a guest, Allison Williams of HBOs Girls, that his ex-wife cheated on him, but this time he took blame.

title: Dancey, Trancey, and Dabs of Spice
description: Britney Spears has been promising that her new album, Britney Jean, is her most personal album ever since July, when she first tweeted the phrase. Fans might have hoped for a candid look at a turbulent life: child stardom as a Mouseketeer, reinvention as a teenage tease and then a trashy sex symbol, marriages, motherhood, public meltdowns, stints in rehab and her rebound as a hitmaker, a judge on The X Factor and, at the end of December, a performer starting a two-year residency in Las Vegas.

title: Gains for Einhorn and Loeb Could Bode Well for Hedge Funds
description: Forget about Black Friday. November is looking as if it could be the month that puts many hedge funds solidly in the black for the year, at least based on performance numbers for two notable portfolios.

title: Talk of the Turner Prize, Where, for One Thing, Talk Is Art
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland  On a recent morning, a group of teenagers stood in a room, now an art gallery in a former military barracks here, and stared at the bare white walls. They were searching for the work of Tino Sehgal, one of the four nominees for this years Turner Prize.

title: It Takes a Lot of Money to Look This Good
description: Lori Zaslow runs her own matchmaking business, ProjectSoulmate.com, but for a long time her look suggested less entrepreneur than anything goes. When she finally decided she needed a more sophisticated persona, she worked with Amanda Sanders, an image consultant she had met at a playgroup for their young children in the basement of a friends home. For a business event, Ms. Sanders put Ms. Zaslow in a Marc Jacobs red cocktail dress and clip-on pearl earrings.

title: Movie Review: 'Frozen'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Frozen."

title: Movie Review: 'Oldboy'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Oldboy.

title: Movie Review: 'Black Nativity'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Black Nativity."

title: For Egypts New Rulers, Familiar Scapegoats
description: Updated, Saturday, 2:39 p.m. | This week, when Egypts military-backed government issued arrest warrants for Alaa Abd El Fattah and Ahmed Maher  two activist bloggers who helped drive the uprising that forced Hosni Mubarak from power in 2011 only to find themselves blamed for inciting unrest by each successive government  the same thought occurred to several readers of their popular Twitter feeds. The only stability and reliability we have in Egypt, the journalist Sharif Kouddous joked, is that successive rulers never fail to arrest @alaa.

title: Daughters of Famous Politicians Create Media Brands
description: Last spring, in her role as NBC News special correspondent, Chelsea Clinton interviewed the designer Stella McCartney. The anchor Brian Williams introduced the segment by describing Ms. McCartney as a young woman of high accomplishment who happens to have a famous father. Well, we happen to have one of those around here as well.

title: Youre Cute and Fired
description: Does it really pay to be beautiful? Unless youre a model, perhaps not.

title: Who Killed the Catchphrase?
description: Wassup.

title: Friday Night Music: Back on the Chain Gang
description: Why? I have no idea, but I went browsing and found this amazing performance:

title: Reality Intrudes at a Utopian Market in Brooklyn, With Light Fingers
description: The woman looked like any other grocery shopper that day until the general manager of the store, after a tip, peered at the feed from the security cameras.

title: Week in Pictures for Nov. 29
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include autumn leaves, the first book printed in the new world, and the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: British Loan Providers Steep Rates Under Siege
description: LONDON  The promotional film depicted the humble, happy lives of a dozen customers of Wonga, Britains biggest so-called payday lender.

title: Obamas Meet Fasting Protesters
description: President Obama and Michelle Obama visited three advocates for immigrants who have been fasting in a tent on the National Mall to press the House of Representatives to act on an immigration overhaul. The Obamas met with Eliseo Medina, a labor leader who is 67, and two other people who were in the 18th day of water-only fasts, and with 24 other activists who have observed shorter fasts. Mr. Obama expressed concern for the their health and told them he believes House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio is sincere about wanting to pass immigration legislation, said Beatriz Lopez, a spokeswoman for the protesters.

title: Saturdays Games to Watch
description: 1 ALABAMA at 4 AUBURN

title: As Fund-Raisers in Congress, Women Break the Cash Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON  The first time Senator Patty Murray ran for local office, she was so embarrassed to ask people for money for her campaign that she and her husband held a garage sale. But her generous husband could not stop himself from giving away an expensive lawn mower, she said, leaving the fund-raiser at a net loss.

title: Through a Novel, a Window to an Authors Beliefs
description: Nearly 20 years ago, when he was three books into an acclaimed literary career, Oscar Hijuelos delivered the manuscript of his new novel to his editor. It was a Christmas tale filled with the joy Mr. Hijuelos had always taken in with the trappings of yuletide, from manger scenes to oratorios to evergreens strung with lights.

title: Seeking Top Toys, Good Housekeeping Puts Them to Test
description: The challenge to find the most popular toys for this holiday season started on a steamy July morning at the Good Housekeeping Research Institute in Hearsts headquarters in Midtown Manhattan. Dozens of children gathered in testing rooms usually reserved for reviewing washing machines and vacuum cleaners. In a surprisingly quiet space, except for the buzz of toy planes and the occasional chirps of childrens voices, the testers bent over tea sets and sprawled out on their bellies to play with cars as Good Housekeeping employees in white lab coats scribbled notes on manila folders.

title: Chemical Weapons Watchdog Rejects a Request by Syria to Convert Arms Sites
description: GENEVA  Despite Syrias cooperation with stringent terms laid down by the United States and Russia for the destruction of its chemical weapons, a request from Syria to convert some of the facilities used in that program to other activities failed Friday to win the approval of the international chemical weapons watchdog.

title: Lights Slowly Come Back in a Storm-Crippled Park
description: Along the Hudson River in the West Village, temporary lights mounted on minigenerators illuminated determined bicyclists and the occasional dog walker who were out despite a persistent rain one recent afternoon.

title: Abortion Cases in Court Helped Tilt Democrats Against the Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON  Within hours of each other, two federal appeals courts handed down separate decisions that affirmed sharp new limits on abortion and birth control. One on Oct. 31 forced abortion clinics across Texas to close. The other, on Nov. 1, compared contraception to a grave moral wrong and sided with businesses that refused to provide it in health care coverage.

title: At Duke, Football Is the New Basketball
description: DURHAM, N.C.  At a university where basketball reigns, the football team is suddenly the talk of campus.

title: Banning the Negative Book Review
description: THE estimable online publication BuzzFeed has changed the rules of critical engagement. All I can say is Bravo!

title: Patience Along the Path to Employment
description: For Victoria Serans-Vidal, 47, patience is not just a virtue; its a way of life.

title: The Almost Year-End Quiz
description: On this weekend after Thanksgiving, its time to see how much you avid readers remember from 2013. No cheating, people!

title: A Forced Adoption, a Lifetime Quest and a Longing That Never Waned
description: LONDON  PHILOMENA LEE is 80 now, and she has made peace with many things. Yet her voice still catches when she describes her last glimpse of her firstborn child as he was being taken away to be adopted by an American family.

title: Statins by Numbers
description: PHILADELPHIA  MEDICINE is having its moneyball moment.

title: In Naming Top Police Official, De Blasio May Signal Change
description: Bill de Blasio had just left the 2011 West Indian American Day parade in Brooklyn when he received an alarming call. Two black leaders he had been marching with, one of them a New York City councilman, had been handcuffed by the police.

title: Matthew Bucksbaum, Mall Developer, Dies at 87
description: Matthew Bucksbaum, who co-founded a family shopping mall empire that helped transform the landscape of suburbia and the habits of American consumers, died on Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 87.

title: For Some Folks, Life Is a Hill
description: I strongly reject the concept of respectability politics, which postulates that a style of dress or speech justifies injustice, and often violence, against particular groups of people or explains away the ravages of their inequality.

title: Mideast Tensions Alarm U.N. Chief
description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, expressed alarm on Friday about what he called the increasingly dangerous situation on the ground in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, fearful that it could threaten the revived peace talks on a two-state solution that have been underway for the past four months. Mr. Ban criticized an escalation of violence and incitement on both sides, including Israeli settlement building, the demolition of Palestinian structures in eastern Jerusalem, and rocket fire and tunneling by Gaza militants into Israel. He said acute financial difficulties at the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which administers aid to millions of Palestinians in Gaza, also had aggravated the situation. We cannot afford to lose the current moment of opportunity, he said.

title: Television Revenue Fuels a Construction Boom in the Pac-12
description: Bill Moos works in sleepy Pullman, Wash., a speck on the map near the Idaho border, but outside, on Washington States campus, it can sound lately more like central Hong Kong. Drills buzz and hammers pound and shovels clank.

title: More Disclosures About Stop-and-Frisk
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg has often defended New York Citys discredited stop-and-frisk program by arguing that it is necessary to cut crime. That claim was never credible; crime declined in cities that did not detain citizens millions of times over the course of the decade, as New York did, often without legitimate reason.

title: Health Care Site Rushing to Make Fixes by Sunday
description: As the Obama administrations weekend deadline for a smoothly functioning online marketplace for health insurance arrives, more than a month of frantic repair work is paying off with fewer crashes and error messages and speedier loading of pages, according to government officials, groups that help people enroll and experts involved in the project.

title: Harry Potters Latest Adventure
description: Can Harry Potters magic lift the sagging fortunes of the United States Postal Service? Thats the 46-cent question posed by the services new first-class Forever stamp  a series of 20 stamps honoring the fictitious British lad and global pop culture icon. The stamps portraying characters and scenes from the best-selling Harry Potter books and movies are a measure of the resolve of the deficit-ridden Postal Service to appeal to consumers cultural preferences to generate revenue.

title: What You Dont Know About Mortgages
description: Thanks largely to new rules from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, taking out a mortgage is not the risky business it was during the bubble. But it is still the largest and most complex financial transaction in the lives of most people. And it still involves inherent imbalances in expertise between lenders and borrowers, including the use of intermediaries who may or may not be trustworthy. In short, conditions for abuse still exist.

title: Desperation in Tibet
description: On Nov. 11, Tsering Gyal, a 20-year-old Tibetan Buddhist monk, set himself on fire in Chinas Qinghai Province. Mr. Gyals death brings the number of Tibetans who have self-immolated since 2009 to 123. Letters some have left and eyewitness accounts of dying words leave no doubt about the cause of these horrible deaths: anguish over Chinese repression.

title: Short on Space, Taiwan Embraces a Boom in Recycling
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Twenty-five miles west of here on Taiwans rugged northwest coast, a cavernous warehouse under construction represents the new priorities for an island where the streets were once littered with piles of discarded electronics and other refuse.

title: On the Line, Giants Boothe Can Play Anywhere
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Justin Pugh was amazed how everyone reacted in the moment. Pugh, a right tackle who was the Giants first-round draft pick in April, noticed that none of his teammates hesitated after center Jim Cordle left Sundays game against the Dallas Cowboys in the second quarter with a knee injury. They all knew who would take Cordles place: Kevin Boothe.

title: Plan to Overhaul Illinoiss Pension System
description: The Illinois legislative leaders plan for an overhaul to the states vastly underfunded pension system.

title: Unions Response to Proposed Overhaul of Illinoiss Pension System
description: A response to the outline of what Illinois lawmakers want to do to pensions from We Are One Illinois, a union coalition.

title: Illinois Gives Plan Details for Bailout of Pensions
description: CHICAGO  Seeking to repair one of the nations worst-financed public pension systems, legislative leaders in Illinois on Friday began urgently trying to sell a rescue plan that cuts cost-of-living increases for retirees, raises the age of retirement for some employees, and sets a cap on pensions for those with the highest salaries.

title: A Place for Dirt Bikers
description: To the Editor:

title: Tale of Two Midwest States
description: To the Editor:

title: Alzheimers Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Rise in Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Confiscated by Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: Common Core and Coddled Kids
At the New Schools New Building, a Sign Isnt Just a Sign
description: Landing someone of Ruedi Baurs stature to develop a wayfinding system for the New Schools new University Center was, in the words of the provost, Tim Marshall, an absolute coup.

title: Securing Help for a Park at Site of Worlds Fairs
description: Julissa Ferreras, a New York City councilwoman, grew up four blocks from Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. It is where she took her first spin on a carousel and learned to ride a bicycle. It is also where, in recent years, her constituents have complained about unkempt fields, potholes, erosion and stagnant lakes.

title: Overcome by Mud
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  If you are a fan of puzzle bylines as I am, you have no doubt noticed that there are some constructors who are capable of making solvers quake in their collective boots. Byron Walden and Brad Wilber are two such constructors, known for their solidly-built grids that are festooned with wonderfully fresh entries and the kinds of arcana that make you just want to jam a pencil in your temple in frustration.

title: In Alabama, the Day of the Big Game (Really Big)
description: Alabama-Auburn is a major game every football season, but this year even more than usual is at stake, including championship hopes on both sides.

title: Close the Store, Its the Years Big Game in Alabama
description: AUBURN, Ala.  The Saturday evening Mass at St. Michael the Archangel Catholic Church here will be a cappella because the organist has football tickets. Weddings and funerals will be rarities. Car dealerships are expected to go dark. The J & M Bookstore will close at kickoff  and reopen after the game only if the home team wins.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 29, 2013
Paul Mayer, 82, Ex-Priest and Peace Activist, Dies
description: Paul Mayer, a Jewish-born former Roman Catholic priest who was at the forefront of peace and social justice campaigns for five decades, for a time working closely with the radical pacifist priests Philip and Daniel Berrigan, died on Nov. 22 at his home in East Orange, N.J. He was 82.

title: Dolan Says Church Is Caricatured as Antigay
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said on Friday that the Roman Catholic Church was being caricatured as being anti-gay, even as he lamented the continued expansion of same-sex marriage in the United States and vowed to keep fighting it.

title: Peter Kaplan, Editor of New York Observer, Dies at 59
description: Peter W. Kaplan, who in his 15 years as editor was credited with making The New York Observer both pertinent and impertinent as it gleefully chronicled the every move and shake of the citys movers and shakers, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 59.

title: Looking Sluggish and Lost, Nets Are Routed by Rockets
description: HOUSTON  The Nets have played some pitiful games this season, but never did four quarters feel like such a formality.

title: Scandal Widens Over Contracts for Navy Work
description: A scandal involving the Navys ship supply network, until now focused on the Pacific Fleet, has spread to another contractor working for Navy ships in the waters off the Middle East, Africa and South America.

title: North Korea Accuses Captive U.S. Veteran of War Crimes
description: HONG KONG  North Korea accused a captive American military veteran of war crimes, saying he was involved in the killing of innocent civilians during the Korean War, state news media reported on Saturday.

title: For Sacred Heart, Patience Has Rewards
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  Gordon Hill is not used to spending Thanksgiving preparing for a football game.

title: Rare Books Vanish, With a Librarian in the Plot
description: NAPLES  It was one of the most dramatic thefts ever to hit the rare-book world, the disappearance of thousands of volumes  including centuries-old editions of Aristotle, Descartes, Galileo and Machiavelli  from the Baroque-era Girolamini Library in Naples. Now, prosecutors at a trial here are trying to show how such a wholesale violation of Western cultural patrimony could have taken place.

title: Al Plastino, 91, Dies; Drew Many Superheroes
description: In the heyday of Superman comic books  the late 1940s through the 1960s  Al Plastino drew scores of issues, earning $50 per page as a freelancer for the publisher that became known as DC Comics. In the late 50s he helped create new characters, including Supergirl, and the Legion of Super-Heroes, and he drew the syndicated Superman and Batman newspaper strips.

title: Experience Lifts Arizona Against Duke
description: It was billed as a matchup between Dukes Jabari Parker and Arizonas Aaron Gordon, top prospects on top teams meeting in a sort of preamble to a rivalry between budding talents.

title: Part II: Adam Minter on Chinas Scrap Trade and the Environment
description: In his new book Junkyard Planet: Travels in the Billion-Dollar Trash Trade (Bloomsbury Press), Adam Minter paints a Dickensian portrait of Chinas massive garbage and recycling dumps. And then he tells us why theyre so vital to the environmental movement.

title: Back in Denver, Anthony Is Booed as Knicks Lose
description: DENVER  The fans at the Pepsi Center booed Carmelo Anthony during pregame introductions. They booed him when he brought the ball up the court. They booed nearly every move he made on Friday night, with the notable exception of his missed shots. The crowd loved those.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) BEAUTIFUL CREATURES (2013) Ethan (Alden Ehrenreich), an almost-too-good-to-be-true high school boy despairing of his conservative South Carolina existence, meets his dream girl, Lena (Alice Englert), when her family of witches moves to town, and its kind of like Romeo and Juliet, but, like you know, happier, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this pop Southern Gothic amusement about teenage love and other powerful magic. Lena has some spooky relatives, including her Uncle Macon (Jeremy Irons) and cousin Ridley (Emmy Rossum). Ethan comes with a nanny, Amma (Viola Davis, above left, with Ms. Englert and Mr. Ehrenreich). Beautiful Creatures, its sweet young things and supernatural shenanigans have been marshaled to help fill the box office void left by the end of the Harry Potter and Twilight franchises, Ms. Dargis said of this adaptation of Kami Garcia and Margaret Stohls book. Its a void that The Hunger Games has already started to fill, partly by tapping into deeply American themes and giving them thrilling female form. Beautiful Creatures has been spun from thinner material, despite its strong female characters, nods at the Civil War and a story that turns on good versus evil, a fight that  as in many young adult stories  is somewhat mirrored in the struggle between the high school herd and the individual. Theres not much new under the moon here, which makes what the writer and director Richard LaGravenese does with the story all the more notable.

title: From Todays Paper: Funeral for a Teenage Morsi Supporter
description: Mourners on Friday carried the coffin of a 19-year-old student killed Thursday during a demonstration at Cairo University, as security forces using shotgun pellets continued their crackdown on supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted Egyptian president.

title: From Todays Paper: Anger Over Ukraines Rejection of Pacts
description: The riot police in Kiev, Ukraine, blocked protesters who supported more cooperation with the European Union.

title: North Korea Releases a Video of a U.S. Veteran Confessing to Hostile Acts
description: BEIJING  North Korea has accused an American veteran of war crimes and on Saturday released a video of him confessing to what it said were hostile acts during the Korean War and while he was visiting the country in October.

title: Police Helicopter Crashes Into Crowded Glasgow Pub
description: LONDON  Eight people were killed when a police helicopter that apparently lost power crashed through the roof of a crowded pub in Glasgow, injuring at least 30 people, police officials saidSaturday.

title: Ukrainians Back in Street to Support E.U. Accord
description: KIEV, Ukraine  After the police violently dispersed several hundred protesters in the center of this roiled capital early Saturday, thousands more took to the streets to denounce President Viktor F. Yanukovichs refusal to sign far-reaching political and free-trade accords with the European Union.

title: Letters to the Editor: On Columbia and Failures in Football
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Pixi Lip Blush
description: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

title: More Luxury Hotels Open in China
description: Updated, 10:50 a.m. | China is experiencing a boom in luxury hotels, and not just in major cities like Shanghai and Beijing  evidence that finer amenities and a touch of Western comfort are becoming more important to the countrys growing number of domestic tourists as well as to international visitors.

title: 1963: False Real-Hair Mustache Speeds Youths to Manhood
description: PARIS  A dandy business is being done these days at le Drug Store in moustaches postiches. It was bound to come, as a natural order of events. If she has a wig, why shouldnt he have a little something extra too?

title: In the Halfpipe With David Wise, the Undude
description: RENO, Nev.  The light from the Monster Energy refrigerator, squatting on the floor below the framed wedding photographs and X Games gold medals, cast a steady glow in the living room. The Smith Optics sunglasses come in handy in the high-desert autumn sun, just as they will in the snow-blinding mountains of winter. Pairs of 4Frnt skis stood in various corners of the house, awaiting deployment.

title: Healing With His Hands
description: Manny Granillo, 59, has been a massage therapist at Miraval Resort and Spa in Tucson for nine years.

title: Variety: An Educational Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  SARAH VOWELL, who has one of the best names in the universe for a book with the word WORDY in the title, is an essayist and self-styled social observer who has been a contributing editor to NPRs This American Life. She has also written a number of nonfiction books on American history and culture, although in many of them (including this one), she wanders off into anecdotes about her own life, politics and her apartment in New York City.

title: A Founder Who Cant Let Go
description: Dear Workologist:

title: Inside the Race to Rescue a Health Care Site, and Obama
description: WASHINGTON  As a small coterie of grim-faced advisers shuffled into the Oval Office on the evening of Oct. 15, President Obamas chief domestic accomplishment was falling apart 24 miles away, at a bustling high-tech data center in suburban Virginia.

title: Arkansas Follows Fashion, and the Money, Out of Its Home Away From Home
description: As major college football teams look for ways to draw more money, more exposure and better recruits, they seem to have little use for certain traditions. Home-away-from-home games, which flourished before cable television as a way for programs to reach larger audiences, are vanishing.

title: Japan Takes Airspace Issue to U.N. Agency
description: NIIGATA, Japan  Seeking broader international support for opposing Chinas claims to airspace over the East China Sea, Japan has asked the United Nations agency that oversees civil aviation to look into whether the newly created Chinese air defense zone could endanger civilian airliners, the Foreign Ministry said Saturday.

title: Climate Casino: An Overview of Global Warming
description: Ive long looked at global warming as a worthy topic that I should try to wrap my mind around. Although I knew I needed to dig deeper, I never truly understood why.

title: When Algorithms Grow Accustomed to Your Face
description: People often reveal their private emotions in tiny, fleeting facial expressions, visible only to a best friend  or to a skilled poker player. Now, computer software is using frame-by-frame video analysis to read subtle muscular changes that flash across our faces in milliseconds, signaling emotions like happiness, sadness and disgust.

title: Confronting the Health Insurance Exchanges Problems
description: A look back at how White House advisers have tried to fix the botched health care website.

title: Jennifer Dulski of Change.org, on Problem-Solving
description: This interview with  Jennifer Dulski, president and chief operating officer of Change.org, a web platform for social change, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Afghans Assail Karzais Disparate Views on Killings
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As so often happens in the fog of war, the attack in a village in Kandahar on Friday missed the enemy patrol that was its intended target, instead killing an 8-year-old boy and wounding two other children.
